-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3158
Sender:Alex Bould <alex.bould-rest@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-03 02:04:31
Subject:FYI - OASIS TC for extensible resource identifiers
Message:

http://lists.oasis-open.org/archives/members/200212/msg00002.html

<snip>
The TC will also define an XML schema to associate metadata with
resources and a service to manipulate this metadata and data associated
with the resources. Specifically, this service will reflect the simple
transactional nature of the WWW, i.e., it will use a small set of REST
(Representational State Transfer) or CRUD-like operators on an
infinitely extensible set of XRI-addressable resources.  This data
exchange service will provide a platform for integration with
directory-related specifications such as LDAP, DSML, and SPML.
</snip>


-- alex





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3159
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-03 03:18:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] FYI - OASIS TC for extensible resource identifiers
Message:

Yah, I've talked with Gabe Wachod about this, who's gone out of his way
to be accomodating of my views.  He may be fuzzy on the technical side,
but he's very aware of the tension.  IIRC, he said they'd remove the
REST reference.

I think we can safely ignore this group.  It seems like they exist to
rubber stamp XNS, which IMO doesn't stand a chance of getting deployed.

MB

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3162
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 04:37:55
Subject:ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

I am trying to figure out how to create a ReST
interface to a mailfolder.

Initially, I figured I could simply POST messages
and have them appended to the mailfolder and then
GET with range-headers to see if anyone has added
anything new since the last time I checked the
folder.

The problem I have is that I want to permit the
server to move attachments to other URIs,
modifying the messages in accord with RFC2017 to
have:

content-type: message/external-body; access-type=URL;
	url="http://location/of/attachment"

So, depending on the constraints on the server at
that moment, the size/shape of the mailfolder file
will change drastically.

Note: The server may move only some attachments to
external URLs so I don't think I can rely on
content-negotiation to solve this problem.  Note
also that even if I force all attachments to be
external-URLs, I still want the server to be able
to change those locations unilaterally.

Any thoughts on how to solve this without forcing
the client to GET the entire folder each time?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3163
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 06:51:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

> I am trying to figure out how to create a ReST
> interface to a mailfolder.
>
> Initially, I figured I could simply POST messages
> and have them appended to the mailfolder and then
> GET with range-headers to see if anyone has added
> anything new since the last time I checked the
> folder.
When you GET, is the response a list of current messages or the actual
content of the messages?
I'd go with a list of messages & use last-modified/if-modified-since, etc.
to check for new messages.


> Any thoughts on how to solve this without forcing
> the client to GET the entire folder each time?
Get a collection of references to messages, each with a little metadata.
Retrieve content with later requests.


-- ask for snapshot of inbox, providing username/password --
GET /pop/user-99/inbox/ HTTP/1.1
Authentication: Basic WZYSHS=

-- snapshot of inbox --
Content-Type: text/xml

<folder>
 <item href='/pop/user-99/msgs/msg1024' from='joe@...' />
</folder>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3164
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 17:41:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

Perhaps I wasn't clear.  There may be a large
number of messages and, ideally, I only want the
client to retrieve new messages.

Again, my initial instinct here was that I could
use range-headers (because the mailbox only
grows), but, even if I just return metadata, I
want to give the server the option of moving the
actual messages to different URLs.

Unfortunately, there is no guarantee that the new
URL will have the same length as the old.  So
changing all the URLs in the folder could
radically change its length, thereby precluding
use of range headers to get new messages.

Does this make sense now?

-Alex-

PS I really want the server to be able to choose
on a per-message basis whether to return the
whole message or simply a URL but URL changes
illustrate my pount sufficiently well.

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3165
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 19:17:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

A couple thoughts:

1) Use HEAD to determine if the contents have changed.  This keeps you from
having to get the entire resource.

2) There is nothing in REST that says the URI must identify a specific
directory location.  As a result, you could create the necessary URIs up
front and just keep an internal map to the actual location.  If the server
wants to move an attachment, it just needs to update the map.  The URI will
still "point to"  the attachment (i.e. the resource/representation isn't any
different).  If you are doing this across multiple web servers, you could
also use the map table to instead return an appropriate HTTP 301 "Moved
Permanently" or 302 "Found" to redirect the client to the actual URI.

3) I am uneasy about the range feature of HTTP.  It doesn't feel very
extensible to me (e.g. if you message format changed, range calculations
would have to change as well).

4) (this is more of a question to the whole list) Would it be RESTful to
maintain a resource whose response to a GET only contained the new items?
For instance, suppose after each successful GET of a mail message, the
client were to POST the URI to this resource.  On a GET of this resource,
the server would return all message URIs for which it had not been notified
of by the POST(s).  This technique would also obviate the need for the HTTP
range technique.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Post ID:3166
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 19:46:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

On Mon, 6 Jan 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> 1) Use HEAD to determine if the contents have changed.  This keeps you from
> having to get the entire resource.

No doubt the contents have changed.  The issue is
that since I know the contents simply grow, if I
prohibited the server from changing URLs, I could
retrieve only the new messages by using range
headers to retrieve all content beyond the
content-length I have received so far.

The problem here is how to retrieve only the new
messages if the length of old messages changes
(perhaps because of changes in the length of the
URLs to which the metadata points).

> 2) There is nothing in REST that says the URI must identify a specific
> directory location.  As a result, you could create the necessary URIs up
> front and just keep an internal map to the actual location.  If the server
> wants to move an attachment, it just needs to update the map.  The URI will
> still "point to"  the attachment (i.e. the resource/representation isn't any
> different).  If you are doing this across multiple web servers, you could
> also use the map table to instead return an appropriate HTTP 301 "Moved
> Permanently" or 302 "Found" to redirect the client to the actual URI.

I'm not sure I understand what you mean.  I
suppose I could commit to a metadata format that
does not actually include the actual URL but
intead includes the URL of a redirect to the
actual URL, but that doubles server round trips
and I would like to avoid that as well.

> 3) I am uneasy about the range feature of HTTP.  It doesn't feel very
> extensible to me (e.g. if you message format changed, range calculations
> would have to change as well).

Yes, that is exactly why range headers don't
appear to be an answer to the question I am
asking.

> 4) (this is more of a question to the whole list) Would it be RESTful to
> maintain a resource whose response to a GET only contained the new items?
> For instance, suppose after each successful GET of a mail message, the
> client were to POST the URI to this resource.  On a GET of this resource,
> the server would return all message URIs for which it had not been notified
> of by the POST(s).  This technique would also obviate the need for the HTTP
> range technique.

Hmm, this looks interesting.  A variant of this
proposal would be for the server to return the URL
at which it will serve the next set of messages
even if those messages don't yet exist... I'm not
sure how RESTful that would be either.

-Alex-

Post ID:3167
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 19:32:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

> Does this make sense now?

Not really.  An HTTP server's URI-space has nothing whatsoever to do
with its storage space, aside from that created by the handlers within
that space.  In other words, what you name the URIs and how the messages
are extracted from relevant storage is defined entirely by the handler
you write for the URIs.  See mod_mbox, for example.

     http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/httpd-mbox/

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3168
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 20:11:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> On Mon, 6 Jan 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> > 2) There is nothing in REST that says the URI must identify a specific
> > directory location.  As a result, you could create the necessary URIs up
> > front and just keep an internal map to the actual location.  If the
server
> > wants to move an attachment, it just needs to update the map.  The URI
will
> > still "point to"  the attachment (i.e. the resource/representation isn't
any
> > different).  If you are doing this across multiple web servers, you
could
> > also use the map table to instead return an appropriate HTTP 301 "Moved
> > Permanently" or 302 "Found" to redirect the client to the actual URI.
>
> I'm not sure I understand what you mean.  I
> suppose I could commit to a metadata format that
> does not actually include the actual URL but
> intead includes the URL of a redirect to the
> actual URL, but that doubles server round trips
> and I would like to avoid that as well.

You would only need to use the redirection if you do not have direct access
to the attachment location.  However, if you do, then imagine the following:

A message is posted with one attachment.  The URI created for that one
attachment is:

    http://www.sample.invalid/mail/attachments/1032

Now, conventional "static" servers would have the particular path mapped to
a folder such as:

c:\inetput\wwwroot\mail\attachments\1032

However, the above path could also just be treated as a key into a map/table
that pointed to the actual directory location:

key        path
1030      d:\extraspace\1030\
1031      d:\extraspace\1031\
1032      \\remoteserver\data\attachments\45\
1033      \\removeserver\data\attachments\72\

Now, when someone does a GET on the above URI, you see where the server has
mapped the path to (in this case "\\remoteserver\data\attachments\45\") and
return the file(s) from there.  No redirections needed.  As Roy mentioned in
his reply, there is nothing in HTTP or REST that requires URI paths to match
directory paths.  That's an implementation feature of most web servers, but
just because it's a convenience for handling static resources.  Nothing in
the books says this is required...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...




> > 3) I am uneasy about the range feature of HTTP.  It doesn't feel very
> > extensible to me (e.g. if you message format changed, range calculations

> appear to be an answer to the question I am

HTTP

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3169
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-06 20:12:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

> see if anyone has added anything new since
> the last time I checked the folder.
If 'checking' is both safe and idempotent, you will have to explicitly mark
messages as being viewed/processed/whatever.
You could do this many ways - send a 'mark all inbox items', send a list of
items to mark, assign URIs to each item & mark each inbox item, etc..

> Any thoughts on how to solve this without forcing
> the client to GET the entire folder each time?
If you mark items as being processed, this can move them to a separate
collection - the 'viewed' list or the 'deleted' list or whatever.
Then when you check for new messages, the 'inbox' list will be empty when
there are no new messages.
You will always need to check periodically, but the response can be empty
which cuts down on data transfer.

I think this is similar to the 'model a message queue with HTTP' discussion
of a few months ago....





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3170
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 05:53:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

I think I have figured out how to do this in a way
that allows the server to move attachments to URLs
on other servers on an ad-hoc basis and that does
not require servers to maintain current view-state
for every client.  Please tell me if this solution
is too HTTP abusive.

Initially, the client makes a simple GET request
to the URL of the mailfolder.  The server returns:

  200 OK
  Content-Type: multipart/digest; boundary="abc"
  Etag: my-etag

Now, if the client want to receive only what has
changed since my-etag, it sends:

  GET /folder/url HTTP/1.1
  If-None-Match: my-etag
  Accept: multipart/byteranges

The question is whether the server is now allowed
to send a multipart/byteranges response.  RFC2616
prohibits a 206 response if the client did not
explicitly make a range request, but I think the
semantics of content negotiation would certainly
allow the server to make a 200 response with
partial content if it so desired.

What I would really like to do is have the server
return a content-range header with a
multipart/digest response.  Is there a way I can
make that legal in response to a request with a
"accept-content-range" header?

Any thoughts?

-Alex-



___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3171
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 06:36:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

> Please tell me if this solution is too HTTP abusive.
I don't think it's abusive, but I think you are trying to do too much with
HTTP.


> Now, if the client want to receive only what has
> changed since my-etag, it sends:
>
>   GET /folder/url HTTP/1.1
>   If-None-Match: my-etag
>   Accept: multipart/byteranges

Why don't you just use a query term like 'received-since' to indicate what
set of inbox messages you are talking about?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3173
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 16:12:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

Using something like "receive-since" (I am assuming a timestamp here) means
that you have to keep track of the time differences between the client and
server, since you need to query the server according to its own time, not
the clients.

I think you would do better to have an "inbox" URI, which only contains new
messages.  Once you have received a specific message (indicated via the
inbox), POST its URI to the URI of the mail resource you want it to be put
in:

POST /mail/trash

http://sample.invalid/mail/inbox/0013


This would remove the link from the inbox and place it in the "trash".  Of
course, you could always just DELETE the URI directly if you were done with
it.

At any rate, all you would ever have to do to check for mail would be to
"GET /mail/inbox".

Simple and clean... I think.  :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, January 07, 2003 10:31 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes

> unRESTful?
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3174
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 16:44:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

If you accepted receive-since, you could always
refer to a particular message-id.  I just think
either version violates the opacity of URLs.

The problem with using POST or DELETE is that the
server now has to maintain read state for each
client and you now have an administrative process
each time you add a client.

-Alex-

On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> Using something like "receive-since" (I am assuming a timestamp here) means
> that you have to keep track of the time differences between the client and
> server, since you need to query the server according to its own time, not
> the clients.
>
> I think you would do better to have an "inbox" URI, which only contains new
> messages.  Once you have received a specific message (indicated via the
> inbox), POST its URI to the URI of the mail resource you want it to be put
> in:
>
> POST /mail/trash
>
> http://sample.invalid/mail/inbox/0013
>
>
> This would remove the link from the inbox and place it in the "trash".  Of
> course, you could always just DELETE the URI directly if you were done with
> it.

> At any rate, all you would ever have to do to check for mail would be to
> "GET /mail/inbox".

Post ID:3176
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 16:56:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

Each client checks mail at different times so each
client has a different set of messages it has read
and messages it has not yet read.

If the client changes the state of the server to
differentiate between the two then the server
needs to maintain state for each client.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3177
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 17:29:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>


> Isn't adding a query term "received-since" unRESTful?
I don't think so. But I am not bothered by constructing URIs on the client.

Also, I meant 'modified-since' - I mis-edited the paragraph before sending
it. It is intended to represent a resource that is a list of items that have
been modified since a certain time.

If I understand what you are trying to do, you have a single resource with a
list of messages. The content of the response may change somewhere in the
middle - e.g. the href attribute of the fifth item.
You would like to talk to this same resource, yet receive only those
portions (or items) that have changed since some previous response,
indicated by either eTag or last-modified or something.
The change to the resource isn't that a new message has arrived - you can
use the 'mark and move' approach to clean out the inbox for that - but that
the storage location of attachments has changed.

If you have multiple collections of messages, then each collection of
messages probably needs to support this 'list only changed items since xyz'
capability.

I can't help but think that using byte-range is fragile - deltas on dynamic
content seems problematic. I'd recommend a content format that is more
suited to having the client merge updates to a list of items.


Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3178
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 17:39:39
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>


> Using something like "receive-since" (I am assuming a timestamp here)
means
> that you have to keep track of the time differences between the client and
> server, since you need to query the server according to its own time, not
> the clients.
There a Last-Modified response header that should work.

>
> I think you would do better to have an "inbox" URI, which only contains
new
> messages.  Once you have received a specific message (indicated via the
> inbox), POST its URI to the URI of the mail resource you want it to be put
> in:
I think this is a good approach for managing the messages, notifying that
they were processed, etc.
But I think the problem S. Alexander is trying to solve has to do with
metadata changing on a listing of items - and getting a list of just the
changed items.

Using a header like If-Modified-Since or If-None-Match doesn't change what
the resource represents - I don't think they can be used to filter out
unmodified items in a list. I think you need to have separate resources to
do the filtering





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3179
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 18:20:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

Isn't the whole point of REST that URIs should be
opaque when describing a web service?

Regarding what I am trying to do, I want to expose
a mailfolder via HTTP.  Three things may happen
to this mailfolder:

* The server may choose to move attachments to
   external URLs
* The server may change those external URLs
* New messages may be added to the folder
Note: Messages will not be deleted from the folder.

I want clients:
1. to be able to rertrieve the entire folder
2. to be able to retreive only messages that have
   been added to the folder without retrieving
   already received messages whose representations
   have changed

I would like to have a large number of anonymous
clients so I don't want to force the server to
maintain a state for each client (as required by
'mark and move' servers).

My proposed solution is to return
multipart/byteranges as a response to queries with
etags.  I suppose I could also return any diff
format, but I'm not aware of one that is
particularly better suited to this problem than
multipart/byteranges.

Is the consensus that this is HTTP-OK, and if so
what is the correct status code to return?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax



On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, S. Mike Dierken wrote:

>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
>
> > Isn't adding a query term "received-since" unRESTful?
> I don't think so. But I am not bothered by constructing URIs on the client.
>
> Also, I meant 'modified-since' - I mis-edited the paragraph before sending
> it. It is intended to represent a resource that is a list of items that have
> been modified since a certain time.
>
> If I understand what you are trying to do, you have a single resource with a
> list of messages. The content of the response may change somewhere in the
> middle - e.g. the href attribute of the fifth item.
> You would like to talk to this same resource, yet receive only those
> portions (or items) that have changed since some previous response,
> indicated by either eTag or last-modified or something.
> The change to the resource isn't that a new message has arrived - you can
> use the 'mark and move' approach to clean out the inbox for that - but that
> the storage location of attachments has changed.
>
> If you have multiple collections of messages, then each collection of
> messages probably needs to support this 'list only changed items since xyz'
> capability.
>
> I can't help but think that using byte-range is fragile - deltas on dynamic
> content seems problematic. I'd recommend a content format that is more
> suited to having the client merge updates to a list of items.
>
>
> Mike

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3180
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-07 22:57:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

>
> I want clients:
> 1. to be able to rertrieve the entire folder
> 2. to be able to retreive only messages that have
>    been added to the folder without retrieving
>    already received messages whose representations
>    have changed
So for #2 you want 'all messages I haven't seen', regardless whether there
are messages that have been seen and modified (with updated URL to
attachments)? I thought you /did/ want to see messages that have changed,
even though they are old messages.


> My proposed solution is to return
> multipart/byteranges as a response to queries with
> etags.
It seems like you are trying to use a single logical resource to do both
these tasks, and it may be much easier if you use two or more resources.

I don't know if it is 'correct' to use the same URI but different ETags to
achieve different representations. Perhaps it is, and this might be an
elegant way of doing it.

> I suppose I could also return any diff
> format, but I'm not aware of one that is
> particularly better suited to this problem than
> multipart/byteranges.
Like I said, binary deltas bother me - I'd go with record based deltas,
rather than byte index based.
You may run into problems with versioning between client and server. The
byte range for older version may not be compatible with newer versions,
whereas record based is easier to consume.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3181
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-08 00:08:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST and Representing Mailboxes
Message:

On Tuesday, January 7, 2003, at 10:20  AM, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> Isn't the whole point of REST that URIs should be
> opaque when describing a web service?

No, the point of REST is to model a Web service.  It wouldn't be 
complete
if it neglected to include query parameters.  However, it works best 
when
query parameters are only used read-only and result in a list of
metadata and specific resource identifiers.  You can then do more 
complex
operations on those identifiers.

> Regarding what I am trying to do, I want to expose
> a mailfolder via HTTP.  Three things may happen
> to this mailfolder:
>
> * The server may choose to move attachments to
>    external URLs
> * The server may change those external URLs
> * New messages may be added to the folder
> Note: Messages will not be deleted from the folder.
>
> I want clients:
> 1. to be able to rertrieve the entire folder
> 2. to be able to retreive only messages that have
>    been added to the folder without retrieving
>    already received messages whose representations
>    have changed
>
> I would like to have a large number of anonymous
> clients so I don't want to force the server to
> maintain a state for each client (as required by
> 'mark and move' servers).

So, you are talking netnews, not mail.  That means the client has to
keep a list of read messages, not the server, and the list should be
by ordered number (the easiest choice given what you describe and
how all news readers work).

> My proposed solution is to return
> multipart/byteranges as a response to queries with
> etags.  I suppose I could also return any diff
> format, but I'm not aware of one that is
> particularly better suited to this problem than
> multipart/byteranges.
>
> Is the consensus that this is HTTP-OK, and if so
> what is the correct status code to return?

No, it is not HTTP okay because you allow the server to change the
file.  Neither etag nor byteranges will work.  In any case, this design
would tie the client implementation to the server storage 
implementation,
which is just a bad idea in general.  You should separate the two and
think of each message as a resource within a collection (the mailbox).
The client will then have to remember what has been read if they
wish to selectively retrieve messages.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3182
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-08 17:55:12
Subject:ANN: Document on REST, Quixote, etc
Message:

As a learning process, I've implemented several trivial examples of
RESTful applications on top of Quixote.

I've also written up a document that explains the examples.  There
is also some commentary about doing REST with Quixote and
AOLserver/PyWX (PyWX provides access to AOLserver's API) and about
how this is "a good thing".  It's pretty elementary stuff.  But, it
might be useful to someone new to Quixote and REST.

You can find this document and the source code for the examples at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/#aolserver
    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/rest_howto.html

Comments and suggestions and corrections are welcome. (code words
for: Please help me improve this document.)

  - Dave


-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3183
Sender:"Josh_Knowles <josh.knowles@...>" <josh.knowles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-08 20:37:36
Subject:POST vs. PUT
Message:

Ok so I have read through all the Wiki pages but still have a 
question on when to use POST vs. PUT.  I am going to post a few 
scenerios and what I think the correct behavior should be and would 
like some help on whether or not I am understanding things correctly.

Lets say I have an address book which contains contacts stored using 
a server defined ID.  Each contact contains a name, phone number and 
email address.

Adding a new contact (I belive this is correct):

POST new contact to /addressbook, server returns 201 along with the 
URI of the new contact.

Modify a contact (This is where I need help):

I want to modify only the name for the resource located 
at /addressbook/000001, do I POST the changes to the name or do I 
PUT them.  Also, do I need to PUT the entire record or just the 
changes?

Thanks for the help,

Josh





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3184
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-08 20:52:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] POST vs. PUT
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: <josh.knowles@...>

>
> I want to modify only the name for the resource located
> at /addressbook/000001, do I POST the changes to the name or do I
> PUT them.  Also, do I need to PUT the entire record or just the
> changes?

If you use PUT you need to send the complete data for the resource - which I
think is messed up in the protocol but I'm not a protocol guy (there are
reasons like caching,etc that may require this behavior).
So, use PUT to do a 'partial update' of a resource. You could also define a
more fine-grained resource and PUT to that...

-- option 1 : partial update via POST --
POST /addressbook/0001 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml
Content-Length: nnnn

<contact>
 <name>bob</name>
 <phone>425-555-1212</phone>
 <email>bob@...</email>
</contact>


-- option 2 : fine-grained update via PUT --
PUT /addressbook/0001;email HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml
Content-Length: nnnn

<email>bob@...</email>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3185
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-08 20:56:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] POST vs. PUT
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>

> So, use PUT to do a 'partial update' of a resource. You could also define
a
> more fine-grained resource and PUT to that...

Auugh... I mean use POST to do a 'partial update'....

Thanks Mike that helps, one question though.  You say, "So, use PUT to
do a 'partial update' of a resource".  Did you mean to say POST because
this contradicts your first sentence where you say you have to send the
complete data when using PUT.
 
Josh

	-----Original Message-----

	> at /addressbook/000001, do I POST the changes to the name or

	> PUT them.  Also, do I need to PUT the entire record or just
the
	> changes?
	
	If you use PUT you need to send the complete data for the
resource - which I
	think is messed up in the protocol but I'm not a protocol guy
(there are
	reasons like caching,etc that may require this behavior).
	So, use PUT to do a 'partial update' of a resource. You could
also define a
	more fine-grained resource and PUT to that...
	
	-- option 1 : partial update via POST --
	POST /addressbook/0001 HTTP/1.1
	Content-Type: text/xml
	Content-Length: nnnn
	
	<contact>
	<name>bob</name>
	<phone>425-555-1212</phone>
	<email>bob@...</email>
	</contact>
	
	
	-- option 2 : fine-grained update via PUT --
	PUT /addressbook/0001;email HTTP/1.1
	Content-Type: text/xml
	Content-Length: nnnn
	
	<email>bob@...</email>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3187
Sender:Gary Shea <shea@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 06:31:14
Subject:Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

Hi --

I'm building a simple order management web service which allows an
order app in the field to submit orders, allows factory-side apps
to access orders by order number, allows factory-side apps to access
the set of unseen orders directly, and allows a factory-side app
to mark an order as seen.

I envision having a top-level uri for the service which returns a
document containing the uris needed to use the service.  The uris would
be something like

    <order-service-uris>
	<submit uri="/orders" />
	<get-order-by-number uri="/order-numbers" />
	<get-new-orders uri="/new-orders" />
    </order-service-uris>

To submit an order, the client POSTs the order to /orders.

To find an order by order number, the client does a GET on
/order-numbers, which returns a page of metadata, like for instance:

    <orders>
	<ranges>
	    <range begin="375" end="399" uri="/db/1201" />
	    <range begin="400" end="424" uri="/db/14287" />
	</ranges>
	<singleton number="425" uri="/db/1798" />
	<singleton number="426" uri="/db/1855" />
    </orders>

I see the singletons as necessary because a partial range uri must be
kept forever in case someone cached it, yuck.  This way, when a range is
complete, it is allocated a permanent uri; until then it is returned as
a collection of singletons.

To get the list of unseen orders, the client does a GET on
/new-orders, which returns a page of metadata like the above except it's
all singletons.  The uris distributed through /order-numbers and
/new-orders are different for any given order, and:

To mark an order seen, the client does a DELETE on the uri acquired from
/new-orders.

Does this seem like a ReSTful interface?  All nitpicking is welcome, I'm
still trying to internalize Roy Fielding's dissertation and the comments
I've read here over the last month or so.

Regards,

Gary Shea
shea@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3188
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 17:48:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>

This looks good overall.

> To find an order by order number, the client does a GET on
> /order-numbers, which returns a page of metadata, like for instance:
>
>     <orders>
> <ranges>
>     <range begin="375" end="399" uri="/db/1201" />
>     <range begin="400" end="424" uri="/db/14287" />
> </ranges>
> <singleton number="425" uri="/db/1798" />
> <singleton number="426" uri="/db/1855" />
>     </orders>
I'm not clear on what the begin/end range means - could you explain?
Is an individual order addressable?

>
> I see the singletons as necessary because a partial range uri must be
> kept forever in case someone cached it, yuck.  This way, when a range is
> complete, it is allocated a permanent uri; until then it is returned as
> a collection of singletons.

>
> To mark an order seen, the client does a DELETE on the uri acquired from
> /new-orders.
I while ago there was some discussion about acknowledging messages or
marking a resource as being processed in some way - there was a comparison
between DELETE and POST with a body of 'status=seen'. I think the end result
was that if there are multiple status values (ready, locked, finished, etc.)
then you would POST the status (or PUT to a more detailed URI). If the
existence of the resource is all the indication needed, then DELETE probably
will work fine. Since you have two distinct URIs for 'new-orders' and
'acknowledged orders' - deleting the one resource merely removes the
relationship that the order is 'new' (or however you want to think of it)
rather than deleting the order itself.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3189
Sender:Gary Shea <shea@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 18:34:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

Hi --

Thanks for taking the time to comment.  See inline...


On Thu, 9 Jan 2003, at 09:48 [-0800], S. Mike Dierken (mdierken@......:

>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>
>
> This looks good overall.


>
> > To find an order by order number, the client does a GET on
> > /order-numbers, which returns a page of metadata, like for instance:
> >
> >     <orders>
> > <ranges>
> >     <range begin="375" end="399" uri="/db/1201" />
> >     <range begin="400" end="424" uri="/db/14287" />
> > </ranges>
> > <singleton number="425" uri="/db/1798" />
> > <singleton number="426" uri="/db/1855" />
> >     </orders>
> I'm not clear on what the begin/end range means - could you explain?
> Is an individual order addressable?

Sorry, I could have been more clear.

An individual order is addressable.  The idea was to find an individual
order by traversing an n-ary tree of uris.  Inner nodes of the tree map
a range of order numbers to a child node of the tree.  The desired
order's uri would be found in a leaf of the tree.

I took this (baroque?) approach because the uri /order/by-number/2275 is
so not opaque!  It felt more ReSTful to act like a browser and follow
a chain of links to get where I needed to go.  The performance cost is
not likely to be significant, given the predicted order load.  Plus,
if the process that traverses the tree has any kind of lifetime, it can
cache everything, as none of the links change.

Too weird?

>
> >
> > I see the singletons as necessary because a partial range uri must be
> > kept forever in case someone cached it, yuck.  This way, when a range is
> > complete, it is allocated a permanent uri; until then it is returned as
> > a collection of singletons.
>
> >
> > To mark an order seen, the client does a DELETE on the uri acquired from
> > /new-orders.
> I while ago there was some discussion about acknowledging messages or
> marking a resource as being processed in some way - there was a comparison
> between DELETE and POST with a body of 'status=seen'. I think the end result
> was that if there are multiple status values (ready, locked, finished, etc.)
> then you would POST the status (or PUT to a more detailed URI). If the
> existence of the resource is all the indication needed, then DELETE probably
> will work fine. Since you have two distinct URIs for 'new-orders' and
> 'acknowledged orders' - deleting the one resource merely removes the
> relationship that the order is 'new' (or however you want to think of it)
> rather than deleting the order itself.

That makes sense.  One of the next steps will be associating a status
with each order so this is very relevant!  Using POST as you describe
sounds like the way to go for updating the order status.  If I think of
NOT_SEEN as the initial status, I could use the POST as you describe to
set the status to SEEN.  So if the order is located at /order/2345,
I could post to /order/2345/status, for instance.

Regards,

	Gary Shea
	shea@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3190
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 18:57:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

one clarification below...

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>
>
> I took this (baroque?) approach because the uri /order/by-number/2275 is
> so not opaque!

Your choice to use one URI over another doesn't indicate whether the URI is
opaque or not.  It's a matter of whether the client attempts to treat it as
anything more than an identifier or not that determines whether it's opaque.
A RESTful client treats *all* URIs as opaque (though there has been some
blurring of that stance lately, it seems).

I think the common confusion about opacity is whether it's perceived as
"human understandable" or not.  The path you give could certainly be
interpreted by a human beyond "it's an identifier", even though it
shouldn't.  Suppose instead that you were to have used the path /19394BC3EA.
At first blush, one might say this URI is "more opaque".  However, it is no
more opaque than your example above if the client knows attempts to
interpret it (e.g. knows the encoding scheme you use) beyond "it's an
identifier".  It is certainly less "human understandable", but that doesn't
necessarily make it more opaque.

If security is an issue, then remember that using /19394BC3EA instead of
/order/by-number/2275 is only "security by obscurity", which not the way to
go.  So... why give up a particular format that makes development easier?
You don't gain anything by it, IMHO.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3191
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 19:15:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>

> An individual order is addressable.  The idea was to find an individual
> order by traversing an n-ary tree of uris.  Inner nodes of the tree map
> a range of order numbers to a child node of the tree.  The desired
> order's uri would be found in a leaf of the tree.
>
> I took this (baroque?) approach because the uri /order/by-number/2275 is
> so not opaque!  It felt more ReSTful to act like a browser and follow
> a chain of links to get where I needed to go.  The performance cost is
> not likely to be significant, given the predicted order load.  Plus,
> if the process that traverses the tree has any kind of lifetime, it can
> cache everything, as none of the links change.
>
> Too weird?

Not weird. Sounds very hypertextual. I'm not sold on that being the best
approach though.
My reasoning is that the client needs to know the document format and
meaning - particular element names and the fact that they are relative
references to more data that needs retrieval. Requiring that the client know
the URI format and meaning - particular path segments or query terms - seems
very similar to being coupled to document format.
The client and server both share knowledge of a value space - the actual
order number. This shared knowledge is required in both scenarios - you need
to know what order number to look for in the list of leaf nodes for example.
If knowledge of particular order numbers did not exist then finding a
particular order is not possible.
Describing that the server accepts order numbers in a portion of a URI as
opposed to describing that the server reports the order numbers in a portion
of XML content isn't much different to me.
Perhaps I'm just biased to using URI query terms to do lookup because it is
simple to code and easy to understand.


> That makes sense.  One of the next steps will be associating a status
> with each order so this is very relevant!  Using POST as you describe
> sounds like the way to go for updating the order status.  If I think of
> NOT_SEEN as the initial status, I could use the POST as you describe to
> set the status to SEEN.  So if the order is located at /order/2345,
> I could post to /order/2345/status, for instance.
You could POST to /order/2345 directly - POST can be used for partial update
of a resource. If you have a resource which represents the status directly,
you could PUT to that instead (but I have problems with the defined behavior
of PUT).





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3192
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 21:08:59
Subject:Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

Understanding visibility[1] is one of the keys to explaining why Web
services currently suck, IMO.  I've got to think of a way to explain it
better.  I've tried every approach I can think of.

If we can do this, I expect we'll see a mass "A ha!" moment, and Web
services will come crumbling down.

BTW, a message where Mike Champion also misses the point in talking
about firewalls, is here;

http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-ws-arch/2003Jan/0321.html

Please respond with any examples, or brief explanations, that you feel
might help out.  Thanks!  I sense an opportunity here.  A couple of WG
members are really close to getting it.

 [1] http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/net_app_arch.htm#sec_2_3_5

MB

----- Forwarded message from Miles Sabin <miles@...> -----

From: Miles Sabin <miles@...>
To: www-ws-arch@...
Subject: Re: Summing up on visibility(?)
Date: Thu, 9 Jan 2003 20:01:30 +0000
In-Reply-To: <20030109143113.S529@...>
X-Archived-At: http://www.w3.org/mid/200301092001.30887.miles@...
X-Mailing-List: <www-ws-arch@...> archive/latest/4035
List-Id: <www-ws-arch.w3.org>
List-Help: <http://www.w3.org/Mail/>
List-Unsubscribe: <mailto:www-ws-arch-request@...?subject=unsubscribe>


Mark Baker wrote,
> Ok, I *really* don't want to open this up again full-blown, but I
> just have to ask ...
>
> On Thu, Jan 09, 2003 at 07:15:01PM +0000, Miles Sabin wrote:
> > Well, I don't believe that application-level semantics are likely
> > to be accessible to anything, intermediary or otherwise, without it
> > having some sort of prior knowledge of those semantics (this is
> > just the good ol' end-to-end principle).
>
> Wouldn't the prior knowledge of HTTP application semantics by an HTTP
> intermediary qualify?  I would agree that, for example, an SMTP
> message isn't visible to an HTTP intermediary.  But there's shared
> knowledge on application semantics in the HTTP/HTTP case.

If the _whole_ content of the application and it's semantics can be 
derived from RFC 2616, then yes. HTTP semantics are visible to HTTP 
intermediaries.

But as acres of earlier mail should have made clear, I don't believe 
that the semantics of Web services can be fully captured at the level 
of HTTP.

Let's face it, HTTP isn't even enough for plain hypertext ... the HTML 
REC isn't an appendix of RFC 2616 ;-)

Cheers,


Miles

----- End forwarded message -----

-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis

Having read Mike's post and Roy's definition, I still don't understand what
your're asking for.  I'm not saying there is no issue, I'm just not seeing
it...  Could you elaborate?

Seairth Jacobs

Post ID:3194
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-09 23:17:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>

>
> BTW, a message where Mike Champion also misses the point in talking
> about firewalls, is here;
>
> http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-ws-arch/2003Jan/0321.html

> > "If an intermediary understands XML and SOAP, in can
> > be configured to use XPath or whatever to peek into messages and make
such
> > decisions.  Thus, *XML* allows "visibility"."
Why is introspecting the message body not 'visibility'?
An explosion of application meaning (lots of custom methods/operations) will
negate the benefit of visibility (being able to find the method/operation in
a message) - administration will become difficult.

>
> Please respond with any examples, or brief explanations, that you feel
> might help out.  Thanks!  I sense an opportunity here.  A couple of WG
> members are really close to getting it.
What is the 'it' that they should be getting? That visibility is good? Or
that visibility without a constrained interface gets you nowhere?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3195
Sender:Gavin Thomas Nicol <gtn@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 01:05:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

On Thursday 09 January 2003 04:08 pm, Mark Baker wrote:
> Understanding visibility[1] is one of the keys to explaining why Web
> services currently suck, IMO.  I've got to think of a way to explain it
> better.  I've tried every approach I can think of.

There's two parts to this though: explaining the notion of visibility, and 
then explaining the benefits of it.

For the notion of visibility... maybe the closest thing I can think of is 
"facade" or "proxy" patterns, though that doesn't capture it very well.

As for the benefits... I think that's not so hard to explain. Personally, I'm 
not convinced visibility is always a good thing... it opens you up to 
spoofing etc.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3196
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 03:07:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!

> Understanding visibility[1] is one of the keys to explaining why Web
> services currently suck, IMO.  I've got to think of a way to explain it
> better.  I've tried every approach I can think of.

I hear the trumpet; I stand ready to answer the call!

> 
> If we can do this, I expect we'll see a mass "A ha!" moment, and Web
> services will come crumbling down.

You need to be drinking way less caffein, my friend.

Can you give a brief rundown of the approaches you've tried and
how/why they don't seem to be getting thru?

Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3197
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 03:54:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

On Thu, Jan 09, 2003 at 03:17:38PM -0800, S. Mike Dierken wrote:
> Why is introspecting the message body not 'visibility'?

It's part of it, sure; the syntax part. 8-)

> An explosion of application meaning (lots of custom methods/operations) will
> negate the benefit of visibility (being able to find the method/operation in
> a message) - administration will become difficult.

Right.

> > Please respond with any examples, or brief explanations, that you feel
> > might help out.  Thanks!  I sense an opportunity here.  A couple of WG
> > members are really close to getting it.
> What is the 'it' that they should be getting? That visibility is good? Or
> that visibility without a constrained interface gets you nowhere?

The "it" is what visibility is, and why it's good, though I think if
the former is recognized, the latter will be clear.

FWIW, and to answer Seairth, here's a quote from Roy's dissertation;

"[...]What makes HTTP significantly different from RPC is that the requests are directed to resources using a generic interface with standard semantics that can be interpreted by intermediaries almost as well as by the machines that originate services.[...]"
 -- http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_5_2

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3198
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 04:22:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

On Thu, Jan 09, 2003 at 10:07:09PM -0500, Walden Mathews wrote:
> > If we can do this, I expect we'll see a mass "A ha!" moment, and Web
> > services will come crumbling down.
> 
> You need to be drinking way less caffein, my friend.

I'm the eternal optimist.  It's why I didn't give up on this shortly
after I started, about three years ago. 8-O

> Can you give a brief rundown of the approaches you've tried and
> how/why they don't seem to be getting thru?

I've tried explaining;

- why caching works
- how firewalls do their job
- the "exploding number of methods" problem
- the coordination language view
- syntax vs. semantics
- transport vs. transfer

I can't tell you why it's not getting through.  Part of it for a lot
of people is certainly "mob mentality"; that there's comfort in knowing
that the person beside you believes the same thing.  There's also the
issue that mental models are hard to change, and getting this point for
many people requires a new one.  Combined, they're nasty.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3199
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 04:34:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>

>
> FWIW, and to answer Seairth, here's a quote from Roy's dissertation;
>
> "[...]What makes HTTP significantly different from RPC is that the
requests are directed to resources using a generic interface with standard
semantics that can be interpreted by intermediaries almost as well as by the
machines that originate services.[...]"
>  --
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_5_2

Okay, what I get out of this is that the benefit is that intermediaries can
do cool things if it knows the intent of the request - and that requires a)
finding the intent (the method/operation) of the message and 2) having a
manageable number of intentions do deal with.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3200
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 04:39:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

Mark Baker wrote:

>Understanding visibility[1] is one of the keys to explaining why Web
>services currently suck, IMO.  I've got to think of a way to explain it
>better.  I've tried every approach I can think of.
>
>If we can do this, I expect we'll see a mass "A ha!" moment, and Web
>services will come crumbling down.
>  
>
I'd love to contribute, but even after reading [1], I'm not sure I 
understand the connection, although do I believe there is one (somewhere 
just beyond the reach of my brain).  In addition, I don't really 
understand what Miles is trying to get at in the included message below, 
so it's hard for me to find the hole in that logic.

>BTW, a message where Mike Champion also misses the point in talking
>about firewalls, is here;
>
>http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-ws-arch/2003Jan/0321.html
>  
>
I've never understood this kind of logic.  It seems to me that this kind 
of thinking leads exactly to what happens with filtering/blocking 
software - lots of false positives because the software can only grok 
syntax and hasn't a clue about semantics.  I don't know about anyone 
else, but I'd prefer that my firewall not suffer false positives when 
trying to determine whether traffic from a partner is allowed through.

--Chuck

>Please respond with any examples, or brief explanations, that you feel
>might help out.  Thanks!  I sense an opportunity here.  A couple of WG
>members are really close to getting it.
>
> [1] http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/net_app_arch.htm#sec_2_3_5
>
>MB
>
>----- Forwarded message from Miles Sabin <miles@...> -----
>
>From: Miles Sabin <miles@...>
>To: www-ws-arch@...
>Subject: Re: Summing up on visibility(?)
>Date: Thu, 9 Jan 2003 20:01:30 +0000
>In-Reply-To: <20030109143113.S529@...>
>X-Archived-At: http://www.w3.org/mid/200301092001.30887.miles@...
>X-Mailing-List: <www-ws-arch@...> archive/latest/4035
>List-Id: <www-ws-arch.w3.org>
>List-Help: <http://www.w3.org/Mail/>
>List-Unsubscribe: <mailto:www-ws-arch-request@...?subject=unsubscribe>
>
>
>Mark Baker wrote,
>  
>
>>Ok, I *really* don't want to open this up again full-blown, but I
>>just have to ask ...
>>
>>On Thu, Jan 09, 2003 at 07:15:01PM +0000, Miles Sabin wrote:
>>    
>>
>>>Well, I don't believe that application-level semantics are likely
>>>to be accessible to anything, intermediary or otherwise, without it
>>>having some sort of prior knowledge of those semantics (this is
>>>just the good ol' end-to-end principle).
>>>      
>>>
>>Wouldn't the prior knowledge of HTTP application semantics by an HTTP
>>intermediary qualify?  I would agree that, for example, an SMTP
>>message isn't visible to an HTTP intermediary.  But there's shared
>>knowledge on application semantics in the HTTP/HTTP case.
>>    
>>
>
>If the _whole_ content of the application and it's semantics can be 
>derived from RFC 2616, then yes. HTTP semantics are visible to HTTP 
>intermediaries.
>
>But as acres of earlier mail should have made clear, I don't believe 
>that the semantics of Web services can be fully captured at the level 
>of HTTP.
>
>Let's face it, HTTP isn't even enough for plain hypertext ... the HTML 
>REC isn't an appendix of RFC 2616 ;-)
>
>Cheers,
>
>
>Miles
>
>----- End forwarded message -----
>
>  
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3201
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 05:10:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:

From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>
> I've tried explaining;
>
> - why caching works
> - how firewalls do their job
> - the "exploding number of methods" problem
> - the coordination language view
> - syntax vs. semantics
> - transport vs. transfer
>
> I can't tell you why it's not getting through.  Part of it for a lot
> of people is certainly "mob mentality"; that there's comfort in knowing
> that the person beside you believes the same thing.  There's also the
> issue that mental models are hard to change, and getting this point for
> many people requires a new one.  Combined, they're nasty.

I look at the list above and it occurs to me that an "aha" moment may not be
needed in the end.  As RPC-style infrastructures proliferate, the features
you mention (caching, firewalls, simple interface, etc) will begin to
crumble (e.g. ineffective caching, overloaded firewalls, administrating a
never-ending list of interfaces/methods, etc.) around them.  They will throw
more hardware and more complex software at the problem.  And when they
discover that this isn't solving the problem (and they *will* discover
that), they will start to look around for alternatives.  And they will see
REST.  They will see applications running in ways that their own can't.  And
they will finally begin to see the light...

What better way of showing how REST is better than RPC than to let them see
how bad RPC can get?

Then again, if people don't want to see, then they won't see.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3202
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 05:14:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Explaining visibility - help!
Message:


Mark Baker wrote:

>[...]
>I can't tell you why it's not getting through.  Part of it for a lot
>of people is certainly "mob mentality"; that there's comfort in knowing
>that the person beside you believes the same thing.  There's also the
>issue that mental models are hard to change, and getting this point for
>many people requires a new one.  Combined, they're nasty.
>  
>
I think you hit the nail on the head there - mental models are hard to 
change.  People are used to RPC for network-based applications, and SOAP 
provides exactly that.  That and the fact that you've taken something 
they're familiar with and sprinkled it with the magic pixie dust that is 
the web and XML; how can it not be the ultimate application platform? :-/

Seriously, though, I expect that a lot of people just don't see the 
relevance of your arguments because they have the wrong mental model.   
 When you're doing RPC, it isn't clear that caching RPC messages has 
much benefit.

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3203
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 05:24:44
Subject:pointers and REST promotion...
Message:

I have decided to implement a RESTful "mail" system.  The design I have come
up with is incredibly simple, flexible, and (i believe) even RESTful (no,
really!).  However, before I get too deep into its design, I thought I would
look around at what others are doing.  Anyone know of any RESTful (from the
ground up, preferably) "mail" systems out there already?


In the end, my objective is to get a simple, easily visible RESTful
application on the web and used by lots of people (the latter part is
possibly more important that the former part).  As I have been reading the
"visibility" thread, I got to thinking that (other than letting people
discover for themselves the pitfalls of RPC) people would be more receptive
to REST if they could actually see something RESTful.  I know the Web itself
is RESTful, but it's hard to convince someone of the legitimacy of a term
that came after the application that demonstrated it.  Coming up with
something *new* would, imho, be an easier thing to digest and understand to
the REST skeptics out there.


To that end, if anyone is interested in working with me on this, I will
happily share my thoughts.  I think it's highly workable, and would
certainly be more successful if it were a group effort.


---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> look around at what others are doing.  Anyone know of any RESTful (from the
> ground up, preferably) "mail" systems out there already?

In case you haven't seen it before:

http://www.prescod.net/rest/restmail/

	-joe

http://BitWorking.org
http://WellFormedWeb.org

Post ID:3206
Sender:Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 06:11:51
Subject:Re: pointers and REST promotion...
Message:

> I have decided to implement a RESTful "mail" system.  The design I
> have come up with is incredibly simple, flexible, and (i believe)
> even RESTful (no, really!).  However, before I get too deep into
> its design, I thought I would look around at what others are doing.
> Anyone know of any RESTful (from the ground up, preferably) "mail"
> systems out there already?

I was wondering how RESTful Microsoft HTTPMail spec is after
reading article at http://www.prescod.net/rest/restmail/.

Recently, I found there's a project trying to document/implement
this spec:

    http://httpmail.sourceforge.net/

Maybe you can use this as a basis for your implementation?
It doesn't provide everything you're looking for, but I believe
it could be added without breaking any compatibility.

--
Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3207
Sender:"Donald Ball" <dball@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 16:32:28
Subject:rest toolkit on the client side
Message:

I'm trying to convince a group of fellow employees that they should develop
an internal webapp RESTfully instead of using SOAP/XML-RPC and friends. The
client in this context isn't a web browser but instead a java application.
One argument in favor of SOAP is that the java toolkits, client and server,
are pretty good, while with RESTful HTTP, the server toolkits are pretty
good while clients aren't so much.

Do y'all buy this argument? Can anyone recommend a very good HTTP client
for RESTful application development in java?

- donald





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3208
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 16:48:47
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] rest toolkit on the client side
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Donald Ball" <dball@...>

> Do y'all buy this argument? Can anyone recommend a very good HTTP client
> for RESTful application development in java?
I strongly agree that the clients need work to be more fully RESTful. I
don't know of any good Java clients - but if you're willing to pay, I'm
willing to code.

mike

I am trying to connect to servlet with different request types like 
POST PUT GET DELETE OPTIONS...  I am getting response code 400 when I 
try to do POST or PUT, which indicates that request sent by the 
client was syntactically incorrect. . Rest of the request types are 
working fine. I am using HttpURLConnection class in Java to connect 
to servlet.
Any Suggestions???

Thanx,

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3212
Sender:"Donald Ball" <dball@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 17:53:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] rest toolkit on the client side
Message:

>>One argument in favor of SOAP is that the java toolkits, client and
>server,
>>are pretty good, while with RESTful HTTP, the server toolkits are pretty
>>good while clients aren't so much.
>>
>>Do y'all buy this argument? Can anyone recommend a very good HTTP client
>>for RESTful application development in java?
>>
>I don't know if I buy this or not.  What is it about Java client tools 
>that is lacking from a REST perspective?

well, availability/stability for one... :) seriously, you've got, what,
three basic choices?

1. java.net.URL and java.net.URLConnection, which barely qualifies as
usable

2. http://www.innovation.ch/java/HTTPClient/ which isn't actively
maintained

3. http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/httpclient/ which is stuck in
perpetual alpha

I would think if you were looking to develop a REST client application,
you'd want a client toolkit that made some things easy on you - simple
things like setting a base URL for a series of requests, easy
authentication... maybe more complex things like associating expected
response codes / response message formats to requests with callback methods
for success or failure. I don't know, I'm in pure speculation mode here,
never having written a non-browser-based REST client, but I guess I don't
see anything in the Java side of things at least that compares favorably
with the RPC toolkits.

Certainly any and all of those could be built on top of the existing http
clients. I guess I'm asking if anyone's aware of anything good that _has_
been written already. If not, why not, and what would a good toolkit look
like?

- donald





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3213
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 18:11:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] rest toolkit on the client side
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Chuck Hinson" <cmhinson@...>

> I don't know if I buy this or not.  What is it about Java client tools
> that is lacking from a REST perspective?

The kind of things I find missing are:
 - simplicity
 - message structure & content awareness
 - efficiency

1 Simplicity
The built-in HTTPUrlConnection helps deal with the network connection
between client and server, rather than simplify access to remote resources.
It has methods like:
 connection.setRequestMethod(String)
 String connection.getResponseMessage()

I would rather see classes and methods that reflect resources and messages
something like:
class Server
{
 void setAuthInfo(AuthInfo info);
 void setHeaders(HashMap defaultHeaders);
 void setHost(String defaultHost);

 Response get(String uri);
 Response post(String uri,Content body);
 Response put(String uri,Content body);
 Response delete(String uri);
}

There are problems with this particular approach, but it illustrates that
the code talks about application concepts rather than network concepts.

2 Message & Content awareness
The built-in URLConnection provides either stream or string views of
response messages. You can use ContentFactory support to inject your own
content parsing to spin up whatever object wrapping the response data, but I
don't see a good wrapper class.
I'd like to see classes like Response and Content

class Response
{
    String getHeader(String name);
    Content getContent();
}

class Content
{
    String getType();

    // used with multipart
    Vector getParts();

    String getBody();
    byte[] getBytes();
    InputStream getStream();
}

3 Efficiency
Mainly this is support of HTTP 1.1 and keepalive. I'm not sure the default
client supports keepalive - it probably does but I'm not sure.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3214
Sender:Kiran Kumar <buddy1908@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 18:18:16
Subject:Syntactically bad request when I POST or PUT
Message:

I am trying to connect to servlet with different
request types like
> POST PUT GET DELETE OPTIONS... I am getting response
code 400 when I
> try to do POST or PUT, which indicates that request
sent by the
> client was syntactically incorrect. . Rest of the
request types are
> working fine. I am using HttpURLConnection class in
Java to connect
> to servlet.
> Any Suggestions???
>
> Thanx,
> Bud
>
sample code
try{
URL url = new URL("http://hostname:8080/servlet/");
HttpURLConnection bind =
(HttpURLConnection)url.openConnection();
bind.setRequestMethod("POST");
bind.setRequestProperty("name","value");
bind.setAllowUserInteraction(true);
bind.setDoOutput(true);
//bind.setDoInput(true);
bind.connect();
System.out.println(" Connected ");
System.out.println(" Response Codes : " +
bind.getResponseCode());
System.out.println(" Response Message : " +
bind.getResponseMessage());

}
catch(MalformedURLException ex)
{

}
catch(IOException ioe)
{

}


Exception thrown:
<E> <ServletContextManager> Servlet request
terminiated with RuntimeException
java.lang.NullPointerException
        at
weblogic.servlet.internal.ServletOutputStreamImpl.finish(ServletOutputStreamImpl.java:422)
        at
weblogic.servlet.internal.ServletContextManager.invokeServlet(ServletContextManager.java:241)
        at
weblogic.socket.MuxableSocketHTTP.invokeServlet(MuxableSocketHTTP.java:391)
        at
weblogic.socket.MuxableSocketHTTP.execute(MuxableSocketHTTP.java:273)
        at
weblogic.kernel.ExecuteThread.run(ExecuteThread.java:129)




__________________________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Mail Plus - Powerful. Affordable. Sign up now.
http://mailplus.yahoo.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3215
Sender:Gary Shea <shea@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 18:19:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

On Thu, 9 Jan 2003, at 13:57 [-0500], Seairth Jacobs (seairth@...)...:

> one clarification below...
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>
> >
> > I took this (baroque?) approach because the uri /order/by-number/2275 is
> > so not opaque!
>
> Your choice to use one URI over another doesn't indicate whether the URI is
> opaque or not.  It's a matter of whether the client attempts to treat it as
> anything more than an identifier or not that determines whether it's opaque.
> A RESTful client treats *all* URIs as opaque (though there has been some
> blurring of that stance lately, it seems).
>
> I think the common confusion about opacity is whether it's perceived as
> "human understandable" or not.  The path you give could certainly be
> interpreted by a human beyond "it's an identifier", even though it
> shouldn't.  Suppose instead that you were to have used the path /19394BC3EA.
> At first blush, one might say this URI is "more opaque".  However, it is no
> more opaque than your example above if the client knows attempts to
> interpret it (e.g. knows the encoding scheme you use) beyond "it's an
> identifier".  It is certainly less "human understandable", but that doesn't
> necessarily make it more opaque.

I completely agree with your points about opacity of URIs.  I don't
think they are relevant to this case though.

The question is, how do I get access to a specific order document, given
the order number.

My original proposal was to do a tree search in a heirarchy of index
pages, where the order number guides the search.  In some index leaf
page a pointer to the actual URI would be found.  There would be no way
to interpret the URI structure, because it doesn't have any: the
mapping from order numbers to URIs is basically random.  Completely
opaque.

The alternative approach suggested by S. Mike Dierken was to put
the order number in the uri.  Easy to interpret, totally not opaque.
The client must know the significance of the final URI component in
order to use the service.

So, which method is more ReSTful?  To me the first one is ReSTful, the
second one isn't, but Mike obviously has been thinking about ReST longer
than I have... so I accept that I'm probably missing something.

My sense is that if the goal is: "Given a set of parameters, find the
corresponding URI", there is only one ReSTful alternative, namely the
inefficient search method described above.  A solution that involves
putting search information in a document and getting back a URI is
RPC like (the intention is not described by the choice of
PUT/POST/blah), and a solution that puts the search criteria in the URL
requires that the structure of the URL be well-defined and so violates
opaqueness.  Eeek!

Regards,

	Gary





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3216
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 18:47:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>

> The question is, how do I get access to a specific order document, given
> the order number.

>
> My original proposal was to do a tree search in a heirarchy of index
> pages, where the order number guides the search.  In some index leaf
> page a pointer to the actual URI would be found.  There would be no way
> to interpret the URI structure, because it doesn't have any: the
> mapping from order numbers to URIs is basically random.  Completely
> opaque.
Not actually completely opaque. The client needs to know the format and
structure of two documents. Either that's hardcoded - and hard things are
brittle - or the server describes the format (which gets you into a
recursive definition of how you describe information and find what you want
from that description).
If you go with the server description approach, then the server can just as
easily describe the format of the URI. If the server changes the structure,
the defintion changes - clients automatically adopt the new format.

> The alternative approach suggested by S. Mike Dierken was to put
> the order number in the uri.  Easy to interpret, totally not opaque.
Add in a server description of how to construct the URI and you reduce the
coupling. I do realize that constructing URIs can be avoided in many
situations, but I think it adds implementation complexity for not a lot of
benefit. Just my opinion though.

> My sense is that if the goal is: "Given a set of parameters, find the
> corresponding URI", there is only one ReSTful alternative, namely the
> inefficient search method described above.
Well stated goal. And very good question - is there only one RESTful
approach?
I see two non-URI based approaches
 a) successive GETs and matching against response content
 b) POSTing some content with the parameter (the purchase order number) and
receiving the actual location

The URI-based approach might be simpler to implement, and a server-provided
description of the structure of the URI reduces coupling, but defining a URI
structure probably is going to limit the server to hosting the resources in
a simple container (like a database) otherwise the description gets too
complicated (although a re-direct would let you put things anywhere else
too). Using the non-URI based approaches lets you put the resources anywhere
on the Web.

So... for me, I'd do something simple when the job is simple and do
something large when the problem is large. Small steps toward automation are
better than no steps at all.
