-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3219
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 20:24:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] pointers and REST promotion...
Message:

I just read Paul's article.
I like the basic idea.  I would just like so
suggest using RFC2017 for notifications.

RFC2017 defines:
Content-Type: Message/External-Body; access-type=URL; URL="http://foo.com/path"

Using that in combination with the
content-description header described in RFC2045
basically achieves what you need in the way of
notification documents.

You can use these mimetype as part of a transition
to HTTP mail.  If you send email using this
format, an increasing number of clients will
recognize it.

The only remaining problem is replacing POP/IMAP.
It would be nice if mailclients could expose HTTP,
but often that is not possible.  My suggestion for
retrieving new mail is again to use this header in
combination with multipart-byteranges.

You treat an INBOX (or newsgroup) as a
multipart/digest document.  Each message in the
digest should have an external-body.

If you want to see what has arrived since the
last time you checked, make a request with an
if-modified-since: etag

The server then returns a multipart/byteranges
document of all messages that have arrived since
that etag was generated.  The nice thing here is
that multipart/byteranges have the same syntax as
multipart/digest, so a client can just process the
returned data using any multipart handler.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax






On Fri, 10 Jan 2003, Joe Gregorio wrote:

> > really!).  However, before I get too deep into its design, I thought I would
> > look around at what others are doing.  Anyone know of any RESTful (from the
> > ground up, preferably) "mail" systems out there already?
>
> In case you haven't seen it before:
>
> http://www.prescod.net/rest/restmail/
>
> 	-joe

> http://BitWorking.org

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3220
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 20:30:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] pointers and REST promotion...
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

>
> If you want to see what has arrived since the
> last time you checked, make a request with an
> if-modified-since: etag

Isn't the response to an out-of-date ETag supposed to be identical to a
response with no ETag?
If so, then the response must be the full list of items.
If not, then ETag can be use to do snapshot-based filtering or deltas using
standard headers rather than custom query terms.

Post ID:3222
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 20:42:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] pointers and REST promotion...
Message:

Since the server can choose which representation
to use for any resource (e.g. gif or jpeg), the
server may respond with a multipart/byteranges
representation to a request for any resource.

My idea is that it actually makes sense to do this
if you know the client already has what came
before.

-Alex-

Post ID:3223
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 21:04:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

From: "Gary Shea" <shea@...>
>
> The alternative approach suggested by S. Mike Dierken was to put
> the order number in the uri.  Easy to interpret, totally not opaque.
> The client must know the significance of the final URI component in
> order to use the service.

Some discussions I have seen in the past (sorry, don't remember where though
probably on this list) had argued that if the server were telling the client
how to construct the URI, then the URI was still effectively opaque.  In a
way, I agree with this, though I can't tell you why.  It just "feels right"
somehow.

Anyone else remember this discussion?

Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3225
Sender:Kendall Clark <kendall@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 21:19:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Kudos!
Message:

On Fri, Jan 10, 2003 at 03:32:31PM -0500, Joe Gregorio wrote:
> Jeff Bone wrote:
> > Go RESTLog!
> > 
> > http://www.intertwingly.net/blog/1104.html
> > http://wellformedweb.org/news/2
> 
> Thank you. I'm glad to see it getting 
> a high profile airing.

Joe,

Interesting stuff. Have you thought about generalizing it a bit? I mean, I
prefer RSS 1.0 to RSS 2.0, and I think RESTlog would be more useful if you
didn't specify so much about how messages are stored on the server side;
both physically and w/r/t to format...

It might be nice to make a capability discovery URI, like:

http://foo.bar/message-types

which one could GET and which would return an XML doc (actually, RDF would
be ideal for this) describing which formats the RESTlog could understand and
store, among other things.

In other words, RESTlog looks neat, but if I were going to use it for
projects, I'd want to store messages not in files on the filesystem but in,
say, ZODB (or MySQL), and I'd want to have more flexibility in the sorts of
message types a client could expect to POST.

Kendall
-- 
Jazz is only what you are. -- Louis Armstrong





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3226
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 21:52:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another "is this ReSTful" question
Message:

Seairth,

> > The alternative approach suggested by S. Mike Dierken was to put
> > the order number in the uri.  Easy to interpret, totally not opaque.
> > The client must know the significance of the final URI component in
> > order to use the service.
>
> Some discussions I have seen in the past (sorry, don't remember where
though
> probably on this list) had argued that if the server were telling the
client
> how to construct the URI, then the URI was still effectively opaque.  In a
> way, I agree with this, though I can't tell you why.  It just "feels
right"
> somehow.
>
> Anyone else remember this discussion?

I think it might have been spawned by Paul Prescod's "First Principles"
paper.  It "feels right" because if the instructions are expressed in a
generic
language, then the client doesn't need the extra coupling to server-specific
protocol.

/walden

Why not just have the server return an
accept: header with MIME types describing what the

If clients have a preference between RSS1.0 and
RSS2.0 they should also use the accept header.

I think the relevenant mimetypes are
text/xml+rss1.0 and text/xml+rss2.0

Subject:Which types of request types accept Inputs
Message:

There are different types of headers
PUT Accepts input
GET Accepts input
POST Accepts input
HEAD ???
TRACE ???
OPTIONS ???
DELETE ???

I know that PUT,GET,POST accept inputs. I tried to add
inputs to TRACE but it didn't work, I got 400 as my
response code. I was wondering whether TRACE doesn't
accept inputs. 

Where can I find more information regarding each of
these request types and their behaviour.

Thanx,
bud

http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3231
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-10 23:48:48
Subject:How to advertise acceptable content types sent via POST or PUT
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>


> Why not just have the server return an
> accept: header with MIME types describing what the
> client is allowed to post?
The immediate reason is that Accept: is a request header, not a response
header.
But since I don't know of a standard way for a resource to advertise its
various representations or to advertise its acceptable content, I think a
simple approach like you suggest sounds neat.

This should probably be posted to www-talk also

Note: there is an Allow response header listing the supported methods...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3232
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 00:37:17
Subject:opaqueness of URI
Message:

> So, which method is more ReSTful?  To me the first one is ReSTful, the
> second one isn't, but Mike obviously has been thinking about ReST 
> longer
> than I have... so I accept that I'm probably missing something.

Maybe I am missing something, but since several people have said that
REST implies opaqueness in the URI, my guess is that a legend
has somehow begun and I need to put it to rest (no pun intended).

REST does not require that a URI be opaque.  The only place where
the word opaque occurs in my dissertation is where I complain about the
opaqueness of cookies.  In fact, RESTful applications are, at all times,
encouraged to use human-meaningful, hierarchical identifiers in order
to maximize the serendipitous use of the information beyond what is
anticipated by the original application.

It is still necessary for the server to construct the URIs and for the
client to initially discover those URIs via hypertext responses, either
in the normal course of creating the resource or by some form of query
that results in a hypertext list.  However, once that list is provided,
people can and do anticipate the names of other/future resources in
that name space, just as I would often directly type URIs into the
location bar rather than go through some poorly designed interactive
multi-page interface for stock charts.

Sites that rely on interstitial advertising (like the annoying yahoo
groups interface) do not like it when user's avoid the indirect path,
but the social network-effect of the Web is enhanced by meaningful URI.
In general, sites that give meaningful URI are used more often.

It also helps prevent the "lost in hyperspace" syndrome, but that's
a separate issue.


Cheers,

Roy T. Fielding, co-founder, The Apache Software Foundation
                  (fielding@...)  <http://www.apache.org/>

                  Chief Scientist, Day Software
                  2 Corporate Plaza, Suite 150
                  Newport Beach, CA 92660-7929   fax:+1.949.644.5064
                  (roy.fielding@...) <http://www.day.com/>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3233
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 02:11:02
Subject:Re: How to advertise acceptable content types sent via POST or PUT
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Bjoern Hoehrmann" <derhoermi@...>

>
> See section 19.6.2.1 of RFC 2068,
RFC 2068 - Hypertext Transfer Protocol -- HTTP/1.1
19.6.2.1 Alternates
   The Alternates response-header field has been proposed as a means for
   the origin server to inform the client about other available
   representations of the requested resource, along with their
   distinguishing attributes,

> section 8.3 of RFC 2295 and
RFC 2295 - Transparent Content Negotiation in HTTP
8.3 Alternates
   The Alternates response header is used to convey the list of variants
   bound to a negotiable resource.  This list can also include
   directives for any content negotiation process.  If a response from a
   transparently negotiable resource includes an Alternates header, this
   header MUST contain the complete variant list bound to the negotiable
   resource

> section 19.6.3 (last paragraph) of RFC 2616.
RFC 2616 - Hypertext Transfer Protocol -- HTTP/1.1
19.6.3 Changes from RFC 2068
The Alternates, Content-Version, Derived-From, Link, URI, Public and
   Content-Base header fields were defined in previous versions of this
   specification, but not commonly implemented. See RFC 2068.


> There is no means I am aware of to
> inform the client about acceptable media types for POST/PUT/...
> requests, but a server will send status 415 if the request entity media
> type is unsupported.

Thanks for the info! Good stuff.

If Alternates indicates the media type for a representation of a resource -
and PUT will store that representation, while not explicit, it may make
sense to try using Alternates as the acceptable format for a PUT. I'd rather
have a more explicit mechanism though, since Alternates seems connected with
GET.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3234
Sender:Joe Gregorio <joe@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 03:45:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Kudos!
Message:

Kendall Clark wrote:

> Joe,
>
> Interesting stuff. Have you thought about generalizing it a bit? I 
> mean, I
> prefer RSS 1.0 to RSS 2.0, and I think RESTlog would be more useful if 
> you
> didn't specify so much about how messages are stored on the server side;
> both physically and w/r/t to format...
>
Thanks. I have been slowly trying to seperate out the documentation into 
'specification'
and 'implementation'. Based on your feedback I added some more verbage to
make the distinction clearer. Let me know if it's sufficient:

http://wellformedweb.org/news/2

>
> It might be nice to make a capability discovery URI, like:
>
> http://foo.bar/message-types
>
> which one could GET and which would return an XML doc (actually, RDF 
> would
> be ideal for this) describing which formats the RESTlog could 
> understand and
> store, among other things.
>
Heheh, RDF isn't really a match philisophicly. Have you read my essay
that stimulated the creation of the WellFormedWeb site?
http://wellformedweb.org/story/1

Discovery is a big area and I have seen a lot of proposals in this area, 
from
RDF, the OPTIONS HTTP verb, WSIL, RSD, etc. This was discussed in relation
to RESTLog on [ucapi-discuss]:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/ucapi-discuss/message/3

>
> In other words, RESTlog looks neat, but if I were going to use it for
> projects, I'd want to store messages not in files on the filesystem 
> but in,
> say, ZODB (or MySQL), and I'd want to have more flexibility in the 
> sorts of
> message types a client could expect to POST.
>
There is a mention of RSS 2.0 in the 'implementation' sections in
which demonstrate how I link up the individual 'item's into 'index.rss'. 
Now that's implementation
so we can safely ignore it. I.e. it's not part of the spec.

The other part where RSS 2.0 raises it's head is in the creation and 
editing of posts.
Are you asking that the 'item' fragment be from RSS 1.0? As I understand 
it that would
require putting the 'item' element in a different namespace. Is there 
any benefit
from making that change? Let me know if I am missing something.

You may also want to look at James Snell's proposed extensions to RESTLog:
http://www.snellspace.com/blog/archives/000127.html

    Thanks,
    -joe

--
http://BitWorking.org
http://WellFormedWeb.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3235
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 04:16:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3237
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 04:32:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

Yah, I thought long and hard about this recently due to Jon Udell's
ISBN-in-the-URI javascript hack.  There's no denying the value in that.

I figure it's one of those things with an upside and a downside.  The
upside is the serendipity.  The downside is serendipity.  8-)  What I
mean is that as a consumer of a URI, it's awesome to be able to get
more info and use it in unexpected ways.  But on the other hand, for
the URI publisher, you can't know what information people or software
may be extracting from your URI, and that ties your hands somewhat with
respect to how your URI space can evolve.

I used to think the problems with the latter outweighed the benefits
of the former, but I think it's the other way around now after seeing
it in action.  At least the publisher has the option of obfuscating
their URIs if they don't want to have to worry about it.

BTW, the RESTwiki's down due to a machine swap.  I'll have to fix it
this weekend.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3238
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 08:07:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

Roy T. Fielding wrote,
> REST does not require that a URI be opaque.

Interesting.

I think you're saying that it's legitimate from a REST POV for a client 
to infer a URI pattern or template, eg.

  http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1

or,

  http://example.invalid/foo/$1

where the client can substitute into the $1 position to obtain a URI and 
have some reasonable expectation that the server manages a 
corresponding resource.

These URI templates aren't URIs, clearly. They represent a family of 
related URIs: an infinite family if arbitrary substitutions into the 
template positions are acceptable; a finite family if the substutions 
should be drawn from a restricted set as in an HTML <select>.

But they do seem like identifiers for all that, even if only virtual/ 
derived and parasitic on the "true" identifiers which support them. 
What would support a clients expectation that substutions into,

  http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1

would be likely to generate dereferencable URIs other than an assumption 
that the URI template effectively identifies a _process_ (or something 
equivalent) which is able to perform the inverse operation on the URI 
and extract the substitued-in value as a parameter for a computation?

I wonder if something like the above would go some way towards tweaking 
RFC 2396 3.4 in a REST-consistent direction?

Cheers,


Miles





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3239
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 10:27:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

> I think you're saying that it's legitimate from a REST POV for a client
> to infer a URI pattern or template, eg.
>
>   http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1
>
> or,
>
>   http://example.invalid/foo/$1
>
> where the client can substitute into the $1 position to obtain a URI 
> and
> have some reasonable expectation that the server manages a
> corresponding resource.

Reasonable expectation?  Hmmm.  All links are wishful thinking.
Guessed links are just somewhat more wishful than others.

> These URI templates aren't URIs, clearly. They represent a family of
> related URIs: an infinite family if arbitrary substitutions into the
> template positions are acceptable; a finite family if the substutions
> should be drawn from a restricted set as in an HTML <select>.

Er, don't think too hard about it.  All URIs are URIs -- some resources
just don't (currently) have a representation.

> But they do seem like identifiers for all that, even if only virtual/
> derived and parasitic on the "true" identifiers which support them.
> What would support a clients expectation that substutions into,
>
>   http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1
>
> would be likely to generate dereferencable URIs other than an 
> assumption
> that the URI template effectively identifies a _process_ (or something
> equivalent) which is able to perform the inverse operation on the URI
> and extract the substitued-in value as a parameter for a computation?

A hierarchical namespace typically assigns semantics to each name in
the hierarchy, and a well-written server-side application will
respond consistently to requests throughout that namespace, keeping
in mind that "not found" is a consistent response if, in fact, there
is no associated representation for that name.  It is often harder
to interpret the same of query info because it is unordered, which
is why developers should not hide hierarchy inside queries.

> I wonder if something like the above would go some way towards tweaking
> RFC 2396 3.4 in a REST-consistent direction?

It is difficult to write good descriptions for URI components given
that schemes frequently differ in some uses.  The descriptions in
RFC 2396 give the intent, even though they can be misused in practice.
I suspect that most of the spec will have to be rewritten before all
of the authors will agree, let alone the IETF reviewers.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3240
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 11:37:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

Roy T. Fielding wrote,
> > I think you're saying that it's legitimate from a REST POV for a
> > client to infer a URI pattern or template, eg.
> >
> >   http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1
> >
> > or,
> >
> >   http://example.invalid/foo/$1
> >
> > where the client can substitute into the $1 position to obtain a
> > URI and have some reasonable expectation that the server manages a
> > corresponding resource.
>
> Reasonable expectation?  Hmmm.  All links are wishful thinking.
> Guessed links are just somewhat more wishful than others.

Well, yeah.

I meant "reasonable" in the sense of "not completely ridiculous". It's 
surely more reasonable for a client to expect that if it which receives 
an HTML form with a GET action of,

  http://example.invalid/foo

and a control name of "foo" that,

  http://example.invalid/foo?foo=wibble

will identify a resource with a representation than it would be for it 
to expect that,

  http://example.invalid/foo/3lk4j5l3jkd84oikl

will (where the last path element it a client genarated random string).

> > These URI templates aren't URIs, clearly. They represent a family
> > of related URIs: an infinite family if arbitrary substitutions into
> > the template positions are acceptable; a finite family if the
> > substutions should be drawn from a restricted set as in an HTML
> > <select>.
>
> Er, don't think too hard about it.  All URIs are URIs -- some
> resources just don't (currently) have a representation.

Right, but a URI _template_ isn't a URI. It's a pattern a client might 
instantiate to create a URI in the hope that that URI identifies a 
resource with a representation.

> > But they do seem like identifiers for all that, even if only
> > virtual/ derived and parasitic on the "true" identifiers which
> > support them. What would support a clients expectation that
> > substutions into,
> >
> >   http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1
> >
> > would be likely to generate dereferencable URIs other than an
> > assumption that the URI template effectively identifies a _process_
> > (or something equivalent) which is able to perform the inverse
> > operation on the URI and extract the substitued-in value as a
> > parameter for a computation?
>
> A hierarchical namespace typically assigns semantics to each name in
> the hierarchy, and a well-written server-side application will
> respond consistently to requests throughout that namespace, keeping
> in mind that "not found" is a consistent response if, in fact, there
> is no associated representation for that name.  It is often harder
> to interpret the same of query info because it is unordered, which
> is why developers should not hide hierarchy inside queries.

OK, I'd be happy to replace "process" with "hierarchical namespace". 
That'd give us something like: a URI template identifies (in a 
virtual/derivative/parasitic sense) a hierarchical namespace maintained 
by the server-side application.

I think that's better than saying it identifies a process, if only 
because it's more general.

> > I wonder if something like the above would go some way towards
> > tweaking RFC 2396 3.4 in a REST-consistent direction?
>
> It is difficult to write good descriptions for URI components given
> that schemes frequently differ in some uses.  The descriptions in
> RFC 2396 give the intent, even though they can be misused in
> practice. I suspect that most of the spec will have to be rewritten
> before all of the authors will agree, let alone the IETF reviewers.

Agreed.

But 3.4 is scheme neutral now, and it might be possible to replace it 
with something more REST-consistent without losing that neutrality. 
Perhaps instead of,

  The query component is a string of information to be interpreted by
  the resource.

we could have something like,

  The presence of a query component suggests the existence of a
  family of resources with representations whose URIs vary in a
  well-defined but scheme-specific and server-dependent way.
  Applications which are aware the constraints of the scheme and the
  capabilities of the server MAY vary the query component in the
  expectation that the resulting URIs identify a resource with a
  representation.

Thoughts?

Cheers,


Miles





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3241
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 14:06:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

Miles Sabin wrote:
> Roy T. Fielding wrote,
> 
>>REST does not require that a URI be opaque.
>  

FTR, it's an axiom of web architecture according to TBL's notes, ie 
a self-evident truth.


> Interesting.
>
> I think you're saying that it's legitimate from a REST POV for a client 
> to infer a URI pattern or template, eg.
> 
>   http://example.invalid/foo?foo=$1
> 
> or,
> 
>   http://example.invalid/foo/$1

Jon Udell [1] has come up with extracting ISBNs from amazon links 
and using them in other sites' query strings. He's recieved near 
universal acclaim for doing so. If you buy into TBL's strong claim 
(URI opacity is an axiom), or Paul Prescod's weaker variant (peeking 
into URIs is a bad idea), then what Jon's done is a nasty hack (a la 
screenscraping), and not has popular opinion has it, a neat hack. 
Either way, this hack seems to offer considerable, immediate, utility.

Maybe this an issue that needs to be punted onto the TAG. It seems 
the web has a constaint over and above any of REST's (is that a first?).

Bill de hra

[1] 
http://weblog.infoworld.com/udell/stories/2002/12/11/librarylookup.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3242
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 16:01:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

From: "Bill de hra" <dehora@...>
>
> Jon Udell [1] has come up with extracting ISBNs from amazon links
> and using them in other sites' query strings. He's recieved near
> universal acclaim for doing so. If you buy into TBL's strong claim
> (URI opacity is an axiom), or Paul Prescod's weaker variant (peeking
> into URIs is a bad idea), then what Jon's done is a nasty hack (a la
> screenscraping), and not has popular opinion has it, a neat hack.
> Either way, this hack seems to offer considerable, immediate, utility.
>
> Maybe this an issue that needs to be punted onto the TAG. It seems
> the web has a constaint over and above any of REST's (is that a first?).

The problem here is not that Jon extracted information out of the URI.  The
problem is that Jon is relying on Amazon to not change it's URIs in a way
that will break his technique.  Had Amazon said "one can extract ISBNs from
our URIs thus", then no one would be saying that what Jon did was a hack.
This all goes back to the/my thought that as long as the server (or server's
authority) dictates how a given URI is composed, then it should be perfectly
fine to extract information out of the URI.

As to whether the URI (or class of URIs) is opaque, I still think that they
are.  As long as the client conforms to the composition rule(s) given by the
server (the simplest case being a URI whose only rule is "this is the URI"),
then I don't see how those constructed URIs would be any different than if
the server returned all possible combinations that matched the given
composition rule(s).  Either way, they would still be "opaque".  It's only
when the client attempts to go outside of the composition rules that we get
in trouble.

Back to Jon's example above, Amazon has implictly told us (as most sites
implicitly do) that the only rule for their URIs is "this is the URI"
(ignoring any generated via a form or javascript).  Jon went outside of the
rules that Amazon provided, thus he is violating the opacity that TimBL
talks about.

IMHO, of course.... :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3243
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 16:43:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> The problem here is not that Jon extracted information out of the URI.  The
> problem is that Jon is relying on Amazon to not change it's URIs in a way
> that will break his technique.  Had Amazon said "one can extract ISBNs from
> our URIs thus", then no one would be saying that what Jon did was a hack.
> This all goes back to the/my thought that as long as the server (or server's
> authority) dictates how a given URI is composed, then it should be perfectly
> fine to extract information out of the URI.

Yep. Low cohesion, high coupling. But it works for now.

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3244
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 17:22:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

Out of curiousity, are there any spec (or what have you) out that that
adress this?  Specifically, I am talking about the ability for a URI
authority to indicate in a computer-readable format the composition rules of
a given URI?  For instance, suppose there was a document that looked
something like (loosely based on regex):

https?://example.invalid/(isbn)
isbn = {regex pattern for ISBNs}

This would have two uses:

1) Allows the client to infer structure and create "valid" URIs that were
not explicitly given to them by the server.
2) Be able to extract information out or URIs that are explicitly given to
them by the server (obviously with a bit of human help).

If Jon had been given something like the above, he could have just told his
program to find the part that matches "isbn".  If Amazon chose to change the
(preferably, add a new) URI pattern to something like:

https?::/example.invalid/somepath/(isbn)/(nuflag)
isbn = {regex pattern for ISBNs}
nuflag = "new" | "used"

Jon's program would keep working because it still new where to find the
appropriate information.  This would allow looser coupling and high
cohesion.  Just a thought....

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

> > that will break his technique.  Had Amazon said "one can extract ISBNs
from
> > our URIs thus", then no one would be saying that what Jon did was a
hack.

server's
> > authority) dictates how a given URI is composed, then it should be
perfectly
> > fine to extract information out of the URI.
>

Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> Out of curiousity, are there any spec (or what have you) out that that
> adress this?  Specifically, I am talking about the ability for a URI
> authority to indicate in a computer-readable format the composition rules of
> a given URI?  For instance, suppose there was a document that looked
> something like (loosely based on regex):
> [...] 
> Jon's program would keep working because it still new where to find the
> appropriate information.  This would allow looser coupling and high
> cohesion.  Just a thought....

I don't think there is, but there should be; it would be useful. The 
biggest problem would be trying to avoid inventing URI Markup 
Language instead of a tidy notation like XPath, or some invariants 
applied to a regex as you did.

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3246
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 17:55:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] rest toolkit on the client side
Message:

(I posted this earlier, but as far as I could tell it did not go
through.  Excuse me if it's a double post.)

Donald Ball wrote:

> I'm trying to convince a group of fellow employees that they
> should develop an internal webapp RESTfully instead of using
> SOAP/XML-RPC and friends. The client in this context isn't a web
> browser but instead a java application. One argument in favor of
> SOAP is that the java toolkits, client and server, are pretty
> good, while with RESTful HTTP, the server toolkits are pretty
> good while clients aren't so much.
> 
> Do y'all buy this argument? Can anyone recommend a very good HTTP
> client for RESTful application development in java?

Asking for a toolkit suggests that you need/want several individual
tools.  You might want to begin by specifying the need for each
tool.  Let me give it a start:

1. Negotiate with the host/server -- Specify the headers. Specify
  the verb (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE). Make the HTTP request.  Get
  the response, the response code, the content.

2. Parse and process the content delivered by the server (i.e. the
  REST application) -- If the content is XML, this means using an
  XML parser and possibly translating the XML content into
  instances of classes in the native programming language.

3. Generate the content to be uploaded to the server (e.g. the
  content for POST requests) -- For example, if the information to
  be uploaded is contained in instances of classes in the
  programming language, then translate (export) these instances to
  XML or "extract" XML from them.

4. In some cases the client application will need to communicate
  with warm fingers and eyeballs -- Create a GUI to show content to
  the user, to accept input from the user, etc. A GUI toolkit, a
  form designer, etc would be helpful here.

The up-side of SOAP is that it does #1, #2, and #3 above for you. 
The down-side is (1) a severe restriction in flexibility and (2) a
large amount of specification creep and complexity growth.
Although, given enough companies producing enough specs (and
complexity), they may fix the restrictions.

For me, working in Python, negotiating with the host (#1 above) is
pretty easy, since there is a standard module (httplib) to help me. 
I'm guessing that Java has equivalent classes.  (Actually, a
subsequent follow-up argued that Java's support in this area is
weak.  I can't believe that.)

Also, parsing the content and generating content (#2 and #3) are
relatively easy, because I have an XML toolkit (PyXML) and I also
have a tool that I've written myself that turns XML Schema document
definitions into classes that can parse and represent an XML
document.  If you think this is what you need, you might want to
read about it and what it does, even though it is Python specific. 
Information is at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/#generateDS
    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/generateDS.html
        
And, I'm still thinking about the GUI stuff.

What other needs does a client and a client developer have? I'm
hoping that others will add ideas to this list of needs and tools
for client-side REST.  After all, recognizing and specifying out
needs is the first step toward filling them.  Or, as a psychiatrist
would tell you, admitting that you are ill is the first step toward
recovery (and paying the psychiatrist, of course).

  - Dave

-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3247
Sender:"inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...>" <inthedarkplace@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 19:05:51
Subject:Re: opaqueness of URI
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@s...> 
wrote:
> Out of curiousity, are there any spec (or what have you) out that 
that
> adress this?  Specifically, I am talking about the ability for a URI
> authority to indicate in a computer-readable format the composition 
rules of
> a given URI?  For instance, suppose there was a document that looked
> something like (loosely based on regex):
> 
> https?://example.invalid/(isbn)
> isbn = {regex pattern for ISBNs}

Personally, I think is an absolutely terrible idea and leads to 
interfaces just as brittle as an RPC system. The best way to 
implement this functionality, (at least the way I do it) is to use a 
redirecting query ie

GET /example.com/somepath/?isbn={isbn}&nuflag={nuflag}

This should return a 302 Redirect who's location header is then the 
real URL, http://example.com/somepath/{isbn}/{nuflag}.

Using redirecting queries is a lot more flexible then 'parameterized' 
URLs since it keeps the full URL-resoultion strategy on the server 
where it belongs. Also, queries are logical constructs which do not 
change while URLs  can change at any time (under heavy load, some 
webservices will migrate resources to another machine). This also 
allows people to throw together quick scripting hacks like Udell's. 

(I would hardly call John's lookup anything other than a hack. It'll 
break as soon as Amazon changes its URLs, something he has no control 
over).

Unfortunately, I really have to disagree Roy on this. There's 
absolutely nothing with human readable resources--in fact they should 
be encouraged--but URI opaqueness is fundamental and very important 
to building flexible systems. The only thing a client should be doing 
to a URL is applying the basic verbs (GET,PUT,POST,etc) to it. It's 
just a locator. Machines aren't as smart as humans. 

- Buko O.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3248
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 19:15:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>

> Specifically, I am talking about the ability for a URI
> authority to indicate in a computer-readable format the composition rules
of
> a given URI?

Like this:

-- document from http://library.example.foo/lookupService/ --
<form method='GET' action='books'>
<input name='isbn'>
</form>

This results in the URI pattern of:
 http://library.example.foo/lookupService/books/?isbn=$value$


 The problem is that nobody knows what 'isbn' means. If we add an attribute
like 'class' or 'type', then Google will be able to tell us all the URI
patterns that support injecting values of a certain type - like ISBN
numbers. Or automobile VINs. Or UPC codes. Or telephone numbers. Or email
addresses. etc.

For example:
<form method='GET' action='books'>
<input name='isbn' class='industry-acceptable-identifier-for-ISBN-concept'>
</form>

Of course, I'd like to have a more rich language that specifies not just a
URI, but a full HTTP request - the method, request-uri, headers, content,
etc. Maybe if we added another attribute on <input> as to what the target
is - where to inject the value - then a client could programmatically
generate the appropriate request.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3249
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 19:28:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] opaqueness of URI
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>

> Yah, I thought long and hard about this recently due to Jon Udell's
> ISBN-in-the-URI javascript hack.  There's no denying the value in that.

There are two aspects to what Jon Udell did that make it work - parsing a
URI and having two services share a common value space.
The sharing a common value space part hasn't been discussed much, but I
think it is an important piece of building network based applications across
organizational boundaries.

In my experience, developers tend to expose internal keys of whatever
database they are using for their application. This is because it makes
sense for the local application and is fast. If you have a URI of
http://localhost/viewstory.jsp?storyId=777 then parsing integers and using
integers for primary keys is fast and keeps the db tables small.
But if you have another 'key' that could possibly be used - like SSN, ISBN,
zip code, etc. - this would help integrate with other systems that also use
or understand those types of values. Storing long textual values as a
primary key might be a practice avoided by db designers, but when looking at
the larger scope of the system (outside a single server or department) it
might bring more benefits. There also might be implementation tricks that
minimize the performance and storage problems of large primary keys.

These are just some rough thoughts I've had for a while & the Library Lookup
bookmarklet makes a great discussion point.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3250
Sender:Gustaf Liljegren <gustaf.liljegren@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-11 18:40:50
Subject:URN
Message:

Hello all,

I've recently read about URI and URN in particular. In this homework, I
also stumbled over a few notes entitled "Why HTTP URIs are better than
URNs" on REST Wiki. Right now I can't reach this page (hmm...), and I don't
remember the arguments.

Does it really mean that one should use URL for names as well as addresses?
 Wouldn't it be very confusing if URL gets the meaning of "a web resource,
or possibly a name, who knows?". I like the separation of URL for addresses
and URN for names. The use of meaningless URLs in XML namespaces has shown
to be confusing. From your point of view, is URN a bad/useless technology?

Gustaf





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3251
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-12 02:09:14
Subject:More URI construction for fun and profit
Message:

The SMBmeta proposal is similar to robots.txt - a resource of general
interest is given a well known name.
In this case http://www.smallbiz.foo/smbmeta.xml (rather than
http://www.smallbiz.foo/robots.txt)

What say you all?

===
http://www.trellixtech.com/2003.01.01_arch.html#1042207063747
Friday, January 10, 2003

The SMBmeta proposal
One of the concerns of businesses is having their web site found by
customers. One of the concerns of customers is being able to find an
appropriate set of businesses from which to choose to meet their needs
[...]
The way we do this is with an "smbmeta.xml" file.
The smbmeta.xml file is an XML file stored at the top level of a domain that
contains machine readable information about the business to which the web
site is connected.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3252
Sender:Joe Gregorio <joe@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-12 02:59:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: opaqueness of URI
Message:

inthedarkplace  wrote:

> Unfortunately, I really have to disagree Roy on this. There's 
> absolutely nothing with human readable resources--in fact they should 
> be encouraged--but URI opaqueness is fundamental and very important 
> to building flexible systems. The only thing a client should be doing 
> to a URL is applying the basic verbs (GET,PUT,POST,etc) to it. It's 
> just a locator. Machines aren't as smart as humans. 
> 

I think you have to be clear about the context before talking about
opaqueness. Are you 'constructing' a URI or 'deconstructing' a URI?
If you are deconstructing a URI, like Jon is doing in his ISBN app
then it is fragile and I agree that the URI should be handled
opaquely.

On the other hand if you are constructing a URI I believe it is
fine to do so. For example search engines do this all the time
when they look for your 'robots.txt' file. Your browser also does it
when it looks for 'favicon.ico'.

	-joe

-- 
http://BitWorking.org
http://WellFormedWeb.org

Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-12 05:45:22

Message:

one didn't have Python set up.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3254
Sender:DJ Adams <dj.adams@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-13 10:16:41
Subject:Idempotency & One-time URLs
Message:

I was just discussing an application requirement with my colleague Piers
and we were wondering about one-time URLs (those which only work once for
security/whatever reasons). 

Is the idempotency broken with such a concept, if you want to GET such a
one-time URL?

This is similar to the earlier question (last year) about Google's 1000 
hit daily restriction, but I was wondering if anyone could offer their
opinion on this flavour of the question...

Thanks very much
DJ





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3255
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-13 12:51:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Idempotency & One-time URLs
Message:

DJ Adams wrote,
> I was just discussing an application requirement with my colleague
> Piers and we were wondering about one-time URLs (those which only
> work once for security/whatever reasons).
>
> Is the idempotency broken with such a concept, if you want to GET
> such a one-time URL?

I think this depends on whether idempotency is supposed to apply to the 
effect on the resource (ie. a resource state change will occur at most 
once) or the effect on the client (ie. the client sees the same 
response each time). One-time or time-limited URIs seem to be 
consistent with the former, but not the latter.

REST also seems to favour the former interpretation, but, despite some 
heroic attempts by Walden Mathews to shed some light on the issue a few 
months back on this list, it's still unclear what RFC 2616 says about 
it, or even whether RFC 2616 is consistent (IMO, it equivocates between 
the two interpretations).

Cheers,


Miles





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3256
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-13 14:29:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Idempotency & One-time URLs
Message:

DJ,

> I was just discussing an application requirement with my colleague Piers
> and we were wondering about one-time URLs (those which only work once for
> security/whatever reasons). 
> 
> Is the idempotency broken with such a concept, if you want to GET such a
> one-time URL?

From the way you've phrased this, I assume you're concerned about
the "idempotency" property of the GET, above.  GET is "idempotent"
in a trivial way, because it is also "safe" (no side effects).

> 
> This is similar to the earlier question (last year) about Google's 1000 
> hit daily restriction, but I was wondering if anyone could offer their
> opinion on this flavour of the question...

So, is your concern that the GET on a one-retrieval-only resource is
not safe because it causes a state change?  I think the answer to that
depends on whether the client uses GET intending to unmap the
resource.  If it's purely a server-side effect, then the semantics of GET
are left intact.  That'd be my interpretation, given the info you
presented.

Walden

Subject:[article] Udell: Services and Links
Message:

http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/webservices/2003/01/13/udell.html

A well-written piece from Jon Udell on the smart coordination of 
resources to create a novel resource.

Oliver

Post ID:3258

Subject:Static or Dynamic URI's
Message:

Hi,

  Should the URI be static or can it be Dynamic too. 
For example if I want to get a object from the
database, if I know the key of the object then can I
send the key of the object in the URI instead of
sending in the message.

like 
http://server:port/addressbook/SSN


Thanks
bud

http://mailplus.yahoo.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3259
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-14 19:46:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URN
Message:

On Sat, Jan 11, 2003 at 07:40:50PM +0100, Gustaf Liljegren wrote:
> Does it really mean that one should use URL for names as well as addresses?

I'll give my 2c on that indirectly.  It means that all URI are just
identifiers, and can be used as names or locators in different
contexts.

There are two important reasons why I believe this is the case.

1.  A URI that cannot be dereferenced is pretty much useless.
That doesn't mean "answers GET", it means that if you can't interact
with what it identifies, then you don't know, authoritatively, what it
identifies.

2.  Any dereferencable URI will include a string for which an
algorithm exists which will map the string to an IP/port tuple.  That
doesn't mean that the string has anything to do with location.  For
example, the URI http://www.markbaker.ca/ is commonly called a URL
because of the mapping between "http", "www.markbaker.ca", and port 80
on 207.236.3.141.  Yet, if that mapping had been tweaked such that the
URI was foo:markbaker-ca, would people still call that a URL because it
doesn't look like a DNS name, even though the algorithm uses DNS after
some inconsequential syntactical morph?  How is that different than
urn:ietf:...?  I suggest that it isn't.

>  Wouldn't it be very confusing if URL gets the meaning of "a web resource,
> or possibly a name, who knows?". I like the separation of URL for addresses
> and URN for names.

I just like identifiers.

> The use of meaningless URLs in XML namespaces has shown
> to be confusing.

True, but I haven't yet seen that it's caused any interoperability
problems.

> From your point of view, is URN a bad/useless technology?

Pretty much.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3260
Sender:"Josh Knowles" <josh.knowles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-14 20:12:07
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Static or Dynamic URI's
Message:

Adding the key to the url is the preferred way to do it.  Then you
reference all get/delete/post/put 's directly to that url.
 
Josh

Post ID:3262
Sender:John <buddy1908@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-15 21:37:13
Subject:problem setting the RequestParameters
Message:

Hi,

  I am facing some problems when I set attribute name
and values using
HttpConnection.setRequestProperty("name","value").
When I print out the names at servlet side using 
ServletRequest.getHeaderNames(), it prints out all the
headers which I have set at the client side but the
corresponding values are null.

code:

URL url = new URL(uri);
		    HttpURLConnection connection =
(HttpURLConnection) url.openConnection();
		    connection.setRequestMethod("GET");
        connection.setAllowUserInteraction(true);
        connection.setDoInput(true);
        connection.setDoOutput(true);
       
connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type","HTML");
       
connection.setRequestProperty("Uname",userName);
       
connection.setRequestProperty("PWord",password);
            
        connection.connect();

output at the server side when I print out all the
attribute names and values( values were printed out
using request.getParameterName("attributeName");

enum 0 Content-Type the value = null
enum 1 UName the value = null
enum 2 PWord the value = null
enum 3 Content-Length the value = null
enum 4 User-Agent the value = null
enum 5 Host the value = null
enum 6 Accept the value = null
enum 7 Connection the value = null

I was able to retrieve Content-Type value using
request.getContentType().
I tried doing a POST instead of GET but there was no
change in the behaviour.

I don't know what I am doing wrong here. Any
suggestions??

Thanks.

__________________________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Mail Plus - Powerful. Affordable. Sign up now.
http://mailplus.yahoo.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3263
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-15 22:33:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] problem setting the RequestParameters
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "John" <buddy1908@...>

The Java HTTP client method of setRequestProperty() is used to set headers -
like Content-Type, Accept, Authorization, User-Agent, etc.
The Java Servlet method of getParameter() is used to get URL query terms for
GET methods and body content for POST methods (where the Content-Type is
'application/x-www-form-urlencoded').
So, you do not use setRequestProperty() in order to have values read by
request.getParameter().

Also, you shouldn't be sending username and password outside of the
Authorization request header - that's what the header is for (unless the
username is not the identifier of the client but some sort of resource
identifier).

You probably also do not want to set doOutput(true) for GET requests.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3264
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-15 22:11:53
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] problem setting the RequestParameters
Message:

Your problem is actually getting them.  For headers 
you need to use:

	request.getHeader("attributeName"); 

-Jeff
 
-----Original Message-----
From: John [mailto:buddy1908@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, January 15, 2003 4:37 PM
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com

Post ID:3265
Sender:"Yannick Loiseau" <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-16 10:02:00
Subject:Linking...
Message:

Hello all,

What are the xml stuffs to link documents? More precisely, how to indicate
in a ressource related ressources, for other actions (where to post, etc.)
for metadata, etc. Here is what i know, but I think there are other
solutions:
    o Link element: in xhtml, rss... one issue is that (as far as I know)
there is no standard values for the rel attribute.
    o xhtml anchors (same problem as link)
    o rdf, with rdf:about
    o xlink: again, the relation type is not clear
    o rddl: work only with xhtml
    o wsdl, wrdl, etc. : links are centralized in a external ressource
    o user define xml element : not standardized
So what kind of link do you use?
One of my problem is to add linking possibility to a xml vocabulary which
don't include it, and that I can't modify.
More precisely, XBEL (bookmarks)  is a hierarchical representation, and i
wan to turn it into a succession of "one-level" ressources, with links to
subressources.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3266
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-16 18:33:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Linking...
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Yannick Loiseau" <yloiseau@...>

I think PaulP may be able to help - he's a linking guru.

> One of my problem is to add linking possibility to a xml vocabulary which
> don't include it, and that I can't modify.
Can your consumers handle new elements and attributes that are not specified
by the vocabulary?

> More precisely, XBEL (bookmarks)  is a hierarchical representation, and i
> wan to turn it into a succession of "one-level" ressources, with links to
> subressources.
Do you want to maintain the knowledge that some nodes are linked to external
resources, or do you want to accumulate the data into a single
representation?
I suggest maintaining the linking information, so if you modify the
retrieved data, you can serialize it back out to update the corresponding
resource.

Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>

Subject:Small project I'm working on...
Message:

I've been working on a small project off and on to provide notification
services to individuals and affiliates.
Basically this site monitors Google for results to a web or news search and
emails the subscribed user when new results show up.
I'm looking for feedback on the site, features and 'automation' features
(web services) that people may like to see.

Take a look and let me know what you think.
http://www.searchalert.net/

Mike





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3268
Sender:Jan Algermissen <algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-19 11:05:37
Subject:URI fragment identifiers and Topic Map PSIs
Message:

Hi,

in the Topic Maps community it is an established praxis to use URIs
that contain fragment identifiers for identifying concepts [1].

Now that I am slowly discovering the principles behind the Web I
realize and understand that this is actually a bad idea [2].

As long is I am absolutely not contrained in the way I create the
URIs I intend to use as names for concepts I see no problem in
using

                 http://www.pets.org/dog

rather than

                 http://www.pets.org/pets.html#dog

to identify the concept 'dog'.


But it will often be the case that one wants to use a parts of a single
document that has been published online to identify concepts. Consider the
concepts 'the 1st Amendment of the US Constitution' and 'the 2nd Amendment
of the US Constitution': it is likely that URIs like

          
          http://www.usconstitution.net/const.html#Am2

will be used as identifiers for them.

I am wondering how to make use of the structure of the document
currently living at http://www.usconstitution.net/const.html and
to adhere to the Web principles at the same time.

Suppose I am the authority that owns http://www.usconstitution.net and
I want to publish names (URIs) for the (concepts of the) amendments of
the US constitution to enable users or semantc web technologies to
make statements about these concepts. Do you think it would be a good
solution to publish URIs such as

          
          http://www.usconstitution.net/constitution/amendments/1
          http://www.usconstitution.net/constitution/amendments/2

and to set up a system on the server that would use const.html and
maybe XSLT transformations to resolve these URIs to representations
that contain the corresponding sections extracted from the large HTML
document?

What about the idea to include links to /const.html#Am1 and /const.html#Am2
in these representations to let humans view the amendment 'in context'?



Within the Topic Maps community the whole issue of fragment identifiers
and URIs that are indended as names isn't yet recognized and we (the community)
are actually promoting this as some sort of 'best practice' or 'this is
how you do it'. (see for example [1]).

I'd really like to come up with a technical solution that enables URI publishing
authorities to use URIs without fragment identifiers but at the same time to
use the internal structure of their documents to return representations that
let humans understand what the published URIs are names for.

Any thoughts about this are very welcome.

Jan


[1] http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/tm-pubsubj/
[2] http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2003Jan/0148.html


-- 
Jan Algermissen                           http://www.topicmapping.com
Consultant & Programmer	                  http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3269
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-19 16:57:03
Subject:InstaBlog = SearchAlert + RESTLog? (was: Re: [rest-discuss] Small project I'm working on...)

Mike,

I'm having problems trying to active the service.  I'm getting a 404 at
http://www.searchalert.net/searchalert/users/activate.jsp. I'm looking
forward to seeing what you have here.

But I actually had a couple of comments and questions:

Comments:

1. Have you considered allowing people to register blog accounts?  The idea
is that you get a story of interest based on a user's subscriptions, dress
the story up in RSS syntax, then POST it to the users registered URL via
RESTLog.

A person's weblog could be getting automatically updated:  InstaBlog.

2. Is there anyway to have the pure XML returned by from Google on your
return mailed to the registered account?

3. If 2 is possible, it would be nice to have a registered XSLT stylesheet
processing instruction glued on the top.

4. Is it possible to register for digest (i.e., newspaper :)) format? Given
enough stories, that match the subscription and a little HTML window 
dressing, each morning there could be a newspaper waiting for you on 
you doorstop (email account.)

Question:

How are you handling Google on your end?  Do you use the SOAP API? How do
you deal with the 1000 hits/day issue?


Thanks,

Jeff

Post ID:3270
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-19 19:59:29
Subject:Re: InstaBlog = SearchAlert + RESTLog? (was: Re: [rest-discuss] Small project I'm working on...)
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jeffrey Winter" <jeffreywinter@...>


>
> I'm having problems trying to active the service.  I'm getting a 404 at
> http://www.searchalert.net/searchalert/users/activate.jsp. I'm looking
> forward to seeing what you have here.

should be resolved now.
I'll find out what's up with that 404...

>
> But I actually had a couple of comments and questions:
>
> Comments:
>
> 1. Have you considered allowing people to register blog accounts?
Yes. I want to incorporate multiple source types (google web, google news,
blogdex, amazon products, ebay listings, etc.) and multiple destination
types (html mail, xml mail, pager, http POST, etc.).

> The idea is that you get a story of interest based on a user's
subscriptions, dress
> the story up in RSS syntax, then POST it to the users registered URL via
> RESTLog.
>
> A person's weblog could be getting automatically updated:  InstaBlog.
Yeah - I'll take a look at the various blogging apis. I'd probably use
Google news as the source, or actually just provide a checkbox list of
sources and let the user decide. Power to the people, and all that.

>
> 2. Is there anyway to have the pure XML returned by from Google on your
> return mailed to the registered account?
I'm actually doing scraping with regular expressions. The XML from Google
requires a developer ID (which I have) but is limited to 1000 per day.
If you register as an affiliate, I currently provide a template for the mail
notification body - you can make it whatever XML you want. The mail
content-type header still says 'text/html' but I can add a choice for that.

>
> 3. If 2 is possible, it would be nice to have a registered XSLT stylesheet
> processing instruction glued on the top.
You can edit the template to add that if you like.

>
> 4. Is it possible to register for digest (i.e., newspaper :)) format?
> Given enough stories, that match the subscription and a little HTML window
dressing,
> each morning there could be a newspaper waiting for you on you doorstop
(email account.)
Someday... that adds more processing and state & I haven't gone there yet.
Hmm... maybe it's not that hard... add a column for each delivery mode and
set the value based on whether it's been delivered... code another agent...
hmm... time for a new pot of coffee...

I'm in the mode of finding users/customers & then I'll prioritize features.
I'd like the system to get rich and flexible enough to build this newspaper
type system without my code knowing too much about the use it will be put
to.

>
> Question:
>
> How are you handling Google on your end?
> Do you use the SOAP API? How do you deal with the 1000 hits/day issue?
No, I just do an HTTP GET and use regular expressions. Until I want more
metadata I'll keep it at that. When I move to the richer API, I'll have to
talk to Google & do something. I"m hoping to get some users first...

>
> Thanks,
Thank you! Keep the ideas coming.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3271
Sender:"kimberliewinter <jeffreywinter@...>" <jeffreywinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-20 19:51:17
Subject:RFC: A REST API for XBEL (& RSS?)
Message:

I've been working on a project to create a REST API for working
with the XBEL schema. The XBEL schema is nominally for use with
bookmarks but it has a fairly generic hierarchical representation
that could be used with for other applications, such as weblog
organization and tranformation to RSS. It's at the point where
it can be looked at and commented on. I would welcome any
feedback that people have.

I've tried to follow my understanding of REST as closely as
possible, so any comments with regards to the interface itself
would be greatly appreciated.

I'm giving it the name "Rebel" for, a RE(ST API for X)BEL, not
because there's anything particularly rebellious about it, but
because I couldn't think of anything else that sounded better.
It's currently implemented in Java as a Servlet.

I think there are interesting things that can be done with the
information when it is stored in this way, beyond simply storing
and managing bookmarks.

The details are here: http://www.xefer.com/rebel

Thanks,

Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3272
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <jeffreywinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-20 19:18:46
Subject:RFC: A REST API for XBEL (& RSS?)
Message:

Ive been working on a project to create a REST API for working
with the XBEL schema. The XBEL schema is nominally for use with
bookmarks but it has a fairly generic hierarchical representation
that could be used with for other applications, such as weblog
organization and tranformation to RSS. Its at the point where
it can be looked at and commented on. I would welcome any
feedback that people have.

I've tried to follow my understanding of REST as closely as
possible, so any comments with regards to the interface itself
would be greatly appreciated.

Im giving it the name Rebel for, a RE(ST API for X)BEL, not
because theres anything particularly rebellious about it, but
because I couldnt think of anything else that sounded better.
It's currently implemented in Java as a Servlet.

I think there are interesting things that can be done with the
information when it is stored in this way, beyond simply storing
and managing bookmarks.

The details are here: http://www.xefer.com/rebel

Thanks,

Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3273
Sender:Dan Brickley <danbri@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-20 21:04:52
Subject:fwd: ANN: Joseki, an RDF server. v1.0
Message:

[ Attachment content not displayed ]

Post ID:3274
Sender:"Yannick Loiseau" <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-20 22:15:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RFC: A REST API for XBEL (& RSS?)
Message:

I'm also working on a rest service for xbel (i've ask some questions about
it on the list, specialy for hyerarchical ressources and links). My API is
quite the same, but the server part is yet very simple (just a dump of a
MySQL DB in PHP). I'm more actively working on a wxPython client.
As i build a full hierarchical tree in a left panel  (explorer-like) i've
decided to transmit all the hierarchical xbel file to minimize connexions. I
try to keep service root URI and the kind of parameters parameters
(bookmarks?folder=123 or bookmarks/folders/123 or bookmarks/123; as my
server is simply a php prototype, I use query parameters) flexibles in a
config file,  to be compliant with any implementation, but the client
(human) has to do the job. I'd like to create a serverside configfile (rddl,
wsl ???) to make it easier.

Any comments ?


----- Original Message -----
From: <jeffreywinter@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, January 20, 2003 8:51 PM
Subject: [rest-discuss] RFC: A REST API for XBEL (& RSS?)


> I've been working on a project to create a REST API for working
> with the XBEL schema. The XBEL schema is nominally for use with
> bookmarks but it has a fairly generic hierarchical representation
> that could be used with for other applications, such as weblog
> organization and tranformation to RSS. It's at the point where
> it can be looked at and commented on. I would welcome any
> feedback that people have.
>
> I've tried to follow my understanding of REST as closely as
> possible, so any comments with regards to the interface itself
> would be greatly appreciated.
>
> I'm giving it the name "Rebel" for, a RE(ST API for X)BEL, not
> because there's anything particularly rebellious about it, but
> because I couldn't think of anything else that sounded better.
> It's currently implemented in Java as a Servlet.
>
> I think there are interesting things that can be done with the
> information when it is stored in this way, beyond simply storing
> and managing bookmarks.

>
