-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3275
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 04:55:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URI fragment identifiers and Topic Map PSIs
Message:

On Sun, Jan 19, 2003 at 12:05:37PM +0100, Jan Algermissen wrote:
> I'd really like to come up with a technical solution that enables URI publishing
> authorities to use URIs without fragment identifiers but at the same time to
> use the internal structure of their documents to return representations that
> let humans understand what the published URIs are names for.
> 
> Any thoughts about this are very welcome.

I find it useful to think of documents like this as compound documents
where a representation of it is comprised of a representation of other
resources.  In that context, it's pretty obvious that you just need a
means of providing a URI that identifies the resource that some
particular document sub-tree happens to represent, ala;

<a id="Am2" resource="http://www.usconstitution.net/amendment/2">

I think that "rdf:about" should work in place of "resource", but I don't
know enough about the whole HTML/RDF integration issue to know if there's
any gotchas there (parsetype, etc..).

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3276
Sender:"inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...>" <inthedarkplace@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 10:39:55
Subject:POST and Authentication
Message:

Often time, the user uses POST to create a new resource. This resource
creation often requires authentication. HTTP authentication, which is
challenge-response, conflicts with this; if the user POSTs a
relatively large resource entity and the server challenges, the entity
is lost. What to do in this scenario? How are others solving this problem?

- itdp





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3277
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 11:07:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] POST and Authentication
Message:

inthedarkplace wrote,
> Often time, the user uses POST to create a new resource. This
> resource creation often requires authentication. HTTP authentication,
> which is challenge-response, conflicts with this; if the user POSTs a
> relatively large resource entity and the server challenges, the
> entity is lost. What to do in this scenario? How are others solving
> this problem?

Lost? Only if the client discards it before reposting with 
authentication.

If it's a problem keeping a large POST entity around during the 
challenge-response you could investigate 100 Continue (see RFC 2616 
8.2.3). The client can add an Accept: 100-continue request header and 
pause before generating and sending the request entity. If the POST is 
authenticated (or no auth is required) the server will respond with a 
100 Continue response and the client can proceed with the request 
entity. OTOH if auth is required the server will respond with a 401 
Unauthorized and client can terminate the request without ever 
generating or sending the request entity.

I believe that server support for 100 Continue is fairly good. 
Unfortunately client support is pretty patchy (I'm pretty sure it's not 
supported by the standard Java HTTP client) but clients with support do 
exist. Not sure what the situation is with proxies tho'.

Cheers,


Miles





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3278
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 15:22:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] POST and Authentication
Message:

From: <inthedarkplace@...>
>
> Often time, the user uses POST to create a new resource. This resource
> creation often requires authentication. HTTP authentication, which is
> challenge-response, conflicts with this; if the user POSTs a
> relatively large resource entity and the server challenges, the entity
> is lost. What to do in this scenario? How are others solving this problem?

First, the only reason you would lose the entity is if the client did not
resend the POST request with the entity in response to the 401.  A few
thoughts come to mind on how to get around the large entity problem (note
that I don't have a feel for the RESTfulness of these ideas):

1) If the URI requires authentication regardless of the verb used, start
with a GET or HEAD to force authentication, returning a 204 (or something
appropriate).  Afterwards, use POST.

2) Variation on #1: have the GET return a unique URI that could be used for
a PUT such that the end result would be the same as a POST that returns the
same URI.

3) Start by POSTing a small placeholder entity.  Once the new URI is
returned, use a PUT to set the resource as you actually want it to be.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3279
Sender:"inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...>" <inthedarkplace@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 15:54:30
Subject:Re: POST and Authentication
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Miles Sabin <miles@m...> wrote:
> inthedarkplace wrote,
> > Often time, the user uses POST to create a new resource. This
> > resource creation often requires authentication. HTTP authentication,
> > which is challenge-response, conflicts with this; if the user POSTs a
> > relatively large resource entity and the server challenges, the
> > entity is lost. What to do in this scenario? How are others solving
> > this problem?
> 
> Lost? Only if the client discards it before reposting with 
> authentication.
> 
> If it's a problem keeping a large POST entity around during the 
> challenge-response you could investigate 100 Continue (see RFC 2616 
> 8.2.3). The client can add an Accept: 100-continue request header and 
> pause before generating and sending the request entity. If the POST is 
> authenticated (or no auth is required) the server will respond with a 
> 100 Continue response and the client can proceed with the request 
> entity. OTOH if auth is required the server will respond with a 401 
> Unauthorized and client can terminate the request without ever 
> generating or sending the request entity.
> 
> I believe that server support for 100 Continue is fairly good. 
> Unfortunately client support is pretty patchy (I'm pretty sure it's not 
> supported by the standard Java HTTP client) but clients with support do 
> exist. Not sure what the situation is with proxies tho'.

I had hope--100 Continue seemed like an elegant solution--but I don't
think it can be used here. Really, the only valid responses of
'Expect: 100-continue' is '417 Expectation Failed' and '100 Continue'.
It can't be used for preauthentication.

- itdp





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3280
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 16:09:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: POST and Authentication
Message:

"inthedarkplace wrote,
> I had hope--100 Continue seemed like an elegant solution--but I don't
> think it can be used here. Really, the only valid responses of
> 'Expect: 100-continue' is '417 Expectation Failed' and '100
> Continue'. It can't be used for preauthentication.

Yes it can, that's one of the the things is was designed for.

From 8.2.3,

  The purpose of the 100 (Continue) status (see section 10.1.1) is to
  allow a client that is sending a request message with a request body
  to determine if the origin server is willing to accept the request
  (based on the request headers) before the client sends the request
  body. In some cases, it might either be inappropriate or highly
  inefficient for the client to send the body if the server will reject
  the message without looking at the body.

Ie. in the absence of an (or an incorrect) Authentication: header it 
would be inappropriate and inefficient for the client to send a 
redundant request entity.

Then later in the same section,

  Requirements for HTTP/1.1 origin servers:

      - Upon receiving a request which includes an Expect request-header
        field with the "100-continue" expectation, an origin server MUST
        either respond with 100 (Continue) status and continue to read
        from the input stream, or respond with a final status code. The
        origin server MUST NOT wait for the request body before sending
        the 100 (Continue) response. If it responds with a final status
        code, it MAY close the transport connection or it MAY continue
        to read and discard the rest of the request.  It MUST NOT
        perform the requested method if it returns a final status code.

Where "final status code" means _any_ response status other than 100 
Continue.

(As you spotted, the request header is Expect: 100-continue, not Allow: 
as I said originally).

Cheers,


Miles





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3281
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 16:25:06
Subject:REST Resource Discovery
Message:

I've seen it said on this list and elsewhere that
REST means that a URL is all one needs to know to
interact with a resource.  This sounds appealing,
but I have not seen a document specifying the
conventions necessary to achieve this.

Questions that I think need to be answered:
1. How do you know what MIME-types one may POST or
PUT to a given resource?

My proposal is that servers return accept-POST and
accept-PUT headers in response to GET requests,
however these headers are not actually defined
in any standard so perhaps there is another
approach.  An issue with this approach is that it
implies that it is incorrect to have a resource
to which one is permitted to POST but not GET.
so...

2. Is it permitted to have a resource that exposes
POST but not GET?

3. What is the correct RESTful response to a POST
or PUT?

My feeling is that if one returns a 200 OK, one
should return the result of a GET to that
resource.  Otherwise return 204, or 201 or 303
with the relevant URLs.  Is that correct?

4. How does one achieve transactional semantics
with REST?

Perhaps this is entirely application level.
Create a transaction URL and POST commit to it
when complete.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3282
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 19:02:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>


> Questions that I think need to be answered:
> 1. How do you know what MIME-types one may POST or
> PUT to a given resource?
>
> My proposal is that servers return accept-POST and
> accept-PUT headers in response to GET requests,
> however these headers are not actually defined
> in any standard so perhaps there is another
> approach.

I would like a solution to this problem also, I think it would help promote
REST oriented applications.
There has been some discussion on this list in the past, here is a summary
of the approaches I've heard:

1 Metadata within response content.
This works for HTML, but isn't suitable for unforgiving content like JPG,
GIF, PDF, MS-Word, schema-bound XML, etc.
For a custom app with your own content types, you could use a <meta> or
<head> element to provide the needed info.
Ideally, the metadata would be available via a HEAD method as well, and this
approach doesn't work with that.

2 Metadata within response headers
This is your proposal, to have something like Accept-POST and Accept-PUT
response headers for GET and HEAD.

3 Metadata in a separate resource known to original resource
3.1 Identified by response content
The content can provide the location of the metadata, rather than the
metadata itself. Same problems as #1 (doesn't work for all content types,
etc.)

3.2 Identified by response header
This would be a header something like Meta-Location and would be availble
via GET or HEAD.
Putting metadata in a separate resource allows for content negotiation to
happen on the description of the resource, so we don't get stuck with not
enough metadata in the headers.

4 Metadata in a separate resource but unknown to original resource
This inverts the problem - you have the URL to a resource definition, but
you don't know what the resources are that it applies to. However, you could
explicitly list those resources, or provide a pattern that matches the URI
of the resources the defintion applies to. If you gather enough descriptions
you probably could do the lookup...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3283
Sender:"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 19:11:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Hi Folks,

See here for a discussion of discovering a resource's metadata, and
vice-versa:

   http://www.xfront.com/dist-reg/distributed-registry.html

/Roger

Post ID:3284
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 19:24:38
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Roger,
 
I'm curious about the need for these extension headers you propose.
Isn't that what the OPTIONS method is for?  Shouldn't you be able to do
an OPTIONS request on the resource itself and have whatever meta
information returned?  That way there's no need for two resources with
links back to each other.
 
- Jeff

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3287
Sender:Vincent D.Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 20:56:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URI fragment identifiers and Topic Map PSIs
Message:

On Tuesday, January 21, 2003, at 04:55 AM, Mark Baker wrote:
> I find it useful to think of documents like this as compound documents
> where a representation of it is comprised of a representation of other
> resources.

FWIW, i have held the same view for some time and concur wholeheartedly.

to take a weblog example, i view the front page of a weblog as a 
representation of a resource which combines all the individual entry 
resources, usually ordered on a 'most recent' basis.

> In that context, it's pretty obvious that you just need a
> means of providing a URI that identifies the resource that some
> particular document sub-tree happens to represent, ala;
>
> <a id="Am2" resource="http://www.usconstitution.net/amendment/2">

the place i think this would be most useful (right now at least) is 
referrers (like trackback etc.) on  weblogs.  referrer mechanisms would 
benefit from having a uri such as:

http://blah/weblog/entries/1

rather than

http://blah/weblog

to track back to, regardless of whether the link was followed from the 
weblog front page or the individual entry page.  that way when somebody 
follows the trackback months later and the '5 most recent' front page 
is totally different, only the uri is of the actual entry is relevant 
and hence used.

wouldn't this require user agent support, making it a bitch to 
implement?  or is it just a bad idea.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3288
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 20:58:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: <jeffreywinter@...>



> I'm curious about the need for these extension headers you propose.  Isn't
that
> what the OPTIONS method is for?  Shouldn't you be able to do an OPTIONS
request
> on the resource itself and have whatever meta information returned?  That
way
> there's no need for two resources with links back to each other.
>
Huh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't appropriate... don't know
what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods were
allowed...
This seems like the best approach so far.


Here's the text from the RFC. The only downside is responses are not
cacheable.
====
OPTIONS
The OPTIONS method represents a request for information about the
communication options available on the request/response chain identified by
the Request-URI. This method allows the client to determine the options
and/or requirements associated with a resource, or the capabilities of a
server, without implying a resource action or initiating a resource
retrieval.

Responses to this method are not cacheable.

If the OPTIONS request includes an entity-body (as indicated by the presence
of Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding), then the media type MUST be
indicated by a Content-Type field. Although this specification does not
define any use for such a body, future extensions to HTTP might use the
OPTIONS body to make more detailed queries on the server. A server that does
not support such an extension MAY discard the request body.

If the Request-URI is an asterisk ("*"), the OPTIONS request is intended to
apply to the server in general rather than to a specific resource. Since a
server's communication options typically depend on the resource, the "*"
request is only useful as a "ping" or "no-op" type of method; it does
nothing beyond allowing the client to test the capabilities of the server.
For example, this can be used to test a proxy for HTTP/1.1 compliance (or
lack thereof).

If the Request-URI is not an asterisk, the OPTIONS request applies only to
the options that are available when communicating with that resource.

A 200 response SHOULD include any header fields that indicate optional
features implemented by the server and applicable to that resource (e.g.,
Allow), possibly including extensions not defined by this specification. The
response body, if any, SHOULD also include information about the
communication options. The format for such a

body is not defined by this specification, but might be defined by future
extensions to HTTP. Content negotiation MAY be used to select the
appropriate response format. If no response body is included, the response
MUST include a Content-Length field with a field-value of "0".

The Max-Forwards request-header field MAY be used to target a specific proxy
in the request chain. When a proxy receives an OPTIONS request on an
absoluteURI for which request forwarding is permitted, the proxy MUST check
for a Max-Forwards field. If the Max-Forwards field-value is zero ("0"), the
proxy MUST NOT forward the message; instead, the proxy SHOULD respond with
its own communication options. If the Max-Forwards field-value is an integer
greater than zero, the proxy MUST decrement the field-value when it forwards
the request. If no Max-Forwards field is present in the request, then the
forwarded request MUST NOT include a Max-Forwards field.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3289
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 21:06:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

On Tue, 21 Jan 2003 jeffreywinter@... wrote:
> I'm curious about the need for these extension headers you propose.  Isn't that
> what the OPTIONS method is for?  Shouldn't you be able to do an OPTIONS request
> on the resource itself and have whatever meta information returned?  That way
> there's no need for two resources with links back to each other.

Interesting idea.  RFC2616 is incredibly vague
about exactly how you use OPTIONS.  It is so vague
so as to be unusable as is.

That being said, I like the idea of putting the
meta-data in OPTIONS.

Perhaps we can define a convention here about the
headers and body of an OPTIONS response so as to
make interoperability easy.

Here is the information it would be nice for the
server to be able to send:
* Allow: methods
* Content-Types: available via content-negotiation
* Accept-POST: content types
* Accept-PUT: content types
* Accept-PUT-Charset:
* Accept-POST-Charset:
* Accept-PUT-Encoding:
* Accept-POST-Encoding:
* Accept-PUT-Language:
* Accept-POST-Language:
* WWW-GET-Authenticate:
* WWW-POST-Authenticate:
* WWW-PUT-Authenticate:

My strawman proposal is that the server sends a
200 OK with these headers in response to an
OPTIONS request.  Content-Types would have the
same format as Accept.

An alternative for all the method specific headers
would be to use the non method specific versions
of each of these headers with a method=METHOD
parameter.

Thoughts?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3290
Sender:"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 21:09:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Hi Jeff,

I am not clear on what you are expecting the HTTP OPTIONS method to
return. For example suppose that this is the URL to a Web service
resource that returns a list of parts:

    http://www.parts.com/parts

Now suppose that you do an HTTP OPTIONS to that URL:

    OPTIONS http://www.parts.com/parts

and somehow you specify in the OPTIONS method "give me the service
description".  What do you expect to receive back?  Are you expecting to
receive the service description as the payload of the HTTP OPTIONS
response?  Let's assume that you do get the service description back as
the payload.  Fine.

But, suppose that you have the URL to the service description resource,
e.g., 

    http://www.parts.com/parts/metadata

How would you then get the URL to the service that it describes?

Further, we would like to allow other people to independently provide
metadata about the service (just like today other people can hyperlink
to my Web site, without even my knowledge).  For example, perhaps your
company wishes to use the parts service, but your company needs an RDF
description of the service.  So, independent of the parts service you go
off and create your own RDF description of the parts service.  Here's
your URL:

     http://www.jwinter.com/services/parts/metadata

Now you need some way to link your service description back to the parts
service.  That's the purpose of the Meta-About HTTP header.

To recap, 
- we wanted the metadata document to be a first class object, separate
from the resource it is describing.
- we wanted to enable anyone to provide metadata about the resource,
i.e., distributed resource description
- we needed some way to some way to associate a resource to its
(primary) metadata, and to associate metadata to the resource it is
describing.  For this, we created the Meta-Location and the Meta-About
HTTP headers, respectively.
- we wanted search engines to be able to index resources and metadata
resources using standard HTTP GET.

I hope that helps.  /Roger





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3291
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 21:40:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery

"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...> writes:

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: <jeffreywinter@...>

> 
> 
> > I'm curious about the need for these extension headers you
> > propose.  Isn't that > what the OPTIONS method is for?  Shouldn't
> > you be able to do an OPTIONS request > on the resource itself and
> > have whatever meta information returned?  That way > there's no need
> > for two resources with links back to each other.
> >
> Huh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't appropriate... don't know
> what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods were
> allowed...

OPTIONS can report the allowed methods by responding with the correct
"Allow" header for the resource.


Nic Ferrier





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3292
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-21 22:54:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...> writes:

> I am not clear on what you are expecting the HTTP OPTIONS method to
> return. For example suppose that this is the URL to a Web service
> resource that returns a list of parts:
> 
>     http://www.parts.com/parts
> 
> Now suppose that you do an HTTP OPTIONS to that URL:
> 
>     OPTIONS http://www.parts.com/parts
> 
> and somehow you specify in the OPTIONS method "give me the service
> description".  What do you expect to receive back?  Are you expecting to
> receive the service description as the payload of the HTTP OPTIONS
> response?  Let's assume that you do get the service description back as
> the payload.  Fine.
> 
> But, suppose that you have the URL to the service description resource,
> e.g.,
> 
>     http://www.parts.com/parts/metadata
> 
> How would you then get the URL to the service that it describes?

Could you not return the link to the service in a "Location" header
on the response?

rfc2616 says:

   The Location response-header field is used to redirect the recipient
   to a location other than the Request-URI for completion of the
   request or identification of a new resource.

It doesn't specifically mention this use of the Location header but
I don't see why it couldn't be overloaded like that. That would
require understanding of course.


Possibly a more RESTy solution is to just provide a link in the
entity returned from the metadata request.



> Further, we would like to allow other people to independently provide
> metadata about the service (just like today other people can hyperlink
> to my Web site, without even my knowledge).  For example, perhaps your
> company wishes to use the parts service, but your company needs an RDF
> description of the service.  So, independent of the parts service you go
> off and create your own RDF description of the parts service.  Here's
> your URL:
> 
>      http://www.jwinter.com/services/parts/metadata
> 
> Now you need some way to link your service description back to the
> parts service.  That's the purpose of the Meta-About HTTP header.

Again, that could use "Location" or a link in the returned
description. Couldn't it?


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3293
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 02:49:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
>
> Huh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't appropriate... don't know
> what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods were
> allowed...
> This seems like the best approach so far.
>
>
> Here's the text from the RFC. The only downside is responses are not
> cacheable.
>
> [deleted]
>

Hmm... When the RFC says the response is not cachable, I am wondering if
they have proxies, etc. in mind.  For the client, it seems that caching
would have to be necessary unless the server could guarantee the metadata in
the OPTIONS response won't change for a certain period of time (which is
effectively caching).  Otherwise, the verb is potentially useless...

WRT this thread, you would do an OPTIONS to a URI and get a response back
indicating the POST/PUTable content-types.  Since there is no guarantee that
the allowable types are going to ba allowable a moment later when you do
your actual POST/PUT, then it follows that it making a decision on the
returned metadata a day later would be little different than making a
decision on it a second later.  At worst case, if the resource's metadata
changed between the time the OPTIONS response came back and the client
submitted a request based on the returned metadata, the server would/should
return the appropriate error.  In turn, this would prompt the client to
request the OPTIONS again and see what has changed...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3294
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <jeffreywinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 03:01:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> I am not clear on what you are expecting the HTTP OPTIONS method to
> return. [...]  What do you expect to receive back?  Are you expecting to
> receive the service description as the payload of the HTTP OPTIONS
> response?

I guess that's the point of OPTIONS, I don't know exactly what I'd get
back.  If it's a WSDL, there are tools that can parse it directly; if
it's a text description, there's more work to do.  But in any case,
one could ask exactly the same questions about the metadata even if
it were a separate resource.

Granted, OPTIONS is sort of a dark corner of the web right now, but
as metadata becomes more important with the advent of web services,
perhaps it won't be always be.

> But, suppose that you have the URL to the service description resource,
> e.g.,
>
>     http://www.parts.com/parts/metadata
>
> How would you then get the URL to the service that it describes?
>
> Further, we would like to allow other people to independently provide
> metadata about the service (just like today other people can hyperlink
> to my Web site, without even my knowledge).  For example, perhaps your
> company wishes to use the parts service, but your company needs an RDF
> description of the service.  So, independent of the parts service you go
> off and create your own RDF description of the parts service.  Here's
> your URL:
>
>      http://www.jwinter.com/services/parts/metadata

Instead of having some third party host the metadata - which will inevitably
get out of synch with the resource who's metadata it is (the
OPTIONS method is explicitly non-cacheable for probably just that reason) -
why not just have a link to the resource itself:

  <a href="http://www.jwinter.com/services/parts">Car Parts Web Service</a>

Google would scoop that up even easier.  When you do a search for "Car Parts
Web Service", if enough people have linked to it, it will probably bubble
up to the top anyway.  In either case, you'll be lead to the service itself,
then you request the OPTIONS and away you go.

> Now you need some way to link your service description back to the parts
> service.  That's the purpose of the Meta-About HTTP header.
>
> To recap,
> - we wanted the metadata document to be a first class object, separate
> from the resource it is describing.

Frankly, I prefer the metadata to be tightly bound to the resource it
is describing.

> - we wanted to enable anyone to provide metadata about the resource,
> i.e., distributed resource description

I think this an interesting point, but I'm not sure that it really matters
so long as you are able to ultimately locate the resource.  Again, it's
fine for others to host the metadata, but they are going to have to be
responsible for keeping it in synch and it might be skipped over by a
normal search engine that's more interested in the text (or the
links in Google's case.)

> - we needed some way to some way to associate a resource to its
> (primary) metadata, and to associate metadata to the resource it is
> describing.  For this, we created the Meta-Location and the Meta-About
> HTTP headers, respectively.

Only if you separate them, which granted, is the case today in most
cases.

> - we wanted search engines to be able to index resources and metadata
> resources using standard HTTP GET.

I'm not sure any search engines out there would even parse
and attempt to understand what the metadata even is.  I think my
example above is much more likely to find the service and lead you
to the metadata.

This to me is one of the more insightful statements I've read in
a while:

"On the other hand, I must say that for me in daily life, Google allows
all sorts of useful queries that 5 years ago I thought  would
require the widespread adoption of XML and XML-based format standards
(e.g., for resumes).  Certainly many of the claims/proposals of metadata
advocates 5 years ago look a bit shopworn in hindsight now that we
see how well Google does by ignoring all (most?) metadata other than the
linking patterns." [1]

> I hope that helps.  /Roger

It does.  I think your right on the money with having web service discovery
be a distributed, search-engine based activity as opposed to the UDDI
approach. I just think that current technologies already support this
without
the need to employ extension headers.

[1] http://lists.xml.org/archives/xml-dev/200210/msg01625.html

Post ID:3296
Sender:Joe Gregorio <joe@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 12:45:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Jeffrey Winter wrote:
>>I am not clear on what you are expecting the HTTP OPTIONS method to
>>return. [...]  What do you expect to receive back?  Are you expecting to
>>receive the service description as the payload of the HTTP OPTIONS
>>response?
> 
> 
> I guess that's the point of OPTIONS, I don't know exactly what I'd get
> back.  If it's a WSDL, there are tools that can parse it directly; if
> it's a text description, there's more work to do.  But in any case,
> one could ask exactly the same questions about the metadata even if
> it were a separate resource.

This brings up a question, can you do content negotiation
when doing OPTIONS? That way you could support 
multiple file formats for describing web services. For 
example could you do an OPTIONS call with the header:

Accept: application/wsdl+xml, application/rsd+xml

	-joe

http://BitWorking.org

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3297
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 13:27:23
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:


According to the spec, yes:

"The response body, if any, SHOULD also include information about the
communication options. The format for such a body is not defined by this
specification, but might be defined by future extensions to HTTP.
Content negotiation MAY be used to select the appropriate response
format. If no response body is included, the response MUST include a
Content-Length field with a field-value of "0"."

- Jeff

when doing OPTIONS? That way you could support

example could you do an OPTIONS call with the header:

Post ID:3298
Sender:"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 13:31:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Hi Jeff,

I don't have a lot of time, but I'll make a few, quick comments.

1. Consider a movie.  Is it worth seeing?  If Gene Siskel gives it a
"two thumbs up", will you go see it?  Personally, I would like to see a
number of reviews before making my decision.

- Movie review = metadata
- The movie review from Gene Siskel is your "primary movie review".
- Other reviews supplement the primary movie review. 
- To get a complete, more accurate picture, I want an "aggregator" to
show me a composite picture.
- Metadata certainty is an illusion ... The Illusion of Certainty ...

Now translate all these comments into Web services and metadata about
Web services.  See where I am going with this?

2.  Separation of concerns.  Keep metadata decoupled from the resource. 
This enables you to have many different forms of metadata, and also
enables the distributed metadata implied in 1.

Gotta run.  /Roger


Jeffrey Winter wrote:
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3299
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 15:09:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Roger L. Costello wrote:
> Consider a movie.  Is it worth seeing?  If Gene Siskel gives it a

I think we are mixing two very separate concepts
of metadata.

One type of metadata describes the what or why of
a resource.  This class of metadata is encompassed
by reviews and ratings and handled by search
engines, RDF, and many other systems that go way
beyond the scope of discussion on REST.  It is
entirely dissociable from the resource being
described.

The other type of metadata describes HOW to use
the resource.  For REST, this HOW information is
basically the content-types one may GET PUT or
POST. (Other protocols have more complex
documentation requirements).

I put a strawman proposal on the table for the
later a few days ago.  Is it satisfactory?  Is it
inadequate?  Does someone have a better idea?

Or do people here think these issues are really
inseparable and want to mix them?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3300
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 15:48:20
Subject:OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> Perhaps we can define a convention here about the
> headers and body of an OPTIONS response so as to
> make interoperability easy.
>
> Here is the information it would be nice for the
> server to be able to send:
> * Allow: methods
> * Content-Types: available via content-negotiation
> * Accept-POST: content types
> * Accept-PUT: content types
> * Accept-PUT-Charset:
> * Accept-POST-Charset:
> * Accept-PUT-Encoding:
> * Accept-POST-Encoding:
> * Accept-PUT-Language:
> * Accept-POST-Language:
> * WWW-GET-Authenticate:
> * WWW-POST-Authenticate:
> * WWW-PUT-Authenticate:

I suggest a slightly different format:

verb request-header:value

where:

verb: GET, PUT, POST, etc., and "*" which means any verb (for which the
following request-header is allowed)
request-header: these are headers that it recognizes (e.g. content-type,
user-agent, etc.)
value: indicates an allowable value (following the same rules for the actual
request-header).

Any combination that is not explicitly defined means that the resource
doesn't care about those headers.

So, suppose you encountered a response like:

PUT content-type:text/html
* content-type: application/xml+rss
GET user-agent:Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1)


In this case, this is saying that PUT only allows a content-type of
text/html or application/xml+rss, while all other verbs (in this case POST)
allow only application/xml+rss.  Also, the resource is only GETable by IE6
(or a client that says it's IE6).  Note that no other combination is defined
for user-agent, so it implies that any client can issue a POST, PUT, etc.

It might even do to extend this format slightly to allow the server to
explicitly indicate that it understands a given header name, thereby
allowing new clients to query a server to see if the server can handle the
added features of the client.  I'm not sure how this format would be.  Maybe
just leave the value out of the above string.  Are there any existing
headers where an empty string is a valid value?  If so, we could possibly
leave the colon off.  For instance, suppose there was a new request header
called "my-feature".  The server could return:

* my-feature:  (or without the colon)

to indicate that it knows about this field and handles it according to
whatever semantics it has.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3301
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 17:32:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>

>
> 1. Consider a movie.  Is it worth seeing?  If Gene Siskel gives it a
> "two thumbs up", will you go see it?  Personally, I would like to see a
> number of reviews before making my decision.
For some forms of metadata, you want the authoritative source to be the
resource itself - like what the allowed programmatic interactions are. Other
metadata, like making claims 'about' the resource (asserting that it is a
member of some topic/subject/concept/etc.) benefits from being external and
having multiple sources to varying trust.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3302
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 17:44:49
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

 
OPTIONS requests can respond with a "303 See Other" which could
point to a cacheable stand-alone, metadata document.
 
 

	-----Original Message-----
	From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...] 
	Sent: Tuesday, January 21, 2003 9:50 PM
	To: rest-discuss
	Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
	
	
	From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
	>
	> Huh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't
appropriate... don't know
	> what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods
were
	> allowed...
	> This seems like the best approach so far.
	>
	>
	> Here's the text from the RFC. The only downside is responses
are not
	> cacheable.
	>
	> [deleted]
	>
	
	Hmm... When the RFC says the response is not cachable, I am
wondering if
	they have proxies, etc. in mind.  For the client, it seems that
caching
	would have to be necessary unless the server could guarantee the
metadata in
	the OPTIONS response won't change for a certain period of time
(which is
	effectively caching).  Otherwise, the verb is potentially
useless...
	
	WRT this thread, you would do an OPTIONS to a URI and get a
response back
	indicating the POST/PUTable content-types.  Since there is no
guarantee that
	the allowable types are going to ba allowable a moment later
when you do
	your actual POST/PUT, then it follows that it making a decision
on the
	returned metadata a day later would be little different than
making a
	decision on it a second later.  At worst case, if the resource's
metadata
	changed between the time the OPTIONS response came back and the
client
	submitted a request based on the returned metadata, the server
would/should
	return the appropriate error.  In turn, this would prompt the
client to
	request the OPTIONS again and see what has changed...
	
	---
	Seairth Jacobs
	seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3303
Sender:"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 18:16:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Hi Alex,

"S. Alexander Jacobson" wrote:
> 
> On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Roger L. Costello wrote:
> > Consider a movie.  Is it worth seeing?  If Gene Siskel gives it a
> 
> I think we are mixing two very separate concepts
> of metadata.

I believe that you are missing my point.  Let me quote David Jacobs:

"Metadata about a web service goes beyond a WSDL file, XML Schemas and a
tmodel description.

A web service may have
* a WSDL file
* an HTML description
* XML schema's it returns and accepts
* a DAML-S description
* a reliability rating
* a usefulness rating
* how it can be integrated with other services

Furthermore, while a service provider will often produce a lot of 
service metadata to facilitate its use, they cannot be seen as
objective 
parties when contributing metadata to be used in matchmaking (i.e., is 
this the service I need).  Clearly there is a role for third parties to
add their own metadata about a service in the form of ratings and new 
metadata formats which might increase the service's usefulness for a 
population segment."

My point is that a HOW metadata document is just a small part of the
metadata that you will associate with web service.  Further, even of the
HOW metadata there will be many, many different formats - XHTML, WSDL,
RDF, DAML-S, OWL, etc.  To top it off, all of the many metadata
documents will be distributed across the Web [just like all of the Web
sites that link to your Web page are distributed across the Web].

Bottom line: for a Web service there will be many (many) metadata
documents, spread across the Web.  The key is to provide a "general
mechanism" for associating a metadata document with a web service. 
That's what Meta-Location buys you.  /Roger





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3304
Sender:"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 18:26:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Hi Mike,

> For some forms of metadata, you want the authoritative source to be the
> resource itself - like what the allowed programmatic interactions are.

If I understand you correctly, you are saying that a Web service should
have an "authoritative service description".  I agree!  The
Meta-Location header provides the URL to the service's authoritative
service description.

> Other
> metadata, like making claims 'about' the resource (asserting that it is a
> member of some topic/subject/concept/etc.) benefits from being external and
> having multiple sources to varying trust.

It's more than that. Suppose that my shop is running RDF engines to
enable inductive reasoning, and suppose that the Web service that my
company wants to use just provides an XHTML description.  Thus, my
company creates an RDF description of the Web service - it tells the HOW
of how the use it, and it does it using RDF.  Thus, my company's RDF
description adds value to the Web service, and it does it in a
distributed fashion. /Roger





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3305
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 19:06:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

MessageTrue, but I'm not seeing how this relates to my comments below...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...


----- Original Message -----
From: Jeffrey Winter
To: Seairth Jacobs ; rest-discuss
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 12:44 PM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery



OPTIONS requests can respond with a "303 See Other" which could
point to a cacheable stand-alone, metadata document.


-----Original Message-----
From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
Sent: Tuesday, January 21, 2003 9:50 PM
To: rest-discuss
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery


From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
>
> Huh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't appropriate... don't know
> what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods were
> allowed...
> This seems like the best approach so far.
>
>
> Here's the text from the RFC. The only downside is responses are not
> cacheable.
>
> [deleted]
>

Hmm... When the RFC says the response is not cachable, I am wondering if
they have proxies, etc. in mind.  For the client, it seems that caching
would have to be necessary unless the server could guarantee the metadata in
the OPTIONS response won't change for a certain period of time (which is
effectively caching).  Otherwise, the verb is potentially useless...

WRT this thread, you would do an OPTIONS to a URI and get a response back
indicating the POST/PUTable content-types.  Since there is no guarantee that
the allowable types are going to ba allowable a moment later when you do
your actual POST/PUT, then it follows that it making a decision on the
returned metadata a day later would be little different than making a
decision on it a second later.  At worst case, if the resource's metadata
changed between the time the OPTIONS response came back and the client
submitted a request based on the returned metadata, the server would/should
return the appropriate error.  In turn, this would prompt the client to
request the OPTIONS again and see what has changed...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3306
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 19:28:33
Subject:Re: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

Another feature that would be good would be to have a new HTTP response
header called "options", which would give a comma-separated list of
content-types a given URI can return for an OPTIONS request.  For instance,
suppose you did a GET on a URI.  You get back a response, including the
following line:

options: text/http-request-options, application/rdf+xml,
application/myformat+xml, text/html

(note: "text/http-request-options" is a bogus mime type for my format
described below.)

This would tell the client that it could issue an OPTIONS request with some
or all of the types and the server would return the appropriate one
(presumably the first one if it was from that list).

This would also allow Google to do some neat stuff.  First it would GET the
resource.  Once received, it would see that there were options available for
that resource.  It could then turn around and selectively query with OPTIONS
to find out all sorts of useful information (such as the details of a web
service interface).  Without the header, Google wouldn't even bother, even
if there were OPTIONS to query...

Thoughts?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...


From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
>
> verb request-header:value
>
> where:
>
> verb: GET, PUT, POST, etc., and "*" which means any verb (for which the
> following request-header is allowed)
> request-header: these are headers that it recognizes (e.g. content-type,
> user-agent, etc.)
> value: indicates an allowable value (following the same rules for the
actual
> request-header).
>
> Any combination that is not explicitly defined means that the resource
> doesn't care about those headers.
>
> So, suppose you encountered a response like:
>
> PUT content-type:text/html
> * content-type: application/xml+rss
> GET user-agent:Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1)
>
>
> In this case, this is saying that PUT only allows a content-type of
> text/html or application/xml+rss, while all other verbs (in this case
POST)
> allow only application/xml+rss.  Also, the resource is only GETable by IE6
> (or a client that says it's IE6).  Note that no other combination is
defined
> for user-agent, so it implies that any client can issue a POST, PUT, etc.
>
> It might even do to extend this format slightly to allow the server to
> explicitly indicate that it understands a given header name, thereby
> allowing new clients to query a server to see if the server can handle the
> added features of the client.  I'm not sure how this format would be.
Maybe
> just leave the value out of the above string.  Are there any existing
> headers where an empty string is a valid value?  If so, we could possibly
> leave the colon off.  For instance, suppose there was a new request header
> called "my-feature".  The server could return:
>
> * my-feature:  (or without the colon)
>
> to indicate that it knows about this field and handles it according to
> whatever semantics it has.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3307
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 19:47:06
Subject:Re: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

I like your version of the format quite a lot.
The only thing I'd like to see in it that is
missing is some way of finding out what
content-types are available via
content-negotiation.

Content-Types: <same format as accept>
Encodings: <same format as accept-encodings>

Regarding the options header on GET, I like that
as a concept, but the practice makes me nervous.
I'd like to avoid a proliferation of file formats
for this sort of thing.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Post ID:3308
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 19:50:50
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Sorry, what I meant was that if there was some concern
that since OPTIONS can't be cached and it would be possible
that the metadata could be out of date by the time you
actually went to use the service, one possible way to deal
with that is to redirect the OPTIONS call using a a 303,
which changes the call into a GET which could be made cachable.
An Expires: timestamp would indicate how long that metadata is
gauranteed not to change.
 
 
- Jeff

	-----Original Message-----
	From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@seairth.com]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3309
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 20:11:12
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

>> For some forms of metadata, you want the authoritative source to be
the
>> resource itself - like what the allowed programmatic interactions
are.

> If I understand you correctly, you are saying that a Web service
should
> have an "authoritative service description".  I agree!  The
> Meta-Location header provides the URL to the service's authoritative
> service description.

Instead of introducing a new header for this, couldn't you just stick 
with the standard OPTIONS method? If you have one authoritative bit of 
metadata that you want to keep in a separate document, respond with 
a "303 See Other"; and if there are multiple documents, that could turn 
around an respond with either Content-Type specific documents, and/or
for
finer grained control, a "300 Multiple Choices."

Since any tool that would be looking for a custom header would need to
be written with that in mind, it would be just as easy for it to 
call the OPTIONS method and deal with the results appropriately.

>> Other
>> metadata, like making claims 'about' the resource (asserting that it
is a
>> member of some topic/subject/concept/etc.) benefits from being
external and
>> having multiple sources to varying trust.
>
> It's more than that. Suppose that my shop is running RDF engines to
> enable inductive reasoning, and suppose that the Web service that my
> company wants to use just provides an XHTML description.  Thus, my
> company creates an RDF description of the Web service - it tells the
HOW
> of how the use it, and it does it using RDF.  Thus, my company's RDF
> description adds value to the Web service, and it does it in a
> distributed fashion. /Roger

If a time comes when search engines are able to parse and understand
semantically marked up documents, wouldn't it be easier to just have
a link to the service right in the document itself instead of
introducing
a custom header?  Google is all about looking a links already.

- Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3310
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 20:17:57
Subject:RE: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

Your already talking about introducing custom header formats, and 
OPTIONS methods can contain an entity body. Perhaps a better way 
of dealing with this is to include a message body in the OPTIONS
request that is just the method you're interested in:

	<method>PUT</method>

(Make it XML just to be fancy :)).  The response could then be 
a standard set of headers and/or metadata about just that method.

A OPTIONS call without the <method/> entity could respond with 
the information that a <method/> element is require for OPTIONS
calls to that service.

- Jeff 



-----Original Message-----
From: S. Alexander Jacobson [mailto:alex@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 2:47 PM
To: Seairth Jacobs
Cc: rest-discuss
Subject: Re: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource
Discovery)


I like your version of the format quite a lot.
The only thing I'd like to see in it that is
missing is some way of finding out what
content-types are available via
content-negotiation.

Content-Types: <same format as accept>
Encodings: <same format as accept-encodings>

Regarding the options header on GET, I like that
as a concept, but the practice makes me nervous.
I'd like to avoid a proliferation of file formats
for this sort of thing.

-Alex-

Post ID:3311
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 21:07:00
Subject:Re: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> I like your version of the format quite a lot.
> The only thing I'd like to see in it that is
> missing is some way of finding out what
> content-types are available via
> content-negotiation.

I'm not sure that's necessary, though.  A client should submit to the server
the list of content-types that it understands (i.e. "Accept" header) and the
server should choose from that list or return an appropriate error response.
What value would it be for a client to get back a list of content-types that
it didn't understand?

Further, I should point out that the format I suggest does allow a server to
return something like:

GET accept: text/html, text/*, */*
GET accept-encoding: compress, gzip

Basically, just about any request header could be specified.  The example in
my original post were just a sampling for demonstration and not the complete
list of possibilities.

> Regarding the options header on GET, I like that
> as a concept, but the practice makes me nervous.
> I'd like to avoid a proliferation of file formats
> for this sort of thing.

I don't understand your concern here.  As it is OPTIONS is woefully
underutilized.  It makes sense that in this emerging world of new metadata
constructs, esp. wrt web services, the OPTIONS feature could fit the bill
nicely (at least for some uses).  Regardless of the suggested header, anyone
could return any response-entity of any content-type for OPTIONS right now.
There is no way we can avoid that.  What the header does is allow a resource
to indicate that metadata is available via OPTIONS in certain formats.  This
is more an ability to actively inform the client of OPTIONS abilities than
it is a method of proliferating multiple content-types when using OPTIONS.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3312
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 21:10:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

MessageTrue.  However, I feel that the caching limitation only applies to
intermediaries.  Otherwise, the verb would be practically useless.  You
could certainly use a 303 as well, but the only advantage I see to that is
allowing intermediaries to cache the response.

Hey, Roy:  if you happen to read this, what is your take on this?  Is
OPTIONS supposed to be non-cachable for everyone or just intermediaries?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

----- Original Message -----
From: Jeffrey Winter
To: Seairth Jacobs ; rest-discuss
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 2:50 PM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery


Sorry, what I meant was that if there was some concern
that since OPTIONS can't be cached and it would be possible
that the metadata could be out of date by the time you
actually went to use the service, one possible way to deal
with that is to redirect the OPTIONS call using a a 303,
which changes the call into a GET which could be made cachable.
An Expires: timestamp would indicate how long that metadata is
gauranteed not to change.


- Jeff
-----Original Message-----
From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 2:06 PM
To: rest-discuss
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery


MessageTrue, but I'm not seeing how this relates to my comments below...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...


----- Original Message -----
From: Jeffrey Winter
To: Seairth Jacobs ; rest-discuss
Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 12:44 PM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery



OPTIONS requests can respond with a "303 See Other" which could
point to a cacheable stand-alone, metadata document.


-----Original Message-----
From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
Sent: Tuesday, January 21, 2003 9:50 PM
To: rest-discuss
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery


From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
>
> Huh. I thought I looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't appropriate... don't know
> what I was thinking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods were
> allowed...
> This seems like the best approach so far.
>
>
> Here's the text from the RFC. The only downside is responses are not
> cacheable.
>
> [deleted]
>

Hmm... When the RFC says the response is not cachable, I am wondering if
they have proxies, etc. in mind.  For the client, it seems that caching
would have to be necessary unless the server could guarantee the metadata in
the OPTIONS response won't change for a certain period of time (which is
effectively caching).  Otherwise, the verb is potentially useless...

WRT this thread, you would do an OPTIONS to a URI and get a response back
indicating the POST/PUTable content-types.  Since there is no guarantee that
the allowable types are going to ba allowable a moment later when you do
your actual POST/PUT, then it follows that it making a decision on the
returned metadata a day later would be little different than making a
decision on it a second later.  At worst case, if the resource's metadata
changed between the time the OPTIONS response came back and the client
submitted a request based on the returned metadata, the server would/should
return the appropriate error.  In turn, this would prompt the client to
request the OPTIONS again and see what has changed...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Post ID:3313

Subject:Re: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

Ok, I accept your point about "Accept:" headers.
But then I would think it applies equally well to
OPTIONS requests.  Why not just send an accept
header with an OPTIONS request?  What does the
options header buy you?

-Alex-

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3314
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 21:51:33
Subject:Re: OPTIONS response (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery)
Message:

I agree.  You could certainly just send the "Accept" header.  But this
requires you to have to initiate a call to OPTIONS just to see if there is a
content-type you can handle (i.e. get a valid response or an error).  The
advantage of the options header is that it allows a resource to actively
inform the client of those content-types that it can return.  This can avoid
additional roundtrips to the server.  Also, since OPTIONS does not seem to
be used all that much right now, this is a simple way to start telling
clients that OPTIONS *is* being used for a given resource.  The lack of the
header is not an indication that OPTIONS is available for the resource
(which is no different than things are now).  But an explicit statement of
OPTIONS can have advantages.  Wrt the Google example I gave earlier, they
would not have to make two requests to every resource when only a very small
percentage (e.g. < .0000001%) would return a useful response to the OPTIONS
request.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3315
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-22 22:13:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> MessageTrue.  However, I feel that the caching limitation only applies 
> to
> intermediaries.  Otherwise, the verb would be practically useless.  You
> could certainly use a 303 as well, but the only advantage I see to 
> that is
> allowing intermediaries to cache the response.
>
> Hey, Roy:  if you happen to read this, what is your take on this?  Is
> OPTIONS supposed to be non-cachable for everyone or just 
> intermediaries?

It is only non-cacheable by default.  Use cache-control to change that.

The Web had a notion of external links, but nobody could agree on the
HTTP syntax so it didn't make the cut.  WebDAV added properties.

Adding a new header field to every GET response would increase latency
for no benefit to the common case and only marginal benefit to the
applications being discussed.  It is therefore more efficient to have
the client request that information only when it is desired.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3316
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 02:43:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Ahh!  That all makes sense.  However, I don't know that I would agree that
the added header would increase latency since it would be an optional
header.  The only time it would be given is if there is reason to give it,
which would also be when it's more likely to be needed.  It wouldn't make
sense using the header for the vast majority of resources out there.  But
for newer resources, it may be a helpful hint at a minimal cost...

On the other hand, it would be one less header to have to deal with...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3317
Sender:"Roger L. Costello" <costello@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 07:20:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Hi Jeff,

Jeffrey Winter wrote:
> 
> > If I understand you correctly, you are saying that a Web service
> should
> > have an "authoritative service description".  I agree!  The
> > Meta-Location header provides the URL to the service's authoritative
> > service description.
> 
> Instead of introducing a new header for this, couldn't you just stick
> with the standard OPTIONS method? If you have one authoritative bit of
> metadata that you want to keep in a separate document, respond with
> a "303 See Other"; and if there are multiple documents, that could turn
> around an respond with either Content-Type specific documents, and/or
> for
> finer grained control, a "300 Multiple Choices."

"standard OPTIONS method"?  There is no such thing.  Don't be under the
illusion that you are using something "that already exists".  You are
redefining/adding-to the semantics of the OPTIONS method, i.e., there is
no server in the world that understands OPTIONS <url> means it should
return the metadata document for a service.   

To recap:

* Yes, the OPTIONS verb is a viable alternative to the using the 
Meta-Location header.  There are pluses and minuses to each approach.
*  However, you still need the Meta-About header to solve the problem
of allowing third parties to add metadata about a resource (see below).
 
> If a time comes when search engines are able to parse and understand
> semantically marked up documents, wouldn't it be easier to just have
> a link to the service right in the document itself instead of
> introducing
> a custom header?  

"link to the service right in the document itself" ... You mean mandate
that every metadata description document must contain  buried within it
a URL to the service it describes?  Consequently, tools must delve into
(and understand the semantics of) the metadata description document to
extract the URL, right?  For example, an aggregator tool which, say,
wants to collect together the URLs of all metadata descriptions which
refer to some vendor's service must parse through every metadata
description document to extract the URL.  Yikes!  Not very RESTful is
it?  This would be analogous to forcing caching tools to examine (and
understand) the contents of every message to decide whether it should
cache the message.  No, this Meta-About URL needs to be in the HTTP
header.  /Roger

P.S. RDF engines that do inductive/deductive reasoning are already here.

Post ID:3320
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3321
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 17:30:10
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Roger,

> "standard OPTIONS method"?  There is no such thing.  Don't be under
the
> illusion that you are using something "that already exists".  You are
> redefining/adding-to the semantics of the OPTIONS method, i.e., there
is
> no server in the world that understands OPTIONS <url> means it should
> return the metadata document for a service.    

I completely agree that very, very few, if any, are using OPTIONS in 
this way currently; but the same could be said of the headers you
are proposing that others support.  Returning an Allow header
along with a set of schemas, or even a link, or a redirect to 
a set of schemas is a perfectly valid and appropriate use of OPTIONS.

I wouldn't say that it is adding to the semantics of the OPTIONS 
method any more than adding an extension header is adding to a GET.
A client is requesting what their options are at that location
and the server is informing them.

What I am saying is that instead of proposing the inclusion of a 
new header with each GET, it might better to propose the
adoption of the convension of using the OPTIONS method.  I don't 
have a problem with a standalone document, but I would like to see 
the OPTIONS method be the mechanism for getting to it.  

> To recap:
>
> * Yes, the OPTIONS verb is a viable alternative to the using the 
> Meta-Location header.  There are pluses and minuses to each approach.
> *  However, you still need the Meta-About header to solve the problem
> of allowing third parties to add metadata about a resource (see
below).
>
>> If a time comes when search engines are able to parse and understand
>> semantically marked up documents, wouldn't it be easier to just have
>> a link to the service right in the document itself instead of
>> introducing
>> a custom header?  

> "link to the service right in the document itself" ... You mean
mandate
> that every metadata description document must contain  buried within
it
> a URL to the service it describes?  Consequently, tools must delve
into
> (and understand the semantics of) the metadata description document to
> extract the URL, right?  

To be honest, I am much more ambivalent about how 3rd-party metadata 
documents refering back to the service.

Google has no idea of the meaning of the documents it is parsing, it
just
indexes the words and pulls URLs out of link tags. Granted, if
some metadata decides to put links into the document in some way that it
doesn't understand (like the soapAction attribute etc.) then it's either
going to miss them; have to start looking for a wider range of
standardize linking
mechanisms (xlink, etc.); or get a lot smarter about the way it parses
document.

> For example, an aggregator tool which, say,
> wants to collect together the URLs of all metadata descriptions which
> refer to some vendor's service must parse through every metadata
> description document to extract the URL.  Yikes!  Not very RESTful is
> it?  

I'm not sure how this is RESTful or non-RESTful.  If a client requests 
a document, it's up to the client to do whatever it sees fit with it.

> This would be analogous to forcing caching tools to examine (and
> understand) the contents of every message to decide whether it should
> cache the message.  No, this Meta-About URL needs to be in the HTTP
> header.  /Roger

Unless the OPTIONS method of the metadata (the meta-metadata of the
service) service included a link to the service that's being 
described. :) If you're pouring over what you know to be metadata 
documents anyway, you could always hit that resource with an OPTIONS
request while your at it.

This has been an interesting discussion.

- Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3322
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 17:34:49
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Roy,

I noticed in your WAKA ApacheCon presentation that you discuss the
ability to include metadata about the resource and representation along
with the response.  Could that assume the form of a link to another
document?  Either way would be the moral equivalent of what Roger is
proposing it seems to me.

Would there be any equivalent of the OPTIONS method?  Or is that sort of
functionality deprecated?

RFC2616 mentions that and further specification of OPTIONS is left for
future versions of HTTP. Is there any work currently underway to further
refine that method?

Thanks,

Jeff

Post ID:3323
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 17:42:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>


> Good grief.  Why does everyone equate REST with HTTP?  REST apps work
> quite well with file, ftp, gopher, wais, urn, ...
Okay, okay - the t-shirts aren't "REST" shirts. They are HTTP attitude/joke
shirts.
And I don't equate the two, but HTTP is the most full featured and practical
tool to use over the Internet when dealing with resources and
representations.

I couldn't come up with a snappy REST quote - like "REST - a really neat
idea" so I thought I'd do something funny.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3324
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 18:11:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts
Message:

> I couldn't come up with a snappy REST quote - like "REST - a really 
> neat
> idea" so I thought I'd do something funny.

that would be an easy pun.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3325
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 18:19:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> I noticed in your WAKA ApacheCon presentation that you discuss the
> ability to include metadata about the resource and representation along
> with the response.  Could that assume the form of a link to another
> document?  Either way would be the moral equivalent of what Roger is
> proposing it seems to me.

Yes, it includes external links with role attributes.  It also allows
metadata to be interleaved with the response data, thus removing the
issue regarding overhead latency.

> Would there be any equivalent of the OPTIONS method?  Or is that sort 
> of
> functionality deprecated?

Yes.  At least one form of OPTIONS request was always intended to
contain the desired (later) request in the OPTIONS body (excluding the
body of the desired request itself), thus allowing the server to know
exactly what options should be described.  It couldn't be standardized
because I didn't have time to implement it, and without that nobody
else was willing to implement.

> RFC2616 mentions that and further specification of OPTIONS is left for
> future versions of HTTP. Is there any work currently underway to 
> further
> refine that method?

Always.  No implementations yet, though.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3326
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-23 18:20:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts

How about:

"REST.  It's so simple, you wouldn't understand." (for attitude)

or

"...and on the seventh day He RESTed." (for the less secular types)

or

"To REST or not to REST. There is no question!" (for the literary types)

or

"While you work, we REST."

or

"That's my URI.  Don't wear it out!"

or

"If I had a penny for every SOAP interface, I'd be rich!"


Seairth

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>; "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Sent: Thursday, January 23, 2003 12:42 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts


>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
>
>
> > Good grief.  Why does everyone equate REST with HTTP?  REST apps work
> > quite well with file, ftp, gopher, wais, urn, ...
> Okay, okay - the t-shirts aren't "REST" shirts. They are HTTP
attitude/joke
> shirts.
> And I don't equate the two, but HTTP is the most full featured and
practical
> tool to use over the Internet when dealing with resources and
> representations.
>
> I couldn't come up with a snappy REST quote - like "REST - a really neat
> idea" so I thought I'd do something funny.
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3333
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-24 18:12:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts
Message:

> I noticed that while idempotence seems an important
> distinguishing property of some HTTP methods, it's not
> mentioned at all in REST.  Or did I miss it?

The reason it is important to HTTP/1.1 is for pipelining requests
and knowing when it should be safe to repeat the same request without
user intervention.  The only part where I briefly touch on it is when
mentioning Waldo's paper on partial failures in RPC systems.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3334
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-24 19:08:37
Subject:Pseudo code and UML and REST
Message:

My believe is that if you follow the "Network is not a LAN" and the
"REST is incompatible with 'end-point' RPC" arguments, then you
will also agree that pseudo code and UML are inappropriate for
designing REST applications.

With respect to pseudo code, if you have control structures, then
you have state, most likely state that is carried on the server,
which is un-REST-ful.

With respect to UML, if your design talks about objects and the
methods exposed by objects and the attributes of objects and
objects as containers and so on, then you will end up with an RPC
style design and creating objects on the server and calling methods
on those objects etc, which is un-REST-ful.

Can anyone give me any additional bullets to use in this argument? 
I believe that these arguments could be used not just against
SOAP/XMLRPC development strategies, but also against the design
strategies and CASE tools that might be used with them.

Or, have you got any reasons why this thinking is wrong headed?

Comments?

  - Dave

-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3335
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-24 19:44:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Pseudo code and UML and REST
Message:

Plug some examples into these interesting assertions,
wouldja?

Walden
