-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3336
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-24 19:51:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts
Message:

Yes.  I was underscoring the tendency for discussion communities
to oversimplify models, leading to the assumption that if one is
talking about idempotence in methods, then one must be talking
about REST.  It's another example of lumping HTTP and REST
into a single lump.  As one learns these patterns, it takes continued
effort and review to keep the lumps from bleeding together.

Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3337
Sender:"Josh Knowles" <josh.knowles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-25 01:00:20
Subject:REST and HTML forms
Message:

Anyone have any tips, or good links, to best practices for integrating a
HTML front end to a REST system.  For example if I remember correctly
HTML forms can only submit POST and GET requests, so if the system is
set up to use PUT and DELETE do I have to put in a intermediary to do
the translation or is there a JavaScript trick that I haven't seen yet?

Thanks,

Josh





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3338
Sender:Vincent D.Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-25 13:11:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and HTML forms
Message:

On Saturday, January 25, 2003, at 01:00 AM, Josh Knowles wrote:
> Anyone have any tips, or good links, to best practices for integrating 
> a
> HTML front end to a REST system.  For example if I remember correctly
> HTML forms can only submit POST and GET requests,

correct.

> so if the system is
> set up to use PUT and DELETE do I have to put in a intermediary to do
> the translation or is there a JavaScript trick that I haven't seen yet?

yes.  i believe xforms will allow you to send put/delete, paul prescod 
mentioned this a while back.

with html forms, you can use both approaches.

with javascript on the client, you can use an XmlHttpRequest object (at 
least i think thats what its called; *weird* name, why not just 
'HttpRequest'?) to send a PUT or DELETE.

because i prefer to avoid client scripting, i prefer to use an 
intermediary on the server which 'pre-processes' the request body.  
approaches i have used include sending the put/delete flag in a hidden 
form field, or using the value of a submit form field.  (i didn't 
widely test browser behaviour with submit field values.)  this then 
forms the basis of an ifThenElse/switch structure which you can use to 
call either PUT or DELETE code.

HTH,
-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3339
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-25 16:16:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and HTML forms
Message:

A system built solely on GET and POST is not at variance
with REST, at least not merely on that criterion.

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3340
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-25 19:54:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and HTML forms
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Vincent D.Murphy" <vdm@...>

> > For example if I remember correctly
> > HTML forms can only submit POST and GET requests,
>
> correct.
Pedantically, HTML FORM can have method='PUT' - it's the client (i.e.
browser) that does or does not recognize it.

> with javascript on the client, you can use an XmlHttpRequest object (at
> least i think thats what its called; *weird* name, why not just
> 'HttpRequest'?) to send a PUT or DELETE.
The MS interfaces define DOM and XML aware methods on the component, hence
the 'Xml' part. It isn't purely content agnostic.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3341
Sender:Ian Clelland <ian@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-26 22:41:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and HTML forms
Message:

On Sat, Jan 25, 2003 at 11:54:54AM -0800, S. Mike Dierken wrote:
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Vincent D.Murphy" <vdm@...>
> 
> > > For example if I remember correctly
> > > HTML forms can only submit POST and GET requests,
> >
> > correct.
> Pedantically, HTML FORM can have method='PUT' - it's the client (i.e.
> browser) that does or does not recognize it.

HTML 4.01 defines (S17.3) "get" and "post" as the only valid values for
the method attribute of the form tag. The browsers don't recognise it
because there is no valid way to construct a PUT or DELETE form in HTML.

Ian
<ian@...>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3343
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-29 00:26:25
Subject:REST and FSM and processes
Message:

I'm fascinated by REST and I'm fascinated by FSMs (finite state
machines).  I also want to find ways to implement complex processes
in a REST-ful way.  My belief is that a possible path to a solution
for this problem goes through FSMs, specifically translating a
complex business process into an FSM and then implementing the FSM
in a REST-ful style.

So, I've created and documented several models or patterns for
implementing FSMs in a REST-ful style.

You can find my document and examples at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/fsm_howto.html

I'm very interested in any comments about whether I have suceeded
in following "the REST way" and in any other suggestions.  Thanks
in advance.

  - Dave


-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3344
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-29 01:22:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and FSM and processes
Message:

Dave,

I read it quickly.  While there's much value in viewing a web
application as a distributed state machine, I'm not sure how far
that model needs to be carried into the implementation.  For
instance, how much about the FSM is the client expected to
understand in order to use the service?  This is a sensitive area,
because if the full FSM model is required on the client side,
then you lose the "low cost of entry" attribute, and make it
harder for the server application to evolve.

If, on the other hand, the server has embodied within it the
notion of an FSM of valid client states, and the client is able
to explore that (changing) state space dynamically, then you
have something cool.

Walden

----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Kuhlman" <dkuhlman@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, January 28, 2003 7:26 PM
Subject: [rest-discuss] REST and FSM and processes


> I'm fascinated by REST and I'm fascinated by FSMs (finite state
> machines).  I also want to find ways to implement complex processes
> in a REST-ful way.  My belief is that a possible path to a solution
> for this problem goes through FSMs, specifically translating a
> complex business process into an FSM and then implementing the FSM
> in a REST-ful style.
>
> So, I've created and documented several models or patterns for
> implementing FSMs in a REST-ful style.
>
> You can find my document and examples at:
>
>     http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/fsm_howto.html
>
> I'm very interested in any comments about whether I have suceeded
> in following "the REST way" and in any other suggestions.  Thanks
> in advance.
>
>   - Dave
>
>
> --
> Dave Kuhlman
> dkuhlman@...
> http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3345
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-29 19:25:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and FSM and processes
Message:

On Tue, Jan 28, 2003 at 08:22:40PM -0500, Walden Mathews wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> I read it quickly.  While there's much value in viewing a web
> application as a distributed state machine, I'm not sure how far
> that model needs to be carried into the implementation.  For
> instance, how much about the FSM is the client expected to
> understand in order to use the service?  This is a sensitive area,
> because if the full FSM model is required on the client side,
> then you lose the "low cost of entry" attribute, and make it
> harder for the server application to evolve.

I agree with you here.  Sigh.  I guess, that means that there is
good bit of work to do.

In my examples, the current state is returned to the client (in the
XML document returned as content).  So, all the client needs to do
is return the content (or the current state from the XML content)
along with some additional input, which the FSM uses to select the
next transition/state.

However, while that's likely true for trivial examples like mine,
for real world, complex problems, I'm sure that clients cannot fly
blind, so to speak.  Client developers will have to understand the
FSM and the BP (business process) that is behind it.

So, I'm agreeing with you.  There are things that can be done to
help, for example, provide a description of the BP, provide an XML
specification of the BP, describe the mapping from the BP to the
FSM (or to an XML document that describes the FSM), provide
documentation on the FSM, provide an XML document that describes
the FSM (along with tools to inspect it), etc.

OK.  Talk's cheap.  I'd better get to work.

> 
> If, on the other hand, the server has embodied within it the
> notion of an FSM of valid client states, and the client is able
> to explore that (changing) state space dynamically, then you
> have something cool.

This is a bit mysterious to me.  By "explore the state space", do
you mean that the client can find out what states (nodes) are in
the FSM and which are connected to which?  If so, I'd agree that
the client needs access to this information (a picture of the
entire FSM), one way or another.

However, the client developer should also be able to take a
"peep-hole" view.  For example, "I'm in state X, so all I have to
do is provide this input (e.g. a user ID)." Or, "If I'm in state X
and I provide a valid user ID, what happens?"

Think of it this way -- Suppose we have an FSM that analyzes a
stream of characters.  All the client should be required to do is
to continually feed the next character.  For more complex
processes, all that should be required of the client is to feed the
next piece of input (e.g. a user ID and password, a part number,
etc).  Granted that the developer of the client application would
have to understand the BP/FSM in order to know what information to
provide.  However, I can imagine a server implementation (the FSM)
that provides a description of the next required piece of input
with each response.

Again, I'm agreeing that something must be done in this area,
although it would be work to do it.

> 
> Walden
> 

  - Dave

-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3346
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-29 19:58:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and FSM and processes
Message:

> In my examples, the current state is returned to the client (in the
> XML document returned as content).  So, all the client needs to do
> is return the content (or the current state from the XML content)
> along with some additional input, which the FSM uses to select the
> next transition/state.

I think the way it typically works is that the "current" state
is represented by the data returned from the last request, and
that the embedded links in that (arbitrarily many, according to the
transition set of your FSM) are invitations for the client to
transition to the next state.  Does that make sense?

> 
> However, while that's likely true for trivial examples like mine,
> for real world, complex problems, I'm sure that clients cannot fly
> blind, so to speak.  Client developers will have to understand the
> FSM and the BP (business process) that is behind it.
> 
> So, I'm agreeing with you.  There are things that can be done to
> help, for example, provide a description of the BP, provide an XML
> specification of the BP, describe the mapping from the BP to the
> FSM (or to an XML document that describes the FSM), provide
> documentation on the FSM, provide an XML document that describes
> the FSM (along with tools to inspect it), etc.

Now you're talking about "choreography", which is not what
I meant at all.  I meant something like the opposite, that "clients
can fly blind" in the sense that you can accomplish something
(you and your code) without having a representation of the
application's FSM in front of you.

> 
> This is a bit mysterious to me.  By "explore the state space", do
> you mean that the client can find out what states (nodes) are in
> the FSM and which are connected to which?  If so, I'd agree that
> the client needs access to this information (a picture of the
> entire FSM), one way or another.

Yes to the first part; no to the second.  Why wouldn't the
client be able to "explore" state space, and having so done,
draw its own map of that space as an FSM or whatever?

> 
> However, the client developer should also be able to take a
> "peep-hole" view.  For example, "I'm in state X, so all I have to
> do is provide this input (e.g. a user ID)." Or, "If I'm in state X
> and I provide a valid user ID, what happens?"

Are you missing the role that URIs embedded in representations
play in this?

> 
> Think of it this way -- Suppose we have an FSM that analyzes a
> stream of characters.  All the client should be required to do is
> to continually feed the next character.  For more complex
> processes, all that should be required of the client is to feed the
> next piece of input (e.g. a user ID and password, a part number,
> etc).  Granted that the developer of the client application would
> have to understand the BP/FSM in order to know what information to
> provide.  However, I can imagine a server implementation (the FSM)
> that provides a description of the next required piece of input
> with each response.

That's how it should work.  "Hypertext as the engine of application
state" and all that.

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3347
Sender:"inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...>" <inthedarkplace@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-30 06:23:59
Subject:New Article re REST & Digital Identities
Message:

http://artificial-philosopher.blog-city.com/readblog.cfm?BID=17023

A thorough explanation of why a REST solution is the best solution to
the identity dilemma.

I'd like to hear others thoughts on this.

- itdp





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3348
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-30 15:34:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] New Article re REST & Digital Identities
Message:

From: <inthedarkplace@...>
>
> http://artificial-philosopher.blog-city.com/readblog.cfm?BID=17023
>
> A thorough explanation of why a REST solution is the best solution to
> the identity dilemma.
>
> I'd like to hear others thoughts on this.

Hmm... well, I am curious to see what will be in part 2 of the blog.  As for
this entry, I feel that some of the observations are either over-simplified
or plain wrong.  It's hard to agree with all of the blogger's conclusions
when it's based on somewhat flimsy arguments.

However, I do agree with the basic theme of the blog.  Using URIs and
documents to form a digital identity makes more sense than going the MS
Passport way.  At one level this is a description of the Web itself.  I have
a URI (http://www.seairth.com) which identifies documents which start to
give a rough idea of who I am.  This is true also for
http://www.microsoft.com and http://home.ccil.org/~cowan/.


Also, for those who are not aware of it, Thawte as the Web of Trust[1],
which is a a bottom-up certificate authority (CA) system.  Using SSL and the
WOT, a certain portion of this bottom-up REST-oriented digital identity
problem could be solved.  I'm not saying this is the solution to all of the
problems, just that there *are* others out there already attacking the
problem in a similar manner.

[1] http://www.thawte.com/html/COMMUNITY/wot/index.html

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Post ID:3349

Subject:TrackBack NG: A Proposal.
Message:

TrackBack is a topic that I know has been discussed from time to time 
and that some of you have been active in its development.

In taking all of the recent discussion and 
experimentation with TrackBack and related 
interfaces, I thought it would be helpful to draft 
some suggestions for consideration for the next 
generation of the interface. (One of the sections is "Make TrackBack 
even more RESTful.") 

http://www.mplode.com/tima/archives/000206.html

This document is meant to be a starting point to further the 
constructive and valuable experimentation done so far. Thoughts? 

<tim/>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3351
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-01-31 05:59:16
Subject:W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Hey - I just found out there was a note back in 1999 about using HTML forms
to do authentication.
I haven't read it fully, but this is one of my pet peeves with HTTP and the
'visual Web' - no visibility of security information in messages. (leading
to sessions, cookies, wacky urls, etc.)

===
http://www.w3.org/TR/1999/NOTE-authentform-19990203

[...]
This proposal suggests extensions to HTML forms to overcome their present
security problems by integrating them with HTTP (or other security sublayer)
mechanisms. It calls for a new type of form; the AUTHFORM and new values for
the TYPE attribute of the INPUT element and SELECT block.
[...]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3353
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-12 19:12:26
Subject:ANN: Generating REST-ful Quixote applications
Message:

I have continued to explore the possibility of supporting FSMs
(finite state machines) and workflows with REST-ful applications. 

In order to do so I've implemented several simple source code
generator which produces REST-ful Quixote applications that
implement an FSM or workflow.  These code generators read an XML
document that describes the FSM/workflow, its states, and its
transitions.  It generates the skeleton of a Quixote application.
And, I've written a document about it, with attached support code
and examples.

You can find this document at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/workflow_howto.html

The attached example files contain code that is from Juan David
Ibez Palomar.  Thanks Juan David.

  - Dave

-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3354
Sender:"Jay Zylstra <jayz@...>" <jayz@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-14 02:56:19
Subject:Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

Why not access all of the various functionality of a service by 
specifying different ACCEPT values on the request?  So, if I want the 
service's response in XML for programmatic access, I would specify 
ACCEPT: text/xml.  Or, if I want the UI for user access, I would 
specify text/html.  To get the schema, I could specify 
application/xsd+xml.  To get the interface def, I could specify 
application/kinda-like-wsdl-for-rest+xml.  Sure, some necessary MIME 
types don't exist, but isn't that a fault of MIME and not HTTP?  
After all, if XML can get its own MIME type even though its really 
just text, why stop there?

Okay, so we'd end up with billions of MIME types for everyone's 
different schemas.  But since XSD is so core, it really should have 
its own MIME type.  Perhaps one more new MIME type is needed: 
application/metadata+xml, which when requested would return an index 
of all various metadata of the service, such as scaler values like 
author and version, and links (different URLs) to complex metadata, 
such as reviews of the service.  Of course, these different URLs 
could themselves be services, which can be accessed programatically 
(via ACCEPT: text/xml) or by a user (via ACCEPT: text/html).  The 
reviews could even have reviews.

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Roger L. Costello" 
<costello@m...> wrote:
> Hi Alex,
> 
> "S. Alexander Jacobson" wrote:
> > 
> > On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Roger L. Costello wrote:
> > > Consider a movie.  Is it worth seeing?  If Gene Siskel gives it 
a
> > 
> > I think we are mixing two very separate concepts
> > of metadata.
> 
> I believe that you are missing my point.  Let me quote David Jacobs:
> 
> "Metadata about a web service goes beyond a WSDL file, XML Schemas 
and a
> tmodel description.
> 
> A web service may have
> * a WSDL file
> * an HTML description
> * XML schema's it returns and accepts
> * a DAML-S description
> * a reliability rating
> * a usefulness rating
> * how it can be integrated with other services
> 
> Furthermore, while a service provider will often produce a lot of 
> service metadata to facilitate its use, they cannot be seen as
> objective 
> parties when contributing metadata to be used in matchmaking (i.e., 
is 
> this the service I need).  Clearly there is a role for third 
parties to
> add their own metadata about a service in the form of ratings and 
new 
> metadata formats which might increase the service's usefulness for 
a 
> population segment."
> 
> My point is that a HOW metadata document is just a small part of the
> metadata that you will associate with web service.  Further, even 
of the
> HOW metadata there will be many, many different formats - XHTML, 
WSDL,
> RDF, DAML-S, OWL, etc.  To top it off, all of the many metadata
> documents will be distributed across the Web [just like all of the 
Web
> sites that link to your Web page are distributed across the Web].
> 
> Bottom line: for a Web service there will be many (many) metadata
> documents, spread across the Web.  The key is to provide a "general
> mechanism" for associating a metadata document with a web service. 
> That's what Meta-Location buys you.  /Roger





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3355
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-14 14:03:38
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> Why not access all of the various functionality of a service 
> by specifying different ACCEPT values on the request? 

There are two basic issues, the most fundamental of which
is that the metadata should be a standalone resource with
it's own URI so that all normal HTTP methods can be 
applied to it.

The other issue, which is sort of a by-product of the first,
is that the scheme that you've outlined wouldn't allow any
natural way to discover the meta-metadata (the metadata of 
the metdata) and on up the potential chain of descriptive 
resources.

I agree though with the notion of using the Accept: header
to obtain the type of metadata of interest, but only 
once the URI of the metadata has been determined [1], a la:

    GET /some-resource/metadata HTTP/1.1
    Host: someplace
    Accept: application/rdf+xml
    
    HTTP/1.1 200 OK
    Content-Type: application/rdf+xml
    Content-Location: /some-resource/metadata/rdf

[1]  http://www.xfront.com/dist-reg/distributed-registry.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3356
Sender:"Zylstra, Jay" <jayz@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-14 21:21:57
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

There must be a way to get to a service's metadata given only the service's URI.  To require modifying the URI to get the metadata could modify the service, or even select a different service.  So, given only the service's URL, you can either hit the service, and discard all the response except some header like MetaData-URI: /some-resource/metadata, which would seem an unnecessarily wasteful invocation of the service just to get that URI.  Or, you can pass some parameter in the request (as a header) specifying that you don't want to invoke the service, but only want to get its metadata (or, as you suggest, a reference to the metadata).

I can't think of any other way to get to the metadata given only the service's URI and without altering it.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeffrey Winter [mailto:JeffreyWinter@crd.com] 
Sent: Friday, February 14, 2003 6:04 AM
To: Zylstra, Jay; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery


> Why not access all of the various functionality of a service 
> by specifying different ACCEPT values on the request? 

There are two basic issues, the most fundamental of which
is that the metadata should be a standalone resource with
it's own URI so that all normal HTTP methods can be 
applied to it.

The other issue, which is sort of a by-product of the first,
is that the scheme that you've outlined wouldn't allow any
natural way to discover the meta-metadata (the metadata of 
the metdata) and on up the potential chain of descriptive 
resources.

I agree though with the notion of using the Accept: header
to obtain the type of metadata of interest, but only 
once the URI of the metadata has been determined [1], a la:

    GET /some-resource/metadata HTTP/1.1
    Host: someplace
    Accept: application/rdf+xml
    
    HTTP/1.1 200 OK
    Content-Type: application/rdf+xml
    Content-Location: /some-resource/metadata/rdf

[1]  http://www.xfront.com/dist-reg/distributed-registry.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3357
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-14 21:32:03
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> There must be a way to get to a service's metadata given 
> only the service's URI. 

You could just call HEAD and no entity would be returned.

Still, this is part of the reason why I've suggested
that the OPTIONS method could be used for this 
purpose.  There wouldn't have to be the "expense" of
an extra header with each GET, but there are trade
offs with using this approach (like firewall restrictions
etc., and the adoption of a standard but obscure method)

[This paraphrases a message I posted to distributed-registry]

While the Allow: header could be returned in any
response, it is normally only returned in response
to an OPTIONS method.  From one perspective this
describes a refinement of a resources interface:

	Allow: GET,PUT,POST,DELETE  being analogous to:

	interface resource {
		delete();
		representation get();
		put(representation r);
		post(representation r);
	}

		vs. 

	Allow: GET,POST  being analogous to:

	interface resource {
		representation get();
		post(representation r);
	}

From this perspective, the OPTIONS method is already supplying
a form of metadata; using it to give the Meta-Location: header
would seem to be a natural extension to this "functionality."





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3358
Sender:"Zylstra, Jay" <jayz@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-14 22:00:53
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

I like your idea of using OPTIONS, but it does seem to be a retrofit to its intended purpose of probing HTTP servers (and proxies) for their supported methods, types, protocol version, etc.  Using HEAD to obtain a service's metadata seems a better match to the methods definition, although head is meant to get the metadata for a GET against the service's URI, not a POST.  In other words, OPTIONS seems to be for obtaining more communications-centric metadata, while HEAD seems to be for obtaining more content-centric metadata.

// see: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec9.html#sec9.4

How about evaluating these approaches against a specific, theoretical scenario?  Suppose we have a service that supplies weather reports given a specific location.  Clients can currently specify the location by zip code or city+state, although it will soon support latitude+longitude too.  The service can provide the response weather report as either text/html, application/xhtml+xml, text/vnd.wap.wml, text/xml, and even image/gif...the client need only specify which it wants via ACCEPT.  The service has a name, description, version, author, and links to reviews.  The reviews are in fact other services provided by Amazon, epinions, etc. that can be accessed both programmatically and interactively.  The service currently supports the USA and Canada, but will soon support much of Western Europe too.

Now I, a user, want to find out about this service.  How do I do it, given only a URL a friend sent me of http://host.domain.tld/services/free/?svc=weather&zip=98005


-----Original Message-----
From: Jeffrey Winter [mailto:JeffreyWinter@...] 
Sent: Friday, February 14, 2003 1:32 PM
To: Zylstra, Jay
Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery


> There must be a way to get to a service's metadata given 
> only the service's URI. 

You could just call HEAD and no entity would be returned.

Still, this is part of the reason why I've suggested
that the OPTIONS method could be used for this 
purpose.  There wouldn't have to be the "expense" of
an extra header with each GET, but there are trade
offs with using this approach (like firewall restrictions
etc., and the adoption of a standard but obscure method)

[This paraphrases a message I posted to distributed-registry]

While the Allow: header could be returned in any
response, it is normally only returned in response
to an OPTIONS method.  From one perspective this
describes a refinement of a resources interface:

	Allow: GET,PUT,POST,DELETE  being analogous to:

	interface resource {
		delete();
		representation get();
		put(representation r);
		post(representation r);
	}

		vs. 

	Allow: GET,POST  being analogous to:

	interface resource {
		representation get();
		post(representation r);
	}

From this perspective, the OPTIONS method is already supplying
a form of metadata; using it to give the Meta-Location: header
would seem to be a natural extension to this "functionality."

Post ID:3359
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <jeffreywinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-14 23:32:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> I like your idea of using OPTIONS, but it does seem to be a
> retrofit to its intended purpose of probing HTTP
> servers (and proxies) for their supported methods, types,
> protocol version, etc.

You may very well be right, but I look at the sentence:

  "This method allows the client to determine the options and/or
  requirements associated with a resource, or the capabilities of
  a server, without implying a resource action or initiating a
  resource retrieval."

which *seems* to support its use as a metadata "hook."  But then
again, I have no idea of the history behind this method so I
could be off base.  (The w3c archives are to the spec as the
Federalist Papers are to the Constitution, but probably a lot
of significant discussion isn't publically available)


> How about evaluating these approaches against a specific, theoretical
scenario?

Are talking about evaluating the mechanisms for binding the metadata or for
what that
metadata would look like?

I don't know whether this is a quality library or not, but I like the DAV
support.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3362
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-15 15:47:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> What's the problem?
> 
> jb

Good question. :)

People have been considering mechanisms for binding
metadata to a resource.  HTTP Extensions for Resource 
Metadata (HERM) [1] looks to be a good solution.  It
calls for the use of a pair of headers, Meta-Location
and Meta-About.

We've been considering some potential refinements. I
felt that the OPTIONS method would be the natural place
to return the Meta-Location in the general case, which
is similar to the use of the Allow header.  It's unclear
though if this is stretching the semantics of OPTIONS 
too far.  I'd like to know if it is.

Roy Fielding had mentioned in a posting to 
this list that adding an extra header to each GET is not
optimal [2], but that might be the easiest road to 
adoption.

Other interesting ideas have been floated on the HERM 
associated discussion list [3].



This topic is essentially one aspect of the TAG issue 
"metadataInURI-31" [4] specifically with regards to 
this comment:

    "... and more importantly there should be a "clean", 
    uniform way to refer to (and thus access) the metadata 
    of web resources..."

Another potential issue brought up by Berners-Lee in 
a recent posting [5] to www-tag concerns a similar issue: how
can site level "metadata" such as /favicons, p3p statements
etc., be bound to a site in a standard way.  It would seem 
that the solution to the first issue could form the basis 
of the solution to the second issue.

- Jeff


[1] http://www.xfront.com/dist-reg/distributed-registry.html
[2] http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/3315
[3] http://groups.yahoo.com/group/distributed-registry/
[4] http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#metadataInURI-31 
[5] http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2003Feb/0093.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3363
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <jeffreywinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-15 15:28:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Resource Discovery
Message:

> What's the problem?
> 
> jb

Good question. :)

People have been considering mechanisms for binding
metadata to a resource.  HTTP Extensions for Resource 
Metadata (HERM) [1] looks to be a good solution.  It
calls for the use of a pair of headers, Meta-Location
and Meta-About.

We've been considering some potential refinements. I
felt that the OPTIONS method would be the natural place
to return the Meta-Location in the general case, which
is similar to the use of the Allow header.  It's unclear
though if this is stretching the semantics of OPTIONS 
too far.  I'd like to know if it is.

Roy Fielding had mentioned in a posting to 
this list that adding an extra header to each GET is not
optimal [2], but that might be the easiest road to 
adoption.

Other interesting ideas have been floated on the HERM 
associated discussion list [3].



This topic is essentially one aspect of the TAG issue 
"metadataInURI-31" [4] specifically with regards to 
this comment:

    "... and more importantly there should be a "clean", 
    uniform way to refer to (and thus access) the metadata 
    of web resources..."

a recent posting [5] to www-tag concerns a similar issue: how
can site level "metadata" such as /favicons, p3p statements
etc., be bound to a site in a standard way.  It would seem 
that the solution to the first issue could form the basis 
of the solution to the second issue.

Post ID:3364
Sender:"inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...>" <inthedarkplace@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-16 01:03:45
Subject:Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

Hello All,

I don't really want to bring the dreaded 'What do URIs identify?'
debate which consumes the tag-list every once and a while to this
peaceful list, but I find myself in a position where I must integrate
RDF into a REST based system. I've written up my thoughts about the
best way to do this in 'Integerating RDF with REST in 15 minutes' at:

http://www.columbia.edu/~aso22/rest/RDFandREST.html

Comments would be appreciated... but again, I don't want to start a war :)

- itdp





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3365
Sender:Sam Hunting <shunting@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-16 01:15:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

I think you might consider adding a disclaimer, much like this mail, to
the front of the paer, saying that "these are your thoughts."

For example, Roy Fielding defines "resource" as follows:

<quote>
The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any information
that can be named can be a resource: a document or image, a temporal
service (e.g. "today's weather in Los Angeles"), a collection of other
resources, a non-virtual object (e.g. a person), and so on. In other
words, any concept that might be the target of an author's hypertext
reference must fit within the definition of a resource. A resource is a
conceptual mapping to a set of entities, not the entity that corresponds
to the mapping at any particular point in time
</quote>

However, you write:

<quote>
Let's quickly go over some of the basics of REST.

A resource is an Object that exists on a network.
</quote>

So apparently your views and Roy Fielding's are quite different.


On Sun, 16 Feb 2003, inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...> wrote:

> 
> Hello All,
> 
> I don't really want to bring the dreaded 'What do URIs identify?'
> debate which consumes the tag-list every once and a while to this
> peaceful list, but I find myself in a position where I must integrate
> RDF into a REST based system. I've written up my thoughts about the
> best way to do this in 'Integerating RDF with REST in 15 minutes' at:
> 
> http://www.columbia.edu/~aso22/rest/RDFandREST.html
> 
> Comments would be appreciated... but again, I don't want to start a war :)
> 
> - itdp
> 
> 
> 
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> 
>  
> 
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ 
> 
> 

Sam Hunting
eTopicality, Inc.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Co-Editor, ISO Reference Model for Topic Maps 

Topic map consulting and training: www.etopicality.com
Free open source topic map tools:  www.gooseworks.org

XML Topic Maps: Creating and Using Topic Maps for the Web.
Addison-Wesley, ISBN 0-201-74960-2.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3366
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 06:42:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Another Java HTTP client library
Message:

Another HTTP Client in Java. Looks newer.

http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/httpclient/features.html

Features
--------
Standards based, pure Java, implementation of HTTP versions 1.0 and 1.1
Full implementation of all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD,
OPTIONS, and TRACE) in an extensible OO framework.
Supports encryption with HTTPS (HTTP over SSL) protocol.
Transparent connections through HTTP proxies.
Authentication using Basic, Digest and the encrypting NTLM (NT Lan Manager)
methods.
Multi-Part form POST for uploading large files.
Pluggable secure sockets implementations, making it easier to use third
party solutions
Automatic Cookie handling for reading Set-Cookie: headers from the server
and sending them back out in a Cookie: header when appropriate.
Request output streams to avoid buffering any content body by streaming
directly to the socket to the server.
Response input streams to efficiently read the response body by streaming
directly from the socket to the server.
Persistent connections using KeepAlive in HTTP/1.0 and persistance in
HTTP/1.1
Direct access to the response code and headers sent by the server.
The ability to set connection timeouts.
HttpMethods implement the Command Pattern to allow for parallel requests and
efficient re-use of connections.
Source code is freely available under the Apache Software License.


----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, February 14, 2003 8:50 PM
Subject: [rest-discuss] Another Java HTTP client library


> I found another Java HTTP client, from Apache Slide project (which is a
> grouping of some other Apache projects). It supports DAV also.
>
> http://jakarta.apache.org/slide/clientjavadoc/index.html
>
> I don't know whether this is a quality library or not, but I like the DAV
> support.
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3367
Sender:dave.cantrell@...
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 13:59:40
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

>The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any information
>that can be named can be a resource: a document or image, a temporal
>service (e.g. "today's weather in Los Angeles"), a collection of other
>resources, a non-virtual object (e.g. a person), and so on. In other
>words, any concept that might be the target of an author's hypertext
>reference must fit within the definition of a resource. A resource is a
>conceptual mapping to a set of entities, not the entity that corresponds
>to the mapping at any particular point in time

Question:

By my understanding of REST, the whole purpose of URIs is to provide a means
of addressing a resource which is then available via the various HTTP verbs.
If so, then why *isn't* it just as easy to say "A resource is an Object that
exists on a network"?

While I will concede the "network" point, since URIs can point to local
resources, what good is a URI which points to nothing (ex: the various "urn"
schemes) since it is not available via the HTTP verbs, and therefore is an
island unto itself, creating exactly the problem REST opposes? I know this
behavior is expressed in the very concept of URIs and is used extensively in
RDF, but from what I gathered REST deals specifically with HTTP and
therefore it deals with, well, objects (resources) on a network.

Thanks,
-dave

Thanks, Mike.  I *really* coulda used this about six months ago!

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3370
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 15:51:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

On Tuesday, Feb 18, 2003, at 07:59 US/Central, 
dave.cantrell@... wrote:

> what good is a URI which points to nothing (ex: the various "urn"
> schemes) since it is not available via the HTTP verbs, and therefore 
> is an
> island unto itself, creating exactly the problem REST opposes?

A URI, even an HTTP URI, that cannot be dereferenced nonetheless 
provides a unique name for an abstract resource that can be 
distinguished from all other names for resources.

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3371
Sender:dave.cantrell@...
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 17:10:53
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

>A URI, even an HTTP URI, that cannot be dereferenced nonetheless 
>provides a unique name for an abstract resource that can be 
>distinguished from all other names for resources.

Yes, believe me I do get that point. :)

Maybe I can re-phrase this somehow...

REST is an architectural style for referencing resources across HTTP, right?
So then, what good does "urn:i-am-foo" do me when I can't (a) GET it, (b)
POST to it, (c) PUT it, or (d) DELETE it? How do these URIs fit into the
scope of REST?

Or are we talking about two different things? I can see their use in RDF (as
mentioned in the original e-mail) as unique identifiers, but not as a
REST/HTTP resource itself.

Hmm... Maybe I'm missing something here?

Thanks,
-dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3372
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 17:29:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

> REST is an architectural style for referencing resources across HTTP,
right?

Not exactly.  REST applies outside the bounds of HTTP as well.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3373
Sender:"inthedarkplace <inthedarkplace@...>" <inthedarkplace@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 18:44:42
Subject:Re: Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

Is anybody really interested in URIs that's you can't dereference? And
also, I'd like to point out that you can dereference URNs... various
protocols do exist and are in use to do that. 

I know the problem I'm trying to solve is this: given a set of of HTTP
resources, how can orthogonal 'metadata' that real clients don't care
about be associated with the resources in a clean, simple manner that
doesn't involve radical alterations to the pre-existing web.

- itdp

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, dave.cantrell@g... wrote:

> >provides a unique name for an abstract resource that can be

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3374
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 19:51:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

inthedarkplace wrote:

>Is anybody really interested in URIs that's you can't dereference? And
>also, I'd like to point out that you can dereference URNs... various
>protocols do exist and are in use to do that. 
>
Well, many namespace names are URIs.  While there is some (much) debate, 
I think many don't expect to dereference a namespace name.

There seems to be a desire on some people's part to be able to say that 
if a URI uses a scheme that is dereferencable, the you must be able to 
dereference the URI.  Or conversely, if I have a name that I don't want 
to be dereferenced, then I shouldn't use a URI with a dereferencable 
scheme.  Personally, I don't understand the problem - a name is a name. 
 Some will dereference, other will not.

>
>I know the problem I'm trying to solve is this: given a set of of HTTP
>resources, how can orthogonal 'metadata' that real clients don't care
>about be associated with the resources in a clean, simple manner that
>doesn't involve radical alterations to the pre-existing web.
>  
>
This is another one I don't really understand (the general case, not 
your specific problem).  How do you determine what is metadata and what 
is data?  (One person's metadata is another's data).  Why isnt a chunk 
of metadata for a resource just another resource?  And does it really 
make sense to only allow the owner of a resource to provide metadata for 
that resource.  To me, the question of how do I find metadata for a 
resource sounds a lot like 'how do i find out what resources point to 
this resource?'

--Chuck

>- itdp
>
>--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, dave.cantrell@g... wrote:
>  
>
>>>A URI, even an HTTP URI, that cannot be dereferenced nonetheless 
>>>provides a unique name for an abstract resource that can be 
>>>distinguished from all other names for resources.
>>>      
>>>

>>
>>Maybe I can re-phrase this somehow...

>>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3375
Sender:dave.cantrell@...
Post Date/Time:2003-02-18 21:00:30
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

I'll preface this by saying I'm a REST newbie, so please be gentle... :)

>There seems to be a desire on some people's part to be able to say that 
>if a URI uses a scheme that is dereferencable, the you must be able to 
>dereference the URI.  Or conversely, if I have a name that I don't want 
>to be dereferenced, then I shouldn't use a URI with a dereferencable 
>scheme.  Personally, I don't understand the problem - a name is a name. 
> Some will dereference, other will not.

And this goes to the heart of my problem with this approach: one of the
fundamental ideas behind REST is that a URL is transferrable from one medium
to the next, and no matter where you find it you know (a) it's a URL and (b)
you can use the HTTP verbs against it.

OK, maybe I should qualify that by saying "HTTP URLs" -- maybe that will
clear this up a bit, since URLs don't have to have just an HTTP scheme.

Now, having clarified it as HTTP URLs, let's ask the question again: Why
would I ever want a URL *which specifies an HTTP scheme* to never be
dereferenced? It seems to fly in the face of the philosophy that, given a
URL, I can at least GET it and probably use the other verbs as well. In
other words, it seems very REST-less.

I can see a use for non-dereferencable (is that a word?) URI/Ls (even those
specifying an HTTP scheme), i.e. as unique names in RDF and such, but why
would I ever need such constructs under REST?

>Why isnt a chunk 
>of metadata for a resource just another resource?

But if it's a resource, then mustn't it be available under REST? Maybe I'm
barking up the wrong tree here, if so please let me know so I can get it
right.

Thanks,
-dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3376
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-19 01:13:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Integrating RDF and REST
Message:


dave.cantrell@... wrote:

>I'll preface this by saying I'm a REST newbie, so please be gentle... :)
>
>  
>
>>There seems to be a desire on some people's part to be able to say that 
>>if a URI uses a scheme that is dereferencable, the you must be able to 
>>dereference the URI.  Or conversely, if I have a name that I don't want 
>>to be dereferenced, then I shouldn't use a URI with a dereferencable 
>>scheme.  Personally, I don't understand the problem - a name is a name. 
>>Some will dereference, other will not.
>>    
>>
>
>And this goes to the heart of my problem with this approach: one of the
>fundamental ideas behind REST is that a URL is transferrable from one medium
>to the next, and no matter where you find it you know (a) it's a URL and (b)
>you can use the HTTP verbs against it.
>  
>
I think you have some terminology confused here.  REST as an 
architectural style has no concept of URI/URLs; it only talks about 
identifiers.   The 'fundamental idea' you talk of above is related to 
the Web, not REST.  

When we say that the web is an implementation of REST, dont make the 
mistake of thinking of the relationship between REST and the Web as one 
of superclass/subclass.  The Web is not a subclass of REST.  The Web can 
be classified as a RESTful (more or less) application - just like some 
other application might be classified as a client-server application.

>OK, maybe I should qualify that by saying "HTTP URLs" -- maybe that will
>clear this up a bit, since URLs don't have to have just an HTTP scheme.
>
>Now, having clarified it as HTTP URLs, let's ask the question again: Why
>would I ever want a URL *which specifies an HTTP scheme* to never be
>dereferenced? 
>
You're not the only one to ask that question.  There's been a lot of 
debate on this in the W3C TAG and other places. See the thread that 
starts at http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2002Oct/0118.html 
for just one instance of this discussion

Personally, I have no problem using URIs as simple identifiers 
(dereferencable or not).  A name is a name.  Names exist outside of the 
Web and outside of REST.  The URI spec provides a nice set of rules for 
the syntax to use when constructing names.  Since part of the name is 
the scheme, I'd just as soon use an existing scheme rather than invent 
yet another scheme.  And if I'm going to use an existing scheme, I'll 
stick with http.  

>It seems to fly in the face of the philosophy that, given a
>URL, I can at least GET it and probably use the other verbs as well. In
>other words, it seems very REST-less.
>
There's nothing stopping you from trying to GET any http URI you want 
to.  Note, however, the web makes no guarantee that the GET operation 
will actually succeed.  And don't forget, some resources may only 
respond to a POST. Or you may have a URI for a resource that doesnt 
exist anymore or that hasnt been created yet.  So even if you presume 
that http URIs are meant to be dereferenced, there's nothing in the 
architecture of the Web that guarantees that you'll get anything useful 
when you do so.

>I can see a use for non-dereferencable (is that a word?) URI/Ls (even those
>specifying an HTTP scheme), i.e. as unique names in RDF and such, but why
>would I ever need such constructs under REST?
>  
>
>>Why isnt a chunk 
>>of metadata for a resource just another resource?
>>    
>>
>
>But if it's a resource, then mustn't it be available under REST? Maybe I'm
>barking up the wrong tree here, if so please let me know so I can get it
>right.
>  
>
I'm not sure what you're asking here.  I was just pointing out that I 
don't see a need to try to create two different worlds - one for 
resources and one for metadata.  It seems to me that metadata about some 
resource is itself a resource, so why cant we just handle metadata the 
same way we handle any other resource.


--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3377
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-19 06:22:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Chuck Hinson" <cmhinson@...>

> There's nothing stopping you from trying to GET any http URI you want 
> to.  
Technically, HTTP supports requests against non 'http' URI.

== getting ldap entries ==
GET ldap:ou=org;dn=my.friend HTTP/1.0
Host: directory.anywhere.net
User-Agent: http-aware-phone/v1.0


== making a phone call ===
GET tel:425-555-1212 HTTP/1.0
Host: dial.anywhere.net
User-Agent: http-aware-phone/v1.0


But I might just be smoking high-grade crack here...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3378
Sender:dave.cantrell@...
Post Date/Time:2003-02-19 21:32:09
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Integrating RDF and REST
Message:

>I think you have some terminology confused here.  REST as an 
>architectural style has no concept of URI/URLs; it only talks about 
>identifiers.   The 'fundamental idea' you talk of above is related to 
>the Web, not REST.  
>
>When we say that the web is an implementation of REST, dont make the 
>mistake of thinking of the relationship between REST and the Web as one 
>of superclass/subclass.  The Web is not a subclass of REST.  The Web can 
>be classified as a RESTful (more or less) application - just like some 
>other application might be classified as a client-server application.

Chuck, 

You really cleared things up for me. I was running into this exact problem
in my argument, assuming that REST was tied to the web environment. So it
appears REST could be used in virtually any architecture that (a) supported
strong, unique names for resources, and (b) exposed a limited, common set of
functions on those resources? "Database" immediately springs to mind, and of
course that is an example I've seen given to show how REST works in the
abstract.

Anyway, thanks for opening my eyes -- it's definitely a learning curve, but
a fun one. :)

Thanks,
-dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3379
Sender:Robert Leftwich <robert@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-19 21:59:35
Subject:FYI- Web services authentication takes leap forward
Message:

 From InternetNews.com [1] :

"The OASIS standards consortium Tuesday took another leap forward toward
securing Web services with the ratification of Extensible Access Control
Markup Language 1.0 (XACML) [2] as an OASIS Open Standard.
XACML is a security standard which allows developers to write and enforce
information access policies, making it a key component in the development of
authorization infrastructures and a foundational step in the creation of
federated authentication environments....

Sun Microsystems followed up on XACML's approval Tuesday with the release of
its implementation of the standard under an open source license. [3]"

On first glance this looks promising for securing REST web services as well
as the other sort :-)

Robert

1 http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/1585771
2. 
http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/www.oasis-open.org/committees/xacml/
3. http://sunxacml.sourceforge.net/

Post ID:3380
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-19 23:19:45
Subject:REST/HTTP interface description language?
Message:

Not knowing a lot about the various options out there, is there an interface
description language that is being used to describe RESTful interfaces?  For
instance, I'd like to be able to convey something like the following:


GET,HEAD
    Content-Type: text/html
    Content-Type: text/rss+xml
POST
    Accept: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
    Accept: text/rss+xml


Ideally, I'd like to describe the allowed format of request entities, but
that's a tall order, I'm sure.  So, any pointers?  Suggestions?


---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Message:

From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>



> Not knowing a lot about the various options out there, is there an
interface
> description language that is being used to describe RESTful interfaces?
>
> Ideally, I'd like to describe the allowed format of request entities, but
> that's a tall order, I'm sure.  So, any pointers?  Suggestions?
>
There was some mail a while ago on this - its a recurring issue.
Let's start a Wiki page on it & harvest the email list archives for the
alternate suggestions & use cases.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3382
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-21 19:41:50
Subject:Generating client user interfaces for REST
Message:

I've been continuing my exploration of exposing complex processes
and business process across the Web in a REST style on top of
Quixote.

I'm now able to generate crude graphical user interfaces from an
FSM (finite state machine) that describes a complex process.

How it's done -- A two step process:

  1. From an FSM XML document, generate a .wxg file.  The FSM XML
    document contains specifications of the input items needed at
    each state to select the next transition.  A .wxg file is an
    XML document that contains the definition of a GUI (the
    graphical user interface) and is loadable by wxGlade. wxGlade
    is a GUI design tool for wxPython.

  2. Load the .wxg file into wxGlade, do a bit of editing and
    re-arranging, then select the File/Generate Code menu item to
    generate Python code.

Why you might care about this:

  1. Suppose that you have implemented a BP (business process) as a
    REST-ful FSM server application (using the tools described at
    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/workflow_howto.html or in some
    other way).  Now you want to implement client applications that
    talk to your server application.  And, further more, suppose
    that this client application needs to present a user interface
    to an end user so that the end user can enter information items
    needed by the FSM (e.g. in order to determine which transition
    to take).  Obviously, Python is your first choice for
    implementing these clients and wxPython is a good platform for
    the GUI.  This GUI generating capability is a good way to
    substantially reduce the amount of work needed to produce those
    user interfaces.

  2. Suppose you have implemented a Web service (a REST-ful one, of
    course). Now you want to encourage others out on the Net
    somewhere to implement clients for your service.  By giving
    them help in the implementation of a client user interface, at
    least that part of the user interface that enables human
    end-users to enter data, you have made their work easier.

You can find more information about this capability and how to use
it at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/workflow_howto.html

Look for the section "How to Generate a Client GUI".

The code that does the work is in fsmappgen.py which is in the
example code linked to by this document and can be found at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/workflow_examples.zip

Please let me know if you have corrections or suggestiongs for
improvements.

And, I'm looking for useful ways to apply this technology.  Let me
know if you have ideas about that.

  - Dave

-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3383
Sender:"Jeff Stern <jastern949@...>" <jastern949@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-23 07:46:45
Subject:apache configuration for REST and pseudo-URL's
Message:

okay, this has to be a FAQ, and i'm embarrassed to ask it, BUT :P

i'm new to REST but would like to give it a shot as a way of solving
some problems for multiple web servers having access to centralized
data in my university..

i'd like to configure our apache server for REST -- i.e., set up a
url-dispatcher to handle all urls on my site under a certain directory
(or pseudo-directory), so that i can dispatch the requests to a
handler..  and i can't seem to figure out how to do it without the
actual file *existing*.. i get Error 404 - Object not found! error
messages.

i've played with the SetHandler and Action apache directives, putting
them in a <Location> such as:

   <Location /test >
     Action url-dispatch /cgi-bin/handler.pl
     SetHandler url-dispatch
   </Location>

what i want is for any URL request for, say, 

   http://my.server.com/test/departments
   http://my.server.com/test/departments/engineering
   http://my.server.com/test/faculty
   http://my.server.com/test/faculty/tbsmith
   http://my.server.com/test/departments/engineering/workingpapers/jan2003

   etc., etc.

the above urls to all go to the same handler.. which then parses it
and sends it to the correct sub-script, etc.. i don't want to have to
actually have the test directory (or subdirectories) exist.

i have been through the apache docs a ba-zillion times, and looked
through newsgroups, forums, etc etc etc.. looked here and on pauls
REST pages and the REST wiki.. spent time with altavista/google, even
scoured computer shelves at barnes & noble.. but i can't seem to
figure out how to do this.. 

i don't want to have to go through the trouble of setting up re-write
rules (using mod-rewrite).. but is that what people generally do?

or is the SetHandler/Action way the easier way, but i'm just missing
something? .. what am i doing wrong?

alternatively, is there a tutorial / directions on this somewhere?

finally, what word/term/jargon does one even *use* to refer to this
phenomenon or technique? i've looked stuff up under "dispatcher", or
"URL", or "cgi" or "script", or even with specific apache terms like
"SetHandler".. but is there generally a name for this "technique" so
that i can even know how to refer to it or how to look for it?

i'm ashamed to ask such a basic question, but i would be very grateful
if anyone could point me in the right direction..

thanks.
jeff stern





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3384
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-23 17:02:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] apache configuration for REST and pseudo-URL's
Message:

On Sun, Feb 23, 2003 at 07:46:45AM -0000, Jeff Stern <jastern949@...> wrote:
> i don't want to have to go through the trouble of setting up re-write
> rules (using mod-rewrite).. but is that what people generally do?

That's what I do, for example on http://www.markbaker.ca/2002/09/Blog/ .
Perhaps there are other ways to do this that I'm not familiar with
though.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3385
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-23 18:50:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] apache configuration for REST and pseudo-URL's
Message:

The solution I use in PHP is the following:

<FilesMatch "^test$">
    ForceType application/x-httpd-php
</FilesMatch>

Then, I make sure to have a PHP file called 'test' in the htdocs.  This is
the handler.  You can get everthing below it from the PATH_INFO CGI
variable.  I do no know what the appropriate Type would be for perl, but I'm
sure it's easily found (if you don't already know it).

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3386
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-24 14:16:57
Subject:Querystring question
Message:

Suppose you have a resource that accepts the querystring 'q=foo', but does
not accept any other value for 'q'.  What is the appropriate HTTP response?
Currently, I am using 404, following the argument that the entire URI, not
just the part up to the querystring identifies a resource.  Since any value
other than 'foo' would not identify that resource, I return a 404.  In a
related question, what if that field were given and were valid ('q=foo'),
but the querystring contained other fields as well?  Again, in my case, I am
using 404 with the same arguement as above.

Anyone see problems with this approach?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3387
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-24 15:05:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Querystring question
Message:

On Mon, 24 Feb 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> related question, what if that field were given and were valid ('q=foo'),
> but the querystring contained other fields as well?  Again, in my case, I am
> using 404 with the same arguement as above.

It would only make sense to do this if the other
fields were inapplicable.
For example, 'name=socrates' and 'name=socrates&mortal=yes'
shold work, but 'name=socrates&mortal=no' should
return 404.

There is something funny about FALSE being equal
to NotFound, but I'm not sure what it is.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Post Date/Time:2003-02-24 15:44:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Querystring question
Message:

If "mortal" isn't recognized at all, then what?  It seems to me that 404 is
the correct response, but I wanted to make sure...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

It's still the authors choice how to handle this. Just like is procedural
languages where some use null to indicate things, as compared to holding a
boolean value.

Post ID:3390
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-24 23:25:13
Subject:Supporting DELETE/PUT via web browser
Message:

Hello All,

I'm looking for information regarding support for DELETE/PUT via a
standard web browser. Browsing through the archive it seems you need a
kludge to do that.

1. If so, what technique is preferable? Hidden field? URL rewriting?
2. Do browsers support it after all??

Thanks for any pointer.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3391
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-24 23:56:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Supporting DELETE/PUT via web browser
Message:

Berend de Boer <berend@...> writes:

> Hello All,
> 
> I'm looking for information regarding support for DELETE/PUT via a
> standard web browser. Browsing through the archive it seems you need a
> kludge to do that.
> 
> 1. If so, what technique is preferable? Hidden field? URL rewriting?
> 2. Do browsers support it after all??

Mozilla supports is through the XMLHttpRequest object.

See this for more info:

http://www.xulplanet.com/references/elemref/ref_XMLHttpRequest.html



Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3392
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-25 00:05:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Supporting DELETE/PUT via web browser
Message:

On Monday, February 24, 2003, at 11:25 PM, Berend de Boer wrote:
> Hello All,
>
> I'm looking for information regarding support for DELETE/PUT via a
> standard web browser. Browsing through the archive it seems you need a
> kludge to do that.

correct.

> 1. If so, what technique is preferable? Hidden field? URL rewriting?

if you mean rewriting to include the method, as in ?method=foo then 
that is NOT preferable because it results in a GET with side-effects; 
GETs are supposed to be idempotent.

frequently, POST and PUT are not applicable to the same resource (at 
least in my experience), so you can overload POST to do what you want.  
i pre-process such POST requests on the server (this is arguably an 
intermediary in REST nomenclature) to call PUT code instead.

delete can be done with a hidden (or submit) form field.

> 2. Do browsers support it after all??

only via XMLHttpRequest.

HTH,
-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3393
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-25 03:12:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Querystring question
Message:

On Mon, Feb 24, 2003 at 10:44:40AM -0500, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> If "mortal" isn't recognized at all, then what?  It seems to me that 404 is
> the correct response, but I wanted to make sure...

I've used 404 myself, but I could think of good reasons not to.

If there was some set of query params that identified the "primary
key" for the resource, then additional parameters could safely be
ignored such that GET returned the same representations as for the
URI with only the primary key params specified.  In theory, it may be
useful to return a 302 response back to this primary URI; in practice,
it's certainly not worth the extra round trip, so probably fine to
just return the same representations on a 200 until new parameters
are supported.

If you expect your primary key may change, then a 404 approach
probably makes good sense.

That's just my first thoughts on the subject.  It's a pretty
interesting question though; a real mental-model stress test.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3394
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-25 04:09:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Querystring question
Message:

From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>
> On Mon, Feb 24, 2003 at 10:44:40AM -0500, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> > If "mortal" isn't recognized at all, then what?  It seems to me that 404
is
> > the correct response, but I wanted to make sure...
>
> I've used 404 myself, but I could think of good reasons not to.
>
> If there was some set of query params that identified the "primary
> key" for the resource, then additional parameters could safely be
> ignored such that GET returned the same representations as for the
> URI with only the primary key params specified.  In theory, it may be
> useful to return a 302 response back to this primary URI; in practice,
> it's certainly not worth the extra round trip, so probably fine to
> just return the same representations on a 200 until new parameters
> are supported.

Hmm... I suppose you could also just return a Content-Location: header with
the 200 response.  On the other hand, this effectively allows others to
extend the URL with your implicit permission.  For instance, suppose someone
chose to add their own query parameter which they used in their own system
for some reason or other.  Now, suppose at a later point in time, you decide
to add a new query parameter to your system which just happens to be the
same name as someone else's parameter name.  Potentially, you could cause
unexpected side effects for that link that's already out there.  Admittedly,
it's unlikely that this scenario would happen, but there's a lot about the
web today that I would have said the same thing about yesterday.

> If you expect your primary key may change, then a 404 approach
> probably makes good sense.

In this case, I do not have the pk in the query string.  I have just
finished writing a new blog system (didn't like any of the ones I found),
trying to use the REST architecture as much as possible.  I still have a
long way to go, but the first version is up and running(?) at
http://www.seairth.com/blog. In this case, the query string is only used to
fetch html-based forms for adding/editing folders and entries.  For
instance, suppose I have an folder whose URL is:

http://www.seairth.com/blog/blogg

(yes, it actually exists)  If you do a GET on that URL, you will get back an
appropriate representation of the resource.  Now, if I wanted to create a
new subfolder or entry, I would POST the appropriate message to that URL.
This could be done by writing a gui application similar to what Joe Gregorio
has done with his blog system.  However, since I don't have ony yet, I opted
to use html-based forms.  In order to fetch the appropriate form, I would
use a URL like:

http://www.seairth.com/blog/blogg?form=addentry

(yes, it exists, but is protected)  This would return to me an html form,
which would in turn just POST to the URL (without the query string).  At the
end of the day, it all works really, really well.  So far, anyhow.  :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3395
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 11:23:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...> writes:

> Hey - I just found out there was a note back in 1999 about using HTML forms
> to do authentication.
> I haven't read it fully, but this is one of my pet peeves with HTTP and the
> 'visual Web' - no visibility of security information in messages. (leading
> to sessions, cookies, wacky urls, etc.)
> 
> ===
> http://www.w3.org/TR/1999/NOTE-authentform-19990203
> 
> [...]
> This proposal suggests extensions to HTML forms to overcome their present
> security problems by integrating them with HTTP (or other security sublayer)
> mechanisms. It calls for a new type of form; the AUTHFORM and new values for
> the TYPE attribute of the INPUT element and SELECT block.
> [...]

I've been thinking about this as well. I'm due to give an
evangelizing talk about REST for a client and I know that this is
going to come up.

My experience of HTTP authentication is that the fixed user interface 
makes it unpopular with users (or at least website designers) and that
has a knock on effect on the architecture of web services components
built as part of the same application.


It seems the ideas put forward in the link above were not
popular. Adding stuff to HTML doesn't seem like the right thing to do
anyway.

I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
via some content-location like header.

If it were possible to associate an entity with the authentication
then browsers could render it when they find it and use the standard
dialog box when they don't.

Would that sort of scheme violate REST principles in anyway?


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3396
Sender:Chris Croome <chris@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 11:34:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Hi

On Wed 26-Feb-2003 at 11:23:07AM +0000, Nic Ferrier wrote:
> 
> My experience of HTTP authentication is that the fixed user
> interface makes it unpopular with users (or at least website
> designers) and that has a knock on effect on the architecture of
> web services components built as part of the same application.

I think the biggest problem with HTTP Authentication is that no web
browser has a 'logout' function and the worst thing about this is
that if you type the wrong password you then have to close your
browser before trying again.

This is the bugzilla entry for this:

  http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=55181

Chris

-- 
Chris Croome                               <chris@...>
web design                             http://www.webarchitects.co.uk/ 
web content management                               http://mkdoc.com/   
everything else                               http://chris.croome.net/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3397
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 11:40:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Chris Croome <chris@...> writes:

> Hi
> 
> On Wed 26-Feb-2003 at 11:23:07AM +0000, Nic Ferrier wrote:
> >
> > My experience of HTTP authentication is that the fixed user
> > interface makes it unpopular with users (or at least website
> > designers) and that has a knock on effect on the architecture of
> > web services components built as part of the same application.
> 
> I think the biggest problem with HTTP Authentication is that no web
> browser has a 'logout' function and the worst thing about this is
> that if you type the wrong password you then have to close your
> browser before trying again.
> 
> This is the bugzilla entry for this:
> 
>   http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=55181

It's a long time since I dealt with basic auth... but I thought it was
possible to send the UNAUTHORIZED response to log the user out and
then have the user log in again with another username and password.

The problem with that is again the crappy UI. If the browser always
displayed the entity "facilitating" the authentication (ie: the entity
in the UNAUTHORIZED response) then the user could have a clear logout
that worked as they expect it to.


Does that make sense?


Nic

> 
> It's a long time since I dealt with basic auth... but I thought it
> was possible to send the UNAUTHORIZED response to log the user out
> and then have the user log in again with another username and
> password.

In my experience it doesn't work like that :-(

Personally I do things like adding a . to the domain name to fool
the browser into letting me have another go but this is not an
answer.

Chris

on the server.  But it's a logout followed immediately by another
login, which I'm not sure is the requirement here.
