-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3401
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 14:04:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Walden Mathews <waldenm@...> writes:

> > > It's a long time since I dealt with basic auth... but I thought it
> > > was possible to send the UNAUTHORIZED response to log the user out
> > > and then have the user log in again with another username and
> > > password.
> >
> > In my experience it doesn't work like that :-(
> 
> It certainly can work like that, provided you build the part needed
> on the server.  But it's a logout followed immediately by another
> login, which I'm not sure is the requirement here.

That's right. If you've ever shown a user an app that works like that
you'll not have quickly forgotten the look of disgust you get  /8->


My point about the entity body was that if the UA aways preferred the
display of the entity over popping up it's own dialog then it woiuld
be easy to present a nice UI with basic auth.

The trouble is I guess, that javascript would be needed to send the
basic auth request because there's no syntax in HTML to do it (which
is what kicked this thread off).


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3402
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 14:35:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Chris Croome" <chris@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, February 26, 2003 9:02 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM
elements


> Hi
>
> On Wed 26-Feb-2003 at 08:58:33AM -0500, Walden Mathews wrote:
> >
> > It certainly can work like that, provided you build the part
> > needed on the server.  But it's a logout followed immediately by
> > another login, which I'm not sure is the requirement here.
>
> Really? which HTTP status code is a logout?
>

401 UNAUTHORIZED, as said above.

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3403
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 15:04:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>

> I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> via some content-location like header.
>
> If it were possible to associate an entity with the authentication
> then browsers could render it when they find it and use the standard
> dialog box when they don't.

Actually, 401 can have an entity in the response[1].  Unfortunately, it's
intended to be displayed only when a login attempt fails.

In truth, the dialog box bothers me less and less.  I think the browser
makers could dress it up a bit, making it look more like a feature of the
browser instead of a out-of-place dumpy dialog box.

As for the 'logout' bit, I think this gets back to some of the theories
behind REST itself.  My understanding is that 401 allows you to
*authenticate*, not *log in*.  "Logging in" implies maintaining some form of
server-side session state, which is a big REST no-no (at least as I
understand it).  In this view, it makes sense that there would not be a
corresponding "logout" ability.  I think that treating 401 as "login"
instead of "authentication" has been one of it's biggest barriers to it
being more widely accepted.  I have to admit that I had the same
issues/problems early on.  However, now that I have the correct mindset, I
find it to be the correct way to go.

It seems to me that if you have a RESTful application that you are
demonstrating (i.e. no server-side session state), when someone asked "how
do you log on?", you could say something like "You don't need to log on or
log off.  That's the old way of doing things.  Now, you only have to
authenticate yourself. That's it."  Sure, you might get a few people asking
"what's the difference?", but this would give you the opportunity to
enlighten them.  :)

[1] http://rfc.net/rfc2616.html#s10.4.2

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3404
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 15:34:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

> As for the 'logout' bit, I think this gets back to some of the theories
> behind REST itself.  My understanding is that 401 allows you to
> *authenticate*, not *log in*.  "Logging in" implies maintaining some form
of
> server-side session state, which is a big REST no-no (at least as I
> understand it).

I think, if I understand this discussion, what's wanted is a protocol
between user and UA, in which login session does exist, such that
the UA knows when to stop sending the credentials to the server.
That would constitute a logout.  There's certainly nothing wrong with
maintaining a session between user and UI, is there?  Otherwise,
the user has to type credentials over and over, which is no good.

Walden

Sender:Chris Croome <chris@...>

> >
> > Really? which HTTP status code is a logout?
> 
> 401 UNAUTHORIZED, as said above.

Oops, sorry :-(

I still don't understand how after sending a 401 you can get a web
browser to re-prompt the user for the username and password? I've
never managed to achieve this.

Chris

Post ID:3406
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 15:51:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...> writes:

> From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>
> 
> > I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> > entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> > via some content-location like header.
> >
> > If it were possible to associate an entity with the authentication
> > then browsers could render it when they find it and use the standard
> > dialog box when they don't.
> 
> Actually, 401 can have an entity in the response[1].  Unfortunately, it's
> intended to be displayed only when a login attempt fails.

Yes, sorry. That was my point. I just wasn't terribly clear.

 
> In truth, the dialog box bothers me less and less.  I think the browser
> makers could dress it up a bit, making it look more like a feature of the
> browser instead of a out-of-place dumpy dialog box.

I don't think that's true, the exact means by which users authenticate
will always need to be under application control because clients like
it that way. I don't know many websites that use basic auth now, but
ones that offer "login" forms abound, and not just for non-techies.

Even from a webservices perspective my suggested change to the 401
behaviour looks useful: a server might want to supply to a client a
page describing the authentication system to be used. Maybe a user
token can be obtained from an ldap server somewhere, or something
like that.


> As for the 'logout' bit, I think this gets back to some of the theories
> behind REST itself.  My understanding is that 401 allows you to
> *authenticate*, not *log in*.  "Logging in" implies maintaining some form of
> server-side session state, which is a big REST no-no (at least as I
> understand it).  In this view, it makes sense that there would not be a
> corresponding "logout" ability.

It depends what you mean by "login" doesn't it  /8->

Does REST really require that there be no server maintained state at
all? I thought the problem was how the association between server and
client is done: if it's done RESTfully (one way would be by
authentication) then it's ok isn't it?


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3407
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 15:53:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> I think, if I understand this discussion, what's wanted is a protocol
> between user and UA, in which login session does exist, such that
> the UA knows when to stop sending the credentials to the server.
> That would constitute a logout.  There's certainly nothing wrong with
> maintaining a session between user and UI, is there?  Otherwise,
> the user has to type credentials over and over, which is no good.

But the user *does* have to type credentials over and over.  Fortunately,
the browser is doing the work for him.  Why would a RESTful application care
whether the user was "logged in" or "logged out"?  All the server should
care about is that the user is authorized.

Now, I do understand the security risk(s) here.  Until the browser is closed
or the server sends another 401 for the same realm, that browser (or
whatever agent) basically has the security clearance of the user.  Since
there is no guarantee that the same user will be using that instance of the
browser, there is the possibility for someone else to get into the system
with the wrong credentials.  However, I do not believe this is a problem for
the server to solve.  Instead, I think it's important to improve the client.

Here are some suggestions:

1) When a browser is sending authentication with each request, prominantly
provide a button on the screen labeled "clear authentication" (or some
such).  A user can click on this at any time to force the browser to dump
the authentication.

2) When the user leaves the authenticated page/realm, have the browser
prompt the user as to whether the authentication information should be
cleared or not.  This way, a user does not have to depend on #1 above or on
closing the browser in order to go to another website.

3) Just as you would expect for gaining access to other everyday items,
require the user to authenticate himself to the browser via biometrics, an
access card, etc.  In other words, the user-to-browser credentials should
leave with the user and cause the browser-to-server credentials to be
cleared immediately.

Again, I think the "logout"/security problem is not with the server.  We
should not be solving it at the server.  The weakness is with the
browser/user-agent and that's where it should be fixed. imho, of course.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Subject:DELETE and 404 Not Found
Message:

I recall reading a while ago that returning an HTTP status 404 against a 
delete request was the wrong thing to do. Can anyone enlighten me as to 
why?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3410
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 16:17:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE and 404 Not Found
Message:

I'm not sure there was consesus on this.  As I recall, this issue came down
to whether the end state of a DELETE is what's important or the state change
itself.  If the state change is important, then returning a 404 would
indicate that there was no state change (since the resource did not exist).
On the other hand, if the end state was important, then returning a 200 (or
204) would always be used whether the resource existed at the time of the
request or not, since the end state would be the same either way.
Personally, I'd say it depends on the requirements of the application...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Richard Padley" <rest-discuss@...>
>
> I recall reading a while ago that returning an HTTP status 404 against a
> delete request was the wrong thing to do. Can anyone enlighten me as to
> why?

How is a 'logout' 401 different from a 'login' 401?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3412
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 17:04:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Following the link below, I read a recent note that was kinda interesting.
Appearently, IE6 (SP1) has added the ability to dump the cache.  Here is a
bit of javascript I wrote to do it:

<a href="javascript:void
document.execCommand('ClearAuthenticationCache',false, null)">Clear
Authentication</a>

Even more interesting is that I added this link to my Favorites/Links (which
I show as a toolbar) and now have a way to clear my authentication cache any
time I want to.  It would be nice for MS to have made this available in
general, but it's neat to have found it anyway.

For those of you who want a logout (at least when IE6 SP1 is used), you
could extend this to clear the cache, then GET a "thanks for using us" page,
or whatever...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Post ID:3414
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 17:07:01
Subject:Containers and nested representations
Message:

I've been working through a few issues related to how a container 
resource behaves, and I'm not sure if I'm bumping into some limitations 
of REST or HTTP.

Imagine I have two kinds of resource, boxes and widgets. All wigets are 
contained in boxes. So, to examine a given box I can

GET /box/100 HTTP/1.1

and the response is

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: text/xml

<box x:href="/box/100">
   <box-id>100</box-id>
   <colour>Blue</colour>
   <widget x:href="/widget/33">
     <widget_id>33<widget_id>
     <colour>Green</colour>
     <size>9</size>
   </widget>
   <widget x:href="/widget/34">
     <widget_id>34<widget_id>
     <colour>Black</colour>
     <size>10</size>
   </widget>
</box>

The idea here is that the contained resources are serialised in the 
representation. I'm assuming that this is OK from a REST perspective.

Now I want to modify a box. I'm going to use PUT to replace the whole 
box. In doing this I'll naturally be replacing the contained widgets as 
well.

PUT /box/100 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml

<box>
   <box-id>100</box-id>
   <colour>Green</colour>
   <widget>
     <widget_id>33<widget_id>
     <colour>Blue</colour>
     <size>9</size>
   </widget>
   <widget>
     <widget_id>35<widget_id>
     <colour>Black</colour>
     <size>9</size>
   </widget>
</box>

The response is

HTTP/1.1 204 No Content

Now, I've changed the colour of this box, and I've both changed the 
colour of widget 33, and added a new widget 35 to the container. Also I 
have deleted widget 34, since it now had no container, and this is not 
allowed (in this particular application).

My question is, have I done too much at once here? I'd like to be able 
to indicate the newly created widget 35 with a 201 Created response, but 
the response I must return relates to the container, not its contents. 
Also I'm not too happy with the indirect addressing that seems to be 
happening here - I have the URI for the box as part of the request, but 
this request affects other resources, which I can only address inside 
the message-body itsself, which just seems wrong.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3415
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 17:06:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Chris Croome <chris@...> writes:

> Hi
> 
> On Wed 26-Feb-2003 at 08:58:33AM -0500, Walden Mathews wrote:
> >
> > It certainly can work like that, provided you build the part
> > needed on the server.  But it's a logout followed immediately by
> > another login, which I'm not sure is the requirement here.
> 
> I'm sorry if I'm being really think but I still don't understand,
> 'logout' and 'login' are _both_ 401's?
> 
> How is a 'logout' 401 different from a 'login' 401?

No... 401 is authentication challenge. Whenever the UA recieves an
authentication challenge it should respond with whatever auth details
it has got.

That may be the subject of your confusion. Some caching somewhere?
I'm a hippy so I never use IE and may not have experienced some cache
induced problem with authentication.


Nic

after a client has, by mistake, typed the wrong passwd, and
submitted it they can be re-prompted for a username and passwd
again.

In my experience the only way to get a new prompt for a username and
passwd is to shut the browser and start again.

1k cache and to refresh everything every time...

Post ID:3417

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements

commercial software. I'm using moz on linux as well, before that I
used mainly navigator 4.x

When my basic auth apps want to log someone out they send a 401 even
when the user is already passing in a WWW-Authenticate header.

The behaviour I see, and what I think is correct, is the browser
popping up the window again.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3418
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 17:43:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Containers and nested representations
Message:

On Wednesday, February 26, 2003, at 05:07 PM, Richard Padley wrote:
> I've been working through a few issues related to how a container
> resource behaves, and I'm not sure if I'm bumping into some limitations
> of REST or HTTP.

Thanks for sharing this; I've been a bit complacent in posting my 
experiences with containers to this list.

> [snip example]

> The idea here is that the contained resources are serialised in the
> representation. I'm assuming that this is OK from a REST perspective.

I see nothing wrong with it; it doesn't say anywhere 'one resource 
can't contain another', AFAIK.

> Now I want to modify a box. I'm going to use PUT to replace the whole
> box. In doing this I'll naturally be replacing the contained widgets as
> well.
>
> [snip example]

> The response is
>
> HTTP/1.1 204 No Content

Maybe this could be a 200 with the updated box/100?  The 204 just seems 
kind of 'useless' to me.

> Now, I've changed the colour of this box, and I've both changed the
> colour of widget 33, and added a new widget 35 to the container. Also I
> have deleted widget 34, since it now had no container, and this is not
> allowed (in this particular application).

Hmm.. I'm not sure that having widget 34 automatically 'fall off a 
cliff' is a good thing.

It may be helpful to consider the fact that 'widgets can not have no 
container' a constraint specific to your application, and try and find 
a strategy that is RESTful to enforce it.

Idea:
Perhaps you should explore the concept of a 'reaper' process (a client 
UA or something on the server) which periodically searches and destroys 
orphaned widgets (it could use explicit DELETE requests to do this on 
the results of a GET /widgets?parent=null or whatever).

But see below.

> My question is, have I done too much at once here? I'd like to be able
> to indicate the newly created widget 35 with a 201 Created response, 
> but
> the response I must return relates to the container, not its contents.
> Also I'm not too happy with the indirect addressing that seems to be
> happening here - I have the URI for the box as part of the request, but
> this request affects other resources, which I can only address inside
> the message-body itsself, which just seems wrong.

I have asked the same question (aloud, not on the list).  I think its 
something of a grey area.

Rather than a big fat PUT to the container, you could split your 
request up in to a number of constituent requests to constituent 
resources.  for example:

1. PUT to widget/33 changing the colour.  this would (or should?) 
update box/100 automatically because it has a dependency on widget/33.
2. POST widget/35's URI to box/100 (possible after POSTing 35 to 
widgets).
3. DELETE 34.
    or
    PUT box/100 minus the mention of widget/34.

the trouble with the delete of 34 is that the semantics are overloaded. 
  the PUT to the box that excludes the 34 really only removes it from 
the container, rather than deleting it outright.  these are two 
seperate semantic actions.

i would be interested to hear what you (and others) think of this.

D.J. Adams has written about this same idea at
http://www.pipetree.com/space/RtRest (warning this is cutnpaste from 
the HTML):

--CUT
Having something like /ticket/42/basics/status returning a 
representation of ticket 42's status in text/plain, say "new", is a 
very attractive feature, I think.

GET /ticket/42/basics/status HTTP/1.1

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Connection: Close
Content-Type: text/plain

open

Preferable to composing a method call, serialising it into XML, sending 
  it to an end point, and then parsing the result out of the XML that 
comes back, all to retrieve such a simple piece of data. It's 
intriguing.
--CUT

anyway, thanks again for the thought-provoking post, and the coherent 
example (works wonders when trying to ask a question!).

regards,
-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3419
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 17:59:07
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Containers and nested representations
Message:

>> My question is, have I done too much at once here? 

It depends entirely on the nature of the application.  There is
nothing wrong with resources containing other resources and updating
them all at once, as this is probably more efficient in many
circumstances.

But you're right, this may result in the silent creation of resources
that you haven't explicity given URIs.

This is the same mechanism I am using in an application that I've 
described here:

  http://www.xefer.com/rebel/rebel.html

I'm using <folder> and <bookmark> but the idea is the same.

>> I'd like to be able
>> to indicate the newly created widget 35 with a 201 Created response, 
>> but
>> the response I must return relates to the container, not its
contents.
>> Also I'm not too happy with the indirect addressing that seems to be
>> happening here - I have the URI for the box as part of the request,
but
>> this request affects other resources, which I can only address inside
>> the message-body itsself, which just seems wrong.

>> Rather than a big fat PUT to the container, you could split your 
>> request up in to a number of constituent requests to constituent 
>> resources.  for example:

> 1. PUT to widget/33 changing the colour.  this would (or should?) 
> update box/100 automatically because it has a dependency on widget/33.
> 2. POST widget/35's URI to box/100 (possible after POSTing 35 to 
> widgets).
> 3. DELETE 34.
>    or
>    PUT box/100 minus the mention of widget/34.

I chose to support both the cource-grained PUT and the finer-grained
methods
on each of the "contained" resources in the exact manner you've
described
here.

> the trouble with the delete of 34 is that the semantics are
overloaded. 
>  the PUT to the box that excludes the 34 really only removes it from 
> the container, rather than deleting it outright.  these are two 
> seperate semantic actions. 

This would depend on the underlying datamodel of course and is entirely
up to the application.  If a <widget> can exist as a standalone entity
then you would probably be forced to implement the operation as a
"remove"
and force a "delete" to be done with a DELETE on the widget resource
itself.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3420

> that I used mainly navigator 4.x

> this and send it to you. It might be interesting to get to the
> bottom of the problem.

That would be great :-)

Here is my test, using a site I have been working on, that anyone
can signup for an account on (on the http interface):

  https://www.helpisathand.gov.uk/

  Username: foo 
  Password: bar

You then get an 401 and after you have this I have never been able
to get a new prompt for a uesername passords pair.

web content management                               http://mkdoc.com/   
everything else                               http://chris.croome.net/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3421
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 21:57:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

Here is a more basic question:
Why is authentication part of the HTTP
specification at all?

You can always generate single-use or secret URLs
for applications that need them.

And if the issue is sharing information, that
would come under the scope of people mailing each
other the information as well...

What are the actual use-cases for HTTP-auth?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


On 26 Feb 2003, Nic Ferrier wrote:

> "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...> writes:
>
> > Hey - I just found out there was a note back in 1999 about using HTML forms
> > to do authentication.
> > I haven't read it fully, but this is one of my pet peeves with HTTP and the
> > 'visual Web' - no visibility of security information in messages. (leading
> > to sessions, cookies, wacky urls, etc.)
> >
> > ===
> > http://www.w3.org/TR/1999/NOTE-authentform-19990203
> >
> > [...]
> > This proposal suggests extensions to HTML forms to overcome their present
> > security problems by integrating them with HTTP (or other security sublayer)
> > mechanisms. It calls for a new type of form; the AUTHFORM and new values for
> > the TYPE attribute of the INPUT element and SELECT block.
> > [...]
>
> I've been thinking about this as well. I'm due to give an
> evangelizing talk about REST for a client and I know that this is
> going to come up.
>
> My experience of HTTP authentication is that the fixed user interface
> makes it unpopular with users (or at least website designers) and that
> has a knock on effect on the architecture of web services components
> built as part of the same application.
>
>
> It seems the ideas put forward in the link above were not
> popular. Adding stuff to HTML doesn't seem like the right thing to do
> anyway.
>
> I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> via some content-location like header.
>
> If it were possible to associate an entity with the authentication
> then browsers could render it when they find it and use the standard
> dialog box when they don't.
>
> Would that sort of scheme violate REST principles in anyway?
>
>
> Nic
>
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3422
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-26 22:03:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:


S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>Here is a more basic question:
>Why is authentication part of the HTTP
>specification at all?
>
>You can always generate single-use or secret URLs
>for applications that need them.
>  
>
Obscurity is generally understood to be a poor security mechanism (at 
least when used as the only mechanism).

>And if the issue is sharing information, that
>would come under the scope of people mailing each
>other the information as well...
>
>What are the actual use-cases for HTTP-auth?
>  
>
I publish a page on a web site that only certain people are allowed to 
see.  How do I restrict access to that page?  If HTTP is the protocol 
used to access resources, then it has to provide some mechanism for 
controlling access.  Where else would you suggest putting the access 
control mechanism?

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3423
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-27 02:51:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

>
> But the user *does* have to type credentials over and over.  Fortunately,
> the browser is doing the work for him.  Why would a RESTful application
care
> whether the user was "logged in" or "logged out"?  All the server should
> care about is that the user is authorized.
>

If the browser is doing the work, then the use isn't typing username and
password for each page accessed in the realm.  That's like a "session"
between user (person) and UI (browser), which is different from a session
between UI and server, which is frowned upon in REST, for scaleability
reasons.

Above, I think you're talking about UI-server stuff; I'm not.

Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3424
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>

> never managed to achieve this.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3425
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-27 04:09:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>

> It seems the ideas put forward in the link above were not
> popular. Adding stuff to HTML doesn't seem like the right thing to do
> anyway.
>
> I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> via some content-location like header.
Fundamentally, the user-agent (browser, spider, utility, etc.) is
responsible for placing the correct bits in the authentication header(s).
Displaying the entity associated with an authentication challenge is nice,
but without indicating that user input is meant as protocol-level
authentication, then the user-agent will not be able to manage that. That is
why adding stuff to HTML is necessary.

The alternative approach is that the server controls the lifetime of
authentication information - essentially cookie based.
Adding things to the protocol to support control over authentication
lifetime might be an approach that gives application authors control, but
provides visibility to user-agents (and intermediaries). The kinds of things
I'm thinking about are responses indicating 'forget auth for this realm' and
'remember this auth-token for this realm'. Cookies are a generalized form of
this, but you lose the visibility that there is security information in
there.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3426
Sender:"Yannick Loiseau" <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-27 07:27:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

> 1) When a browser is sending authentication with each request, prominantly
> provide a button on the screen labeled "clear authentication" (or some
> such).  A user can click on this at any time to force the browser to dump
> the authentication.

This is the way DAVExplorer (a webDAV browser in Java,  la explorer) manage
authentication.
There is a menu function "clear auth buffer"





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3427
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-27 14:54:03
Subject:RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation
Message:

I want to provide a syndicated feed of my new blog system.  For starters, I
intend to support the following specs:

RSS 0.92
RSS 2.0

However, how would I RESTfully determine which version to return to a given
request?  Getting a request Accept: header value of "text/xml" or
"application/rss+xml" wouldn't necessarily do any good (would it?).  As a
result, I have implemented a query parameter called "rss" which can have the
values of "0.92" or "2.0".  However, I have seen some other blog systems
(most notably Sam Ruby's [1]) that use pseudo-extensions (".rss", ".rss2")
to acheive the same goal.

So, either way you look at it, a given resource could have three URIs.  Each
URI returns a slightly different representation of the resource (e.g.
additional data in RSS 2.0 that's not in RSS 0.92, etc.).  To some extent, I
think this is okay, RESTfully speaking.  However, this brings into question
the need for content negotiation.

When should one technique be used above another?  When conneg is not an
option, what is the best technique to use, and is that technique nothing but
a kludge?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

[1] http://www.intertwingly.net/rss/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3428
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-27 19:13:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Containers and nested representations
Message:

On Wed, Feb 26, 2003 at 05:07:01PM +0000, Richard Padley wrote:
> My question is, have I done too much at once here?

Not AFAIK.  I'm surprised I haven't run into this yet, but in all the
work I've done with containers, PUT never made sense.  That doesn't
mean it can't though.

I always figured that when I did need to support PUT, I would end up
using WebDAV's 207 (Multi-Status) response.  AFAICT though, there's no
provision for communicating Location header values within the response.
I wonder if you could shove that in the response, as some XML encoded
RDF (and not break DAV clients)?

> I'd like to be able 
> to indicate the newly created widget 35 with a 201 Created response, but 
> the response I must return relates to the container, not its contents. 
> Also I'm not too happy with the indirect addressing that seems to be 
> happening here - I have the URI for the box as part of the request, but 
> this request affects other resources, which I can only address inside 
> the message-body itsself, which just seems wrong.

There's no problem with that from a REST POV, AFAIK.  Shit happens, so
to speak. 8-)

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3429
Sender:dave.cantrell@...
Post Date/Time:2003-02-27 19:34:29
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] RESTfully distinguishing requests without cont ent negotiation
Message:

> So, either way you look at it, a given resource could have 
> three URIs.  Each URI returns a slightly different 
> representation of the resource (e.g. additional data in RSS 
> 2.0 that's not in RSS 0.92, etc.).  To some extent, I think 
> this is okay, RESTfully speaking.  However, this brings into 
> question the need for content negotiation.
> 
> When should one technique be used above another?  When conneg 
> is not an option, what is the best technique to use, and is 
> that technique nothing but a kludge?

If I can rephrase this slightly, I have a similar question: is the
querystring (after the ? Character) part of the resource "noun" under REST?

In other words, given the following URL:

	http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2

Is the "noun" resource http://www.my-server.com/foo with parameters attached
to the query, or is it http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2 ?

If it's the latter, then I assume this is considered a completely different
"noun"?

	http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2&c=3

By my (admittedly limited) understanding of REST, the URL is simply an
address to a resource, and the server returns a representation of a
resource. So which is the resource in the first URL above?

Thanks,
-dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3430
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 01:05:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Wed, 26 Feb 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> >You can always generate single-use or secret URLs
> >for applications that need them.
> Obscurity is generally understood to be a poor security mechanism (at
> least when used as the only mechanism).

If each user gets his/her own URL then this is
equivalent to passing a name/password with each
request.

> >What are the actual use-cases for HTTP-auth?
> >
> >
> I publish a page on a web site that only certain people are allowed to
> see.  How do I restrict access to that page?  If HTTP is the protocol
> used to access resources, then it has to provide some mechanism for
> controlling access.  Where else would you suggest putting the access
> control mechanism?

You POST credentials to a login resource and
receive a redirect to the restricted URL.

Under this scheme, you have really direct control
of login/logout.

-Alex-

S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Post ID:3432
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 01:32:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation
Message:

The correct answer is to define another MIME type.
e.g. application/rss2+xml

Until it is officially in IANA, use
application/x-rss2+xml

Blurring MIME types just erodes MIME.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3434
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 01:45:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Thu, 27 Feb 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> So if I have a really large user population and I want 250000 of them to
> have access to a particular document document or resource, you want me
> to create 250000 different URLs?

Depends on your application.  In many application
domains, it is completely reasonable to generate a
different URL in each announcment email.

Alternatively:

> >You POST credentials to a login resource and
> >receive a redirect to the restricted URL.
> >
> But how do I relate that login resource to the resources that are protected?

You have a login resource per protected resource
or resources.

One REST pattern is that applications should
expose a single root URL from which you navigate
to the others.  So the redirect should probably be
to this root.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

>
> S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

> >>>for applications that need them.
