-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3435
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 03:40:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: <dave.cantrell@...>

> In other words, given the following URL:
>
> http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2
>
> Is the "noun" resource http://www.my-server.com/foo with parameters
attached
> to the query, or is it http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2 ?

In HTTP, the resource is the full URI including the query terms. This means
that there are a /lot/ of resources. A resource is not always a concrete
implementation 'code object' - it is more often a conceptual information
entity.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3436
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 03:47:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

>
> If each user gets his/her own URL then this is
> equivalent to passing a name/password with each
> request.
Except that the name is not visible to intermediaries as being a username,
and that users have no incentive to not share this URL with others.
However, if the name/password pair is also bound to the specific resource,
then you could disable that particular password when you like, without
affecting other resources - similar to 'capabilities'.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3437
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 04:07:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation
Message:


S. Mike Dierken wrote:

>----- Original Message -----
>From: <dave.cantrell@...>
>
>  
>
>>In other words, given the following URL:
>>
>>http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2
>>
>>Is the "noun" resource http://www.my-server.com/foo with parameters
>>    
>>
>attached
>  
>
>>to the query, or is it http://www.my-server.com/foo?a=1&b=2 ?
>>    
>>
>
>In HTTP, the resource is the full URI including the query terms. This means
>that there are a /lot/ of resources. A resource is not always a concrete
>implementation 'code object' - it is more often a conceptual information
>entity.
>
>  
>
My favorite example for this is Google.  Consider the following URIs:

http://www.google.com/search?q=rest+patterns
http://www.google.com/search?q=soap+rpc

While they differ only by their querystrings, they identify two distinct 
resources.  One is a list of all known pages containing the words 'rest' 
and 'pattern', while the other is a list of all known pages containing 
the words 'soap' and 'rpc'.


--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3438
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 04:08:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:


S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>On Thu, 27 Feb 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
>  
>
>>So if I have a really large user population and I want 250000 of them to
>>have access to a particular document document or resource, you want me
>>to create 250000 different URLs?
>>    
>>
>
>Depends on your application.  In many application
>domains, it is completely reasonable to generate a
>different URL in each announcment email.
>  
>
While I'm sure there are possibilities that I've not thought of, I'm 
having difficulty imagining a scenario where that is a reasonable 
solution.  

The way I see it, having a URL per user has several disdvantages:
1. exponential explosion of URIs - one URL per resource per user - makes 
content management much harder than it needs to be
2. can't share URIs between authorized users since everyone has their 
own personal URI for a resource
3. kills caching since every unique user will use a different name for 
the same resource
4. provides no real security since all you need is a URI in order to 
access a supposedly protected resource

I'm sure others can add to this list.  

And for all that, I really can't think of any advantages.

>Alternatively:
>
>  
>
>>>You POST credentials to a login resource and
>>>receive a redirect to the restricted URL.
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>But how do I relate that login resource to the resources that are protected?
>>    
>>
>
>You have a login resource per protected resource
>or resources.
>
>One REST pattern is that applications should
>expose a single root URL from which you navigate
>to the others.  So the redirect should probably be
>to this root.
>  
>
I'm not sure I understand the connection between navigation from a root 
URL and REST.  I wasn't aware that REST said anything about how to 
organize your resources.

Actually, I'm not really sure I understand what you're proposing.  You 
seem to be suggesting that any time I want to access an arbitraty 
resource, I must navigate my way there from the root of something.  This 
seems to break so many of the principles of REST that I'm sure I 
misunderstand what you're suggesting.  Can you give an example of how 
this might work?

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3439
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 10:08:55
Subject:URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 01:32 AM, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> The correct answer is to define another MIME type.
> e.g. application/rss2+xml
>
> Until it is officially in IANA, use
> application/x-rss2+xml
>
> Blurring MIME types just erodes MIME.

this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like 
namespace URIs in xml.

that way almost anybody can define a mime type without going through 
the IANA.

maybe i'm missing something obvious and this is a bad idea?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3440
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 12:12:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Containers and nested representations
Message:

Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Wednesday, February 26, 2003, at 05:07 PM, Richard Padley wrote:
> 
>> I've been working through a few issues related to how a container
>> resource behaves, and I'm not sure if I'm bumping into some limitations
>> of REST or HTTP.
> 
> 
> Thanks for sharing this; I've been a bit complacent in posting my 
> experiences with containers to this list.
> 
>> [snip example]
> 
> 
>> The idea here is that the contained resources are serialised in the
>> representation. I'm assuming that this is OK from a REST perspective.
> 
> 
> I see nothing wrong with it; it doesn't say anywhere 'one resource can't 
> contain another', AFAIK.
> 
>> Now I want to modify a box. I'm going to use PUT to replace the whole
>> box. In doing this I'll naturally be replacing the contained widgets as
>> well.
>>
>> [snip example]
> 
> 
>> The response is
>>
>> HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
> 
> 
> Maybe this could be a 200 with the updated box/100?  The 204 just seems 
> kind of 'useless' to me.

I've never been sure what to return in the message-body after a PUT. I 
figured that if the client needs to check the state of the resource (in 
case the server adds some information to the PUT representation), it 
could perform a GET request.

> 
>> Now, I've changed the colour of this box, and I've both changed the
>> colour of widget 33, and added a new widget 35 to the container. Also I
>> have deleted widget 34, since it now had no container, and this is not
>> allowed (in this particular application).
> 
> 
> Hmm.. I'm not sure that having widget 34 automatically 'fall off a 
> cliff' is a good thing.
> 
> It may be helpful to consider the fact that 'widgets can not have no 
> container' a constraint specific to your application, and try and find a 
> strategy that is RESTful to enforce it.
> 
> Idea:
> Perhaps you should explore the concept of a 'reaper' process (a client 
> UA or something on the server) which periodically searches and destroys 
> orphaned widgets (it could use explicit DELETE requests to do this on 
> the results of a GET /widgets?parent=null or whatever).
> 
> But see below.
> 
>> My question is, have I done too much at once here? I'd like to be able
>> to indicate the newly created widget 35 with a 201 Created response, but
>> the response I must return relates to the container, not its contents.
>> Also I'm not too happy with the indirect addressing that seems to be
>> happening here - I have the URI for the box as part of the request, but
>> this request affects other resources, which I can only address inside
>> the message-body itsself, which just seems wrong.
> 

My reading of RFC 2616 seems to indicate this is OK. I've just started 
reading RFC 2518 (WEBDAV), and theres a whole load of stuff in there 
about containers and nesting.

> 
> I have asked the same question (aloud, not on the list).  I think its 
> something of a grey area.
> 
> Rather than a big fat PUT to the container, you could split your request 
> up in to a number of constituent requests to constituent resources.  for 
> example:

My application semantics require that the update is atomic. This fits 
nicely with the idea of supplying a 'complete' representation of a 
container resource (with all its contained resources).

> 
> 1. PUT to widget/33 changing the colour.  this would (or should?) update 
> box/100 automatically because it has a dependency on widget/33.

Agreed

> 2. POST widget/35's URI to box/100 (possible after POSTing 35 to widgets).

Again there are choices here. I can either POST the URI for the 
contained resource (widget 35) into the container :

POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml

<box x:href="/box/100">
    <widget x:href="/widget/35">
</box>

Provided widget 35 already exists I'd assume the server response would be

HTTP/1.1 204 No Content

Or I could post the respresentation of the contained resource to the 
container:

POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml

<box x:href="/box/100">
    <widget>
      <widget_id>35<widget_id>
      <colour>Black</colour>
      <size>9</size>
    </widget>
</box>

Now I'm not sure what the response is - 201 Created seems absolutlely 
the right thing here, but it simply breaks if I POST the respresntation 
of two new resources at the same time

POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml

<box x:href="/box/100">
    <widget>
      <widget_id>35<widget_id>
      <colour>Black</colour>
      <size>9</size>
    </widget>
    <widget>
      <widget_id>40<widget_id>
      <colour>White</colour>
      <size>9</size>
    </widget>
</box>

Now the only response possible seems to be 204 (or 200) - I can't 
respond with two lots of 201 Created. And this can only get more complex 
if we consider the case then a POST to that box could create one widget 
and modify another.

> 3. DELETE 34.
>    or
>    PUT box/100 minus the mention of widget/34.
> 
> the trouble with the delete of 34 is that the semantics are overloaded. 
>  the PUT to the box that excludes the 34 really only removes it from the 
> container, rather than deleting it outright.  these are two seperate 
> semantic actions.

I think the semantics I need require that deleteing a container will 
also delete all of the resouces it contains - atomic requirement again. 
I could see that case that this would not be a requirement in all 
applications.

> 
> i would be interested to hear what you (and others) think of this.
> 
> D.J. Adams has written about this same idea at
> http://www.pipetree.com/space/RtRest (warning this is cutnpaste from the 
> HTML):
> 
> --CUT
> Having something like /ticket/42/basics/status returning a 
> representation of ticket 42's status in text/plain, say "new", is a very 
> attractive feature, I think.
> 
> GET /ticket/42/basics/status HTTP/1.1
> 
> HTTP/1.1 200 OK
> Connection: Close
> Content-Type: text/plain
> 
> open
> 
> Preferable to composing a method call, serialising it into XML, sending 
>  it to an end point, and then parsing the result out of the XML that 
> comes back, all to retrieve such a simple piece of data. It's intriguing.
> --CUT
> 
> anyway, thanks again for the thought-provoking post, and the coherent 
> example (works wonders when trying to ask a question!).
> 
> regards,
> -vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3441
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 12:25:50
Subject:Rebel
Message:

Jeffrey Winter wrote:
> This is the same mechanism I am using in an application that I've 
> described here:
> 
>   http://www.xefer.com/rebel/rebel.html
> 
> I'm using <folder> and <bookmark> but the idea is the same.

I like the idea that you have both a flat and a fully nested 
respresentation to play with. I wondered about too in the past.

As far as exports are concered I'd imagine that you could deal with the 
issue of XBEL fragments vs conformant XBEL documents by using content 
negotiation, rather than a separate URI space. Sending the appropriate 
Accept: header would indicate whether a fragment or a standalone XBEL 
document was required. Or would this be an abuse of Accept:? This 
approach could also be used to specify 'flat' for neseted resource 
expansions.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3442
Sender:"Yannick Loiseau" <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 12:36:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

> This approach could also be used to specify 'flat' for neseted resource
> expansions.


One can use the "Depth:" dav header to specify the "flatness" of a
container...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3443
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 13:31:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Containers and nested representations
Message:

On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 12:12 PM, Richard Padley wrote:
>>> The response is
>>>
>>> HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
>>
>> Maybe this could be a 200 with the updated box/100?  The 204 just 
>> seems
>> kind of 'useless' to me.
>
> I've never been sure what to return in the message-body after a PUT. I
> figured that if the client needs to check the state of the resource (in
> case the server adds some information to the PUT representation), it
> could perform a GET request.

yeah, but why make the client perform an extra request?

if the client isn't interested it can check for 200 or whatever and 
throw away the body.

i am thinking of a scenario where an abbreviation or shortcut string 
(like "/.") is PUT and its expansion ("slashdot") is used as the 
representation.  maybe this isn't useful enough to warrant returning an 
entity body, but perhaps there are application use cases where it is.

>> Rather than a big fat PUT to the container, you could split your 
>> request up in to a number of constituent requests to constituent 
>> resources.  for example:
>
> My application semantics require that the update is atomic. This fits
> nicely with the idea of supplying a 'complete' representation of a
> container resource (with all its contained resources).

agreed.

>> 2. POST widget/35's URI to box/100 (possible after POSTing 35 to 
>> widgets).
>
> Again there are choices here. I can either POST the URI for the
> contained resource (widget 35) into the container :
>
> POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
> Content-Type: text/xml
>
> <box x:href="/box/100">
>     <widget x:href="/widget/35">
> </box>

why the outer <box> element in the body?  haven't you addressed that in 
the request URI?  i don't want to appear to be pedantic but this looks 
like an instance of the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) anti-pattern.

what are the semantics if the request URI and the (xpath) /box/x:href 
attribute is another (different) URI?

> Provided widget 35 already exists I'd assume the server response would 
> be
>
> HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
>
> Or I could post the respresentation of the contained resource to the
> container:
>
> POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
> Content-Type: text/xml
>
> <box x:href="/box/100">
>     <widget>
>       <widget_id>35<widget_id>
>       <colour>Black</colour>
>       <size>9</size>
>     </widget>
> </box>

i think whether you use the URI or the inline representation depends on 
whether the widget is being implicitly created.  if it already exists i 
would definitely say that the URI should be used.  if there is no URI, 
then the server application can go ahead and implicitly create it.  i 
think all combinations of uri/representation are acceptable so long as 
their semantics are clearly defined, e.g.:

uri | representation | action
----+----------------+--------------------------------------
   1 |              0 | use uri
   1 |              1 | use uri (ignore representation)
   0 |              1 | create (using supplied represenation)
   0 |              0 | invalid

> Now I'm not sure what the response is - 201 Created seems absolutlely
> the right thing here, but it simply breaks if I POST the respresntation
> of two new resources at the same time
>
> POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
> Content-Type: text/xml
>
> <box x:href="/box/100">
>     <widget>
>       <widget_id>35<widget_id>
>       <colour>Black</colour>
>       <size>9</size>
>     </widget>
>     <widget>
>       <widget_id>40<widget_id>
>       <colour>White</colour>
>       <size>9</size>
>     </widget>
> </box>
>
> Now the only response possible seems to be 204 (or 200) - I can't
> respond with two lots of 201 Created. And this can only get more 
> complex
> if we consider the case then a POST to that box could create one widget
> and modify another.

agreed.  however i question how important this use case is.  can't you 
always just POST one widget at a time?  then you can reject input with 
more than one URIless widget element.

also i think this scenario breaks down if you accept my previous point 
about the redundancy of the outer <box> element.  you couldn't have a 
second <widget> element in this case because you can only have one root 
element in an XML document.

another possibility to throw in the soup is that box resources could 
have subordinate 'widgets' container resources to which you POST e.g. 
/boxes/100/widgets but i won't go in to that here.

>> 3. DELETE 34.
>>    or
>>    PUT box/100 minus the mention of widget/34.
>>
>> the trouble with the delete of 34 is that the semantics are 
>> overloaded.
>>  the PUT to the box that excludes the 34 really only removes it from 
>> the
>> container, rather than deleting it outright.  these are two seperate
>> semantic actions.
>
> I think the semantics I need require that deleteing a container will
> also delete all of the resouces it contains - atomic requirement again.
> I could see that case that this would not be a requirement in all
> applications.

absolutely not; this mirrors the functionality of cascading 
updates/deletes in a relational database, and is therefore specific to 
applications.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3444
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 14:00:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

Frankly, I think this is an excellent idea.  In a similar vein, this was my
suggested solution to a Meta-Query header conversation over in the
distributed-registry list.  My only fear would be that using URIs in fields
like Accept and Content-Type would break many existing applications.  One
way we could maintain backwards compatibility would be to add another MIME
type like "alt/uri".  When this type was present, it would tell the
application to look for another header or headers.  The name of the
header(s) would be specific to the protocol.  For instance, in HTTP, the
MIME type might indicate the presence of a header called "Content-Type-URI:"
or some such.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Vincent D Murphy" <vdm@...>
>
> On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 01:32 AM, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> > The correct answer is to define another MIME type.
> > e.g. application/rss2+xml
> >
> > Until it is officially in IANA, use
> > application/x-rss2+xml
> >
> > Blurring MIME types just erodes MIME.
>
> this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like
> namespace URIs in xml.
>
> that way almost anybody can define a mime type without going through
> the IANA.
>
> maybe i'm missing something obvious and this is a bad idea?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3445
Sender:Joe Gregorio <joe@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 14:29:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 01:32 AM, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> 
>>The correct answer is to define another MIME type.
>>e.g. application/rss2+xml
>>
>>Until it is officially in IANA, use
>>application/x-rss2+xml
>>
>>Blurring MIME types just erodes MIME.

Actually using the x- types is current discouraged in favor of
vendor and personal trees:

"  For convenience and symmetry with this registration scheme, media
   type names with "x." as the first facet may be used for the same
   purposes for which names starting in "x-" are normally used.  These
   types are unregistered, experimental, and should be used only with
   the active agreement of the parties exchanging them.
   However, with the simplified registration procedures described above
   for vendor and personal trees, it should rarely, if ever, be
   necessary to use unregistered experimental types, and as such use of
   both "x-" and "x." forms is discouraged."

From:
 RFC 2048 - MIME Registration Procedures  
 ftp://ftp.isi.edu/in-notes/rfc2048.txt 

> 
> 
> this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like 
> namespace URIs in xml.
> 
> that way almost anybody can define a mime type without going through 
> the IANA.
> 
> maybe i'm missing something obvious and this is a bad idea?

It is being considered:
http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#uriMediaType-9

But given the problems of using URIs to identify namespaces in XML
I doubt that the idea will make much progress.

	-joe

-- 
http://BitWorking.org
http://WellFormedWeb.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3446
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 14:43:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

From: "Joe Gregorio" <joe@...>
>
> >
> >
> > this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like
> > namespace URIs in xml.
> >
> > that way almost anybody can define a mime type without going through
> > the IANA.
> >
> > maybe i'm missing something obvious and this is a bad idea?
>
> It is being considered:
> http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#uriMediaType-9
>
> But given the problems of using URIs to identify namespaces in XML
> I doubt that the idea will make much progress.

While I could see someone getting carried away with the idea, I don't think
that it would be a good idea to compare XML Namespace URIs and Media Type
URI.  In my head, they are not the same thing.  URI Media Types are just a
way to make media type registration distributed, while XML Namespace URIs
are used to mix multiple document parts within a single package.  Very
different usage to me.

Besides... just think what this could do for XML Namespaces.  :)  Instead of
using the namespacing mechanism, one could define a media type URI to
indicate the usage of a specific set of XML vocabularies.  As a result, as
long as this media type was encountered, element names, etc. would be
uniform across *all* documents.  Then you would be able to have your
regex-able xml.  :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3447
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 14:59:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 02:29 PM, Joe Gregorio wrote:
> Actually using the x- types is current discouraged in favor of
> vendor and personal trees:
>
> "  For convenience and symmetry with this registration scheme, media
>    type names with "x." as the first facet may be used for the same
>    purposes for which names starting in "x-" are normally used.  These
>    types are unregistered, experimental, and should be used only with
>    the active agreement of the parties exchanging them.
>    However, with the simplified registration procedures described above
>    for vendor and personal trees, it should rarely, if ever, be
>    necessary to use unregistered experimental types, and as such use of
>    both "x-" and "x." forms is discouraged."
>
> From:
>  RFC 2048 - MIME Registration Procedures
>  ftp://ftp.isi.edu/in-notes/rfc2048.txt

if using x- and x. is discouraged, and registration is encouraged, this 
still seems to leaves a single point of failure (the IANA).

the IANA is also as vulnerable as any other single authority to being 
hijacked by the US Dept. of Commerce/ICANN etc. acting in the interests 
of megacorps.   witness what happened to DNS.  </rant>

i just think URIs, being Universal, are a good fit for what mime does 
now.

>> this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like
>> namespace URIs in xml.
>>
>> that way almost anybody can define a mime type without going through
>> the IANA.
>>
>> maybe i'm missing something obvious and this is a bad idea?
>
> It is being considered:
> http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#uriMediaType-9
>
> But given the problems of using URIs to identify namespaces in XML
> I doubt that the idea will make much progress.

correct me if i'm wrong, but i think the problems of URIs being used to 
identify namespaces are to do with a lack of understanding of what URIs 
are, rather than problems arising simply because of the use of URIs per 
se.

IMO the problems can be associated with the same type of people who 
believe fallacies like 'the web is a filesystem' and 'a URI is a 
filesystem path, so where's the file'?

thanks for your points anyway.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3448
Sender:Joe Gregorio <joe@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 15:08:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> From: "Joe Gregorio" <joe@...>
> 
>>>
>>>this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like
>>>namespace URIs in xml.
>>>
>>>that way almost anybody can define a mime type without going through
>>>the IANA.
>>>
>>>maybe i'm missing something obvious and this is a bad idea?
>>
>>It is being considered:
>>http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#uriMediaType-9
>>
>>But given the problems of using URIs to identify namespaces in XML
>>I doubt that the idea will make much progress.
> 
> 
> While I could see someone getting carried away with the idea, I don't think
> that it would be a good idea to compare XML Namespace URIs and Media Type
> URI.  In my head, they are not the same thing.  URI Media Types are just a
> way to make media type registration distributed, while XML Namespace URIs
> are used to mix multiple document parts within a single package.  Very
> different usage to me.

I agree they're not the same thing, but they are both using an HTTP URI as a unique identifier.
Using an HTTP URI as a unique identifier for anything but a web resource
is fraught with problems:

1. Users will take those URIs and plug them into a browser. What should they get back?
   (The "what does a namespace uri dereference to is an [xml-dev] permathread.)
2. How do you compare two URIs? Are they case sensitive? Because some parts of an HTTP
   URI are not case sensitive while some other parts may be case sensitive. 
   What about escaped characters, 
   i.e. does %42 in the URI get decoded or left as is? (How to compare two URIs 
   is another issue on the tags plate: http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#URIEquivalence-15 )

I don't want to throw cold water on the idea, just pointing out that you're wandering
into some pretty murky waters :)

	-joe

-- 
http://BitWorking.org
http://WellFormedWeb.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3449
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 15:52:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Vincent D Murphy" <vdm@...>

> this just makes me wonder why we can't use URIs as mime types, like
> namespace URIs in xml.
You mean like Content-Type:
http://www.dierken.com/Just-Like-html/only/better





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3450
Sender:"sem_antico <rest-discuss@...>" <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 17:24:00
Subject:Re: Containers and nested representations
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Vincent D Murphy <vdm@v...>
wrote:
> On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 12:12 PM, Richard Padley wrote:
> >>> The response is
> >>>
> >>> HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
> >>
> >> Maybe this could be a 200 with the updated box/100?  The 204
just 
> >> seems
> >> kind of 'useless' to me.
> >
> > I've never been sure what to return in the message-body after a
PUT. I
> > figured that if the client needs to check the state of the
resource (in
> > case the server adds some information to the PUT representation),
it
> > could perform a GET request.
> 
> yeah, but why make the client perform an extra request?
> 
> if the client isn't interested it can check for 200 or whatever and 
> throw away the body.
> 
> i am thinking of a scenario where an abbreviation or shortcut
string 
> (like "/.") is PUT and its expansion ("slashdot") is used as the 
> representation.  maybe this isn't useful enough to warrant
returning an 
> entity body, but perhaps there are application use cases where it
is.
> 
> >> Rather than a big fat PUT to the container, you could split your 
> >> request up in to a number of constituent requests to constituent 
> >> resources.  for example:
> >
> > My application semantics require that the update is atomic. This
fits
> > nicely with the idea of supplying a 'complete' representation of a
> > container resource (with all its contained resources).
> 
> agreed.
> 
> >> 2. POST widget/35's URI to box/100 (possible after POSTing 35 to 
> >> widgets).
> >
> > Again there are choices here. I can either POST the URI for the
> > contained resource (widget 35) into the container :
> >
> > POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
> > Content-Type: text/xml
> >
> > <box x:href="/box/100">
> >     <widget x:href="/widget/35">
> > </box>
> 
> why the outer <box> element in the body?  haven't you addressed
that in 
> the request URI?  i don't want to appear to be pedantic but this
looks 
> like an instance of the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) anti-pattern.

I'm glad you mentioned that, I'll try to explain. The box resource is
both a container (for widgets) and a resource as well (it has <colour>
in my original example). If I POST to a box I have to have a way of
updating its colour, as well as updating the widgets it contains.
Therefore I need a container element. But I think I may just have
placed the wrong container around it in my example. So the example
should probably be (namespace attrs removed for brevity)

POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml

<app:resource>
  <colour>Moonlight beige</colour>
  <widget x:href="/widget/35">
</app:resource>

I've used the app:resource as generic resource representation to hold
the updated colour information and updated information saying that
widget 35 is now contained by this box.

> 
> what are the semantics if the request URI and the (xpath)
/box/x:href 
> attribute is another (different) URI?

Quite, it does seem somehow wrong to duplicate this information which
shold be completely clear from the request URI.

> 
> > Provided widget 35 already exists I'd assume the server response
would 
> > be
> >
> > HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
> >
> > Or I could post the respresentation of the contained resource to
the
> > container:
> >
> > POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
> > Content-Type: text/xml
> >
> > <box x:href="/box/100">
> >     <widget>
> >       <widget_id>35<widget_id>
> >       <colour>Black</colour>
> >       <size>9</size>
> >     </widget>
> > </box>
> 
> i think whether you use the URI or the inline representation
depends on 
> whether the widget is being implicitly created.  if it already
exists i 
> would definitely say that the URI should be used.  if there is no
URI, 
> then the server application can go ahead and implicitly create it. 
i 
> think all combinations of uri/representation are acceptable so long
as 
> their semantics are clearly defined, e.g.:
> 
> uri | representation | action
> ----+----------------+--------------------------------------
>    1 |              0 | use uri
>    1 |              1 | use uri (ignore representation)
>    0 |              1 | create (using supplied represenation)
>    0 |              0 | invalid
> 
> > Now I'm not sure what the response is - 201 Created seems
absolutlely
> > the right thing here, but it simply breaks if I POST the
respresntation
> > of two new resources at the same time
> >
> > POST /box/100 HTTP/1.1
> > Content-Type: text/xml
> >
> > <box x:href="/box/100">
> >     <widget>
> >       <widget_id>35<widget_id>
> >       <colour>Black</colour>
> >       <size>9</size>
> >     </widget>
> >     <widget>
> >       <widget_id>40<widget_id>
> >       <colour>White</colour>
> >       <size>9</size>
> >     </widget>
> > </box>
> >
> > Now the only response possible seems to be 204 (or 200) - I can't
> > respond with two lots of 201 Created. And this can only get more 
> > complex
> > if we consider the case then a POST to that box could create one
widget
> > and modify another.
> 
> agreed.  however i question how important this use case is.  can't
you 
> always just POST one widget at a time?  then you can reject input
with 
> more than one URIless widget element.

I dont think so. It seems wrong to prevent me updating more than one
property of the box resource at one time. If the box has width and
height, as well as containing widgets, I should be able to POST to
update the width and height at the same time surely? Why should this
methodology not apply also to the widgets that are in the box?

> 
> also i think this scenario breaks down if you accept my previous
point 
> about the redundancy of the outer <box> element.  you couldn't have
a 
> second <widget> element in this case because you can only have one
root 
> element in an XML document.

I think this is covered by the modification involving the
<app:resource> as an outer container. It is needed because the box
itsself has properties that must be modifiable via POST.

> 
> another possibility to throw in the soup is that box resources
could 
> have subordinate 'widgets' container resources to which you POST
e.g. 
> /boxes/100/widgets but i won't go in to that here.

Yes thats true. Logically the URI for a widget could be a subcomponent
of the URI for a box. This might have some advantages, in that there
would be no need to specify the box that a widget was contained in as
part of the representation of a widget. But I guess thats something
that you'd actually _want_ to specify, because doing a GET on
/widget/40 should return a representation that contains the URI to its
container, so that I can follow this URI for more information.

> 
> >> 3. DELETE 34.
> >>    or
> >>    PUT box/100 minus the mention of widget/34.
> >>
> >> the trouble with the delete of 34 is that the semantics are 
> >> overloaded.
> >>  the PUT to the box that excludes the 34 really only removes it
from 
> >> the
> >> container, rather than deleting it outright.  these are two
seperate
> >> semantic actions.
> >
> > I think the semantics I need require that deleteing a container
will
> > also delete all of the resouces it contains - atomic requirement
again.
> > I could see that case that this would not be a requirement in all
> > applications.
> 
> absolutely not; this mirrors the functionality of cascading 
> updates/deletes in a relational database, and is therefore specific
to 
> applications.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3451
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-02-28 17:24:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs as mime types? (was: Re: RESTfully distinguishing requests without content negotiation)
Message:

On Friday, February 28, 2003, at 03:52 PM, S. Mike Dierken wrote:
> You mean like Content-Type:
> http://www.dierken.com/Just-Like-html/only/better

or
Content-type: http://www.yaml.org/yaml/1.0





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3452
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-01 14:16:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

 
> > This approach could also be used to specify 'flat' for neseted resource
> > expansions.
> 
> 
> One can use the "Depth:" dav header to specify the "flatness" of a
> container...

That is an interesting idea, but I had poked around at the WebDAV 
spec and my reading of it was that Depth: was only supported on 
LOCK, COPY, MOVE and PROPFIND.

All in all, it seemed conceptually simpler to accomplish
what I wanted without introducing all the semantics of any of
the WebDAV stuff.

- Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3453
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <jeffreywinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-01 14:00:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

> As far as exports are concered I'd imagine that you could deal with the
> issue of XBEL fragments vs conformant XBEL documents by using content
> negotiation, rather than a separate URI space. Sending the appropriate
> Accept: header would indicate whether a fragment or a standalone XBEL
> document was required. Or would this be an abuse of Accept:? This
> approach could also be used to specify 'flat' for neseted resource
> expansions.

I'm not sure that there is any hard-and-fast rule about how to employ
the Accept: header, but I think the general use case is one in which 
the various resource respresentations are otherwise addressable on
their own.  For example, you PUT to

    /image/test.jpg
    /image/test.bmp
    /image/test.gif

but GET from

    /image/test 

with an appropriate Accept header.

Most of the examples I've seen of pushing the Accept: header much
beyond this start to subtly introduce what amounts to a hidden 
address space.

- Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3454
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-01 19:45:15
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:


Tyler Close wrote:

>On Friday 28 February 2003 00:08, Chuck Hinson wrote:
>  
>
>>While I'm sure there are possibilities that I've not thought of,
>>    
>>
>
>Quite a number actually. The basic mechanism that Alex proposed,
>inserting an unguessable random number into a URL, can be used to
>implement distributed capability security. The capability security
>model has been used to secure a wide range of software, from
>operating systems to end-user applications.
>
>  
>
>>I'm
>>having difficulty imagining a scenario where that is a reasonable
>>solution.
>>
>>The way I see it, having a URL per user has several disdvantages:
>>1. exponential explosion of URIs - one URL per resource per user - makes
>>content management much harder than it needs to be
>>2. can't share URIs between authorized users since everyone has their
>>own personal URI for a resource
>>3. kills caching since every unique user will use a different name for
>>the same resource
>>    
>>
>
>It appears that you're only thinking about protecting read-access
>to a read-only resource. I base this on your assumption that many
>users have access to a shared (and cacheable!) resource.
>
>This really isn't a very good example to use when trying to
>understand the benefits of capability-based security. For
>starters, the example isn't one in which there are any actually
>enforceable security properties. You can't prevent users from
>sharing access to the resource with "unauthorized" users. There is
>also very little sense is revoking read-access to a cacheable
>resource: why get it from the site at all when you've still got it
>in your cache.
>
>For a better overview of capability-based security, I suggest the
>paper at:
>
>http://www.erights.org/elib/capability/ode/index.html
>
>The paper explains capability-based security using tradeable
>electronic credit as an example. This is a better example to use
>when explaining capability-based security.
>  
>

I have to confess that the above paper is way too dense for my humber 
brain.  It would appear that I lack the necessary background.

>For an explanation of how capability-based security could be
>applied using REST design principles, I suggest my own paper at:
>
>http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/
>
>The paper also uses tradeable electronic credit as an example, but
>with a different design. The paper describes a RESTful interface
>for tradeable electronic credit.
>  
>
I'm at a disadvantage here since I really don't understand the 
capability model that's being described.  However, reading the paper, I 
got the sense that security is provided as a result of traversing a 
graph.  This doesnt seem terribly useful - why should I have to traverse 
a graph to get to a resource every time I want to access the resource? 
 Why can't I just directly access it.

>  
>
>>4. provides no real security since all you need is a URI in order to
>>access a supposedly protected resource
>>    
>>
>
>A lot of people get hung up on this, since they are so used to
>username/password. Consider that a randomly-generated 128 bit
>number contains more entropy than any password you could possibly
>remember. If it were possible to guess a random 128 bit number, it
>would also be possible to break any symmetric-key encryption
>algorithm. A symmetric encryption key is typically also 128 bits.
>  
>
I really dont get this.  Perhaps I'm dense, but it just doesn't seem 
useful to have a world where everybody gets their own URI to a single 
resource.  What happens to sharing and linking?

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3455
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-01 14:40:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Friday 28 February 2003 00:08, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> While I'm sure there are possibilities that I've not thought of,

Quite a number actually. The basic mechanism that Alex proposed,
inserting an unguessable random number into a URL, can be used to
implement distributed capability security. The capability security
model has been used to secure a wide range of software, from
operating systems to end-user applications.

> I'm
> having difficulty imagining a scenario where that is a reasonable
> solution.
>
> The way I see it, having a URL per user has several disdvantages:
> 1. exponential explosion of URIs - one URL per resource per user - makes
> content management much harder than it needs to be
> 2. can't share URIs between authorized users since everyone has their
> own personal URI for a resource
> 3. kills caching since every unique user will use a different name for
> the same resource

It appears that you're only thinking about protecting read-access
to a read-only resource. I base this on your assumption that many
users have access to a shared (and cacheable!) resource.

This really isn't a very good example to use when trying to
understand the benefits of capability-based security. For
starters, the example isn't one in which there are any actually
enforceable security properties. You can't prevent users from
sharing access to the resource with "unauthorized" users. There is
also very little sense is revoking read-access to a cacheable
resource: why get it from the site at all when you've still got it
in your cache.

For a better overview of capability-based security, I suggest the
paper at:

http://www.erights.org/elib/capability/ode/index.html

The paper explains capability-based security using tradeable
electronic credit as an example. This is a better example to use
when explaining capability-based security.

For an explanation of how capability-based security could be
applied using REST design principles, I suggest my own paper at:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/

The paper also uses tradeable electronic credit as an example, but
with a different design. The paper describes a RESTful interface
for tradeable electronic credit.

> 4. provides no real security since all you need is a URI in order to
> access a supposedly protected resource

A lot of people get hung up on this, since they are so used to
username/password. Consider that a randomly-generated 128 bit
number contains more entropy than any password you could possibly
remember. If it were possible to guess a random 128 bit number, it
would also be possible to break any symmetric-key encryption
algorithm. A symmetric encryption key is typically also 128 bits.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3456
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-02 16:31:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Saturday 01 March 2003 15:45, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> Tyler Close wrote:
> >For an explanation of how capability-based security could be
> >applied using REST design principles, I suggest my own paper at:
> >
> >http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/
> >
> >The paper also uses tradeable electronic credit as an example, but
> >with a different design. The paper describes a RESTful interface
> >for tradeable electronic credit.
>
> I'm at a disadvantage here since I really don't understand the
> capability model that's being described.

The basics of the model are fairly simple. Based on your next
sentence, it looks like you've already groked the main point.

> However, reading the paper, I got the sense that security is
> provided as a result of traversing a graph.

That's correct. The graph basically says: "If a user has access to
this resource, they are also authorized to use these other
resources." You can tell which resources the user is not
authorized to use by noticing that there is no way to get to those
resources by traversing the graph. Having a simple and
well-defined model like this makes it a lot easier to study your
application security and make sure you got it right.

> This doesnt seem terribly useful - why should I have to traverse
> a graph to get to a resource every time I want to access the resource?
>  Why can't I just directly access it.

You can directly access it. Any resource in the graph can have a
URI associated with it. You can use this URI to directly access
the resource. The graph defines how you get additional URIs, given
the ones you've already got.

> I really dont get this.  Perhaps I'm dense, but it just doesn't seem
> useful to have a world where everybody gets their own URI to a single
> resource.  What happens to sharing and linking?

You're not dense, just a little hard of hearing. ;) As I said in
the last message, you're right, you wouldn't use this model to
give everyone their own URI to a single, shared, read-only
resource. You use this model to protect and share access to
private resources.  Think more about your online banking interface
than your Wall Street Journal subscription.

For example, you might have a capability URL for your bank
account. From this resource, you can navigate to resources that
let you pay bills and view your withdrawal/deposit history. The
account history might be composed of a different resource for each
of the calendar months. At tax time, you might give your
accountant the URIs for your January to December account history
resources. Your accountant can then do up your tax forms, but
cannot pay bills from your account.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3457
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 09:38:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

Jeffrey Winter wrote:
> As far as exports are concered I'd imagine that you could deal with the
> issue of XBEL fragments vs conformant XBEL documents by using content
> negotiation, rather than a separate URI space. Sending the appropriate
> Accept: header would indicate whether a fragment or a standalone XBEL
> document was required. Or would this be an abuse of Accept:? This
> approach could also be used to specify 'flat' for neseted resource
> expansions.
> 
> 
> I'm not sure that there is any hard-and-fast rule about how to employ
> the Accept: header, but I think the general use case is one in which 
> the various resource respresentations are otherwise addressable on
> their own.  For example, you PUT to
> 
>     /image/test.jpg
>     /image/test.bmp
>     /image/test.gif
> 
> but GET from
> 
>     /image/test 
> 
> with an appropriate Accept header.

This still would fit with the fragment vs complete doc issue - just take 
a couple of file extension, one for fragment (e.g. .frag), one for 
standalone compliant doc (.e.g. .xml). Then

GET /xbel/hello-world.frag

will return just the fragment, and

GET /xbel/hello-world.xml

will return the standalone compliant doc. Whats more this maps 
completely to the approach of using the accept header, one just needs a 
couple of mime type (mabe there is a standard for the XBEL one already?)

GET /xbel/hello-world
Accept: application/x-xbel-fragment

would give one representation, the other would be

GET /xbel/hello-world
Accept: application/x-xbel-standalone

> 
> Most of the examples I've seen of pushing the Accept: header much
> beyond this start to subtly introduce what amounts to a hidden 
> address space.

Yes and no. I see nothing wrong with using Accept: to choose the 
representation you want - its much cleaner than using a filename, 
because it allows multiple representations to have the same URI. By 
choosing a different URI (xbel-export) yu've effectively gone down the 
filename-like route, the only difference being folder name instead of 
file-extension (neither of which should matter to a client as the URI is 
opaque).

> 
> - Jeff





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3458
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 15:01:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

On Monday, Mar 3, 2003, at 03:38 US/Central, Richard Padley wrote:

> GET /xbel/hello-world
> Accept: application/x-xbel-fragment
>
> would give one representation, the other would be
>
> GET /xbel/hello-world
> Accept: application/x-xbel-standalone
>
>>
>> Most of the examples I've seen of pushing the Accept: header much
>> beyond this start to subtly introduce what amounts to a hidden
>> address space.
>
> Yes and no. I see nothing wrong with using Accept: to choose the
> representation you want - its much cleaner than using a filename,

Yet Accept: (and all header-based approaches) do nonetheless introduce 
another namespace and a fair bit of complexity as well.  IFF the 
particular representations in question can / should be regarded as 
"first-class" entities in their own right, distinguishing them from 
each other via different URI is certainly do-able.

I'm playing with this with a current application.  I've got a mess of 
little resources, all of which have various representations.  This goes 
beyond mere MIME type to functional types;  for example, a given piece 
of content might also have an "editor" representation which 
encapsulates the content in a Web-based interface for editing and 
saving said content.  Hence, I've got URIs like:

/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=editor-xhtml
/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=printable-xhtml
/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=rss2.0
/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=xml-raw
/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=rdf-factset

This allows all of these things to be directly accessed by simply 
GETting them, rather than having to dip into conneg.  AND it works well 
for alternate representations that have some associated functionality, 
beyond just this or that static format.

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3459
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 17:04:25
Subject:HTML form representations vs. resources (was: Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel)
Message:

[started a new thread because this has nothing to do with Rebel..]

On Monday, March 3, 2003, at 03:01 PM, Jeff Bone wrote:
> a given piece
> of content might also have an "editor" representation which
> encapsulates the content in a Web-based interface for editing and
> saving said content.  Hence, I've got URIs like:
>
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=editor-xhtml

i just thought i would chime in and mention that i am using a similar 
technique for web editing interfaces.  i have found that it doesn't 
make sense to have only a form-oriented HTML representation because 
e.g. drop-downs are problematic (read: impossible) to use hyperlinks 
with, and a pure HTML representation (with no form HTML) doesn't let 
you do any editing unless you're running some fringe client agent like 
amaya.

so i have a HTML representation, and put the form-HTML representation 
in a seperate resource.  i look at the form as a subordinate resource 
rather than just another representation.

i would be interested in hearing what others think of this, pros/cons 
etc.  my original thought process was that HTML forms don't have their 
own mime-type, (e.g. text/html+forms) so conneg was not an option.  
<shrug>

so i would have something like:
/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33/form

a GET on this gets you a HTML page with a form rather than 'normal' 
HTML; this form's target attribute is set to

/~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33

the form does a POST but i pre-process this on the server to actually 
mean PUT.

> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=rdf-factset
>
> This allows all of these things to be directly accessed by simply
> GETting them, rather than having to dip into conneg.  AND it works well
> for alternate representations that have some associated functionality,
> beyond just this or that static format.

i was going to suggest that perhaps "Content-type" or something would 
be a better name than "repr" but deja-vu tells me this has come up on 
this list before.

off-topic tangent: try
http://www.google.com/search?q=rest-discuss+Content-type+Vincent
google doesn't seem to have crawled any archives of rest-discuss; 
bummer.  sometimes i hate yahoo groups.  i wonder whether the archives 
are hidden from crawlers behind their ads.

i do think its important that people use standard attribute name/values 
for this though.  otherwise interoperability will suffer big time, IMHO.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3460
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 17:34:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

From: "Jeff Bone" <jbone@...>
>
> Yet Accept: (and all header-based approaches) do nonetheless introduce
> another namespace and a fair bit of complexity as well.  IFF the
> particular representations in question can / should be regarded as
> "first-class" entities in their own right, distinguishing them from
> each other via different URI is certainly do-able.

When you say "'first-class' entity", do you mean "resource"?

> I'm playing with this with a current application.  I've got a mess of
> little resources, all of which have various representations.  This goes
> beyond mere MIME type to functional types;  for example, a given piece
> of content might also have an "editor" representation which
> encapsulates the content in a Web-based interface for editing and
> saving said content.  Hence, I've got URIs like:
>
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=editor-xhtml
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=printable-xhtml
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=rss2.0
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=xml-raw
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=rdf-factset
>
> This allows all of these things to be directly accessed by simply
> GETting them, rather than having to dip into conneg.  AND it works well
> for alternate representations that have some associated functionality,
> beyond just this or that static format.

I use a similar technique with a new blog system I wrote.  In the case of
"folder" resources, I have the following:

/blog?form=addentry
/blog?form=addfolder
/blog?form=editfolder

For "entry" resources, I have:

/blog/12?form=editentry
/blog/12?form=trackback

In each of these cases, a form related to an aspect of the resource is
returned.  This would be equivalent to your "?repr=editor-xhtml", I think.

Independently, I also allow the folders to be returned as RSS.  In case the
client is not using the Accept: header (my blog system supports conneg), you
can append the following query to the folder:

/blog?rss=0.91
/blog?rss=0.92
/blog?rss=0.93
/blog?rss=2.0

(depending on which version you want).  I think this would be similar to
your "?repr=rss2.0".  I just use two different query parameters, but is
otherwise the same.  However, I still treat all of these representations as
the same resource.  I do not consider them sub-resources or anything like
that.  I agree that a form to add a subfolder looks a lot different from an
rss feed, but who says that a given representation of a resource must convey
all of that resource?

Now, I do also have conneg support in the places that it can be used.  For
instance, submitting a request to a folder with an "Accept: text/xml", you
will get back the RSS2.0 feed.  Now, if I needed to return another xml
representation which also used "text/xml" as the mime-type, I would probably
have to fall back to the query string method.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3461
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 17:49:22
Subject:Re: HTML form representations vs. resources (was: Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel)
Message:

On Monday, March 3, 2003, at 05:04 PM, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> i was going to suggest that perhaps "Content-type" or something would
> be a better name than "repr" but deja-vu tells me this has come up on
> this list before.
>
> i do think its important that people use standard attribute name/values
> for this though.  otherwise interoperability will suffer big time, 
> IMHO.

just found this; makes the point more clearly:
http://bitworking.org/news/45





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3462
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 17:52:55
Subject:more than one representation with the same MIME type
Message:

This topic has been in some of the threads lately, as well as in other
similar topics (see distributed-registry thread about Meta-Query).  How do
you go about, in a RESTful manner, returning different representations of
the same resource when those representations have the same content-type?
Admittedly, this is not a common case these days, but I think such a
scenario will become more frequent.

As mentioned in a couple posts, a common technique is to use a query string
to distinquish.  Another technique is to treat the variants as a sort of
sub-resource.  Both of these techniques have their advantages and
disadvantages.  However, the one disadvantage they both have is that they
are in no way standardized across implementations.  For instance, Jeff Bone,
Joe Gregorio, and I use different query strings for serving up RSS.

One of the nice things about MIME types is that they are "standardized",
hence the Accept header.  But that is course-grained.  For instance, there
is no way using Accept: to indicate whether the client wants to receive RSS
0.91 or RSS 2.0.  Sure, we could register more and more content-types, but
that seems like a nightmare (though I gather some work is being done to
address such a problem).

So what is a RESTful app to do?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3463
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 17:56:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Rebel
Message:

From: "Jeff Bone" <jbone@...>
>
> Yet Accept: (and all header-based approaches) do nonetheless introduce
> another namespace and a fair bit of complexity as well.  IFF the
> particular representations in question can / should be regarded as
> "first-class" entities in their own right, distinguishing them from
> each other via different URI is certainly do-able.

When you say "'first-class' entity", do you mean "resource"?

> I'm playing with this with a current application.  I've got a mess of
> little resources, all of which have various representations.  This goes
> beyond mere MIME type to functional types;  for example, a given piece
> of content might also have an "editor" representation which
> encapsulates the content in a Web-based interface for editing and
> saving said content.  Hence, I've got URIs like:
>
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=editor-xhtml
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=printable-xhtml
> /~jbone/Journal/2003/03/01/33?repr=rss2.0

all of that resource?

instance, submitting a request to a folder with an "Accept: text/xml", you
will get back the RSS2.0 feed.  Now, if I needed to return another xml
representation which also used "text/xml" as the mime-type, I would probably
have to fall back to the query string method.

Seairth Jacobs
