Post ID:3464
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 21:21:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] more than one representation with the same MIME type
Message:

We should be proliferating mimetypes.
Their purpose is to represent different document
expectations.
We should use them that way!

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson			i2x Media
1-646-244-1914 voice			1-212-697-1427 fax

On Mon, 3 Mar 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> This topic has been in some of the threads lately, as well as in other
> similar topics (see distributed-registry thread about Meta-Query).  How do
> you go about, in a RESTful manner, returning different representations of
> the same resource when those representations have the same content-type?
> Admittedly, this is not a common case these days, but I think such a
> scenario will become more frequent.
>
> As mentioned in a couple posts, a common technique is to use a query string
> to distinquish.  Another technique is to treat the variants as a sort of
> sub-resource.  Both of these techniques have their advantages and
> disadvantages.  However, the one disadvantage they both have is that they
> are in no way standardized across implementations.  For instance, Jeff Bone,
> Joe Gregorio, and I use different query strings for serving up RSS.
>
> One of the nice things about MIME types is that they are "standardized",
> hence the Accept header.  But that is course-grained.  For instance, there
> is no way using Accept: to indicate whether the client wants to receive RSS
> 0.91 or RSS 2.0.  Sure, we could register more and more content-types, but
> that seems like a nightmare (though I gather some work is being done to
> address such a problem).
>
> So what is a RESTful app to do?
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3465
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 21:31:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

I know that I was the one advocating capabilities,
but I think the examples show how difficult they
are to use in real life.

If I am looking at a page with my January
bank account history, I would like some way to
navigate back to the main menu....

If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
at the same time allow users to refer to the same
document?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson			i2x Media
1-646-244-1914 voice			1-212-697-1427 fax

On Sun, 2 Mar 2003, Tyler Close wrote:

> On Saturday 01 March 2003 15:45, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> > Tyler Close wrote:
> > >For an explanation of how capability-based security could be
> > >applied using REST design principles, I suggest my own paper at:
> > >
> > >http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/
> > >
> > >The paper also uses tradeable electronic credit as an example, but
> > >with a different design. The paper describes a RESTful interface
> > >for tradeable electronic credit.
> >
> > I'm at a disadvantage here since I really don't understand the
> > capability model that's being described.
>
> The basics of the model are fairly simple. Based on your next
> sentence, it looks like you've already groked the main point.
>
> > However, reading the paper, I got the sense that security is
> > provided as a result of traversing a graph.
>
> That's correct. The graph basically says: "If a user has access to
> this resource, they are also authorized to use these other
> resources." You can tell which resources the user is not
> authorized to use by noticing that there is no way to get to those
> resources by traversing the graph. Having a simple and
> well-defined model like this makes it a lot easier to study your
> application security and make sure you got it right.
>
> > This doesnt seem terribly useful - why should I have to traverse
> > a graph to get to a resource every time I want to access the resource?
> >  Why can't I just directly access it.
>
> You can directly access it. Any resource in the graph can have a
> URI associated with it. You can use this URI to directly access
> the resource. The graph defines how you get additional URIs, given
> the ones you've already got.
>
> > I really dont get this.  Perhaps I'm dense, but it just doesn't seem
> > useful to have a world where everybody gets their own URI to a single
> > resource.  What happens to sharing and linking?
>
> You're not dense, just a little hard of hearing. ;) As I said in
> the last message, you're right, you wouldn't use this model to
> give everyone their own URI to a single, shared, read-only
> resource. You use this model to protect and share access to
> private resources.  Think more about your online banking interface
> than your Wall Street Journal subscription.
>
> For example, you might have a capability URL for your bank
> account. From this resource, you can navigate to resources that
> let you pay bills and view your withdrawal/deposit history. The
> account history might be composed of a different resource for each
> of the calendar months. At tax time, you might give your
> accountant the URIs for your January to December account history
> resources. Your accountant can then do up your tax forms, but
> cannot pay bills from your account.
>
> Tyler
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3466
Sender:"Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 21:59:28
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] more than one representation with the same MIME type
Message:

> We should be proliferating mimetypes.  Their purpose is to 
> represent different document expectations.  We should use 
> them that way!

A rich set of MIME types is a good thing, but my issue with relying
on them for extracting different types of content from a single
resource comes down to a couple of points:

1.  How would you even know what content types are available?  If
    an indeterminate set of representations were associated with
    a resource, how would you even know what MIME types to chuck at it?

2.  Different content types may have completely different
    interfaces.  In my own application I happen to split
    some types out into "resource-spaces" that support 
    different methods: 

       /blog/x/y/z  GET only (HTML document)
       /rss/x/y/x   GET only (RSS 2.0 document)
       /xbel/x/y/z  GET, PUT, POST, DELETE (XBEL document)

    It wouldn't feel particularly intuitive to have the available
    methods change based on the Accept: header or even a query
    string.

    I could see using a Accept: header to distinguish different RSS 
    types from the resources in the /rss "resource-space" above because 
    they are at least clearly different representations of a similar 
    underlying type, but a unique URL (a la query string?) should be 
    available too. Perhaps the absence of either in the request could 
    result in a 300 Multiple Choices, etc.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3467
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 22:17:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] more than one representation with the same MIME type
Message:

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> We should be proliferating mimetypes.
> Their purpose is to represent different document
> expectations.
> We should use them that way!

That would be nice, but the practice seems somewhat different than theory
here.

For instance, there is no way for a server to know which version of HTML to
return based on the content-type.  Should the HTML be strictly 3.2 or should
it be 4.0?  Using "text/html" is not enough.  Using the user-agent (which is
probably the most common technique) it just plain wrong.  A server can't
possibly know every user-agent out there and shouldn't even care.  To avoid
this, sites are left to tactics like home pages that have a low-end home
page with links to the rest of the site in different version.  Hardly a good
solution.

The same could be said for distinguishing between RSS 0.91, 0.92, 0.93, and
2.0 (along with any other generic xml) since all that's used is "text/xml".
Using "text/rss+xml" wouldn't be enough either.  In my blog system, if it
gets "Accept:text/xml", it return RSS 2.0.  In order to get any other
version, you have to resort to a kludge (in this case using a query string
indicating the specific version).  This is just plain wrong and should not
be how it has to be done...

Now, maybe if people got into the habit of using a "version" parameter in
mime types, this could be avoided(?).  For instance, it would be no problem
to determine what a request means by "Accept:text/rss+xml;version=0.92".  I
realize you could just register something like "text/rss092+xml", but the
parameter is somewhat extensible without the need to register each new
version.  As is done with the xhtml "profile" parameter, it may even make
sense to use a URI instead of a simple version number.  This obviously has
tradeoffs, of course.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3468
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-03 23:02:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Monday 03 March 2003 17:31, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> I know that I was the one advocating capabilities,
> but I think the examples show how difficult they
> are to use in real life.

You're a true contrarian. ;)

Capabilities are actually very easy to use "in real life" and much
easier to use than ACLs. ACLs are difficult to manage and open you
up to all sorts of subtle security vulnerabilities. If you've ever
written code that uses ACLs, chances are you've written code that
is vulnerable to a Confused Deputy attack.

> If I am looking at a page with my January
> bank account history, I would like some way to
> navigate back to the main menu....

There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
variable.

It's also easy to implement "navigate back" from within a web
browser interface to the application. The simplest answer is just:
"Use the 'back' button to navigate 'back'.". A step up from there
is using frames. You can keep your main menu in a small frame
along the left or top of the screen. The main menu is then always
accessible to the user. If you don't like frames, you can use XSLT
to build a composite page on the server. The XSLT code can suck in
XML from a variety of capability URLs and then display a composite
page that includes navigation tools.

Everything really is at your fingertips. Having the security model
integrated right into the programming model really simplifies
things. Imagine building an application that aggregates
information from a bunch of different applications. With a
capability-based security model, you just suck in the XML and do
your thing. In an ACL model, you've got the additional headache of
managing credentials and authentication protocols with each
different application.

> If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
> at the same time allow users to refer to the same
> document?

You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
not use the capability model to solve this problem.

There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
problems, not DRM problems.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3469
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-04 00:59:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

I should note first, that I'm a bit confused where this thread is going. 
 It seems to me that we started by bitching about how browsers aren't 
terribly helpful with HTTP authentication.  Somehow, we've ending up 
talking about capabilities-based security, which you have already 
indicated isn't really the best choice for the majority of what's on the 
web today.

I think part of the problem I have is that with a capability model, it 
seems that you end up with everyone having their own private web of 
resources rather than having a public web of resources that are sharable 
with others.  As a result, you've lost the ability for people to connect 
those resources together in new ways to create new things on the web.

Don't get me wrong - I think the capabilities model is interesting and 
has a place.  Something tells me it might line up well with "hypermedia 
as the engine of application state", but I haven't thought about enough yet.

Other comments below...

Tyler Close wrote:

>On Monday 03 March 2003 17:31, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
>  
>
>>I know that I was the one advocating capabilities,
>>but I think the examples show how difficult they
>>are to use in real life.
>>    
>>
>
>You're a true contrarian. ;)
>
>Capabilities are actually very easy to use "in real life" and much
>easier to use than ACLs. ACLs are difficult to manage and open you
>up to all sorts of subtle security vulnerabilities. If you've ever
>written code that uses ACLs, chances are you've written code that
>is vulnerable to a Confused Deputy attack.
>
>  
>
>>If I am looking at a page with my January
>>bank account history, I would like some way to
>>navigate back to the main menu....
>>    
>>
>
>There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
>issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
>program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
>to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
>doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
>variable.
>  
>
I'm not sure I'd agree that "web services" is about program to program 
communication.  I'm sure there are a lot of "web services" where there's 
only a program at one end and some things that look like documents or 
document processors at the other end.  "Program-to-program 
communication" the way you  seem to be using it sounds a lot like an RPC 
model to me, and in my mind REST and RPC don't mix.

>It's also easy to implement "navigate back" from within a web
>browser interface to the application. The simplest answer is just:
>"Use the 'back' button to navigate 'back'.". 
>

This is an example of poor usability.  If I'm in the middle of a 
hierarchy, you better not make me hit the back button 50 times to get 
back to the home page (or whatever the starting point is).  Further, 
what if I've got that page bookmarked?  I never came in through the 
front page, so no amount of hitting the back button is going to get me 
there.  

>A step up from there
>is using frames. You can keep your main menu in a small frame
>along the left or top of the screen. The main menu is then always
>accessible to the user. If you don't like frames, you can use XSLT
>to build a composite page on the server. The XSLT code can suck in
>XML from a variety of capability URLs and then display a composite
>page that includes navigation tools.
>  
>
>Everything really is at your fingertips. Having the security model
>integrated right into the programming model really simplifies
>things. Imagine building an application that aggregates
>information from a bunch of different applications. With a
>capability-based security model, you just suck in the XML and do
>your thing. In an ACL model, you've got the additional headache of
>managing credentials and authentication protocols with each
>different application.
>  
>
So how do you establish an initial context (or whatever its called) in a 
capability-based system without doing authentication?

>  
>
>>If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
>>at the same time allow users to refer to the same
>>document?
>>    
>>
>
>You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
>the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
>not use the capability model to solve this problem.
>
I'm not disagreeing, but how about giving an example of something 
(web-based) that you would use a capability model to solve.

>
>There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
>just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
>control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
>problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
>problems, not DRM problems.
>  
>
Well, you may just have go into your long explanation, because if DRM 
isn't about controlling access, then I'm pretty confused.

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3470
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-04 03:29:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Monday 03 March 2003 20:59, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> I should note first, that I'm a bit confused where this thread is going.
>  It seems to me that we started by bitching about how browsers aren't
> terribly helpful with HTTP authentication.  Somehow, we've ending up
> talking about capabilities-based security,

The link between the two topics is that HTTP Authentication is
also not terribly helpful for implementing access control.
Switching to capabilities improves your GUI, your application
design and your security.

> which you have already
> indicated isn't really the best choice for the majority of what's on the
> web today.

That is not the impression I intended to convey. Capability-based
security is the best choice for implementing access control. Both
capabilities *and* ACLs fail to implement DRM, so you might as
well stick with ACLs for DRM hacks. (More on this at the end of
the message.)

> I think part of the problem I have is that with a capability model, it
> seems that you end up with everyone having their own private web of
> resources rather than having a public web of resources that are sharable
> with others.

Well, that's kinda the whole point of access control isn't it? Do
you want your bank account to be part of the public web of
resources?  If so, please send me the first link. ;)

The point of access control is to create private webs of
resources, with finely controlled links between them. Capabilities
are an excellent tool for implementing this.

> As a result, you've lost the ability for people to connect
> those resources together in new ways to create new things on the web.

Exactly the opposite.  What you've done is empowered people to
securely connect those resource that they want connected. The ACL
model prevents this.

Just as an example, why don't you post to this list a link to a
withdrawal record from your online bank account. With the current
interface, this is not possible: you can't do it without also
posting the password for your entire account. If your bank account
was implemented with a capability-based security model, posting
the withdrawal record link would be no problem.  Capabilities
enable you to create links.  ACLs prevent you from creating links.

> >There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
> >issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
> >program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
> >to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
> >doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
> >variable.
>
> I'm not sure I'd agree that "web services" is about program to program
> communication.  I'm sure there are a lot of "web services" where there's
> only a program at one end and some things that look like documents or
> document processors at the other end.  "Program-to-program
> communication" the way you  seem to be using it sounds a lot like an RPC
> model to me, and in my mind REST and RPC don't mix.

Is it your contention that program to program communication is RPC
and therefore not REST? If so, this has grave implications for any
thoughts of business integration with REST.

My only point from the quoted paragraph is that browser GUI issues
do not apply to software integration through REST.

> >It's also easy to implement "navigate back" from within a web
> >browser interface to the application. The simplest answer is just:
> >"Use the 'back' button to navigate 'back'.".
>
> This is an example of poor usability.

In which case the more sophisticated techniques I layed out next
are appropriate.

> Further, what if I've got that page bookmarked?

Bookmark the page that you want to bookmark. If you want to
bookmark the top level page, bookmark the top level page.

> So how do you establish an initial context (or whatever its called) in a
> capability-based system without doing authentication?

Your initial context is whatever set of URIs you start with. If
your program is an XSLT stylesheet, your initial context is the
set of URIs in the input XML document.

> >>If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
> >>at the same time allow users to refer to the same
> >>document?
> >
> >You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
> >the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
> >not use the capability model to solve this problem.
>
> I'm not disagreeing, but how about giving an example of something
> (web-based) that you would use a capability model to solve.

I did. Your web-based bank account.

> >There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
> >just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
> >control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
> >problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
> >problems, not DRM problems.
>
> Well, you may just have go into your long explanation, because if DRM
> isn't about controlling access, then I'm pretty confused.

Access control is about controlling what authority you hand out.
DRM is about controlling how people use authority they have
already been given.

In the WSJ scenario, a subscribed user is given the authority to
read WSJ articles. The read authority implicitly carries with it
the authority to pass-on the article to others. If you can read
bits, you can copy bits. Neither capabilities nor ACLs can prevent
you from giving a WSJ article to someone who is not a WSJ
subscriber. The best you can do is make it less convenient to
share the article. That is all the WSJ ACL does. It is just a
feeble DRM measure.

Fortunately, business integration and trading is about access
control, not DRM. Capabilities are ideal for this.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3471
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-04 05:52:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:


Tyler Close wrote:

>On Monday 03 March 2003 20:59, Chuck Hinson wrote:
>  
>
>>I should note first, that I'm a bit confused where this thread is going.
>> It seems to me that we started by bitching about how browsers aren't
>>terribly helpful with HTTP authentication.  Somehow, we've ending up
>>talking about capabilities-based security,
>>    
>>
>
>The link between the two topics is that HTTP Authentication is
>also not terribly helpful for implementing access control.
>
Which isn't surprising since its HTTP _Authentication_.  But that's 
neither here nor there.

>Switching to capabilities improves your GUI, your application
>design and your security.
>  
>
I'll take your word on the security bit.  I'm not convinced of the other 
two.  I get the feeling that you'd just end up trading one set of 
problems for another.  But again, that's neither here nor there.

>  
>
>>which you have already
>>indicated isn't really the best choice for the majority of what's on the
>>web today.
>>    
>>
>
>That is not the impression I intended to convey. Capability-based
>security is the best choice for implementing access control. Both
>capabilities *and* ACLs fail to implement DRM, so you might as
>well stick with ACLs for DRM hacks. (More on this at the end of
>the message.)
>  
>
So then, I don't understand your comment from an earlier message:
<quote>... you're right, you wouldn't use this model to give everyone 
their own URI to a single, shared, read-only resource. </quote>

As far as I am able to observe, an awful lot of the web consists of 
shared, read-only resources.  Are you saying that access control isn't 
necessary for shared, read-only resources?

>  
>
>>I think part of the problem I have is that with a capability model, it
>>seems that you end up with everyone having their own private web of
>>resources rather than having a public web of resources that are sharable
>>with others.
>>    
>>
>
>Well, that's kinda the whole point of access control isn't it? Do
>you want your bank account to be part of the public web of
>resources?  If so, please send me the first link. ;)
>  
>
https://www.accountlink.pncbank.com/index.html  :-)  

Unfortunately, its not a good example because the frame that actually 
shows my account info has a URL that simply has a session id encoded in 
it.  Besides, I'm really not interested in sharing my bank account info.

A more useful example would be something like

https://www.bank.com/myaccounts/savings/register

With http auth, I can give this URL to everyone who has an account at 
the bank, and that URI means the same thing to all of them - the page 
that shows the viewer the last 20 entries in their savings account register.

I can put that link in a set of help pages that are not protected by any 
access controls (and that don't need to be dynamically rendered).  I can 
bookmark that page and always go straight to it (modulo a login 
 prompt).  I can send that link to a friend who also has an account at 
the same bank (to tell him how to get to his saving account register). 
 I can distribute a tool that somehow processes the info from a savings 
account register at my bank without requiring each user configure the 
tool with their private URI.

Note that I'm not suggesting that this is a good solution for accessing 
bank accounts - it just illustrates the idea of a public, sharable URI. 
 My understanding of the capability model leads me to conclude that I 
can't do anything like the above because every user would have to have 
their own URI.

>The point of access control is to create private webs of
>resources, with finely controlled links between them. Capabilities
>are an excellent tool for implementing this.
>  
>
I dont disagree.  But it appears to me that the private web that is 
created is only useful to one individual.  What about groups of people? 
 If the answer is that everyone in the group shares the same, private 
URI, then how do I revoke access to just one member of the group. (I 
suspect your answer to this is going show that I don't understand the 
capability model after all.)

>  
>
>>As a result, you've lost the ability for people to connect
>>those resources together in new ways to create new things on the web.
>>    
>>
>
>Exactly the opposite.  What you've done is empowered people to
>securely connect those resource that they want connected. The ACL
>model prevents this.
>
>Just as an example, why don't you post to this list a link to a
>withdrawal record from your online bank account. With the current
>interface, this is not possible: you can't do it without also
>posting the password for your entire account. If your bank account
>was implemented with a capability-based security model, posting
>the withdrawal record link would be no problem.  Capabilities
>enable you to create links.  ACLs prevent you from creating links.
>  
>
I'm not sure why.  Assuming the withdrawal record has a URI, I dont see 
why I couldn't do that using a non-capability-based solution.  (I've 
also just realized that we're probably using the word _link_ differently.)

>  
>
>>>There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
>>>issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
>>>program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
>>>to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
>>>doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
>>>variable.
>>>      
>>>
>>I'm not sure I'd agree that "web services" is about program to program
>>communication.  I'm sure there are a lot of "web services" where there's
>>only a program at one end and some things that look like documents or
>>document processors at the other end.  "Program-to-program
>>communication" the way you  seem to be using it sounds a lot like an RPC
>>model to me, and in my mind REST and RPC don't mix.
>>    
>>
>
>Is it your contention that program to program communication is RPC
>and therefore not REST? If so, this has grave implications for any
>thoughts of business integration with REST.
>  
>
No, that is not my contention - but only because I don't know what form 
that program-to-program communications takes.  If it is RPC, then no, it 
is not REST.  And yes, that does have implications for business 
integration with REST, but I wouldn't call them grave.

>My only point from the quoted paragraph is that browser GUI issues
>do not apply to software integration through REST.
>  
>
I agree.

>>So how do you establish an initial context (or whatever its called) in a
>>capability-based system without doing authentication?
>>    
>>
>
>Your initial context is whatever set of URIs you start with. If
>your program is an XSLT stylesheet, your initial context is the
>set of URIs in the input XML document.
>
But how do I (as a client) get that initial set of URIs without 
participating in some kind of authentication process?  What do I click 
on (or reference) to get started?

>  
>
>>>>If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
>>>>at the same time allow users to refer to the same
>>>>document?
>>>>        
>>>>
>>>You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
>>>the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
>>>not use the capability model to solve this problem.
>>>      
>>>
>>I'm not disagreeing, but how about giving an example of something
>>(web-based) that you would use a capability model to solve.
>>    
>>
>
>I did. Your web-based bank account.
>
Ok - I guess I meant an example of how you would solve it.  What does 
the URI namespace look like?  How do you navigate among the various 
resources?

>>>There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
>>>just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
>>>control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
>>>problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
>>>problems, not DRM problems.
>>>      
>>>
>>Well, you may just have go into your long explanation, because if DRM
>>isn't about controlling access, then I'm pretty confused.
>>    
>>
>
>Access control is about controlling what authority you hand out.
>DRM is about controlling how people use authority they have
>already been given.
>  
>
I wont contest your definition, but my impression is that most people 
dont use that definition (rightly or wrongly).  Controlling access to a 
Resource (the R in URI) is about determining whether or not you are 
allowed to perform an operation on that resource - are you allowed to 
perform a GET/PUT/POST/DELETE.  

Which brings me to another question.  I understand that you control who 
can access a URI by controlling to whom you give the URI, but how do you 
control how they access the named resource.  That is, how do you control 
whether or not they can POST vs GET?

>In the WSJ scenario, a subscribed user is given the authority to
>read WSJ articles. The read authority implicitly carries with it
>the authority to pass-on the article to others. If you can read
>bits, you can copy bits. Neither capabilities nor ACLs can prevent
>you from giving a WSJ article to someone who is not a WSJ
>subscriber. The best you can do is make it less convenient to
>share the article. That is all the WSJ ACL does. It is just a
>feeble DRM measure.
>
I don't even think they're attempting DRM - its not necessary.  But 
that's a different discussion (one that I'm not interested in having 
either).

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3472
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-04 22:55:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

As the guy on the fence, here is my review of the
state of play so far:

1. There is an obvious conflict between UI and
capabilities.  It is obviously better to have
the option of having back links on a page rather
than being forced to play with frames.  But in
practice this conflict is not large because the
application designer can offer links to
"safe-to-share" URLs that don't link back and in
practice, you rarely want to share access-control
information (as distinct from DRM info).
Advantage: HTTP-Auth +.5

2. The practical advantage of capabilities is not
in sharing data, it is in manipulating it.  If I
simply want to share data in a HTTP auth world, I
can simply email it.  The only reason capabilities
offer an advantage over HTTP-Auth is if I need to
offer another POST/PUT/DELETE on the data and
don't want to go through some annoying ACL update
process to get there.
Note: if the data is large and complex then you
may want a viewer URL, in which case capabilities
are superior in this repect as well.
Advantage: Capabilities +.5

3. Access Control and DRM are different
applications.  Capabilities and HTTP-AUTH both
suck for DRM.  Capabilities are arguably better
for DRM because you can put a link on the page
that exposes the sender to harm if shared too
widely (but then you have to educate the user
about the risks of sharing)
Advantage Capabilities +.5

4. Getting to a user-specific starting
point requires some authentication process.
So either you use the standard HTTP-auth process
or something application specific.  Interop makes
HTTP-auth preferable, however there is no reason
that that presentation of an HTTP-auth credential
does not simply redirect you to a capability
graph.  Public login points are shared.  The
resulting URLs are not (like the bank session-id).
Advantage HTTP-auth +.5 Capabilities +.5

4. Many uses of HTTP-AUTH appeare unRESTful?
> https://www.bank.com/myaccounts/savings/register
>
> With http auth, I can give this URL to everyone who has an account at
> the bank, and that URI means the same thing to all of them - the page
> that shows the viewer the last 20 entries in their savings account register.
> I can put that link in a set of help pages that are not protected by any
> access controls (and that don't need to be dynamically rendered).  I can
> bookmark that page and always go straight to it (modulo a login
>  prompt).  I can send that link to a friend who also has an account at
> the same bank (to tell him how to get to his saving account register).

Shouldn't a URL uniquely identify a resource?
Having the content of the resource be completely
different depending on the login information
seems... wrong.

At minimum you POST authentication information to
a URL and should then get back a redirect to
unique URL for your savings register.

The URL you should share would be this POST url
not the URL of your actual data....

Advantage Capabilities +.5

So, in practice, it looks like the answer is both.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

On Tue, 4 Mar 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:

>
>
> Tyler Close wrote:
>
> >On Monday 03 March 2003 20:59, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> >
> >
> >>I should note first, that I'm a bit confused where this thread is going.
> >> It seems to me that we started by bitching about how browsers aren't
> >>terribly helpful with HTTP authentication.  Somehow, we've ending up
> >>talking about capabilities-based security,
> >>
> >>
> >
> >The link between the two topics is that HTTP Authentication is
> >also not terribly helpful for implementing access control.
> >
> Which isn't surprising since its HTTP _Authentication_.  But that's
> neither here nor there.
>
> >Switching to capabilities improves your GUI, your application
> >design and your security.
> >
> >
> I'll take your word on the security bit.  I'm not convinced of the other
> two.  I get the feeling that you'd just end up trading one set of
> problems for another.  But again, that's neither here nor there.
>
> >
> >
> >>which you have already
> >>indicated isn't really the best choice for the majority of what's on the
> >>web today.
> >>
> >>
> >
> >That is not the impression I intended to convey. Capability-based
> >security is the best choice for implementing access control. Both
> >capabilities *and* ACLs fail to implement DRM, so you might as
> >well stick with ACLs for DRM hacks. (More on this at the end of
> >the message.)
> >
> >
> So then, I don't understand your comment from an earlier message:
> <quote>... you're right, you wouldn't use this model to give everyone
> their own URI to a single, shared, read-only resource. </quote>
>
> As far as I am able to observe, an awful lot of the web consists of
> shared, read-only resources.  Are you saying that access control isn't
> necessary for shared, read-only resources?
>
> >
> >
> >>I think part of the problem I have is that with a capability model, it
> >>seems that you end up with everyone having their own private web of
> >>resources rather than having a public web of resources that are sharable
> >>with others.
> >>
> >>
> >
> >Well, that's kinda the whole point of access control isn't it? Do
> >you want your bank account to be part of the public web of
> >resources?  If so, please send me the first link. ;)
> >
> >
> https://www.accountlink.pncbank.com/index.html  :-)
>
> Unfortunately, its not a good example because the frame that actually
> shows my account info has a URL that simply has a session id encoded in
> it.  Besides, I'm really not interested in sharing my bank account info.
>
> A more useful example would be something like
>
> https://www.bank.com/myaccounts/savings/register
>
> With http auth, I can give this URL to everyone who has an account at
> the bank, and that URI means the same thing to all of them - the page
> that shows the viewer the last 20 entries in their savings account register.
>
> I can put that link in a set of help pages that are not protected by any
> access controls (and that don't need to be dynamically rendered).  I can
> bookmark that page and always go straight to it (modulo a login
>  prompt).  I can send that link to a friend who also has an account at
> the same bank (to tell him how to get to his saving account register).
>  I can distribute a tool that somehow processes the info from a savings
> account register at my bank without requiring each user configure the
> tool with their private URI.
>
> Note that I'm not suggesting that this is a good solution for accessing
> bank accounts - it just illustrates the idea of a public, sharable URI.
>  My understanding of the capability model leads me to conclude that I
> can't do anything like the above because every user would have to have
> their own URI.
>
> >The point of access control is to create private webs of
> >resources, with finely controlled links between them. Capabilities
> >are an excellent tool for implementing this.
> >
> >
> I dont disagree.  But it appears to me that the private web that is
> created is only useful to one individual.  What about groups of people?
>  If the answer is that everyone in the group shares the same, private
> URI, then how do I revoke access to just one member of the group. (I
> suspect your answer to this is going show that I don't understand the
> capability model after all.)
>
> >
> >
> >>As a result, you've lost the ability for people to connect
> >>those resources together in new ways to create new things on the web.
> >>
> >>
> >
> >Exactly the opposite.  What you've done is empowered people to
> >securely connect those resource that they want connected. The ACL
> >model prevents this.
> >
> >Just as an example, why don't you post to this list a link to a
> >withdrawal record from your online bank account. With the current
> >interface, this is not possible: you can't do it without also
> >posting the password for your entire account. If your bank account
> >was implemented with a capability-based security model, posting
> >the withdrawal record link would be no problem.  Capabilities
> >enable you to create links.  ACLs prevent you from creating links.
> >
> >
> I'm not sure why.  Assuming the withdrawal record has a URI, I dont see
> why I couldn't do that using a non-capability-based solution.  (I've
> also just realized that we're probably using the word _link_ differently.)
>
> >
> >
> >>>There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
> >>>issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
> >>>program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
> >>>to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
> >>>doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
> >>>variable.
> >>>
> >>>
> >>I'm not sure I'd agree that "web services" is about program to program
> >>communication.  I'm sure there are a lot of "web services" where there's
> >>only a program at one end and some things that look like documents or
> >>document processors at the other end.  "Program-to-program
> >>communication" the way you  seem to be using it sounds a lot like an RPC
> >>model to me, and in my mind REST and RPC don't mix.
> >>
> >>
> >
> >Is it your contention that program to program communication is RPC
> >and therefore not REST? If so, this has grave implications for any
> >thoughts of business integration with REST.
> >
> >
> No, that is not my contention - but only because I don't know what form
> that program-to-program communications takes.  If it is RPC, then no, it
> is not REST.  And yes, that does have implications for business
> integration with REST, but I wouldn't call them grave.
>
> >My only point from the quoted paragraph is that browser GUI issues
> >do not apply to software integration through REST.
> >
> >
> I agree.
>
> >>So how do you establish an initial context (or whatever its called) in a
> >>capability-based system without doing authentication?
> >>
> >>
> >
> >Your initial context is whatever set of URIs you start with. If
> >your program is an XSLT stylesheet, your initial context is the
> >set of URIs in the input XML document.
> >
> But how do I (as a client) get that initial set of URIs without
> participating in some kind of authentication process?  What do I click
> on (or reference) to get started?
>
> >
> >
> >>>>If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
> >>>>at the same time allow users to refer to the same
> >>>>document?
> >>>>
> >>>>
> >>>You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
> >>>the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
> >>>not use the capability model to solve this problem.
> >>>
> >>>
> >>I'm not disagreeing, but how about giving an example of something
> >>(web-based) that you would use a capability model to solve.
> >>
> >>
> >
> >I did. Your web-based bank account.
> >
> Ok - I guess I meant an example of how you would solve it.  What does
> the URI namespace look like?  How do you navigate among the various
> resources?
>
> >>>There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
> >>>just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
> >>>control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
> >>>problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
> >>>problems, not DRM problems.
> >>>
> >>>
> >>Well, you may just have go into your long explanation, because if DRM
> >>isn't about controlling access, then I'm pretty confused.
> >>
> >>
> >

> >DRM is about controlling how people use authority they have
> >already been given.
> >

> perform a GET/PUT/POST/DELETE.
>
> Which brings me to another question.  I understand that you control who
> can access a URI by controlling to whom you give the URI, but how do you
> control how they access the named resource.  That is, how do you control
> whether or not they can POST vs GET?
>

> >read WSJ articles. The read authority implicitly carries with it
> >the authority to pass-on the article to others. If you can read
> >bits, you can copy bits. Neither capabilities nor ACLs can prevent
> >you from giving a WSJ article to someone who is not a WSJ

> >feeble DRM measure.

Post ID:3473
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 00:02:39
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] more than one representation with the same MIME type
Message:

As to the question of what MIME types are
available and how/whether to use them, I think
that comes in the category we discussed earlier:
How do we describe a REST resource.  If I remember
correctly, the best proposal on this was yours!

-Alex-

On Mon, 3 Mar 2003, Jeffrey Winter wrote:

>
> > We should be proliferating mimetypes.  Their purpose is to
> > represent different document expectations.  We should use
> > them that way!
>
> A rich set of MIME types is a good thing, but my issue with relying
> on them for extracting different types of content from a single
> resource comes down to a couple of points:
>
> 1.  How would you even know what content types are available?  If
>     an indeterminate set of representations were associated with
>     a resource, how would you even know what MIME types to chuck at it?
>
> 2.  Different content types may have completely different
>     interfaces.  In my own application I happen to split
>     some types out into "resource-spaces" that support
>     different methods:
>
>        /blog/x/y/z  GET only (HTML document)
>        /rss/x/y/x   GET only (RSS 2.0 document)
>        /xbel/x/y/z  GET, PUT, POST, DELETE (XBEL document)
>
>     It wouldn't feel particularly intuitive to have the available
>     methods change based on the Accept: header or even a query
>     string.
>
>     I could see using a Accept: header to distinguish different RSS
>     types from the resources in the /rss "resource-space" above because
>     they are at least clearly different representations of a similar
>     underlying type, but a unique URL (a la query string?) should be
>     available too. Perhaps the absence of either in the request could
>     result in a 300 Multiple Choices, etc.
>

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3474
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 00:05:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] more than one representation with the same MIME type
Message:

I don't know enough about MIME politics to know
the correct answer to whether you proliferate MIME
types (per se) or simply add a version parameter.

My point is simply that MIME provides the OBVIOUS
and traditional mechanism for solving this
problem.

Better to fix MIME implementations, than to create
an entirely new mechanism for content-type.

-Alex-



On Mon, 3 Mar 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> >
> > We should be proliferating mimetypes.
> > Their purpose is to represent different document
> > expectations.
> > We should use them that way!
>
> That would be nice, but the practice seems somewhat different than theory
> here.
>
> For instance, there is no way for a server to know which version of HTML to
> return based on the content-type.  Should the HTML be strictly 3.2 or should
> it be 4.0?  Using "text/html" is not enough.  Using the user-agent (which is
> probably the most common technique) it just plain wrong.  A server can't
> possibly know every user-agent out there and shouldn't even care.  To avoid
> this, sites are left to tactics like home pages that have a low-end home
> page with links to the rest of the site in different version.  Hardly a good
> solution.
>
> The same could be said for distinguishing between RSS 0.91, 0.92, 0.93, and
> 2.0 (along with any other generic xml) since all that's used is "text/xml".
> Using "text/rss+xml" wouldn't be enough either.  In my blog system, if it
> gets "Accept:text/xml", it return RSS 2.0.  In order to get any other
> version, you have to resort to a kludge (in this case using a query string
> indicating the specific version).  This is just plain wrong and should not
> be how it has to be done...
>
> Now, maybe if people got into the habit of using a "version" parameter in
> mime types, this could be avoided(?).  For instance, it would be no problem
> to determine what a request means by "Accept:text/rss+xml;version=0.92".  I
> realize you could just register something like "text/rss092+xml", but the
> parameter is somewhat extensible without the need to register each new
> version.  As is done with the xhtml "profile" parameter, it may even make
> sense to use a URI instead of a simple version number.  This obviously has
> tradeoffs, of course.
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3475
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 01:42:57
Subject:extensible MIME types (was Re: more than one representation with the same MIME type)
Message:

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> I don't know enough about MIME politics to know
> the correct answer to whether you proliferate MIME
> types (per se) or simply add a version parameter.
>
> My point is simply that MIME provides the OBVIOUS
> and traditional mechanism for solving this
> problem.
>
> Better to fix MIME implementations, than to create
> an entirely new mechanism for content-type.

I agree.  To that end:

I propose the addition of a new MIME subtype to each of the 8 existing
media-types.  The name of the subtype will be "type-uri".  The type will
have a single required parameter "uri", whose value is a URI.  The complete
media type (including URI) will identify a specification.

The following limitations are placed on the URI (yes, Joe.  I know I'm
wading into those murky waters.  <g>) :

1) Creation rules of a new URI *must* be according to the scheme used.

2) The URI *must* be compared at the octet level.  As a result, creators of
new URIs should be very careful about the characters they use to ensure
maximum compatibility (e.g. do not use characters that may need escaping in
some instances).  This also means that URIs are case-sensitive.  I realize
that some schemes are case-insensitive, but require a case-sensitive version
of the URI to be used will not break those schemes.

3) If the scheme used has any form of dereferencing, then the URI *must* be
dereferencable and *should* dereference to details about the associated
specification.  Since it is not possible to guarantee that a URI will be
dereferencable at all times (e.g. network or server outages), recognition of
the MIME type *must* not rely on the ability to derefence the URI.  For this
purpose, the URI must be recognized as nothing more than an octet string.

4) It is strongly recommended that a dereferencable URI point to an entity
describing (or otherwise directing the user to) the associated
specification.


That's it really.  I'm sure there are all sorts of unanswered... umm...
questions.  So let's here them.  If you have a better suggestion for the
subtype name, let's here that too.  :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3476
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 01:45:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

>
>
>>https://www.bank.com/myaccounts/savings/register
>>
>>With http auth, I can give this URL to everyone who has an account at
>>the bank, and that URI means the same thing to all of them - the page
>>that shows the viewer the last 20 entries in their savings account register.
>>I can put that link in a set of help pages that are not protected by any
>>access controls (and that don't need to be dynamically rendered).  I can
>>bookmark that page and always go straight to it (modulo a login
>> prompt).  I can send that link to a friend who also has an account at
>>the same bank (to tell him how to get to his saving account register).
>>    
>>
>
>Shouldn't a URL uniquely identify a resource?
>Having the content of the resource be completely
>different depending on the login information
>seems... wrong.
>  
>
But it does identify a single resource.  The resource is NOT Chuck 
Hinson's bank account - the resource is 'my' bank account with 'my' 
being whoever is accessing it.

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3477
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 09:00:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Tue, 4 Mar 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> But it does identify a single resource.  The resource is NOT Chuck
> Hinson's bank account - the resource is 'my' bank account with 'my'
> being whoever is accessing it.

That is sophistry.  Most charitably, I would refer
you to all the people who want URL's for the
different variants produced in
content-negotiation.

But I think that authentication is very different
from content negotiation.  The notion that mailing
the URL of a WSJ article means something different
from mailing the URL of a bank savings register is
a little odd.

Using HTTP-auth for customization is abusive.
Now, I can define all sorts of resources
parametrized by username password.

Rather than adding a id=thingid to the query
string.  In the future, I can simply pass thingid
in the username...

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3478
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 15:13:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] extensible MIME types (was Re: more than one representation with the same MIME type)
Message:

I think dereferenceable MIME types are a bad idea.
Domain names change ownership all the time.
Organizations evolve.  Accidents happen.  Think
about allowing microsoft to change the definition
of application/msword whenever they want! (oh,
nevermind ;-))

I like the notion that it is easy to remember the
names of MIME types you actually use.

Anything wrong with the vnd- system?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax



On Tue, 4 Mar 2003, Seairth Jacobs wrote:

> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> >
> > I don't know enough about MIME politics to know
> > the correct answer to whether you proliferate MIME
> > types (per se) or simply add a version parameter.
> >
> > My point is simply that MIME provides the OBVIOUS
> > and traditional mechanism for solving this
> > problem.
> >
> > Better to fix MIME implementations, than to create
> > an entirely new mechanism for content-type.
>
> I agree.  To that end:
>
> I propose the addition of a new MIME subtype to each of the 8 existing
> media-types.  The name of the subtype will be "type-uri".  The type will
> have a single required parameter "uri", whose value is a URI.  The complete
> media type (including URI) will identify a specification.
>
> The following limitations are placed on the URI (yes, Joe.  I know I'm
> wading into those murky waters.  <g>) :
>
> 1) Creation rules of a new URI *must* be according to the scheme used.
>
> 2) The URI *must* be compared at the octet level.  As a result, creators of
> new URIs should be very careful about the characters they use to ensure
> maximum compatibility (e.g. do not use characters that may need escaping in
> some instances).  This also means that URIs are case-sensitive.  I realize
> that some schemes are case-insensitive, but require a case-sensitive version
> of the URI to be used will not break those schemes.
>
> 3) If the scheme used has any form of dereferencing, then the URI *must* be
> dereferencable and *should* dereference to details about the associated
> specification.  Since it is not possible to guarantee that a URI will be
> dereferencable at all times (e.g. network or server outages), recognition of
> the MIME type *must* not rely on the ability to derefence the URI.  For this
> purpose, the URI must be recognized as nothing more than an octet string.
>
> 4) It is strongly recommended that a dereferencable URI point to an entity
> describing (or otherwise directing the user to) the associated
> specification.
>
>
> That's it really.  I'm sure there are all sorts of unanswered... umm...
> questions.  So let's here them.  If you have a better suggestion for the
> subtype name, let's here that too.  :)
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3479
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 16:04:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] extensible MIME types (was Re: more than one representation with the same MIME type)
Message:

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> I think dereferenceable MIME types are a bad idea.
> Domain names change ownership all the time.
> Organizations evolve.  Accidents happen.  Think
> about allowing microsoft to change the definition
> of application/msword whenever they want! (oh,
> nevermind ;-))

True.  However, there are safeguards (which may or may not be resistant to
these issues):

1) Use PURLs.  Hmm... we could change "type-uri" to "purl" and just use the
PURL mechanism.  :)
2) Do not use a dereferencable URI scheme.  Heck, we could even come up with
one specifically for this purpose.  It would even be able to adress your
other comment about the "[ease of remembering] the names of MIME type you
actually use."
3) Just because a specification changes doesn't mean that it's bad.  As long
as the specification has its own versioning built in, it would be no
different than asking for an "image/gif" without knowing whether you will
get back an 87a or 89a version.
4) I want to point out that the dereferencability of a of a URI is a
convenience only in my proposal.  In order to determine whether a given
media-type is recognized, the URI must be interpreted as a string only.

I should point out that this technique should not replace the existing
registration process.  The regular registration process has much value in of
itself.  If anything, this technique is a cross between using the "x-" and
full registration.  For the very reasons you point out above, people should
not rely on them as much as you would for a registered media-type.  On the
other hand, the use of a URI allows for additional authority and guarantee
of uniqueness that "x-" does not.  For instance, RSS 1.0 is an RDF document
while RSS 2.0 is not.  It would not make sense to use "application/rss+xml"
for both of them (which doesn't even appear to be a registered media type).
On the other hand, if each had something like:

RSS 1.0 : application/type-uri;uri="http://example.invalid/rss10"
RSS 2.0 : application/type-uri;uri="http://sample.invalid/rss20"

There would be no mistaking which is which.

> Anything wrong with the vnd- system?

This still requires you to register each new subtype.


I am not convinced myself that this is the right way to go about doing
things.  It's just that I have adde conneg to an application and suddenly
realized just how useless it can be, both in terms of support for it and in
terms of the available media-types out there.  This is just an attempt to
answer my own frustration at it all.  In truth, I would like a better
solution, but until one comes along would this one "work"?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Post ID:3480

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:


S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>On Tue, 4 Mar 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
>  
>
>>But it does identify a single resource.  The resource is NOT Chuck
>>Hinson's bank account - the resource is 'my' bank account with 'my'
>>being whoever is accessing it.
>>    
>>
>
>That is sophistry.  Most charitably, I would refer
>you to all the people who want URL's for the
>different variants produced in
>content-negotiation.
>
>But I think that authentication is very different
>from content negotiation.  The notion that mailing
>the URL of a WSJ article means something different
>from mailing the URL of a bank savings register is
>a little odd.
>
>Using HTTP-auth for customization is abusive.
>Now, I can define all sorts of resources
>parametrized by username password.
>
>Rather than adding a id=thingid to the query
>string.  In the future, I can simply pass thingid
>in the username...
>  
>
I respectfully disagree, and I'll leave it at that.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3481
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-05 23:17:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

I'm sorry.  I was waayy too strident (too little
sleep).

Anyway, the question remains: Is it RESTful for
resources to be parametrized by authentication
information?

From an API, it would be sort of annoying if a
resource can be completely different depending on
auth.

From a UI perspective, it strikes me as
frustrating not to be able to mail a URL to the
exact resource I am looking at if I want to.

OTOH it also strikes me that it would be nice to
be able to specify a URL for this TYPE of
resource.  My instinct is that application
providers should provide distinct login entry
points.

Anyone else have an opinion here?

-Alex-





On Wed, 5 Mar 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:

>
>
> S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
>
> >On Tue, 4 Mar 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> >
> >
> >>But it does identify a single resource.  The resource is NOT Chuck
> >>Hinson's bank account - the resource is 'my' bank account with 'my'
> >>being whoever is accessing it.
> >>
> >>

> >That is sophistry.  Most charitably, I would refer
> >you to all the people who want URL's for the
> >different variants produced in
> >content-negotiation.

> >from content negotiation.  The notion that mailing
> >the URL of a WSJ article means something different
> >from mailing the URL of a bank savings register is
> >a little odd.

> >Now, I can define all sorts of resources

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3482
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-03-06 11:49:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] W3C Note - User Agent Authentication FORM elements
Message:

On Tuesday 04 March 2003 01:52, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> Tyler Close wrote:
> >Switching to capabilities improves your GUI, your application
> >design and your security.
>
> I'll take your word on the security bit.  I'm not convinced of the other
> two.

So how important is application security to you and others on this
list? Are there people on this list that implement business
applications, or is it mostly open use applications?

I request that the list owner open a poll on this question: "I am
currently implementing a web-service that provides access to a
business process. yes/no".

> So then, I don't understand your comment from an earlier message:
> <quote>... you're right, you wouldn't use this model to give everyone
> their own URI to a single, shared, read-only resource. </quote>
>
> As far as I am able to observe, an awful lot of the web consists of
> shared, read-only resources.  Are you saying that access control isn't
> necessary for shared, read-only resources?

Often, access control does not make sense for a shared, read-only
resource. To answer the question, you have to study the situation
to determine the roles of the participants.

In order for shared access to be an access control problem, it
must be the case that *all* participants want to protect access to
the shared resource. If any participant does not care about
protecting access, the access-control mechanism is without
meaning.  This is the case in the WSJ example.

When only a subset of the participants wish to protect access to
the shared resource, the problem is a DRM problem.

Typically, access to a shared resource is only an access control
problem when the shared resource is modifiable. It is rare for a
modifiable resource to be shared between more than two
participants.

> A more useful example would be something like
>
> https://www.bank.com/myaccounts/savings/register
>
> With http auth, I can give this URL to everyone who has an account at
> the bank, and that URI means the same thing to all of them - the page
> that shows the viewer the last 20 entries in their savings account
> register.

Ah, but that's not the question I asked you. Can you post a
traversable link to an entry from *your* account history?

> Note that I'm not suggesting that this is a good solution for accessing
> bank accounts - it just illustrates the idea of a public, sharable URI.
>  My understanding of the capability model leads me to conclude that I
> can't do anything like the above because every user would have to have
> their own URI.

Telling someone how to access their own resource is also easily
done in the capability model. Using the graph that defines the
structure of the web of resources, you can determine what path
they need to follow. So, in a capability solution, you would say:
"Starting from your main account page, follow the path:
'savings/register/'." Using my web-calculus solution, you would do
this by appending the query string "?path=savings/register/" to
the main account page URI.

> >The point of access control is to create private webs of
> >resources, with finely controlled links between them. Capabilities
> >are an excellent tool for implementing this.
>
> I dont disagree.  But it appears to me that the private web that is
> created is only useful to one individual.  What about groups of people?
>  If the answer is that everyone in the group shares the same, private
> URI, then how do I revoke access to just one member of the group. (I
> suspect your answer to this is going show that I don't understand the
> capability model after all.)

I think you are still thinking about DRM scenarios. As I said
above, it is rare for a modifiable resource to be shared between
more than two participants.

When you want to have revokable access to a shared resource, you
do give each participant a unique URI for the shared resource. To
revoke access, you revoke just the corresponding URI. This is no
more complex than managing an ACL for the resource would be.

> >>As a result, you've lost the ability for people to connect
> >>those resources together in new ways to create new things on the web.
> >
> >Exactly the opposite.  What you've done is empowered people to
> >securely connect those resource that they want connected. The ACL
> >model prevents this.
> >
> >Just as an example, why don't you post to this list a link to a
> >withdrawal record from your online bank account. With the current
> >interface, this is not possible: you can't do it without also
> >posting the password for your entire account. If your bank account
> >was implemented with a capability-based security model, posting
> >the withdrawal record link would be no problem.  Capabilities
> >enable you to create links.  ACLs prevent you from creating links.
>
> I'm not sure why.  Assuming the withdrawal record has a URI, I dont see
> why I couldn't do that using a non-capability-based solution.  (I've
> also just realized that we're probably using the word _link_ differently.)

Does your bank account have a separate ACL for every addressable
resource? Are you allowed to modify those ACLs? Are you allowed to
introduce new principals into the ACL system? Are you allowed to
delegate all of this authority to others? Typically, the answer to
all these questions is 'no'. To support linking, all these
questions have to be answered 'yes'.  An ACL design becomes far
too complex when it tries to answer 'yes' to all these questions.
When the application becomes this complex, it becomes a playground
for crackers.  A capability security model supports fine-grained
linking with minimal complexity.

> >>So how do you establish an initial context (or whatever its called) in a
> >>capability-based system without doing authentication?
> >
> >Your initial context is whatever set of URIs you start with. If
> >your program is an XSLT stylesheet, your initial context is the
> >set of URIs in the input XML document.
>
> But how do I (as a client) get that initial set of URIs without
> participating in some kind of authentication process?  What do I click
> on (or reference) to get started?

Are you asking how a new user gets added to an existing
application? If so, the first URI is given to the new user in much
the same way as a username/password is given to a new user.

> Ok - I guess I meant an example of how you would solve it.  What does
> the URI namespace look like?  How do you navigate among the various
> resources?

If you want a fully worked out example, I suggest something
simpler, like the tradeable credit example in the web-calculus
specification:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/

The schemas for all the resources used in this example can be
found at:

http://waterken.com/iou/

> >Access control is about controlling what authority you hand out.
> >DRM is about controlling how people use authority they have
> >already been given.
>
> I wont contest your definition, but my impression is that most people
> dont use that definition (rightly or wrongly).

I agree that most people don't know the first thing about
software security. I blame this mostly on the complexity of
existing software security solutions. I think the simpler
capability security model could change the status quo.

> Controlling access to a
> Resource (the R in URI) is about determining whether or not you are
> allowed to perform an operation on that resource - are you allowed to
> perform a GET/PUT/POST/DELETE.

Actually, that's just a product of access control. Access control
is about how you came to have the authority to perform a
GET/PUT/POST/DELETE, how you exercise that authority, and how you
delegate that authority to others. This is a subtle but very
important distinction. The difference has caused great confusion
and error for many people, even some very smart people.

> Which brings me to another question.  I understand that you control who
> can access a URI by controlling to whom you give the URI, but how do you
> control how they access the named resource.  That is, how do you control
> whether or not they can POST vs GET?

One of the main design principles in capability-based security is
that distinctions in authority be reified as different resources.
If POST and GET provide different kinds of authority, they should
be different resources, accessed through different URIs.

This means that GET on a POSTable resource should only provide
information about what to POST. GETing the results of POSTing
should be a different URI. This means you've got one URI that
provides read-access to the current state of the resource, and a
different URI that provides the authority to modify the state of
the resource. Most existing web-applications are already designed
this way.

Tyler
