a typical structure could be:

[ ( weight, [ (weight, term)+ ] )+ ]

with [ ] and ( ) beeing arrays and sequences (as in python or prolog)

Post ID:3517
Sender:Erik Terpstra <erik@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-08 08:38:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>ReST programming takes this evolution further.
>Where OOP created a relatively small number of
>object classes, ReST creates many.  Where OOP
>reduced the number of methods per object
>moderately, ReST reduces them drastically.
>Although we largely have been discussing ReST in
>terms of web architecture, there is no obvious
>reason why those design principles should not
>apply equally well within smaller scale
>programming contexts.

I am not sure if a reduced number of methods per object is beneficial 
for smaller scale programming contexts, but a programming context based 
on sending messages between resources (components) definitely is (see 
the links below).

>The transition to OOP resulted in new programming
>languages specifically designed to support that
>style of programming.  Is anyone working on a
>ReST Oriented Programming Environments?

In my opinion this theory comes close:

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~franz/pubs-pdf/C13.pdf

This one is a bit more specific, really good example code, but the pages 
seem to be scanned and are very hard to read, definitely worth a try though:

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~franz/pubs-pdf/J06.pdf

-- Erik





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3518
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-08 12:02:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

S. Alexander Jacobson wrote,
> The transition to OOP resulted in new programming languages
> specifically designed to support that style of programming.  Is anyone
> working on a ReST Oriented Programming Environments?

Not as such to the best of my knowledge.

But if you squint really hard, you might notice that REST has an awful 
lot in common with the programming model implicit in the pi-calculus 
... the key point is to think of a URI in REST corresponding to the 
name of a communication channel in pi.

I think the most interesting aspect of the comparison is that REST's 
most powerful idiom (passing continuation/capability URIs in 
request/response entities) carries over directly to pi (names of 
channels can be passed over channels).

There are a few experimental programming languages modelled on pi which 
you might enjoy playing with. They might also be a source of 
inspiration for anyone interested in putting together a full-blown REST 
toolkit. PICT and Nomadic PICT are probably the most interesting ... 
implementations for Linux available here,

  http://lsewww.epfl.ch/~pawel/nomadicpict.html

Cheers,


Miles





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3519
Sender:Sam Hunting <shunting@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-08 13:22:08

> lot in common with the programming model implicit in the pi-calculus 
> ... the key point is to think of a URI in REST corresponding to the 
> name of a communication channel in pi.

Interesting paper on pi-calculus. (I wonder if an arc could be a channel?)

http://www.dcs.ed.ac.uk/home/fhlt/docs/project.pdf

<quote>The models are based on a new mathematical structure which 
we call pi- forests. We build an abstract machine which has 
these structures as machine states, almost as if we are 
presenting an implementation</quote>

> I think the most interesting aspect of the comparison is that REST's 
> most powerful idiom (passing continuation/capability URIs in 
> request/response entities) carries over directly to pi (names of 
> channels can be passed over channels).
>

> you might enjoy playing with. They might also be a source of 
> inspiration for anyone interested in putting together a full-blown REST 
> toolkit. PICT and Nomadic PICT are probably the most interesting ...

Post ID:3521
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-08 15:16:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

Sam Hunting wrote,
> I wonder if an arc could be a channel?

That's a bit cryptic for someone like me who knows virtually nothing 
about Topic Maps ... care to elaborate?

My wild guess is that the answer is "maybe" but only with a bit of 
reinterpretation of TM. In pi, channels link processes. In TM I suppose 
arcs relate topics. So, if it makes any kind of sense to think of a 
topic as a process, there might be a corrspondance between arcs and 
channels.

Cheers,


Miles

Post ID:3522
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-08 19:29:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] GET with complex parameters
Message:

>>>>> "Yannick" == Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...> writes:

    Yannick> I'm modeling a search engine in Rest. Queries are more
    Yannick> complex than just a list of keywords, and should be
    Yannick> represented in xml. So my question is: how could I send
    Yannick> the query to the server ?  The obvious solution would be
    Yannick> a POST, but as it is a search, GET would be more
    Yannick> convenient?  

convenient? You mean more RESTful? I think the names of verbs is pure
ideology. It's the ideas that count. If POST works better for pure
technical reasons, use POST.

Best would be probably a hidden field, name "method" or so that really
indicates what you wanted. You need to have it for PUT/DELETE anyway.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:

Post ID:3523
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-08 20:20:49
Subject:DELETE container?
Message:

Suppose you have resources with the following structure:

    /container
    /container/1
    /container/2
    /container/3

Now, suppose I were to issue a "DELETE /container".  Would it be acceptable
to end up at the end with "/container" still existing, but empty?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

Post ID:3525
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 03:47:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

On Tuesday, Apr 8, 2003, at 07:02 US/Central, Miles Sabin wrote:

> But if you squint really hard, you might notice that REST has an awful
> lot in common with the programming model implicit in the pi-calculus
> ... the key point is to think of a URI in REST corresponding to the
> name of a communication channel in pi.

Yup.

> I think the most interesting aspect of the comparison is that REST's
> most powerful idiom (passing continuation/capability URIs in
> request/response entities) carries over directly to pi (names of
> channels can be passed over channels).

Yup.

NB, I think pi gets overlooked a lot because people think it's all 
mobile agent passe-crufty.  Too bad, really.

> There are a few experimental programming languages modelled on pi which
> you might enjoy playing with. They might also be a source of
> inspiration for anyone interested in putting together a full-blown REST
> toolkit. PICT and Nomadic PICT are probably the most interesting ...
> implementations for Linux available here,

Cf. Piccola instead.  Much more approachable for most of the folks who 
aren't steeped in that particular lit, I'd imagine.  (I found it so 
myself.)

	http://iamwww.unibe.ch/~scg/Research/Piccola/

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3526
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 13:45:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

Hmm...  that feels less intuitive to me.  But if "DELETE /container" is
strictly not allowed to be used in this manner, then that's probably the
best way to go.  But is it not allowed?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> How 'bout DELETE  /container/all to accomplish that?
>
> From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
>
> > Suppose you have resources with the following structure:
> >
> >     /container
> >     /container/1
> >     /container/2
> >     /container/3
> >
> > Now, suppose I were to issue a "DELETE /container".  Would it be
> acceptable
> > to end up at the end with "/container" still existing, but empty?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3527
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 14:12:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

I don't know where it would say that its 'not allowed'....

Maybe a better way to look at it is to consider the impact of one choice 
over the other.

For instance, if you use DELETE /container to delete the contents of the 
container, then what will you use to delete the container itself?  If 
DELETEing the container is something that doesnt make sense in your 
application, then it may be OK.  What do you use to create the container?

Personally, I don't see a problem doing it either way - as long as the 
semantics of the DELETE operation for you application are made clear, 
are consistent, and aren't in conflict with what most people would 
construe delete to mean.

--Chuck

want to delete its contents seems non-intuitive to me.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3529
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 14:54:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

I think the general question here is what are the
standard ReST semantics for container.  It feels
like we loop through this periodically on this
list but never resolve it generically.  Here are
the questions that should be in the FAQ (I don't
know the answers).

1. How do you create a container?
  Do we use the WebDAV MKCOL method?
  Do we PUT a content-type that is, by definition,
   a container e.g. text/xml+rss or multipart/mixed?

2. How do we add things to the container?
  Do we rely on directory structure and just do
   a PUT /collection/item?
  Do we POST /collection and get back a 201 CREATED?

3. How do we specify the order of items in a collection?
  If we do this by POSTing to the collection, how
  do we disambiguate between an add-to-collection
  POST and an "order-by" POST.

4. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and its contents?
  My answer: DELETE /container

5. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and not
  its contents?
  My answer: Make it a container of links (see #4)

6. How do you DELETE only the contents of a container?
  My answer: Either iterate through the contents
  and DELETE individually or DELETE the container
  and then create it again but then see #1

Some people may want to argue that these choices
are application specific, but to the extent they
are, it would be useful to know what the standard
choices are.   Part of the point of ReST is to
reduce the amount of prior knowledge you need to
interact with any resource.  Standard patterns for
these things would be helpful.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3530
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 15:14:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:


S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>I think the general question here is what are the
>standard ReST semantics for container.
>
<pedantic>
I don't disagree with the intent of the question, but shouldnt the 
question really be "what are the standard _HTTP_ semantics for a 
container?"  As far as I know, REST (as described in Fielding's thesis) 
says nothing about the concept of containers; it only talks about 
resources in general.  (The closest it comes is a statement that a 
resource may be a collection of other resources).
</pedantic>

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

-ALex-

Post ID:3532
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 15:47:17
Subject:Fw: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Baker" <mbaker@...>
To: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>; "rest-discuss"
<rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 11:29 AM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?


I've found the following heuristics useful; if the life
of the child is inextricably linked to the life of the
parent, then kill the child when the parent is killed.
Otherwise, don't.

In order to kill off independant children, I'd be tempted
to use DAV's "Depth" feature on a delete to delete the
childen.  But I've never implemented that.

MB

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]

Post ID:3534
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 17:00:27
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 5:47 PM
> To: rest-discuss
> Subject: Fw: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Mark Baker" <mbaker@...>
> To: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>; "rest-discuss"
> <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 11:29 AM
> Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
>
>
> I've found the following heuristics useful; if the life
> of the child is inextricably linked to the life of the
> parent, then kill the child when the parent is killed.
> Otherwise, don't.
>
> In order to kill off independant children, I'd be tempted
> to use DAV's "Depth" feature on a delete to delete the
> childen.  But I've never implemented that.
>
> MB

In WebDAV, DELETE is always "deep". There's no way to delete a collection
without it's children, because it would result in a DAV-inconsistent
namespace

Julian.

--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3535
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-09 21:10:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

> I think the general question here is what are the
> standard ReST semantics for container.  It feels
> like we loop through this periodically on this
> list but never resolve it generically.  Here are
> the questions that should be in the FAQ (I don't
> know the answers).

Well, for one, it is REST -- not ReST.  I like uniformity in some
things.

> 1. How do you create a container?
>   Do we use the WebDAV MKCOL method?
>   Do we PUT a content-type that is, by definition,
>    a container e.g. text/xml+rss or multipart/mixed?

Theoretically, you simply PUT something that needs containment,
as evidenced by the slash in the path.  However, most webdav
implementers believed that a collection should exist prior to
a PUT within it, since that makes it easier to catch user mistakes
such as mistyping a long URI.  Hence, MKCOL.

REST will happily accept either alternative, providing that the
method is standardized (has the same meaning) for all resources
(even if some may not allow it).

> 2. How do we add things to the container?
>   Do we rely on directory structure and just do
>    a PUT /collection/item?

If you know that item os the name you want, yes.

>   Do we POST /collection and get back a 201 CREATED?

If you don't know what the name should be, yes.

> 3. How do we specify the order of items in a collection?
>   If we do this by POSTing to the collection, how
>   do we disambiguate between an add-to-collection
>   POST and an "order-by" POST.

Order is a property of the collection representation.

> 4. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and its contents?
>   My answer: DELETE /container

That is certainly how the user agent would express the semantic.
The server might tell you to delete the children first.

> 5. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and not
>   its contents?
>   My answer: Make it a container of links (see #4)

Move the contents first.

> 6. How do you DELETE only the contents of a container?
>   My answer: Either iterate through the contents
>   and DELETE individually or DELETE the container
>   and then create it again but then see #1

If you delete the container, it may have adverse effects on other
links.  For example, if the server automatically maintains links,
then you should not delete the container unless you want all of
those links to go away.  So, delete each resource individually.

BTW, why do you switch from "collection" to "container"?

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3536
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 03:28:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] GET with complex parameters
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Berend de Boer" <berend@...>
>
> Best would be probably a hidden field, name "method" or so that really
> indicates what you wanted. You need to have it for PUT/DELETE anyway.
Not for pure-automation approaches where you go beyond a classic web
browser.

It's not harmful to retrieve via POST, just not optimal. But it is harmful
to modify via GET. So the method names are not merely ideology.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3537
Sender:"bhaugen32" <bhaugen32@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 09:50:46
Subject:Re: DELETE container?
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Roy T. Fielding" 
<fielding@a...> wrote:

> > 5. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and not
> >   its contents?
> >   My answer: Make it a container of links (see #4)
> 
> Move the contents first.

Let me see if I understand this correctly yet:

Say I have a container of products...
http://example.com/products
...containing individual products e.g....
http://example.com/products/productA
http://example.com/products/productB
...etc.

And then I have another collection:
http://example.com/topTenProducts/productB
...etc.

Would I need to move the products under topTenProducts before I 
DELETE the topTenProducts collection because 
http://example.com/topTenProducts/productB is a different resource 
than http://example.com/products/productB ?

Even though they are the same product?  And that the 
physical "resource" behind the covers is the same?

Is there a name in REST-speak for that physical thing behind the 
covers that is the same?

(Or am I still thinking incorrectly about this REST stuff?)

Thanks.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3538
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 10:46:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Jeffrey Winter" <JeffreyWinter@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 12:26 PM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?


> If you want to delete the contents of a container, why not
> just PUT and empty container to the URL?
> 

What would the body of that PUT look like?

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3539
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 12:32:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

Bob,

> Would I need to move the products under topTenProducts before I 
> DELETE the topTenProducts collection because 
> http://example.com/topTenProducts/productB is a different resource 
> than http://example.com/products/productB ?
> 
> Even though they are the same product?  And that the 
> physical "resource" behind the covers is the same?
> 
> Is there a name in REST-speak for that physical thing behind the 
> covers that is the same?
> 
> (Or am I still thinking incorrectly about this REST stuff?)

I think I can answer the REST part of this: If you are the authority
at example.com, and you assert/enforce that /topTenProducts/productB
and /products/productB are two names for the same resource, then
that's exactly what you have: two names, one resource.

Sameness = identity = resource; that much is clear.

What happens to a resource that appears (by virtue of being
named) in multiple containers when a container is deleted
is not so clear  But I don't think REST covers that either, at
least not yet.  (It might be fun and useful to model containment
semantics.)

But I can synthesize the following argument.  If DELETE on a
container is interpreted to mean 'deep delete', such that it implies
DELETE on all (recursively) contained resources, then any
resource contained will be zapped, regardless of whether it
was contained elsewhere as well.  This should be true in any
situation where a resource has multiple names, regardless of
any containment semantics or absence of same.  For instance,
if /a and /b denote the same resource, and 'DELETE /a' happens,
then 'GET /b' should result in 'not found'.

That's my understanding.  Could somebody please check that
and correct me where/if I've gone astray?

Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3540
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 13:26:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

Walden Mathews wrote:
> Bob,
> 
>  > Would I need to move the products under topTenProducts before I
>  > DELETE the topTenProducts collection because
>  > http://example.com/topTenProducts/productB is a different resource
>  > than http://example.com/products/productB ?
>  >
>  > Even though they are the same product?  And that the
>  > physical "resource" behind the covers is the same?
>  >
>  > Is there a name in REST-speak for that physical thing behind the
>  > covers that is the same?
>  >
>  > (Or am I still thinking incorrectly about this REST stuff?)
> 
> I think I can answer the REST part of this: If you are the authority
> at example.com, and you assert/enforce that /topTenProducts/productB
> and /products/productB are two names for the same resource, then
> that's exactly what you have: two names, one resource.

And a Content-Location header MAY be used to supply the URI when the 
requested resource is available from a different location. This would 
allow you to have a model where you establish a definitive URI for the 
resource (say under /products/productB). This would allow you to say 
that a DELETE request is only permitted against the definitive URI.

Another possible model is to think of the alternative URIs like UNIX 
hard links - you can keep deleting them until the last one is gone.

> 
> Sameness = identity = resource; that much is clear.
> 
> What happens to a resource that appears (by virtue of being
> named) in multiple containers when a container is deleted
> is not so clear  But I don't think REST covers that either, at
> least not yet.  (It might be fun and useful to model containment
> semantics.)
> 
> But I can synthesize the following argument.  If DELETE on a
> container is interpreted to mean 'deep delete', such that it implies
> DELETE on all (recursively) contained resources, then any
> resource contained will be zapped, regardless of whether it
> was contained elsewhere as well.  This should be true in any
> situation where a resource has multiple names, regardless of
> any containment semantics or absence of same.  For instance,
> if /a and /b denote the same resource, and 'DELETE /a' happens,
> then 'GET /b' should result in 'not found'.
> 
> That's my understanding.  Could somebody please check that
> and correct me where/if I've gone astray?
> 
> Walden
> 
> 
> *Yahoo! Groups Sponsor*
> <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/M=249982.3083889.4452939.1728375/D=egroupweb/S=1705701014:HM/A=1524963/R=0/*http://hits.411web.com/cgi-bin/autoredir?camp=556&lineid=3083889&prop=egroupweb&pos=HM> 
> 
> 
>

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

> <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3541
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 13:45:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> Suppose you have resources with the following structure:
> 
>     /container
>     /container/1
>     /container/2
>     /container/3
> 
> Now, suppose I were to issue a "DELETE /container".  Would it be acceptable
> to end up at the end with "/container" still existing, but empty?

Existing but empty. Hmm. What does the representation of an empty 
container look like? Does it even have a representation? I'd say that if 
it has a representation then this would be somewhat confusing, but not 
altogether wrong; it would be as if the container had magically been 
created immediately after deletion.

This sounds like an implementation convenience question - is the 
requirement to provide a simple way of deleting all the contained 
resources. I'd suggest an alternative container which also contains all 
the resources

/container?id=*

Then you could DELETE this, which would also delete all the contained 
resources. But you would not have removed the /container resource. Any 
further requests to /container?id=* at this point should get 404 Not 
Found (or is 410 Gone better?), until the /container is non empty.

This seems clearer to me because I get the behaviour I'd expect on the 
alternative container - when DELETED it is gone. And the /container 
resource is still there, ready to accept POST (or whatever really) in 
the future.

> 
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
> 
> 
> *Yahoo! Groups Sponsor*
> <http://us.ard.yahoo.com/M=249982.3083889.4452939.1728375/D=egroupweb/S=1705701014:HM/A=1524963/R=0/*http://hits.411web.com/cgi-bin/autoredir?camp=556&lineid=3083889&prop=egroupweb&pos=HM> 
> 
> 
> 
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> 
> 
> 
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service 
> <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3542
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 13:59:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

> Another possible model is to think of the alternative URIs like UNIX 
> hard links - you can keep deleting them until the last one is gone.

I'm not sure about this (I'm not sure about anything, but especially
this).  DELETE seems to work against the mapping of resource to
representations, not against the mapping of identifier(s) to resources,
as would be the case above.

The linking and unlinking of identifiers to resources seems to be
solely in the domain of the authority, not something exposed through
the methods of HTTP.

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3543
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 14:32:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> > Another possible model is to think of the alternative URIs like UNIX
> > hard links - you can keep deleting them until the last one is gone.
>
> I'm not sure about this (I'm not sure about anything, but especially
> this).  DELETE seems to work against the mapping of resource to
> representations, not against the mapping of identifier(s) to resources,
> as would be the case above.
>
> The linking and unlinking of identifiers to resources seems to be
> solely in the domain of the authority, not something exposed through
> the methods of HTTP.

How can you DELETE the representation-to-resource mapping and still have the
identifier-to-resource mapping exist?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3544
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 15:02:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

Seairth,

I believe this, in essence, is what Roy Fielding meant when he
said [somewhere] "resources always exist".

And why not?  You have a concept, no current way to express
(represent) it, but you still have name(s) for it.  For example,
"my retirement".

WM

Post ID:3545
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 16:05:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

I can't think of *any* resource I have a name for which I have no
representation.  The very act of naming it means I have a representation.
"Your retirement", for instance, still has a representation.  In this case
it may be "what it will be like" or "never get around to having one" (or
whatever your represtentation of it currently is).  I bet you can't talk or
even think of your retirement without conjuring up a single representation
of it.  I know I can't.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> I believe this, in essence, is what Roy Fielding meant when he
> said [somewhere] "resources always exist".

Post ID:3546
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 17:20:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

Seairth,

Remember that we are talking about a protocol that transfers
representations, not one that "conjures up" representations, or has
the capability of conjuring up representations.

It's more like my decision to answer your question or not,
regardless of whether I have an answer or could think of one.

This topic is a rathole;  let's stay out.  Thread should be about
containment and deletion.

Walden

Post ID:3547
Sender:"sem_antico" <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 19:31:26
Subject:Re: DELETE container?
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Walden Mathews <waldenm@o...> wrote:
> > Another possible model is to think of the alternative URIs like UNIX 
> > hard links - you can keep deleting them until the last one is gone.
> 
> I'm not sure about this (I'm not sure about anything, but especially
> this).  DELETE seems to work against the mapping of resource to
> representations, not against the mapping of identifier(s) to resources,
> as would be the case above.
> 
> The linking and unlinking of identifiers to resources seems to be
> solely in the domain of the authority, not something exposed through
> the methods of HTTP.
> 
> WM

OK, I admit I was being a little fanciful about the hard link idea. My
(re) reading of RFC 2616 leads me to beleive that DELETE works against
the resource itself. Therefore if there are multiple representations
(and multiple URI for that resource) then I'd expect they should all
be deleted by the request - though the RFC is not explicit on this point.

I vaguely recall an earlier discussion about DELETE and content
negotiaon - if its relevant anyone care to summarise?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3548
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 19:49:15
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Re: DELETE container?
Message:

People may be interested to review the current WebDAV Binding draft at:

http://www.webdav.org/bind/draft-ietf-webdav-bind-01.3.htm

(it tries to define how multiple bindings to the same resource and the
DELETE method interact).

--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3549
Sender:"sem_antico" <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 19:51:23
Subject:REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

Following on from the recent thread which discussed modelling a multi
page form submission process using REST principles, I'm wondering if
there is any place at all for the use of cookies in a REST style http
application?

It seems clear that cookies should not be used to store hidden state,
states should be exposed in the request URI. This seems to preclude
the use of cookies in this context.

Another popular use of cookies is as an alternative authentication
mechanism. The chief motivation for this is the lack of control most
user agents give application designers over the standard http
authorisation mechanisms - no easy way of providing customised login
prompts and no control over expiring authentication are two of the
issues here. Does this application of cookies break REST principles?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3550
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 23:13:11
Subject:URLs are not containers! (was Re: DELETE container?)
Message:

I think the premise of this discussion is
incorrect.  A URL is not a container.
Relationships between URLs are entirely client and
application driven.  If you think that one URL
contains another, specify that in some RDF
document.  And when you do, you need need to
precisely specify the meaning of this containment
relation:

1. Does deleting a container without first
   deleting its contents result in a 50x error?
2. Does deleting a container also delete all of
   its contents and disable any further
   GET/POSTs to the URL?
3. Does deleting a container simply empty its
   contents but allow further GET/POSTs to
   the URL?
[Note: these are equivalent to the issue of
referential integrity and cascading deletes from
the RDBMS world]

DELETEing a URL should simply mean that you can no
longer GET or POST to it.  Adding arbitrary side
effects just makes it more complex to interact
with your application.

Note: It would be great to solve the referential
integrity problem for the web, but I think that
goes WAYYY beyond the scope of this discussion.

Note: If you don't want the overhead of
downloading all the URLs in the collection and
deleting them one by one, you probably need the
container to handle a POST whose body is "delete
contents."  But handling this sort of message is
really an optimization and all the warnings about
optimizations apply here.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax



On Thu, 10 Apr 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:

> > Another possible model is to think of the alternative URIs like UNIX
> > hard links - you can keep deleting them until the last one is gone.
>
> I'm not sure about this (I'm not sure about anything, but especially
> this).  DELETE seems to work against the mapping of resource to
> representations, not against the mapping of identifier(s) to resources,
> as would be the case above.
>
> The linking and unlinking of identifiers to resources seems to be
> solely in the domain of the authority, not something exposed through
> the methods of HTTP.
>
> WM
>
>
>
>

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>

>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3551
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 23:35:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

On Wed, 9 Apr 2003, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> > 1. How do you create a container?
>
> Theoretically, you simply PUT something that needs containment,
> as evidenced by the slash in the path.  However, most webdav
> implementers believed that a collection should exist prior to
> a PUT within it, since that makes it easier to catch user mistakes
> such as mistyping a long URI.  Hence, MKCOL.

Why is slash definitive about containment?
If you PUT /foo/bar?baz, does that create a
container?
How about PUT http://objectname.domain.com?

My claim at this point is that (ignorning WebDAV)
URLs tell you nothing about containment relations.

> > 4. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and its contents?
> >   My answer: DELETE /container
>
> That is certainly how the user agent would express the semantic.
> The server might tell you to delete the children first.

This is actually related to the question I didn't
ask.  What happens when you GET a container?  I
think that GET on a container isn't standardized
because, again, HTTP URLs are not defined to have
containment relations.  I think for WebDAV to
specify DELETE in this context without
constraining GET is weird.

Note: If GET were specified on a containe, we
wouldn't need index.html files.

> BTW, why do you switch from "collection" to "container"?

We are talking implicitly about containment
relationships.  A directory contains other files,
it does not collect them.

Note: If you want to use collection, then I would
observe that to delete a name for the collection
is not to delete the members of the collection.

And to DELETE a URL is really only to DELETE a
name.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Post ID:3552
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URLs are not containers! (was Re: DELETE container?)
Message:

> Note: If you don't want the overhead of
> downloading all the URLs in the collection and
> deleting them one by one, you probably need the
> container to handle a POST whose body is "delete
> contents."  But handling this sort of message is
> really an optimization and all the warnings about
> optimizations apply here.

Not to mention that you're bypassing the generic
interface constraint and reducing visibility.

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3553
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-10 23:53:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

> Note: If you want to use collection, then I would
> observe that to delete a name for the collection
> is not to delete the members of the collection.
> 
> And to DELETE a URL is really only to DELETE a
> name.

But 'DELETE <url>' doesn't translate to "delete this
URL". Is there even a mechanism for "deleting" URLs?
I thought not.

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3554
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-11 01:06:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

On Thu, 10 Apr 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
> But 'DELETE <url>' doesn't translate to "delete this
> URL". Is there even a mechanism for "deleting" URLs?
> I thought not.

It doesn't?  Once DELETE <URL> succeeds, <URL>
no longer designates the location of a resource.
Further use of <URL> should result in a 404 or 410
from the server.  If you want to use <URL> in some
other context, thats fine, but it is no longer a
URL, just a string that has URL syntax and any
other string would do in its place.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Message:

Oh.  I thought DELETE meant something like "unmap
this resource from its representations".

I can delete a URL with my backspace key, but that's
not HTTP DELETE.

WM

anymore (but it may be PUT to).

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3557
Sender:Miles Sabin <miles@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-11 10:37:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URLs are not containers! (was Re: DELETE container?)
Message:

S. Alexander Jacobson wrote,
> DELETEing a URL should simply mean that you can no longer GET or POST
> to it.  Adding arbitrary side effects just makes it more complex to
> interact with your application.

It also has the potential to interact interestingly with DELETE's 
idempotence. 

FWIW, slightly related: the strawman "proof" I gave here,

  http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/2349

that all sequences of idempotent requests are idempotent sequences 
relies on the assumption that URIs are independent irrespective of any 
shared lexical prefix. Clearly this proof fails if that assumption is 
false.

I can't remember if Walden's Alloy model made the same assumption. 
Walden?

Cheers,


Miles

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

> I'd say it's still a URL. It just doesn't have a mapped representation
> anymore (but it may be PUT to).

I would think so.

That's interesting, though.  What about POST under these
conditions?

WM





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3559
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-11 12:42:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URLs are not containers! (was Re: DELETE container?)
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Miles Sabin" <miles@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, April 11, 2003 6:37 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] URLs are not containers! (was Re: DELETE
container?)


> S. Alexander Jacobson wrote,
> > DELETEing a URL should simply mean that you can no longer GET or POST
> > to it.  Adding arbitrary side effects just makes it more complex to
> > interact with your application.
>
> It also has the potential to interact interestingly with DELETE's
> idempotence.
>
> FWIW, slightly related: the strawman "proof" I gave here,
>
>   http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/2349
>
> that all sequences of idempotent requests are idempotent sequences
> relies on the assumption that URIs are independent irrespective of any
> shared lexical prefix. Clearly this proof fails if that assumption is
> false.
>
> I can't remember if Walden's Alloy model made the same assumption.
> Walden?

The model I posted was extremely abstract, as you may recall,
treating "function" in the relational sense of a mapping, which we
understood to represent a state transition for some resource or
another.  There's no expressive power in a model like that for the
concept of parallel state transitions on other resources, all wrapped
up in a single operation.

In short, yes, by dint of minimal expressiveness.

Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3560
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-11 23:32:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

> Why is slash definitive about containment?

Because that is the meaning of slash in a URI (name containment, not
storage containment).  RFC 2396.

> If you PUT /foo/bar?baz, does that create a
> container?
> How about PUT http://objectname.domain.com?
>
> My claim at this point is that (ignorning WebDAV)
> URLs tell you nothing about containment relations.

Then you are talking about storage containment, which is irrelevant
to REST.

>>> 4. How do you DELETE a non-empty container and its contents?
>>>   My answer: DELETE /container
>>
>> That is certainly how the user agent would express the semantic.
>> The server might tell you to delete the children first.
>
> This is actually related to the question I didn't
> ask.  What happens when you GET a container?  I
> think that GET on a container isn't standardized
> because, again, HTTP URLs are not defined to have
> containment relations.  I think for WebDAV to
> specify DELETE in this context without
> constraining GET is weird.
>
> Note: If GET were specified on a containe, we
> wouldn't need index.html files.

Huh?  index.html files are an implementation mechanism for providing
a representation for the ancestor/ name, which most people call a
collection (of names).  That is not a container.

>> BTW, why do you switch from "collection" to "container"?
>
> We are talking implicitly about containment
> relationships.  A directory contains other files,
> it does not collect them.

You used both words interchangeably.  Traditionally, a container is a
storage component that contains other addressable items, whereas a
collection is a list of addressable items independent of storage.
Containers are represented by an aggregation of its contents.
A collection is represented by a list of names and related information.

In REST, a "directory" can be presented as two different resources --
container or collection -- only by providing different identifiers
for each purpose.

> Note: If you want to use collection, then I would
> observe that to delete a name for the collection
> is not to delete the members of the collection.
>
> And to DELETE a URL is really only to DELETE a
> name.

More assumptions about the implementation.  The method only signifies
the action desired by the user agent.  How that is accomplished is left
to the server implementation.  Some implementations will have garbage
collection, others will delete on last reference removed, and still
others will refuse a delete until the namespace is empty.  In any case,
the client cannot delete the URI -- it can only see and manipulate the
representation, and all it expects from the origin server is that the
old representation is no longer available once the DELETE succeeds.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3561
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-12 02:02:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

From: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
>
> > And to DELETE a URL is really only to DELETE a
> > name.
>
> More assumptions about the implementation.  The method only signifies
> the action desired by the user agent.  How that is accomplished is left
> to the server implementation.  Some implementations will have garbage
> collection, others will delete on last reference removed, and still
> others will refuse a delete until the namespace is empty.  In any case,
> the client cannot delete the URI -- it can only see and manipulate the
> representation, and all it expects from the origin server is that the
> old representation is no longer available once the DELETE succeeds.

When you say "all it expects from the origin server is that the old
representation is no longer available", do you mean that no representation
is available for the given URI or that a representation can still be
available after-the-fact, but the client can make the absolute claim that
the two representations (before and after the DELETE) are not the same?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3562
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-12 02:04:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:


Seairth Jacobs wrote:

>From: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
>  
>
>>>And to DELETE a URL is really only to DELETE a
>>>name.
>>>      
>>>
>>More assumptions about the implementation.  The method only signifies
>>the action desired by the user agent.  How that is accomplished is left
>>to the server implementation.  Some implementations will have garbage
>>collection, others will delete on last reference removed, and still
>>others will refuse a delete until the namespace is empty.  In any case,
>>the client cannot delete the URI -- it can only see and manipulate the
>>representation, and all it expects from the origin server is that the
>>old representation is no longer available once the DELETE succeeds.
>>    
>>
>
>When you say "all it expects from the origin server is that the old
>representation is no longer available", do you mean that no representation
>is available for the given URI or that a representation can still be
>available after-the-fact, but the client can make the absolute claim that
>the two representations (before and after the DELETE) are not the same?
>  
>
Or simply that the representation(state) that existed at the time the 
DELETE operation was applied no longer exists?

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3563
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-12 02:18:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:


Roy T. Fielding wrote:

>>1. How do you create a container?
>>  Do we use the WebDAV MKCOL method?
>>  Do we PUT a content-type that is, by definition,
>>   a container e.g. text/xml+rss or multipart/mixed?
>>    
>>
>
>Theoretically, you simply PUT something that needs containment,
>as evidenced by the slash in the path.  However, most webdav
>implementers believed that a collection should exist prior to
>a PUT within it, since that makes it easier to catch user mistakes
>such as mistyping a long URI.  Hence, MKCOL.
>
>REST will happily accept either alternative, providing that the
>method is standardized (has the same meaning) for all resources
>(even if some may not allow it).
>  
>

But does HTTP happily accept either alternative?  Or does HTTP 
standarize on one or the other method?

[...]

>  
>
>>6. How do you DELETE only the contents of a container?
>>  My answer: Either iterate through the contents
>>  and DELETE individually or DELETE the container
>>  and then create it again but then see #1
>>    
>>
>
>If you delete the container, it may have adverse effects on other
>links.  For example, if the server automatically maintains links,
>then you should not delete the container unless you want all of
>those links to go away.  So, delete each resource individually.
>  
>

What do you mean by "the server automatically maintains links?"

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3564
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-12 02:39:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

Roy T. Fielding wrote:

>>1. How do you create a container?
>>  Do we use the WebDAV MKCOL method?
>>  Do we PUT a content-type that is, by definition,
>>   a container e.g. text/xml+rss or multipart/mixed?
>>    
>>
>
>Theoretically, you simply PUT something that needs containment,
>as evidenced by the slash in the path.  
>

So if I PUT to /foo/bar/xyz, there now exists a resource with that name 
(assuming all goes well).  Does that necessarily imply that there is now 
also a resource named /foo/bar?  That is, if I start with an empty 
hierarchy and no resources, then do a PUT to /foo/bar/xyz, is there 
anything about REST or HTTP that dictates that  I now have three 
resources rather than one?

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3565
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-12 22:06:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "sem_antico" <rest-discuss@...>

> Another popular use of cookies is as an alternative authentication
> mechanism. The chief motivation for this is the lack of control most
> user agents give application designers over the standard http
> authorisation mechanisms - no easy way of providing customised login
> prompts and no control over expiring authentication are two of the
> issues here. Does this application of cookies break REST principles?

If one of the REST principles is visibility into messages for key
information - like authentication - then moving authentication out of the
standard header and into custom cookies would then violate this aspect.

I found a Note on the W3C site about extending HTML FORM with authentication
information - this would allow application authors to declare their usage of
authentication in a way that provides control over the user experience as
well as allowing the user-agent to correctly translate that into protocol
level authentication.

http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-authentform

---an example---
<AUTHFORM>
User Name: <INPUT TYPE=AUTHUSER><BR>
Password:  <INPUT TYPE=AUTHSECRET><BR>
Realm:     <SELECT TYPE=AUTHREALM>
             <OPTION VALUE=READONLY SELECTED>Read Only</OPTION>
             <OPTION VALUE=READWRITE>Read/Write</OPTION>
           </SELECT><BR>
<INPUT TYPE=AUTHLOAD VALUE="Log In">
<INPUT TYPE=AUTHUNLOAD  VALUE="Log Out">
</AUTHFORM>
---an example---





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3566
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-12 22:34:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...> writes:

> If one of the REST principles is visibility into messages for key
> information - like authentication - then moving authentication out of the
> standard header and into custom cookies would then violate this aspect.
> 
> I found a Note on the W3C site about extending HTML FORM with authentication
> information - this would allow application authors to declare their usage of
> authentication in a way that provides control over the user experience as
> well as allowing the user-agent to correctly translate that into protocol
> level authentication.
> 
> http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-authentform

Remember that for web services the existing model is not really
broken. 

It's only really broken in the way browsers work and the way
most marketing managers want the application to do authentication.

It's my belief that basic authentication could be fixed as a device
for doing web authentication if the user agents always displayed the
entity from the server.



Nic Ferrier





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3567
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 00:55:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>
>
> It's my belief that basic authentication could be fixed as a device
> for doing web authentication if the user agents always displayed the
> entity from the server.

Except that entity already has a use:  to be displayed if the user hits the
cancel button.  An alternative might be to provide a new response header
during challenges that points a browser to a server-defined skin (possibly
using the technique S. Mike found in the W3C Note).  Newer browsers that
recognized the header would  be able to give a more "polished" look, while
older browsers would continue working without problem.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3568
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 01:10:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...> writes:

> From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>
> >
> > It's my belief that basic authentication could be fixed as a device
> > for doing web authentication if the user agents always displayed the
> > entity from the server.
> 
> Except that entity already has a use:  to be displayed if the user hits the
> cancel button.  An alternative might be to provide a new response header
> during challenges that points a browser to a server-defined skin (possibly
> using the technique S. Mike found in the W3C Note).  Newer browsers that
> recognized the header would  be able to give a more "polished" look, while
> older browsers would continue working without problem.

You misunderstand me.

When a user requests a protected resource the server can send back an
entity body with the initial 401. The rfc says that the entity is for
when the response fails - but that should only happen after a
challenge has been sent. 

Therefore, if browsers displayed any entity body sent by the server
when no challenge has been sent the entity body could be used to
provide a "normal" authentication FORM (ie: a username and password
POSTing to some place).

In other words the entity body from the server replaces the login
dialog box for the user.

This would fit in with the way most web applications want to do
authentication and it's REST compliant (as far as I can see).


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3569
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 03:38:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Thu, Apr 10, 2003 at 07:51:23PM -0000, sem_antico wrote:
> Following on from the recent thread which discussed modelling a multi
> page form submission process using REST principles, I'm wondering if
> there is any place at all for the use of cookies in a REST style http
> application?
> 
> It seems clear that cookies should not be used to store hidden state,
> states should be exposed in the request URI.

Well, somewhere in the message anyhow.

> This seems to preclude
> the use of cookies in this context.

I'd say so.

> Another popular use of cookies is as an alternative authentication
> mechanism. The chief motivation for this is the lack of control most
> user agents give application designers over the standard http
> authorisation mechanisms - no easy way of providing customised login
> prompts and no control over expiring authentication are two of the
> issues here. Does this application of cookies break REST principles?

Yep.

Any application of cookies breaks REST, because they are by definition
stateful, and all REST interactions are stateless.  That doesn't mean
they don't have their uses, of course.  But there other ways of doing
"sessions" statelessly, and doing them statefully is not REST.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3570
Sender:"bhaugen32" <bhaugen32@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 12:38:47
Subject:Re: REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Mark Baker <distobj@a...> wrote:
> Any application of cookies breaks REST, because they are by 
definition
> stateful, and all REST interactions are stateless.  That doesn't 
mean
> they don't have their uses, of course.  But there other ways of 
doing
> "sessions" statelessly, and doing them statefully is not REST.

At least three frequently asked questions are contained in that 
paragraph:
1. Cookies vs REST?
2. Sessions vs REST?
3. What does REST mean by "stateless"?

#1 & #2 of course are closely related.
#3 has a larger range.  

I added those questions to the rest-wiki FAQ page.  Without answers, 
since I don't really feel qualified to sort out the various confused 
answers I've seen on this list and elsewhere.

Good answers would be a blessing.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3571
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 13:05:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Thursday, Apr 10, 2003, at 20:51 Europe/Dublin, sem_antico wrote:
> Following on from the recent thread which discussed modelling a multi
> page form submission process using REST principles, I'm wondering if
> there is any place at all for the use of cookies in a REST style http
> application?

i don't think so.

however the reality of contemporary user agents dictates a more 
pragmatic approach.  (IMHO of course).

i will take two examples where i have had to use cookies as keys to 
server-side session state:
1. shopping cart.
2. authentication.

it seems to me that early web/REST people may have thought shopping 
carts would be handled as client side state, and be all posted to an 
/orders resource or whatever at the end.  however this isn't the 
reality of how client UAs work.  the state needs to be stored on the 
server because there isn't any standard way of doing it on the client.  
you can't do this without a session, otherwise, what URI does the 'buy 
this item' POST operate on?

> Another popular use of cookies is as an alternative authentication
> mechanism. The chief motivation for this is the lack of control most
> user agents give application designers over the standard http
> authorisation mechanisms - no easy way of providing customised login
> prompts and no control over expiring authentication are two of the
> issues here. Does this application of cookies break REST principles?

i think so.

as mentioned by others, user agents need to display the entity returned 
by the server.  i would say they also need to supply 'log out' UI and 
make the current authentication status highly visible and obvious.

regards,
-vincent

> 2. authentication.

> reality of how client UAs work.  the state needs to be stored on the

But having state on the server is surely fine with REST?

> you can't do this without a session, otherwise, what URI does the 'buy 
> this item' POST operate on?

If you create a 'basket' resource for my shopping on the server, the
I'd imagine POST-ing new items into the basket. Once I was ready I'd
POST a reference to the basket to the checkout URI. Why does this need
cookies? - it can all be done if you ensure you 'carry' the basket URI
around the online shop as you go.

> > mechanism. The chief motivation for this is the lack of control most

they 'stick' that makes it possible to break the stateless http model

> "sessions" statelessly, and doing them statefully is not REST.
