-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3574
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 18:28:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

The question here is whether the availability of
HTTP resources are dependent or independent on
resources higher than them in the HTTP URI path
hierarchy.  e.g. whether:

  DELETE /parent

implies anything about how the server should then
respond to:

  GET /parent/child

RFC2396 says:
  URI that are hierarchical in nature use the
  slash "/" character for separating
  hierarchical components. For some file systems,
  a "/" character (used to denote the hierarchical
  structure of a URI) is the delimiter used to
  construct a file name hierarchy, and thus the URI
  path will look similar to a file pathname.
  This does NOT imply that the resource is a file
  or that the URI maps to an actual filesystem pathname.

So the semantics of the hierarchical relationship
are dependent on the scheme (or perhaps even the
implementation) and are not specified by RFC2396.

RFC 2616 (HTTP), says:

  As far as HTTP is concerned, Uniform Resource
  Identifiers are simply formatted strings which
  identify--via name, location, or any other
  characteristic--a resource.

Since RFC2616 makes no specific reference to
resource hierarchies or containers, this language
would imply that hierarchy means very little in
HTTP and therefore the default assumption for HTTP
should be Resource Independence.

Roy argues that it is the Implementor's Choice;
that resource dependence is up to the implementor.
If the resource is defined as a container of
addressable elements, DELETEing the resource would
DELETE its contents.  OTOH, if the resource is
defined to be a collection, DELETEing the resource
would affect only those applications that view the
other resources as a collection.

The problem with Implementor's Choice is that no
RFC specifies that being higher in the path
hierarchy of an HTTP URL implies either a
collection or container relationship with the
those lower down.  As such, any implementation of
resource dependence is really an imeplementation
with large non-standard side-effects.

So, given that a major REST design principle is to
make the effects of all methods as predictable as
possible, HTTP-REST applications SHOLD implement
resource independence rather than resource
dependence.

Note: Resource independence does not prohibit an
application from prohibiting deletes until some
other set of resources are deleted.  It only
prohibits non-standard side-effects associated
with allowing a DELETE to succeed.

Note 2: A further syntactic argument against
Resource Dependence is that the side effects of a
DELETE with a query string become extremely
unpredictable, but I think such an argument is
unnessary given the above.

-Alex-
___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


o





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3575
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-14 06:58:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Sunday, Apr 13, 2003, at 17:36 Europe/Dublin, sem_antico wrote:
>> it seems to me that early web/REST people may have thought shopping
>> carts would be handled as client side state, and be all posted to an
>> /orders resource or whatever at the end.  however this isn't the
>> reality of how client UAs work.  the state needs to be stored on the
>> server because there isn't any standard way of doing it on the client.
>
> But having state on the server is surely fine with REST?

of course.  i'm not sure how that contradicts what i said though.  i'm 
referring to the fact that you have to 'build up' the shopping basket 
'incrementally' on the server rather than on the client.  the question 
discussed below is a direct consequence of this fact ('which basket do 
i POST to?').

>> you can't do this without a session, otherwise, what URI does the 'buy
>> this item' POST operate on?
>
> If you create a 'basket' resource for my shopping on the server, the
> I'd imagine POST-ing new items into the basket. Once I was ready I'd
> POST a reference to the basket to the checkout URI. Why does this need
> cookies? - it can all be done if you ensure you 'carry' the basket URI
> around the online shop as you go.

how do you distinguish between your basket and my basket?  they're two 
seperate resources, as they should be.  now how do you know which 
basket to target the POST at (without having it hard-coded in to the 
representation of the item being bought?)?  and how do you do *that* 
without having a cookie to tell you who's logged in, and hence to use 
/customers/semantico/basket/ vis-a-vis /customers/vdm/basket/ ?

just to be clear, while i think this reduces the RESTfulness of an app, 
i think its still better than a totally non-RESTful app, because its 
limiting the use of cookies to a well-defined area.  same goes for auth.

maybe there's a better way, but i have yet to see it.

regards,
-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3576
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-14 08:42:39
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Sunday, Apr 13, 2003, at 17:36 Europe/Dublin, sem_antico wrote:
> 
>>> it seems to me that early web/REST people may have thought shopping
>>> carts would be handled as client side state, and be all posted to an
>>> /orders resource or whatever at the end.  however this isn't the
>>> reality of how client UAs work.  the state needs to be stored on the
>>> server because there isn't any standard way of doing it on the client.
>>
>>
>> But having state on the server is surely fine with REST?
> 
> 
> of course.  i'm not sure how that contradicts what i said though.  i'm 
> referring to the fact that you have to 'build up' the shopping basket 
> 'incrementally' on the server rather than on the client.  the question 
> discussed below is a direct consequence of this fact ('which basket do i 
> POST to?').
> 
>>> you can't do this without a session, otherwise, what URI does the 'buy
>>> this item' POST operate on?
>>
>>
>> If you create a 'basket' resource for my shopping on the server, the
>> I'd imagine POST-ing new items into the basket. Once I was ready I'd
>> POST a reference to the basket to the checkout URI. Why does this need
>> cookies? - it can all be done if you ensure you 'carry' the basket URI
>> around the online shop as you go.
> 
> 
> how do you distinguish between your basket and my basket?  they're two 
> seperate resources, as they should be.  now how do you know which basket 
> to target the POST at (without having it hard-coded in to the 
> representation of the item being bought?)?

I think that is the answer - the representation of the items that I can 
buy will contain a pointer to _my_ basket. Thats what I meant when I 
said I have to 'carry' my basket around the store.

This may make the programming maginally trickier, granted, as the 
product pages will have to contain the identifier for my basket within them.

> and how do you do *that* 
> without having a cookie to tell you who's logged in, and hence to use 
> /customers/semantico/basket/ vis-a-vis /customers/vdm/basket/ ?

Ah, but if you were using cookies then the POST would be to /my_basket, 
and the internal logic of the application would direct that to 
/customers/semantico/basket/ or /customers/vdm/basket/ - these resources 
would not be directly exposed to the POST, they would be internal to the 
application. Which reduces visibility.

> 
> just to be clear, while i think this reduces the RESTfulness of an app, 
> i think its still better than a totally non-RESTful app, because its 
> limiting the use of cookies to a well-defined area.  same goes for auth.
> 
> maybe there's a better way, but i have yet to see it.
> 
> regards,
> -vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3577
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-13 18:34:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Sun, Apr 13, 2003 at 04:43:09PM -0000, sem_antico wrote:
> > Any application of cookies breaks REST, because they are by definition
> > stateful, and all REST interactions are stateless.
> 
> But on one level are cookies not pieces of state representation that
> get transferred between client and server?

Not really.  Cookies aren't the state, they're "receipts" for the state.
e.g. if you login to a web site using cookies, your browser just gets an
opaque string which represents your login information.  It's your login
info which is the state.  Subsequent interactions are called "stateful"
because the meaning of the message depends upon state which is not
present in the message, requiring parties wanting to process those
messages to already know how to lookup the login/password info given
the cookie.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3578
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-14 13:46:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Monday, Apr 14, 2003, at 09:42 Europe/Dublin, Richard Padley wrote:
>> how do you distinguish between your basket and my basket?  they're two
>> seperate resources, as they should be.  now how do you know which 
>> basket
>> to target the POST at (without having it hard-coded in to the
>> representation of the item being bought?)?
>
> I think that is the answer - the representation of the items that I can
> buy will contain a pointer to _my_ basket. Thats what I meant when I
> said I have to 'carry' my basket around the store.
>
> This may make the programming maginally trickier, granted, as the
> product pages will have to contain the identifier for my basket within 
> them.

yes.

the representations generated can differ depending on whether there is 
a logged in session; e.g. include some HTML form UI which does a POST 
to the URI of 'my basket' or else some text saying 'you need to log in 
before you can buy stuff' or whatever.

>> and how do you do *that*
>> without having a cookie to tell you who's logged in, and hence to use
>> /customers/semantico/basket/ vis-a-vis /customers/vdm/basket/ ?
>
> Ah, but if you were using cookies then the POST would be to /my_basket,
> and the internal logic of the application would direct that to
> /customers/semantico/basket/ or /customers/vdm/basket/ - these 
> resources
> would not be directly exposed to the POST, they would be internal to 
> the
> application. Which reduces visibility.

quite.  i hadn't even considered that possibility to be honest.  thanks 
for sharing it.

regards,
-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3579
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-14 14:59:26
Subject:another DELETE question
Message:

This is a half REST, half RDF question.

Suppose a I have an RDF document at http://example.invalid/rdf/1.  Now, suppose inside the document, I had something like the following (minus namespace junk):

<rdf:RDF>
    <resource rdf:about="http://anothersite.invalid/somepath">
        <dc:description>Something or other</dc:description>
    </resource>

    <resource rdf:about="http://anothersite.invalid/someotherpath">
        <dc:description>Yadda</dc:description>
    </resource>
</rdf:RDF>


Are there any known techiques for RESTfully updating RDF documents?  I suspect one could use POST to add/updated individual statements.  Or is there any way to use PUT plus a query string to "directly" update statements?  How about removal of individual statements? In order to remove *all* statements, could I do something like:

DELETE /rdf/1?http://anothersite.invalid/somepath


---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3580
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 01:46:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Sunday, April 13, 2003, at 06:05  AM, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Thursday, Apr 10, 2003, at 20:51 Europe/Dublin, sem_antico wrote:
>> Following on from the recent thread which discussed modelling a multi
>> page form submission process using REST principles, I'm wondering if
>> there is any place at all for the use of cookies in a REST style http
>> application?
>
> i don't think so.
>
> however the reality of contemporary user agents dictates a more
> pragmatic approach.  (IMHO of course).

Yes, for current implementations.  Eventually, someone points
out the security hole and some poor sap is assigned to make the browser
compliant with one or more standards, and suddenly they find out that
a raft of user-reported errors just go away.

> i will take two examples where i have had to use cookies as keys to
> server-side session state:
> 1. shopping cart.
> 2. authentication.
>
> it seems to me that early web/REST people may have thought shopping
> carts would be handled as client side state, and be all posted to an
> /orders resource or whatever at the end.  however this isn't the
> reality of how client UAs work.

That can be fixed.  Back in the really old days, all of the people who
were actually working on the Web implementations would talk about this
kind of thing on www-talk and it would be implemented by half the
browsers before the day ended.  Now such a suggestion would be tabled
within the W3C and two years later they would figure out which working
group has the appropriate right and W3C representation to work on the
topic, and two years after that we would have two different
recommendations based on technologies that none of the browsers 
implement.

>> Another popular use of cookies is as an alternative authentication
>> mechanism. The chief motivation for this is the lack of control most
>> user agents give application designers over the standard http
>> authorisation mechanisms - no easy way of providing customised login
>> prompts and no control over expiring authentication are two of the
>> issues here. Does this application of cookies break REST principles?
>
> i think so.
>
> as mentioned by others, user agents need to display the entity returned
> by the server.  i would say they also need to supply 'log out' UI and
> make the current authentication status highly visible and obvious.

Yes, that would be the correct fix.  Note that this is a well-known
security hole in browsers that has been consistently reported since
1993, and yet no one ever fixed it.  Probably because Netscape and MSIE
were too busy battling over blink and marquee tags.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3581
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 00:55:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

>> Theoretically, you simply PUT something that needs containment,
>> as evidenced by the slash in the path.  However, most webdav
>> implementers believed that a collection should exist prior to
>> a PUT within it, since that makes it easier to catch user mistakes
>> such as mistyping a long URI.  Hence, MKCOL.
>>
>> REST will happily accept either alternative, providing that the
>> method is standardized (has the same meaning) for all resources
>> (even if some may not allow it).
>
> But does HTTP happily accept either alternative?  Or does HTTP
> standarize on one or the other method?

HTTP doesn't tell applications how to do a sequence of actions.
It only defines what each action means and how the client should
interpret the response to each action.  WebDAV is a little more
explicit about sequences, which is why it prefers MKCOL and would
probably reject a deep PUT.

>> If you delete the container, it may have adverse effects on other
>> links.  For example, if the server automatically maintains links,
>> then you should not delete the container unless you want all of
>> those links to go away.  So, delete each resource individually.
>
> What do you mean by "the server automatically maintains links?"

Many content management products (like Day Software's Communique)
include an automatic link maintenance function that will recognize
a delete on a resource and either note all links to it as being
broken (and thus scheduled for review) or simply deactivate those
links so that they don't show up on the published pages until someone
either changes the destination or restores the deleted resource.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3582
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 01:30:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

On Sunday, April 13, 2003, at 11:28  AM, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> The question here is whether the availability of
> HTTP resources are dependent or independent on
> resources higher than them in the HTTP URI path
> hierarchy.  e.g. whether:
>
>   DELETE /parent
>
> implies anything about how the server should then
> respond to:
>
>   GET /parent/child

/parent is not an ancestor resource.  /parent/ is.

> RFC2396 says:
>   URI that are hierarchical in nature use the
>   slash "/" character for separating
>   hierarchical components. For some file systems,
>   a "/" character (used to denote the hierarchical
>   structure of a URI) is the delimiter used to
>   construct a file name hierarchy, and thus the URI
>   path will look similar to a file pathname.
>   This does NOT imply that the resource is a file
>   or that the URI maps to an actual filesystem pathname.
>
> So the semantics of the hierarchical relationship
> are dependent on the scheme (or perhaps even the
> implementation) and are not specified by RFC2396.

No, the slash character is not dependent on the scheme.  It is not
allowed to appear in any URI that does not treat the slash as being a
hierarchical separator.  That includes "http" URIs.

> RFC 2616 (HTTP), says:
>
>   As far as HTTP is concerned, Uniform Resource
>   Identifiers are simply formatted strings which
>   identify--via name, location, or any other
>   characteristic--a resource.

which says nothing about this discussion.

> Since RFC2616 makes no specific reference to
> resource hierarchies or containers, this language
> would imply that hierarchy means very little in
> HTTP and therefore the default assumption for HTTP
> should be Resource Independence.

Huh?  HTTP is dependent on RFC 2396.  Every restriction in 2396
is an absolute requirement on 2616.

> Roy argues that it is the Implementor's Choice;
> that resource dependence is up to the implementor.

No, I did not.  What I said was that making assumptions about the
implementation is strictly not allowed in REST.  Therefore, much
of what you were arguing simply does not apply.

> If the resource is defined as a container of
> addressable elements, DELETEing the resource would
> DELETE its contents.  OTOH, if the resource is
> defined to be a collection, DELETEing the resource
> would affect only those applications that view the
> other resources as a collection.

No, that is completely confused.  The method defines what the user
agent intends in regards to the identifier name space.  How the server
accomplishes that is none of the user agent's business.  DELETE'ing
a hierarchical ancestor is a request to delete the entire name space.
There is no other choice.  The only issue is whether a server should
require that the child name space be empty before allowing the DELETE
to succeed, and that choice is left to the server.  The client must
be prepared to handle a 4xx response.  The server cannot respond with
a 2xx response unless the entire name space is deleted.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3583
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 03:36:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

> Any application of cookies breaks REST, because they are by definition
> stateful, and all REST interactions are stateless.  That doesn't mean
> they don't have their uses, of course.  But there other ways of doing
> "sessions" statelessly, and doing them statefully is not REST.

That concept tends to be a little confusing, partly because HTTP,
like many network protocols, has a notion of stateless interactions
that only refers to having all of the information needed to
understand each request inside the request or defined by universal
standard.  REST goes further and constrains application state
(not resource state) to be held on the client.  It is hard to
describe without further defining what "application" means, but
we can think of it as the context between user agent requests:
the server cannot be aware of any such context and still be REST.

This is also what allows individual pages to be bookmarked and
shared with others, but that's a longer story.

The purpose of statelessness is to prevent partial failures and
allow for substrate independence (e.g., load-balanced gateways
managing the traffic for many servers).  Cookies don't
necessarily break that because they are inside the request,
unless developers make the mistake of defining the cookie such
that it varies by gateway.

Most of the problems with cookies are due to breaking visibility,
which impacts caching and the hypertext application engine, but
even worse is its use for authentication, as evidenced by the
cross-site-scripting security holes in sites that use it.
It ends up being a weird trade-off of security versus efficiency.

Using cookies is more efficient than authentication because the
server (and intermediaries) will simply ignore cookies for the
vast majority of URI (e.g., inline images).  That allows everything
except the pages that set cookies to be cacheable, and those are
typically non-cacheable pages in any case.  However, using cookies
in that fashion means the server is relying on security by obscurity
to associate the client's stored cookie with the application state
(attackers ability to guess the cookie or obtain it illegitimately
via XSS).  Likewise, keeping state in the cookie means that the
URIs can be independent of the user state, but doing that messes-up
the client's understanding of state as presented by the hypertext
engine: it breaks the "back" button.

Unfortunately, cookies were not presented for discussion by the
community until after they had been deployed and announced as one
of Netscape's infamous "extensions".  If they had, then it is more
likely that HTML would have been extended to indicate selectable
items, and browsers could then have developed a client-side
market basket that is more reliable and subject to a fancier UI.
Doing that now is simply a chicken-and-egg problem: browers won't
bother til there is user demand for the feature, and sites won't
offer it as an option until browsers implement it consistently.
Java was supposed to solve that problem, but Sun screwed that up.

Cookies that simply store a reference to server-maintained state
do violate REST's constraint on state being stored on the client,
rather than the server, for scalability.  The effect of violating
that constraint can be seen on any site that uses client-sessions
on the back-end, such as is common in J2SE.  Such sites are usually
several orders of magnitude less scalable than REST-based
applications, but some folks still prefer it for "personalization".
My experience has been that this is the number one cause of failed
website applications: reliance on server-side sessions.

BTW, "personalization" can be defined as deliberately trading off
scalability for customized content.  The advertising folks who took
over the Web design space in 1996 claimed that this was a necessity,
often making it a core component of third-party "evaluations" of
website usability, but if you actually go and talk to the customers
using those sites you will find that they hate it with a passion.
Amazon is the only site that did it well, and it continues to cost
them a fortune in back-end costs.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3584
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 04:19:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:

> So if I PUT to /foo/bar/xyz, there now exists a resource with that name
> (assuming all goes well).  Does that necessarily imply that there is 
> now
> also a resource named /foo/bar?  That is, if I start with an empty
> hierarchy and no resources, then do a PUT to /foo/bar/xyz, is there
> anything about REST or HTTP that dictates that  I now have three
> resources rather than one?

What is a resource?  What makes you think it didn't exist before the 
PUT?

Yeah, I know that's an annoying answer, but it is quite pointless to be
discussing these things if we aren't even clear on what is a resource.

A resource is a source for *future* responses to future requests.  Thus,
the resource will already exist by virtue of you eventually doing the 
PUT,
and what you are doing with those requests is changing the responses
to future requests.  Whether or not those ancestral names, or any other
names that might have been created by the usual side-effects, are
accessible to future requests (and hence are resources) is defined by
the server and not by the protocol (or even the style).

The server might choose to reject the PUT request simply because it
wants access control to be specified first.  Interoperability is
obtained not by restricting the behavior of the server, but by
requiring that the server respond according to its desires and
enabling the client to understand that response.

One of the keys to understanding how REST works is to understand that
the implementations have no clue what the resource is or how it is
defined or what, in fact, makes it a resource.  That is just too hard
a concept for the implementations to handle.  Even the human beings
maintaining the site have a hard time figuring that one out, because
we just aren't very good at predicting the future.  In contrast,
it is relatively easy to talk about representations, storing them
and mapping them to names that are resources, since those are
operations that manipulate bits in the "now" and are easy for
server mechanisms to understand and implement.

Thus, it is not necessary to know what the fate of /foo/bar/ might
be after a

    PUT /foo/bar/thing

even though we do know what its fate will be after a

    DELETE /foo/

has successfully completed.  Note, however, that the success of the
first request does not imply that the server must allow the second
request.  It may choose to forbid it (for any reason).

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3585
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 05:22:30
Subject:Application Level Errors
Message:

I know this is a dumb question, but I can't figure
it out from reading RFC2616:

If I do a POST and the content of my post is not
what the server expects (e.g. my zip code is
missing), what code should the server return?

The closest things are 409 or 415 but they don't
seem exactly right....

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Post ID:3586
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 06:44:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] DELETE container?
Message:


Roy T. Fielding wrote:

>> So if I PUT to /foo/bar/xyz, there now exists a resource with that name
>> (assuming all goes well).  Does that necessarily imply that there is now
>> also a resource named /foo/bar?  That is, if I start with an empty
>> hierarchy and no resources, then do a PUT to /foo/bar/xyz, is there
>> anything about REST or HTTP that dictates that  I now have three
>> resources rather than one?
>
>
> What is a resource?  What makes you think it didn't exist before the PUT?
>
> Yeah, I know that's an annoying answer, but it is quite pointless to be
> discussing these things if we aren't even clear on what is a resource. 


It's only annoyting because I had to be reminded again that  I have a 
bad habit of thinking that a resource only exists when a mapping 
function for that resource has been implemented and is able to respond 
to a request with something other than the equivalent of a 404.

>
>
> A resource is a source for *future* responses to future requests.  Thus,
> the resource will already exist by virtue of you eventually doing the 
> PUT,
> and what you are doing with those requests is changing the responses
> to future requests.  Whether or not those ancestral names, or any other
> names that might have been created by the usual side-effects, are
> accessible to future requests (and hence are resources) is defined by
> the server and not by the protocol (or even the style).
>
> The server might choose to reject the PUT request simply because it
> wants access control to be specified first.  Interoperability is
> obtained not by restricting the behavior of the server, but by
> requiring that the server respond according to its desires and
> enabling the client to understand that response.
>
> One of the keys to understanding how REST works is to understand that
> the implementations have no clue what the resource is or how it is
> defined or what, in fact, makes it a resource.  That is just too hard
> a concept for the implementations to handle.  Even the human beings
> maintaining the site have a hard time figuring that one out, because
> we just aren't very good at predicting the future.  In contrast,
> it is relatively easy to talk about representations, storing them
> and mapping them to names that are resources, since those are
> operations that manipulate bits in the "now" and are easy for
> server mechanisms to understand and implement.
>
> Thus, it is not necessary to know what the fate of /foo/bar/ might
> be after a
>
>    PUT /foo/bar/thing
>
> even though we do know what its fate will be after a
>
>    DELETE /foo/
>
> has successfully completed.  Note, however, that the success of the
> first request does not imply that the server must allow the second
> request.  It may choose to forbid it (for any reason).



Despite the poor phrasing of my question, I think you've answered the 
question that I intended to ask.  As I understand it, then, neither REST 
nor HTTP dictate the existance of any sort of relationship between 
/foo/bar/thing and /foo/bar/ other than name containment (and that only 
from HTTP).


--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3587
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 09:17:32
Subject:Personalisation and REST (Gedankenexperiment)
Message:

The folks at pointlessvanity.com would like to construct a website which 
personalises each page delivered to the user by including their name in 
small letters at the bottom of each page. They would like to build a 
standards compliant REST system, so user authentication will be done 
with one of the schemes in RFC 2617.

In order to meet the REST visibility requirement, the URI structure will 
include the userid. Although in practice this could be done using CGI 
style parameters, the developers are lazy, so the userid will be 
represented as the top level path component.

Thus

/<userid>/home

is the home page, and

/<userid>/mirroronthewall

is the vanity mirror on the wall page.

This allows the developers to use relative links and thus static pages 
which do not need to contain the userid directly.

As a further access control requirement, users are only alloed to access 
their own pages; thus the <userid> in the URI must match the userid 
given in the HTTP Authorization: header.

So far so good, this seems to not break REST principles.

Pointlessvanity.com would like to publicly adverise some of the URI 
within the site (e.g. the vanity mirror), but they obviously cannot give 
a specific URI since this would only be valid for one user. So they 
would like an intelligent redirector, such that accesses to any page 
within their site with an empty <userid>, will redirect to the 
appropriate page based on the authorisation header.

So, if a client accesses

/mirroronthewall

with a userid of 'Richard' in the Authorization header, the redirector 
would redirect to

/Richard/mirroronthewall

The problem (to me) is this redirector seems to break REST principles, 
due to its use of the non-visible Authorization header to determine 
where to redirect to. Is this the case, or am I misunderstnding REST?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3588
Sender:"sem_antico" <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 10:36:14
Subject:Re: Application Level Errors
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "S. Alexander Jacobson"
<alex@v...> wrote:
> I know this is a dumb question, but I can't figure
> it out from reading RFC2616:
> 
> If I do a POST and the content of my post is not
> what the server expects (e.g. my zip code is
> missing), what code should the server return?
> 
> The closest things are 409 or 415 but they don't
> seem exactly right....
> 

403 Forbidden is probably what you want, unless the representation
POSTed is XML and is not valid against a schema you have defined (to
validate the presence of ZIP codes for example...) In that case then
400 Bad Request might be applicable.

> -Alex-
> 
> 
> ___________________________________________________________________
> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

invalid.

> 400 Bad Request might be applicable.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3590
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 15:07:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

Hi Roy,

On Tue, Apr 15, 2003 at 08:36:00PM -0700, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> > Any application of cookies breaks REST, because they are by definition
> > stateful, and all REST interactions are stateless.  That doesn't mean
> > they don't have their uses, of course.  But there other ways of doing
> > "sessions" statelessly, and doing them statefully is not REST.
> 
> That concept tends to be a little confusing, partly because HTTP,
> like many network protocols, has a notion of stateless interactions
> that only refers to having all of the information needed to
> understand each request inside the request or defined by universal
> standard.  REST goes further and constrains application state
> (not resource state) to be held on the client.

Right.  Correct me if I'm wrong, but I've always assumed that this
additional constraint is a constraint on application semantics.  That
is, that a RESTful application semantic may not punt application
state.  So "LOGIN" wouldn't be a permitted semantic, because even though
a LOGIN message may be semantically self-contained (and uniform even),
it defers the maintenance of some application state (whether you're
authorized or not) to the server.

Is that right?  Does this additional constraint impact anything else?

> The purpose of statelessness is to prevent partial failures and
> allow for substrate independence (e.g., load-balanced gateways
> managing the traffic for many servers).  Cookies don't
> necessarily break that because they are inside the request,
> unless developers make the mistake of defining the cookie such
> that it varies by gateway.

Very good point.

But there's also a problem if the cookie is defined such that the
referenced state varies with time, which I would expect is much more
common than varying by gateway.  A message that references some other
state may be processed at a time when that state is different than it
was when the message was constructed.

I understand that this isn't as relevant to the simple browser/server
interactions of today, but architecturally speaking it seems quite
important, especially as we move towards disconnected and queued
interactions.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3591
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 15:26:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

> > That concept tends to be a little confusing, partly because HTTP,
> > like many network protocols, has a notion of stateless interactions
> > that only refers to having all of the information needed to
> > understand each request inside the request or defined by universal
> > standard.  REST goes further and constrains application state
> > (not resource state) to be held on the client.
> 
> Right.  Correct me if I'm wrong, but I've always assumed that this
> additional constraint is a constraint on application semantics.  That
> is, that a RESTful application semantic may not punt application
> state.  So "LOGIN" wouldn't be a permitted semantic, because even though
> a LOGIN message may be semantically self-contained (and uniform even),
> it defers the maintenance of some application state (whether you're
> authorized or not) to the server.
> 
> Is that right?  Does this additional constraint impact anything else?


After reading carefully, I'm not sure I can discern any additional
constraint in the above.  I'm starting with the assumption that without
"application state" there is no application.  Moving from there, if
each request is self-contained in that the server can interpret it
adding only universal standards, then by process of elimination there
must be some conversational state maintained by the client, because
there's not other place it can be.  And if the client doesn't maintain
that state, then there is no application, just an isolated iteraction.

What am I missing?

--Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3592
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 16:57:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Wed, Apr 16, 2003 at 11:26:03AM -0400, Walden Mathews wrote:
> After reading carefully, I'm not sure I can discern any additional
> constraint in the above.

Consider that a single LOGIN message may be stateless (semantically
self-contained), yet have consequences for the interpretation of the
semantics of subsequent messages.  So while it's true that those
subsequent messages wouldn't be stateless in that case, the interaction
that made that the case, by handing off (right term?) application state,
was stateless.

Subtle, for sure.  But I don't even know that I'm right about how this
additional constraint reveals itself, so there could be more to it than
that.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3593
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-16 18:50:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

>> That concept tends to be a little confusing, partly because HTTP,
>> like many network protocols, has a notion of stateless interactions
>> that only refers to having all of the information needed to
>> understand each request inside the request or defined by universal
>> standard.  REST goes further and constrains application state
>> (not resource state) to be held on the client.
>
> Right.  Correct me if I'm wrong, but I've always assumed that this
> additional constraint is a constraint on application semantics.  That
> is, that a RESTful application semantic may not punt application
> state.  So "LOGIN" wouldn't be a permitted semantic, because even 
> though
> a LOGIN message may be semantically self-contained (and uniform even),
> it defers the maintenance of some application state (whether you're
> authorized or not) to the server.

Well, keep in mind that the actions of PUT and POST also defer the
maintenance of state to the server.  Since we could construct a login
semantic via the PUT of a user-specific resource, with logout being
signified by a DELETE, it would be odd for REST to disallow LOGIN
just on the basis of it being a stateful semantic.  I think it is more
accurate to say that, because user identification must be supplied
with each request subject to authentication, that an action like LOGIN
would only add overhead.

> But there's also a problem if the cookie is defined such that the
> referenced state varies with time, which I would expect is much more
> common than varying by gateway.  A message that references some other
> state may be processed at a time when that state is different than it
> was when the message was constructed.
>
> I understand that this isn't as relevant to the simple browser/server
> interactions of today, but architecturally speaking it seems quite
> important, especially as we move towards disconnected and queued
> interactions.

That same problem applies to resources.  We could attempt to model REST
as a shared-memory-by-message-passing system, but don't because that
model tries to maintain distributed consistency.  REST just says that
there is no consistency -- only representations that indicate state
at some point in the past and an implicit grant of use for some time
into the future.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3594
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-17 03:41:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

Oi, LOGIN was a terrible example.  I didn't think it through.

What I was trying to learn by asking was this; what am I constrained
from doing with the application-state-on-the-client constraint, that I'm
not already constrained from doing by the
all-necessary-info-in-the-message constraint?

Thanks.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3595
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-17 11:30:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

Oh, then we have the same question afterall.

WM

Post ID:3596
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-17 23:50:38
Subject:SD Web Services Report: On Track or Hijacked?
Message:

Here is an email newsletter that I get.

The section "The Future of Web Services: On Track or Hijacked?" on
Web services, is mostly thinly veiled promotion, but had a few
interesting points.

Apparently, they want Web services standards to be more powerful
*and* less complex *and* easier to understand *and* more
interoperable.

I'd say that if that is where you want to get to, then Web services
is not the road you want to start down.

  - Dave

----- Forwarded message from SD Web Services <SDWebServicesReport@...-publisher.com> -----

Subject: SD Web Services Report: On Track or Hijacked?
Date: Thu, 17 Apr 2003 11:45:00 -0700
From: SD Web Services <SDWebServicesReport@...-publisher.com>
To: dkuhlman@...
Errors-To: <tdm-errors.800044018.200915.834842838.008.0.1@...>
X-Topica-Id: <1050605133.svc002.9593.1000830>

WEB SERVICES REPORT
April 2003
BY WARREN KEUFFEL

In This Issue:
>>>Jolt Winners Announced 
>>>The Future of Web Services: On Track or Hijacked?
>>>Hot Links


>>>Jolt Winners Announced

The Jolts! The best products! The lights! The glamor! The music 
was catchy, the patter snappy, the jokes ... well, hey, the best
products! And the Winners Are: 
http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXq58a4E4Veb/
 
 
**************************advertisement***********************
==============================================================
Extend the Life of C/C++ Apps with Web Services
==============================================================
 
Take those indispensable C/C++ applications, add Web services, 
and interoperate with .NET and J2EE. It's easier than you might 
think! Rogue Wave's LEIF: a cost-effective alternative to 
heavyweight middleware or total rewrites. Learn more:

http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXq59a4E4Veb/
==============================================================
**************************************************************

**************************advertisement***********************
==============================================================
Select on Web Services
==============================================================
Select Component Manager streamlines the development, 
management and publication of your Web services. It provides 
configuration management for your WSDL and XLM, change 
notification, deployment design and UDDI publication. 
 
Find out more and download your free demonstration copy today at

http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXq6aa4E4Veb/ 
==============================================================
**************************************************************

>>> The Future of Web Services: On Track or Hijacked?

At SD West 2003, a panel of industry experts called 
for more powerful standards, business-strength solutions and 
interoperability to help Web services grow beyond the "very 
small tip of a very big iceberg."

Classes and panels at Software Development 2003, held last
month in Santa Clara, Calif., provided me with some useful 
insights into the current state of Web services deployment. 
Future newsletters will explore some of the ideas suggested by 
SD instructors, but this month I focus on "The Future of Web 
Services," a panel moderated by Jeff Moad, an editor at eWeek.

Participants included one CEO and three evangelists from vendors
marketing Web services solutions. Joining them was Jeff Barr, 
Web services evangelist from online bookseller Amazon.com. 

Moad kicked off the discussion by asking the panelists to
identify the gaps that remain unfilled in this interim period
before Web services becomes a new way of computing. Simon Phipps,
chief software evangelist from Sun Microsystems, noted that 
it's easy to get the impression that all the technical problems
have been solved, but that, in fact, many remain. The current
technology, as specified by the W3C and other standards 
organizations, is fine for small projects, he went on, but
business-strength solutions are lacking, creating a need for
proprietary products.

David Orchard, BEA's technical director, said that Web services 
lack tested interoperability, and that standards committees need 
to do much more to get important interoperability capabilities,
such as security and transactionality, working satisfactorily.

Barr sees a glass that is half full, and noted that the vendor
representatives' focus on a complete, industrial-strength 
solution--while ultimately necessary and well-intentioned--doesn't
negate the ability to build many solutions today, with existing 
technologies.

Developers have their hands full learning those current techno-
logies, Barr explained. Simply because a new standard is released
doesn't necessarily mean that developers feel a need to adopt it
immediately. He's also concerned that the industry could be 
"over-complicating" Web services with far too many complex and
interrelated specifications.

Mansour Safai, CEO of M7, commented that Web services doesn't 
make old, tough problems disappear. All of the existing challenges,
such as application integration and workflow, remain, regardless
of the technology used to implement a solution. Safai noted that,
at the end of the day, Web services are simply an API with 
different underpinnings than other distributed computing solutions.


**************************advertisement***********************
==================================================================
Microsoft Tech Ed 2003 
June 1-6, Dallas, TX
==================================================================
Realize your potential at Tech Ed 2003, Microsoft's 
premier technical conference. The latest in-depth 
sessions on the entire .NET developer-language family. 
Register by April 25; save $400!

http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXq6ba4E4Veb/
==================================================================
**************************************************************

Focusing on the standards effort, IBM's Mark Colan, lead eBusiness
technical evangelist, asserted that a good Web services road map
is in place. All  that is needed now, he said, is to standardize
the pieces of the map.

Sun's Phipps commented that he felt that developers would respond
best to powerful and simple standards, though he acknowledged the
risk of large companies hijacking the standards process.

Safai emphasized that because enterprises have systems from different
vendors, interoperability is a key requirement. He cautioned that
simply because a standard describes a way for applications to talk
to each other, interoperability does not necessarily result.

Moad then directed the panelists to consider Phipp's contention
that Web services open standards are in danger of being hijacked
by proprietary solutions. BEA's Orchard suggested that, by their
nature, XML, SOAP and WSDL are extensible, and that keeping out
proprietary extensions will prove to be difficult. Phipps added
that there's nothing wrong with companies adding value through
proprietary extensions, as long as the companies clearly label 
them as such.

Turning to language implementations, Moad asked if Web services
will remain language-independent. Sun's Phipps said that everyone
except Microsoft is committed to Java. Although Sun, IBM and BEA
all use Java at the "end-points" of the Web services pipe, and
although there is twice as much Java code as there is XML code,
there is no required connection between the two.

Addressing the $64,000 question, Moad asked the panelists if they
considered Web services a success. Barr said that Amazon is currently
processing millions of calls per day using Web services, and that a
significant amount of business is transacted through the returned 
data. He feels that what Amazon, and others, have accomplished to date
is "just the very small tip of a very big iceberg."

That said, Barr continued, the industry needs to spend more time 
building applications using standards that have had a year or so to
mature and migrate to various toolkits. Working in this "comfort 
zone" produces the most successful application implementations.

Clearly--for Amazon, at least--Web services constitute an important
element of their distributed computing strategy, and in a future
newsletter, we'll revisit what Amazon and others are doing in the 
real world. 


**************************advertisement***********************
==============================================================

==============================================================

http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXr5la4E4Veb/
==============================================================

thanks to a new XMPL Pointer Language (XPointer) Recommendation 
from W3C. The Recommendation includes the XPointer Framework, the
XPointer Element Scheme, and the XPointerXMLnsScheme. Details 
can be found at: 
http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXq6ca4E4Veb/

are available at:
http://click.sd.email-publisher.com/maaa0qJaaXq6da4E4Veb/

multiple options for securing, provisioning, monitoring and managing
Web services-based transactions. More information can be found at:

Post ID:3597
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-18 00:30:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Wednesday, April 16, 2003, at 08:41  PM, Mark Baker wrote:
> Oi, LOGIN was a terrible example.  I didn't think it through.
>
> What I was trying to learn by asking was this; what am I constrained
> from doing with the application-state-on-the-client constraint, that  
> I'm
> not already constrained from doing by the
> all-necessary-info-in-the-message constraint?

Oh, I see what you mean.  If you look back in my dissertation,

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/ 
net_arch_styles.htm#sec_3_4_3
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/ 
rest_arch_style.htm#sec_5_1_3

you will notice that there is only one constraint: communication must
be stateless in nature.  The remainder of the description is simply
explaining the properties induced by that constraint and the effect it
has on architectures based on that style.

In other words, they are just two sides of the same coin.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3598
Sender:"bhaugen32" <bhaugen32@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-19 15:11:29
Subject:Re: REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Roy T. Fielding" 
<fielding@a...> wrote:
> We could attempt to model REST
> as a shared-memory-by-message-passing system, but don't because that
> model tries to maintain distributed consistency.  REST just says 
that
> there is no consistency -- only representations that indicate state
> at some point in the past and an implicit grant of use for some time
> into the future.

What do you think of the attempts of Paul Prescod and others to cast 
state-transition models into RESTful hyperlinked resources?

For example,
http://www.prescod.net/rest/state_transition.html 

For another example, many if not most business dealings require 
explioit agreements between trading partners, which is a form of 
consistency.  

A common business protocol for contracts (of which orders are a 
subtype) is Offer-Acceptance, which we have tried to RESTify several 
times on this list.

One way to do it, I think following Paul's proposals, would be to 
create separate hyperlinked resources for Offer, Response (Acceptance 
or Rejection) and Order.

If the Offer resource exists, and is not already hyperlinked to a 
Response, then the counter-party can post an Acceptance to the Offer 
resource.

If an Acceptance is posted, then an Order resource will be created, 
hyperlinked to the Offer and Acceptance.

Does this kind of interaction seem acceptably RESTful to you?  The 
interpretation of a message is dependent on the state of the resource 
to which it is posted, and to which it refers, in addition to the 
contents of the message itself.  (But nothing else.)

Thanks,
Bob Haugen





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3599
Sender:"S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-21 00:16:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Personalisation and REST (Gedankenexperiment)
Message:

Interesting question.
I'm not clear on the use of redirection from a generic URI to a specific
URI... sounds good & I'll use it when I can, but I don't know how to
describe that URI as a resource.

You may want to look into the Vary response header - this may give the
ability to use the same URI for different representations (e.g. the username
somewhere on the page) and indicate by what request header the
representation varies by.

> due to its use of the non-visible Authorization header to determine
I'm not sure what you mean by 'non-visible'. Visibility means to me the
ability for software to consistently find and use the information, not about
human user visibility... perhaps I misunderstood your statement.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3600
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-21 02:07:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Personalisation and REST (Gedankenexperiment)
Message:

On Wed, Apr 16, 2003 at 10:17:32AM +0100, Richard Padley wrote:
> The problem (to me) is this redirector seems to break REST principles, 
> due to its use of the non-visible Authorization header to determine 
> where to redirect to. Is this the case, or am I misunderstnding REST?

There's a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem, of course, if that's what
you mean; you don't have the Authorization header until after a 401
response has been sent.  But how you outlined that app is exactly how
I'd do it, and I believe it's quite RESTful.

I'd solve the chicken/egg prob by writing up a little app (rather than
using the Web server's auth/redirection capabilities) that returns 401
when accessed without an Authorization header and 302 to /$userid/ when
accessed with one, and then bind that to whatever URI you want to use to
identify the indirect reference (e.g. /mypage).

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3601
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-21 14:55:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

On Tuesday 08 April 2003 02:27, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> The transition to OOP resulted in new programming
> languages specifically designed to support that
> style of programming.  Is anyone working on a
> ReST Oriented Programming Environments?
>

Yes, Waterken Inc. is.

The web-calculus that we discussed a while back isn't just about
providing a security model. The web-calculus is a model for
building a REST interface to an application. I've built a number
of mappings of the web-calculus to local application models. The
one I'm pushing the most at this time is the Waterken RDB Webizer.
See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/

There's a high level overview and a full developer tutorial linked
to from that page.

I am a little late getting to this thread because I was away at
the DOCsec 2003 conference when the thread started. At the
conference, I presented the web-calculus and the Waterken RDB
Webizer. The response was very enthusiastic. A number of people
found the union of REST and capability-based security to be a very
compelling model. This is especially interesting since DOCsec is
an OMG sponsored conference. Most of the attendees are still
committed to CORBA technology and find REST a foreign concept.

The DOCsec 2003 conference home page is:

http://www.omg.org/news/meetings/docsec2003/index.htm

My presentation slides are at:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/DOCsec2003/

Building a REST programming environment for relational databases
is a very interesting first case. Since SQL doesn't come with any
procedural programming baggage, it's possible to build a
programming environment in which the entire application is built
in the REST mindset. You can build the entire application by just
defining the resource web, never being forced to switch gears and
write procedural code.

If anyone on the list would like to use the Waterken RDB Webizer
on a current project, I would be willing to provide a free license
in exchange for a product testimonial.

Tyler

world of web servers and web browsers.

Post ID:3603
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 02:42:39
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

On Tue, Apr 22, 2003 at 07:29:03AM +1200, Berend de Boer wrote:
> >>>>> "Roy" == Roy T Fielding <fielding@...> writes:
> 
>     Roy> you will notice that there is only one constraint:
>     Roy> communication must be stateless in nature.  
> 
> It is too bad that the theoretic ideals don't map easily to the real
> world of web servers and web browsers.

That's the point, really.  Where the mapping is problematic, it's not a
failing of REST, it's it working as planned; it tells you that your app
probably has issues, and what they may be.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis

Post ID:3604
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 03:18:53
Subject:REST can do it all? (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies)
Message:

From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>
> On Tue, Apr 22, 2003 at 07:29:03AM +1200, Berend de Boer wrote:
> > >>>>> "Roy" == Roy T Fielding <fielding@...> writes:
> >
> >     Roy> you will notice that there is only one constraint:
> >     Roy> communication must be stateless in nature.
> >
> > It is too bad that the theoretic ideals don't map easily to the real
> > world of web servers and web browsers.
>
> That's the point, really.  Where the mapping is problematic, it's not a
> failing of REST, it's it working as planned; it tells you that your app
> probably has issues, and what they may be.

Hmm... this would imply to me that any application can be done RESTfully if
refactored enough.  First, is this true?  Second, is this always ideal?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3605
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 03:50:28
Subject:Re: REST can do it all? (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies)
Message:

On Mon, Apr 21, 2003 at 11:18:53PM -0400, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> > That's the point, really.  Where the mapping is problematic, it's not a
> > failing of REST, it's it working as planned; it tells you that your app
> > probably has issues, and what they may be.
> 
> Hmm... this would imply to me that any application can be done RESTfully if
> refactored enough.  First, is this true?

Sure, but that's not REST-specific.

>  Second, is this always ideal?

Of course not.

IMO, REST is the best available description of a "good Web app".  My
response above was just saying that if you're building a Web app, and it
isn't RESTful, that REST tells you what problems to expect (e.g.
cookies = less visibility and application state issues (i.e. back
button problems)).  That's not making a value judgement on whether or
not your app should or shouldn't be RESTful, it's just saying that if it
isn't, there's a downside.  There may very well be an upside to not
being RESTful for some Web apps.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3606
Sender:Kaleem Aziz <kaleemaziz@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-21 19:40:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

I think the stuff you provided is exciting. I had a comment only about this:http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/Tour/xml_files.html I try to tell folks not to implement Web Services to open up their database ... opens up can of worms from security perspective. It allows hackers just the open door access to steal us. I agree it may work as an example, but please correct me if this is indeed used or supposed to be used in real world scenarios. As discussed earlier on service-oriented-architecture@yahoogroups.com, there are bound to be lots of wrong implementations with SOA (just like we see lots of ill-developed HTML websites, there are bound to be lots of ill-developed XML websites). I was a proponent of the discussion that database must not be opened as in the UI above. I'd like to hear thoughts. (Just want to generate a learning experience. I could be more wrong than I think.)

Tyler Close <tyler@...> wrote:On Tuesday 08 April 2003 02:27, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

> languages specifically designed to support that

webapps can't be done with REST because it's a requirement that there
be no session.

Post ID:3608
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 08:30:51
Subject:Re: REST can do it all? (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies)

Nic Ferrier wrote:
> "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...> writes:

>  > From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>

>  >
>  > Hmm... this would imply to me that any application can be done 
> RESTfully if
>  > refactored enough.  First, is this true?  Second, is this always ideal?
> 
> If we're talking about using no non-REST ideas then no. Session based
> webapps can't be done with REST because it's a requirement that there
> be no session.
> 

I don't think thats quite right; REST does not prohibit sessions, the 
constraint is that the HTTP protocol is stateless. As long as your 
sessions are _visible_ (i.e. probably manifest as a resource on the 
server) then sessions and REST can be compatable.

Having said this sessions are often a lazy way of web app programming 
where information is stuffed into an (invisible) session instead of 
carried around in the URI - visibility again.

> 
> Nic
> 
> 
> *Yahoo! Groups Sponsor*
> 
> <http://rd.yahoo.com/M=247865.3003379.4507215.1728375/D=egroupweb/S=1705701014:HM/A=1482387/R=0/*http://ads.x10.com/?bHlhaG9vaG0xLmRhd=1050996884%3eM=247865.3003379.4507215.1728375/D=egroupweb/S=1705701014:HM/A=1482387/R=1=1050996884%3eM=247865.3003379.4507215.1728375/D=egroupweb/S=1705701014:HM/A=1482387/R=2>
> 
> 
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> 
> 
> 
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service 
> <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3609
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 08:41:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Personalisation and REST (Gedankenexperiment)
Message:

S. Mike Dierken wrote:
> Interesting question.
> I'm not clear on the use of redirection from a generic URI to a specific
> URI... sounds good & I'll use it when I can, but I don't know how to
> describe that URI as a resource.
> 
> You may want to look into the Vary response header - this may give the
> ability to use the same URI for different representations (e.g. the username
> somewhere on the page) and indicate by what request header the
> representation varies by.

Aha, very interesting. From RFC 2616 it seems that I can use the 
Authorisation header to determine the respresentation - and I can 
indicate this clearly with the Vary header. Therefore this information 
does not need to go into the URI. Does this not decrease visibility somehow?

> 
>  > due to its use of the non-visible Authorization header to determine
> I'm not sure what you mean by 'non-visible'. Visibility means to me the
> ability for software to consistently find and use the information, not about
> human user visibility... perhaps I misunderstood your statement.

Point taken - I was being too literal with visibility.

> 
> *Yahoo! Groups Sponsor*
> <http://rd.yahoo.com/M=250099.3088638.4504503.1728375/D=egroupweb/S=1705701014:HM/A=1546002/R=0/*http://ads.track-star.com/linker.ts?ts=1;2;315;15_1_48> 
> 
> 
>

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>

> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service 
> <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3610
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 09:13:47
Subject:Re: REST can do it all? (was Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies)
Message:

Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...> writes:

> Nic Ferrier wrote:
> > If we're talking about using no non-REST ideas then no. Session based
> > webapps can't be done with REST because it's a requirement that there
> > be no session.
> 
> I don't think thats quite right; REST does not prohibit sessions, the
> constraint is that the HTTP protocol is stateless. As long as your
> sessions are _visible_ (i.e. probably manifest as a resource on the
> server) then sessions and REST can be compatable.
> 
> Having said this sessions are often a lazy way of web app programming
> where information is stuffed into an (invisible) session instead of
> carried around in the URI - visibility again.

I agree that REST is the best way of building webapps. But session
based webapps are sometimes necessary because of user requirements
and REST does not strictly handle those.

However, cookies can be put in on top of a REST architecture without
complicating it too much. Roy is right that they're evil but user now
sometimes expect them unfortunately.

I've just finished building an app for a user that had one of these
odd requirements. It's a legal information app, users buy access and
get an account. The accounts aren't necessarily unique to a user (an
organisation might buy the right to login 10 times). My client has a
very confused idea of what authentication is, but they have legacy
business reasons for it, so I can't change it.

The requirement that really breaks REST is that the user's can store
altered forms of the documents in the system but those documents are
only visible to them. These documents are in XML on a SQL database so
we have a session based user document table. In effect the session
lasts a long time, but it's still a session.

Without embedding the user id in a url (strictly, against REST as
well) I can't see how I would have done this without cookies.


Having said that, the rest (scuse the pun) of the app is REST based
and works pretty well. At the end of the day the cookie stuff is
really only an interaction between the client and the stored procs in
the database.


I think you can state categorically that REST cannot handle
personalization because user id urls are frowned on and cookies are
disliked. How else to maintain the personalization state?

Roy says that personalization applications aren't worth
much and I broadly agree, but some are and we can't always convince
our clients that they don't need personalization.


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3611
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 11:26:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST, HTTP, Sessions and Cookies
Message:

It's the Principle of Beneficint Difficulty at work, as
Michael Jackson would say.

WM

> >     Roy> you will notice that there is only one constraint:
> >     Roy> communication must be stateless in nature.
> >
> > It is too bad that the theoretic ideals don't map easily to the real
> > world of web servers and web browsers.
>
> That's the point, really.  Where the mapping is problematic, it's not a
> failing of REST, it's it working as planned; it tells you that your app
> probably has issues, and what they may be.
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3612
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 13:04:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

On Monday 21 April 2003 15:40, Kaleem Aziz wrote:
> I think the stuff you provided is exciting.

Thanks.

> I had a comment only about
> this:http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/Tour/xml_files.html I try to tell
> folks not to implement Web Services to open up their database ...

I don't understand what you mean here. Obviously, there has to be
some sort of information flow between the people and software that
use the information and the database that stores the information.

> opens up can of worms from security perspective.

Yes, it does, but it's not a can of worms that you can avoid.
There are security issues whenever you build software. This
reality is what makes having a robust security model so important.
The web-calculus was built starting from a security model:
capability-based security. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/

> It allows hackers just the open door access to steal us.

This all depends on how good your application security is. If you
build your application without any kind of security model, as
current web services are, you are indeed building an open door.

The main reason the web-calculus is so interesting is that it was
built starting from a security model.

> I agree it may work as an example, but please correct me if this
> is indeed used or supposed to be used in real world scenarios.

The Waterken RDB Webizer tutorial shows how the tool is meant to
be used in real world scenarios. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/Tutorial/

> As discussed earlier on
> service-oriented-architecture@yahoogroups.com, there are bound to be lots
> of wrong implementations with SOA (just like we see lots of ill-developed
> HTML websites, there are bound to be lots of ill-developed XML websites).

A great deal of the design effort that went into building the
Waterken RDB Webizer was focused on reducing the likelihood of
such errors. The tool is designed such that the way developers
naturally use it encourages the construction of secure and
auditable software. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Methodology/

> I was a proponent of the discussion that database must not be
> opened as in the UI above. I'd like to hear thoughts.

Can you link to the specific email, or summarize your argument
again here?

> (Just want to generate a learning experience. I could be more
> wrong than I think.)

Great, that's what a good mailing list is for.

Tyler

Post ID:3614
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-22 20:19:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

On Tuesday 22 April 2003 16:19, kaleemaziz wrote:

> query/update from browser without "https" over an open channel.
>
> ...
>
> This security model is based on "http" and doesn't require "https"?
> Please clarify, because this is where I think my confusion is.

Ah. The screenshot you point out should indeed be using an https
connection. I'll replace the screenshot. When a capability is
passed between computers, an encrypted and server authenticated
channel MUST be used.

The preceding Tour page shows a correct capability URL. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/Tour/caps.html

Thanks for pointing out the screenshot error.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3615
Sender:Dave Kuhlman <dkuhlman@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 00:02:27
Subject:Python support for Amazon Web services
Message:

I've developed a small amount of Python support for the
XML-over-HTTP mode of Amazon Web services.  Amazon describes this
as their REST mode.

The support I've developed consists mostly consists of Python code
that helps to parse and process the Amazon WS XML documents.

Also, to produce this support I used generateDS.py (see:
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/#generateDS). Therefore, I needed
XML Schema documents.  So, being a Calvinist [1], I decided
implement generateXsd.py, which extracts an XML Schema from an XML
instance document.  It's included in the distribution.

There is a document describing this support at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/amazon_ws_support.html

And the distribution file is at:

    http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman/amazon_ws_support-1.0.tar.gz

The Amazon WS developer's kit is available at:

    http://www.amazon.com/webservices

  - Dave

[1] Calvin and Hobbes, the comic strip --  Once, when Calvin's Mom
tried to force him to clean up his room, Calvin decided to invent a
robot to do the work.  After much struggle, Hobbes asked him:
"Wouldn't it be less work to just clean your room yourself?" Calvin
replied, without looking up: "It's only work if they make you do
it."

-- 
Dave Kuhlman
dkuhlman@...
http://www.rexx.com/~dkuhlman





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3616
Sender:"bhaugen32" <bhaugen32@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 11:42:04
Subject:Re: ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Tyler Close <tyler@w...> wrote:
> When a capability is
> passed between computers, an encrypted and server authenticated
> channel MUST be used.

Ok, good, that answers one important question.  Here are some others, 
don't know yet if they are important or not - just trying to get my 
mind around capabilities + REST.

* How do capabilities and hyperlinks go together?  Does a tension 
arise between them?  E.g. wouldn't a capability container resource 
necessarily give you capabilities for all of the contained resources? 
What about navigating networks (graphs) of hyperlinks?

* Do capabilities and digital signatures (e.g. for non-repudiation) 
go together?  I don't see why not.  If I understand correctly, access 
is not dependent on your identity (only that you possess the 
capability URI).  But your identity is still significant in other 
ways.

* Has anybody used capabilities and access control lists based on 
identity together?  Do you think that is a bad idea, or useful in 
some situations?  Which situations?

* Open-ended, sorry:  what are the disadvantages of capability URIs?

Thanks, interesting stuff,
Bob Haugen





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3617
Sender:Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 12:46:12
Subject:Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

Hi. I've been following this REST vs. "document style" SOAP
debate (I assume RPC style is dead on both sides), and I'm
starting to think one of the advantages of REST is that you
can actually create a hybrid web service that both human and
machine can handle.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe this is difficult with
SOAP (even with document-style one) unless it gets fully
RESTified and utilizes URI to locate every resource/service.

For example, while I was attending Amazon BOF held at O'Reilly
ETech conf, I was playing with the idea of browser extension
that keep track of books I have shown interest (i.e. clicked or
browsed). Okay, I'm not sure how useful is that, but the point is
that embedded, machine-processible REST interface (probably
using XHTML+XML?) can be used not only for browsing, but to
seamlessly enhance my ability to explore information. This is
difficult if "for-human" WS and "for-machine" WS are separate
things.

Can anyone here verify me, or am I missing something?

--
Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division
