-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3619
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 14:58:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: ROPE: ReST Oriented Programming Environments
Message:

On Wednesday 23 April 2003 07:42, bhaugen32 wrote:
> Here are some others,
> don't know yet if they are important or not - just trying to get my
> mind around capabilities + REST.

I am happy to help.

> * How do capabilities and hyperlinks go together?  Does a tension
> arise between them?

Capabilities and hyperlinks go together like peas in a pod. The
action of clicking a hyperlink on a previously received page, to
get another page, is exactly the style of interaction that use of
capabilities is modelled on.

As a simple example of this, consider the Accountant resource at:

https://www.waterken.com/coffeebreak/6gjz7l6fnoxlbikw7akqgxhrsy.html

(Note: www.waterken.com is using a self-signed certificate with
SHA1 fingerprint:
28:B5:86:C5:76:AE:9F:9D:DA:1D:8F:32:3B:1A:E5:FF:B2:AF:1B:F3)

> E.g. wouldn't a capability container resource
> necessarily give you capabilities for all of the contained resources?

Yes, as is demonstrated in the example above. Typically, I don't
think of this in terms of containers, but in terms of what
resources are reachable from a given resource.

> What about navigating networks (graphs) of hyperlinks?

The graph of hyperlinks is how your define your application's
security policy. At runtime, users traverse the graph, or
resource web, that is your application. In this way, the graph
simultaneously defines and enforces your access policy.

> * Do capabilities and digital signatures (e.g. for non-repudiation)
> go together?  I don't see why not.  If I understand correctly,
> access is not dependent on your identity (only that you possess
> the capability URI).

Capabilities and digital signatures do not typically go together.
You nailed it with your first guess: capabilities are not identity
based, whereas digital signatures are.  Use of a digital signature
implicitly means that your security model is identity-based, ie:
the signature is done by some principal.

There are simple capability graph patterns that can be used to
solve most problems that people use digital signatures for.
Non-repudiation is not one of these. The crux of non-repudiation
based on a digital signature is that the client possesses a
private key that no one else does. Capabilities themselves do not
provide a similar cryptographic primitive.

That said, I doubt the value of digital signature based
non-repudiation. I very much doubt it is something you could take
to court, and if you can't, what's the point. Unless you are also
going to deploy a new legal court system, digital signatures don't
make much sense.

> But your identity is still significant in other ways.

Actually, when you get right down to specific scenarios, identity
is more of a problem than a requirement. Using an identity-based
security model opens you up to the Confused Deputy attack. See:

http://www.cap-lore.com/CapTheory/ConfusedDeputy.html

> * Has anybody used capabilities and access control lists based on
> identity together?

I think Agorics Inc. implemented an MLS system on top of KeyKOS, a
capability-based operating system. They did this solely to satisfy
the demands of a government contract.

> Do you think that is a bad idea, or useful in
> some situations?  Which situations?

People always seem to want to pile security devices on top of each
other, but in this case, it doesn't make much sense.

> * Open-ended, sorry:  what are the disadvantages of capability URIs?

The main problem with capabilities is one of perception rather
than fact. In the capability model, it is only possible to express
security policies that are actually enforceable. In contrast, the
ACL security model allows, even encourages, expression of security
policies that are not actually enforceable. As a result, people
often happily accept the false promises of an ACL and are annoyed
that the capability model won't tell them similarly comforting
lies.

We went through an example of this during the last discussion of
capabilities on this list. See the thread root at:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/3456

> Thanks, interesting stuff,

Thanks. I look forward to continuing this discussion.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3620
Sender:Kaleem Aziz <kaleemaziz@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 18:45:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

For clarity my reply is inline.

Taisuke Yamada <tai@...> wrote:

Hi. I've been following this REST vs. "document style" SOAP
debate (I assume RPC style is dead on both sides), and I'm
starting to think one of the advantages of REST is that you
can actually create a hybrid web service that both human and
machine can handle.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe this is difficult with
SOAP (even with document-style one) unless it gets fully
RESTified and utilizes URI to locate every resource/service.

For example, while I was attending Amazon BOF held at O'Reilly
ETech conf, I was playing with the idea of browser extension
that keep track of books I have shown interest (i.e. clicked or
browsed). Okay, I'm not sure how useful is that, but the point is
that embedded, machine-processible REST interface (probably
using XHTML+XML?) can be used not only for browsing, but to
seamlessly enhance my ability to explore information. 

This is
difficult if "for-human" WS and "for-machine" WS are separate
things.


<MKA>

Here's a partial answer of the partial question I understood. Tell me if that's not the question.

"for person" WS is similar to B2C (business to consumer). The promise of WS to B2C may come much more in future, because of (1) smaller market segmet, (2) lower utility, and (3) lack of clarity in what it could solve in reality (remember, WS is not fully evolved).

"for machine" WS is similar to EDI, EAI or B2B (automated or semi-automated to a large extent). The current era we are living in WS (REST vs SOAP), I think, is about this mechanization of internet (aka, Internet ver 2.0).

So, yes, B2C and B2B are two different needs with two different set of requirements, objectives, concentrations and technological infrastructure. Having saturated B2B solutions in the 3 phases (viz, ROI, Strategy & Expansion phases of WS implementations); may be someday we will step in B2C WS (where your refrigerator orders milk automatically, when it is low on supply?).

I'd like to hear other thoughts/comments/disagreements.

</MKA>


Can anyone here verify me, or am I missing something?

--
Taisuke Yamada 
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division


To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com



Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ 




Take care.
Kaleem. 
"Great minds discuss ideas; lesser minds discuss events; small minds discuss persons."

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3621
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 20:05:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

>>>>> "Taisuke" == Taisuke Yamada <tai@...> writes:

    Taisuke> Hi. I've been following this REST vs. "document style"
    Taisuke> SOAP debate (I assume RPC style is dead on both sides),
    Taisuke> and I'm starting to think one of the advantages of REST
    Taisuke> is that you can actually create a hybrid web service that
    Taisuke> both human and machine can handle.

1. RPC is not dead, REST and SOAP are forms of RPC. 

2. REST is about server holds state is stateless, with SOAP you can do
   that, but its not a dogma.

3. So REST versus SOAP is a meaningless distinction.

4. REST is about resources that you can access by an URI. No
   implication that it is better or easier human or machine readable.


-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3622
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 21:03:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

Berend de Boer <berend@...> writes:

> 4. REST is about resources that you can access by an URI. No
>    implication that it is better or easier human or machine readable.

Yes there is. SOAP is encapsulating it's own protocol in HTTP
messages. REST is just using HTTP messages.


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3623
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 21:30:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

>     Taisuke> Hi. I've been following this REST vs. "document style"
>     Taisuke> SOAP debate (I assume RPC style is dead on both sides),
>     Taisuke> and I'm starting to think one of the advantages of REST
>     Taisuke> is that you can actually create a hybrid web service that
>     Taisuke> both human and machine can handle.
>
> 1. RPC is not dead, REST and SOAP are forms of RPC.

He said "document style" SOAP, which is a reference to the interaction
style described in the SOAP 1.2 specs.  SOAP 1.1 is RPC.  SOAP 1.2 is
a bunch of things.  REST is not a form of RPC.

> 2. REST is about server holds state is stateless, with SOAP you can do
>    that, but its not a dogma.

REST is an architectural style that is only present when all of its
constraints are met.  SOAP is a protocol.

> 3. So REST versus SOAP is a meaningless distinction.

Yes, but he wasn't talking about SOAP.  He was talking about one of
the interaction styles described by the SOAP specifications.

> 4. REST is about resources that you can access by an URI. No
>    implication that it is better or easier human or machine readable.

Having the URI makes it possible for both human and machine-driven
interaction.  He is right -- that is one of the advantages of REST-style
applications, and it is used every day in the form of bookmarks.
However, the document-style interactions in SOAP 1.2 do allow for
the server to provide a URI, so the advantage only exists over those
SOAP 1.2 resources that are poorly implemented (i.e., all of them).

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3624
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 21:46:13
Subject:Talking about REST
Message:

I have just given a talk about REST to the other techies at my
current client (including the man in charge of development). The
audience was of mixed ability, from old time hackers to complete
newbies in web development.

Here is a very short summary of audience reaction and my thoughts
about it. I hope it's useful.


The reaction of most was to question whether I was talking about
anything clever, to question the validity of REST because of it's
simplicity. The more experience programmers (who have topyed with
SOAP and XMLRPC) were more enthusisatic.


It's clear that many people don't really understand HTTP. REST
evangelists need to do more to explain HTTP to people.


I expected some confusion and incredulity about the stuff about
sessions and I got some. Again, the more experienced were more
inclined to listen to the REST p-o-v. But the prevaliing view about
sessions was "go tell the marketing dept" because this company does
quite a lot of personalization based on cookies.


So, in summary, the talk was pretty succesful. My only doubt is how
much I should push the sessions issue. I'm still not clear myself
about that.



Nic Ferrier





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3625
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 22:40:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

>>>>> "Roy" == Roy T Fielding <fielding@...> writes:

    >> 3. So REST versus SOAP is a meaningless distinction.

    Roy> Yes, but he wasn't talking about SOAP.  He was talking about
    Roy> one of the interaction styles described by the SOAP
    Roy> specifications.

I really didn't understand it then. If I read "interaction style", I
suppose you refer to Request-Response, Solicit-Response stuff?? Was
already present in SOAP 1.1.

Throwing document in the mix, I understood this as the RPC versus
Document style of message exchange, the particular format of the body
of a SOAP message. I.e. the style attribute in an WSDL <soap:binding>
with values "rpc" or "document".

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:

Post ID:3626
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-23 22:42:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

>>>>> "Nic" == Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...> writes:

    Nic> Berend de Boer <berend@...> writes:
    >> 4. REST is about resources that you can access by an URI. No
    >> implication that it is better or easier human or machine
    >> readable.

    Nic> Yes there is. SOAP is encapsulating it's own protocol in HTTP
    Nic> messages. REST is just using HTTP messages.

Is it easier for a machine to extract information from tag soup or
from a SOAP response?

--

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3627
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-24 04:16:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Berend de Boer" <berend@...>
>
> 1. RPC is not dead, REST and SOAP are forms of RPC.
Although a system based on REST may use RPC to accomplish the job, REST is
different from RPC in that it is not an 'extensible procedures' type of
approach. In fact, it is the opposite - 'limited set of procedures' is the
goal.

>
> 2. REST is about server holds state is stateless, with SOAP you can do
>    that, but its not a dogma.
I'm not sure I understand the grammar of the sentence, but REST isn't about
one side or the other 'holding' state - its about the transfer of whatever
state you do have between the components.

>
> 3. So REST versus SOAP is a meaningless distinction.
REST is architecture, SOAP is technology. You can build REST based systems
with SOAP. But if everybody builds their own unique (non-interoperable) REST
based system, then that aggregate larger system becomes unRESTful.

>
> 4. REST is about resources that you can access by an URI. No
>    implication that it is better or easier human or machine readable.
REST is about resources you can identify. Using a URI is the Web way of
doing things. An RDBMS has another way of identifying resources that does
not use URI (to the extent that an RDBMS has aspects of REST). A particular
implementation system would use a protocol to actually access the resource.
For example, HTTP as a protocol can be used to access resources that are not
identified via the 'http' URI scheme.

----example request----
GET mailto:mdierken@... HTTP/1.1
User-Agent: ThoughtExperiment1.0
Accept: text/xml
Authorization: BASIC Y7HUH876=


----example response----
200 OK
Content-Type: text/xml
Content-Length: nnnn

<folder name='inbox'>
<item name='msg_001' href='some long uri' />
<item name='msg_002' href='another long uri' />
<folder name='work messages' href='relative uri' />
</folder>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3628
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-24 04:35:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Talking about REST
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>

>
> It's clear that many people don't really understand HTTP.
This is truly an understatement. Even when explained, it takes some
implementation practice for people to really trust that it really is that
easy & that it really can do a lot.

Here are some books to look at:

<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1565925092/topiczero-20/>
HTTP: The Definitive Guide (Price:   $31.47US)
by David Gourley, Brian Totty
Behind every web transaction lies the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)-the
language of web browsers and servers, of portals and search engines, of
e-commerce and web services. Understanding HTTP is essential for practically
all web-based programming, design, analysis, and administration.

<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1565928628/topiczero-20>
HTTP Pocket Reference (Price:  $9.95US)
by Clinton Wong
All web programmers, administrators, and application developers need to be
familiar with HTTP in order to work effectively. The HTTP Pocket Reference
provides a solid conceptual foundation of HTTP, and also serves as a quick
reference to each of the headers and status codes that compose an HTTP
transaction. For those who need to get "beyond the browser," this book is
the place to start.

<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0471398233/topiczero-20/>
HTTP Essentials (Price:   $24.49US)
by Stephen A. Thomas
This guide explains the protocol that defines how Web browsers communicate
with Web servers, the mechanisms that keep that communication secure, and
techniques for accelerating HTTP. Topics include the structure and format of
HTTP messages; security technologies such as SSL, TLS, and SHTTP; and how to
handle compatibility between HTTP versions. Coverage extends to related
technologies such as Proxy Auto Configuration (PAC), Web Proxy Auto
Discovery (WPAD), Web Cache Coordination Protocol (WCCP), Internet Cache
Protocol (ICP) and Hypertext Caching Protocol (HTCP).





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3629
Sender:Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-25 04:01:59
Subject:Re: Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

>> Hi. I've been following this REST vs. "document style" SOAP
>> debate (I assume RPC style is dead on both sides), and I'm
>> starting to think one of the advantages of REST is that you can
>> actually create a hybrid web service that both human and machine
>> can handle.
>> [snip]
>
> Here's a partial answer of the partial question I understood. Tell
> me if that's not the question.

Well, it was more of an thought experiment on how to support
user's information activity by utilizing "for machine" WS, so
I did not have specific model like B2C or B2B in my mind.

I'm using the word "for-human WS" as the current Web as it is
today, and "for-machine WS" as an upcoming part of the Web
where machines can do information processing. And I came to
think that hybrid, complementary use of these two will result
in a synergy that brings better web experience. And from this
point of view, RESTfullness of a service does seems to matter,
because in this case, "for machine" WS is actually part of
existing "for human" WS infrastructure (which is, RESTful).

> "for person" WS is similar to B2C (business to consumer). The
>  promise of WS to B2C may come much more in future, because of (1)
>  smaller market segmet, (2) lower utility, and (3) lack of clarity in
>  what it could solve in reality (remember, WS is not fully evolved).
>
>  "for machine" WS is similar to EDI, EAI or B2B (automated or
>  semi-automated to a large extent). The current era we are living in
>  WS (REST vs SOAP), I think, is about this mechanization of internet
>  (aka, Internet ver 2.0).

Yes, I agree current WS activity focuses more on B2B-like environment.
In such environment, machine-to-machine interoperation is the top
priority, and humans are usually not in the scope of the problem.

However, I disagree that human/machine hybrid style B2C (I'm not
sure if this is anything that we call B2C) has a lower utility.
Human is the ultimate target of productivity improvement, and so
IMHO this is not anything less useful than B2B thing. But yes, it's
probably true that it has smaller market in capitalization value.

-- 
Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3630
Sender:Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-25 04:14:31
Subject:Re: Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

>> 1. RPC is not dead, REST and SOAP are forms of RPC.
>
> Although a system based on REST may use RPC to accomplish the job, REST is
> different from RPC in that it is not an 'extensible procedures' type of
> approach. In fact, it is the opposite - 'limited set of procedures' is the
> goal.

I guess you could also say that REST's "uniform interface" is a
variation of RPC that it has lost "all hairs" because every REST
object is the same thing from RPC point of view. Is is still RPC
even if you have lost traditional RPC way of "differentiating" one
service from another?

--
Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division

Post ID:3631
Sender:Kaleem Aziz <kaleemaziz@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-25 05:06:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

Thoughts inline at places where I had an opinion ...

Taisuke Yamada <tai@...> wrote:

>> Hi. I've been following this REST vs. "document style" SOAP
>> debate (I assume RPC style is dead on both sides), and I'm
>> starting to think one of the advantages of REST is that you can
>> actually create a hybrid web service that both human and machine
>> can handle.
>> [snip]
>
> Here's a partial answer of the partial question I understood. Tell
> me if that's not the question.

Well, it was more of an thought experiment on how to support
user's information activity by utilizing "for machine" WS, so
I did not have specific model like B2C or B2B in my mind.

I'm using the word "for-human WS" as the current Web as it is
today, and "for-machine WS" as an upcoming part of the Web
where machines can do information processing. And I came to
think that hybrid, complementary use of these two will result
in a synergy that brings better web experience. And from this
point of view, RESTfullness of a service does seems to matter,
because in this case, "for machine" WS is actually part of
existing "for human" WS infrastructure (which is, RESTful).


<MKA>

UI vs Server Side distinction is probably what you are refering to? To that I think everything should be attempted to be automated to the extent that you need a user decision or input. User, IMHO, slows the computers down more than any other thing ... but on the flip side, computers of today cannot decide in adhoc ways like we do (no matter how hybrid). So, computers slow down humans too in that way?! :)

</MKA>


> "for person" WS is similar to B2C (business to consumer). The
> promise of WS to B2C may come much more in future, because of (1)
> smaller market segmet, (2) lower utility, and (3) lack of clarity in
> what it could solve in reality (remember, WS is not fully evolved).
>
> "for machine" WS is similar to EDI, EAI or B2B (automated or
> semi-automated to a large extent). The current era we are living in
> WS (REST vs SOAP), I think, is about this mechanization of internet
> (aka, Internet ver 2.0).

Yes, I agree current WS activity focuses more on B2B-like environment.
In such environment, machine-to-machine interoperation is the top
priority, and humans are usually not in the scope of the problem.

However, I disagree that human/machine hybrid style B2C (I'm not
sure if this is anything that we call B2C) has a lower utility.
Human is the ultimate target of productivity improvement, and so
IMHO this is not anything less useful than B2B thing. But yes, it's
probably true that it has smaller market in capitalization value.


<MKA>

Lower utility or not is economics of it (hardwork that can be traded). I think you are considering market capital and human utility as two different things; but I think they are not. They are related too closely.

Businesses exist for human need, but the distinction between prioritizing B2C vs B2B is that more impact can be made for the same human society at this time by B2B rather than B2C. 

(If not for economics based priorities, I think, people would breaking rocks in search of milk, and justifying their hardwork as very useful. Where we should put our efforts first and when is beyond technology alone to decide -- unless technology is for art and not for practical solutions.)

</MKA>
-- 
Taisuke Yamada 
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division

Post ID:3632
Sender:"Mailinglisten" <tbayerml@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-28 12:56:39
Subject:Handling big resources
Message:

Hi,

I've a REST interface for relational databases. A GET message to (table)
resource produces the following list:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<resources xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
    <resource
xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/0/">0</resource>
    <resource
xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/1/">1</resource>
    <resource
xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/2/">2</resource>
    <resource
xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/3/">3</resource>
    ...
    <resource
xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/600000/">600000</resource
>
</resource>

The list is to big to send it in one chunk. It would be better to breakt it
in smaller pieces.


Questions:

1.) Can the server send the response with a 206 Partial Content SC, even the
client hasn't requested a range?

2.) That is the RESTian way for the server, to give the client a hint where
or how he can request the next chunk?
    a.) A reference in the XML Content like <resources
xlink:href="http://...
    b.) A Location Header field with the URL of the next Chunk
    c.) A Content-Range header field in the form:

        Content-Range: resources start-end / total

    d.) Both? A link in the XML Content and information in the header?

3.) Only the type "bytes" are mentioned in the HTTP specification. Can I use
a own type like resources or are there any proposals for REST?

4.) Are there a more REST like approach?

Thanx,
Thomas





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3633
Sender:"softtouchit" <softtouchit@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-30 05:02:58
Subject:What is good about SOAP?
Message:

The more I look at SOAP, the less sense I can make out of it.  First
of all, it appears to be nice little RPC but then everyone agrees that
RPC is dead for Web Services. People then argue that SOAP is good
because it serves as an envelope and the processing patterns
associated are useful. Well, it appears that even HTTP headers can do
better jobs. 

I really like to hear your comments on this.

Hao





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3634
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-30 02:24:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

This is a strange debate.
REST is a web service architecture (style) not a human interface guideline 
(AFAIK).

REST is the back end for web sites or client side apps that expose user 
interfaces.

Notably, Amazon and Google expose web services distinct from their user 
interfaces.

Writing programs that talk to human interfaces strikes me as risky.

-Alex-





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3637
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-30 19:52:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] What is good about SOAP?
Message:

On Wed, Apr 30, 2003 at 05:02:58AM -0000, softtouchit wrote:
> The more I look at SOAP, the less sense I can make out of it.  First
> of all, it appears to be nice little RPC but then everyone agrees that
> RPC is dead for Web Services.

To clarify, what most Web services folks mean by "RPC" is fine grained
invocations, like getStockQuote() returning "14.25".

What I mean by "RPC" (and I think many on rest-discuss do too) is where
developers get to define the remote "API", rather than having it
provided for them by the application protocol.

> People then argue that SOAP is good
> because it serves as an envelope and the processing patterns
> associated are useful. Well, it appears that even HTTP headers can do
> better jobs. 

Actually, no, they can't, at least without jumping through hoops.  SOAP
has mandatory and scoped extensions, which HTTP can't do very easily.
Just check out PEP and RFC 2774 to see an example of that.  Both those
forms of extension are not backwards-compatible, so deployment issues
abound too.

On the other hand, Waka's going to have both of those in there natively.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis

Post ID:3640
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 00:01:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] What is good about SOAP?
Message:

>>>>> "Bill" == Bill de hra <dehora@...> writes:

    >> >> SOAP is quite useful for asynchronous processing for
    >> example.
    Vincent> .. as is SMTP.
    >> Real message queueing adds a lot more goodies.

    Bill> I'm not sure what your point is. What has message queueing
    Bill> got to do with SOAP/SMTP?

I mentioned that SOAP is well suited if you want to to asynchrononous
calls. You mentioned SMTP as a possible transport (else I couldn't
really make sense of the comment). But usually asynchronous
communcation is done with message queueing.

Post ID:3641
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-04-30 23:57:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Talking about REST
Message:

The sessions issue seems like a Red Herring.
You make UI web servers that interact with the web
service.  They can be as stateful as you want them
to be because they are really just web based user
agents (not really different from X-windows based
user-agents).

-Alex-

> anything clever, to question the validity of REST because of it's
> simplicity. The more experience programmers (who have topyed with

Post ID:3642
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 00:42:36
Subject:Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

So, over the last year or so, I've worked my way through the various 
concepts of REST - resources, representations, hypermedia as the engine 
of application state, etc.  And now I've come to visibility.

I've been trying to get my mind around exactly what visibility means and 
why its important to REST.  I think I have a vague sense of what it is, 
but I'm not sure I understand why its important.  I took a look at 
Fielding's thesis, but I didn't see much at all on visibility.

Can someone give me an example of why and how visibility is important 
(in REST).  I suspect that one of the examples will involve proxies, so 
if someone could give an additional example that'd be even better.

--Chuck

Post ID:3643
Sender:"softtouchit" <softtouchit@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 04:33:06
Subject:Using SOAP in a RESTful way
Message:

Dear All,

Everyone is taking the document centric approach, even for the SOAP
guys. This appears to be a good step away from "fine grained" RPC.
Some new additions to SOAP 1.2 look like RESTful.

Questions are:

1. Is the new SOAP (1.2) RESTful enough that one can build a REST Web
Services?
2. Has anyone actually implemeted a RESTful Web Services? 

Hao





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3644
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 04:50:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Hybrid interface - Advantage of REST?
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>

>
> REST is the back end for web sites or client side apps that expose user
> interfaces.
I think of it as an 'automation' interface parallel with the 'visual'
interface of a web site. Same general data, use & purposes but different
capabilities.

>
> Notably, Amazon and Google expose web services distinct from their user
interfaces.
Distinct & much simpler to program with (at least the REST oriented Amazon
ones - I don't think Google makes GET/XML available). They'll get better
over time.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3645
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 04:54:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] What is good about SOAP?
Message:

> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Berend de Boer" <berend@...>

> I mentioned that SOAP is well suited if you want to to asynchrononous
> calls. You mentioned SMTP as a possible transport (else I couldn't
> really make sense of the comment). But usually asynchronous
> communcation is done with message queueing.
What are the differences between SMTP and message queueing (besides cost)?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3646
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 04:59:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

----- Original Message -----
From: "Chuck Hinson" <cmhinson@...>


> So, over the last year or so, I've worked my way through the various
> concepts of REST - resources, representations, hypermedia as the engine
> of application state, etc.  And now I've come to visibility.
>
> I've been trying to get my mind around exactly what visibility means and
> why its important to REST.  I think I have a vague sense of what it is,
> but I'm not sure I understand why its important.  I took a look at
> Fielding's thesis, but I didn't see much at all on visibility.
>
> Can someone give me an example of why and how visibility is important
> (in REST).  I suspect that one of the examples will involve proxies, so
> if someone could give an additional example that'd be even better.
>
Hmm. Good question. For me, visibility also implies standardization, which
lets me program a server regardless of client - everybody uses the same auth
header & syntax & meaning. It's not just for intermediaries.
Visibility for me is also the standardization of key aspects & generic
aspects of a message - resource identifier, method, authentication,
representation metadata (content-type...), etc. I'm not all that interested
in visibility for something like the phone number of someone purchasing a
book.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3647
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 18:21:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

On Wed, Apr 30, 2003 at 08:42:36PM -0400, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> So, over the last year or so, I've worked my way through the various 
> concepts of REST - resources, representations, hypermedia as the engine 
> of application state, etc.  And now I've come to visibility.
> 
> I've been trying to get my mind around exactly what visibility means and 
> why its important to REST.  I think I have a vague sense of what it is, 
> but I'm not sure I understand why its important.  I took a look at 
> Fielding's thesis, but I didn't see much at all on visibility.

What it said was pretty good though, even just this sentence;

"Visibility in this case refers to the ability of a component to monitor
or mediate the interaction between two other components. "

I think that says it all.  Was there something in particular about that
definition that you had trouble with?

> Can someone give me an example of why and how visibility is important 
> (in REST).  I suspect that one of the examples will involve proxies, so 
> if someone could give an additional example that'd be even better.

Given the definition, providing an example that doesn't use an
intermediary would be tough. 8-)

MB

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

>>of application state, etc.  And now I've come to visibility.

>>why its important to REST.  I think I have a vague sense of what it is,

>>Fielding's thesis, but I didn't see much at all on visibility.
>>

>"Visibility in this case refers to the ability of a component to monitor
>or mediate the interaction between two other components. "

Well, its one of those definitions where my reaction is "OK - now what 
does that mean."  I'm sure its an accurate and succinct definition, its 
just too terse for my small brain.  What are the pros and cons of 
having/not having visibility?  How do I determine what or how much an 
intermediary needs to see in order to have 'good' visibility?  When is 
something not visible?  What does it take to make something visible?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3649
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 20:03:18
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

>> I've been trying to get my mind around exactly what visibility means 
>> and
>> why its important to REST.  I think I have a vague sense of what it 
>> is,
>> but I'm not sure I understand why its important.  I took a look at
>> Fielding's thesis, but I didn't see much at all on visibility.
>
> What it said was pretty good though, even just this sentence;
>
> "Visibility in this case refers to the ability of a component to 
> monitor
> or mediate the interaction between two other components. "

Why it's important?  Hmm...

There are several places where it comes into play:

   o efficient intermediaries

     - security across trust boundaries

     Many networks don't trust each other, or at least don't trust what
     is on the other side of a firewall.  As a result, intermediaries are
     installed to filter traffic.  That is a hard problem for 
general-purpose
     application protocols, so we need to make it easier in order to make
     filtering more efficient and gain the trust of firewall admins.

     - extensibility

     Visibility calls for more explicit descriptions within messages, as
     opposed to relying on external IDLs or XDR-style typing by schema,
     which in turn makes it easier to extend the functionality later.

     - evolvability

     When intermediaries can understand a request, they can more easily
     perform or adjust it on behalf of the intended recipient, just as
     WebTV or cell phone networks can adjust for their clients.

     - performance

     Visibility is necessary for cacheability.

   o understandability

     It is simply easier to build complex systems if you can see and
     understand the individual interactions.

   o reusability

     People learn by emulation.  That is described somewhat in the 
section
     on Java versus Javascript.

There are probably others.


Cheers,

Roy T. Fielding, Chief Scientist, Day Software
                  2 Corporate Plaza, Suite 150
                  Newport Beach, CA 92660-7929   fax:+1.949.644.5064
                  (roy.fielding@...) <http://www.day.com/>

                  Co-founder, The Apache Software Foundation
                  (fielding@...)  <http://www.apache.org/>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3650
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 20:06:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] What is good about SOAP?
Message:

>>>>> "Mike" == Mike Dierken <mdierken@...> writes:

    Mike> What are the differences between SMTP and message queueing
    Mike> (besides cost)?

I think the basics are:

1. Transactions (one or more messages within a transaction get there
   all or none).

2. Guaranteed delivery (+ error handling in case of timeouts).

3. Notification of delivery.

4. Guaranteed order of delivery.

5. Priorization.


-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3651
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 21:43:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

On Thursday 01 May 2003 16:03, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
>      - security across trust boundaries
>
>      Many networks don't trust each other, or at least don't trust what
>      is on the other side of a firewall.  As a result, intermediaries are
>      installed to filter traffic.  That is a hard problem for
> general-purpose
>      application protocols, so we need to make it easier in order to make
>      filtering more efficient and gain the trust of firewall admins.

I am wondering how much thought you have put into application
security and how it fits in with REST. Do you have a model for how
application security should be done? Has there been an exploration
of how application security affects other REST guidelines? It
seems like supporting access control has ramifications for many
parts of REST, the most well-known effect being the interplay of
HTTP Auth and caching. It seems that if not done carefully,
access control could negate many of the benefits of REST. What are
your thoughts?

Thank you for sharing your expertise.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3652
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 23:05:33
Subject:ACID REST-HTTP (was: What is good about SOAP?)
Message:

[prior discussion about SOAP and message-queues
elided]

Its nice that they defined a protocol for these
things on top of SOAP, but is there any reason to
believe that if they had put this design effort
into doing it on top of HTTP/SMTP (and perhaps
RESTfully), we would not have these services
without the SOAP horror?

Strawman ACID REST-HTTP Protocol:
1. Define Client MIME header:
 transaction: yes

2. Define Server MIME header:
 transaction-location: http://controlURL

3. Client makes HTTP requests with transaction
header.  If the server can accomplish the request,
it responds with ACCEPTED and a
transaction-location header.

4. If client wants to rollback the transaction,
it posts ROLLBACK to all the
transaction-locations.  If the client wants to
commit the transaction, it posts PREPARE to all
the transaction-locations.  If any return
an error then it posts ROLLBACK to all of them
and the transaction fails.  If none return an
error, the client posts COMMIT to all the
transaction-locations and the transaction
succeeds.

RESTful and transactional without all of SOAP's
plumbing.

Strawman SMTP:
On Fri, 2 May 2003, Berend de Boer wrote:
> 1. Transactions (one or more messages within a transaction get there
>    all or none).
> 2. Guaranteed delivery (+ error handling in case of timeouts).

1. Send messages with a transaction header and a
message-id header. e.g.

 Transaction: yes
 Message-id: abc123@....1234
 From: dsn-recipient@...

 insert foo into bar

2. To commit send a multipart/digest with subject:
COMMIT and each part with a RFC2017 external-body
content type, e.g.:

 From: dsn-recipient@...
 Message-id: abc123@....1234
 Subject: COMMIT
 Content-type: multipart/mixed; boundar=abc

 --abc
 content-type: external-body; access-type=url;
   URL="mid:message-id_1"

 --abc
 content-type: external-body; access-type=url;
   URL="mid:message-id_2"

 --abc--

Message is processed (and in order) only if all
external-bodies are present.

Note: This protocol nests.  The commit message may
itself have a transaction: yes header in which
case it waits until someone commits the commmit.

> 3. Notification of delivery.

See RFC1891: Delivery Service Notifications

> 4. Guaranteed order of delivery.

See above.

> 5. Priorization.

I am not sure what this means, but I suspect you
don't want it because it violates the End-To-End
principle.

-Alex-

PS The above protocols are entirely strawmen made
to make a point and set us on the road to
industrial stength variants.  Please be gentle.

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3653
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-01 23:45:58
Subject:Re: ACID REST-HTTP
Message:

>>>>> "S" == S Alexander Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    S> Its nice that they defined a protocol for these things on top
    S> of SOAP, but is there any reason to believe that if they had
    S> put this design effort into doing it on top of HTTP/SMTP (and
    S> perhaps RESTfully), we would not have these services without
    S> the SOAP horror?

Maybe. Or would we have ended with a lot of HTTP horror? I don't
know. The world's data doesn't neatly fit in name/value pairs.


    S> ...
    S> RESTful and transactional without all of SOAP's plumbing.

    S> ...
    S> Message is processed (and in order) only if all external-bodies
    S> are present.

    S> Note: This protocol nests.  The commit message may itself have
    S> a transaction: yes header in which case it waits until someone
    S> commits the commmit.

This is so wrong, that I must assume you have not worked on enterprise
level applications. I hardly know how to correct you, but I'll try:

1. What if an entity I invoke, invokes other entities, and what if
   they have transactions of their own? Are they in the same
   transaction? A new transaction? Do they nest?

2. What if an entity I invoke also sends messages? Are they in the
   transaction as well? In what order?

3. If the client goes down, is the transaction committed? Rolled back?

4. Doing two or three phase commit at the client is really innovative
   I assume... What do we need transaction managers for??


    >> 5. Priorization.

    S> I am not sure what this means, but I suspect you don't want it
    S> because it violates the End-To-End principle.

Absolutely not! If I want to have certain orders served at higher
priority, why should software prevent me? If I want paying customers
to serve at a higher priority at some site, why not?


    S> PS The above protocols are entirely strawmen made to make a
    S> point and set us on the road to industrial stength variants.
    S> Please be gentle.

Maybe I sounded a bit harsh, not my intention really. If you have not
worked with transaction managers and the Corba/MTS (COM+) stuff, you
might not have a real idea what those can do for you and what problems
they try to solve.

My intention is not to defend what they are doing, or to deny there
might be better ways to solve it. But the issues they try to solve are
real, and they bring in a lot of value.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:

Post ID:3654
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>

Roy T. Fielding wrote:

>>>I've been trying to get my mind around exactly what visibility means 
>>>and
>>>why its important to REST.  I think I have a vague sense of what it 
>>>is,
>>>but I'm not sure I understand why its important.  I took a look at
>>>Fielding's thesis, but I didn't see much at all on visibility.
>>>      
>>>
>>What it said was pretty good though, even just this sentence;
>>
>>"Visibility in this case refers to the ability of a component to 
>>monitor
>>or mediate the interaction between two other components. "
>>    
>>
>
>Why it's important?  Hmm...
>
>There are several places where it comes into play:
>  
>
[. . .]

So is it fair to say that visibility is about a third party's ability to 
understand the intent or meaning of a message or an interaction?  And 
increasing visibility is about making it as easy as possible for a third 
party to figure out the intent/meaining of a message?

Also, does visibility imply the ability of any arbitrary third party to 
understand a message, or does it just mean the ability for some 
particular third party to be able to understand the message.  In other 
words, is visibility, to a ceratin extent, application specific (and by 
application I dont mean HTTP, I mean my particular web app built on top 
of HTTP)?

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3655
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-02 06:56:18
Subject:Re: ACID REST-HTTP
Message:

Berend,

If these are your major objections, I think HTTP/SMTP based transactions 
look fairly plausible:

--On Friday, May 02, 2003 11:45 AM +1200 Berend de Boer <berend@...> 
wrote:
> 1. What if an entity I invoke, invokes other entities, and what if
>    they have transactions of their own? Are they in the same
>    transaction? A new transaction? Do they nest?

Presumably, when an entity receives a PREPARE request, it attempts to 
PREPARE any sub-transactions for which it is responsible.  If all those 
PREPAREs are successful, it returns 200 in response to  PREPARE, otherwise 
it returns an error.  If it does anything else, it violates the semantics 
of PREPARE.

> 2. What if an entity I invoke also sends messages? Are they in the
>    transaction as well? In what order?

Presumably in the order of the entities that send them.  How does SOAP 
handle this issue?

> 3. If the client goes down, is the transaction committed? Rolled back?
> 4. Doing two or three phase commit at the client is really innovative
>    I assume... What do we need transaction managers for??

In either protocol, there is no commit until COMMIT.
If you are concerned about client reliability in then set up a durable 
server
to handle the commits.  In the HTTP context, you have a reliable HTTP 
server that posts PREPARE and perhaps COMMIT to a list of URLs supplied in 
a single HTTP request.  In the SMTP context, this is what SMTP servers 
already do for desktop mail clients.  The "unreliable" client sends 
messages to the server and the server is responsible for guaranteeing 
delivery.

>     >> 5. Priorization.
>
>     S> I am not sure what this means, but I suspect you don't want it
>     S> because it violates the End-To-End principle.
>
> Absolutely not! If I want to have certain orders served at higher
> priority, why should software prevent me? If I want paying customers
> to serve at a higher priority at some site, why not?

I assume you are not familiar with the End-To-End (Dumb Network) principle.
Discussion on the internet is quite extensive.  I'd point you to a URL, but 
I'm offline now (try http://isen.com).  The short answer is that 
prioritization is an application layer issue and not a protocol issue.  The 
Internet and even IP-telephony have been quite successful without QoS IP 
routing (some IP packets are more important than others).  Southwest 
Airlines chooses not to prioritize and is doing better than most airlines 
that do (yield-management).

-Alex-





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3656
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-04 21:16:58
Subject:Re: ACID REST-HTTP
Message:

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    >> 1. What if an entity I invoke, invokes other entities, and what
    >> if they have transactions of their own? Are they in the same
    >> transaction? A new transaction? Do they nest?

    Alex> Presumably, when an entity receives a PREPARE request, it
    Alex> attempts to PREPARE any sub-transactions for which it is
    Alex> responsible.  If all those PREPAREs are successful, it
    Alex> returns 200 in response to PREPARE, otherwise it returns an
    Alex> error.  If it does anything else, it violates the semantics
    Alex> of PREPARE.

Why burden the programmer with this? How will you ever proof this
works? I rather have declarative transactional semantics. And
sometimes you want to have points in a transaction that are saved
regardless if an error occurs later on. Sometimes you want to start a
new transaction. And sometimes an administrator wants to have a
different policy (declarative).

All supported by current transaction processing software.


    >> 2. What if an entity I invoke also sends messages? Are they in
    >> the transaction as well? In what order?

    Alex> Presumably in the order of the entities that send them.  How
    Alex> does SOAP handle this issue?

It does not. It's completely outside SOAP. SOAP 1.1 is only about the
wire format. I find SOAP 1.2 so unreadable, that I don't have any idea
what it is saying )-:

I just mentioned some things that message queuing software can
do. Those are really outside the SMTP protocol at the moment. Nothing
prevents them to be added. But if you are lookingn for a solution now,
SMTP does not play.


    >> 3. If the client goes down, is the transaction committed?
    >> Rolled back?  4. Doing two or three phase commit at the client
    >> is really innovative I assume... What do we need transaction
    >> managers for??

    Alex> In either protocol, there is no commit until COMMIT.  If you
    Alex> are concerned about client reliability in then set up a
    Alex> durable server to handle the commits.  In the HTTP context,
    Alex> you have a reliable HTTP server that posts PREPARE and
    Alex> perhaps COMMIT to a list of URLs supplied in a single HTTP
    Alex> request.  In the SMTP context, this is what SMTP servers
    Alex> already do for desktop mail clients.  The "unreliable"
    Alex> client sends messages to the server and the server is
    Alex> responsible for guaranteeing delivery.

Replace your "durable server" by transaction processing manager and
your solution is exactly what I was talking about. Your "durable
server" is doing the work.

But again, the point is not if the HTTP server can do it, but that it
does not currently. And secondly, letting the client decide the
transaction boundaries, is not very wide on the internet: you don't
want someone on the internet to have the possibility to determine
duration of locks in your database.



    >> >> 5. Priorization.
    >> 
    S> I am not sure what this means, but I suspect you don't want it
    S> because it violates the End-To-End principle.
    >>  Absolutely not! If I want to have certain orders served at
    >> higher priority, why should software prevent me? If I want
    >> paying customers to serve at a higher priority at some site,
    >> why not?

    Alex> I assume you are not familiar with the End-To-End (Dumb
    Alex> Network) principle.  Discussion on the internet is quite
    Alex> extensive.  

Well, this is a business issue, isn't it? If a client asks you to
implement something, are you going to argue that maybe they should do
something different? You can argue, if you are at a certain level in
the discussion, but if you are just hired to install the plumbing,
you're not going to decide that a different building might have been
better.

Maybe I was not clear in my replies: on request, I just pointed out
what message queuing can do NOW for you. You started to give a
possible implementation in SMTP/HTTP, which I argued does not even
start to address the issues that transaction processing software has
solved for a great many years. We can argue that transaction
processing software is not needed, but that's a different discussion.

I think message queueing etc. is great stuff for building your
enterprise software. It's probably not that great to expose it to
clients you don't have control about. I expose an SMTP/HTTP interface
to the world, not COM objects, or an MQ Series queue. I think both
solutions have their proper place and proper ues.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3659
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-05 15:56:17
Subject:Style extensions in the small
Message:

I'll take a crack at this if Roy isn't going to, because there's a good
question that's really about software architecture in general that I've
given a fair amount of thought to.

On Fri, May 02, 2003 at 12:14:54AM -0400, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> So is it fair to say that visibility is about a third party's ability to 
> understand the intent or meaning of a message or an interaction?

Yes.

>  And 
> increasing visibility is about making it as easy as possible for a third 
> party to figure out the intent/meaining of a message?

Yes.

> Also, does visibility imply the ability of any arbitrary third party to 
> understand a message, or does it just mean the ability for some 
> particular third party to be able to understand the message.

Visibility is just the property, and an architectural style has a
certain amount of it.  I would say that any RESTful interaction has at
least some (large) amount of visibility.  "At least", because for any
given use of it in a "RESTful app", one can probably find additional
constraints (even unintended ones) that induce additional properties,
some of which may yield improved visibility.  For example, an HTML
knowledgeable HTTP intermediary has greater visibility into an
interaction between two components exchanging HTML with HTTP, than it
does with those same components exchanging SVG.

What's really going on here, IMO, is that the app I described can be
viewed as its own system, while remaining a subsystem of the Web.  So if
you created an architectural style which described this subsystem, you
would likely include all of REST's constraints, but have an additional
constraint called "Common data format and language", or some such.  This
constraint is what induces the additional visibility in this app beyond
what REST, by itself, provides.

But visibility isn't special, of course.  Any architectural property
works the same way.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3660
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-05 19:27:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: ACID REST-HTTP
Message:

>>>>> "Softtouch" == Softtouch IT <softtouchit@...> writes:

    Softtouch> Agree. Does the SOAP head do better than name/value
    Softtouch> pairs? Also, embedding another XML into SOAP body seems
    Softtouch> awkward as well.

SOAP body you mean? Embedding XML in XML is no more awkward than
having a proper escape string function in your library. It might not
perform optimal, but if you're looking for the last bits, XML might
not be suitable anyway.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3661
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-05 21:45:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Why do I care about visibility?
Message:

> I am wondering how much thought you have put into application
> security and how it fits in with REST.

Bunches.

> Do you have a model for how
> application security should be done? Has there been an exploration
> of how application security affects other REST guidelines? It
> seems like supporting access control has ramifications for many
> parts of REST, the most well-known effect being the interplay of
> HTTP Auth and caching. It seems that if not done carefully,
> access control could negate many of the benefits of REST. What are
> your thoughts?

Even if it is done carefully, access control does negate some goals
of REST (shared caching in particular).  However, it doesn't negate
the benefits of the model: a given security model can be analyzed
to see how it affects applications that are attempting to communicate
using the REST model, and then improved based on those observations.
Likewise, security models can learn from the lessons of REST in order
to improve their efficiency.

I think it is very important to note that the REST model is not ideal
for all applications, and that various aspects of security (access
control, authentication, authorization, accounting, and privacy of
communication) will place requirements on the architecture that need
to be addressed in the interaction model.

Most sites address this issue by separating secure services from the
services that need higher scalability.  This is hampered somewhat by
the goofy way that WWW browsers warn about "secure" sites containing
"insecure" embedded content.  Likewise, just about every variation on
securing web sites is damaged in one way or another by browser
behavior, which is why sites currently use cookies as authenticators.

I should note that the big conflict between REST and security models
is the fact that REST does not allow for sessions.  What needs to be
understood is that sessions are bad for security models too -- they
cause most of the denial-of-service and man-in-the-middle attacks
to be possible.  What is needed is an efficient, session-free means
of authenticating that is more secure than username/password, which
is actually an easy problem to solve if you don't try to solve all
of the security problems at once.  What is blocking that is the need
to negotiate security mechanisms before engaging in secure
communication, which is currently done within a session.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3662
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-05 21:20:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Style extensions in the small
Message:

I am swamped trying to finish the URI revision...

I'll just add that one thing we want out of an architecture is the
ability to adapt to, or be adapted by, future changes in the evolving
way that the system is being used.  Life is change.

In general, it is far easier to adapt a system that is self-descriptive
(high visibility of syntactic and semantic meaning within the structure
of communication), both because the interactions are easier for third
parties to understand and because the communicating parties are less
likely to base their communication on shared out-of-band assumptions:
assumptions that may not be applicable in the future.  In other words,
the components of a successful computing systems are never just
communicating among themselves, because success will lead to change
and change will lead to new components.

....Roy

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3664
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-07 19:39:11
Subject:Has trailing slash any significance?
Message:

Hello All,

If you start doing URL rewriting you can make URLs that cannot exist
in a file system. For example I can say that:

    /authors

returns a list of authors and

    /authors/peter

returns a single author.

But with URL rewriting it's just as easy to say that

  /authors/

returns the list of authors.


My point is that /authors cannot exist in a file system if it has a
subdirectory. You either must say /authors/ (and get some default
file) or peter should go into another directory like:

    /author-list
    /authors/peter

(I think webservers send a moved/redirect if you ask for /authors or
fetch the default page in that directory anyway??)


But my question: for cases like this is it better to append a trailing
slash if you want to get a list of things in a directory or does it
not matter at all? So is:

    /authors

or

    /authors/

preferred?

Any thoughts on this appreciated.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3665
Sender:Nic Ferrier <nferrier@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-07 20:26:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Has trailing slash any significance?
Message:

Berend de Boer <berend@...> writes:

> Hello All,
> 
> If you start doing URL rewriting you can make URLs that cannot exist
> in a file system. For example I can say that:
> 
>     /authors
> 
> returns a list of authors and
> 
>     /authors/peter
> 
> returns a single author.
> 
> But with URL rewriting it's just as easy to say that
> 
>   /authors/
> 
> returns the list of authors.

And you could say that

   /authors

returns the list of authors as well.


> My point is that /authors cannot exist in a file system if it has a
> subdirectory. 

Yes it can. It's the subdirectory itself. What that means is open to
interpretation. On un*x systems a directory is a special file
containing a list of the files and directorys contained within the
directory.


> (I think webservers send a moved/redirect if you ask for /authors or
> fetch the default page in that directory anyway??)

A lot of webservers do behave like that. But that behaviour is not
intrinsic to the way the web works. A webserver after all meerly maps
an arbritary URI based namespace to some behaviour (in this case
returning an index.html page or some such).

Apache just returns an index in this situation, the index behaviour
is often the commonly understood index.html trick. But it needn't be.
 

> But my question: for cases like this is it better to append a trailing
> slash if you want to get a list of things in a directory or does it
> not matter at all? So is:
> 
>     /authors
> 
> or
> 
>     /authors/
> 
> preferred?

The trailing slash does have an effect on HTML form posts for browser
contexts. If you're resource is:

   /authors/

you can have a form POST or GET to "." and it will go to the current
page. Having:

  /authors

as the resource and doing a POST or GET to "." will send the request
to:

  /


So there is a difference as far as common browsers are concerned. I'm
not sure it's spec compliant behaviour though. Just common.


Nic





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3666
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-07 18:03:29
Subject:Re: ACID REST-HTTP
Message:

The context of this discussion was whether SOAP is superior to REST-HTTP 
because it specifies ACID/MQ services.  My point is that if we put in a 
little work we can specify the same services on top of HTTP/SMTP and reuse 
more of our installed based of software while simultaneously avoiding the 
complexity of SOAP.

The implementation details of transaction managers/monitors, ease of 
development, long/dropped transactions, and prioritization are really 
implementation or application issues not protocol issues.  If someone has a 
reliable client, they don't need a separate HTTP transaction manager 
server.  Control of sub-transactions can be as easy as editing a list of 
current commits/rollbacks, but that is really an IDE question and not a 
protocol one.
There are millions of shopping carts abandoned everyday across the 
Internet.  How you handle this issue depends on your site. etc.

I am suggesting the HTTP/SMTP equivalent of ODBC.  That MS Access exposes 
ODBC but does not implement two-phase-commit may be a problem with MS 
Access, but it is not a problem with ODBC.  Similarly, that you may want a 
separate transaction manager for ACID-HTTP is not an objection to 
ACID-HTTP, it is just one of your particular implementation issues.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3667
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-08 22:37:28
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Has trailing slash any significance?
Message:

On Wednesday, May 7, 2003, at 21:26 Europe/Dublin, Nic Ferrier wrote:
> So there is a difference as far as common browsers are concerned. I'm
> not sure it's spec compliant behaviour though. Just common.

i think this is more generally about relative URIs, which are 
interpreted relative to a base URI (that of the request).  much like a 
relative and absolute path in a filesystem, but not exactly the same.

and yes, a trailing slash or lack thereof affects how dot (.) is 
interpreted in a user agent.  therefore it is important to be 
consistent or your HTML/client code will start breaking in subtle ways.

for the record, i stick with *always* using a trailing slash, and 
redirect requests that lack them to URIs that have them.  no index.html 
cruft whatsoever.  i don't know whether this is superior in any way to 
not having them though because i haven't tried this alternative.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3668
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-09 01:43:51
Subject:Caching question
Message:

Which would be the best way to ensure cachability of a resource where a
limited set of individuals require access, but cannot share a common URI.

1) Assign a user/pwd pair and a single URL.  In this case, the user/pwd is
little more than a nonce.
2) Generate a unique URL for each individual (likely by adding a nonce to
the end of the path), then use the "Content-Location:" header with a single,
global URL value.
3) Other thoughts?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3669
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-09 06:06:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

On Thursday 08 May 2003 21:43, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> Which would be the best way to ensure cachability of a resource where a
> limited set of individuals require access, but cannot share a common URI.
>
> 1) Assign a user/pwd pair and a single URL.  In this case, the user/pwd is
> little more than a nonce.
> 2) Generate a unique URL for each individual (likely by adding a nonce to
> the end of the path), then use the "Content-Location:" header with a
> single, global URL value.
> 3) Other thoughts?

If a resource is subject to access control, representations must
be transferred over an encrypted communications channel, such as
is provided by HTTPS. If HTTPS is used, there will be no shared
cache. In this case, the only relevant cache is the client's
personal cache. The client's personal cache can be keyed off the
client's personal URI. This makes option 2 the best choice, with
no need for setting a global "Content-Location" header.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3670
Sender:Mark Nottingham <mnot@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-10 19:56:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

Digest authentication doesn't require SSL to maintain privacy of the  
authenticator.

Seairth, I'm a bit confused about your requirements. You say that they  
cannot share a common URI, but appear to list that as option #1. It's  
also unclear whether you just want user-agent caching or shared caching  
(e.g., in proxies); I'll assume the latter.

If that's the case, I'd recommend option #1 with
   Cache-Control: public, must-revalidate, max-age=0
This allows a cache to keep a copy of the representation, but forces it  
to validate each request on the origin server, thereby maintaining  
access control. (BTW, I would not recommend using no-cache, as some  
implementations may still incorrectly interpret this as having the  
semantics of no-store).

A few years back, I did a deployment of an authenticated document  
caching system for Merrill Lynch using this technique with both open  
source and commercial proxy caches, and it worked flawlessly.

A more efficient approach would be to cache the authentication state on  
intermediaries, rather than just the representations; this would allow  
them to avoid the round-trip back to the origin server every time. I  
wrote up an Internet-Draft [1] about this a while back, but the major  
drawback is that it won't work with Digest authentication. I don't know  
of any implementations.

Hope this helps,

1.  http://www.mnot.net/papers/draft-nottingham-http-auth-cache-00.txt


On Thursday, May 8, 2003, at 11:06 PM, Tyler Close wrote:

> On Thursday 08 May 2003 21:43, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
>> Which would be the best way to ensure cachability of a resource where  
>> a
>> limited set of individuals require access, but cannot share a common  
>> URI.
>>
>> 1) Assign a user/pwd pair and a single URL.  In this case, the  
>> user/pwd is
>> little more than a nonce.
>> 2) Generate a unique URL for each individual (likely by adding a  
>> nonce to
>> the end of the path), then use the "Content-Location:" header with a
>> single, global URL value.
>> 3) Other thoughts?
>
> If a resource is subject to access control, representations must
> be transferred over an encrypted communications channel, such as
> is provided by HTTPS. If HTTPS is used, there will be no shared
> cache. In this case, the only relevant cache is the client's
> personal cache. The client's personal cache can be keyed off the
> client's personal URI. This makes option 2 the best choice, with
> no need for setting a global "Content-Location" header.
>
> Tyler

is a better format:

Aha!  This was the answer I was looking for.  I suspected this was the
better approach, but I did not know the Cache-Control details.

> A more efficient approach would be to cache the authentication state on
> intermediaries, rather than just the representations; this would allow
> them to avoid the round-trip back to the origin server every time. I

> drawback is that it won't work with Digest authentication. I don't know
