-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3672
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-10 20:36:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

On Saturday 10 May 2003 15:56, Mark Nottingham wrote:
> Digest authentication doesn't require SSL to maintain privacy of the
> authenticator.

If you send the resource representation in plaintext, you are
effectively delegating access to the resource to everyone else on
your network path. This violates the semantics of your access
control check.

In this case, using HTTP Auth without SSL doesn't provide any
actual security. I don't know how knowledgeable you are about
these things, but a compelling case can be made that providing
imaginary security is worse than providing no security at all.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3673
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-10 21:02:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

On Saturday 10 May 2003 15:56, Mark Nottingham wrote:
> Digest authentication doesn't require SSL to maintain privacy of the
> authenticator.

You may also want to take a look at this post:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-explore/message/407

In this case, there is no sense in using digest authentication
over plain authentication.

I assume that you know that digest authentication only protects
the password, not the "privacy of the authenticator".

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3674
Sender:Michael Day <mikeday@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-11 01:58:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

> If you send the resource representation in plaintext, you are
> effectively delegating access to the resource to everyone else on
> your network path. This violates the semantics of your access
> control check.

Perhaps rather than saying "access to the resource" it would be better to 
say "access to a representation of the resource".

For example, if the resource is a coffee machine and I POST something to
it that starts water boiling using digest authentication to prove that I
have authority to do so, that seems to be a valid use of authentication
over unencrypted HTTP.

Michael Day

-- 
YesLogic Prince prints XML!
http://yeslogic.com/prince





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3675
Sender:Mark Nottingham <mnot@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-11 07:03:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

Quoting Tyler Close <tyler@...>:

> On Saturday 10 May 2003 15:56, Mark Nottingham wrote:
> > Digest authentication doesn't require SSL to maintain privacy of the
> > authenticator.
> 
> If you send the resource representation in plaintext, you are
> effectively delegating access to the resource to everyone else on
> your network path. This violates the semantics of your access
> control check.

No, you could be said to be delegating access to the representation, but
not the resource; whilst the representation is available to anyone who is
able to observe it as it goes by, other representations of the resource
are not available to them upon demand without the proper credentials.


> In this case, using HTTP Auth without SSL doesn't provide any
> actual security. I don't know how knowledgeable you are about

"security" is such an imprecise term, isn't it?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3676
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-11 10:56:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

On Sunday 11 May 2003 03:03, Mark Nottingham wrote:
> Quoting Tyler Close <tyler@...>:
> > On Saturday 10 May 2003 15:56, Mark Nottingham wrote:
> > > Digest authentication doesn't require SSL to maintain privacy of the
> > > authenticator.
> >
> > If you send the resource representation in plaintext, you are
> > effectively delegating access to the resource to everyone else on
> > your network path. This violates the semantics of your access
> > control check.
>
> No, you could be said to be delegating access to the representation, but
> not the resource; whilst the representation is available to anyone who is
> able to observe it as it goes by, other representations of the resource
> are not available to them upon demand without the proper credentials.

In this case, access to a representation of the resource is
equivalent to access to the resource. We know this because Seairth
is specifically asking about a resource for which caching is
important. Given this information, your suggestion to use digest
authentication to "maintain the privacy of the authenticator"
doesn't make any sense.

Even if you wish to quibble over the above, it doesn't change the
fact that you've violated the semantics of the access control
check. The requestor intends to fetch a representation for
himself, not himself and everyone in the neighborhood.

Does it seem odd to anyone that I am needing to argue that it is
important to encrypt private data before transmitting it over a
public network?

> > In this case, using HTTP Auth without SSL doesn't provide any
> > actual security. I don't know how knowledgeable you are about
>
> "security" is such an imprecise term, isn't it?

Not in this context it isn't. Context is always important in
English.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3677
Sender:Mark Nottingham <mnot@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-11 17:58:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Caching question
Message:

Quoting Tyler Close <tyler@...>:

> In this case, access to a representation of the resource is
> equivalent to access to the resource. We know this because Seairth
> is specifically asking about a resource for which caching is
> important. Given this information, your suggestion to use digest
> authentication to "maintain the privacy of the authenticator"
> doesn't make any sense.

Yeeessss.... and I'm saying that a cached representation of a resource is
not equivalent to the range of representations that resource is capable of
emitting. There are scenarios where this is an important distinction.

> Does it seem odd to anyone that I am needing to argue that it is
> important to encrypt private data before transmitting it over a
> public network?

Who said public network? Once again, there are scenarios where protecting
the authentication credentials is valuable, but the representations
themselves aren't as sensitive. I grant that there are likely many, many
more which do require encryption for appropriate security, but am
unwilling to say that all scenarios require it.

Since we seem to be starting to repeat ourselves, I suggest we move on.

Post ID:3679
Sender:Jan Algermissen <algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-18 19:50:41
Subject:"Schema language for REST"
Message:

Paul,

in http://mail.python.org/pipermail/xml-sig/2002-February/007186.html
you write:

"I need a schema language that says what happens when you follow links,
 or apply HTTP methods to things that are referenced in links...I guess
 I'll have to do it myself some day."

Do you (or someone else) have any pointers to material related to this
issue?

Do you have any specific ideas how to formalize the way to 'say what happens'?
[a defined set of actions/modifications on representations perhaps?]

If there is any effort going on in that direction, I'd be happy to contribute.

Thanks in advance,


Jan



-- 
Jan Algermissen                           http://www.topicmapping.com
Consultant & Programmer	                  http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3680
Sender:Jan Algermissen <algermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-18 20:15:09
Subject:What method to apply to a 'link'?
Message:

When a web service returns some XML encoded representation to
a client adn this XML is containing XLinks to other resources,
how could the web service provide information what methods to
use in the request to those resources?

In http://www.prescod.net/rest/state_transition.html Paul
Prescod uses the example HTTP reply

200 OK

<challenge><p>Stop! 
Who would cross the Bridge of Death must answer me 
these questions three, 
ere the other side he see. 
Do you agree?</p>
<method>POST</method> your answer in             <------------**
<uri>/sessions</uri></challenge>

which to me implies that <method> is a specialized element
used in this interaction. Is there a way something like this
could be used with/added to XLink to be understood be every software
that supports XLink?

Other thoughts?


Jan




-- 
Jan Algermissen                           http://www.topicmapping.com
Consultant & Programmer	                  http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3681
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-19 19:16:38
Subject:REST and RDBMS: mapping relational models to resource models
Message:

So we've done this one before, just wanted to check in to see if there 
was any new state-of-the-art thinking about this.

Assume:  I have an object model / relational database model (one, the 
other, and / or a mapping between them) that describes the domain 
objects of interest to me.  I would like to expose this in a naive 
fashion to via a RESTful interface;  i.e., assuming something like

GET /Entity --> a representation of the extent (all instances of class 
/ rows in associated table)
GET /Entity?id=xxx --> a represenation of the particular instance of 
Entity with id=xxx
POST /Entity <-- some representation of an Entity --> creates new 
/Table?id=yyy, redirects to it

It would be nice to have:

(1) a declarative way to describe the ER table.  There are many of 
these that generate DDL and object stubs or code
(2) a declarative way to map the ER model to a resource model / URI 
namespace
(3) a runtime framework which glues the two together
(4) preferably Python, but patterns / research in this area of any type 
is good
(5) abstraction of view / controller and app workflow to generate UI 
from declarative description a plus

Waterken looks interesting, but the capability stuff is 
overcomplicating unless it solves a specific problem you've got.

Kuhlman's FSM stuff is close, but no cookie:  modeling workflows, not 
an ER or object model.

Anyone one else?

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3682
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-19 21:26:58
Subject:Documenting REST resource models
Message:

So we've all been using a variety of ad-hoc mechanisms to describe 
resource models for a while now, including the chatty but pervasive 
sort of "protocol traces" that show the back-and-forth flow of messages 
between a resource provider and consumer / client.  I'm wondering if 
anybody's got preferred formats / standards / conventions for how to 
describe:

the set of resources that are available
i.e. the permutations of URIs that are allowed / meaningful
the set of methods each one takes
for POST and PUT, the formats and constraints of allowed input
descriptions of representations / result codes returned by each method 
/ input permutation per resource

Love to see what people are doing in this sense.  I would hazard an 
intuitive guess that a lack of even a semi-formal set of conventions 
for declaratively describing / documenting resource models is one of 
the main sources of friction that we (the REST community) experience in 
trying to communicate with the unenlightened. ;-)

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3683
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-19 22:46:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models
Message:

Jeff,

I think I get your drift.  Last year, when I did the REST-based
interface overhaul for my group's web service project, the spec I
wrote was partly about capturing the xml vocabulary of the
application, and partly about specifying the legal permutations
of resources and HTTP methods (and of course response codes).

The spec was somewhat formal (in the sense that it followed a
pretty strict pattern for conveying these data), but I could imagine
a strictly formal notation as well, not unlike WSDL.

I don't know WSDL very well, but I'll conjecture out loud that
there's nothing stopping you from using it to describe the
syntax and legal operation/resource space for an application that
is REST-based.

Does anyone know why that wouldn't work?  Is this not what you're
driving at?

Walden
----- Original Message -----
From: "Jeff Bone" <jbone@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, May 19, 2003 5:26 PM
Subject: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models


>
> So we've all been using a variety of ad-hoc mechanisms to describe
> resource models for a while now, including the chatty but pervasive
> sort of "protocol traces" that show the back-and-forth flow of messages
> between a resource provider and consumer / client.  I'm wondering if
> anybody's got preferred formats / standards / conventions for how to
> describe:
>
> the set of resources that are available
> i.e. the permutations of URIs that are allowed / meaningful
> the set of methods each one takes
> for POST and PUT, the formats and constraints of allowed input
> descriptions of representations / result codes returned by each method
> / input permutation per resource
>
> Love to see what people are doing in this sense.  I would hazard an
> intuitive guess that a lack of even a semi-formal set of conventions
> for declaratively describing / documenting resource models is one of
> the main sources of friction that we (the REST community) experience in
> trying to communicate with the unenlightened. ;-)
>
> jb
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3684
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-20 02:56:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models
Message:

On Monday, May 19, 2003, at 17:46 US/Central, Walden Mathews wrote:

> I don't know WSDL very well, but I'll conjecture out loud that
> there's nothing stopping you from using it to describe the
> syntax and legal operation/resource space for an application that
> is REST-based.
>
> Does anyone know why that wouldn't work?  Is this not what you're
> driving at?

Yeah, seems that would be kind of like trying to write object-oriented 
assembler.  Or something. ;-)  Possible, tedious, and of high cost for 
dubious benefit.  WSDL appears to me to be extreme overkill and 
low-level cognitive damage for something as simple as a REST-based 
application --- an overcooked layer cake with colorful acronym 
sprinkles.  Doubtless you need it (and the rest of the "stack") if 
you're doing RPCs, but if you're just exposing a resource model --- too 
much.  (Coordination is punted in either case.)

I think what I'm looking for is something like WSDL that lives at the 
resource / URIspace / HTTP level of abstraction.

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3685
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-20 03:06:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST and RDBMS: mapping relational models to resource models
Message:

On Monday, May 19, 2003, at 14:16 US/Central, Jeff Bone wrote:

>
> So we've done this one before, just wanted to check in to see if there
> was any new state-of-the-art thinking about this.

BTW, in part what I'm looking for is something along the lines of Dan 
Connolly's RDBMS <--> RDF <--> URI resource space integration 
investigation [1],  based on some musings on this by Tim B-L. [2]  Not 
to disparage Dan --- he may be pushing the state-of-the-art frontier, 
here, yet again --- but hopefully a little further along...

jb

[1] http://www.w3.org/2000/10/swap/dbork/dbview.py
[2] http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/RDB-RDF.html

a format for use with Tarawa[1] so that machine-readable documentation can
automagically be generated from the annotated code. The list that you
describe seems about right.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3687
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-20 17:56:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models
Message:

On Monday 19 May 2003 17:26, Jeff Bone wrote:
> Love to see what people are doing in this sense.

The purpose of the Waterken web-calculus is to create a rigorous
model for building and describing a RESTful interface. The
web-calculus is a more constrained application of REST than HTTP
is, but I don't think this is at the cost of any functionality.

The web-calculus is at:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/

A collection of machine generated schemas can be found at:

http://waterken.com/

A page showing how some of these descriptions were generated is at:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/Tutorial/schema.html

I would appreciate any feedback on how this model could better
suit your needs. That said, I am not looking to model all the
myriad ways in which HTTP allows you to build a RESTful interface.
I think a more constrained model is needed to enable analysis and
more automated interoperation.

> I would hazard an
> intuitive guess that a lack of even a semi-formal set of conventions
> for declaratively describing / documenting resource models is one of
> the main sources of friction that we (the REST community) experience in
> trying to communicate with the unenlightened. ;-)

I agree. I think a great deal of the friction is based on
illogical arguments. With a more rigorous model, these arguments
could be more easily and decisively refuted.

Tyler

> > intuitive guess that a lack of even a semi-formal set of conventions
> > for declaratively describing / documenting resource models is one of
> > the main sources of friction that we (the REST community) experience in
> > trying to communicate with the unenlightened. ;-)
> 
> I agree. I think a great deal of the friction is based on
> illogical arguments. With a more rigorous model, these arguments
> could be more easily and decisively refuted.

Which arguments?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3689
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-20 19:30:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models
Message:

On Tuesday, May 20, 2003, at 12:23 US/Central, Mark Nottingham wrote:

>
> I'm interested in this as well; I've been considering coming up with 
> such
> a format for use with Tarawa[1] so that machine-readable documentation 
> can
> automagically be generated from the annotated code. The list that you
> describe seems about right.
>
> 1. http://www.mnot.net/tarawa/

This is cool, Mark!

I think you might have it backwards, though --- wouldn't it be cool to 
be able to generate Tarawa Resource subclasses from declarative 
descriptions?  Instead of extracting the documentation from the code, 
generate the code (and possibly its glue to persistent storage, ORM, 
presentation layer stuff, etc.) from the documentation?

My current short-term holy grail is the following:  Deepfile's 
management interface is currently a (not-very-RESTful, unfortunately) 
Web app but the juicy bits are the metadata repository we create over a 
set of filesystems.  I've got four eventual goals:  (1) I'd like for my 
dev team to be less in the Web app business and more in the filesystem 
management domain business.  (2) In pursuit of that, I'd like to be 
able to describe MVC declaratively and focus on modeling and 
specification rather than gluing abstraction layers together w/ code.  
We're already 60% of the way to automating the model piece of things 
from a formal declarative spec / description;  I'd like to do the same 
thing on the UI state flow, presentation, etc. fronts.  (3) I'd like to 
expose the underlying domain object model in a RESTful fashion, to ease 
integration friction down the road.  (4) There are several kinds of 
models that need to be mapped in my problem space:  the "hierarchical" 
(really network) database model of networked filesystems, the 
underlying relational storage for the metadata repository, the object 
model inside the application server, and (eventually) a semantic model 
that unifies these, probably RDF-based.  Right now all that mapping is 
impedance mismatch;  simplifying, unifying, or even eliminating some of 
those models and mappings is highly desirable.

Things like sqlREST, Tarawa, Dan's work, and so forth are conceptual 
puzzle pieces in a kind of generic solution to the problems I (and many 
others in lots of application domains!) am struggling with today.  I 
may end up having to fabricate many if not most of the pieces myself, 
but I think we're all driving towards some very similar goals or, even 
when the goals differ, there's a lot of overlap in the paths. :-)

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3690
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-20 20:35:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models
Message:

On Tuesday 20 May 2003 15:16, Walden Mathews wrote:
> > > I would hazard an
> > > intuitive guess that a lack of even a semi-formal set of conventions
> > > for declaratively describing / documenting resource models is one of
> > > the main sources of friction that we (the REST community) experience in
> > > trying to communicate with the unenlightened. ;-)
> >
> > I agree. I think a great deal of the friction is based on
> > illogical arguments. With a more rigorous model, these arguments
> > could be more easily and decisively refuted.
>
> Which arguments?

For example, I have repeatedly seen the claim that REST may be
good for simple applications, but that larger applications are
better done using the SOAP-based web-services machinery.

You and Mark Baker were just involved in a go-round of this
permathread on the www-ws-arch list. Mark responded to the
challenge with a simple sketch of how additional functionality
could be added to a purchase order application. I have seen
similar answers in the past. I suspect the critics will remain
unsatisfied with this response and the permathread will continue
another day.

With a rigorous model, it could be more convincingly shown that a
REST model is at least as expressive as a SOAP-based model. For
example, in the web-calculus spec, I show that the web-calculus
encompases the functionality of DEM. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/#Document_Exchange_Model_(DEM)

Hopefully, people will find such an analytic answer more
convincing.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3691
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-20 21:17:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Documenting REST resource models
Message:

Tyler,

Thanks for spelling that out.  I'm not sure I share your
optimism in this, although I do like models myself.  The problem
is that group is adept at avoiding the stimulae that result in
a change of position, and they're getting better and better with
practice.

The people who really want to learn REST end up on this list
throwing stones at it until either they win or they learn.  Most if
not all also dabble in concrete implementations of the pattern. You
don't see the WSA group members doing that;  I think it's doubly
doubtful they'd engage in a formal models-based inquiry.

Thanks for the reference; I want to check it out when I get
a chance.

Walden

I may be wrong, but I think that the purpose of XLink is to describe
relations (links) between resources, I mean existing resources, and thuth
retreived with a GET. I don't think it can be used to describe how to
interact with these resources. But may be this is the purpose of RDF and I
misunderstood XLink ...

transitions via GET or POST (or extended POST), just like HTML forms,
only for RDF and SOAP.

It shouldn't be too difficult, I don't believe.  I just have to get
off my a$$.

MB

Post ID:3694

Subject:Why REST for posting?
Message:

Hi. I've tried to find an explanation why I should
implement REST for a "posting service" (like Blogger).
At the RPC to REST wiki there are some hints but
still, I don't get it.
The GET thing with "smart" URLs and making things
transparent I get, it's like a command line URL.
My question is, what advantages are there using REST
for posting?


Rikard

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3695
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-22 16:58:54
Subject:Missing REST constraint?
Message:

It seems that when you take all the REST constraints as a whole, that
there is nothing which constrains that all "give me a representation
of this resource" requests use the same semantic (i.e.  GET in HTTP).
Tim talks about this[1] as one of his "axioms".

The "uniform interface" constraint doesn't appear to cover it, as there
may exist many different uniform semantics as part of a single interface
which could mean "give me a representation" ("RETRIEVE", "SNARF",
"GRAB", etc..).  I can't see how any of the other constraints would
prevent this either.

Surely I'm missing something here.  Thoughts?  Roy (when you have time -
no urgency)?

 [1] http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/Axioms.html#GET2

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
Web architecture consulting, technical reports, evaluation & analysis
  Actively seeking contract work or employment





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3696
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-22 22:00:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Missing REST constraint?
Message:

> It seems that when you take all the REST constraints as a whole, that
> there is nothing which constrains that all "give me a representation
> of this resource" requests use the same semantic (i.e.  GET in HTTP).
> Tim talks about this[1] as one of his "axioms".

I think it is important to differentiate between things that the
architectural style does not allow (constraints) and things that
it allows but assumes nobody will do.  Tim has a lot of axioms
that are, at best, personal preferences for a rational universe.
Universality is one of them -- the principle that doing it well
enough in one place suggests that nobody else should duplicate
the same functionality, since duplication can be harmful.

> The "uniform interface" constraint doesn't appear to cover it, as there
> may exist many different uniform semantics as part of a single 
> interface
> which could mean "give me a representation" ("RETRIEVE", "SNARF",
> "GRAB", etc..).  I can't see how any of the other constraints would
> prevent this either.
>
> Surely I'm missing something here.  Thoughts?  Roy (when you have time 
> -
> no urgency)?
>
>  [1] http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/Axioms.html#GET2

Nope, that's about right.  Should the architectural style prevent
people from shooting themselves in the foot, or simply note the
advantages of using one verb for each meaning?  I don't have an
answer to that one.

....Roy

Post ID:3697
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>

On Thu, May 22, 2003 at 03:00:41PM -0700, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> Nope, that's about right.  Should the architectural style prevent
> people from shooting themselves in the foot, or simply note the
> advantages of using one verb for each meaning?  I don't have an
> answer to that one.

Sure, that's fair enough.  But given that so many people are as excited
about Web services as they are, perhaps we shouldn't underestimate some
folks' proclivity for shooting feet? 8-)

MB

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3699
Sender:"Hugh Winkler" <hwinkler99@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-26 18:46:18
Subject:Re: Documenting REST resource models
Message:

[Sorry Jeff, I first posted a reply but sent it to you alone not the 
list]


It seems like RDF Schema would be a good way to describe any URI 
based web service. For the case of simple GET, you would simply 
supply RDFS describing your schema. For the case of PUT/POST/GET 
with query parameters, you could invent a REST RDF vocabulary 
describing the accepted and returned documents. Below would be a 
description of a reservations service:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" 
xmlns:rdfs="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#" 
xmlns:rest="http://hughw.net/20030524/rest-schema#">
	<rest:Service 
rdf:about="http://www.bigreservations.com/service">
		<rest:Method>POST</rest:Method>
		<rest:Accept rdf:type="#ReservationRequest"/>
		<rest:Response rdf:type="#ReservationResponse"/>
	</rest:Service>
	<rdfs:Class rdf:ID="ReservationRequest"/>
	<rdfs:Class rdf:ID="ReservationResponse"/>
	<rdfs:Class rdf:ID="CustomerID"/>
	<rdfs:Class rdf:ID="FlightID"/>
	<rdfs:Class rdf:ID="ReservationID"/>
	<rdf:Property rdf:ID="Customer">
		<rdfs:domain rdf:resource="#ReservationRequest"/>
		<rdfs:range rdf:resource="#CustomerID"/>
	</rdf:Property>
	<rdf:Property rdf:ID="Flight">
		<rdfs:domain rdf:resource="#ReservationRequest"/>
		<rdfs:range rdf:resource="#FlightID"/>
	</rdf:Property>
	<rdf:Property rdf:ID="Reservation">
		<rdfs:domain rdf:resource="#ReservationResponse"/>
		<rdfs:range rdf:resource="#ReservationID"/>
	</rdf:Property>
</rdf:RDF>

You would have to design markup describing how to map e.g. the 
ReservationResponse class to some xml schema. (Mapping Definition 
Language is one approach to that problem, could be overkill here).



--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Bone <jbone@d...> wrote:
...snip...
> the set of resources that are available
> i.e. the permutations of URIs that are allowed / meaningful
> the set of methods each one takes
> for POST and PUT, the formats and constraints of allowed input
> descriptions of representations / result codes returned by each 
method 
> / input permutation per resource

> jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3700
Sender:"Hugh Winkler" <hughw@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-28 20:00:53
Subject:Re: Why SSL is not enough?
Message:

 

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Kaleem Aziz <kaleemaziz@y...> wrote:
> http://www.xml.com/pub/a/ws/2003/01/15/ends.html


SSL is just fine for 99.9% of real world applications. And that
includes strategic business to business integration services. Many
businesses today run RosettaNet over SSL (I'm tempted to say most RN
implementations do but all I can say is 100% of my small sample [4] do).

The article suggests that using SSL makes it impossible to implement
non-repudiation schemes because you can't get at the encrypted bits.
But non-repudiation schemes I have dealt with of rely on digesting the
plain text of the message. You can send a signed multipart message or
use XMLDSIG across SSL and that is as reliable a nonrepudiation scheme
as any -- you don't need to digest the encrypted bits. 

As far as encryption goes, few scenarios gain anything from encrypting
the application level message as opposed to encrypting at the
transport level. The endpoint argument isn't really very interesting.
The article says ISPs often can't set up a multihomed server properly.
Set up a new endpoint or get a competent ISP! And I mean, are you
really running this strategic business app on a multihomed server your
ISP configures?


Hugh





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3701
Sender:Hugh Winkler <hughw@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-05-29 18:10:06
Subject:Design question
Message:

Say you have a query service that returns a bag of items, e.g.

http://myserver/select-items?color=blue

Ignoring performance issues for a moment, would it be more RESTful to 
return the  "item" representations themselves, or to return  URIs where 
the caller may retrieve them?

Consider whether the list of items specified by 
"http://myserver/select-items?color=blue" changes over time. Seems like 
if the list *does* change,  returning the URIs gives the client a way to 
retrieve those items later even if the query no longer returns them 
(e.g. a discontinued item). If the list *doesn't* change, any advantage 
to returning URIs rather than the representations seems a little less 
obvious... and then if you bring performance back into the calculation, 
returning URIs implies at least another round trip.

Thanks to anyone who can comment on this issue.

Hugh





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3702
Sender:"grimlinda" <grimlinda@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-05 16:48:48
Subject:Java support for WSDL http bindings
Message:

I'm new to the group and like most newbies, am full of questions.  
The one most pressing to me at the moment is that, while I don't 
much care for SOAP and prefer a URI-based approach to services, I do 
see a need for something WSDL-like to support discovery and service 
registration.  What I am looking for is a Java tool that will take 
in a WSDL with URL bindings and generate an easy to use interface 
object to populate appropriate parameters in the http URI.

This object would provide methods 
like "getParameterList", "getParameterType", "setParmeter
(parmname)", etc.  Eventually, I'm looking at being able to resolve 
semantic differences between the requestor's vocabulary and the 
service provider vocabulary, but that's down the road.

I am happy to write the class  if it doesn't already exist, but was 
wondering if there were any tools out there for this sort of thing?  
SOAP seems to have them (it really needs them- otherwise no one 
would use it), but the URL bindings option in WSDL does not seem to 
have any tool support.

Help!  And does any of this make sense?

Linda





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3703
Sender:"sem_antico" <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-09 13:59:27
Subject:Re: Design question
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Hugh Winkler <hughw@h...> wrote:
> Say you have a query service that returns a bag of items, e.g.
> 
> http://myserver/select-items?color=blue
> 
> Ignoring performance issues for a moment, would it be more RESTful to 
> return the  "item" representations themselves, or to return  URIs where 
> the caller may retrieve them?
Either pattern is RESTful as far as I can see.
> 
> Consider whether the list of items specified by 
> "http://myserver/select-items?color=blue" changes over time. Seems like 
> if the list *does* change,  returning the URIs gives the client a
way to 
> retrieve those items later even if the query no longer returns them 
> (e.g. a discontinued item). If the list *doesn't* change, any advantage 
> to returning URIs rather than the representations seems a little less 
> obvious... and then if you bring performance back into the calculation, 
> returning URIs implies at least another round trip.

It all depends on your application requirements. There is a general
pattern here which I've seen a number of times. One possible solution
you have not mentioned is to return a list of items *together* with
the URIs that can be used to address those items individually - then
you get all the advantages of both approaches.

This is an example what I think of as a container GET pattern - do you
serailise the contents of the container, or just return a list of
pointers to each contained resource?

> 
> Thanks to anyone who can comment on this issue.
> 
> Hugh





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3704
Sender:"gattaca15pcr" <gattaca15pcr@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-12 14:25:03
Subject:Nesting containers to a depth of ?
Message:

Can anyone give me some advice on the following...

I'm attempting to define REST-style interface for a system delivering 
genomic map data.  

Central to my design is the possibility of maps nesting one within 
the other. Thus a map is, potentially, a composite of other maps. 
Furthermore there may be many levels of nesting.  My question is, how 
can traversal up an down this hierarchy be carried out in a REST-ful 
manner? To illustrate:

http://bioinformatics/Map - returns details list of all maps

<Maps>
	<Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1">
		<label>Chromosome 1</label>
		<locations 
href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location"/>
	</Map>
	... thousands of Map nodes ...
	<Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
		<label>Chromosome Z</label>
		<locations 
href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location"/>
	</Map>
</Maps>
		 

http://bioinformatics/Map/123 - returns a specific map
<Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
	<label>Clone Z</label>
	<locations href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123/Location"/>
</Map>

Let's suppose that http://bioinformatics/Map/1 contains other maps 
(e.g. http://bioinformatics/Map/123). At present the way to retrieve 
a list of the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1 is to 
issue a GET to http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location. This returns a 
list of positional Locations on the map (i.e coordinates). Embedded 
within these locations are links to the parent map and the mappable 
(i.e. the Map located at this position):

<Locations>
	<Location href="...">
		.... 
	<Location>
	.... thousands of Location nodes ...
	<Location href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location/10">
		<position>0.2</position>
		<map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1"/>
		<mappable href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123"/>
	</Location>
</Locations>

Using the links provided in a Location node it should be possible to 
traverse the graph of Maps.

To my mind this is consistent with the REST-ful idea of gradually 
revealing data. Applications wishing to use the data should certainly 
be relatively simple to write and the consistency of the interface 
appeals to me. However, this scheme has the disadvantage of, 
potentially, requiring many GET requests to traverse the graph. This 
is mainly because the 'hierarchy' is not a simple tree or forest - a 
map be contained by more than one map. While mutliple GET's shouldn't 
be an issue for any client keeping a connection to the server open, 
I'd like to avoid any such requirement. Thus, I'd like to extend the 
interface such that it is possible to traverse the graph of Maps, 
bypassing the intermediate step of accessing Locations (the Location 
data may not be of much interest to a client in any case). Is there 
any sensible way to represent such a traversal? So far I've thought 
of defining two new resources, Maps ( = Containers) and Mappables ( = 
Contents), to make such traversal possible. By specifying in the URI 
the resource to which movement should be relative, traversal up or 
down the hierarchy should be possible. For example:


http://bionformatics/Maps/Map/123  - would return a list of Maps that 
contain http://bioinformatics/Map/123.

and

http://bioinformatics/Mappables/Map/1 - would return a list of all 
the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1


Does this scheme make sense? Although it seems distinctly un-REST 
like, it does allow me to do what I want to do. Mmmm... should I even 
want to do what I want to do?

Thanks in advance.


Richard





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3705
Sender:"Narayan D. Iyengar" <ndevarajan@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-13 14:37:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nesting containers to a depth of ?
Message:

Hi Richard

My comments are:

1. The presence of location elements (that represent a specific schema design) in the web pages implies knowledge of implementation details, which goes against the grain of REST-ful architectures. Hence, to eliminate this, each web page should only contain (apart from other static, formatting and similar content) URIs to Resources. When you "click" on a URI, that "opens" another web page containing yet some more links, and so on. How the web page is generated and how it obtains access to the resources should be completely hidden from the "users". Thus, details of your schema or interfaces should not appear in your page design.

2. Given this, you may probably want to refactor your code so that the implementation details are moved out of the REST-ful "pages" (that represent the web service you are making available).

Does this make sense, or am I missing the point?

Narayan Iyengar
 

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: gattaca15pcr 
  To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, June 12, 2003 10:25 AM
  Subject: [rest-discuss] Nesting containers to a depth of ?


  Can anyone give me some advice on the following...

  I'm attempting to define REST-style interface for a system delivering 
  genomic map data.  

  Central to my design is the possibility of maps nesting one within 
  the other. Thus a map is, potentially, a composite of other maps. 
  Furthermore there may be many levels of nesting.  My question is, how 
  can traversal up an down this hierarchy be carried out in a REST-ful 
  manner? To illustrate:

  http://bioinformatics/Map - returns details list of all maps

  <Maps>
        <Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1">
              <label>Chromosome 1</label>
              <locations 
  href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location"/>
        </Map>
        ... thousands of Map nodes ...
        <Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
              <label>Chromosome Z</label>
              <locations 
  href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location"/>
        </Map>
  </Maps>
              

  http://bioinformatics/Map/123 - returns a specific map
  <Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
        <label>Clone Z</label>
        <locations href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123/Location"/>
  </Map>

  Let's suppose that http://bioinformatics/Map/1 contains other maps 
  (e.g. http://bioinformatics/Map/123). At present the way to retrieve 
  a list of the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1 is to 
  issue a GET to http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location. This returns a 
  list of positional Locations on the map (i.e coordinates). Embedded 
  within these locations are links to the parent map and the mappable 
  (i.e. the Map located at this position):

  <Locations>
        <Location href="...">
              .... 
        <Location>
        .... thousands of Location nodes ...
        <Location href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location/10">
              <position>0.2</position>
              <map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1"/>
              <mappable href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123"/>
        </Location>
  </Locations>

  Using the links provided in a Location node it should be possible to 
  traverse the graph of Maps.

  To my mind this is consistent with the REST-ful idea of gradually 
  revealing data. Applications wishing to use the data should certainly 
  be relatively simple to write and the consistency of the interface 
  appeals to me. However, this scheme has the disadvantage of, 
  potentially, requiring many GET requests to traverse the graph. This 
  is mainly because the 'hierarchy' is not a simple tree or forest - a 
  map be contained by more than one map. While mutliple GET's shouldn't 
  be an issue for any client keeping a connection to the server open, 
  I'd like to avoid any such requirement. Thus, I'd like to extend the 
  interface such that it is possible to traverse the graph of Maps, 
  bypassing the intermediate step of accessing Locations (the Location 
  data may not be of much interest to a client in any case). Is there 
  any sensible way to represent such a traversal? So far I've thought 
  of defining two new resources, Maps ( = Containers) and Mappables ( = 
  Contents), to make such traversal possible. By specifying in the URI 
  the resource to which movement should be relative, traversal up or 
  down the hierarchy should be possible. For example:


  http://bionformatics/Maps/Map/123  - would return a list of Maps that 
  contain http://bioinformatics/Map/123.

  and

  http://bioinformatics/Mappables/Map/1 - would return a list of all 
  the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1


  Does this scheme make sense? Although it seems distinctly un-REST 
  like, it does allow me to do what I want to do. Mmmm... should I even 
  want to do what I want to do?

  Thanks in advance.


  Richard

Post ID:3706
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-13 15:24:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Nesting containers to a depth of ?
Message:

I don't think there's anything wrong with the scheme Richard proposed.  If
users
have a mental model of these maps, then I see nothing wrong with exposing
them in
all their bizarre containment glory through a REST interface.  Even if they
don't
start out with that mental model, it's valid to introduce it as an access
paradigm
to aid the client in expressing intent.

The one quibble I have with Richard's proposal is mainly syntactic.

>http://bionformatics/Maps/Map/123  - would return a list of Maps that
>contain http://bioinformatics/Map/123.

I think more in terms of http://bionformatics/Map/123/Parents
(or some other suitable noun in place of "Parents").

>and

>http://bioinformatics/Mappables/Map/1 - would return a list of all
>the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1

And the corresponding http://bionformatics/Map/1/Children
(or some such suitable noun)

In other words, the conceptual hierarchy and the names used in it
can include inversions of the normalized view of the space, and there's
no law against having multiple names for the same resource, either.

Walden





----- Original Message ----- 
From: Narayan D. Iyengar
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com ; gattaca15pcr
Sent: Friday, June 13, 2003 10:37 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Nesting containers to a depth of ?


Hi Richard

My comments are:

1. The presence of location elements (that represent a specific schema
design) in the web pages implies knowledge of implementation details, which
goes against the grain of REST-ful architectures. Hence, to eliminate this,
each web page should only contain (apart from other static, formatting and
similar content) URIs to Resources. When you "click" on a URI, that "opens"
another web page containing yet some more links, and so on. How the web page
is generated and how it obtains access to the resources should be completely
hidden from the "users". Thus, details of your schema or interfaces should
not appear in your page design.

2. Given this, you may probably want to refactor your code so that the
implementation details are moved out of the REST-ful "pages" (that represent
the web service you are making available).

Does this make sense, or am I missing the point?

Narayan Iyengar


----- Original Message ----- 
From: gattaca15pcr
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, June 12, 2003 10:25 AM
Subject: [rest-discuss] Nesting containers to a depth of ?


Can anyone give me some advice on the following...

I'm attempting to define REST-style interface for a system delivering
genomic map data.

Central to my design is the possibility of maps nesting one within
the other. Thus a map is, potentially, a composite of other maps.
Furthermore there may be many levels of nesting.  My question is, how
can traversal up an down this hierarchy be carried out in a REST-ful
manner? To illustrate:

http://bioinformatics/Map - returns details list of all maps

<Maps>
      <Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1">
            <label>Chromosome 1</label>
            <locations
href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location"/>
      </Map>
      ... thousands of Map nodes ...
      <Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
            <label>Chromosome Z</label>
            <locations
href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location"/>
      </Map>
</Maps>


http://bioinformatics/Map/123 - returns a specific map
<Map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
      <label>Clone Z</label>
      <locations href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123/Location"/>
</Map>

Let's suppose that http://bioinformatics/Map/1 contains other maps
(e.g. http://bioinformatics/Map/123). At present the way to retrieve
a list of the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1 is to
issue a GET to http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location. This returns a
list of positional Locations on the map (i.e coordinates). Embedded
within these locations are links to the parent map and the mappable
(i.e. the Map located at this position):

<Locations>
      <Location href="...">
            ....
      <Location>
      .... thousands of Location nodes ...
      <Location href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location/10">
            <position>0.2</position>
            <map href="http://bioinformatics/Map/1"/>
            <mappable href="http://bioinformatics/Map/123"/>
      </Location>
</Locations>

Using the links provided in a Location node it should be possible to
traverse the graph of Maps.

To my mind this is consistent with the REST-ful idea of gradually
revealing data. Applications wishing to use the data should certainly
be relatively simple to write and the consistency of the interface
appeals to me. However, this scheme has the disadvantage of,
potentially, requiring many GET requests to traverse the graph. This
is mainly because the 'hierarchy' is not a simple tree or forest - a
map be contained by more than one map. While mutliple GET's shouldn't
be an issue for any client keeping a connection to the server open,
I'd like to avoid any such requirement. Thus, I'd like to extend the
interface such that it is possible to traverse the graph of Maps,
bypassing the intermediate step of accessing Locations (the Location
data may not be of much interest to a client in any case). Is there
any sensible way to represent such a traversal? So far I've thought
of defining two new resources, Maps ( = Containers) and Mappables ( =
Contents), to make such traversal possible. By specifying in the URI
the resource to which movement should be relative, traversal up or
down the hierarchy should be possible. For example:


http://bionformatics/Maps/Map/123  - would return a list of Maps that
contain http://bioinformatics/Map/123.

and

http://bioinformatics/Mappables/Map/1 - would return a list of all
the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1


Does this scheme make sense? Although it seems distinctly un-REST
like, it does allow me to do what I want to do. Mmmm... should I even
want to do what I want to do?

Thanks in advance.


Richard

Post ID:3707
Sender:"gattaca15pcr" <gattaca15pcr@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-16 15:38:31
Subject:Re: Nesting containers to a depth of ?
Message:

Walden, Narayan

Thanks for the feedback. The point about syntax is appreciated. In 
fact I'd tried (probably mistakenly and ham fistedly) to simplify the 
issue when posting... The real interface uses Children, Siblings, and 
Parents as means of traversing the graph. Within the domain I'm 
concerned with such nouns can have various meanings and can end up 
confusing matters. Nonetheless, they seem to be appropriate in this 
case. It nice to have my thinking confirmed.

With respect to the elimination of Location elements, I agree that 
the ideal would be to remove them. For historical reasons they serve 
more than one purpose at present. However, pragmatism and time 
constraints mean that I'll maintain them for now, possibly splitting 
the geometric information from the links at a later date. Advice 
noted and filed for reference.

Regards

Richard

Post ID:3708
Sender:Gary Lawrence Murphy <garym@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-25 19:36:41
Subject:OT: RESTful GIS?
Message:

>>>>> "g" == gattaca15pcr  <gattaca15pcr@...> writes:

    g> I'm attempting to define REST-style interface for a system
    g> delivering genomic map data.

This is off-topic and I only ask because everyone here is already on
the lookout for REST-style implementations: Anyone know of any GIS
packages/vendors with an HTTP rest-like interface for adding point or
area data?  I found MapCloud's geoCette (http://www.freshmaps.net/)
but it's .Net based.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3709
Sender:"joujans" <hwlgw@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-06-30 17:37:42
Subject:cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

First of all, excuse my english, I am dutch.  I joined this group 
because I am interested in REST, there seem to be several good ideas 
here.

I have a webservice that is something like an online civilization 
game.  Users can conquer land, cities, build things there, explore 
maps, etc.  How do you design something like that RESTful?  Can 
something like that be done?  I am using Python for cgi scripts, 
generating HTML with CSS inline (by means of style attributes).  The 
main thing I don't understand is how to give a player access to 
his/her cities, and denying other players access to those cities.  
HTTPS could be available.  As it is now, the webapplication starts 
with asking a username+password combo, and as I understand it that 
is already against REST principles?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3710
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 09:21:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

> As it is now, the webapplication starts
> with asking a username+password combo, and as I understand it that
> is already against REST principles?

No, that is not against REST principles.  Access control and 
authorization
are the normal way of doing user-specific services.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3711
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 14:37:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday 01 July 2003 05:21, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> > As it is now, the webapplication starts
> > with asking a username+password combo, and as I understand it that
> > is already against REST principles?
>
> No, that is not against REST principles.  Access control and
> authorization
> are the normal way of doing user-specific services.

I am going to make an argument otherwise.

In section 5.2.1.1 of your dissertation, you open with:

"The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any
information that can be named can be a resource: ..."

Using an ACL means that the information cannot be named using a
URI (assuming you do not wish to abdicate your entire user
account). Therefore, this information is not a resource.
Therefore, the application is not RESTful. Conclusion: ACLs are
not RESTful.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3712
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 15:33:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

> I am going to make an argument otherwise.
>
> In section 5.2.1.1 of your dissertation, you open with:
>
> "The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any
> information that can be named can be a resource: ..."
>
> Using an ACL means that the information cannot be named using a
> URI (assuming you do not wish to abdicate your entire user
> account).

The URI identifies the resource, not the information that is
sent in response to a GET on that resource.  As such, I don't
understand what you mean by abdicating the user account.

>  Therefore, this information is not a resource.

It isn't.  The mapping defined by the origin server is the resource.
A server can and will take into account the entire request when
determining which representation should be sent in response to
a request, just as it does so for determining whether the response
should be 200 or 401.

> Therefore, the application is not RESTful. Conclusion: ACLs are
> not RESTful.

That is a bizarre conclusion.  If that were the case, I would have put
a section in the dissertation explaining why one of the central features
of HTTP isn't modeled by REST.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3713
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 15:41:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday 01 July 2003 11:33, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> > I am going to make an argument otherwise.
> >
> > In section 5.2.1.1 of your dissertation, you open with:
> >
> > "The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any
> > information that can be named can be a resource: ..."
> >
> > Using an ACL means that the information cannot be named using a
> > URI (assuming you do not wish to abdicate your entire user
> > account).
>
> The URI identifies the resource, not the information that is
> sent in response to a GET on that resource.

I used the term "information" because that is the term you used in
the quoted section of your dissertation.

> As such, I don't
> understand what you mean by abdicating the user account.

In the original email, you wrote:

> No, that is not against REST principles.  Access control and
> authorization
> are the normal way of doing user-specific services.

If HTTP Auth is used to make a user-specific service, the
resulting "resource" is named using the combination of the URI
and the username + password. The URI alone cannot be used to name
the "resource". This means the "resource" is not a real resource.
It is not part of the global URI namespace.

If the user were willing to abdicate their entire user account,
they could use the <userinfo> part of the URI syntax to include
their username + password in the URI. I am assuming that this is
not a viable option.

As a simple demonstration of this, note that it not feasible for
you to create hyperlinks to any of the "resources" in your online
bank account. This is true despite the fact that you have access
to these "resources", using a normal WWW client. The failure of
this application to obey REST design principles has prevented the
user from sharing information in the normal WWW way.

> >  Therefore, this information is not a resource.
>
> It isn't.  The mapping defined by the origin server is the resource.
> A server can and will take into account the entire request when
> determining which representation should be sent in response to
> a request, just as it does so for determining whether the response
> should be 200 or 401.

The "resource" that is the user-specific resource is not a
resource. You seem to be saying that it is RESTful for the origin
server to say the resource is the conglomeration of all user's
user-specific resources. If you take this stance, you diminish the
power of REST, since the web of resources is central to REST.
Making everything one big resource defeats this.

This argument is closely related to the REST argument against
using proprietary identifiers inside the body of a request. The
REST view is that the URI is *THE* identifier. This is necessary
to enable hyperlinks.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3714
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 17:26:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday, July 1, 2003, at 08:41  AM, Tyler Close wrote:

> On Tuesday 01 July 2003 11:33, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
>>> I am going to make an argument otherwise.
>>>
>>> In section 5.2.1.1 of your dissertation, you open with:
>>>
>>> "The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any
>>> information that can be named can be a resource: ..."
>>>
>>> Using an ACL means that the information cannot be named using a
>>> URI (assuming you do not wish to abdicate your entire user
>>> account).
>>
>> The URI identifies the resource, not the information that is
>> sent in response to a GET on that resource.
>
> I used the term "information" because that is the term you used in
> the quoted section of your dissertation.

It isn't the *only* information in REST.  The identified information
is an abstraction. If I have a link to

    http://bigbank.com/services/myaccount

then it is identifying the same abstraction regardless of the number
of different users that might receive different bytes in response
to successfully authenticating and accessing that resource via GET.

>
>> As such, I don't
>> understand what you mean by abdicating the user account.
>
> In the original email, you wrote:
>
>> No, that is not against REST principles.  Access control and
>> authorization
>> are the normal way of doing user-specific services.
>
> If HTTP Auth is used to make a user-specific service, the
> resulting "resource" is named using the combination of the URI
> and the username + password. The URI alone cannot be used to name
> the "resource". This means the "resource" is not a real resource.
> It is not part of the global URI namespace.

I think you need to go back and figure out what "resource" means
instead of assuming that it is the information resulting from
a request.

> If the user were willing to abdicate their entire user account,
> they could use the <userinfo> part of the URI syntax to include
> their username + password in the URI. I am assuming that this is
> not a viable option.

Right, it isn't.  But do you see why the URI supplied above is not
user-specific even though its response may be?  Likewise, the URI

    http://bigbank.com/services/account/1234565432

is not user-specific even if only one user in the universe has
access rights to GET responses on that URI.

> As a simple demonstration of this, note that it not feasible for
> you to create hyperlinks to any of the "resources" in your online
> bank account. This is true despite the fact that you have access
> to these "resources", using a normal WWW client. The failure of
> this application to obey REST design principles has prevented the
> user from sharing information in the normal WWW way.

No, that isn't true in general -- it depends entirely upon how the
app UI was designed.  Most such systems use a frame or an appserver
session that hides the URI; that isn't RESTful, but it has nothing
to so with the access control part.

>>>  Therefore, this information is not a resource.
>>
>> It isn't.  The mapping defined by the origin server is the resource.
>> A server can and will take into account the entire request when
>> determining which representation should be sent in response to
>> a request, just as it does so for determining whether the response
>> should be 200 or 401.
>
> The "resource" that is the user-specific resource is not a
> resource. You seem to be saying that it is RESTful for the origin
> server to say the resource is the conglomeration of all user's
> user-specific resources. If you take this stance, you diminish the
> power of REST, since the web of resources is central to REST.
> Making everything one big resource defeats this.

It doesn't defeat anything that wasn't already defeated by the
nature of the application: the page cannot be placed in a
shared cached.

The purpose of REST is to model how the Web is supposed to work.
If I were to take the stance that access control doesn't fit the
REST model, then it wouldn't be the right model.  User-specific
responses via access control are no different than negotiated
response by conneg, except that access-controlled resources
default to not-shared-cacheable.

> This argument is closely related to the REST argument against
> using proprietary identifiers inside the body of a request. The
> REST view is that the URI is *THE* identifier. This is necessary
> to enable hyperlinks.

The URI is still *THE* identifier.  It identifies the same thing
regardless of who uses the URI.  But that has only an indirect
relation to the information returned in response to GET on that
resource.  If the application wishes to provide an account-specific
URI, such as the second one above, then it can certainly choose
to do so via a redirect after the initial access control exchange.
However, that doesn't make it any more (or less) RESTful.

A related example is

     file://localhost/etc/host

What is that resource?  If you think it is the file on your own
Unix-based system, you would be mistaken.  URIs identify interfaces,
not implementations.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3715
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 18:51:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday 01 July 2003 13:26, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> It isn't the *only* information in REST.  The identified information
> is an abstraction. If I have a link to
>
>     http://bigbank.com/services/myaccount
>
> then it is identifying the same abstraction regardless of the number
> of different users that might receive different bytes in response
> to successfully authenticating and accessing that resource via GET.

In this thread, we are interested in the granularity of the
abstraction identified by the URL.

Let's use a different example to make the point, and then relate
it back to the issues created by HTTP Auth.

Say there is a web site that hosts multiple documents. The web
site has a single URL for its home page.  The site determines
which particular document to respond with based on a string
contained in the body of the request.

We would all agree that such a web site is not RESTful. Since the
site does not present a collection of identifiable resources, it
is impossible to make hyperlinks to particular documents.

HTTP Auth similarly aggregates multiple logical resources under
the same URL. There is a significant loss of granularity in the
abstraction identified by the URL. Just like the RESTless web
site, the HTTP Auth application makes it infeasible to make
hyperlinks to the logical resources.

> User-specific
> responses via access control are no different than negotiated
> response by conneg, except that access-controlled resources
> default to not-shared-cacheable.

This is false. Conneg only changes the format used for the
produced representation, it does not loosen the granularity of the
identified abstraction. When you use HTTP Auth to determine the
user-specific, logical resource for a request, you loosen the
granularity of the URI. If you have 2 users on the same URI, you
do not have a URI for each user-specific logical resource. You
have taken what could be 2 resources and made them one. Combining
multiple logical resources into a single resource is not RESTful;
it defeats the creation of a web.

> The purpose of REST is to model how the Web is supposed to work.
> If I were to take the stance that access control doesn't fit the
> REST model, then it wouldn't be the right model.

This is not the stance I am arguing for. Access control and HTTP
Auth are not synonymous. There are other ways of implementing
access control.

I am arguing that the way access control is popularly implemented
on the WWW is not RESTful. I am making my argument based on the
principles presented in your dissertation.

> It doesn't defeat anything that wasn't already defeated by the
> nature of the application:

This is also false. The application MUST initially give the bank
account holder sole access to the application resources. There is
no reason why the user should not be allowed to voluntarily share
some of those resources with other users. You present a black and
white view of totally private, or totally public resources. This
view is too simple. Many useful resources are subject to
discretionary sharing. HTTP Auth prevents discretionary sharing by
users.  This constraint is not part of generic application
requirements.

To clarify this debate I have broken my argument down into a
progression of simple statements:

1. REST states that important resources should have a URI.
2. A user-specific resource is an important resource.
3. HTTP Auth is used to discriminate between user-specific
resources.
4. This use of HTTP Auth amalgamates user-specific resources under
a shared URI.
5. Such use of HTTP Auth is RESTless.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3716
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 18:56:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday 01 July 2003 14:51, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 16:41 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> > As a simple demonstration of this, note that it not feasible for
> > you to create hyperlinks to any of the "resources" in your online
> > bank account.
>
> excuse me for butting in, but why not?
>
> example:
>
> To: support@...
> From: me@...
> Subject: problem transaction
>
> Hello,
>
> a person i made a payment to yesterday (see
> http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/me@.../payments/123/ ) has
> been seen implementing a RESTless web service.  please cancel
> this payment immediately.
>
> thanks,
> me
>
> --END
>
> i and the bank may be the only people who can GET representations of
> that payment resource, but i don't believe that makes it any less
> feasible to hyperlink to it (as i more or less did in that silly
> email).  a court who wanted to GET a representation could order the
> bank to supply it given that URI.
>
> am i missing the point?

You are very close to the point. You just demonstrated an
important use of giving user-specific resources their own URI. I
am arguing in favour of this.

I am arguing against URIs like
<http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3717
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 18:51:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 16:41 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> As a simple demonstration of this, note that it not feasible for
> you to create hyperlinks to any of the "resources" in your online
> bank account.

excuse me for butting in, but why not?

example:

To: support@...
From: me@...
Subject: problem transaction

Hello,

a person i made a payment to yesterday (see
http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/me@.../payments/123/ ) has
been seen implementing a RESTless web service.  please cancel
this payment immediately.

thanks,
me

--END

i and the bank may be the only people who can GET representations of
that payment resource, but i don't believe that makes it any less
feasible to hyperlink to it (as i more or less did in that silly
email).  a court who wanted to GET a representation could order the
bank to supply it given that URI.

am i missing the point?

-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3718
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 21:04:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday 01 July 2003 14:56, Tyler Close wrote:
> I am arguing against URIs like
> <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
> refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.

For clarity, make this:

I am arguing against URIs like
<http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/payment/12/>, where this URI
refers to the 12th payment made by any user.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3719
Sender:Vincent D Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-01 21:02:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 19:56 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> I am arguing against URIs like
> <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
> refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.

ah.  thanks for that clarification.

i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
access to some server-side state, or a session.

this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).

YMMV.

-v





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3720
Sender:Richard Padley <rest-discuss@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-02 14:06:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

This discussion needs to be much clearer about what the resource in 
question is. AFAICS the example is an 'account' resource.

The URI need not be the only factor in determining /who's/ account we 
are talking about - the server may take into account any of the other 
request headers to determine this. Of course it is easier to understand 
the application if the information is all in the URI, but using other 
headers does not break a REST constraint.

Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 19:56 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
>  > I am arguing against URIs like
>  > <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
>  > refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.
> 
> ah.  thanks for that clarification.
> 
> i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
> clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
> account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
> access to some server-side state, or a session.
> 
> this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
> to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).
> 
> YMMV.
> 
> -v
> 
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3721
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-02 14:52:05
Subject:URIs are RESTful
Message:

On Tue, Jul 01, 2003 at 10:02:16PM +0100, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 19:56 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> > I am arguing against URIs like
> > <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
> > refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.
> 
> ah.  thanks for that clarification.
> 
> i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
> clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
> account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
> access to some server-side state, or a session.
> 
> this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
> to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).

If it's a URI, then there's nothing at all RESTless about it.  That
URI is perfectly fine, even if what you GET from it differs depending
upon who invoked GET, the time of day, etc..  To say otherwise is
to prevent me from identifying a whole class of useful resources,
such as "The person to my right", "The colour of the next traffic
light up ahead", etc..

Mark.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3722
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-02 14:27:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] cgi generating HTML, do you have a REST example ?
Message:

On Tuesday 01 July 2003 17:02, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
> clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
> account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
> access to some server-side state, or a session.
>
> this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
> to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).

..., or HTTP Auth, which is conceptually nothing more than a
specially tagged cookie.

Thank you for adding this clarification to the argument.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3723
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-02 14:45:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

On Wednesday 02 July 2003 10:52, Mark Baker wrote:
> On Tue, Jul 01, 2003 at 10:02:16PM +0100, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> > On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 19:56 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> > > I am arguing against URIs like
> > > <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
> > > refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.
> >
> > ah.  thanks for that clarification.
> >
> > i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
> > clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
> > account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
> > access to some server-side state, or a session.
> >
> > this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
> > to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).
>
> If it's a URI, then there's nothing at all RESTless about it.  That
> URI is perfectly fine, even if what you GET from it differs depending
> upon who invoked GET, the time of day, etc..  To say otherwise is
> to prevent me from identifying a whole class of useful resources,
> such as "The person to my right", "The colour of the next traffic
> light up ahead", etc..

It is not the URI on its own that I am arguing against. It is the
absence of the user-specific resource URI that I am arguing
against. I am arguing against using HTTP Auth as a resource
identification supplement. The example URL is an example of a URL
that requires supplemental resource identification information in
order to provide any function.

An application may very well provide container URLs, in addition
to user-specific URLs, and be RESTful. It is the absence of the
user-specific URLs that is RESTless.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3724
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-02 16:49:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

However, there are issues with the durability of identity.  In the
example of the court case, the URI that identifies "the bank account
of some person currently using a user agent" is not very useful.  Even
the bank couldn't tell whose account that was based only on the URI.

Walden
