-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3725
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-02 17:21:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Tyler, Mark, Roy,

a. Cookie dependent URIs are inherently restless

-or-

b. (http-)authentication  is inherently restless
   (401s considered RESTless)

-or-

c. Cookie/http-auth based *authorization* is inherently restless
   (403s and 405s considered RESTless)

You all appear to be arguing for or against one of
these positions, but it is not clear which.

Here is an example to clarify this distinction.
The choice is between

(1) CookieBank uses cookies or auth to provide
access to a customer payment at URL:

  http://CookieBank.com/accounts/payments/12

(2) RestBank tops CookieBank by making URIs for
specific payments visible in the "Location" bar
so users can forward them to others:

  http://RestBank.com/accounts/user123/payments/12

(3) RestAuthenticateBank claims superiority over
RestBank because it logs who accesses forwarded
URIs and who POSTs "Cancel" or "Confirm" to them:

  http://RestAuthenticateBank.com/accounts/user123/payments/12

(4) AuthorizeBank claims to be the best because
its URIs are unforwardable.  Users who want to
provide their accountant access to a particular
payment can do so.  Those user's can also be sure
that the accountant does not delegate handling to
some intern:

  http://AuthorizeBank.com/account/user123/payments/12?user=user456

  Note: Only the user authenticated as user456 may
  access this URI!

My opinion:

REST and Authentication are orthogonal, but that
people frequently abuse authentication to make it
unrestful.  So, RESTAuthenticateBank is RESTful,
but CookieBank is not.

AuthorizeBank is also RESTful.  There is a
substantive difference between the specificity of
a URI and whether one can access it.  There are no
status codes that indicate that the body returned
is dependent on a cookie/auth.  However, there are
status codes to indicate availability for
particular purposes, e.g. 403 Forbidden, 404 Not
Found, 405 Not Allowed.

CookieBank WOULD be restful if it sent a
content-location header that specified the URI of
the underlying resource.  However, it would be
annoying to have to check for the existence of
this header to determine which URI to forward.
(Question: Is it legal to use content-location
header for this purpose?  If the customer forwards
the HTML version of the resource, can the
accountant access it with an accept: header to
retrieve the PDF version instead?)

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax




On Wed, 2 Jul 2003, Tyler Close wrote:

> On Wednesday 02 July 2003 10:52, Mark Baker wrote:
> > On Tue, Jul 01, 2003 at 10:02:16PM +0100, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> > > On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 19:56 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> > > > I am arguing against URIs like
> > > > <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
> > > > refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.
> > >
> > > ah.  thanks for that clarification.
> > >
> > > i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
> > > clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
> > > account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
> > > access to some server-side state, or a session.
> > >
> > > this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
> > > to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).
> >
> > If it's a URI, then there's nothing at all RESTless about it.  That
> > URI is perfectly fine, even if what you GET from it differs depending
> > upon who invoked GET, the time of day, etc..  To say otherwise is
> > to prevent me from identifying a whole class of useful resources,
> > such as "The person to my right", "The colour of the next traffic
> > light up ahead", etc..
>
> It is not the URI on its own that I am arguing against. It is the
> absence of the user-specific resource URI that I am arguing
> against. I am arguing against using HTTP Auth as a resource
> identification supplement. The example URL is an example of a URL
> that requires supplemental resource identification information in
> order to provide any function.
>
> An application may very well provide container URLs, in addition
> to user-specific URLs, and be RESTful. It is the absence of the
> user-specific URLs that is RESTless.
>
> Tyler
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3726
Sender:Paul Prescod <paul@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 01:42:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Tyler Close wrote:
> On Wednesday 02 July 2003 10:52, Mark Baker wrote:
> ...
> 
> It is not the URI on its own that I am arguing against. It is the
> absence of the user-specific resource URI that I am arguing
> against. I am arguing against using HTTP Auth as a resource
> identification supplement. The example URL is an example of a URL
> that requires supplemental resource identification information in
> order to provide any function.
> 
> An application may very well provide container URLs, in addition
> to user-specific URLs, and be RESTful. It is the absence of the
> user-specific URLs that is RESTless.

Trying to decide how many resources there are behind a URL is kind of an 
angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question. But it is demonstrably necessary 
to make URLs to things that behave differently for different people 
(whether different because of conneg, or language sniffing, or HTTP 
version or username/password or ...)

 From a UI point of view it is important to be clear with the user about 
what the resource is.

But we're somewhat far afield of what the user asked. Can the system 
deny access to other people's cities? The answer is clearly that REST 
allows this. Tyler's favorite security model may not, but REST has no 
problem with it. The issue of whether the user sees their own cities at 
a user-specific URL or user-generic URL is separate.

  Paul Prescod





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3727
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 05:21:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>

> There are no status codes that indicate that the body returned is
dependent on a cookie/auth.
There is the 'Vary' response header. This is used to indicate what request
headers were used to determine the representation returned.
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.44





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3728
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 06:42:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

On Wednesday 02 July 2003 21:42, Paul Prescod wrote:
> Trying to decide how many resources there are behind a URL is kind of an
> angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question.

Unfortunately, REST only says "important" resources should have a
URI. This leaves us with a subjective test.

I take it from your response that you believe user-specific
resources are not "important" and that you see no value in the
example offered by Vincent D. Murphy?

As for the original example, if the application is designed
without user-specific resource URLs, it will not be possible to
even link to cities created by other users. Ah well, foreign
travel is overrated anyways.

> But it is demonstrably necessary
> to make URLs to things that behave differently for different people
> (whether different because of conneg, or language sniffing, or HTTP
> version or username/password or ...)

I would like to see your demonstration that HTTP Auth is necessary
to the REST model. I would also like to see your rebuttal to my
argument that using HTTP Auth to provide user-specific responses
violates REST principles. I provided my argument in 5 simple
steps.  Show me yours.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3729
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 09:21:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

> You all appear to be arguing for or against one of
> these positions, but it is not clear which.

Not really.  I was arguing against a claim that simply is not
true about REST.

> Here is an example to clarify this distinction.
> The choice is between
>
> (1) CookieBank uses cookies or auth to provide
> access to a customer payment at URL:
>
>   http://CookieBank.com/accounts/payments/12

That is not a likely scenario.  Applications working within an
account context will typically use a company-unique payment ID or
one that is account-specific.  A more realistic example is the "top"
page, which is often made account-generic specifically because
the company wants customers to bookmark a single URI for the
initial access point.  It is not identified with an account
number because the user is going to choose from their accounts
after visiting that page.

> (2) RestBank tops CookieBank by making URIs for
> specific payments visible in the "Location" bar
> so users can forward them to others:
>
>   http://RestBank.com/accounts/user123/payments/12

The purpose would be for auditing, not sharing transactions.

> My opinion:
>
> REST and Authentication are orthogonal, but that
> people frequently abuse authentication to make it
> unrestful.  So, RESTAuthenticateBank is RESTful,
> but CookieBank is not.

Authentication is orthogonal.  Cookies are also orthogonal when
they are simply used for content negotiation or authentication.
However, Cookie authentication is not allowed in REST because it
lacks visibility, which causes security problems because the other
components don't know it is sensitive information.

If the semantics of the request is determined by the contents of
authentication or cookies, then that in non-RESTful.  All of the
examples I used were requests with the semantics determined entirely
by the URI and only the response content determined by the request
metadata. That is why the exchange remains RESTful, because the URI
is universally applicable (means the same thing) for other users
even though the content exchanged will be user-specific.  Likewise,
a user-specific URI that is access-controlled for a single user
is universally applicable even if the rest of the universe is denied
access -- the semantics are clear from the request method and URI.

> CookieBank WOULD be restful if it sent a
> content-location header that specified the URI of
> the underlying resource.

No, content-location was an attempt to set the base URI for
embedded relative URIs, but it has not been implemented sufficiently
to make it useful for even that purpose.  It cannot be used to
compensate for multi-semantic URIs, such as a single URI being
used for many different types of request via POST, because
visibility of those actions must occur in the request (prior
to the response being generated).

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3730
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 18:28:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Ok, is use of Vary RESTful and if so is it good REST style?

"Vary" means that resources are addressable via a URI+mimeheaders and not 
just a URI.  I had been under the impression that one of the goals of REST 
was to make sure resources are uniquely identified by their URIs and not 
via some RPC mechanism laundered through HTTP.

-Alex-

--On Wednesday, July 02, 2003 10:21 PM -0700 Mike Dierken 
<mdierken@...> wrote:

>> ----- Original Message -----
>> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
>> There are no status codes that indicate that the body returned is
> dependent on a cookie/auth.
> There is the 'Vary' response header. This is used to indicate what request
> headers were used to determine the representation returned.
> http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.44
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3731
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 18:43:19
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

--On Thursday, July 03, 2003 2:42 AM -0400 Tyler Close <tyler@...> 
wrote:
> I would like to see your demonstration that HTTP Auth is necessary
> to the REST model.

Preempting Paul....

There are occasions when you want to restrict or control who has access to 
a resource.
How would you provide the services of RestAuthenticateBank or AuthorizeBank 
without HTTP-auth or an equivalent mechanism?

Note: You could be right that use of these mechanisms is un-RESTful, but 
that would make REST pretty useless.

-Alex-

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3733
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 19:50:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

I think we are talking about three different
things:

* Availability
* Representation
* Personalization

I think Availability and Representation are
RESTful because there is an automatic way to get
from a URI to a resource via availability and
representation negotiations (aka 40x responses and
accept- headers).

I think personalization is unRestful because there
is no way to negotiate automatically to a
particular resource from a URI.

-Alex-




On Thu, 3 Jul 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:

> The point that keeps slipping away for some reason seems to be
> that it's representations that vary, not resources.  True?
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>

I thought we were talking about an identity crisis, actually.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3735
Sender:Paul Prescod <paul@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 22:40:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Tyler Close wrote:
> On Wednesday 02 July 2003 21:42, Paul Prescod wrote:
> 
>>Trying to decide how many resources there are behind a URL is kind of an
>>angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question.
> 
> Unfortunately, REST only says "important" resources should have a
> URI. This leaves us with a subjective test.

Unfortunately this is unavoidable. Similarly in an OO language you would 
say that important resources should be represented as objects (as 
opposed to being embedded in strings, for example).

> I take it from your response that you believe user-specific
> resources are not "important" and that you see no value in the
> example offered by Vincent D. Murphy?

Not at all. My point is that if Roy defines a service and says that the 
URI "/mybooks" represents the current user's books and that is a single 
resource then consumers have to treat that as the defined interface. You 
can't argue "really that's two resources". It isn't. It is one resource 
that happens to serve very different representations to different users. 
But you could _separately_ make an engineering argument that it would be 
more useful if there were multiple resources. Sure, given a set of goals 
and requirements for a system that is probably the right engineering 
choice. My point was that it is not productive for two people to argue 
whether a given URL has N or M resources behind it.

My rule of thumb is that the thing has multiple resources behind it if 
you have to invent a new addressing scheme to talk about the things, and 
you start embedding those addresses in XML documents or passing them 
around as parameters to APIs etc.

> As for the original example, if the application is designed
> without user-specific resource URLs, it will not be possible to
> even link to cities created by other users. Ah well, foreign
> travel is overrated anyways.

I would presume that every city has its own URL and the only question is 
whether every user is allowed to see every city or whether they get an 
authorization complaint. That's why I think that the discussion about 
user-specific URLs is a little bit of a tangent.

> 1. REST states that important resources should have a URI.

Great.

> 2. A user-specific resource is an important resource.

Great.

> 3. HTTP Auth is used to discriminate between user-specific
> resources.

HTTP auth can be used to do two things. One is to disallow access to a 
resource. The other is to personalize a resource. Let's say I send you a 
URL for a site that we both have accounts for (Slashdot is a perfect 
example). It shows up for you with a blue background because of a 
preference you set and it shows up as green for me. This is good from a 
usability point of view: you are seeing the information as you asked for 
it and I am seeing it as I asked for it. It is the same resource.

Conversely, it could be quite confusing if the URL behaves totally 
differently for me than for you (not just different colours but totally 
different content). On the other hand, if this is part of the contract 
of the resource ("We use your user name as the seed for a random number 
generator before we generate you a random quote") then fair enough.

  Paul Prescod





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3736
Sender:Paul Prescod <paul@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-03 22:55:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> I think we are talking about three different
> things:
> 
> * Availability
> * Representation
> * Personalization
> 
> I think Availability and Representation are
> RESTful because there is an automatic way to get
> from a URI to a resource via availability and
> representation negotiations (aka 40x responses and
> accept- headers).
> 
> I think personalization is unRestful because there
> is no way to negotiate automatically to a
> particular resource from a URI.

You're presuming that each personalized representation is its own 
resource. That's the point that Walden is trying to get across. The 
Slashdot home page is the Slashdot home page whether it is in English or 
French (presuming that Slashdot was not totally US-centric), whether the 
user has asked Google to turn off images or not, whether the user has 
asked Google to use a blue background or a red one.

True, I cannot send you a URL and have you see Slashdot exactly the same 
way I do. If this is important then Slashdot could generate "view" URLs 
that always returns the same view. But this is clearly not important for 
Slashdot so they don't bother.

One issue with the Web is that people tend not to be explicit about what 
resource the URI represents so you are left to guess about the 
universality and longevity of a representation you are looking at. You 
could imagine an interface that would allow end-users to generate a 
URI/resource with the capabilities you want:

"I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page as it was three seconds ago 
with my personalization applied (no matter who the user is)."

versus

"I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page with the latest stories on it 
and my personalization applied (no matter who the user is)."

versus

"I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page with the latest stories on it 
and the user's personalization applied."

This is probably overkill for 99% of all web sites so it isn't common. 
But it shows how to address this personalization versus universality 
issue. Just make some resources personalized and some universal.

  Paul Prescod





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3737
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 01:12:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Paul,

I buy all that, and yet I still have an issue with Tyler's example
of the bank account URI that identifies anyone's account at that
bank, depending on who's fired up their user agent.  To me, the
account (identified by the bank sure enough with its own number)
has identity that transcends the clever "my account" resource,
and the legal system is going to be more interested in the former
than the latter, if issues arise.  Identity is tricky business.

Then there's that temple somewhere in the Orient that moves itself
among two or more eligible plots, but it's the same temple where-
ever it's standing.  The identity of the temple is different for worshipers
than it is for the construction crew, and the HTTP authority is yet
another party to reckon with.

If the person sitting to my left pilfers from my bank account, I want
the identity of both to be irrefutable, so I guess I won't be dragging
any URI into court.

Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Paul Prescod" <paul@...>

> > is no way to negotiate automatically to a
> > particular resource from a URI.

>
> versus
>
> "I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page with the latest stories on it
> and my personalization applied (no matter who the user is)."
>
> versus
>
> "I'd like a URI for the Slashdot home page with the latest stories on it
> and the user's personalization applied."
>
> This is probably overkill for 99% of all web sites so it isn't common.
> But it shows how to address this personalization versus universality
> issue. Just make some resources personalized and some universal.
>
>   Paul Prescod

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3738
Sender:Paul Prescod <paul@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 01:17:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Walden Mathews wrote:
> Paul,
> 
> I buy all that, and yet I still have an issue with Tyler's example
> of the bank account URI that identifies anyone's account at that
> bank, depending on who's fired up their user agent.  To me, the
> account (identified by the bank sure enough with its own number)
> has identity that transcends the clever "my account" resource,
> and the legal system is going to be more interested in the former
> than the latter, if issues arise.  Identity is tricky business.
 > ...
 > If the person sitting to my left pilfers from my bank account, I want
 > the identity of both to be irrefutable, so I guess I won't be dragging
 > any URI into court.

Yes, it seems clear to me that one needs to drag _digitally signed 
messages_ into courts. Let's say you have a very precise (specific) and 
  URI for a single transaction with a single invariant representation. 
Then you go to court and you notice that the transaction has changed. 
The interface said it was invariant but the scoundrels have changed it 
in the database. You'll be out of luck unless you saved a digitally 
signed message with the old value.

  Paul Prescod





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3739
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 01:44:56
Subject:Self-describing data
Message:

The relevant test here is, I believe, whether the state of the resource
is relevant to the meaning of the message/data, or whether its identity
is all that is relevant.  This is a key part of the "self-describing"
umbrella.  As an example, if you were a party to the court action, then
your identity (via your name) on some document is likely relevant.  But
the colour of your hair probably wouldn't be (as an example of what
might be returned from GET on my URI).

In Paul's example there, if the state of the resource was important,
even if it was believed static, it should have been included in the
court documents by value rather than by reference.

MB

On Thu, Jul 03, 2003 at 06:17:46PM -0700, Paul Prescod wrote:
> Walden Mathews wrote:
> > Paul,
> > 
> > I buy all that, and yet I still have an issue with Tyler's example
> > of the bank account URI that identifies anyone's account at that
> > bank, depending on who's fired up their user agent.  To me, the
> > account (identified by the bank sure enough with its own number)
> > has identity that transcends the clever "my account" resource,
> > and the legal system is going to be more interested in the former
> > than the latter, if issues arise.  Identity is tricky business.
>  > ...
>  > If the person sitting to my left pilfers from my bank account, I want
>  > the identity of both to be irrefutable, so I guess I won't be dragging
>  > any URI into court.
> 
> Yes, it seems clear to me that one needs to drag _digitally signed 
> messages_ into courts. Let's say you have a very precise (specific) and 
>   URI for a single transaction with a single invariant representation. 
> Then you go to court and you notice that the transaction has changed. 
> The interface said it was invariant but the scoundrels have changed it 
> in the database. You'll be out of luck unless you saved a digitally 
> signed message with the old value.
> 
>   Paul Prescod
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> 
>  
> 
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ 

-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3740
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 03:56:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Self-describing data
Message:

With all due respect, the signing/court issue is a
red-herring.

In real life, I have a http://universalcard.com
credit card.  When I log in (via a web form), I
arrive at the homepage for my account:

  https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary

This page has my current balance, available
credit, last payment made, and last payment date,
among other information.  There is also a link on
that page to:

  https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary?PRINT_VERSION=Y

I can also link to a printable version of my
unbilled transactions:

  https://www.accountonline.com/UnbilledTrans?PRINT_VERSION=Y

Both printable versions are simply current records
of my account state without any links/buttons to
make changes.

I'd like to be able to provide third parties
(e.g. my accountant) with access to these pages,
but I can't without providing them with control
over my entire account.

The questions are:
1. Is this system RESTful?
2. Would it be RESTful if it used HTTP-auth rather than cookie auth?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

namely "Is a URI to a 'my account' bank account good enough to
work as an identifier in a court of law?".  I think your concern comes
a little later in the process...

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3743
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 14:45:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Self-describing data
Message:

I think the RESTful-ness of these systems falls into a gray
area that exists because the durability of identity is also a gray
area.  You could offer test cases in which two consecutive GETs
on the same URI yield unacceptably different representations,
indicating that no *identity* was backing them.  You can find many
test cases where there seems to be a backing *identity*.  And
notice that there are different perspectives for forming judgments
about when there is backing identity and when there is not.

Is the system unRESTful, or am I a wacky authority with a bent
view of identity that doesn't fit with the rest of the world?  You
can certainly stretch the concept of identity too far for general
consumption.

I don't think the court use case is a red herring.  It represents a
possible worst case scenario for resolving what constitutes an acceptable
notion of identity in a formalized business environment using the web.
In other words, a dot com.

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3744
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 14:59:48
Subject:Identification of resources
Message:

On Thu, Jul 03, 2003 at 11:56:23PM -0400, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> With all due respect, the signing/court issue is a
> red-herring.

Well, it was in response to part of Paul's message, and seems quite
relevant.  It's perhaps only partially relevant to what you ask here
though.

> In real life, I have a http://universalcard.com
> credit card.  When I log in (via a web form), I
> arrive at the homepage for my account:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary
> 
> This page has my current balance, available
> credit, last payment made, and last payment date,
> among other information.  There is also a link on
> that page to:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary?PRINT_VERSION=Y
> 
> I can also link to a printable version of my
> unbilled transactions:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/UnbilledTrans?PRINT_VERSION=Y
> 
> Both printable versions are simply current records
> of my account state without any links/buttons to
> make changes.
> 
> I'd like to be able to provide third parties
> (e.g. my accountant) with access to these pages,
> but I can't without providing them with control
> over my entire account.
> 
> The questions are:
> 1. Is this system RESTful?

Good question.  REST has an interface constraint called "identification
of resources", and there is clearly a resource in your example which is
not being identified ("The summary of Alex's account").  Roy's
dissertation is a bit vague with respect to what this constraint
actually constrains, so it's hard for me to say with any certainty.

But my hunch is that it is still RESTful, but with an obvious bug that
an important resource isn't identified.  It would be unRESTful if,
for example, cookies were used to define the context for interpretation
of that indirect reference (whether that was authentication info, or
anything else).

> 2. Would it be RESTful if it used HTTP-auth rather than cookie auth?

If it used cookie auth, it wouldn't be RESTful.

MB
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3745
Sender:Paul Prescod <paul@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 15:58:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Self-describing data
Message:

S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> With all due respect, the signing/court issue is a
> red-herring.

It isn't a red-herring. It is a separate issue. Someone asked a question 
about it and we answered it!

> ...
> I can also link to a printable version of my
> unbilled transactions:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/UnbilledTrans?PRINT_VERSION=Y
> 
> Both printable versions are simply current records
> of my account state without any links/buttons to
> make changes.
> 
> I'd like to be able to provide third parties
> (e.g. my accountant) with access to these pages,
> but I can't without providing them with control
> over my entire account.
> 
> The questions are:
> 1. Is this system RESTful?
> 2. Would it be RESTful if it used HTTP-auth rather than cookie auth?

1. Yes, it is RESTful, but it is lacking a feature that would be useful 
to you. It would be easy to extend the system with the feature you ask 
for. There could be a button that says: "universal link".

Conversely, if there was _only_ the universal link then your accountant 
could not send you a URI and say: "Click this to see your unbilled 
transactions."

But it is hard to imagine how this would work from a UI point of view. 
There are serious security implications. Would a typical user understand 
how to give someone else read permissions to a single page and not to 
the whole account? Or would the universal link be truly universal (i.e. 
not ACL-protected at all)? Arguably it is easier for you to send the 
page to your accountant by email (send by value rather than send by 
reference).

If identity is confusing to geeks imagine how it would be to end-users 
if we started trying to give them every possible option. (but on the 
other hand, the pervasive concept of "permalink" shows that some people 
are innovating around issues of resource identity UI)

2. In this case I don't see the relevance of which of the two 
authorization regimes you use.

  Paul Prescod





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3746
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 16:13:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Identification of resources
Message:

Crikey, you guys are getting all mixed up.  REST is defined by
my dissertation.  REST is not defined by the TAG discussion or
the W3C's Webarch document or TimBL's design notes.  REST is an
architectural style, not the Web architecture.  Please try
to keep the terminology consistent.

REST does not claim that all important resources must have identifiers.
REST merely requires that actions be applied to an identified resource,
and that identification be in the form of a resource identifier (rather
than, for example, a sequence of events).  Obviously, if you do not
have an identifier for a given resource, then you cannot interact
with it directly in REST, which means you can't do things like share
that specific resource with others or use the URI alone as some form
of audit reference (you can't do that anyway -- you need all of the
information that typically gets stored in a logfile, including time,
method, authentication token, etc.).

That does not in any way imply that all resources are direct or,
conversely, that you cannot have an effect on resources via indirect
actions under the control of the origin server.  Yes, there are
trade-offs between the two, and I personally prefer that multi-valued
resource identifiers always result in a redirection to the more
specific resource before further actions take place, but both are
fully equal parts of the REST model.  They allow interaction to be
vague when specificity is neither desired nor needed, and particularly
when a component has yet to determine the specific URI.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3747
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 18:58:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

On Thursday 03 July 2003 18:40, Paul Prescod wrote:
> But you could _separately_ make an engineering argument that it would be
> more useful if there were multiple resources.

I am making the engineering argument. I am arguing about how to
design RESTful applications.

> My rule of thumb is that the thing has multiple resources behind it if
> you have to invent a new addressing scheme to talk about the things, and
> you start embedding those addresses in XML documents or passing them
> around as parameters to APIs etc.

A username is an identifier that exists in an address space
separate from the URI address space.

> > As for the original example, if the application is designed
> > without user-specific resource URLs, it will not be possible to
> > even link to cities created by other users. Ah well, foreign
> > travel is overrated anyways.
>
> I would presume that every city has its own URL and the only question is
> whether every user is allowed to see every city or whether they get an
> authorization complaint.

You can only make this presumption if there is an established and
adhered to convention that it is RESTless to do otherwise. Are you
ready to declare so?

> > 1. REST states that important resources should have a URI.
>
> Great.

I was very surprised to read that Roy does not agree with us. See:

On Friday 04 July 2003 12:13, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> REST does not claim that all important resources must have identifiers.

Roy, are you saying that the "must" is a "should"? I used
"should", not "must". If you wish to even further weaken the
constraint, I think you should provide clear and objective
guidance on when an important resource need not have an
identifier. If you have already done so, please provide a link.

On Thursday 03 July 2003 18:40, Paul Prescod wrote:
> > 2. A user-specific resource is an important resource.
>
> Great.

If you accept points 1 and 2, the argument is made. Points 3 to 5
simply draw out the consequences of 1 and 2. Given points 1 and 2,
it is RESTless to not give a user-specific resource a URI.

> > 3. HTTP Auth is used to discriminate between user-specific
> > resources.
>
> HTTP auth can be used to do two things. One is to disallow access to a
> resource. The other is to personalize a resource. Let's say I send you a
> URL for a site that we both have accounts for (Slashdot is a perfect
> example). It shows up for you with a blue background because of a
> preference you set and it shows up as green for me. This is good from a
> usability point of view: you are seeing the information as you asked for
> it and I am seeing it as I asked for it. It is the same resource.

Again, I am not arguing against container URLs. I am arguing
against the absence of user-specific URLs.

I am also not arguing that Slashdot should actually implement a
user-specific URL for its home page. I am only arguing that it is
RESTless for Slashdot to not do so. In this case, it is likely
that this RESTless design will have no negative consequences.
This result will not always be the same. The more "important" the
resource, the more likely it is that RESTless design will have
negative consequences. RESTless design of a less "important"
resource may go unnoticed.

I suspect that RESTless design is more of a problem in a web
service than in a web site. A web site may have many appearance
variation resources that are not present in a web service.

Clear rules help us identify potential design problems and avert
them. This is the basis for engineering. You seem to be taking the
stance that a feel-good "anything goes" ruleset should be used.
This leaves REST without a real model or way of evaluating
designs.

It is OK to call things RESTless and still use them. However, if
you are unable to correctly categorize designs, you reduce your
ability to improve your designs. Let's drop the squeamishness
around calling things RESTless.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3748
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 19:37:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Self-describing data
Message:

Sorry, but I don't understand how that question relates to my point.

Mark.

On Fri, Jul 04, 2003 at 10:34:30AM -0400, Walden Mathews wrote:
> How can you subpoena state information with an underspecified
> identifier?  Isn't it always going to resolve to that problem?
> 
> Walden
> 
> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
> To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Thursday, July 03, 2003 9:44 PM
> Subject: [rest-discuss] Self-describing data
> 
> 
> > The relevant test here is, I believe, whether the state of the resource
> > is relevant to the meaning of the message/data, or whether its identity
> > is all that is relevant.  This is a key part of the "self-describing"
> > umbrella.  As an example, if you were a party to the court action, then
> > your identity (via your name) on some document is likely relevant.  But
> > the colour of your hair probably wouldn't be (as an example of what
> > might be returned from GET on my URI).
> >
> > In Paul's example there, if the state of the resource was important,
> > even if it was believed static, it should have been included in the
> > court documents by value rather than by reference.
> >
> > MB





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3749
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 20:26:09
Subject:sharing my banking data
Message:

This has been a very interesting conversation.  For the fun of it, what
about the following architecture:

Premise: I want to access my banking information.  I also want to share bits
of it with my accountant.  The URL for the bank is http://my.bank.


1) I GET http://my.bank/access.  The server returns an HTTP Authentication
challenge
2) I re-submit the request with my credentials. The server authenticates me
and returns a 201 with a Location of http://my.bank/access/12345.

Note:  The returned URL is unique to me.  The HTTP Authentication headers
have no meaning at this point.  The URL has some constraints on its
existance. In this case, it only exists for 5 minutes between requests
(resetting the timer after each request).

3) I GET http://my.bank/access/12345.  The server returns the options
available to me:

    http://my.bank/access/12345/options
    http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts
    http://my.bank/access/12345/reports

4) I GET http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts.  The server returns a list of
accounts:

    http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking
    http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/savings

5) I GET http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking.  The server returns
a list of transactions:

    http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking/456
    http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking/455
    http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking/454

6) I GET http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking/456.  The server
returns the details of the transaction.

7) Also on the screen is an option that says "send this page to:" and an
input box.  I fill in my accountant's e-mail address, and press submit.  The
form is POSTed to http://my.bank/proxy-access.  The form contains two
fields:  the e-mail address and the current page's URL (which was
http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking/456).  The server e-mails the
following URL to my accountant: http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789.

Note:  The link generated for the accountant only provides access to the
given checking entry.  If I had wanted to give him access to my entire
checking account, I would have sent him
"http://my.bank/access/12345/accounts/checking", except that the URL she
would have received would show that page instead, with the contained URLs
being:

    http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789/456
    http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789/455
    http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789/454

The e-mailed URL would have a limited time limit such as 30 minutes, after
which, the link will only return a 404 response or some such.

Now, if I wanted to revoke access, I could just issue a DELETE on the URL.
There isn't even any need to authenicate the DELETE request.  Likewise, if I
wanted to "log out", I could DELETE my own URL.  If I forgot, both URLs
would have a limited lifetime anyhow, at the end of which only a 404
response would be returned.


Obviously, this is a rather simple scenario.  But I think it illustrates a
simple, clean way of handling access in a RESTful manner.  Was this how
others were imagining that it might work?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3750
Sender:Seth Johnson <seth.johnson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 20:24:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

I think there's a great deal to be gained from acknowledging that the
architecture of the Web is largely to create an effective *public* space. 
If a username separate from the URI is RESTless, I personally don't have a
problem with recognizing it.  The availability-of-personalization issue is
really something that arises in the area of private interest issues, like
some web services of the sort we've been discussing here.
Seth Johnson


Tyler Close wrote:
> 
> On Thursday 03 July 2003 18:40, Paul Prescod wrote:
> > But you could _separately_ make an engineering argument that it would be
> > more useful if there were multiple resources.
> 
> I am making the engineering argument. I am arguing about how to
> design RESTful applications.
> 
> > My rule of thumb is that the thing has multiple resources behind it if
> > you have to invent a new addressing scheme to talk about the things, and
> > you start embedding those addresses in XML documents or passing them
> > around as parameters to APIs etc.
> 
> A username is an identifier that exists in an address space
> separate from the URI address space.
> 
> > > As for the original example, if the application is designed
> > > without user-specific resource URLs, it will not be possible to
> > > even link to cities created by other users. Ah well, foreign
> > > travel is overrated anyways.
> >
> > I would presume that every city has its own URL and the only question is
> > whether every user is allowed to see every city or whether they get an
> > authorization complaint.
> 
> You can only make this presumption if there is an established and
> adhered to convention that it is RESTless to do otherwise. Are you
> ready to declare so?
> 
> > > 1. REST states that important resources should have a URI.
> >
> > Great.
> 
> I was very surprised to read that Roy does not agree with us. See:
> 
> On Friday 04 July 2003 12:13, Roy T. Fielding wrote:
> > REST does not claim that all important resources must have identifiers.
> 
> Roy, are you saying that the "must" is a "should"? I used
> "should", not "must". If you wish to even further weaken the
> constraint, I think you should provide clear and objective
> guidance on when an important resource need not have an
> identifier. If you have already done so, please provide a link.
> 
> On Thursday 03 July 2003 18:40, Paul Prescod wrote:
> > > 2. A user-specific resource is an important resource.
> >
> > Great.
> 
> If you accept points 1 and 2, the argument is made. Points 3 to 5
> simply draw out the consequences of 1 and 2. Given points 1 and 2,
> it is RESTless to not give a user-specific resource a URI.
> 
> > > 3. HTTP Auth is used to discriminate between user-specific
> > > resources.
> >
> > HTTP auth can be used to do two things. One is to disallow access to a
> > resource. The other is to personalize a resource. Let's say I send you a
> > URL for a site that we both have accounts for (Slashdot is a perfect
> > example). It shows up for you with a blue background because of a
> > preference you set and it shows up as green for me. This is good from a
> > usability point of view: you are seeing the information as you asked for
> > it and I am seeing it as I asked for it. It is the same resource.
> 
> Again, I am not arguing against container URLs. I am arguing
> against the absence of user-specific URLs.
> 
> I am also not arguing that Slashdot should actually implement a
> user-specific URL for its home page. I am only arguing that it is
> RESTless for Slashdot to not do so. In this case, it is likely
> that this RESTless design will have no negative consequences.
> This result will not always be the same. The more "important" the
> resource, the more likely it is that RESTless design will have
> negative consequences. RESTless design of a less "important"
> resource may go unnoticed.
> 
> I suspect that RESTless design is more of a problem in a web
> service than in a web site. A web site may have many appearance
> variation resources that are not present in a web service.
> 
> Clear rules help us identify potential design problems and avert
> them. This is the basis for engineering. You seem to be taking the
> stance that a feel-good "anything goes" ruleset should be used.
> This leaves REST without a real model or way of evaluating
> designs.
> 
> It is OK to call things RESTless and still use them. However, if
> you are unable to correctly categorize designs, you reduce your
> ability to improve your designs. Let's drop the squeamishness
> around calling things RESTless.
> 
> Tyler

--

I reserve no rights restricting copying, modification or distribution of
this incidentally recorded communication.  Original authorship should be
attributed reasonably, but only so far as such an expectation might hold for
usual practice in ordinary social discourse to which one holds no claim of
exclusive rights.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3751
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-04 04:24:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>


> Ok, is use of Vary RESTful and if so is it good REST style?
>
> "Vary" means that resources are addressable via a URI+mimeheaders and not
> just a URI.
The resource is identified by the URI - the request header(s) were used to
return one of a variety of representations. Using content negotiation
(conneg) the Accept header can be used to as for an image in either GIF or
JPEG format - same resource, different representations. Or use the Accept
header to request XML .vs. HTML. Etc.

> I had been under the impression that one of the goals of REST
> was to make sure resources are uniquely identified by their URIs and not
> via some RPC mechanism laundered through HTTP.
Responding with different variations of a representation are not introducing
extensible methods - no rpc here. Move along. These are not the droids
you're looking for.

>
> -Alex-
>
> --On Wednesday, July 02, 2003 10:21 PM -0700 Mike Dierken
> <mdierken@...> wrote:
>
> >> ----- Original Message -----
> >> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> >
> >> There are no status codes that indicate that the body returned is
> > dependent on a cookie/auth.
> > There is the 'Vary' response header. This is used to indicate what
request
> > headers were used to determine the representation returned.
> > http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.44
> >
>
>
>
> ___________________________________________________________________
> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
>
>
>

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>

>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3752
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-05 04:08:23
Subject:Re: sharing my banking data
Message:

From: "wiki1000" <wiki1000@...>
>
> It is possible also to use other conventions....
>
>
> --- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@s...>
> wrote:
> > This has been a very interesting conversation.  For the fun of it, what
> > about the following architecture:
> >
> > Premise: I want to access my banking information.  I also want to
> share bits
> > of it with my accountant.  The URL for the bank is http://my.bank.
> >
> >
> > 1) I GET http://my.bank/access.  The server returns an HTTP
> Authentication
> > challenge
>
> I think that doing GET to an "anonymous" uri and obtain an invisible
> context after authentication is not restful. Why not doing a GET to:
>
> http://my.bank/private/sj
>
> which asks for credentials (here, sj credentials)?

*sigh* sorry.  This is a mistake.  Originally, Steps 1 returned a web form
and Step 2 was a POST that created the URI.  I changed it to HTTP Auth to
avoid limiting the scope of the example to HTML.  I failed to re-read what I
changed it to, and therefore didn't catch that I was returning a 201 in
response to a GET.  So... let's go back and change that somewhat:

1) I POST my credentials to http://my.bank/access, be this from a web form,
some proprietary xml, etc.  The server authenticates me and returns a 201
with a Location of http://my.bank/access/12345.  (note: the html form could
be retrieved with a GET to http://my.bank/access.)

> > 7) Also on the screen is an option that says "send this page to:" and an
> > input box.  I fill in my accountant's e-mail address, and press
> submit.
>
> What could be done here is first to POST to the URI:
>
> http://my.bank/accountant/sj
>
> an xml document containing the uri :
>
> http://my.bank/private/sj/accounts/checking/456
>
> This POST has for effect to make the corresponding resource available
> as :
>
> http://my.bank/accountant/sj/accounts/checking/456
>
> I could then mail this uri to my accountant.
>
> If an authenticated user try to GET this, it has to be authenticated,
> and if not the user sj himself, has to own the role "accountant".
>
> Of course, the role "private" does not give any right... .

I'm not sure I understand what you are saying here.  I get the bit about
creating the URI, but not the rest.

> > The e-mailed URL would have a limited time limit such as 30 minutes,
> after
> > which, the link will only return a 404 response or some such.
> >
>
> In my mind, this create a state inside the server (a timer). This is
> bad isn't it ?

The timer is not part of the client state.  It's part of the resource state.
It's the client state that the server is not suppose to be maintaining.

By the way, the reason I created the URI instead of using HTTP Auth (or a
cookie or whatever) at all times was partly due to Tyler and his crazy
capabilities-based security model.  :)  I am not sure if I am doing it
right, but the basic idea here was that the bank issued a URI
(http://my.bank/access/12345) with a defined set of capabilities (the
"contract").  I could do anything that's defined, nothing more.  On top of
that, when I want to share part of my access, I ask the bank for another
capability URI (http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789) for that particular bit.
Like the first URI, use is limited to what is defined.  This also means that
I do not have to get my accountant set up with a separate password, flip a
potentially large set of switches to set the security context, etc. just to
give access.  Of course, this is a somewhat weak example, since most people
would likely just copy-n-paste the screen and e-mail it instead of go
through all of this effort.  But in a more complex situation, I see how this
approach could work well (I think).

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3753
Sender:"joujans" <hwlgw@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-05 07:52:49
Subject:Re: sharing my banking data
Message:

> [Seairth Jacobs]
> This has been a very interesting conversation...
> 1) I GET http://my.bank/access.  The server returns an HTTP 
> Authentication challenge...

I am the "OP" and I am surprised how my original question turned 
into this long conversation :-)

I was just asking how to solve a CGI programming problem with Python 
in a RESTful way!

I can not do HTTP authentication from a Python CGI script, can I?  I 
tried to look for examples or to figure it out but I have been 
unsuccessful.  And then somebody explained to me that HTTP auth. is 
not used by banks etc. on the internet, because it is not secure 
enough.  For my civilization like game HTTP auth. could be secure 
enough, but oh well, I don't know how to implement it from a CGI 
script anyway.
  
So I was thinking about setting up the "login" page with HTTPS and 
this then calls a CGI script generating a "sessionID" passed along 
with HIDDEN HTML FORM parameters on every next page, and then all 
the next pages don't need SSL.  The nice thing for me is then that I 
don't have to change source code when the SSL part is turned on 
later.  I can develop it using Apache on my laptop (without SSL).
Or is there a more RESTful way to do it?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3754
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-05 14:47:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Self-describing data
Message:

So you take the fifth? :)

Mark, I think identity without state is a canard.  If you substitute
"sameness"
for "identity", then sans state, there would be nothing to put to the test.

You seem to be arguing that if resource state is important, drag that into
court directly.  I was pointing out that there is a process for doing that,
and it
begins with identification of the thing to be dragged.  So the quality of
identifiers cannot be ignored.

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3755
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-05 15:04:49
Subject:Back to the original topic (was: sharing my banking data)
Message:

From: "joujans" <hwlgw@...>
>
> > [Seairth Jacobs]
> > This has been a very interesting conversation...
> > 1) I GET http://my.bank/access.  The server returns an HTTP
> > Authentication challenge...
>
> I am the "OP" and I am surprised how my original question turned
> into this long conversation :-)

Yeah, that tends to happen here.  :)

> I was just asking how to solve a CGI programming problem with Python
> in a RESTful way!
>
> I can not do HTTP authentication from a Python CGI script, can I?  I
> tried to look for examples or to figure it out but I have been
> unsuccessful.  And then somebody explained to me that HTTP auth. is
> not used by banks etc. on the internet, because it is not secure
> enough.  For my civilization like game HTTP auth. could be secure
> enough, but oh well, I don't know how to implement it from a CGI
> script anyway.

Assuming that all banks use HTTPS, HTTP Auth no less secure than the use of
a session cookie.  The main reason that it's not used (I suspect) is that
the banks cannot control the look of the dialog box.  Another possbility is
that banks (wrongly) believe that HTTP Auth is less secure because it passes
plaintext user/pwd in every request.  But this is no less true of passing
the user/pwd from an HTML form.  The security is in the use of HTTPS.
Certainly, using HTTP Digest Auth (as opposed to Basic) would protect the
password, but the extra measure is pointless if using HTTPS.

One advantage to HTTP Auth (as opposed to an HTML form) is that you can
potentially access any resource in a collection directly instead of going to
a single "entrypoint".  As to whether you can handle HTTP Basic or Digest
Auth through Python CGI, I don't really know.  If you have access to all of
the HTTP request headers, then I'd think you should be able to manually
implement it.  Though it may be necessary to be running a SAPI module
instead of a CGI program...

> So I was thinking about setting up the "login" page with HTTPS and
> this then calls a CGI script generating a "sessionID" passed along
> with HIDDEN HTML FORM parameters on every next page, and then all
> the next pages don't need SSL.  The nice thing for me is then that I
> don't have to change source code when the SSL part is turned on
> later.  I can develop it using Apache on my laptop (without SSL).
> Or is there a more RESTful way to do it?

This technique would be no better than using a session cookie, in my
opinion, and a whole lot more work (how would you handle GET requests?).
Placing the sessionID in the URL's query string would be another way to go.
Of course, there are a good number of opinions go around about what is the
right or wrong way of doing this and it is a far from settled topic.

As for the original topic, could you give a slightly more detailed example
who can and cannot access cities, what access is allowed in those cases, and
how you are currently doing it (or planning on doing it)?

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3756
Sender:x y <wiki1000@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-05 17:12:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: sharing my banking data
Message:

--- Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> wrote:
> From: "wiki1000" <wiki1000@...>
> >
> > It is possible also to use other conventions....
> >
> >
> > --- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Seairth
> Jacobs" <seairth@s...>
> > wrote:
> > > This has been a very interesting conversation. 
> For the fun of it, what
> > > about the following architecture:
> > >
> > > Premise: I want to access my banking
> information.  I also want to
> > share bits
> > > of it with my accountant.  The URL for the bank
> is http://my.bank.
> > >
> > >
> > > 1) I GET http://my.bank/access.  The server
> returns an HTTP
> > Authentication
> > > challenge
> >
> > I think that doing GET to an "anonymous" uri and
> obtain an invisible

> 1) I POST my credentials to http://my.bank/access,
> be this from a web form,

> with a Location of http://my.bank/access/12345. 
> (note: the html form could
> be retrieved with a GET to http://my.bank/access.)

You miss my point, sorry.
I wanted to say that your initial URI is just a "place
holder" for a modal interaction.
In fact, according to what you enter as a user id,
you will get different resources. 

I was suggesting
to directly enter a personalized URI containing 
you login name in it, like: 

http://my.bank/private/sj


> > > 7) Also on the screen is an option that says
> "send this page to:" and an
> > > input box.  I fill in my accountant's e-mail
> address, and press
> > submit.
> >
> > What could be done here is first to POST to the
> URI:
> >
> > http://my.bank/accountant/sj
> >
> > an xml document containing the uri :
> >
> > http://my.bank/private/sj/accounts/checking/456
> >
> > This POST has for effect to make the corresponding
> resource available
> > as :
> >
> > http://my.bank/accountant/sj/accounts/checking/456
> >
> > I could then mail this uri to my accountant.
> >
> > If an authenticated user try to GET this, it has
> to be authenticated,
> > and if not the user sj himself, has to own the
> role "accountant".
> >
> > Of course, the role "private" does not give any
> right... .
> 
> I'm not sure I understand what you are saying here. 
> I get the bit about
> creating the URI, but not the rest.
> 
Well, I mean that I add a simple interaction before,
which simply add the resource you want to share in a
kind of shared folder which can only be seen by users
authenticated with the role "accountant". 

I suppose here that you accountant has this role. 

Of course both the operations can be made in one shot
by the server when you click on "send this page to".

In fact, what I propose here is to encode into URIs 
the owner of the resource (here "sj") along with a
"right"  (here "accountant") usable by non owners. 

I also proposed a simple way to share a personal
resource  (in POSTing to another place). 

> > > The e-mailed URL would have a limited time limit
> such as 30 minutes,
> > after
> > > which, the link will only return a 404 response
> or some such.
> > >
> >
> > In my mind, this create a state inside the server
> (a timer). This is
> > bad isn't it ?
> 
> The timer is not part of the client state.  It's
> part of the resource state.
> It's the client state that the server is not suppose
> to be maintaining.
> 
Yes, but such a timer is a dynamic, in memory
resource, which is very difficult to implement in a
scalable way. It suppose a kind of daemon attached to
the resource.

Imagine a farm of timers managing the state of hundred
such resources...

> By the way, the reason I created the URI instead of
> using HTTP Auth (or a
> cookie or whatever) at all times was partly due to
> Tyler and his crazy
> capabilities-based security model.  :)  I am not
> sure if I am doing it
> right, but the basic idea here was that the bank
> issued a URI
> (http://my.bank/access/12345) with a defined set of
> capabilities (the
> "contract").  I could do anything that's defined,
> nothing more.  On top of
> that, when I want to share part of my access, I ask
> the bank for another
> capability URI (http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789)
> for that particular bit.
> Like the first URI, use is limited to what is
> defined.  This also means that
> I do not have to get my accountant set up with a
> separate password, flip a
> potentially large set of switches to set the
> security context, etc. just to
> give access.  

This is the point: what you want to do is to share
personalized resources without pain. 

However, your solution implies the generation of a
fake URI which has universal validity during its life
time. This is not really secure... 

Of course, this is a somewhat weak
> example, since most people
> would likely just copy-n-paste the screen and e-mail
> it instead of go
> through all of this effort.  But in a more complex
> situation, I see how this
> approach could work well (I think).
> 

I aggree, this is not top notch security. Thats why
it is necessary to impose to the accountant to
authenticate himself before reading a shared URI. 

This also suppose an access control system providing 
roles (or capabilities). I suggested to encode them in
the URI, and to allocate to each registered users a
set of such roles, handled by the server. 

Encoding the "needed roles" in the URI allow a very
efficient check : the access control has simply to get
the available user roles from the authenticated user
profile, and then check that there is one which match
the "role part" of the presented URI. This trick avoid
to store a map resource->role in the server. 

My question was: is this acceptable ? 

Cheers,


__________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
SBC Yahoo! DSL - Now only $29.95 per month!
http://sbc.yahoo.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3757
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-06 04:13:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] sharing my banking data
Message:

From: "x y" <wiki1000@...>
>
> --- Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> wrote:
> >
> > *sigh* sorry.  This is a mistake.  Originally, Steps
> > 1 returned a web form
> > and Step 2 was a POST that created the URI.  I
> > changed it to HTTP Auth to
> > avoid limiting the scope of the example to HTML.  I
> > failed to re-read what I
> > changed it to, and therefore didn't catch that I was
> > returning a 201 in
> > response to a GET.  So... let's go back and change
> > that somewhat:
> >
> > 1) I POST my credentials to http://my.bank/access,
> > be this from a web form,
> > some proprietary xml, etc.  The server authenticates
> > me and returns a 201
> > with a Location of http://my.bank/access/12345.
> > (note: the html form could
> > be retrieved with a GET to http://my.bank/access.)
>
> You miss my point, sorry.
> I wanted to say that your initial URI is just a "place
> holder" for a modal interaction.
> In fact, according to what you enter as a user id,
> you will get different resources.
>
> I was suggesting
> to directly enter a personalized URI containing
> you login name in it, like:
>
> http://my.bank/private/sj

That's fine, if you are going to use something like HTTP Auth the entire
time.  My example was attempting to avoid use of HTTP Auth (except for the
initial authentication).

> > > > The e-mailed URL would have a limited time limit
> > such as 30 minutes,
> > > after
> > > > which, the link will only return a 404 response
> > or some such.
> > > >
> > >
> > > In my mind, this create a state inside the server
> > (a timer). This is
> > > bad isn't it ?
> >
> > The timer is not part of the client state.  It's
> > part of the resource state.
> > It's the client state that the server is not suppose
> > to be maintaining.
> >
> Yes, but such a timer is a dynamic, in memory
> resource, which is very difficult to implement in a
> scalable way. It suppose a kind of daemon attached to
> the resource.
>
> Imagine a farm of timers managing the state of hundred
> such resources...

I don't see why you need timers.  Store an expiration timestamp in the
resource.  On access the the URL, the timestamp is checked.  If expired,
return the appropriate 4xx response.  This method should scale fine.  Also,
caching would not be an issue because if SSL is being used, nothing is
cached anyhow.

> > By the way, the reason I created the URI instead of
> > using HTTP Auth (or a
> > cookie or whatever) at all times was partly due to
> > Tyler and his crazy
> > capabilities-based security model.  :)  I am not
> > sure if I am doing it
> > right, but the basic idea here was that the bank
> > issued a URI
> > (http://my.bank/access/12345) with a defined set of
> > capabilities (the
> > "contract").  I could do anything that's defined,
> > nothing more.  On top of
> > that, when I want to share part of my access, I ask
> > the bank for another
> > capability URI (http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789)
> > for that particular bit.
> > Like the first URI, use is limited to what is
> > defined.  This also means that
> > I do not have to get my accountant set up with a
> > separate password, flip a
> > potentially large set of switches to set the
> > security context, etc. just to
> > give access.
>
> This is the point: what you want to do is to share
> personalized resources without pain.
>
> However, your solution implies the generation of a
> fake URI which has universal validity during its life
> time. This is not really secure...

First, the URI is not fake.  It is a fully functional, legitimate URI.
Second, I do not see why this method isn't secure.  It is every bit as
secure as any of the traditional methods (cookies, HTTP Basic Auth, etc).
The security is provided by the SSL, not the format of the URI.  About the
only thing I can think of is the possibility of someone looking over your
shoulder and writing down the URI.

> Of course, this is a somewhat weak
> > example, since most people
> > would likely just copy-n-paste the screen and e-mail
> > it instead of go
> > through all of this effort.  But in a more complex
> > situation, I see how this
> > approach could work well (I think).
> >
>
> I aggree, this is not top notch security. Thats why
> it is necessary to impose to the accountant to
> authenticate himself before reading a shared URI.

So would the mean that the accountant would have to get an access account
set up with my bank?  Somehow, I doubt that banks are going to want to take
the time to set up all of these accounts just so I can share views of my
transactions with my accountant, my lawyer, or the service rep on the other
end of the phone who refuses to believe that they overcharged me.  Not only
that, it means that my accountant would have to maintain accounts with all
of the banks, stock brokers, etc. that her clients use.  What a pain!  As
long at the generated URI is securely given to the intended recipient, I
don't see where the security issue is.  It would certainly be much easier
for my accountant to get a single encryption certificate with which I could
securely sender her an e-mail.

> Encoding the "needed roles" in the URI allow a very
> efficient check : the access control has simply to get
> the available user roles from the authenticated user
> profile, and then check that there is one which match
> the "role part" of the presented URI. This trick avoid
> to store a map resource->role in the server.

I will have to defer to Tyler on this one.  As I understand it, role-based
security is more prone to security holes than is capability-based security.
However, I come from the practice of a role-based model (good ol' MS
Windows) and am still learning the capability-based model, so my experience
is quite limited.

AND I am perfectly willing to admit that this whole thing could be very
unRESTful.  That's why I'm putting it out there ...

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> > > some proprietary xml, etc.  The server authenticates

> time.  My example was attempting to avoid use of HTTP Auth (except
for the
> initial authentication).

Could you elaborate that ? you mean that you "hide" all uris of your 
sessions with generated keys inserted in each uri and only known by
which receive them ?

> > > > > The e-mailed URL would have a limited time limit
> > > such as 30 minutes,
> > > > after
> > > > > which, the link will only return a 404 response
> > > or some such.
> > > > >
> > > >
> > > > In my mind, this create a state inside the server
> > > (a timer). This is
> > > > bad isn't it ?
> > >
