> > > part of the resource state.
> > > It's the client state that the server is not suppose
> > > to be maintaining.
> > >
> > Yes, but such a timer is a dynamic, in memory
> > resource, which is very difficult to implement in a
> > scalable way. It suppose a kind of daemon attached to
> > the resource.
> >
> > Imagine a farm of timers managing the state of hundred
> > such resources...
> 
> I don't see why you need timers.  Store an expiration timestamp in the
> resource.  On access the the URL, the timestamp is checked.  If expired,
> return the appropriate 4xx response.  This method should scale fine.
 Also,
> caching would not be an issue because if SSL is being used, nothing is
> cached anyhow.

you are right. This suppose however additional data stored with each
resource and SSL used with all uris. This would be server SSL however.

Note that SSL is perhaps not 
the whole story. Data could be encrypted at the application level with
a key only known by the identified recipient. This would allow caching...
> 
> > > By the way, the reason I created the URI instead of
> > > using HTTP Auth (or a
> > > cookie or whatever) at all times was partly due to
> > > Tyler and his crazy
> > > capabilities-based security model.  :)  I am not
> > > sure if I am doing it
> > > right, but the basic idea here was that the bank
> > > issued a URI
> > > (http://my.bank/access/12345) with a defined set of
> > > capabilities (the
> > > "contract").  I could do anything that's defined,
> > > nothing more.  On top of
> > > that, when I want to share part of my access, I ask
> > > the bank for another
> > > capability URI (http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789)
> > > for that particular bit.
> > > Like the first URI, use is limited to what is
> > > defined.  This also means that
> > > I do not have to get my accountant set up with a
> > > separate password, flip a
> > > potentially large set of switches to set the
> > > security context, etc. just to
> > > give access.
> >
> > This is the point: what you want to do is to share
> > personalized resources without pain.
> >
> > However, your solution implies the generation of a
> > fake URI which has universal validity during its life
> > time. This is not really secure...
> 
> First, the URI is not fake.  It is a fully functional, legitimate URI.
> Second, I do not see why this method isn't secure.  It is every bit as
> secure as any of the traditional methods (cookies, HTTP Basic Auth,
etc).
> The security is provided by the SSL, not the format of the URI. 
About the
> only thing I can think of is the possibility of someone looking over
your
> shoulder and writing down the URI.

Thats true again. But as far as I understand, security is mainly
provided by the fact that the uri cannot be guessed. 

> > Of course, this is a somewhat weak
> > > example, since most people
> > > would likely just copy-n-paste the screen and e-mail
> > > it instead of go
> > > through all of this effort.  But in a more complex
> > > situation, I see how this
> > > approach could work well (I think).
> > >
> >
> > I aggree, this is not top notch security. Thats why
> > it is necessary to impose to the accountant to
> > authenticate himself before reading a shared URI.
> 
> So would the mean that the accountant would have to get an access
account
> set up with my bank?  Somehow, I doubt that banks are going to want
to take
> the time to set up all of these accounts just so I can share views of my
> transactions with my accountant, my lawyer, or the service rep on
the other
> end of the phone who refuses to believe that they overcharged me. 
Not only
> that, it means that my accountant would have to maintain accounts
with all
> of the banks, stock brokers, etc. that her clients use.  What a pain!  

Yes but a bank has infrastructures to allocate accounts, and I
personaly doubt that they will let anonymous users GET sensitive
information only protected by the obscurity of an identifier...


> As
> long at the generated URI is securely given to the intended recipient, I
> don't see where the security issue is.  It would certainly be much
easier
> for my accountant to get a single encryption certificate with which
I could
> securely sender her an e-mail.

This is person-to-person encryption, precisely the case where using a
central authority (here the bank, for data related to the bank) is
very useful. 

> 
> > Encoding the "needed roles" in the URI allow a very
> > efficient check : the access control has simply to get
> > the available user roles from the authenticated user
> > profile, and then check that there is one which match
> > the "role part" of the presented URI. This trick avoid
> > to store a map resource->role in the server.
> 
> I will have to defer to Tyler on this one.  As I understand it,
role-based
> security is more prone to security holes than is capability-based
security.
> However, I come from the practice of a role-based model (good ol' MS
> Windows) and am still learning the capability-based model, so my
experience
> is quite limited.

As far as I understand, it seems that encoding a "right" in the URI is
precisely which makes it a capability. You have in the same piece of
information (the URI) the address of the resource and the required
right to access it. My sharing example seems to be what capability
guys want: the ability to build dedicated handles on the same resource
without modifying it. Since it is Restful to have different URIs on
the same resource, it seems ok. 

What you do seems also to be a kind of capability based system in the
same aspect. My problem is that i dont like URIs with generated
numbers in them. What do experts think ? 

> AND I am perfectly willing to admit that this whole thing could be very
> unRESTful.  That's why I'm putting it out there ...
> 
> Seairth

Yes I am piggybacking  on your idea, but for the same reasons. Anyway
its a lot of fun and it is very interesting, thanks.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3759
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-06 16:12:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] URIs are RESTful
Message:

Paul Prescod wrote:

> HTTP auth can be used to do two things. One is to disallow access to a 
> resource. The other is to personalize a resource. Let's say I send you a 
> URL for a site that we both have accounts for (Slashdot is a perfect 
> example). It shows up for you with a blue background because of a 
> preference you set and it shows up as green for me. This is good from a 
> usability point of view: you are seeing the information as you asked for 
> it and I am seeing it as I asked for it. It is the same resource.

It's worth being precise about this. Http-auth only disallows access 
to representations. It doesn't disallow access to resources - the 
URI is already to hand and anyone can attempt to GET against it. 
Security-wise this is a similar approach to ACLs - a handle is 
issued for the resource in question before it's been established you 
have rights to interact with it.

I suspect ACL-style access management is not RESTful, but I don't 
have a compelling argument, just indigestion. Perhaps it's something 
to do with the security managers not being visible.

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3760
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-06 19:35:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] sharing my banking data
Message:

>>>>> "Seairth" == Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> writes:

    Seairth> This has been a very interesting conversation.  

For me everything so far sounded more like the responses of Zen
masters to their disciples :-)

Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3761
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-07 16:16:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Identification of resources
Message:

Roy,

The issue here is whether resources parametrized by HTTP-auth or cookies 
are RESTful; whether e.g. two different bank accounts are different 
"representations" of the same underlying resource.  Here is what you said 
in your dissertation:
<http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/rest_arch_style.htm>

"""
The central feature that distinguishes the REST architectural style from 
other network-based styles is its emphasis on a uniform interface between 
components (Figure 5-6)[...]
In order to obtain a uniform interface, multiple architectural constraints 
are needed to guide the behavior of components. REST is defined by four 
interface constraints: identification of resources; manipulation of 
resources through representations; self-descriptive messages; and, 
hypermedia as the engine of application state. These constraints will be 
discussed in Section 5.2.
"""

And in section 5.2 you say:

"""
More precisely, a resource R is a temporally varying membership function 
MR(t), which for time t maps to a set of entities, or values, which are 
equivalent. The values in the set may be resource representations and/or 
resource identifiers
"""

So, if my credit card company exposes 
<https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary>,
the content of which varies depending on a cookie, do you believe that 
response to a request for this URI is a representation of a REST style 
Resource?  In particular, do you believe that my account information and 
your account information are really different representations of the same 
underlying resource (that they are "equivalent") or that the resource 
identified by this URI is simply changing rapidly depending on which of us 
is making a request at that exact moment?

Alternatively, if my credit card company starts using HTTP-auth instead of 
cookie-auth, would that somehow make your account data and my account data 
different representations of the same underlying resource?

Note to Walden and the other folks on the legal-subpoena thread: We all 
have a pretty clear notion of what "my account" means.  That the content of 
my account changes over time (because I spend money or others steal it), 
doesn't change its identity (Herclitus/flux arguments notwithstanding). 
The issue here is simply whether or not the concept of "Representation" in 
Representational State Transfer is sufficiently broad so that a 
"Representation" is nothing more than the content return by an HTTP server 
at a specific moment in time.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

--On Friday, July 04, 2003 6:13 PM +0200 "Roy T. Fielding" 
<fielding@...> wrote:

> Crikey, you guys are getting all mixed up.  REST is defined by
> my dissertation.  REST is not defined by the TAG discussion or
> the W3C's Webarch document or TimBL's design notes.  REST is an
> architectural style, not the Web architecture.  Please try
> to keep the terminology consistent.
>
> REST does not claim that all important resources must have identifiers.
> REST merely requires that actions be applied to an identified resource,
> and that identification be in the form of a resource identifier (rather
> than, for example, a sequence of events).  Obviously, if you do not
> have an identifier for a given resource, then you cannot interact
> with it directly in REST, which means you can't do things like share
> that specific resource with others or use the URI alone as some form
> of audit reference (you can't do that anyway -- you need all of the
> information that typically gets stored in a logfile, including time,
> method, authentication token, etc.).
>
> That does not in any way imply that all resources are direct or,
> conversely, that you cannot have an effect on resources via indirect
> actions under the control of the origin server.  Yes, there are
> trade-offs between the two, and I personally prefer that multi-valued
> resource identifiers always result in a redirection to the more
> specific resource before further actions take place, but both are
> fully equal parts of the REST model.  They allow interaction to be
> vague when specificity is neither desired nor needed, and particularly
> when a component has yet to determine the specific URI.
>
> ....Roy
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3762
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-07 16:57:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Identification of resources
Message:

Alex,

Thanks for the note at the end.  I'm agreed that we all know what
"my account" means.  However, I'm not sure whether the crux of
the current matter is in the interpretation of "representation", or in
the interpretation of "identity".  I think it's the latter.

Intuitively, the "my account" identifier is dependent on an implicit
"me" identifier, which is dependent on some context or another in
order to provide a referent that could pass a reasonable "identity"
test.

Our society doesn't seem to accept "me" as an identifier in cases
where property or life is at stake, and I take my clues from that
observation.  Does it matter whether it's RESTful or not?

Walden


----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>; "rest-discuss"
<rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, July 07, 2003 12:16 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Identification of resources


> Roy,
>
> The issue here is whether resources parametrized by HTTP-auth or cookies
> are RESTful; whether e.g. two different bank accounts are different
> "representations" of the same underlying resource.  Here is what you said
> in your dissertation:
> <http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/rest_arch_style.htm>
>
> """
> The central feature that distinguishes the REST architectural style from
> other network-based styles is its emphasis on a uniform interface between
> components (Figure 5-6)[...]
> In order to obtain a uniform interface, multiple architectural constraints
> are needed to guide the behavior of components. REST is defined by four
> interface constraints: identification of resources; manipulation of
> resources through representations; self-descriptive messages; and,
> hypermedia as the engine of application state. These constraints will be
> discussed in Section 5.2.
> """
>

>
> """
> More precisely, a resource R is a temporally varying membership function

> > have an identifier for a given resource, then you cannot interact

> > method, authentication token, etc.).

> > conversely, that you cannot have an effect on resources via indirect
> > actions under the control of the origin server.  Yes, there are
> > trade-offs between the two, and I personally prefer that multi-valued

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3763
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-09 21:51:12
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] sharing my banking data
Message:

On Friday 04 July 2003 16:26, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> Obviously, this is a rather simple scenario.  But I think it illustrates a
> simple, clean way of handling access in a RESTful manner.  Was this how
> others were imagining that it might work?

I have different preferences for the details, but the overall
approach fits my idea of RESTful access control.

By giving each user-specific resource its own URL, you bring your
access control policy into the REST model. Each permission has a
URL and can be manipulated like a normal resource. When relying on
usernames, individual permissions don't have a URL and thus can't
be manipulated, or even referred to, using the REST model. REST
needs URLs in order to function.

One of the things I like most about this type of solution is how
easy it is to model the solution using a web diagram. A web
diagram is just a diagram that uses circles to represent resources
and arrows to represent URLs. You could very easily go up to a
whiteboard and draw a web diagram for your http://my.bank/ example
application. You could use the web diagram to explain to someone
exactly what your application's security policy is and how it
works. You could then go to a web browser and show how your
implementation directly corresponds to the model drawn on the
whiteboard. I think this makes access control very tangible, easy
to undertand, and RESTful.

For an introduction to web diagrams, see:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/SQL/Tutorial/overview.html

Tyler

-- 
The union of REST and capability-based security:
http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3764
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-17 02:43:52
Subject:auth now or later?
Message:

Suppose you have a URI like:

/client/xyz

where all paths beginning with 'client' require authentication and 'xyz'
could be any number of values.  When parsing the path, is it better to check
authentication as soon as you encounter 'client' or should you wait until
you have parsed the entire path and confirmed whether the path (and
therefore request URI) is valid or not?

If you authenticate first, it would be possible to request authentication
for a URI that's not even valid.  On the other hand, authenticating only
valid URIs would possibly allow a malicious user to "discover" valid URIs
without being authenticated.

Currently, I am implementing a system where I authenticate first, validate
the full path/URI second.  This greatly simplifies my code.  However, I am
curious to know if one approach is better than the other...

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3765
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-17 03:47:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] auth now or later?
Message:

Seairth,

Wouldn't one need the project requirements in hand to
answer such a question?

Walden

> Suppose you have a URI like:

> could be any number of values.  When parsing the path, is it better to
check
> authentication as soon as you encounter 'client' or should you wait until
> you have parsed the entire path and confirmed whether the path (and
> therefore request URI) is valid or not?
>
> If you authenticate first, it would be possible to request authentication
> for a URI that's not even valid.  On the other hand, authenticating only
> valid URIs would possibly allow a malicious user to "discover" valid URIs
> without being authenticated.
>

> the full path/URI second.  This greatly simplifies my code.  However, I am

Post ID:3766

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] auth now or later?
Message:

I didn't think so, really.  In the case of something I am working on (RNA
implementation), I chose one approach over the other because of a
programming convenience.  But there may be some technical (REST-related?)
reason(s) why I should do it the other way.  If not, that's fine.  I'm happy
to stick with the "easier to implement" way.  :)

Seairth

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3767
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-17 18:00:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] auth now or later?
Message:

On Wednesday 16 July 2003 22:43, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> Suppose you have a URI like:
>
> /client/xyz
>
> where all paths beginning with 'client' require authentication and 'xyz'
> could be any number of values.  When parsing the path, is it better to
> check authentication as soon as you encounter 'client' or should you wait
> until you have parsed the entire path and confirmed whether the path (and
> therefore request URI) is valid or not?
>
> If you authenticate first, it would be possible to request authentication
> for a URI that's not even valid.  On the other hand, authenticating only
> valid URIs would possibly allow a malicious user to "discover" valid URIs
> without being authenticated.

If a valid URI does not convey any authority (ie: the client must
be authenticated to use it), there is no need to worry about
"discovery" of valid URIs. From a security point of view, you
should assume that if your URIs are guessable, the attacker has
already guessed them.

Note that the type of URI you are proposing '/client/xyz' is
exactly the type of RESTless URI we were discussing in the
previous thread.

Tyler

-- 
The union of REST and capability-based security:
http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3768
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-17 18:30:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] auth now or later?
Message:

From: "Tyler Close" <tyler@...>
>
> On Wednesday 16 July 2003 22:43, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> > Suppose you have a URI like:
> >
> > /client/xyz
> >
> > where all paths beginning with 'client' require authentication and 'xyz'
> > could be any number of values.  When parsing the path, is it better to
> > check authentication as soon as you encounter 'client' or should you
wait
> > until you have parsed the entire path and confirmed whether the path
(and
> > therefore request URI) is valid or not?
> >
> > If you authenticate first, it would be possible to request
authentication
> > for a URI that's not even valid.  On the other hand, authenticating only
> > valid URIs would possibly allow a malicious user to "discover" valid
URIs
> > without being authenticated.
>
> If a valid URI does not convey any authority (ie: the client must
> be authenticated to use it), there is no need to worry about
> "discovery" of valid URIs. From a security point of view, you
> should assume that if your URIs are guessable, the attacker has
> already guessed them.

Hmm... I suppose that's true....

> Note that the type of URI you are proposing '/client/xyz' is
> exactly the type of RESTless URI we were discussing in the
> previous thread.

Actually, the example URI was a bit on the generic side to avoid discussions
of URI construction...  In the case of the application I'm working on,
there's a one-to-one relationship between the URI and the user (i.e. I don't
have multiple people logging in at the /client level).

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3769
Sender:Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-18 02:17:23
Subject:Re: auth now or later?
Message:

> If a valid URI does not convey any authority (ie: the client must
> be authenticated to use it), there is no need to worry about
> "discovery" of valid URIs. From a security point of view, you
> should assume that if your URIs are guessable, the attacker has
> already guessed them.

Hmm, but from security point of view, you should not provide
functionality to verify that "guess". That is why you simply
get "login failed" instead of "invalid username" or "invalid
password" when you try to login UNIX system (at least, recent
ones). By returning 404 or 401, you're providing extra one bit
of information.

But since this is only a security restriction, I don't think
there's any REST constraint on this policy. It's up to the
implementor. If you think that bit of information is valuable
for RESTful interaction of the Web, then it should be free to
do so.

--
Taisuke Yamada <tai@...>
Internet Initiative Japan Inc., Technical Planning Division





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3770
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-19 17:07:01
Subject:RNA progress...
Message:

For those of you who are interested in the RNA spec I was mentioned
recently, I have been working on an implementation of it.  I recently
decided to start a series of dedicated blog entries at
http://www.seairth.com/blog/industry/RNA.  The RSS2 version is available at
http://www.seairth.com/blog/industry/RNA?rss=2.0.  I welcome all the
feedback I can get.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3771
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-20 21:06:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: auth now or later?
Message:

On Thursday 17 July 2003 22:17, Taisuke Yamada wrote:
> > If a valid URI does not convey any authority (ie: the client must
> > be authenticated to use it), there is no need to worry about
> > "discovery" of valid URIs. From a security point of view, you
> > should assume that if your URIs are guessable, the attacker has
> > already guessed them.
>
> Hmm, but from security point of view, you should not provide
> functionality to verify that "guess".  That is why you simply
> get "login failed" instead of "invalid username" or "invalid
> password" when you try to login UNIX system (at least, recent
> ones).

Some Unix systems do this in an attempt to protect users from
poorly chosen passwords. It's like saying: "Given that I know the
security is broken, what can I do to make things suck less?"
Limiting the login attempts does not make it infeasible for an
attacker to gain illegitimate access to the system.  Obviously
when designing a new system, the goal is to make a stronger
security model. The Unix login should not be your ideal. It has a
rather notorious history.

> By returning 404 or 401, you're providing extra one bit
> of information.

"Leaking bits" means that your security depends on an unguessable
identifier, but your implementation reveals some of the bits,
turning the unguessable identifier into a guessable identifier.
The attack on SSL that was recently in the press is an example of
"leaking bits".

Revealing a guessable URL is not leaking bits. Trying to hide
a guessable URL is just security through obfuscation.

Tyler

-- 
The union of REST and capability-based security:
http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3772
Sender:Michael Day <mikeday@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-21 07:16:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RNA progress...
Message:

Hi Seairth,

The new blog looks interesting; you have brought up two issues in
particular:

 * "in RNA, there is no defined GET operation on the Identity URI"

From a usability point of view it is definitely worth encouraging
implementations to return a meaningful response to GET for this URI.

 * "Some may observe that any such URL is more difficult to type in
   than a typical e-mail address"

True! Can't be helped though, without a cleverer URI resolution scheme
allowing URNs or something to be used instead.

Michael

-- 
YesLogic Prince prints XML!
http://yeslogic.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3773
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-22 02:38:20
Subject:REST & User Interfaces
Message:

Hi all,

I'd like to learn about how REST principles have been and can be applied
to certain kinds of user interface cruft. I've just joined a company
that consciously applies REST to a back-end server interface, but the
front-end user interface is not very RESTy at all. I'm struggling to
imagine how certain features of that user interface, in common with user
interfaces I've seen in several Web applications, could be redesigned
consistent with REST principles.

These are some of the features I'm wondering about:

1. Login Page

The support for HTTP Basic authentication in common Web browsers is not
particularly user friendly. Therefore, Web applications that require
user authentication universally present an HTML login page with a form
that, when submitted, results in a cookie being set in the browser. This
cookie is often a session key, which is obviously not RESTful; on the
other hand, if the cookie were used purely as an authentication token
not requiring server state, would such use be consistent with REST?

2. Current User

Once the user is logged in, it is common to have at the very least the
user's name displayed in the corner of every page of the application. At
a further extreme, any given page may be completely different per user,
such as a user-customizable "dashboard". As I understand REST, the
representation returned from a GET should not depend on the
authorization state, but only on the URI.

What if instead of </dashboard> the URI was </joe/dashboard>? Any user
other than joe who tried to GET that resource could simply be forbidden.
But does that make sense for putting the user's name at the top of every
page of the application? Should every page view that a user can see be
considered a resource specific to that user?

3. Menus, Etc.

I wrote some comments and questions on this topic at the bottom of
<http://conveyor.com/RESTwiki/moin.cgi/HowWikiComparesToRest>. In that
discussion, it had been posited that a RESTful Wiki would use PUT for
editing pages. However, every page of a typical Wiki has a menu bar at
the top & other bits of information like the last modified date at the
bottom, none of which can be edited by users.

More generally, Web applications tend to have lots of menus on the top
and left of every page that aren't directly relevant to the content of
the page, but are really window dressing for the entire site. How can
all that UI cruft be understood in a RESTful way?

Justin Sampson





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3774
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-22 17:20:29
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST & User Interfaces
Message:

I agree with your assessments.  Here are some short comments.
1. Cookies are an obviously better UI than HTTP-auth.  You just need to 
make sure you send a no-cache header if the request comes through a proxy. 
Otherwise users will get access to each other's cached pages.

2. Current user.  You should look at recent discussion we had on this topic 
(identification of resources).  You may want to make the URLs of the user 
pages unguessable.  Then users could opt to allow others to read them if 
they so chose (by sending a URL).  You then need to decide what these 
referred users are authorized to do.

3. Menus, etc.  You can use PUT.  Remember GET retrieves a representation 
of the resource.  If the PUT is text/plain and the GET has an accept: 
text/plain header, you could assume that the user wants the editable 
version of the page and not the rendered version.

-Alex-

PS I am starting a new company and am looking for REST/Python/XP-Agile 
developers in NYC area.  If you're interested, please email me.

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


--On Monday, July 21, 2003 7:38 PM -0700 Justin Sampson 
<justin.sampson@...> wrote:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3775
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-23 18:29:48
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] REST & User Interfaces
Message:

Alex Jacobson wrote:

> 1. Cookies are an obviously better UI than HTTP-auth. You just need to
> make sure you send a no-cache header if the request comes through a
proxy.
> Otherwise users will get access to each other's cached pages.

Interesting, I wouldn't have thought of that. That really points out the
issue of security in general; if users really must not see each other's
pages, the server must require SSL, which prevents proxies along the way
anyway... But in this case, just specifying no-cache would at least
prevent
a proxy from *accidentally* sending one user's cached page to other
users.

> 2. Current user. You should look at recent discussion we had on this
topic
> (identification of resources). You may want to make the URLs of the
user
> pages unguessable. Then users could opt to allow others to read them
if
> they so chose (by sending a URL). You then need to decide what these
> referred users are authorized to do.

Ah, I see now this has been a common topic. I had tried to search the
archives a bit, but didn't lurk very long. Thanks.

> 3. Menus, etc. You can use PUT. Remember GET retrieves a
representation
> of the resource. If the PUT is text/plain and the GET has an accept:
> text/plain header, you could assume that the user wants the editable
> version of the page and not the rendered version.

But here's the question -- is the page with all that UI cruft
surrounding
the central content really just another "representation" of that
content? I
can easily accept the original Wiki text and its HTML rendering as two
representations of the same content resource, but the extra stuff put
around
it (menus, logos, search forms, last-modified notations, etc.) doesn't
feel
like part of the same resource.

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3776
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-23 18:57:09
Subject:Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

Roy Fielding wrote, in response to Alex Jacobson, in message 3729:

> > My opinion:
> >
> > REST and Authentication are orthogonal, but that people frequently
abuse
> > authentication to make it unrestful. So, RESTAuthenticateBank is
> > RESTful, but CookieBank is not.
>
> Authentication is orthogonal. Cookies are also orthogonal when they
are
> simply used for content negotiation or authentication. However, Cookie
> authentication is not allowed in REST because it lacks visibility,
which
> causes security problems because the other components don't know it is
> sensitive information.

Can that prohibition be more stated more specifically, to say that
cookie
authentication is not allowed in REST applications using HTTP as
currently
defined, simply because Cookie is a nonstandard header that proxies
ignore?

That is, assuming that I were to implement cookie authentication with
some
kind of secure token not requiring any server state, and Cookie was a
part
of the HTTP standard, and proxies were to treat Cookie similarly to how
they
treat Authorization for caching, would such use of cookies be consistent
with REST? It would be almost like having a Set-Authorization response
header that could be returned from posting a login form, giving the
credentials that should be returned by the client on subsequent
requests.
Does that make any sense?

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3777
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-23 19:29:04
Subject:Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

Mark Baker wrote, in message 3721:

> If it's a URI, then there's nothing at all RESTless about it.

Hmm, I think that a URI containing a session key, like Java's
;jsession=12345 mechanism used when cookies are turned off,
probably isn't RESTful. It's just a hack to pass around a handle
for application state on the server and an abuse of the URI
syntax. That's not the case you were talking about it this
thread, but it was my first reaction to this one sentence...

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3778
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-23 21:53:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

> That is, assuming that I were to implement cookie authentication with 
> some
> kind of secure token not requiring any server state, and Cookie was a 
> part
> of the HTTP standard, and proxies were to treat Cookie similarly to 
> how they
> treat Authorization for caching, would such use of cookies be 
> consistent
> with REST? It would be almost like having a Set-Authorization response
> header that could be returned from posting a login form, giving the
> credentials that should be returned by the client on subsequent
> requests.
> Does that make any sense?

You should note that there is no design reason why Authorization
and WWW-Authenticate are limited to Basic and Digest.  That is why
those fields are extensible.  Why would you want to duplicate that
functionality in another field?

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3779
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 04:35:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

> > That is, assuming that I were to implement cookie authentication with
> > some
> > kind of secure token not requiring any server state, and Cookie was a
> > part
> > of the HTTP standard, and proxies were to treat Cookie similarly to
> > how they
> > treat Authorization for caching, would such use of cookies be
> > consistent
> > with REST? It would be almost like having a Set-Authorization response
> > header that could be returned from posting a login form, giving the
> > credentials that should be returned by the client on subsequent
> > requests.
> > Does that make any sense?
>
> You should note that there is no design reason why Authorization
> and WWW-Authenticate are limited to Basic and Digest.  That is why
> those fields are extensible.  Why would you want to duplicate that
> functionality in another field?
>
Maybe the protocol & existing software (user-agents & servers) do not
satisfy the use case most web site authors have in mind. The
'Set-Authorization' response header suggested leads into what the real
desire from the community is - authentication tokens originating at the
server.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3780
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-23 20:42:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST & User Interfaces
Message:


Justin Sampson wrote:

>Alex Jacobson wrote:
>
>  
>
>>3. Menus, etc. You can use PUT. Remember GET retrieves a
>>    
>>
>representation
>  
>
>>of the resource. If the PUT is text/plain and the GET has an accept:
>>text/plain header, you could assume that the user wants the editable
>>version of the page and not the rendered version.
>>    
>>
>
>But here's the question -- is the page with all that UI cruft
>surrounding
>the central content really just another "representation" of that
>content? I
>can easily accept the original Wiki text and its HTML rendering as two
>representations of the same content resource, but the extra stuff put
>around
>it (menus, logos, search forms, last-modified notations, etc.) doesn't
>feel
>like part of the same resource.
>  
>

I would recommend treating your UI components as the resources rather 
than treating them as just another representation of the content. I say 
this in part because browsers dont support PUT or DELETE, but also 
because you end up jumping through hoops for anything more than the 
simplest of UIs.

For example (off the top of my head), a user management system might 
have as resources /app/usercreator (a create screen), 
/app/usereditor?uid=x (an edit screen), and /app/userviewer?uid=x (a 
view screen).  The resource is then the UI component.  You can still 
make users first-class resources (give the URIs) - but you would still 
pass the URI in to the UI component resource 
(/app/usereditor?user=/app/users/foo).

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3781
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 18:00:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

--On Wednesday, July 23, 2003 2:53 PM -0700 "Roy T. Fielding" 
<fielding@...> wrote:
> You should note that there is no design reason why Authorization
> and WWW-Authenticate are limited to Basic and Digest.  That is why
> those fields are extensible.  Why would you want to duplicate that
> functionality in another field?

With all due respect, given that HTTP authentication is fundamentally 
broken*, that cookies are a defacto standard, and that HTTP-auth is poorly 
supported by actual UAs.  The bigger question is why duplicate cookie 
functionality with auth-specific headers?

The argument for HTTP-auth is that it provides an automated mechanism for a 
web server to tell a web client that authentication information is required 
and specifies the type.

When end-users are accessing a web site, auth is a user interface issue and 
not automatic so there is no reason why auth requirements cannot be 
specified in the body of a 401 response.

When auth-access is automated, are there actual contexts in which automated 
clients try to access get a 401 and then try some auth protocol?  In 
reality don't they simply request with the correct auth and if that's what 
they do, isn't that simply passing a cookie?

-Alex-

* HTTP-auth is broken because nothing binds the auth to the content of the 
request, so there is no protection from MITM attacks.  You can solve this 
with SSL, but that is not part of the HTTP spec and is unfortunately 
overkill for many applications.



___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3782
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 18:46:27
Subject:Case Study (was Re: REST & User Interfaces)
Message:

Okay... here's a test case I am currently working on (RNA).  Tell me if this
looks good or not:

Key:
    {id} would be something like "seairth" or "bob" or "cmhinson" or
whatever.
    {abc} is currently a 32-hex character representation of a random 16-byte
number.
    {uri} is a URL-Encoded URI to be used in a query string
    "Auth-" indicates these methods require HTTP Authentication.
    note: almost all of the names are changable (at least until there are
        resources bound to them).

/{id}
    POST agreements, GET user-defined page (likely HTML)
/{id}/inbox/{abc}
    POST notifications (e.g. send {id} a notification)
/{id}/notifications/{abc}
    GET notificaction (e.g. notification sent to others)


/{id}/access
    Auth-GET returns the list of URIs to access the following resources
    (e.g. /{id}/received, /{id}/agreements, etc.)
/{id}/notifications
    Auth-GET returns the list of notifications user has created
    Auth-POST to create a new notification.
/{id}/received
    Auth-GET returns list of URIs to received notifications
/{id}/received/{abc}
    Auth-GET returns a received notification
    Auth-DELETE deletes a received notification
/{id}/agreements
    Auth-GET returns list of URIs to existing agreements
    Auth-POST to create a new agreement returns agreement URI
/{id}/agreements/{abc}
    Auth-GET returns an agreement
    Auth-PUT updates an agreement
    Auth-DELETE deletes an agreement
/{id}/sent
    Auth-GET returns a list of individuals sent notifications
    Auth-POST to send a notification (after creating the notification)
/{id}/sent/{abc}
    Auth-GET returns "record" on the sending of a notification to an
individual
    Auth-PUT updates the "record"
    Auth-DELETE deletes the "record"
/{id}/settings
    Auth-GET returns settings
    Auth-PUT updates settings

The above URIs are broken into two groups.  The first group of URIs are
those that are accessible by anyone (as long as they know the actual URI),
and are defined by the RNA spec.  The second group of URIs are those that
are accessible only to the "owner" of {id}.  Only XML documents are passed,
containing only data (no presentation).  This group of URIs would likely be
accessed by a client program and not directly by a user.

Now, I am also trying to write a web-based (html) client to demonstrate the
application.  Originally, the client had a series of URIs that more or less
mapped to several of the URIs above.  However, this was getting confusing,
since I needed additional things like edit windows and

/client?uri={uri}
    Auth-GET returns the appropriate resource representation
    {uri} must be one of the URIs in the second group above. The
    "/{id}/access" URI would be the "main" URI, which would return
    the entry page, main menu, etc.
/client/addform?uri={uri}
    Auth-GET returns the appropriate form
    Auth-POST submits the form
    {uri} must be one of the "container" URIs (e.g. "/{id}/agreements")
    mentioned above that accepts POST (client internally POSTs XML to the
    target {uri}).
/client/editform?ur={uri}
    Auth-GET returns the appropriate form
    Auth-POST submits the form
    {uri} must be one of the individual resource URIs (e.g.
    "/{id}/agreements/{abc}") mentioned above that accepts PUT (client
    internally updates using PUT to the target {uri}).
/client/delete?uri={uri}
    Auth-POST submits form
    {uri} must be a parent URI of the URI that will be deleted (which is
    passed in the form itself).  Response returns the equivalent of
    "GET /client?{uri}" (minus the deleted resource).

In general, the idea is that the appropriate screen according to the value
of {uri} is returned.  For clarity, look at the following examples:

    GET /client?uri={/{id}/access}
        returns the main menu options
    GET /client?uri={/{id}/settings}
        returns a static view of the current settings.
    GET /client/editform?uri={/{id}/settings}
        returns a form for editing changes.
    GET /client?uri={/{id}/agreements}
        returns a static list of the agreements.
    GET /client/addform?uri={/{id}/agreements}
        returns form to add an agreement.
    etc.

Otherwise, the client is designed to work with any implementation that uses
the XML documents associated to the second group of URIs above.  As a
result, it would be possible to use the same client to access entirely
different servers as long as the XML interface stayed the same.  Of course,
this is all conceptual now, so I am sure there are some details that I have
overlooked which may make some or all of this approach difficult to do.

But, as a general pattern, what does everyone think?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3783
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 19:00:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

cookie-based and HTTP auth are identical when the
client is software.  The only difference is the
name of the HTTP header in which the
authentication token is passed.  But really the
whole premise of HTTP auth is unreasonable for
automated clients.  Clients just send a secret
token.  They don't need a mnemonic separating
usernames from passwords.

For human users, the login form that comes in the
401 response is as visible as you want.  In
practice Mozilla appears to auto-fill most login
forms I reach correctly and without issue which
makes me think that visibility is a non-issue.

-Alex-






On Thu, 24 Jul 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:

>
>
> Alex Jacobson wrote:
>
> >--On Wednesday, July 23, 2003 2:53 PM -0700 "Roy T. Fielding"
> ><fielding@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >>You should note that there is no design reason why Authorization
> >>and WWW-Authenticate are limited to Basic and Digest.  That is why
> >>those fields are extensible.  Why would you want to duplicate that
> >>functionality in another field?
> >>
> >>
> >
> >With all due respect, given that HTTP authentication is fundamentally
> >broken*, that cookies are a defacto standard, and that HTTP-auth is poorly
> >supported by actual UAs.  The bigger question is why duplicate cookie
> >functionality with auth-specific headers?
> >
> >
> I would think that while cookies may be a defacto standard, cookie-based
> authentication is not (i.e., there is no standard implementation of
> authentication using cookies).  Thus, it would seem to me that
> visibility still suffers.
>
> --Chuck
>
>

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3784
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 19:15:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Case Study (was Re: REST & User Interfaces)
Message:


Seairth Jacobs wrote:
[ . . .]

>Now, I am also trying to write a web-based (html) client to demonstrate the
>application.  Originally, the client had a series of URIs that more or less
>mapped to several of the URIs above.  However, this was getting confusing,
>since I needed additional things like edit windows and
>
>/client?uri={uri}
>    Auth-GET returns the appropriate resource representation
>    {uri} must be one of the URIs in the second group above. The
>    "/{id}/access" URI would be the "main" URI, which would return
>    the entry page, main menu, etc.
>/client/addform?uri={uri}
>    Auth-GET returns the appropriate form
>    Auth-POST submits the form
>    {uri} must be one of the "container" URIs (e.g. "/{id}/agreements")
>    mentioned above that accepts POST (client internally POSTs XML to the
>    target {uri}).
>/client/editform?ur={uri}
>    Auth-GET returns the appropriate form
>    Auth-POST submits the form
>    {uri} must be one of the individual resource URIs (e.g.
>    "/{id}/agreements/{abc}") mentioned above that accepts PUT (client
>    internally updates using PUT to the target {uri}).
>/client/delete?uri={uri}
>
Did you forget Auth_GET to get the form?

>    Auth-POST submits form
>    {uri} must be a parent URI of the URI that will be deleted (which is
>    passed in the form itself).  Response returns the equivalent of
>    "GET /client?{uri}" (minus the deleted resource).
>  
>

This looks more or less like the approach that I use as far as treating 
UI element as resources.  I'd probably change the syntax of your URI 
namespace, but that's just personal perference (i.e, I cant give a good 
reason why you shouldn't do it the way you are).

>In general, the idea is that the appropriate screen according to the value
>of {uri} is returned.  For clarity, look at the following examples:
>
>    GET /client?uri={/{id}/access}
>        returns the main menu options
>    GET /client?uri={/{id}/settings}
>        returns a static view of the current settings.
>    GET /client/editform?uri={/{id}/settings}
>        returns a form for editing changes.
>    GET /client?uri={/{id}/agreements}
>        returns a static list of the agreements.
>    GET /client/addform?uri={/{id}/agreements}
>        returns form to add an agreement.
>    etc.
>  
>

These seem fine, although I personally would change the structure of the 
URIs to something like
   GET /client/menu?id={id}
   GET /client/settingsviewer?id={id}
   GET /client/settingseditor?id={id}
   GET /client/agreementsviewer?id={id}
   GET /client/agreementscreator?id={id}

Again, this is just a reflection of the way I'm doing things now - I 
can't give any justification for doing it one way or the other (other 
than it makes more sense to me).  (It also assumes that I haven't 
misinterpreted the intent of the examples you gave.)

--Chuck
