Post ID:3785
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 19:47:16
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Case Study (was Re: REST & User Interfaces)
Message:

From: "Chuck Hinson" <cmhinson@...>
> >/client/delete?uri={uri}
> >
> Did you forget Auth_GET to get the form?

I hand't originally planned on it, but such a form could have it's
advantages (like deleting multiple resources at a time)  On the other hand,
it might also be possible to drop the whole /delete bit and add a POST
/client?uri={uri} that could handle the delete.  This second approach would
likely be cleaner anyhow...

>
> >    Auth-POST submits form
> >    {uri} must be a parent URI of the URI that will be deleted (which is
> >    passed in the form itself).  Response returns the equivalent of
> >    "GET /client?{uri}" (minus the deleted resource).
> >
> >
>
> This looks more or less like the approach that I use as far as treating
> UI element as resources.  I'd probably change the syntax of your URI
> namespace, but that's just personal perference (i.e, I cant give a good
> reason why you shouldn't do it the way you are).
>
> >In general, the idea is that the appropriate screen according to the
value
> >of {uri} is returned.  For clarity, look at the following examples:
> >
> >    GET /client?uri={/{id}/access}
> >        returns the main menu options
> >    GET /client?uri={/{id}/settings}
> >        returns a static view of the current settings.
> >    GET /client/editform?uri={/{id}/settings}
> >        returns a form for editing changes.
> >    GET /client?uri={/{id}/agreements}
> >        returns a static list of the agreements.
> >    GET /client/addform?uri={/{id}/agreements}
> >        returns form to add an agreement.
> >    etc.
> >
> >
>
> These seem fine, although I personally would change the structure of the
> URIs to something like
>    GET /client/menu?id={id}
>    GET /client/settingsviewer?id={id}
>    GET /client/settingseditor?id={id}
>    GET /client/agreementsviewer?id={id}
>    GET /client/agreementscreator?id={id}
>
> Again, this is just a reflection of the way I'm doing things now - I
> can't give any justification for doing it one way or the other (other
> than it makes more sense to me).  (It also assumes that I haven't
> misinterpreted the intent of the examples you gave.)

Except in my examples above, which I don't think I have made very clear
(sorry) is that {/{id}/access} would actually be something like
"http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/access" (notice the last part of the
path).  As a result, above examples would look more like:

GET /client?uri=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/access
GET /client?uri=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/settings
GET /client/editform?uri=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/settings
GET /client?uri=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/agreements
GET /client/addform?uri=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/agreements

This would also allow the client's host server to be independent, meaning  I
could access an RNA interface on http://example.invalid from
http://www.sample.invalid.  Now, I suppose you could have something like:

GET /client/menu?id=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/
GET /client/settingsviewer?id=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/
GET /client/settingseditor?id=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/
GET /client/agreementsviewer?id=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/
GET /client/agreementscreator?id=http://example.invalid/rna/seairth/

However, what would the URI be when you wanted to work with a specific
agreement?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3786
Sender:Duncan Wilcox <duncan@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 20:19:19
Subject:Concurrent updates and proxies
Message:

I originally posted this question to www-talk@... a couple days ago. 
Maybe someone here has some thoughts?

I'm working on a system that has a REST interface used to exchange, 
among other things, configuration documents.

The interface used to be a CGI, for many reasons I wrote a bare bones 
HTTP server, I can now attempt to make the interface more RESTful.

Specifically, the CGI environment doesn't let me deal with ETags and 
preconditions (If-Match, If-None-Match), so the configuration documents 
in my system contain a sort of CRC of the document, to solve the 
concurrent update problem (CRC in submitted document doesn't match 
stored version = reject).

With my web server I'm planning on using ETags and preconditions, as 
outlined in:

http://www.w3.org/1999/04/Editing/

I think I have the mechanics clear, the client GETs a document, 
modifies the document, PUTs it back with an If-Match with the original 
ETag. The server rejects the PUT unless the string supplied through 
If-Match actually matches.

I have been recently bitten by Squid downgrading a request to HTTP/1.0, 
in a bug in my code I would respect the "Expect: 100-continue" header 
even though the incoming request was HTTP/1.0 and emit a 100, which 
Squid apparently doesn't really know what to do with, confusing the 
original client.

Now, if my configuration document update process requires and relies on 
HTTP/1.1 features like If-Match, what should I do with proxies like 
Squid that downgrade the connection to HTTP/1.0?

Squid would probably leave the If-Match header in place, as it left the 
Expect header. Can I rely on this to use the If-Match anyway and 
simulate the precondition failure through a generic 400 after the PUT 
(instead of a PUT-aborting 412)? Or will some HTTP/1.0 proxy 
resynthetize the headers and drop the unknown ones, thus breaking an 
HTTP/1.1-specific application?

Thanks,
Duncan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3787
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-25 01:30:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Case Study (was Re: REST & User Interfaces)
Message:

From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
>
[snip]
> Now, I am also trying to write a web-based (html) client to demonstrate
the
> application.  Originally, the client had a series of URIs that more or
less
> mapped to several of the URIs above.  However, this was getting confusing,
> since I needed additional things like edit windows and
>
> /client?uri={uri}
>     Auth-GET returns the appropriate resource representation
>     {uri} must be one of the URIs in the second group above. The
>     "/{id}/access" URI would be the "main" URI, which would return
>     the entry page, main menu, etc.
[snip]
> In general, the idea is that the appropriate screen according to the value
> of {uri} is returned.  For clarity, look at the following examples:
>
>     GET /client?uri={/{id}/access}
>         returns the main menu options
[snip]

Well, it occurs to me that there are a few  design problems here...

First, suppose I had an RNA address of http://example.com/rna/seairth and
the client software was at http://example.com/rnaclient.  According to the
above stuff, the 'entry-point' would be:

http://example.com/rnaclient?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/access

Frankly, this isn't very user-friendly.  First, the URL is way to long to
have to type in.  Second, it requires me to know/remember the URI of my
"access" resource.  So what would be some solutions?  So far, I have thought
of the following (along with their limitations):

1) The client could have a "default" URI, but this would only be useful
where a particular copy of the client was being used by one person only.

2) Instead, one could use just the RNA Address
(http://example.com/rna/seairth) and the client would auto-append the
"access" bit.  If the server returned a 404, it could then try other
possibilities, effectively hunting for the interface.  This solution is not
very flexible, since all it would take is a particular inplementation to
change the path slightly (e.g. "client-access") in order for the client to
fail discovery.

3) If no uri is given, show a simple form requesting the appropriate access
URI.  Once given, store as a cookie to auto-fill the textbox in future.
Problems: not portable, still requires knowledge of access URI, etc.

4) Double up the access URI and the RNA address.  Since the only purpose of
the access URI is to return an xml document, it would be possible to use
conneg on a GET of the RNA Address.  This way, a user would only have to
know their own RNA Address (which they would anyhow).  This could be coupled
with #3 above, where the coookie bit would only be a convenience.  The down
side is that I'm not too crazy about overloading the RNA Address like this
(purely from a technical POV; I think end-users would be oblivious and
therefore fine with it).

5) Move the client to be under the RNA Address, effectively replacing the
"access URI".  Through conneg, it would still be possible to return the
original XML document from the client URI so that "thick" clients could
still have access.  The main advantage here is that the URI would be
memorable (e.g. http://example.com/rna/seairth/client).  However, it seems
somewhat like overkill to pass entire URIs in the query string, esp. since
it would be unlikely that you would use the client to access any RNA address
other than the one it was under.  On the other hand, I could be wrong here.
For instance, this would allow one to customize the look-and-feel of the
client program, then access other RNA Addresses while continuing to keep
that look-and-feel.  When accessing another site, you would have to use
something akin to the original syntax (e.g.
http://example.com/rna/seairth/client?uri=http://example.com/rna/bob), but
it's probably fine at that point.



The other problem is that the current approach would require a GET of the
"access URI" resource for every request in order to determine what the
actual uri parameter is pointing to.  For instance, in order to understand
the following:

    GET /client/addform?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements

I would have to first do a GET on the "access URI".  Now, given the above
URI, the access URI isn't known (unless using solution #4 above).  It seems
to me that there are two possible approaches (other than #4):

1) To change the structure so that everything pointed to by the access URI
was under the access URI (e.g. /{id}/access/agreements,
/{id}/access/settings, etc.), which doesn't seem to be a very good solution.
While it may give access to the "access URI" (in a not-so-opaque manner), it
still means that an additional GET is required to understand the bits
underneath it.

2) To go Chuck's way, sort of.  He suggested:

>    GET /client/menu?id={id}
>    GET /client/settingsviewer?id={id}
>    GET /client/settingseditor?id={id}
>    GET /client/agreementsviewer?id={id}
>    GET /client/agreementscreator?id={id}

Where I took {id} as I meant it in the original post ( "something like
'seairth' or 'bob' or 'cmhinson'"). Instead, they could be:

    GET /client/menu?id={uri}
    GET /client/settingsviewer?id={uri}
    GET /client/settingseditor?id={uri}
    GET /client/agreementsviewer?id={uri}
    GET /client/agreementscreator?id={uri}

In other words, when you get back the initial "access URI" list, they are
translated into meaningful (to the client) URIs that would no longer require
additional accesses to the "access URI" list.  For instance, a request gets
back the list of agreements:

    http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements/123
    http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements/456

This would be translated into client-specific URIs looking something like:


http://example.com/rnaclient/agreementviewer?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements/123

http://example.com/rnaclient/agreementeditor?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements/123


http://example.com/rnaclient/agreementviewer?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements/456

http://example.com/rnaclient/agreementeditor?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/agreements/456

The uri is still intact (and totally opaque) and the client program still
implicitly knows what the resource at the other end of the URI is (though it
should probably validate anyhow).


So, for the second problem, I'd be likely to go with option #2.  For the
first problem, I am leanding towards #5, but am unsure.  Any thoughts?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3788
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-24 18:23:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:


Alex Jacobson wrote:

>--On Wednesday, July 23, 2003 2:53 PM -0700 "Roy T. Fielding" 
><fielding@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>You should note that there is no design reason why Authorization
>>and WWW-Authenticate are limited to Basic and Digest.  That is why
>>those fields are extensible.  Why would you want to duplicate that
>>functionality in another field?
>>    
>>
>
>With all due respect, given that HTTP authentication is fundamentally 
>broken*, that cookies are a defacto standard, and that HTTP-auth is poorly 
>supported by actual UAs.  The bigger question is why duplicate cookie 
>functionality with auth-specific headers?
>  
>
I would think that while cookies may be a defacto standard, cookie-based 
authentication is not (i.e., there is no standard implementation of 
authentication using cookies).  Thus, it would seem to me that 
visibility still suffers.

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3789
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-25 04:14:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Case Study (was Re: REST & User Interfaces)
Message:


Seairth Jacobs wrote:

>From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
>  
>
>[snip]
>  
>
>>Now, I am also trying to write a web-based (html) client to demonstrate
>>    
>>
>the
>  
>
>>application.  Originally, the client had a series of URIs that more or
>>    
>>
>less
>  
>
>>mapped to several of the URIs above.  However, this was getting confusing,
>>since I needed additional things like edit windows and
>>
>>/client?uri={uri}
>>    Auth-GET returns the appropriate resource representation
>>    {uri} must be one of the URIs in the second group above. The
>>    "/{id}/access" URI would be the "main" URI, which would return
>>    the entry page, main menu, etc.
>>    
>>
>[snip]
>  
>
>>In general, the idea is that the appropriate screen according to the value
>>of {uri} is returned.  For clarity, look at the following examples:
>>
>>    GET /client?uri={/{id}/access}
>>        returns the main menu options
>>    
>>
>[snip]
>
>Well, it occurs to me that there are a few  design problems here...
>
>First, suppose I had an RNA address of http://example.com/rna/seairth and
>the client software was at http://example.com/rnaclient.  According to the
>above stuff, the 'entry-point' would be:
>
>http://example.com/rnaclient?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/access
>
>Frankly, this isn't very user-friendly.  First, the URL is way to long to
>have to type in.  Second, it requires me to know/remember the URI of my
>"access" resource.  
>

I'm not sure I would worry too much about the URI being too long.  No 
matter what the length, the user will probably just bookmark it anyway.

If your client software has the same host as your RNA address and your 
access URIs are always the same except for the id part (seairth above), 
then I could easily see where you have a default page at 
http://example.com/rnaclient that asks you for your id (seairth in this 
case) and then fowards/redirects you to the appropriate page using the 
URI above.  Once there, the user shouldn't have to type any URIs - he 
should be able to click his way anywhere else he needs to go.  And given 
one URI, the server should be able to generate content containing 
appropriately formed URIs for that user.


>So what would be some solutions?  So far, I have thought
>of the following (along with their limitations):
>
>1) The client could have a "default" URI, but this would only be useful
>where a particular copy of the client was being used by one person only.
>

This isnt a whole lot different than the way mail clients work right 
now.  Each user has a separate copy of the client configured with their 
mail server info.

>
>2) Instead, one could use just the RNA Address
>(http://example.com/rna/seairth) and the client would auto-append the
>"access" bit.  If the server returned a 404, it could then try other
>possibilities, effectively hunting for the interface.  This solution is not
>very flexible, since all it would take is a particular inplementation to
>change the path slightly (e.g. "client-access") in order for the client to
>fail discovery.
>

Why bother with the hunting part?  For the sake of interop, just require 
that the access page is the rna address with /access appended. Once 
enough implementations do it that way, any implementation that does it 
differently will be considered broken.

>
>3) If no uri is given, show a simple form requesting the appropriate access
>URI.  Once given, store as a cookie to auto-fill the textbox in future.
>Problems: not portable, still requires knowledge of access URI, etc.
>

Uggh.  Plenty of other options.  Let's drop this one.

>4) Double up the access URI and the RNA address.  Since the only purpose of
>the access URI is to return an xml document, it would be possible to use
>conneg on a GET of the RNA Address.  This way, a user would only have to
>know their own RNA Address (which they would anyhow).  This could be coupled
>with #3 above, where the coookie bit would only be a convenience.  The down
>side is that I'm not too crazy about overloading the RNA Address like this
>(purely from a technical POV; I think end-users would be oblivious and
>therefore fine with it).
>

What's the hangup.  Actually, the only problems I can think of are 
semantic, not technical - in one case the URI identifies a user, in the 
other, the URI identifies the user's access page.  Given recent 
discussion on the TAG list, this might not be the 'purest' way to do 
things, but it sure seems practical.

>
>5) Move the client to be under the RNA Address, effectively replacing the
>"access URI".  Through conneg, it would still be possible to return the
>original XML document from the client URI so that "thick" clients could
>still have access.  The main advantage here is that the URI would be
>memorable (e.g. http://example.com/rna/seairth/client).  However, it seems
>somewhat like overkill to pass entire URIs in the query string, esp. since
>it would be unlikely that you would use the client to access any RNA address
>other than the one it was under.  On the other hand, I could be wrong here.
>For instance, this would allow one to customize the look-and-feel of the
>client program, then access other RNA Addresses while continuing to keep
>that look-and-feel.  When accessing another site, you would have to use
>something akin to the original syntax (e.g.
>http://example.com/rna/seairth/client?uri=http://example.com/rna/bob), but
>it's probably fine at that point.
>

Why not http://example.com/rna/client?uri=http://example.com/rna/bob 
when you're on a different server?

Why does bob need to know about seairth (or seairth's rna address)?

I think any of the above would probably work out just fine (although I 
really dont like 3).

--Chuck





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3790
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-25 03:17:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:


S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>cookie-based and HTTP auth are identical when the
>client is software.  The only difference is the
>name of the HTTP header in which the
>authentication token is passed.  But really the
>whole premise of HTTP auth is unreasonable for
>automated clients.  Clients just send a secret
>token.  They don't need a mnemonic separating
>usernames from passwords.
>
>For human users, the login form that comes in the
>401 response is as visible as you want.  In
>practice Mozilla appears to auto-fill most login
>forms I reach correctly and without issue which
>makes me think that visibility is a non-issue.
>
>-Alex-
>
>  
>
Hmmm.  I thought visibility was about the ability of 
components/intermediaries to understand the meaning of the message.  
I.e., a proxy can't tell whether or not a cookie contains auth info 
since it doesnt know the syntax of what's been packed in the cookie.  
However, it does know what the HTTP auth header means, and thus knows 
what it can or cant do with the message (and its response).  (This all 
may be moot as far as auth headers and cookies go since I think many 
proxies wont cache things with cookies in them).

--Chuck

>On Thu, 24 Jul 2003, Chuck Hinson wrote:
>
>  
>
>>Alex Jacobson wrote:
>>
>>    
>>
>>>--On Wednesday, July 23, 2003 2:53 PM -0700 "Roy T. Fielding"
>>><fielding@...> wrote:
>>>
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>>>You should note that there is no design reason why Authorization
>>>>and WWW-Authenticate are limited to Basic and Digest.  That is why
>>>>those fields are extensible.  Why would you want to duplicate that
>>>>functionality in another field?
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>        
>>>>
>>>With all due respect, given that HTTP authentication is fundamentally
>>>broken*, that cookies are a defacto standard, and that HTTP-auth is poorly
>>>supported by actual UAs.  The bigger question is why duplicate cookie
>>>functionality with auth-specific headers?
>>>
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>I would think that while cookies may be a defacto standard, cookie-based
>>authentication is not (i.e., there is no standard implementation of
>>authentication using cookies).  Thus, it would seem to me that
>>visibility still suffers.
>>
>>--Chuck
>>
>>
>>    
>>
>
>
>  
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3791
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-25 13:55:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Case Study (was Re: REST & User Interfaces)
Message:

From: "Chuck Hinson" <cmhinson@...>
> >
> >http://example.com/rnaclient?uri=http://example.com/rna/seairth/access
> >
> >Frankly, this isn't very user-friendly.  First, the URL is way to long to
> >have to type in.  Second, it requires me to know/remember the URI of my
> >"access" resource.
> >
>
> I'm not sure I would worry too much about the URI being too long.  No
> matter what the length, the user will probably just bookmark it anyway.

Yes, but bookmarks aren't very portable.  If you sit down at any other
browser, your SOL.  Bookmarks should be a convenience, not a solution.

> >2) Instead, one could use just the RNA Address
> >(http://example.com/rna/seairth) and the client would auto-append the
> >"access" bit.  If the server returned a 404, it could then try other
> >possibilities, effectively hunting for the interface.  This solution is
not
> >very flexible, since all it would take is a particular inplementation to
> >change the path slightly (e.g. "client-access") in order for the client
to
> >fail discovery.
> >
>
> Why bother with the hunting part?  For the sake of interop, just require
> that the access page is the rna address with /access appended. Once
> enough implementations do it that way, any implementation that does it
> differently will be considered broken.

To my knowledge, it's bad form to "force" a specific URI naming convention.
For example, look at the conversations on the www-tag concerning
"favicon.ico", "robots.txt", and "p3p" a couple months ago.

> >4) Double up the access URI and the RNA address.  Since the only purpose
of
> >the access URI is to return an xml document, it would be possible to use
> >conneg on a GET of the RNA Address.  This way, a user would only have to
> >know their own RNA Address (which they would anyhow).  This could be
coupled
> >with #3 above, where the coookie bit would only be a convenience.  The
down
> >side is that I'm not too crazy about overloading the RNA Address like
this
> >(purely from a technical POV; I think end-users would be oblivious and
> >therefore fine with it).
> >
>
> What's the hangup.  Actually, the only problems I can think of are
> semantic, not technical - in one case the URI identifies a user, in the
> other, the URI identifies the user's access page.  Given recent
> discussion on the TAG list, this might not be the 'purest' way to do
> things, but it sure seems practical.

I agree.  One could probably restate it so that it sounded kosher, but it
still doesn't feel right somehow...

> >
> >5) Move the client to be under the RNA Address, effectively replacing the
> >"access URI".  Through conneg, it would still be possible to return the
> >original XML document from the client URI so that "thick" clients could
> >still have access.  The main advantage here is that the URI would be
> >memorable (e.g. http://example.com/rna/seairth/client).  However, it
seems
> >somewhat like overkill to pass entire URIs in the query string, esp.
since
> >it would be unlikely that you would use the client to access any RNA
address
> >other than the one it was under.  On the other hand, I could be wrong
here.
> >For instance, this would allow one to customize the look-and-feel of the
> >client program, then access other RNA Addresses while continuing to keep
> >that look-and-feel.  When accessing another site, you would have to use
> >something akin to the original syntax (e.g.
> >http://example.com/rna/seairth/client?uri=http://example.com/rna/bob),
but
> >it's probably fine at that point.
> >
>
> Why not http://example.com/rna/client?uri=http://example.com/rna/bob
> when you're on a different server?
>
> Why does bob need to know about seairth (or seairth's rna address)?

Normally, bob wouldn't need to know about seairth's RNA address.  bob would
likely access http://example.com/rna/bob/client.  However, I have multiple
identities: personal, work, etc.  In each of those cases, I may have a
separate RNA Address.  I may have full control over my personal address and
client, and therefore may customize it in various ways.  When accessing my
work address, I *could* use the client at that address, but I could also use
the client at my personal address which has my personal customizations.

But this does bring up another interesting issue.  It would be possible to
use any web client to access any RNA Address.  As a result, I could use your
client to access my address.  Now, I don't know *why* I would want to do
such a thing, esp. since I would be giving you the oportunity to discover my
auth-info.  But it is possible.  Of course, it would also be possible to
just disable the feature that would allow such a thing.  For most people,
this would likely be the prefered setting.  Another possbility to would be
to require independent authentication for use of the client.  In most cases,
the authentication info would be the same as for the associated RNA Address
itself.  However, in the case where a second address is accessed (e.g.
work), it would probably be necessary to maintain a separate profile with
separate authentication information so that the client could properly access
the remote RNA Address.  This way, only addresses specified in profiles
would be accessible.

And a final thought (for now)...  If one really wanted to set up a server to
use a format like

> http://example.com/rna/client?uri=http://example.com/rna/bob

This could be done with a redirection.  All bob would have to remember is
http://example.com/rna/bob/client.  Upon typing that in, he would be
redirected to the extended version.  This makes it easy for him to remember
while still allowing flexibility in the way that the client is implemented.

> I think any of the above would probably work out just fine (although I
> really dont like 3).

The more I think about it, the more #5 seems like the way to go.
---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3792
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-25 15:07:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: URIs are RESTful
Message:

The only thing that a proxy decides based on the content of the auth 
headers is caching and if you do cookie-auth you just do more explicit 
cache-control.  And if you are doing auth-related stuff, you should be 
doing more explicit cache control anyway so I don't see the value that 
special purpose auth headers provide.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

--On Thursday, July 24, 2003 11:17 PM -0400 Chuck Hinson 
<cmhinson@...> wrote:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3793
Sender:"justin_t_sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-27 09:59:00
Subject:Pure-REST Wiki experiment
Message:

Trying to reconcile some of the ideas I've been reading here,
last night I threw together the beginnings of a pure-REST Wiki.
The client and server are both included at the end of this
message.

The resources are Wiki topics, with URIs like </wiki/HomePage>,
with GET returning the Wiki-text representation of a topic, PUT
supplying a new Wiki-text representation to create or modify a
topic, and DELETE deleting a topic. POST is not accepted for any
resource in this application. This is all implemented by a single
Java servlet.

The user interface is implemented completely on the client side
using HTML and JavaScript. It uses the XmlHttpRequest object to
make requests to the server. User interaction is done through
form elements, but the form never gets submitted anywhere; it's
just accessed by the JavaScript. The GET, PUT, and DELETE
commands are shown as buttons, and the name of the current topic
is shown in an editable text field. All the commands construct
the URI from the topic name. GET displays the Wiki-text of the
topic in a large textarea; and PUT transfers the contents of that
textarea back to the server, allowing editing of a topic
retrieved by GET. PUT and DELETE both clear the contents of that
textarea. The status code of each response is displayed in a
small non-editable text field.

What I really had in mind was to implement the HTML rendering of
the Wiki text in the JavaScript client as well, including links
between topics as JavaScript onClick handlers, but I didn't get
that far yet.

Some issues:

1. IE caches the GET responses, which is kind of cool. However,
it doesn't invalidate the cache after a PUT or DELETE! So doing a
GET, editing the text, doing a PUT, and then doing a GET again
gives the original text. I had to turn off caching in IE while
playing with it; I guess the GET responses could carry a no-cache
directive instead...

2. At first I returned 204 from PUT if the resource already
existed (201 otherwise), but it seemed that the JavaScript send()
call was never returning. Simply changing it to 205 avoided this
problem.

3. As it is, the user interface is really a browser-in-the-
browser. It has its own location bar, and manages navigation
among Wiki topics entirely within one browser "page".  That
implies a couple of problems -- for one, the browser's history
buttons don't work.

4. Every topic has a URI, but if that URI is typed directly in
the browser, the user will be able to view the Wiki-text
representation of the topic, but won't see any of the UI.

Altogether a successful experiment, demonstrating how to deploy a
potentially-fancy JavaScript-driven UI for a pure-REST
application. I wonder how to resolve the 4 issues above...

Any reactions?

Justin Sampson

P.S. Here's the code:

--- client.html
<HTML>
    <HEAD>
        <TITLE>REST Wiki</TITLE>
        <SCRIPT>
            function wikiGet()
            {
                document.client.status.value = "---";
                var http = new ActiveXObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP");
                var page = document.client.page.value;
                var url = "http://localhost:8080/wiki/" + page;
                http.open("GET", url, false);
                http.send(null);
                if (http.status == 200)
                {
                    document.client.content.value =
                        http.responseText;
                }
                else
                {
                    document.client.content.value = "";
                }
                document.client.status.value = http.status;
            }
            function wikiPut()
            {
                document.client.status.value = "---";
                var http = new ActiveXObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP");
                var page = document.client.page.value;
                var url = "http://localhost:8080/wiki/" + page;
                http.open("PUT", url, false);
                http.setRequestHeader("Content-Type",
                    "text/x-wiki; charset=UTF-8");
                http.send(document.client.content.value);
                document.client.content.value = "";
                document.client.status.value = http.status;
            }
            function wikiDelete()
            {
                document.client.status.value = "---";
                var http = new ActiveXObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP");
                var page = document.client.page.value;
                var url = "http://localhost:8080/wiki/" + page;
                http.open("DELETE", url, false);
                http.send(null);
                document.client.content.value = "";
                document.client.status.value = http.status;
            }
        </SCRIPT>
    </HEAD>
    <BODY onLoad="wikiGet()">
        <FORM name="client">
            <INPUT type="text" name="page" value="HomePage">
            <INPUT type="button" value="Get" onClick="wikiGet()">
            <INPUT type="button" value="Put" onClick="wikiPut()">
            <INPUT type="button" value="Delete"
                onClick="wikiDelete()">
            <INPUT type="text" name="status" disabled>
            <BR>
            <TEXTAREA name="content" cols="80" rows="25">
            </TEXTAREA>
        </FORM>
    </BODY>
</HTML>

--- RestWikiServlet.java
package restwiki;

import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileInputStream;
import java.io.FileOutputStream;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStream;
import java.io.OutputStream;

import javax.servlet.ServletException;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse;

public class RestWikiServlet extends HttpServlet
{

    private File root;

    public void init() throws ServletException
    {
        root = new File(getInitParameter("root"));
    }

    private boolean validWikiName(String wikiName)
    {
        return wikiName != null
            && wikiName.matches("([A-Z][a-z]+){2,}");
    }

    private File pageFile(String wikiName)
    {
        return new File(root, wikiName);
    }

    private String wikiName(HttpServletRequest request)
    {
        String pathInfo = request.getPathInfo();

        if (pathInfo != null && pathInfo.startsWith("/"))
        {
            return pathInfo.substring(1);
        }
        else
        {
            return pathInfo;
        }
    }

    protected synchronized void doGet(
        HttpServletRequest request,
        HttpServletResponse response)
        throws ServletException, IOException
    {
        String wikiName = wikiName(request);

        if (!validWikiName(wikiName))
        {
            response.setStatus(404);
            return;
        }

        File pageFile = pageFile(wikiName);

        if (!pageFile.exists())
        {
            response.setStatus(404);
            return;
        }

        InputStream input = new FileInputStream(pageFile);
        try
        {
            response.setContentType(
                "text/x-wiki; charset=UTF-8");
            response.setStatus(200);
            OutputStream output = response.getOutputStream();
            byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
            int n;
            while ((n = input.read(buffer)) != -1)
            {
                output.write(buffer, 0, n);
            }
        }
        finally
        {
            input.close();
        }
    }

    protected synchronized void doPut(
        HttpServletRequest request,
        HttpServletResponse response)
        throws ServletException, IOException
    {
        String wikiName = wikiName(request);

        if (!validWikiName(wikiName))
        {
            response.setStatus(403);
            return;
        }

        if (!"text/x-wiki; charset=UTF-8".equals(
            request.getContentType()))
        {
            response.setStatus(415);
            return;
        }

        File pageFile = pageFile(wikiName);

        boolean created = !pageFile.exists();

        OutputStream output = new FileOutputStream(pageFile);
        try
        {
            InputStream input = request.getInputStream();
            byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
            int n;
            while ((n = input.read(buffer)) != -1)
            {
                output.write(buffer, 0, n);
            }
            input.close();
        }
        finally
        {
            output.close();
        }

        response.setStatus(created ? 201 : 205);
    }

    protected synchronized void doDelete(
        HttpServletRequest request,
        HttpServletResponse response)
        throws ServletException, IOException
    {
        String wikiName = wikiName(request);

        if (!validWikiName(wikiName))
        {
            response.setStatus(404);
            return;
        }

        File pageFile = pageFile(wikiName);

        if (!pageFile.exists())
        {
            response.setStatus(404);
            return;
        }

        response.setStatus(205);
        pageFile.delete();
    }

}





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3794
Sender:Vincent D.Murphy <vdm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-27 13:04:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Pure-REST Wiki experiment
Message:

On Sunday, Jul 27, 2003, at 10:59 Europe/Dublin, justin_t_sampson wrote:
> The user interface is implemented completely on the client side
> using HTML and JavaScript.

at first i wondered why not use conneg (perhaps based on the user agent 
(UA))
rather than a 'browser-within-a-browser' approach.  as in, the editor 
GETs
wiki-text, and everything else GETs HTML.

i would like to create a RESTful wiki one day as well, real life 
permitting.
FWIW i would model the resources as:

/topic/ : GET gets HTML.
/topic/form/ : GET gets a HTML form with a target of ".." and the 
wikitext
loaded in to a textarea.  the submit method would be POST, even though
semantically i think PUT would be more appropriate here.

i would also like a resource /topic/revisions/ which gives an
annotated-diff revision history of the topic, like viewcvs.

it's always nice to see another real-world RESTful application; kudos on
a nice piece of work.

-vincent





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3795
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-28 13:20:20
Subject:OT: terminology?
Message:

We all know that

    API = Application Program(ming) Interface

However, is this the correct terminology for RESTful interfaces (as
implemented with HTTP)?  Somehow, "API" doesn't seem right.  I would think
something like

    HTTPAI = HTTP Application Interface

or

    ARI = Application Representation Interface

or

    ASI = Application State Interface

or

    RRI = Resource Representation Interface

or

    RHI = REST-HTTP Interface

or something along those lines would be more appropriate...  Is there such a
term already?  If not, any thoughts on what a good one would be?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3796
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-28 15:01:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

network programming interface

Post ID:3797
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-28 17:27:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Pure-REST Wiki experiment
Message:

Very cool.  Its too bad it works only in IE.

Rather than implementing rending in javascript, you could use conneg on the 
server to differentiate between retrieving rendered pages and the source. A 
GET with a "accept: text/plain" would retrieve the source.  A GET with an 
"accept: text/html" would retrieve the rendered page.

Question for the group: Suppose that the wiki also rendered into ASCII.  Is 
there some convention for retrieving the source rather than the output 
beyond a slight hack involving coercing them to have different 
content-types?

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax



--On Sunday, July 27, 2003 9:59 AM +0000 justin_t_sampson 
<justin.sampson@...> wrote:

> Trying to reconcile some of the ideas I've been reading here,
> last night I threw together the beginnings of a pure-REST Wiki.
> The client and server are both included at the end of this
> message.
>
> The resources are Wiki topics, with URIs like </wiki/HomePage>,
> with GET returning the Wiki-text representation of a topic, PUT
> supplying a new Wiki-text representation to create or modify a
> topic, and DELETE deleting a topic. POST is not accepted for any
> resource in this application. This is all implemented by a single
> Java servlet.
>
> The user interface is implemented completely on the client side
> using HTML and JavaScript. It uses the XmlHttpRequest object to
> make requests to the server. User interaction is done through
> form elements, but the form never gets submitted anywhere; it's
> just accessed by the JavaScript. The GET, PUT, and DELETE
> commands are shown as buttons, and the name of the current topic
> is shown in an editable text field. All the commands construct
> the URI from the topic name. GET displays the Wiki-text of the
> topic in a large textarea; and PUT transfers the contents of that
> textarea back to the server, allowing editing of a topic
> retrieved by GET. PUT and DELETE both clear the contents of that
> textarea. The status code of each response is displayed in a
> small non-editable text field.
>
> What I really had in mind was to implement the HTML rendering of
> the Wiki text in the JavaScript client as well, including links
> between topics as JavaScript onClick handlers, but I didn't get
> that far yet.
>
> Some issues:
>
> 1. IE caches the GET responses, which is kind of cool. However,
> it doesn't invalidate the cache after a PUT or DELETE! So doing a
> GET, editing the text, doing a PUT, and then doing a GET again
> gives the original text. I had to turn off caching in IE while
> playing with it; I guess the GET responses could carry a no-cache
> directive instead...
>
> 2. At first I returned 204 from PUT if the resource already
> existed (201 otherwise), but it seemed that the JavaScript send()
> call was never returning. Simply changing it to 205 avoided this
> problem.
>
> 3. As it is, the user interface is really a browser-in-the-
> browser. It has its own location bar, and manages navigation
> among Wiki topics entirely within one browser "page".  That
> implies a couple of problems -- for one, the browser's history
> buttons don't work.
>
> 4. Every topic has a URI, but if that URI is typed directly in
> the browser, the user will be able to view the Wiki-text
> representation of the topic, but won't see any of the UI.
>
> Altogether a successful experiment, demonstrating how to deploy a
> potentially-fancy JavaScript-driven UI for a pure-REST
> application. I wonder how to resolve the 4 issues above...
>
> Any reactions?
>
> Justin Sampson
>
> P.S. Here's the code:
>
> --- client.html
> <HTML>
>     <HEAD>
>         <TITLE>REST Wiki</TITLE>
>         <DEFANGED_SCRIPT>
>             function wikiGet()
>             {
>                 document.client.status.value = "---";
>                 var http = new ActiveXObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP");
>                 var page = document.client.page.value;
>                 var url = "http://localhost:8080/wiki/" + page;
>                 http.open("GET", url, false);
>                 http.send(null);
>                 if (http.status == 200)
>                 {
>                     document.client.content.value =
>                         http.responseText;
>                 }
>                 else
>                 {
>                     document.client.content.value = "";
>                 }
>                 document.client.status.value = http.status;
>             }
>             function wikiPut()
>             {
>                 document.client.status.value = "---";
>                 var http = new ActiveXObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP");
>                 var page = document.client.page.value;
>                 var url = "http://localhost:8080/wiki/" + page;
>                 http.open("PUT", url, false);
>                 http.setRequestHeader("Content-Type",
>                     "text/x-wiki; charset=UTF-8");
>                 http.send(document.client.content.value);
>                 document.client.content.value = "";
>                 document.client.status.value = http.status;
>             }
>             function wikiDelete()
>             {
>                 document.client.status.value = "---";
>                 var http = new ActiveXObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP");
>                 var page = document.client.page.value;
>                 var url = "http://localhost:8080/wiki/" + page;
>                 http.open("DELETE", url, false);
>                 http.send(null);
>                 document.client.content.value = "";
>                 document.client.status.value = http.status;
>             }
>         </SCRIPT>
>     </HEAD>
>     <BODY DEFANGED_OnLoad="wikiGet()">
>         <FORM name="client">
>             <INPUT type="text" name="page" value="HomePage">
>             <INPUT type="button" value="Get" DEFANGED_OnClick="wikiGet()">
>             <INPUT type="button" value="Put" DEFANGED_OnClick="wikiPut()">
>             <INPUT type="button" value="Delete"
> DEFANGED_OnClick="wikiDelete()">
>             <INPUT type="text" name="status" disabled>
>             <BR>
>             <TEXTAREA name="content" cols="80" rows="25">
>             </TEXTAREA>
>         </FORM>
>     </BODY>
> </HTML>
>
> --- RestWikiServlet.java
> package restwiki;
>
> import java.io.File;
> import java.io.FileInputStream;
> import java.io.FileOutputStream;
> import java.io.IOException;
> import java.io.InputStream;
> import java.io.OutputStream;
>
> import javax.servlet.ServletException;
> import javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet;
> import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest;
> import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse;
>
> public class RestWikiServlet extends HttpServlet
> {
>
>     private File root;
>
>     public void init() throws ServletException
>     {
>         root = new File(getInitParameter("root"));
>     }
>
>     private boolean validWikiName(String wikiName)
>     {
>         return wikiName != null
>             && wikiName.matches("([A-Z][a-z]+){2,}");
>     }
>
>     private File pageFile(String wikiName)
>     {
>         return new File(root, wikiName);
>     }
>
>     private String wikiName(HttpServletRequest request)
>     {
>         String pathInfo = request.getPathInfo();
>
>         if (pathInfo != null && pathInfo.startsWith("/"))
>         {
>             return pathInfo.substring(1);
>         }
>         else
>         {
>             return pathInfo;
>         }
>     }
>
>     protected synchronized void doGet(
>         HttpServletRequest request,
>         HttpServletResponse response)
>         throws ServletException, IOException
>     {
>         String wikiName = wikiName(request);
>
>         if (!validWikiName(wikiName))
>         {
>             response.setStatus(404);
>             return;
>         }
>
>         File pageFile = pageFile(wikiName);
>
>         if (!pageFile.exists())
>         {
>             response.setStatus(404);
>             return;
>         }
>
>         InputStream input = new FileInputStream(pageFile);
>         try
>         {
>             response.setContentType(
>                 "text/x-wiki; charset=UTF-8");
>             response.setStatus(200);
>             OutputStream output = response.getOutputStream();
>             byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
>             int n;
>             while ((n = input.read(buffer)) != -1)
>             {
>                 output.write(buffer, 0, n);
>             }
>         }
>         finally
>         {
>             input.close();
>         }
>     }
>
>     protected synchronized void doPut(
>         HttpServletRequest request,
>         HttpServletResponse response)
>         throws ServletException, IOException
>     {
>         String wikiName = wikiName(request);
>
>         if (!validWikiName(wikiName))
>         {
>             response.setStatus(403);
>             return;
>         }
>
>         if (!"text/x-wiki; charset=UTF-8".equals(
>             request.getContentType()))
>         {
>             response.setStatus(415);
>             return;
>         }
>
>         File pageFile = pageFile(wikiName);
>
>         boolean created = !pageFile.exists();
>
>         OutputStream output = new FileOutputStream(pageFile);
>         try
>         {
>             InputStream input = request.getInputStream();
>             byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
>             int n;
>             while ((n = input.read(buffer)) != -1)
>             {
>                 output.write(buffer, 0, n);
>             }
>             input.close();
>         }
>         finally
>         {
>             output.close();
>         }
>
>         response.setStatus(created ? 201 : 205);
>     }
>
>     protected synchronized void doDelete(
>         HttpServletRequest request,
>         HttpServletResponse response)
>         throws ServletException, IOException
>     {
>         String wikiName = wikiName(request);
>
>         if (!validWikiName(wikiName))
>         {
>             response.setStatus(404);
>             return;
>         }
>
>         File pageFile = pageFile(wikiName);
>
>         if (!pageFile.exists())
>         {
>             response.setStatus(404);
>             return;
>         }
>
>         response.setStatus(205);
>         pageFile.delete();
>     }
>
> }
>
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>

Post ID:3798
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-28 19:05:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Pure-REST Wiki experiment
Message:

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "justin_t_sampson" <justin.sampson@...>;
<rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, July 28, 2003 1:27 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Pure-REST Wiki experiment


> Question for the group: Suppose that the wiki also rendered into ASCII.
Is
> there some convention for retrieving the source rather than the output
> beyond a slight hack involving coercing them to have different
> content-types?

Slightly different URI?  For instance, given a folder in my blog system, you
can return different formats as follows:

http://www.seairth.com/blog?rss=0.91
http://www.seairth.com/blog?rss=0.92
http://www.seairth.com/blog?rss=0.93
http://www.seairth.com/blog?rss=2.0

Using a content-type of "text/xml" would not be enough.  In the wiki, maybe
you could add a global "type" URL parameter so that you could do something
like:

http://example.com/wiki/HomePage?type=editable

interface, but it's constructed differently (new XmlHttpRequest(), I
think
-- imagine that). Don't know about other browsers.

Post ID:3800
Sender:Michael Day <mikeday@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-28 23:45:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

> However, is this the correct terminology for RESTful interfaces (as
> implemented with HTTP)?  Somehow, "API" doesn't seem right.  I would think
> something like

An API provides an interface without which the code/library/service cannot 
be used. However a RESTful interface uses hypertext as the engine of 
application state (so the set of possible transitions is documented in the 
instance data, not in some external interface definition) with a small set 
of known verbs. So it seems to me that no such term is necessary, aside 
from "RESTful interface" (RI?).

Michael

-- 
YesLogic Prince prints XML!
http://yeslogic.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3801
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-29 05:54:44
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Pure-REST Wiki experiment
Message:

Vincent Murphy wrote:

> > The user interface is implemented completely on the client
> > side using HTML and JavaScript.
>
> at first i wondered why not use conneg (perhaps based on the
> user agent (UA)) rather than a 'browser-within-a-browser'
> approach. as in, the editor GETs wiki-text, and everything else
> GETs HTML.

I have a feeling what I really want is to convince the browser
that my client.html is actually a plugin appropriate for
text/x-wiki content. So, whenever the user types in a URI that
dereferences to a representation of type text/x-wiki, the
response would simply be passed off to this JavaScript client.
The client would still have its own buttons for Edit and Delete,
sending PUT and DELETE requests, respectively; but links to other
Wiki topics or to non-Wiki URIs would be handed back to the
browser.

Justin

Post ID:3802
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-29 14:19:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

On Monday 28 July 2003 19:45, Michael Day wrote:
> > However, is this the correct terminology for RESTful interfaces (as
> > implemented with HTTP)?  Somehow, "API" doesn't seem right.  I would
> > think something like
>
> An API provides an interface without which the code/library/service cannot
> be used. However a RESTful interface uses hypertext as the engine of
> application state (so the set of possible transitions is documented in the
> instance data, not in some external interface definition) with a small set
> of known verbs. So it seems to me that no such term is necessary, aside
> from "RESTful interface" (RI?).

But the document schemas are a prerequisite. Even with GET, the
programmer needs to know how to interpret the returned document.
The HTML spec has to exist for the WWW to work.

W3 specs of this kind seem to be called "languages".  Perhaps the
replacement for API is AL (Application Language).

Tyler

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3803
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-29 23:13:25
Subject:MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

Note: Draft musings.  Please be gentle.

Model State Transfer is an emerging web architecture style in which agents 
transfer application data models themselves occasionally packaged with 
metadata describing how the model should be viewed and constraining how it 
may be altered (e.g. HTML/XML with css/xsl stylesheets and schemas).  In 
contrast Representational State Transfer, is an older style in which agents 
transfer representations of application referents (e.g. HTTP with conneg 
and content-type).

REST pretends that we can talk about transferring representations without 
talking about being able to talk unambiguously about what is represented. 
This pretense is surprisingly effective in publishing information hidden in 
databases.  It runs into serious trouble however when we want to shift from 
publishing apps to two-way apps.  Examples include the difficulty in 
describing how to implement a Wiki, the meaninglessness of "index" and HTTP 
containers, the failure of conneg, the uselessness of PUT (and WebDAV 
almost everywhere), and the lack of a coherent story about POST.

No ReSTful general Wikis or web editting (or the uselessness of PUT)
ReSTful clients lack a model for the data they receive and therefore can do 
little other than render it.  The uselessness of PUT is an obvious 
consequence of this failure.   PUT only works in the small set of apps 
where the returned data happens to correspond to the underlying model or 
when changes in the representation are invertible.  Those apps are actually 
relatively rare.  Wiki and database apps both fall outside that category. 
Of course, one CAN design apps to make sure that this constraint is 
followed, but then you are no longer passing around representations, you 
are passing around data models themselves.
The upshot of ReSTs failure here is that we are actually spending any time 
at all implementing Wikis as opposed to WebDAV and that none of this work 
is useful for editing user-friendly directories.  In contrast, MoST 
architectural style would give the client the underlying data so that 
File|Edit would have the browser open an editor appropriate to the data 
content-type.  For example, in a addressbook application, the server would 
send XML V-Cards with a stylesheet URL in the XML header that transforms 
those v-cards into user-friendly SVG.  The client would apply the 
transformation and render the SVG using an SVG viewer.   If the user chose 
File|Edit from the browser menu, the browser would open up an editor 
designed to handle v-cards (outlook? if installed) or perhaps simply an XML 
editor.  And when the user "saves" the changes, they are simply PUT back to 
the server.


Containers
Another example of the failure of the ReST model is uselessness of the 
container metaphor.  The most obvious operation to perform on a container 
is to obtain an enumeration of its contents.  ReST provides no standard way 
to do that.  Instead servers are intended to return a "respresentation" of 
the container. In practice this representation is so far from representing 
the container that a foo/ URL is really just a URL like any other with no 
particularly interesting special properties.  Under MoST GETting a foo/ URL 
would actually result in a model of the container.  This model may be 
packaged with a view URL/transformation, but containership would actually 
have real meaning.

Content-Negotiation
Content-negotiation exacerbates the problem above.  It is particularly 
incompatible with PUT/POST because the server has no way to tell the client 
what types may be PUT/POST and REST provides no way to understand what was 
meant when a client does so.  MoST applications  give each URL a specific 
content-type/data-model.  MoST clients and servers know that they are 
communicating about that data model.  Under MoST it is meaningful to update 
content from a PUT.  In real life, conneg is used much less often than 
simply proliferating URLs.  MoST endorses that approach, viewing e.g. 
language translations as different objects and not simply different 
representations.

What is a POST?
In theory a POST is intended to update the server about some refferent.  In 
practice usage of POST also ends up being application specific.  There is 
no way to know what one may POST to a particular URL without having access 
to some special purpose meta-data located at some arbitrarily different URL 
(the location of e.g. an HTTP form).  ReST also provides no way of knowing 
what the consequence of a POST is, other than, abstractly, some state 
change, perhaps.  In contrast, a MoST POST has some semantic coherence.  It 
is an append to a container (because we now have containers) or it is an 
update to particular data model based on the semantics of updates to models 
of that type.  Note: Unlike ReST POSTs, MoST POSTs are NOT database queries 
unless they create new resources that are result-sets.

Queries
ReST has no interpretation of query strings either.  They are opaque and 
invisible.  MoST constrains query strings to be filters on the set of 
objects returns by a container (because it actually has access to models it 
can do this).  Query-strings on non-container objects are not-meaninful.

Container Creation
MKDIR is a silly semantic.  Simply PUT a container data model at a URL 
where you want the container to be.  Then you have a container.  If the 
server doesn't understand the semantics of the container data model the 
client puts, it gives an error.

HTTP support for MoST architectural style is relatively weak.  Content-type 
ends up being used both to constrain viewing and editing.  XML with schemas 
and stylesheets better supports MoST.   It would be nice to be able to do 
MoST with other content-types.  Perhaps HTTP will eventually have a 
content-view or model-location header.

Note: MoST isn't a PhD thesis.  It is just my description of a different 
design philosophy
that I see around.  Hoping for useful comments.

Justin is effectively describing a MoST wiki implementation rather than a 
ReST implementation below.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

>> > side using HTML and JavaScript.
>>
>> at first i wondered why not use conneg (perhaps based on the
>> user agent (UA)) rather than a 'browser-within-a-browser'
>> approach. as in, the editor GETs wiki-text, and everything else
>> GETs HTML.
>
> I have a feeling what I really want is to convince the browser
> that my client.html is actually a plugin appropriate for
> text/x-wiki content. So, whenever the user types in a URI that
> dereferences to a representation of type text/x-wiki, the
> response would simply be passed off to this JavaScript client.
> The client would still have its own buttons for Edit and Delete,
> sending PUT and DELETE requests, respectively; but links to other
> Wiki topics or to non-Wiki URIs would be handed back to the
