Post ID:3804
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 01:06:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    Alex> REST pretends that we can talk about transferring
    Alex> representations without talking about being able to talk
    Alex> unambiguously about what is represented.  

How is this different from Content-Type? If I ask for a GET with
Content-Type V-Card isn't that unambigious? Or GET with Content-Type
audio/wav or audio/mp3, isn't that clear?


    Alex> Content-Negotiation Content-negotiation exacerbates the
    Alex> problem above.  It is particularly incompatible with
    Alex> PUT/POST because the server has no way to tell the client
    Alex> what types may be PUT/POST and REST provides no way to
    Alex> understand what was meant when a client does so.

A GET with Content-Type rest/content-types can solve this perhaps?

A server can always accepts content types it understands and issue a
4xx when it doesn't of course.


I'm afraid that meta modeling doesn't solve any problem. The next
problem is usually the meta meta model of that. And the meta meta meta
model of that.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3805
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 14:57:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

--On Wednesday, July 30, 2003 1:06 PM +1200 Berend de Boer 
<berend@...> wrote:
>>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:
>     Alex> REST pretends that we can talk about transferring
>     Alex> representations without talking about being able to talk
>     Alex> unambiguously about what is represented.
>
> How is this different from Content-Type? If I ask for a GET with
> Content-Type V-Card isn't that unambigious? Or GET with Content-Type
> audio/wav or audio/mp3, isn't that clear?

My point is that ReST views the returned content as a representation of the 
refferent of a URL.  So, in ReST, a V-Card or an MP3 is only a 
representation of a business card or a song not the business-card or song 
itself.  We've known since Plato that there is no unmediated access to any 
real-world thing so this representational view guarantees vagueness.

I am suggesting that we concentrate all the representational vagueness in 
the construction of the data model and then focus our Internet applications 
only on manipulating particular data models -- which is much less vague.

In other words, I am suggesting that clients and servers have a shared data 
model (content-type) and not just a shared referent (URI).

>     Alex> Content-Negotiation Content-negotiation exacerbates the
>     Alex> problem above.  It is particularly incompatible with
>     Alex> PUT/POST because the server has no way to tell the client
>     Alex> what types may be PUT/POST and REST provides no way to
>     Alex> understand what was meant when a client does so.
>
> A GET with Content-Type rest/content-types can solve this perhaps?

I'm not sure what you mean

> A server can always accepts content types it understands and issue a
> 4xx when it doesn't of course.

On some level, my point is that machines don't understand content-types 
PERIOD; they only manipulate them according to some set of predefined 
rules.  My issue with ReST is that it provides no rules for manipulating 
them other than the application specific rules divined by the server 
operator and hidden from the world.

If the data model of the server is hidden, then the effect of a PUT is 
completely unpredictable.  If a client GETs foo.gif and then PUTs bar.gif, 
exactly what should be the expected behavior?  Should the server delete the 
foo.gif and replace it with the bar.gif?  If the foo.gif is a picture of a 
person wearing a blue shirt and bar.gif a person wearing a green shirt, 
should the server simply update a database entry about the color of a 
shirt?  Without the underlying data model, we have no way to understand the 
effect of any change operation without a lot of application/server specific 
local knowledge.

In contrast, if a MoST client GETs a foo.gif, it knows that foo.gif is the 
shared data model for whatever it represents. If it PUTs bar.gif, the 
effect actually will be simply to replace foo.gif with a new model.

Alternatively, if we are really talking about colors of shirts, then 
perhaps the MoST server would return a
<shirt><color>#12aabb</color></shirt> perhaps with some stylesheet that 
converts <shirt> into a user friendly representation and perhaps with the 
URL of a shirt editor (or perhaps the user has an editor for <shirt>s).

Again the problem is that just saying that agents transfer Representations 
is not enough of a constraint to have any useful understanding of what is 
going on.  Unless the content-type is the thing itself, it really tells you 
very little.  The only thing you an do with a representation (absent a data 
model) is receive it.

> I'm afraid that meta modeling doesn't solve any problem. The next
> problem is usually the meta meta model of that. And the meta meta meta
> model of that.

I'm not sure what you are referencing here.  My point is simple that 
clients and servers should share data models and not simply transfer 
representations/views.  Communications between agents centers around 
synchronizing data models of particular referrents.  Effectively I am 
saying that each agent should implements Model-View-Controller locally and 
when its Model changes state, it should transfer that state change.

In contrast, ReST has clients transfer Views around.  Since in most 
application contexts it is very hard to know what changed in the model 
simply by an arbitrary view, ReST then requires a lot more coordination 
behavior to understand change in view means from a local (private) model 
perspective.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3806
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 19:34:29
Subject:RE: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

Alex Jacobson wrote:

> Model State Transfer is an emerging web architecture style in
> which agents transfer application data models themselves
> occasionally packaged with metadata describing how the model
> should be viewed and constraining how it may be altered (e.g.
> HTML/XML with css/xsl stylesheets and schemas). [...]

It sounds like by "model" you're referring to a primary
representation for the resource, like the Wiki-text
representation as opposed to the HTML rendering of a Wiki topic.
This jibes with the discomfort I expressed about treating the
HTML rendering as another representation of the same resource.

A couple of points come to mind:

1. Content negotiation is confusing, and multiple representations
   just aren't used very often.

2. For PUT to be meaningful, the browser must GET the primary
   representation anyway, for the user to edit.

We're still talking about transferring representations of
resources, but expressing a preference for a single
representation for each resource, with stylesheets or scripts for
rendering.

The HTML4 spec describes an HTTP header called Link that can
specify one or more stylesheets appropriate for rendering a
resource for different media. I like this idea because it keeps
the rendering hints entirely outside of the representation of the
resource itself, which is what we've been talking about.

Link can also give the "global" links that appear at the top and
bottom of every page in a typical Web UI (index, contents, etc.),
though I don't think such links are typically displayed by
existing browsers.

See <http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/present/styles.html#h-14.6>.
(There's a note that Link is not defined by HTTP/1.1.)

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3807
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 19:35:02
Subject:RE: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

Alex Jacobson wrote:

> Justin is effectively describing a MoST wiki implementation rather
> than a ReST implementation below.

Nice acronym, but it's odd that what I described as "pure REST" you
feel a need to call something else entirely...

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3808
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 15:08:33
Subject:Re: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

--On Wednesday, July 30, 2003 9:14 AM +0000 justin_t_sampson 
<justin.sampson@...> wrote:

>> Model State Transfer is an emerging web architecture style in
>> which agents transfer application data models themselves
>> occasionally packaged with metadata describing how the model
>> should be viewed and constraining how it may be altered (e.g.
>> HTML/XML with css/xsl stylesheets and schemas). [...]
>
> It sounds like by "model" you're referring to a primary
> representation for the resource, like the Wiki-text
> representation as opposed to the HTML rendering of a Wiki topic.
> This jibes with the discomfort I expressed about treating the
> HTML rendering as another representation of the same resource.

Exactly.  Yes.

> A couple of points come to mind:
>
> 1. Content negotiation is confusing, and multiple representations
>    just aren't used very often.

Yes.  The only use of alternative content is in some form of 
transfer-encoding.  Both endpoints need to be talking about the same model. 


> 2. For PUT to be meaningful, the browser must GET the primary
>    representation anyway, for the user to edit.
>
> We're still talking about transferring representations of
> resources, but expressing a preference for a single
> representation for each resource, with stylesheets or scripts for
> rendering.

Yes, you could say that.  The issue is that ReST does not sufficiently 
constrain the meaning of representation.  The ReST definition of 
representation is that what is transferred is a representation of a human 
concept or thing.  I am saying there is an intermediate step where we build 
a shared model of that concept or thing and manipulate the models in 
various ways.  The relationship between the model and any referent is 
entirely in the heads of humans.  The software deals only with models.

> The HTML4 spec describes an HTTP header called Link that can
> specify one or more stylesheets appropriate for rendering a
> resource for different media. I like this idea because it keeps
> the rendering hints entirely outside of the representation of the
> resource itself, which is what we've been talking about.
>

Exactly.  The XML/HTML world is moving in the MoST direction.  HTTP in 
general still seems to be stuck with ReST.  HTTP needs either a 
Content-View header (a generalization of the Link header) or it needs a 
Model-Location header.

I think we are very much on the same page here.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3809
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 15:12:26
Subject:Re: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

MoST is either ReST with additional constraints to achieve much greater 
levels of visibility or MoST supercedes ReST because ReST is useful only 
for web publishing and we want more.

I don't have a huge stake in defining ReST one way or another.  My personal 
view is that ReST is sufficiently semantically incoherent so you can go in 
whatever direction you like.  Try reading Roy's dissertation and figuring 
out the exact meaning of resource and representation in his paper and 
you'll see what I mean.



-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

--On Wednesday, July 30, 2003 9:39 AM +0000 justin_t_sampson 
<justin.sampson@...> wrote:

> Alex Jacobson wrote:
>
>> Justin is effectively describing a MoST wiki implementation rather
>> than a ReST implementation below.
>
> Nice acronym, but it's odd that what I described as "pure REST" you
> feel a need to call something else entirely...
>
> Jstin
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3810
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 19:56:05
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    Alex> Content-Negotiation Content-negotiation exacerbates the
    Alex> problem above.  It is particularly incompatible with
    Alex> PUT/POST because the server has no way to tell the client
    Alex> what types may be PUT/POST and REST provides no way to
    Alex> understand what was meant when a client does so.

    >>  A GET with Content-Type rest/content-types can solve this
    >> perhaps?

    Alex> I'm not sure what you mean

Retrieving the list of "what types may be PUT/POST".


    Alex> In contrast, if a MoST client GETs a foo.gif, it knows that
    Alex> foo.gif is the shared data model for whatever it
    Alex> represents. If it PUTs bar.gif, the effect actually will be
    Alex> simply to replace foo.gif with a new model.

Yep, but what about versioning? Some systems allow you to retrieve
the system state at a particular point in time. Sometimes you want
bar.gif only to take effect at a future point in time, etc. etc.

Having all that into a meta model makes things quite
complex. Inevitable you will make a meta-model that does not cover
everything.


    >> I'm afraid that meta modeling doesn't solve any problem. The
    >> next problem is usually the meta meta model of that. And the
    >> meta meta meta model of that.

And that's where this comes into play. The next person makes a
slightly different metamodel that allows for updating put.gif
retrospectively in time for example (if you view the system state at
now - 10 days, you get bar.gif instead of foo.gif what you got when
you actually had looked 10 days ago)

And so forth. Now we have several competing meta models (just look at
the web services coordination/work flow/transaction/whatever specs
that are coming out at a rate of one a week).

Someone looking at that might decide: ah, the solution is a meta
metamodel that describes meta models.


    Alex> I'm not sure what you are referencing here.  My point is
    Alex> simple that clients and servers should share data models and
    Alex> not simply transfer representations/views.  

But that data model, inevitably, will not be complete. Some clients
want to know more. And we have the same issue you have know.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3811
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 20:39:14
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

On Thu, 31 Jul 2003, Berend de Boer wrote:
>     Alex> Content-Negotiation Content-negotiation exacerbates the
>     Alex> problem above.  It is particularly incompatible with
>     Alex> PUT/POST because the server has no way to tell the client
>     Alex> what types may be PUT/POST and REST provides no way to
>     Alex> understand what was meant when a client does so.
>
>     >>  A GET with Content-Type rest/content-types can solve this
>     >> perhaps?
>
>     Alex> I'm not sure what you mean
>
> Retrieving the list of "what types may be PUT/POST".

We had a discussion earlier about standardizing these things.
My conclusion is that the best way to standardize these things
is to associate each URI with a single shared data model.

But the types don't matter.  If you look at the
example of GETting foo.gif and PUTting bar.gif and
even if we know that the server accepts image/gif,
ReST still can't tell you what the result of the
PUT will be!  That strikes me as ridiculous.

>     Alex> In contrast, if a MoST client GETs a foo.gif, it knows that
>     Alex> foo.gif is the shared data model for whatever it
>     Alex> represents. If it PUTs bar.gif, the effect actually will be
>     Alex> simply to replace foo.gif with a new model.
>
> Yep, but what about versioning? Some systems allow you to retrieve
> the system state at a particular point in time. Sometimes you want
> bar.gif only to take effect at a future point in time, etc. etc.
>
> Having all that into a meta model makes things quite
> complex. Inevitable you will make a meta-model that does not cover
> everything.

If the data-model represents versions, then you
have versions.  If it doesn't, you don't. The only
way to accomplish this versioning is to have a
shared versioned data model.

More generally, the server always has SOME model.
All I want to do is expose it.  If you want to
build an app ABOUT the server, fine but that is
just some other model.  When you build that app,
you should expose *that* model.

Absent a shared model, you have NO way to
anticipate the result of ANY state change.

>     >> I'm afraid that meta modeling doesn't solve any problem. The
>     >> next problem is usually the meta meta model of that. And the
>     >> meta meta meta model of that.
>
> And that's where this comes into play. The next person makes a
> slightly different metamodel that allows for updating put.gif
> retrospectively in time for example (if you view the system state at
> now - 10 days, you get bar.gif instead of foo.gif what you got when
> you actually had looked 10 days ago)

Again.  You have whatever model you have.  Absent
that model, you have no way to understand what
happens when you do a POST or PUT.  If you change
the model the server uses, that is fine.  You then
need to expose that.  If the model is a changelog
represented in XML e.g.
<changelog>
<change date="200307060000" href="/foo.gif">
<change date="200307100000" href="/bar.gif">
</changelog>

You can allow or disallow PUTs to /foo.gif
/bar.gif or to the changelog itself.  All I'm
saying is that you have to expose SOME model and
the same goes for a changelog of this changelog.

> And so forth. Now we have several competing meta models (just look at
> the web services coordination/work flow/transaction/whatever specs
> that are coming out at a rate of one a week).

At the end of the day, we are all just
synchronizing models of various referents.  I am
saying your life will be easier if you have
generic semantics for doing this rather than
custom developing a mapping between a PUT
representation and an underlying data model for
each URI!

>     Alex> I'm not sure what you are referencing here.  My point is
>     Alex> simple that clients and servers should share data models and
>     Alex> not simply transfer representations/views.
>
> But that data model, inevitably, will not be complete. Some clients
> want to know more. And we have the same issue you have know.

When clients want to know more, you build more
models.  Until then, you have the models you have.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3812
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 01:47:59
Subject:HTTP 4xx response entities
Message:

Typically, entities in a 4xx response have been html messages giving details
of the error.  This is fine if the client is a web browser, but more or less
useless if the client doesn't work with html.  For instance, suppose you
have a client that GETs, POSTs, PUTs, and DELETEs XML documents.  If a PUT
fails, then an appropriate error response must be returned (e.g. 403
Forbidden).  Ideally, the response entity would given an indication of what
went wrong and the format of the entity would be something that the client
understood.  In this case, it makes sense that the response entity would
likely be XML since it was the content-type of the request entity.

So, where to go from here?  Is there a specification for conveying "error"
information? If not, I would like to propose the following:

The general format would be something like:

<responseMetadata level="" code="">
    details
</responseMetadata>

"level" can be either "HTTP" or "APPLICATION".  "HTTP" would be used to
provide extended response information beyond what HTTP currently allows.
For instance, if the response were 406 (Not Acceptable), the details could
list the possible content-types that could be returned. "APPLICATION" would
be used to provide extended response information about the processing
application.  For instance, when the PUT of an XML document fails due to an
invalid value, this level would be used to indicate the failure was not at
the HTTP level.

    Note: "realm" or "type" may be a better name than "level".

"code" is a akin to an error number.  The type of code used depends on the
value of "level".  If level="HTTP", then the code would be the same as the
HTTP response code (e.g., if a 403 response is sent, then code="403").  If
level="APPLICATION", then the possible values of code are
application-specific.

    Note: Maybe for level="HTTP", the "code" would be left off, as it is
redundant.

The "details" would be additional markup specific to the level and code
given.  In the case of level="HTTP", this specification would be fleshed out
to include "standard" markup for each response code (if there is any).  For
level="APPLICATION", the nature of the markup is entirely
application-specific.

For example:

1) POST an "application/xml" document returns:

HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden
Content-Type: application/responseMetadata+xml

<responseMetadata level="APPLICATION" code="14">
    <!-- code="14" indicates a missing element in
        the request. In this case, "identity". -->
    <element name="identity"/>
</responseMetadata>

2) GET an "text/oddball" document returns:

HTTP/1.1 406 Not Acceptable
Content-Type: application/responseMetadata+xml

<responseMetadata level="HTTP">
    <!-- listed in order of preference? -->
    <content-type value="text/xml"/>
    <content-type value="application/xml"/>
    <content-type value="image/gif"/>
    <content-type value="text/html"/>
</responseMetadata>



Additional notes:

1) This could also be used for 5xx responses.

2) This could technique *could* be used to respond to OPTIONS request (with
a 200 response).  For level="HTTP", additional information about the list of
understood request headers and their possible values could be given.  For
level="APPLICATION", additional application-specific information about the
resource could be given.

3) Though this response could be used for requests other than POSTing and
PUTing of XML documents, an additional level of "XML" may be provided, where
a series of codes and detail would be provided which correspond to the
well-formedness rules in the XML specification.  Is there maybe a list like
this already?

At any rate, you all get the idea... what do you think?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3813
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-30 22:33:57
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

> MoST is either ReST with additional constraints to achieve much greater
> levels of visibility or MoST supercedes ReST because ReST is useful 
> only
> for web publishing and we want more.
>
> I don't have a huge stake in defining ReST one way or another.  My 
> personal
> view is that ReST is sufficiently semantically incoherent so you can 
> go in
> whatever direction you like.  Try reading Roy's dissertation and 
> figuring
> out the exact meaning of resource and representation in his paper and
> you'll see what I mean.

Well, now that's a completely clueless statement.  The point of the
definitions is that the interface does not define the exact meaning,
leaving meaning to be defined by the nature of the links between
the information.  A server does the interpolation between the contents
of a PUT and the model hidden behind the server -- saying that isn't
defined by REST is just goofy.  I have no problems building PUT,
containers, or any of the other things that you claim are not defined
by REST, since those are implementation details that are defined within
HTTP by the origin server and not by the client.  I don't even need to
use webdav, though it has its definitions as well.  The only problems
I run into are buggy browsers that never managed to implement basic
HTTP correctly, let alone the advanced features.

If you don't like the generic interface, then just implement a
distributed file system.  That has all the features you are looking
for in a concrete model.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3814
Sender:Jeff Bone <jbone@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 05:43:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

On Wednesday, Jul 30, 2003, at 17:33 US/Central, Roy T. Fielding wrote:

> If you don't like the generic interface, then just implement a
> distributed file system.  That has all the features you are looking
> for in a concrete model.

Roy,

Small point to pick nits, but I thought we'd converged on this point 
before...

What's the difference between the Web and a distributed filesystem such 
as Plan 9's 9P or Amoeba's Bullet File System?

Who says distributed filesystems don't have generic interfaces?

IMHO, there differences between REST and the architectural styles of 
certain distributed filesystems are rather superficial.  You could 
easily tool out various filesystem implementations (I'm particularly 
thinking of e.g. Amoeba's) to strictly conform to REST at a high level. 
  (Not sure why you'd want to, but that's a different matter entirely.)

jb





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3815
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 06:05:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

> What's the difference between the Web and a distributed filesystem such
> as Plan 9's 9P or Amoeba's Bullet File System?

A shared data model between client and server for directories,
metadata, and content.  Basically, the same as the difference
between REST and Alex's notion of MoST, which is why I said he
might as well use a distributed file system.

> Who says distributed filesystems don't have generic interfaces?

Sorry, I should have said "REST's definitions of resource and
representation" rather than "generic interface".  I was talking
about that specific interface, not the notion in general.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3816
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 06:31:31
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities
Message:

I think it's a good idea, but it seems you're re-inventing something that
already exists in WebDAV protocols:

	http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc3253.html#rfc.section.1.6

Note that the format doesn't do all that your proposal does, but it is
extensible. It also avoids the issue of code collisions by marshalling XML
error elements instead.

--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3817
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 13:01:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities
Message:

Hmm... I do see the similarities.  However, I was hoping for something
stand-alone.  I do like the idea of using element-naming instead of the
"code" attribute.  The original example might look something like:

<responseMetadata level="APPLICATION">
    <missingElement name="identity"/>
</responseMetadata>

I do not see a need for extensability here, with the possible exception of
providing more values for "level".  For instance,

<responseMetadata level="WebDAV">
    <D:error xmlns:D="DAV:">
        <must-be-checked-in/>
    </D:error>
</responseMetadata>

or it could be simplified to:

<responseMetadata level="WebDAV">
        <must-be-checked-in/>
</responseMetadata>

After all, the "error" bit is redundant if receiving this in a 4xx (Client
Error) response.  On the other hand, it may be that WebDAV would fall under
the "APPLICATION" level...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...


From: "Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
>
> I think it's a good idea, but it seems you're re-inventing something that
> already exists in WebDAV protocols:
>
> http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc3253.html#rfc.section.1.6
>
> Note that the format doesn't do all that your proposal does, but it is
> extensible. It also avoids the issue of code collisions by marshalling XML
> error elements instead.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3818
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 13:11:23
Subject:403 vs. 409
Message:

Suppose an application detects a problem with the request entity.  Should a
403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be returned?  Only 409 talks about
informing the client of how the problem might be fixed.  However, 409 talks
about conflicts with the resource.  I would not consider an error in the
request entity to be a "conflict", as it was never even compared to the
existing resource (if one even exists).  On the other hand, 403 doesn't
contain any language about correcting the problem and trying again (but it
also doesn't say *not* to do so), though it does say that the response
should indicate the problem.

So, is 403 the prefered response or is it 409?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3819
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 14:21:58
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities
Message:

> From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
> Sent: Thursday, July 31, 2003 3:01 PM
> To: rest-discuss
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities
>
>
> ...
>
> or it could be simplified to:
>
> ...

Well, this is a RFC that is already implemented by many servers, so it's not
likely to change. RFC2518bis (WebDAV RFC revision) is supposed to adopt this
format as well.


--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3820
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 14:54:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities
Message:

Yeah, I realize that.  It was more of an example than a suggestion.  :)
However, have any other applications/specifications out there adopted this
same format?  I could certainly role something for my own use (and may still
do so).  However, I'd much rather use a common/general-purpose format
instead of borrow one that's not intended for use outside of the
specification in which it's defined.

Seairth

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
To: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>; "rest-discuss"
<rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, July 31, 2003 10:21 AM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities

> > or it could be simplified to:
> >
> > ...

not
> likely to change. RFC2518bis (WebDAV RFC revision) is supposed to adopt
this
> format as well.

Post ID:3821
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>

Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] HTTP 4xx response entities
Message:

Well,

I'd say that WebDAV and DeltaV are probably the two most visible extensions
to HTTP/1.1. And there's really no reason *not* to use it outside these
specs -- it's designed to work in any "pure" HTTP environment after all...

Julian

<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760

> same format?  I could certainly role something for my own use

> do so).  However, I'd much rather use a common/general-purpose format
> instead of borrow one that's not intended for use outside of the
> specification in which it's defined.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3822
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 15:57:21
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer (was Pure-REST Wiki experiment)
Message:

Roy,

If there is other source material on ReST than your dissertation, please 
let me know.
Here are the key quotes:
"""
The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any information 
that can be named can be a resource: a document or image, a temporal 
service (e.g. "today's weather in Los Angeles"), a collection of other 
resources, a non-virtual object (e.g. a person), and so on. In other words, 
any concept that might be the target of an author's hypertext reference 
must fit within the definition of a resource. A resource is a conceptual 
mapping to a set of entities, not the entity that corresponds to the 
mapping at any particular point in time.
"""

"""
REST components perform actions on a resource by using a representation to 
capture the current or intended state of that resource and transferring 
that representation between components. A representation is a sequence of 
bytes, plus representation metadata to describe those bytes. Other commonly 
used but less precise names for a representation include: document, file, 
and HTTP message entity, instance, or variant.
"""

The elephant in the room here is that we have no way to talk about HOW a 
representation captures the current state of a resource nor do we have a 
way of knowing what to do with "intended state."  How do we differentiate 
between e.g. disagreements about the accuracy of a representation and 
attempts to change the underlying resource?  And if we intend to change the 
underlying resource, how does a client know what change will result from 
the presentation of a particular representation?

The reality is that both client and server need a shared model for mapping 
between "representations" and "resources."  I am just saying we might as 
well make the model explicit rather than developing custom mappings for 
every single URI.

You advocate for ReST by saying:
"""
REST provides a hybrid of all three options by focusing on a shared 
understanding of data types with metadata, but limiting the scope of what 
is revealed to a standardized interface. REST components communicate by 
transferring a representation of a resource in a format matching one of an 
evolving set of standard data types, selected dynamically based on the 
capabilities or desires of the recipient and the nature of the resource.
"""

The problem is that absent a shared MODEL having a shared understanding of 
data types with metadata is useless.  I may understand GIF format and that 
a GIF is intended to represent the current state of a resource, but unless 
I know the relationship between the GIF and the underlying resource its 
pretty worthless.  If I GET a GIF of a ":-)"does that mean a resource is 
happy?  If I PUT a ":-(" back does that make the resource sad?  So we have 
a 1-bit database field that gets updated by these images?  Or perhaps the 
resource simply storing a random GIF and I can store any GIF there?  How 
should I know?

At this point, you may argue that all that we are talking about is the 
referent of the URI.  My point is that we need to do the work to get to the 
point where we understand whether we are talking about a 1-bit database 
field or about a random BLOB store.  Since ReST mandates that the 
relationship between a representation and a resource is entirely arbitrary, 
these relationships end up being negotiated on a URI by URI basis and 
visibility suffers to the point of near-blindness.

We can achieve a MUCH higher level of visibility if constrain resources 
simply to be model stores (think MVC).
Models are data combined with meta-data constraining how it may be changed. 
In the real-world, this metadata takes the form of content-types and 
XML-schema.  Obviously the effect of updating a model in a particular store 
is still application specific, but at least we can now understand 
communication back and forth as being ABOUT updating a model.  Taking this 
idea to its logical conclusion would allow a new sort of proxy that could 
collect a set of PUT and POSTs into a batch update to a resource when it 
actually connects.

Just to knock this point home, in your mail you say:
> The point of the definitions is that the interface does not define the 
exact meaning,
> leaving meaning to be defined by the nature of the links between
> the information.

My point is that it defines NO MEANING AT ALL!  All the work put into 
schemas and content-types are effectively useless without special purpose 
knowledge about each URI that ReST thinks should remain hidden!

> A server does the interpolation between the contents
> of a PUT and the model hidden behind the server -- saying that isn't
> defined by REST is just goofy.

I think it is goofy that ReST means that I can have absolutely no idea what 
the effect of PUT or POST actually is without an extended out of band 
conversation with the web server operator.

Flexibility comes in defining agents that themselves respond to changes in 
the model (either via internal notification, external notification, or 
perhaps GET from somewhere else).

Unless you know the relationship between the content returned from a GET 
and the underlying model, you have no way to know what it means.  Unless 
you know how the server will interpret a representation, you have no way to 
understand the effect of a PUT or POST and therefore no way to interact 
with the server programmatically.

> If you don't like the generic interface, then just implement a
> distributed file system.  That has all the features you are looking
> for in a concrete model.

I want a generic interface.  However without some constraints on the 
meaning of the interface elements, you don't have one.  Instead you have a 
lot of special purpose interfaces which happen to share the same method 
names.
However, if you constrain the meaning of methods in terms of the resource 
data-model/content-type/schema, you do get a generic interface.

Regarding the DFS, how would you implement that with ReST without a large 
amount of documentation about the meaning of each method w/r/t each file 
and directory? However, if I'm willing to expose the model, then all I need 
is a XML schema for a DFS and I'm good to go.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax




--On Wednesday, July 30, 2003 3:33 PM -0700 "Roy T. Fielding" 
<fielding@...> wrote:

>> MoST is either ReST with additional constraints to achieve much greater
>> levels of visibility or MoST supercedes ReST because ReST is useful
>> only
>> for web publishing and we want more.
>>
>> I don't have a huge stake in defining ReST one way or another.  My
>> personal
>> view is that ReST is sufficiently semantically incoherent so you can
>> go in
>> whatever direction you like.  Try reading Roy's dissertation and
>> figuring
>> out the exact meaning of resource and representation in his paper and
>> you'll see what I mean.
>
> Well, now that's a completely clueless statement.  The point of the
> definitions is that the interface does not define the exact meaning,
> leaving meaning to be defined by the nature of the links between
> the information.  A server does the interpolation between the contents
> of a PUT and the model hidden behind the server -- saying that isn't
> defined by REST is just goofy.  I have no problems building PUT,
> containers, or any of the other things that you claim are not defined
> by REST, since those are implementation details that are defined within
> HTTP by the origin server and not by the client.  I don't even need to
> use webdav, though it has its definitions as well.  The only problems
> I run into are buggy browsers that never managed to implement basic
> HTTP correctly, let alone the advanced features.
>
> If you don't like the generic interface, then just implement a
> distributed file system.  That has all the features you are looking
> for in a concrete model.
>
> ....Roy
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3823
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 20:23:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    Alex> I think it is goofy that ReST means that I can have
    Alex> absolutely no idea what the effect of PUT or POST actually
    Alex> is without an extended out of band conversation with the web
    Alex> server operator.

That's true for every routine and function you call in this world. The
solution to this (not widely used yet, too many people seem to love C)
is the notion of pre- and postcondition:

1. If the client fullfills its part of the obligation, i.e. meeting
   all the conditions stated in the precondition,

2. then the server fullfills its part of the obligation, i.e. meeting
   all the conditions stated in the postcondition.

Everything beyond that is of no concern to the client.


Explicit pre- and postconditions are missing from REST, but that it is
all you need. If the precondition states that you can PUT, you can. If
the postcondition states that the result of the PUT is that a GET
returns the putted resource, than that's all there is.

If you seek an understanding of how different resouces work together
and how to accomplish certain tasks (booking a meeting with different
participans for example), that has and will always be part of the
documentation. That's just part of the architecture. UI don't see any
metamodel solving that problem.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3824
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 20:26:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

>>>>> "Seairth" == Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> writes:

    Seairth> Suppose an application detects a problem with the request
    Seairth> entity.  Should a 403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be
    Seairth> returned?  

If *access* to the resource is not forbidden, it's not a 403.

I return a 409 for example when the user submits an invalid query
(invalid SQL/Xpath/whatever).

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3825
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 21:19:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

So does that mean that a mal-formed XML document is considered a conflict
with the resource?  Further, if the request was a POST where a successful
response would be the creation of a resource, what would the mal-formed XML
document be conflicting with?  The rules of the resource pointed to by the
POST?

And if 409 is what should be used for the mal-formed XML, what would 403 be
used for?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Berend de Boer" <berend@...>
>
> Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> writes:
>
>     Seairth> Suppose an application detects a problem with the request
>     Seairth> entity.  Should a 403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be
>     Seairth> returned?
>
> If *access* to the resource is not forbidden, it's not a 403.
>
> I return a 409 for example when the user submits an invalid query
> (invalid SQL/Xpath/whatever).





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3826
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-07-31 21:36:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

ReST says that the relationship between the returned representation and the 
underlying model is entirely arbitrary.
So what is truly goofy is that, with ReST, I don't even know what the 
result of a GET means without out of band documentation! 
Pre/Post-conditions are really irrelevant to solving this problem.

Here is another way to think about this from an OO/MVC perspective:

* ReST: the web server should hide the data model and implement the viewer 
and controller itself.
(Pre/post-conditions are irrelevant to ReST because they are already 
enforced by the server-based controller.)

* MoST the web server should expose the data model (aka class instance or 
data+content-type/schema) and the client should implement the viewer and 
controller.
(Pre/post-conditions are irrelevant to MoST because they are covered in the 
content-type/schema definition.)

As a programmer, I would much rather code against a model with clearly 
articulated interface (specified by a content-type/schema) than I would 
against arbitrary ReST UI components.  Effectively ReST means writing 
screen-scraping applications.  In advocating MoST, I am claiming that 
screen-scraping is silly.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3827
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-01 01:55:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: MoST - Model State Transfer
Message:

REST says that resources are mappings from time to sets
of representations.  It doesn't even imply that what would cause
the mapping at time t+n to differ from the mapping at time t
has anything necessarily to do with protocol methods.

Said another way, it doesn't take a PUT or a POST to
make the weather change.  And a PUT and a POST won't
change the weather either.

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3829
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-01 19:30:58
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

On Thu, Jul 31, 2003 at 09:11:23AM -0400, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> Suppose an application detects a problem with the request entity.  Should a
> 403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be returned?

I'd use 400.  Neither 403 nor 409 seem relevant.

Mark.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3830
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-01 20:07:26
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

That's what I thought, except when I was working on Jot (my RESTful blog
system) someone (forgot who) said that 400 indicated a problem with HTTP
layer itself (e.g. "host" header missing in HTTP/1.1) and should not be used
for application-level errors.  Currently, I am using 403, saying that an
invalid request entity (say, a non-well-formded XML document) would be
"forbidden". But the problem here is that the resource is what defines
whether the request entity is valid or not (even the well-formedness of an
XML document), so in *some* sense, a bad request entity "conflicts" with the
resource.

So, supposing that 409 was the correct response to use, then what is 403
for?  About the only example I could come up with was one mirroring a
filesystem operation.  Suppose you have a resource that is marked
"read-only".  An attempt to PUT to that resource may be valid if it were not
read-only, but otherwise would return a 403.  This is not a conflict,
necessarily (though I could see it rephrased that way), and therefore not
appropriate for a 409 response.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>
> On Thu, Jul 31, 2003 at 09:11:23AM -0400, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> > Suppose an application detects a problem with the request entity.
Should a
> > 403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be returned?
>
> I'd use 400.  Neither 403 nor 409 seem relevant.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3831
Sender:David John Powell <djpowell@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-01 08:29:33
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

>Suppose an application detects a problem with the request entity.  Should
a
>403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be returned?  Only 409 talks about
>informing the client of how the problem might be fixed.  However, 409
talks
>about conflicts with the resource.  I would not consider an error in the
>request entity to be a "conflict", as it was never even compared to the
>existing resource (if one even exists).  On the other hand, 403 doesn't
>contain any language about correcting the problem and trying again (but
it
>also doesn't say *not* to do so), though it does say that the response
>should indicate the problem.
>
>So, is 403 the prefered response or is it 409?
>


Well all 4xx codes indicate a problem with the request.
Have you got a specific example? Do you mean something like missing
required information from a POST request?

I tend to use 400 for that sort of error, but I just checked, and 400
is explicitly for syntactic errors, rather than semantic ones. So I
guess that that isn't really right either. Is 400 intended only for
syntactic errors at the HTTP level such as illegal URIs, or would it
be allowed for syntactic errors at a higher level, such as if you
tried to PUT or POST a corrupt document, or refered to a badly formatted
identifier?

403 doesn't sound right to me, because I've always seen it as a kind
of "get lost" response for requests that have broke some sort of
out-of-band policy, such as for IP restricted sites, but I notice that
in the HTTP1.0 RFC, the description of 403 suggests that it can 
be used when other status codes are inappropriate, but that is for
1.0.

WebDAV defines a "422 Unprocessable entity" status for semantic
problems with the XML request, and uses 400 if the XML request is not
properly formed. I don't see why WebDAV would be a special case here,
so that sounds wrong too.

I wouldn't worry about 403 not specifying that the body should contain
instructions on how to remedy the problem though, because the text
describing
4xx codes in general says that the server SHOULD include a body describing
the
error for all of these codes.

-- 
Dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3832
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-02 04:38:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Ah, Seairth was asking *that* question.  I didn't realize.  We should
add this to the FAQ, as we've had this twice before I think.

Sometimes it's 400, sometimes it's 200.  It depends on the method too.
For PUT, I'd use 400, because to return 200 would be telling
intermediaries that what was sent, was stored.  For POST, more than
likely I'd use 200, because I may want to resolve the bad data problem
by, for example, driving the application to ask for the data again,
and perhaps I want to count the retries or some such.  If I used 400,
then the application makes no progress, so I can't do that.  I think.
Funny how such a seemingly simple question opens up the whole "state"
can-o-worms.

Mark.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3833
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-02 08:36:07
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

> From: David John Powell [mailto:djpowell@...]
> Sent: Friday, August 01, 2003 10:30 AM
> To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
>
>
> ...
>
> Well all 4xx codes indicate a problem with the request.
> Have you got a specific example? Do you mean something like missing
> required information from a POST request?
>
> I tend to use 400 for that sort of error, but I just checked, and 400
> is explicitly for syntactic errors, rather than semantic ones. So I
> guess that that isn't really right either. Is 400 intended only for
> syntactic errors at the HTTP level such as illegal URIs, or would it
> be allowed for syntactic errors at a higher level, such as if you
> tried to PUT or POST a corrupt document, or refered to a badly formatted
> identifier?

RFC2616 says:

"The request could not be understood by the server due to malformed syntax.
The client SHOULD NOT repeat the request without modifications."

So it seems that's perfectly OK to indicate syntax problems in the request
body using 400.

> 403 doesn't sound right to me, because I've always seen it as a kind
> of "get lost" response for requests that have broke some sort of
> out-of-band policy, such as for IP restricted sites, but I notice that
> in the HTTP1.0 RFC, the description of 403 suggests that it can
> be used when other status codes are inappropriate, but that is for
> 1.0.

"The server understood the request, but is refusing to fulfill it.
Authorization will not help and the request SHOULD NOT be repeated. If the
request method was not HEAD and the server wishes to make public why the
request has not been fulfilled, it SHOULD describe the reason for the
refusal in the entity. If the server does not wish to make this information
available to the client, the status code 404 (Not Found) can be used
instead."

> WebDAV defines a "422 Unprocessable entity" status for semantic
> problems with the XML request, and uses 400 if the XML request is not
> properly formed. I don't see why WebDAV would be a special case here,
> so that sounds wrong too.

Could you please explain why you think this is wrong?

> ...

Julian

--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3834
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-02 17:49:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Mark,

What would you be telling intermediaries if you used 200 to reply
to a POST of some malformed content:

    a. that something was successfully appended or annotated?
    b. that some data processing was successfully performed?

Why wouldn't 400 in this case be the ideal way to drive the
application in asking for the data again after correcting syntax?

How does 400 prevent the application from making progress?

Also, in general, where did I get the impression that an application
unsure about specific status codes can/should punt and use the x00
in the appropriate category?  Doesn't seem to say that in 2616 for
the 400 family.

Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, August 02, 2003 12:38 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409


> Ah, Seairth was asking *that* question.  I didn't realize.  We should
> add this to the FAQ, as we've had this twice before I think.
>
> Sometimes it's 400, sometimes it's 200.  It depends on the method too.
> For PUT, I'd use 400, because to return 200 would be telling
> intermediaries that what was sent, was stored.  For POST, more than
> likely I'd use 200, because I may want to resolve the bad data problem
> by, for example, driving the application to ask for the data again,
> and perhaps I want to count the retries or some such.  If I used 400,
> then the application makes no progress, so I can't do that.  I think.
> Funny how such a seemingly simple question opens up the whole "state"
> can-o-worms.
>
> Mark.
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3835
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-03 01:08:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Hey Walden,

On Sat, Aug 02, 2003 at 01:49:55PM -0400, Walden Mathews wrote:
> Mark,
> 
> What would you be telling intermediaries if you used 200 to reply
> to a POST of some malformed content:
> 
>     a. that something was successfully appended or annotated?
>     b. that some data processing was successfully performed?

b, I'd say, keeping in mind that "successful data processing" can
include the determination of some "invalid" information within that
data, such as non-well-formed XML, or an invalid credit card number.
Where you draw this line is up to the needs of your application,
which is why I say "sometimes 400, sometimes 200" (but mostly 200,
in my experience).

> Why wouldn't 400 in this case be the ideal way to drive the
> application in asking for the data again after correcting syntax?
>
> How does 400 prevent the application from making progress?

Because it's an error.  An error response describes the specifics of the
error, leaving the client no way to proceed through the application,
except to do a logical "Back"; as far as the state of the application is
concerned (which the client maintains), that interaction never happened.

> Also, in general, where did I get the impression that an application
> unsure about specific status codes can/should punt and use the x00
> in the appropriate category?  Doesn't seem to say that in 2616 for
> the 400 family.

Sec 6.1.1;

"HTTP status codes are extensible. HTTP applications are not required
 to understand the meaning of all registered status codes, though such
 understanding is obviously desirable. However, applications MUST
 understand the class of any status code, as indicated by the first
 digit, and treat any unrecognized response as being equivalent to the
 x00 status code of that class, with the exception that an
 unrecognized response MUST NOT be cached."

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3836
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-03 02:28:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

So far, all I am seeing is that just about everyone has a different take on
whether to use 400, 403, or 409 (and maybe even 200 for POSTs).  I realize
that there are cut-and-dried cases that no one would argue with, but for
these other cases where everyone seems to have a different opinion, I am
wondering if maybe the best approach is to just pick the response(s) that
seem appropriate and document the decision.  In the end, I may choose to use
403 where some (though not all) others think 409 would be more appropriate.
However, as long as the documentation clearly indicates which responses to
expect for which occasions, can we all accept the difference of opinion and
move on?  I have continued to implement my code using 403 and have not yet
seen any compelling reasons to change it.  As long as people working with my
documented interface know that 403 is the expected response (among others),
does it really matter?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3837
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-03 15:00:11
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Mark,

> > What would you be telling intermediaries if you used 200 to reply
> > to a POST of some malformed content:
> >
> >     a. that something was successfully appended or annotated?
> >     b. that some data processing was successfully performed?
>
> b, I'd say, keeping in mind that "successful data processing" can
> include the determination of some "invalid" information within that
> data, such as non-well-formed XML, or an invalid credit card number.
> Where you draw this line is up to the needs of your application,
> which is why I say "sometimes 400, sometimes 200" (but mostly 200,
> in my experience).

Well, in my *inexperience* that looks like a loss of visibility.  I
understand
syntax error to be a condition that aborts meaningful processing, and this
is application level protocol, so the status code should tell us about how
effectively state was transferred, not how effectively bits were
transported.

>
> > Why wouldn't 400 in this case be the ideal way to drive the
> > application in asking for the data again after correcting syntax?
> >
> > How does 400 prevent the application from making progress?
>
> Because it's an error.  An error response describes the specifics of the
> error, leaving the client no way to proceed through the application,
> except to do a logical "Back"; as far as the state of the application is
> concerned (which the client maintains), that interaction never happened.

"Back" seems more like a browser idiom.  I would say that the absence
of a 2xx is the absence of a forward transition, which leaves application
state
right where it was.  In this case, the "way to proceed" is to correct syntax
and try again.  What am I missing?

Another thought: the details of a malformed request and an aborted
state transition are analogous to (or perhaps just examples of)
conversational state.  Not part of the "application state" model.

>
> > Also, in general, where did I get the impression that an application
> > unsure about specific status codes can/should punt and use the x00
> > in the appropriate category?  Doesn't seem to say that in 2616 for
> > the 400 family.
>
> Sec 6.1.1;
>
> "HTTP status codes are extensible. HTTP applications are not required
>  to understand the meaning of all registered status codes, though such
>  understanding is obviously desirable. However, applications MUST
>  understand the class of any status code, as indicated by the first
>  digit, and treat any unrecognized response as being equivalent to the
>  x00 status code of that class, with the exception that an
>  unrecognized response MUST NOT be cached."

Ah, thanks.  So it would seem the part of 2616 that says 400 is about
syntax error specifically kind of violates that class/subclass thing, since
other 4xx responses are not about syntax.  Season to taste?

-Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3838
Sender:David Powell <djpowell@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-04 07:07:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Saturday, August 2, 2003, 9:36:07 AM, you wrote:

>> WebDAV defines a "422 Unprocessable entity" status for semantic
>> problems with the XML request, and uses 400 if the XML request is not
>> properly formed. I don't see why WebDAV would be a special case here,
>> so that sounds wrong too.

> Could you please explain why you think this is wrong?

I just don't think that it is a WebDAV specific problem, so I would
expect WebDAV to use whatever status would be appropriate for any
other HTTP application.

I tend to favour 400, but it looks as if 422 was invented for WebDAV
because it was decided that 400 couldn't be used to report errors that
weren't strictly syntactic?


-- 
Dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3839
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-04 07:32:15
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

> From: David Powell [mailto:djpowell@...]
> Sent: Monday, August 04, 2003 9:08 AM
> To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
>
>
> Saturday, August 2, 2003, 9:36:07 AM, you wrote:
>
> >> WebDAV defines a "422 Unprocessable entity" status for semantic
> >> problems with the XML request, and uses 400 if the XML request is not
> >> properly formed. I don't see why WebDAV would be a special case here,
> >> so that sounds wrong too.
>
> > Could you please explain why you think this is wrong?
>
> I just don't think that it is a WebDAV specific problem, so I would
> expect WebDAV to use whatever status would be appropriate for any
> other HTTP application.

So you think this is wrong because WebDAV added a new status code? I can't
agree -- the whole point of WebDAV is to *extend* HTTP/1.1 (with new
methods, request headers...), and therefore adding a new specific 4xx status
code because none of the existing ones fitted well seems to be absolutely
right thing to do.

> I tend to favour 400, but it looks as if 422 was invented for WebDAV
> because it was decided that 400 couldn't be used to report errors that
> weren't strictly syntactic?

Julian

--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3840
Sender:David Powell <djpowell@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-04 19:43:09
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

>> Saturday, August 2, 2003, 9:36:07 AM, you wrote:
>>
>> >> WebDAV defines a "422 Unprocessable entity" status for semantic
>> >> problems with the XML request, and uses 400 if the XML request is not
>> >> properly formed. I don't see why WebDAV would be a special case here,
>> >> so that sounds wrong too.
>>
>> > Could you please explain why you think this is wrong?
>>
>> I just don't think that it is a WebDAV specific problem, so I would
>> expect WebDAV to use whatever status would be appropriate for any
>> other HTTP application.

JR> So you think this is wrong because WebDAV added a new status code? I can't
JR> agree -- the whole point of WebDAV is to *extend* HTTP/1.1 (with new
JR> methods, request headers...), and therefore adding a new specific 4xx status
JR> code because none of the existing ones fitted well seems to be absolutely
JR> right thing to do.

I wasn't trying to pick on WebDAV. I have no problem with WebDAV
inventing new codes. I was just trying to figure out what was the best
status to return for a semantic error in HTTP, and WebDAV was a good
case study because it invents a new code for this purpose. If WebDAV
had to invent a new code, then does that mean that this is a situation
that HTTP/1.1 doesn't cater for?

What I am really trying to figure out is whether 400 is allowed for
requests that are syntactically correct at the HTTP level, but have a
semantic error.  I always thought that it was OK, because it looks
like the most appropriate code.  I'm assuming that WebDAV invented
422, because it considered it not to be OK - but I don't really know
the history.



-- 
Best regards,
 David                            mailto:djpowell@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3841
Sender:"Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-04 20:42:40
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

> From: David Powell [mailto:djpowell@...]
> Sent: Monday, August 04, 2003 9:43 PM
> To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
>
>
> ...
>
> I wasn't trying to pick on WebDAV. I have no problem with WebDAV
> inventing new codes. I was just trying to figure out what was the best
> status to return for a semantic error in HTTP, and WebDAV was a good
> case study because it invents a new code for this purpose. If WebDAV
> had to invent a new code, then does that mean that this is a situation
> that HTTP/1.1 doesn't cater for?
>
> What I am really trying to figure out is whether 400 is allowed for
> requests that are syntactically correct at the HTTP level, but have a
> semantic error.  I always thought that it was OK, because it looks
> like the most appropriate code.  I'm assuming that WebDAV invented
> 422, because it considered it not to be OK - but I don't really know
> the history.

It seems that this is just a shortcoming in HTTP. 4xx is for client errors.
We are definitvely talking about a client error. In the absence of a more
specific code (401...), one would use 400. But 400 is defined as:

"The request could not be understood by the server due to malformed syntax.
The client SHOULD NOT repeat the request without modifications." (RFC2616:
status 400)

WebDAV defines 422 for:

"The 422 (Unprocessable Entity) status code means the server understands the
content type of the request entity (hence a 415(Unsupported Media Type)
status code is inappropriate), and the syntax of the request entity is
correct (thus a 400 (Bad Request) status code is inappropriate) but was
unable to process the contained instructions. For example, this error
condition may occur if an XML request body contains well-formed (i.e.,
syntactically correct), but semantically erroneous XML instructions."
(RFC2518)

So the point of view seems to be that the request entitity indeed had
wellformed syntax, but wasn't semantically valid. Now we all know that the
boundaries between syntax and semantics aren't THAT well-defined. So even
though the request body may be well-formed XML, an HTTP server could still
claim a syntax error.

It seems that the WebDAV WG didn't want to choose that direction and just
defined a new, more specific status code. This is perfectly ok, any client
that doesn't know 422 will have to treat it as 400, so no harm is done. As
WebDAV is the product of an IETF working group (and is currently progressing
to the next standards level), 422 is definitively here to stay, so I'd
recommend just to adopt it.

(it would be interesting to reseacg up how the WG came up with this design)

Julian





--
<green/>bytes GmbH -- http://www.greenbytes.de -- tel:+492512807760





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3842
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-04 16:52:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Why isn't the correct response 415 (Unsupported Media Type)?

Your application requires that the POST conform to a particular schema and 
that schema has been violated.  2616 does not say that the value of the 
content-type header is bad, but that the actual media-type is bad.  XML DTD 
and schema have already moved a lot of media-type information outside of 
the content-type header.  Isn't 415 the status code to use if the client is 
violating schema requirements?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


--On Friday, August 01, 2003 4:07 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:

> That's what I thought, except when I was working on Jot (my RESTful blog
> system) someone (forgot who) said that 400 indicated a problem with HTTP
> layer itself (e.g. "host" header missing in HTTP/1.1) and should not be
> used for application-level errors.  Currently, I am using 403, saying
> that an invalid request entity (say, a non-well-formded XML document)
> would be "forbidden". But the problem here is that the resource is what
> defines whether the request entity is valid or not (even the
> well-formedness of an XML document), so in *some* sense, a bad request
> entity "conflicts" with the resource.
>
> So, supposing that 409 was the correct response to use, then what is 403
> for?  About the only example I could come up with was one mirroring a
> filesystem operation.  Suppose you have a resource that is marked
> "read-only".  An attempt to PUT to that resource may be valid if it were
> not read-only, but otherwise would return a 403.  This is not a conflict,
> necessarily (though I could see it rephrased that way), and therefore not
> appropriate for a 409 response.
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
> From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>>
>> On Thu, Jul 31, 2003 at 09:11:23AM -0400, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
>> > Suppose an application detects a problem with the request entity.
> Should a
>> > 403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be returned?
>>
>> I'd use 400.  Neither 403 nor 409 seem relevant.
>
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3843
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-04 18:12:57
Subject:Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

Seairth, I just took a look at your blog and your comments on Jot/ReSTful 
blog architecture and at RNA <http://www.seairth.com/blog/industry/49> and 
<http://www.seairth.com/blog/jot/docs/6> <http://www.seairth.com/web/rna/>

These specs strike me as excessively complex.  By forcing applications 
interface specifications to include both a set of verbs and the 
content-types/schemas allowed w/r/t those verbs we lose all the visibility 
and genericity that ReST is intended to promise.

If we had a standard mapping between HTTP methods and underlying 
content-types, everything would get MUCH simpler.  The most useful mapping 
would be from HTTP to XML and would probably look something like this:

GET /myRSSblog returns an XML document.
POST /myRSSblog#channelId adds a new child to the XML node with that id.
GET /myRSSblog#itemId returns an XML node with that id
PUT /myRSSblog#itemId replaces the XML node with that id
DELETE /myRSSblog#itemId deletes the XML node with that id
(Style using <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="yourstyle.xsl"?> for 
your viewing pleasure.)

Now you don't need any special purpose plumbing for indexing, mapping to 
directory structure, or all sorts of other annoying administrivia.  If you 
are maintaing a blog and you want to switch from RSS to nEcho just use an 
xslt transform and update your stylesheet.  No special purpose plumbing 
required....

Similarly, you can simplify the RNA spec to an addressbook/subscribers 
schema and an INBOX schema.  Sending messages obviously is just a POST to 
an inbox, etc.

For total coverage, a wiki is also just an XML document with client-side 
javascript placed in the stylesheet that does the wikitext rendering.  You 
can even standardize the rendering by using a script-src rather than 
bundling your own (it is also, therefore, more likely to be cached).  The 
existing wiki systems encourage proliferation of wikitext formats because 
the rendering is done on the servers.

Thoughts?  Any reason why things need to be more complex than this?

-Alex-

PS The point of my advocating Model State Transfer over Representational 
State Transfer is precisely that I think ReST forces servers to implement 
all sorts of special purpose plumbing to hide the data model rather than 
just assuming that other agents (perhaps residing on the server) will do 
data model conversions if needed. I'd like to get to get rid of 
content-negotiation and get to the point where the content-type/xml-schema 
of a resource is all you need to know in order to interact with it.

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax




--On Friday, August 01, 2003 4:07 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:

> That's what I thought, except when I was working on Jot (my RESTful blog
> system) someone (forgot who) said that 400 indicated a problem with HTTP
> layer itself (e.g. "host" header missing in HTTP/1.1) and should not be
> used for application-level errors.  Currently, I am using 403, saying
> that an invalid request entity (say, a non-well-formded XML document)
> would be "forbidden". But the problem here is that the resource is what
> defines whether the request entity is valid or not (even the
> well-formedness of an XML document), so in *some* sense, a bad request
> entity "conflicts" with the resource.
>
> So, supposing that 409 was the correct response to use, then what is 403
> for?  About the only example I could come up with was one mirroring a
> filesystem operation.  Suppose you have a resource that is marked
> "read-only".  An attempt to PUT to that resource may be valid if it were
> not read-only, but otherwise would return a 403.  This is not a conflict,
> necessarily (though I could see it rephrased that way), and therefore not
> appropriate for a 409 response.
>
> ---

> seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3844
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-05 00:52:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] 403 vs. 409
Message:

Okay... now we are up to:

400
or 403
or 409
or 415
(or sometimes 200)


I am unsure about using 415, though.  If someone POSTs/PUTs an "text/xml"
request entity (that happens to not  be well-formed) and gets back a 415,
how likely are they to know that it's the entity itself that's not valid,
not necessarily the content-type they said it was?  I know you could convey
this information in the response entity, but let's face it, the only
successful use of this is with HTML, which isn't at all program-friendly.
As a result, you have one of the following choices:

1) Use the code that's closest and hope the client understands it.
2) Use 400 generally and come up with an xml-based (since the request was
supposedly xml) response entity that conveys all possible information.  Then
make sure all clients know how to use this xml-based specification.
3) Create a new 4xx response code that means *exactly* what you want it to
mean.  Then make sure all clients now how to handle that response code (or
fall back to 400 equivalence and rely on option #1).

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...
