-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3864
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-07 17:57:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST
Message:

--On Wednesday, August 06, 2003 9:10 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@...> wrote:
> As I understand it, MoST is a data driven standardised interface. Stuck
> to xml. But I've allway understood ReST in this way.

ReST is NOT a *standardized* interface (see my response to Seairth).

> as an example, a messaging service can be modeled as

Once you have to document this model, you no longer have a standardized 
interface.  You now have to provide some mechanism for the client to 
discover and understand how to interact with this service (you lose 
visibility and interoperability).

> POST /your/inbox/
> message           : send a message ...
[...]
> formats can be just mime for messages and a list of plain text
> "subject : uri " for inbox,

How should a client know that this is the appropriate way to send a 
message?  It certainly violates the syntax your inbox type to append a MIME 
message to its end so we can't discover it that way.  Given the formats you 
describe, the obvious way to send a message is to PUT a message at some 
arbitrary newURI and then POST only "subject: newURI" to /your/inbox, but, 
according to your documentation that would be INCORRECT...  Sigh.

> This is a simple service, but it helps to understand.
> How do you model this in MoST ??

You don't, or at least not specifically!  MoST says that server operators 
should not be defining the meaning of resource interfaces; that these 
resource interfaces should be constrained entirely by their 
content-type/schema/format.  Note above how I gave the *obvious* way to 
send a message from your formats alone.  In practice, the documentation of 
your simple ReST messaging service would be verbose.  Even your abstract 
had 9 lines (not including the format description).  Aside from the format 
description, MoST requires NO DOCUMENTATION AT ALL.
Just GET the inbox, its format tells you everything you need to know to 
interact with it.  If you later switch to an XML inbox, again, you don't 
need any new documentation....

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3865
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-07 17:58:40
Subject:Re: Is the web-calculus Most? (Was: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST)
Message:

--On Wednesday, August 06, 2003 12:05 PM -0400 Tyler Close 
<tyler@...> wrote:
> Based on other emails in the thread, I suspect Alex would agree
> that MoST is a further constraining of REST. Alex's arguments
> about MoST being different from REST seem to be comparing MoST
> constraints to the absence of constraints in REST, not to
> expressed constraints in REST.

Yes.  That is correct.

> I think the main impetus for MoST is the desire to have a more
> constrained model for representations than just "a representation
> of a resource at time t". The web-calculus uses a more narrowly
> defined model and defines its generic interface in terms of this
> model. I suspect the web-calculus satisfies the desires expressed
> in this thread about MoST.

I took a look at the web calculus and I think it addresses an orthogonal 
problem.

MoST views HTTP as a blackboard communication interface for agents both on 
the server and across the Internet (See my response to Seairth) and just 
seeks to standardize the blackboard interface (not the interface to the 
agents themselves!).

If I am understanding the documentation I saw, the "web calculus" attempts 
to model how all of these agents across the Internet react to changes in 
what is on the blackboard.  That's a *very ambitious* enterprise and 
generalizes way beyond HTTP.  I am not in a position to judge the efficacy 
of your model, but, if it works, calling it simply a "web calculus" strikes 
me as *extremely* modest.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3866
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-07 17:57:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

--On Tuesday, August 05, 2003 10:36 PM -0700 Mike Dierken 
<mdierken@...> wrote:
> The URI addressability of node-ids is what you need to standardize - the
> mapping between local data (an element in an XML document) and remote
> resources (a URI). And that turns into XLink. Where among the
> nodes/sub-nodes/etc is the URI for that node?

XLink is a user agent standard not an HTTP standard.  As you already noted, 
'#' is not legal in HTTP URIs and it is required in XLink URIs.  Also XLink 
may be much more than is needed simply for an HTTP binding.  I don't see 
any reason why HTTP exposed XML documents should not give every HTTP 
addressable node a node-id and if they do so, why the interface I described 
is not sufficient, perhaps with ;node-id@attribute to address attributes. 
Perhaps someone more intimate with issues surrounding XML standards could 
take a shot at formalizing this more precisely (esp. w/r/t namespace 
semantics)....

> But you are right, define the set of resources and stick to
> get/put/post/delete. I don't know how you'll avoid documentation of some
> kind.

Yes thanks.  I'm not saying we can avoid documentation per se.  I just want 
to avoid per-URI documentation.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3867
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-07 19:23:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

Alex Jacobson wrote:
> Seairth and Bill,
> 
> The genius of ReST is its recognition of the value of a standardized 
> resource interface in a heterogeneous large scale networked environments 
> and its attempt to articulate such an interface.  Its tragic flaw is 
> that it did not standardize enough of the *semantics* of this interface 
> to achieve the value it promised.  To be perfectly clear about the problem:
> 
> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server maps the state 
> of a resource into a response to a GET request, a client can have 
> ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA what the content of that response means; it is simply 
> has bits that can mean anything at all.

Yes. but the majority of clients don't need to know what the content 
means (for some definition of means). Adding this to a transfer 
protocol would be an overconstraint. It's only now, that the web has 
grown without formal semantics, that we are in the position to 
wonder about whether we should have a tronger semantics. In some 
cases, such as web services I would say yes, a stronger semantic 
underpinning is useful. Consider that we've hade distributed 
computing models with decent semantics for longer that either the 
web  or REST and they have not been been adopted, not even when they 
are really quite good (such as FIPA).

So, I see no tragic flaw, just an opportunity :)


> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server uses PUT/POST-ed 
> content to change the state of a resource, a client can have ABSOLUTELY 
> NO IDEA what the effect of a PUT or POST actually will be.

Sure. But what exactly is the problem? Maybe premature formalization 
is the root of all evil.


> Because Roy's resources are so abstract, access to them has to be 
> mediated by agents of arbitrary power and complexity.  Allowing clients 
> to interact with agents of this power and complexity through HTTP then 
> requires that service operators be permitted to overload HTTP methods to 
> have essentially arbitrary meanings.

Well yes, but to avoid this each method needs a formal semantics and 
each protocol might well need a model theory. Consider KQML. That 
was far more formal that HTTP, yet it wasn't formal enough to stop 
interoperation problems and inter-agent confusion, and that's 
without any commercial incentive to differentiate.


> But resources don't really need to be so abstract and the meanings of 
> HTTP methods don't need to be so loose.  Programs don't actually 
> manipulate "concepts" or "non-virtual objects;" they just manipulate 
> bits.  

I think the kind of programs that result from what you are proposing 
will manipulate symbols first and foremost. Bits would be an 
implementation detail.


> It would be more realistic to say that an HTTP resource is simply 
> a set of bits whose syntactic structure is enforced by an HTTP server 
> and whose meaning is determined entirely by agents which interact with 
> this server.  To say otherwise is to say that there is a meaningful 
> difference in effect between having an agent poll a resource and act 
> when it changes and having a server notify an agent to act whenever a 
> resource is changed or to say that there is a meaningful difference 
> between such an agent residing on the HTTP server itself and such an 
> agent residing on another machine across the Internet and interacting 
> via HTTP.

After half a decade, I've conluded that the best option regarding 
Web resources is to say as little as possible about them.


> PS Bill, I have heard of speech acts, but I don't know how they apply here.

Each HTTP method can be understood as a speech act or performative 
used by a client to get a server to do something on their behalf. 
The server may refuse, comply, be silent, or do something completely 
nonsensical. So even after you model everything down the last 
degree, you still need two agents to intend to communicate 
effectively (ie something like Grice's maxims) or the ability to 
adapt to deceitful behaviour (ie utility models).

There isn't a direct correspondance, no more that CRUD is a direct 
correspondance to the REST uniform interface, but I've always 
thought of HTTP methods as a poor man speech acts.

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3868
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-07 19:35:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST
Message:

> Once you have to document this model, you no longer have a standardized 
> interface.  You now have to provide some mechanism for the client to 
> discover and understand how to interact with this service (you lose 
> visibility and interoperability)

but whatever is your system, you'll always have to document it, i.e. to
describe formats, etc. You can't define a data format, and thus a set of
behaviours, that will fit any applications needs.... 

> > POST /your/inbox/
> > message           : send a message ...
> [...]
> > formats can be just mime for messages and a list of plain text
> > "subject : uri " for inbox,
> 
> How should a client know that this is the appropriate way to send a 
> message?  It certainly violates the syntax your inbox type to append a MIME 
> message to its end so we can't discover it that way.  Given the formats you 
> describe, the obvious way to send a message is to PUT a message at some 
> arbitrary newURI and then POST only "subject: newURI" to /your/inbox, but, 
> according to your documentation that would be INCORRECT...  Sigh.

As long as you know that /inbox/ is a container containing mime
messages, posting a mime message to /inbox/ add the message to the
container... you don't have to know that (for instance) the server
actually append the message to an mbox file, if you can GET you message
(even in text/html) to the url of the Location header and if the GET
/inbox/ return a list with the "subjet : uri" appended. 

> > This is a simple service, but it helps to understand.
> > How do you model this in MoST ??
> 
> You don't, or at least not specifically!  MoST says that server operators 
> should not be defining the meaning of resource interfaces; that these 
> resource interfaces should be constrained entirely by their 
> content-type/schema/format.  Note above how I gave the *obvious* way to 
> send a message from your formats alone.  In practice, the documentation of 
> your simple ReST messaging service would be verbose.  Even your abstract 
> had 9 lines (not including the format description).  Aside from the format 
> description, MoST requires NO DOCUMENTATION AT ALL.
> Just GET the inbox, its format tells you everything you need to know to 
> interact with it.  If you later switch to an XML inbox, again, you don't 
> need any new documentation....
> 

so describe your format. In this descriptin, i wanted to be unambiguous,
but the knowledge that the /inbox/ is a container is suffisant, has I
know that i can POST to add a content and GET to obtain the listing (and
delete to reset the container)





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3869
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-07 23:11:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

> The genius of ReST is its recognition of the value of a standardized
> resource interface in a heterogeneous large scale networked 
> environments
> and its attempt to articulate such an interface.  Its tragic flaw is 
> that
> it did not standardize enough of the *semantics* of this interface to
> achieve the value it promised.  To be perfectly clear about the 
> problem:
>
> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server maps the state 
> of a
> resource into a response to a GET request, a client can have 
> ABSOLUTELY NO
> IDEA what the content of that response means; it is simply has bits 
> that
> can mean anything at all.

What does "mean" mean in this context?

> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server uses 
> PUT/POST-ed
> content to change the state of a resource, a client can have 
> ABSOLUTELY NO
> IDEA what the effect of a PUT or POST actually will be.

That just says that REST doesn't mandate one single model.  Nothing
prevents the server from establishing a model and telling the client
what it is.  That is how hypertext works: the engine of application
state change.

> Roy thinks these explicit models should be entirely arbitrary and 
> specified
> at the whim of the server operator on a per-URI basis.  I think these
> models should be standardized in some manner and be URI independent.

They aren't entirely arbitrary; they are merely chosen by the server.
In some cases they will be selected from a standard (such as webdav).
In other cases they will be defined by an interface language (like 
WSDL).

> Because Roy's resources are so abstract, access to them has to be 
> mediated
> by agents of arbitrary power and complexity.

Ah, so httpd modules must be gods.

> Allowing clients to interact
> with agents of this power and complexity through HTTP then requires 
> that
> service operators be permitted to overload HTTP methods to have 
> essentially
> arbitrary meanings.

That doesn't follow at all.  Service operators control the 
implementation
of HTTP methods.  Methods get overloaded because service operators do 
want
additional semantics, but normal people don't know how to extend them 
and
implementers can't read protocol specs.  It is an artifact of the social
process surrounding standardized protocols.  You can't fix it by
forbidding the extension of methods.

> But resources don't really need to be so abstract and the meanings of 
> HTTP
> methods don't need to be so loose.  Programs don't actually manipulate
> "concepts" or "non-virtual objects;" they just manipulate bits.

Right.  It's people that manipulate concepts and non-virtual objects.

>   It would
> be more realistic to say that an HTTP resource is simply a set of bits
> whose syntactic structure is enforced by an HTTP server and whose 
> meaning
> is determined entirely by agents which interact with this server.

No it wouldn't, since such a definition ignores the ability of people
to anticipate changes that have not yet occurred.  Time is essential
to the meaning of a hypertext link, and thus the definition of resource.
HTTP servers store representations, not resources.

>   To say
> otherwise is to say that there is a meaningful difference in effect 
> between
> having an agent poll a resource and act when it changes and having a 
> server
> notify an agent to act whenever a resource is changed or to say that 
> there
> is a meaningful difference between such an agent residing on the HTTP
> server itself and such an agent residing on another machine across the
> Internet and interacting via HTTP.

Or simply that resource isn't what you think it means.

> Viewed this way, it makes no sense to talk about some single *special*
> hidden representation to which a single special HTTP server agent 
> mediates
> access.  Instead we should recognize that agents on the server and 
> across
> the Internet can use any data structures they want for their 
> activities but
> that their doing so is really beside the point.  The function of an 
> HTTP
> server as such is simply to provide a shared blackboard for 
> communication
> between these agents.  What these agents really need is a shared 
> *explicit
> model* for determining what is on this blackboard and for how it may be
> changed.

The blackboard model is another architectural style with a lot of
interesting work associated with it.  Tuple-spaces use that.  The
problem with blackboards isn't just a lack of a data model;
they also have centralized identification and lack metadata.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3870
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 00:27:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

>>>>> "Roy" == Roy T Fielding <fielding@...> writes:

    Roy> HTTP servers store representations, not resources.

Eh, you probably mean *return* resources?

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3871
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 00:28:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

>>>>> "Roy" == Roy T Fielding <fielding@...> writes:

    Roy> HTTP servers store representations, not resources.

Oops, I made the same mistake, I meant to say "return
representations".

So you ask for a resource and you get a representation. Is that what
you wanted to say?

-- 
Sorry for the confusion,

Berend. (-:





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3872
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 00:52:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

>     Roy> HTTP servers store representations, not resources.
>
> Oops, I made the same mistake, I meant to say "return
> representations".
>
> So you ask for a resource and you get a representation. Is that what
> you wanted to say?

No.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3873
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 02:33:51
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

On Thu, Aug 07, 2003 at 01:55:48PM -0400, Alex Jacobson wrote:
> The genius of ReST is its recognition of the value of a standardized 
> resource interface in a heterogeneous large scale networked environments 
> and its attempt to articulate such an interface.  Its tragic flaw is that 
> it did not standardize enough of the *semantics* of this interface to 
> achieve the value it promised.

If it was any more specific, then the semantics wouldn't be uniform,
and the ability for HTTP to be used with all resources would be
jeopardized; the "universal information space" that is the Web, wouldn't
be universal.

It's fine for HTTP's interface to be used in a manner which is more
specific than HTTP defines, if the two parties agree.  But when Roy
talks about the difficulty of extension, what I think he means is that
on the wilds of the Web, private agreements like that are problematic
because they're not visible and require out-of-band agreement.  To be
RESTful requires ensuring messages are self-descriptive and therefore
declare any "extended intentions" (but unfortunately, HTTP 1.1 doesn't
support doing that).

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3874
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 10:09:47
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

Mark Baker wrote:


> If it was any more specific, then the semantics wouldn't be uniform,
> and the ability for HTTP to be used with all resources would be
> jeopardized; the "universal information space" that is the Web, wouldn't
> be universal.

I'm not sure what you're saying; I think I might disagree with it. 
HTTP method semantics seem to be /adequate/. I'm not sure they're 
ideal or optimal (how would we know?).


> It's fine for HTTP's interface to be used in a manner which is more
> specific than HTTP defines, if the two parties agree.  But when Roy
> talks about the difficulty of extension, what I think he means is that
> on the wilds of the Web, private agreements like that are problematic
> because they're not visible and require out-of-band agreement.  To be
> RESTful requires ensuring messages are self-descriptive and therefore
> declare any "extended intentions" (but unfortunately, HTTP 1.1 doesn't
> support doing that).

In work we call these 'bilateral exchanges'. They have immediate 
utility and are attractive for that, but the costs rise as more 
parties want to communicate, yada yada.

The hardest part is getting the first three parties to agree to 
uniformity. The fourth party always thinks it's a no-brainer.

I suspect the problem Alex really wants to fix is pinning down 
content models for exchanges of representations and not HTTP 
methods, which are fine. That's work that can be tackled outside 
HTTP entirely, I'm not sure about REST. It's also a main beef of 
mine with SOAP/WSDL. All that effort and we're not really any closer 
to having solid content models - I wish FIPA would get some 
marketing dollars behind it :)

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3875
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 10:47:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

On Fri, Aug 08, 2003 at 11:09:47AM +0100, Bill de hra wrote:
> > If it was any more specific, then the semantics wouldn't be uniform,
> > and the ability for HTTP to be used with all resources would be
> > jeopardized; the "universal information space" that is the Web, wouldn't
> > be universal.
> 
> I'm not sure what you're saying; I think I might disagree with it. 
> HTTP method semantics seem to be /adequate/. I'm not sure they're 
> ideal or optimal (how would we know?).

They're optimal in the sense that they are meaningful (though perhaps
not "implemented") with every resource.  You'd know that they weren't
if there existed a single resource for which any of the methods were
not meaningful.

I sometimes liken this to java.lang.Object, for illustrative purposes.
If it included a method which didn't make sense to all objects, then
not all objects could extend it.

> > It's fine for HTTP's interface to be used in a manner which is more
> > specific than HTTP defines, if the two parties agree.  But when Roy
> > talks about the difficulty of extension, what I think he means is that
> > on the wilds of the Web, private agreements like that are problematic
> > because they're not visible and require out-of-band agreement.  To be
> > RESTful requires ensuring messages are self-descriptive and therefore
> > declare any "extended intentions" (but unfortunately, HTTP 1.1 doesn't
> > support doing that).
> 
> In work we call these 'bilateral exchanges'. They have immediate 
> utility and are attractive for that, but the costs rise as more 
> parties want to communicate, yada yada.
> 
> The hardest part is getting the first three parties to agree to 
> uniformity. The fourth party always thinks it's a no-brainer.
> 
> I suspect the problem Alex really wants to fix is pinning down 
> content models for exchanges of representations and not HTTP 
> methods, which are fine. That's work that can be tackled outside 
> HTTP entirely, I'm not sure about REST. It's also a main beef of 
> mine with SOAP/WSDL. All that effort and we're not really any closer 
> to having solid content models - I wish FIPA would get some 
> marketing dollars behind it :)

I don't know what he means by "Content models".  RDF maybe?

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3876
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 11:01:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

Mark Baker wrote:


> They're optimal in the sense that they are meaningful (though perhaps
> not "implemented") with every resource.  You'd know that they weren't
> if there existed a single resource for which any of the methods were
> not meaningful.

So why do we have an Allow header? ;)


> I don't know what he means by "Content models".  RDF maybe?

I might have introduced that term into the thread. But yes RDF would 
be a content model or, a 'model of data'. XML itself isn't, but XML 
vocabs get you some of the way.

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3877
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 13:26:29
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

On Fri, Aug 08, 2003 at 12:01:04PM +0100, Bill de hra wrote:
> > They're optimal in the sense that they are meaningful (though perhaps
> > not "implemented") with every resource.  You'd know that they weren't
> > if there existed a single resource for which any of the methods were
> > not meaningful.
> 
> So why do we have an Allow header? ;)

I see the smiley; does that mean you do or don't see the difference
between "implements" and "meaningful"?  It's an important difference.

In case it's the former, "Allow" specifies which methods are
*implemented*, such as whether or not I choose to implement toString()
on some particular Java object of my own creation.  That toString()
is even *on* java.lang.Object at all, is what I mean by "meaningful";
putting a "walkDog()" method on java.lang.Object would be an example of
"not meaningful".

> > I don't know what he means by "Content models".  RDF maybe?
> 
> I might have introduced that term into the thread. But yes RDF would 
> be a content model or, a 'model of data'. XML itself isn't, but XML 
> vocabs get you some of the way.

Ok, then maybe I agree with that part of his point.

I disagree with his emphasis on schemas.  They are just syntactic
rules, and normally used in an un-RESTful way (not self-descriptive).
What you need is an architectural property called "partial
understanding"[1] which allows machines to process the portion of a
document that they can, rather than the all-or-nothing approach
typically taken in the XML+ schema world.  RDF is very well suited to
this, as is TopicMaps.

 [1] http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-webarch-extlang#Requirements

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3878
Sender:"Hammond, Tony (ELSLON)" <t.hammond@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 14:03:33
Subject:FW: Announcement: RSS 1.0 Module 'mod_context'
Message:

Am forwarding this post to the rest-discuss list as the document provides
examples of the OpenURL being used as a query API for context-sensitive
services. This may be of some interest to the REST discussions.

 

Tony

 

Tony Hammond

 

Advanced Technology Group, Elsevier Ltd

32 Jamestown Road, London, NW1 7BY, UK

 

<tel:+44-20-7424-4445>

<mailto:t.hammond@...> 

 

 

  _____  

From: Hammond, Tony (ELSLON) 
Sent: 08 August 2003 14:57
To: 'rss-dev@egroups.com'; 'www-rdf-interest@...'

 

Hi all:

 

Please excuse the cross-post but this may be of interest to both lists. We
are making available for comment a new RSS 1.0 Module 'mod_context':

 

      http://www2.elsevier.co.uk/~tony/spec/rss/mod_context.html
<http://www2.elsevier.co.uk/~tony/spec/rss/mod_context.html>  

 

Note that the URL is provisional and that we expect that the Module will be
subsequently lodged under the URL

 

      http://www.egroups.com/files/rss-dev/Modules/Proposed/mod_context.html
<http://www.egroups.com/files/rss-dev/Modules/Proposed/mod_context.html> 

 

The rationale in defining the 'mod_context' RSS 1.0 module is that this
module allows RSS 1.0 feeds to provide contextual information which relates
a description of the feed channel or item to the provenance of the feed, the
requester of the feed, and the where and how the feed should be processed.
Rich descriptions of this contextual information can be provided using both
identifiers and metadata. The OpenURL Framework data model exists to support
network applications in the provisioning of context-sensitive services. 

 

This draft RSS 1.0 module is being released to support applications that
wish to make use of the ANSI/NISO Draft Standard for Trial Use 'The OpenURL
Framework for Context-Sensitive Services'. It is anticipated that a revised
version of this module will be resubmitted following a successful ballot by
NISO Voting Members when the Draft Standard is published as currently
expected NISO Standard Z39.88-2003.

 

For further information on the OpenURL Framework see the Draft Standard
documents

 

Part 1:
http://library.caltech.edu/openurl/PubComDocs/StdDocs/Part1-PC-20030513.pdf
<http://library.caltech.edu/openurl/PubComDocs/StdDocs/Part1-PC-20030513.pdf
> 

Part 2:
http://library.caltech.edu/openurl/PubComDocs/StdDocs/Part2-PC-20030513.pdf
<http://library.caltech.edu/openurl/PubComDocs/StdDocs/Part2-PC-20030513.pdf
> 

 

on the ANIS/NISO AX website 

 

http://library.caltech.edu/openurl/Public_Comments.htm
<http://library.caltech.edu/openurl/Public_Comments.htm> 

 

All feedback is welcome.

 

Thanks,

 

Tony Hammond, Elsevier

Timo Hannay, Nature Publishing Group

Eamonn Neylon, Manifest Solutions

Herbert Van de Sompel, Los Alamos National Laboratory





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3879
Sender:"bhaugen32" <bhaugen32@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 18:10:21
Subject:Re: Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

Bill de hra wrote:

> The hardest part is getting the first three parties to agree to 
> uniformity. The fourth party always thinks it's a no-brainer.

That's delicious!  Did you make it up?

Hope you won't mind if I quote you in another context...

-Bob Haugen





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3880
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 18:57:39
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

> but whatever is your system, you'll always have to document it, i.e. to
> describe formats, etc. You can't define a data format, and thus a set of
> behaviours, that will fit any applications needs....

Again and to be perfectly clear:

THE FORMATS SHOULD BE *ALL* YOU NEED TO UNDERSTAND THE SYSTEM'S BEHAVIOR

~90% of your specification described how to use HTTP with your resources
~10% was a description of the formats.

So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you would 
have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.

> As long as you know that /inbox/ is a container containing mime
> messages,

The question (again) is:

HOW do you know that /inbox/ actually is a container containing MIME 
messages?

Also, what does it mean actually to be a container?  FIFO? LIFO? by 
from-address...?  How does the shape of the container relate to your index 
format for representing it?

MoST provides enough constraints so that knowing *ONLY* your index format, 
a client can deliver mail.  The client does not need to know *anything* 
about how the server thinks about inboxes internally.

> so describe your format. In this description, i wanted to be unambiguous,
> but the knowledge that the /inbox/ is a container is sufficient, has I
> know that i can POST to add a content and GET to obtain the listing (and
> delete to reset the container)

Again, how does the client know that /inbox/ is a container and not simply 
an index?

Your inbox format was a list of plaintext "subject : uri"  A few years ago, 
DJ Bernstein proposed an alternative to SMTP which made mail storage the 
sender's responsibility.  Your inbox format caused me to assume you 
intended something similar.  It implies that mail delivery is simply adding 
an entry to an index and letting the client be responsible for storing the 
message at some URI.

However, if you want mail storage to be the recipient's responsibility, and 
you want messages in MIME format, you should use a format for your inbox 
that supports appending MIME messages e.g. mbox or multipart/digest.

Note that simply by defining your file formats correctly you can completely 
control the semantics of your application!

Also note that whether the server STORES the messages in these format is 
TOTALLY IRRELEVANT.  The point is only that by exposing the resource using 
this content-type, it is saying that the resource can be manipulated as if 
in fact it is represented on the server in that content type.  (See my 
response to Roy).

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3881
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 21:15:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

In your dissertation, you say:
"""
REST components communicate by transferring a representation of a resource 
in a format matching one of an evolving set of standard data types, 
selected dynamically based on the capabilities or desires of the recipient 
and the nature of the resource. Whether the representation is in the same 
format as the raw source, or is derived from the source, remains hidden 
behind the interface.
[...]
Each origin server provides a generic interface to its services as a 
resource hierarchy. The resource implementation details are hidden behind 
the interface.
"""

MoST says that the semantics of this generic interface should apply to the 
exposed representation rather than the "hidden" one.  Because, if HTTP 
methods apply only to the exposed representation of a resource, then their 
semantics are constrained entirely by the HTTP protocol and the 
content-type of the subject resource and HTTP thereby becomes a truly 
generic interface (at least on a per-content-type basis).

However, if HTTP methods are intended to apply to the "hidden" 
representation then, aside from the fact that the "hidden" representation 
would not be truly hidden, the semantics of HTTP methods would need to 
include the mapping between hidden and external representations.  If this 
mapping varies from resource to resource then the semantics of HTTP methods 
cease to be generic as they depend on the behavior of each resource 
server's mapping functions.

Although, based on your comments quoted above, I believe MoST follows 
logically and necessarily from ReST, many of the people on this list appear 
to disagree.  They believe that HTTP methods should be interpreted as 
applying to the internal representations rather than the external ones, 
forcing me so articulate this issue as "ReST vs MoST" rather than "ReST 
implies MoST."

>> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server maps the >> 
state of a resource into a response to a GET request, a client >> can have 
ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA what the content of that response
>> means; it is simply has bits that can mean anything at all.
>
> What does "mean" mean in this context?

If I GET a number and that number is intended to *represent* another 
number, how do I know what functions were applied to the represented number 
to produce the representing number.  Was it only the identity function? Was 
ln() applied?  Was round() or floor() applied?  If I don't know the mapping 
function between the internal and external representations, exactly what do 
I know about a represented resource simply from GETting a  representation 
from its server?

>> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server uses
>> PUT/POST-ed content to change the state of a resource, a client
>> can have ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA what the effect of a PUT or POST
>> actually will be.
>
> That just says that REST doesn't mandate one single model.  Nothing
> prevents the server from establishing a model and telling the client
> what it is.  That is how hypertext works: the engine of application
> state change.

Exactly how does hypertext tell me the relationship between a resource and 
its representation?

Following the above example, if I PUT a number to the server, how does 
hypertext tell me what transformations the server applies to that number to 
change the actual state of the resource?

Note absent this hypothetical hypertext engine, what you are really saying 
is that ReST allows every server to choose its own semantics for GET, PUT, 
POST and that all the advantages ReST claims from delivering a generic 
interface would be bogus.


>> Roy thinks these explicit models should be entirely arbitrary
>> and specified at the whim of the server operator on a per-URI
>> basis.  I think these models should be standardized in some
>> manner and be URI independent.
>
> They aren't entirely arbitrary; they are merely chosen by the server.

They are arbitrarily chosen by the server operator because the server 
operator can choose whichever internal representation suits his/her fancy.

> In some cases they will be selected from a standard (such as webdav).
> In other cases they will be defined by an interface language (like WSDL).

You used to think differently.  In your dissertation you say:

"""
The semantics are thus not defined by the network interface (IIOP), but by 
the object's IDL spec. Whether this is a good thing or not depends on the 
application -- for distributed objects it is a necessity, for the Web it 
isn't.
"""

Now you tell us that we need these IDLs (now taking the form of WSDL). 
What changed?

You used to want "generic interface with standard semantics that can be 
interpreted by intermediaries almost as well as by the machines that 
originate services."

You now appear to have abandoned that project in favor of per-service 
semantics.  What happened?

>> Allowing clients to interact with agents of this power and
>> complexity through HTTP then requires that service operators be
>> permitted to overload HTTP methods to have essentially arbitrary
>> meanings.
>
> That doesn't follow at all.  Service operators control the implementation
> of HTTP methods.  Methods get overloaded because service operators do want
> additional semantics, but normal people don't know how to extend them and
> implementers can't read protocol specs.  It is an artifact of the social
> process surrounding standardized protocols.  You can't fix it by
> forbidding the extension of methods.

In another thread on this topic, Yannick wants to create an "inbox" 
resource that is represented by plaintext lines of "subject : uri".  He 
says that this format actually represents a container of MIME messages, 
that one can add a message to this container by POSTing message/rfc822, and 
that a GET of a URI in the inbox representation should return a 
message/rfc822.

In other words, Yannick arbitrarily overloads GET to return his new index 
format as a representation of a "hidden" container rather than e.g. a 
multipart/digest containing all the messages (no downloading of mail 
archives allowed!).  He arbitrarily overloads POST to take a message/rfc822 
and add it to this imaginary container (in what order?),  rather than e.g. 
taking text/xml+message and converting and rather than taking the POST 
content as a message body and constructing message headers from the HTTP 
headers.

I'm pretty sure that Yannick is doing nothing that contravenes any spec. 
But I am also pretty sure that there is a problem if all of these methods 
can mean so many different things for such a tiny application.  It means 
that we need documentation of how to use HTTP for each and every actual and 
hypothetical URI on the Internet.  It means we lose the whole notion of 
simple interoperability.

Perhaps we could use WSDL, but why not simply follow the rule that HTTP 
semantics operate on external representations.  Then Yannick's index format 
specifies everything about you need to know and we don't need him to tell 
us how to use HTTP to operate on his resources.  (See the other thread for 
details).

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


>> But resources don't really need to be so abstract and the meanings of
>> HTTP
>> methods don't need to be so loose.  Programs don't actually manipulate
>> "concepts" or "non-virtual objects;" they just manipulate bits.
>
> Right.  It's people that manipulate concepts and non-virtual objects.
>
>>   It would
>> be more realistic to say that an HTTP resource is simply a set of bits
>> whose syntactic structure is enforced by an HTTP server and whose
>> meaning
>> is determined entirely by agents which interact with this server.
>
> No it wouldn't, since such a definition ignores the ability of people
> to anticipate changes that have not yet occurred.  Time is essential
> to the meaning of a hypertext link, and thus the definition of resource.
> HTTP servers store representations, not resources.




>>   To say
>> otherwise is to say that there is a meaningful difference in effect
>> between
>> having an agent poll a resource and act when it changes and having a
>> server
>> notify an agent to act whenever a resource is changed or to say that
>> there
>> is a meaningful difference between such an agent residing on the HTTP
>> server itself and such an agent residing on another machine across the
>> Internet and interacting via HTTP.
>
> Or simply that resource isn't what you think it means.
>
>> Viewed this way, it makes no sense to talk about some single *special*
>> hidden representation to which a single special HTTP server agent
>> mediates
>> access.  Instead we should recognize that agents on the server and
>> across
>> the Internet can use any data structures they want for their
>> activities but
>> that their doing so is really beside the point.  The function of an
>> HTTP
>> server as such is simply to provide a shared blackboard for
>> communication
>> between these agents.  What these agents really need is a shared
>> *explicit
>> model* for determining what is on this blackboard and for how it may be
>> changed.
>
> The blackboard model is another architectural style with a lot of
> interesting work associated with it.  Tuple-spaces use that.  The
> problem with blackboards isn't just a lack of a data model;
> they also have centralized identification and lack metadata.
>
> ....Roy
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3882
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-08 23:25:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

> MoST says that the semantics of this generic interface should apply to 
> the exposed representation rather than the "hidden" one.  Because, if 
> HTTP methods apply only to the exposed representation of a resource, 
> then their semantics are constrained entirely by the HTTP protocol and 
> the content-type of the subject resource and HTTP thereby becomes a 
> truly generic interface (at least on a per-content-type basis).
>
> However, if HTTP methods are intended to apply to the "hidden" 
> representation then, aside from the fact that the "hidden" 
> representation would not be truly hidden, the semantics of HTTP 
> methods would need to include the mapping between hidden and external 
> representations.  If this mapping varies from resource to resource 
> then the semantics of HTTP methods cease to be generic as they depend 
> on the behavior of each resource server's mapping functions.

No.  Information comes in many different representations.  That does not
change the semantics of GET or PUT -- not even a tiny bit.  IF the 
server
allows a resource to be negotiable in terms of representations, then the
resource (that abstract concept mapping) is independent of the bits.
That means the server either must disallow PUT on that resource,
possibly redirecting the request to some other resource that is
bit-for-bit equivalent, or be capable of inspecting each PUT
representation for the new abstract state.  The latter is not too
difficult for many practical uses: Day's Communique product extracts
the atoms of content from the individual cells of table whether it
is PUT as an excel spreadsheet, an HTML table, or a Word RTF table.

> Although, based on your comments quoted above, I believe MoST follows 
> logically and necessarily from ReST, many of the people on this list 
> appear to disagree.  They believe that HTTP methods should be 
> interpreted as applying to the internal representations rather than 
> the external ones, forcing me so articulate this issue as "ReST vs 
> MoST" rather than "ReST implies MoST."

They apply to representations depending upon how the resource is 
defined,
but they apply to the resource (as in changing its state) uniformly.  
The
problem is the way you view a resource -- if you constrain the notion of
a resource to being a stored representation, then you simply eliminate
the freedom of the server to choose whether the resource is going to
be negotiable in bit format.  There are good things and bad things
about such a model, but it certainly isn't necessary.  The Web works
fine without such a constraint.

>>> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server maps the >>
> state of a resource into a response to a GET request, a client >> can 
> have ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA what the content of that response
>>> means; it is simply has bits that can mean anything at all.
>>
>> What does "mean" mean in this context?
>
> If I GET a number and that number is intended to *represent* another 
> number, how do I know what functions were applied to the represented 
> number to produce the representing number.  Was it only the identity 
> function? Was ln() applied?  Was round() or floor() applied?  If I 
> don't know the mapping function between the internal and external 
> representations, exactly what do I know about a represented resource 
> simply from GETting a  representation from its server?

Whatever is applied, it cannot change the information state.  Obviously,
that means round() and floor() are out of the question.

>>> * Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server uses
>>> PUT/POST-ed content to change the state of a resource, a client
>>> can have ABSOLUTELY NO IDEA what the effect of a PUT or POST
>>> actually will be.
>>
>> That just says that REST doesn't mandate one single model.  Nothing
>> prevents the server from establishing a model and telling the client
>> what it is.  That is how hypertext works: the engine of application
>> state change.
>
> Exactly how does hypertext tell me the relationship between a resource 
> and its representation?

By including the identifier in a context of use wherein the relationship
is predefined, just as it is for an HTML anchor.

> Following the above example, if I PUT a number to the server, how does 
> hypertext tell me what transformations the server applies to that 
> number to change the actual state of the resource?

It doesn't, because you don't need to know.

> Note absent this hypothetical hypertext engine, what you are really 
> saying is that ReST allows every server to choose its own semantics 
> for GET, PUT, POST and that all the advantages ReST claims from 
> delivering a generic interface would be bogus.

That's just bullshit.

>>> Roy thinks these explicit models should be entirely arbitrary
>>> and specified at the whim of the server operator on a per-URI
>>> basis.  I think these models should be standardized in some
>>> manner and be URI independent.
>>
>> They aren't entirely arbitrary; they are merely chosen by the server.
>
> They are arbitrarily chosen by the server operator because the server 
> operator can choose whichever internal representation suits his/her 
> fancy.

Which is irrelevant because the interface is to a RESOURCE.

>> In some cases they will be selected from a standard (such as webdav).
>> In other cases they will be defined by an interface language (like 
>> WSDL).
>
> You used to think differently.  In your dissertation you say:
>
> """
> The semantics are thus not defined by the network interface (IIOP), 
> but by the object's IDL spec. Whether this is a good thing or not 
> depends on the application -- for distributed objects it is a 
> necessity, for the Web it isn't.
> """
>
> Now you tell us that we need these IDLs (now taking the form of WSDL). 
> What changed?

No, I said that what you wanted to do (define an interface model for 
some
set of resources) can be done with something like WSDL.  The Web still
doesn't need them.

> You used to want "generic interface with standard semantics that can 
> be interpreted by intermediaries almost as well as by the machines 
> that originate services."
>
> You now appear to have abandoned that project in favor of per-service 
> semantics.  What happened?

Nothing -- you are just wrong about them being necessary.

>>> Allowing clients to interact with agents of this power and
>>> complexity through HTTP then requires that service operators be
>>> permitted to overload HTTP methods to have essentially arbitrary
>>> meanings.
>>
>> That doesn't follow at all.  Service operators control the 
>> implementation
>> of HTTP methods.  Methods get overloaded because service operators do 
>> want
>> additional semantics, but normal people don't know how to extend them 
>> and
>> implementers can't read protocol specs.  It is an artifact of the 
>> social
>> process surrounding standardized protocols.  You can't fix it by
>> forbidding the extension of methods.
>
> In another thread on this topic, Yannick wants to create an "inbox" 
> resource that is represented by plaintext lines of "subject : uri".  
> He says that this format actually represents a container of MIME 
> messages, that one can add a message to this container by POSTing 
> message/rfc822, and that a GET of a URI in the inbox representation 
> should return a message/rfc822.
>
> In other words, Yannick arbitrarily overloads GET to return his new 
> index format as a representation of a "hidden" container rather than 
> e.g. a multipart/digest containing all the messages (no downloading of 
> mail archives allowed!).  He arbitrarily overloads POST to take a 
> message/rfc822 and add it to this imaginary container (in what 
> order?),  rather than e.g. taking text/xml+message and converting and 
> rather than taking the POST content as a message body and constructing 
> message headers from the HTTP headers.

Why "overloads"?  He is simply using those methods as they were defined.
He isn't defining an interface of bits -- he is defining an information
interface.

> I'm pretty sure that Yannick is doing nothing that contravenes any 
> spec. But I am also pretty sure that there is a problem if all of 
> these methods can mean so many different things for such a tiny 
> application.  It means that we need documentation of how to use HTTP 
> for each and every actual and hypothetical URI on the Internet.  It 
> means we lose the whole notion of simple interoperability.

No, it doesn't -- you have no basis for such a claim.

> Perhaps we could use WSDL, but why not simply follow the rule that 
> HTTP semantics operate on external representations.  Then Yannick's 
> index format specifies everything about you need to know and we don't 
> need him to tell us how to use HTTP to operate on his resources.  (See 
> the other thread for details).

Because HTTP semantics do not operate on external representations,
and therefore any attempt to claim such a rule for the general case
is false.  HTTP needs to be flexible to support gateways and legacy
systems for which the semantics you are demanding simply do not apply.

That does not prevent you from applying that rule in a specific case,
such as in a specific set of resources that your software is going
to be interacting with -- such an additional constraint is still
compatible with REST-based systems and may have some additional
properties that make it worthwhile, but you should also document
the trade-offs: those properties that are degraded by applying
that rule.

....Roy

Post ID:3883
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-09 05:41:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

> >
> > Exactly how does hypertext tell me the relationship between a resource 
> > and its representation?
> 
> By including the identifier in a context of use wherein the relationship
> is predefined, just as it is for an HTML anchor.


Good gravy, I think I actually understood that.

Post ID:3884
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-09 09:08:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Le ven 08/08/2003  20:57, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> > but whatever is your system, you'll always have to document it, i.e. to
> > describe formats, etc. You can't define a data format, and thus a set of
> > behaviours, that will fit any applications needs....
> 
> Again and to be perfectly clear:
> 
> THE FORMATS SHOULD BE *ALL* YOU NEED TO UNDERSTAND THE SYSTEM'S BEHAVIOR
> 
> ~90% of your specification described how to use HTTP with your resources
> ~10% was a description of the formats.
> 
> So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you would 
> have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.

Ok, so give an example.. I have to admit that i don't really understand.
You have to define a format that is suitable for any kind of
application. This look quite ambitious. You can use RDF to help the
representation to be self descriptive, but you still have to define (ou
refine) and RDFS. From an other pov, your proposal looks like wsdl (as 
Bill? said).

> 
> HOW do you know that /inbox/ actually is a container containing MIME 
> messages?

it's a one-line-doc matter...  :), or application/x-container, and no
need for doc!

> Also, what does it mean actually to be a container?  FIFO? LIFO? by 
> from-address...?  How does the shape of the container relate to your index 
> format for representing it?

why does the client have to care about that ???

> MoST provides enough constraints so that knowing *ONLY* your index format, 
> a client can deliver mail.

Here, i don't have to anything about the index format to deliver mail. I
have to know about it to retrieve mails. To deliver, all i have to know
is that /inbox/ accepts mime as the Content-Type of a POST, which can be
stated in an OPTION response (not sure) .

>   The client does not need to know *anything* 
> about how the server thinks about inboxes internally.

Why does it need it in the proposed example ?

>  Your inbox format caused me to assume you 
> intended something similar.  It implies that mail delivery is simply adding 
> an entry to an index and letting the client be responsible for storing the 
> message at some URI.

no. 

> However, if you want mail storage to be the recipient's responsibility, and 
> you want messages in MIME format, you should use a format for your inbox 
> that supports appending MIME messages e.g. mbox or multipart/digest.

agin, no. 

the index is a *representation* of the container. e.g.

c: 
GET /inbox/

s:
200 ok
aaa: http://host/inbox/aaa-mid
bbb: http://host/inbox/aaa-mid

c:
GET /inbox/aaa-mid

s:
200 ok
MIME version: 1.0
...

c:
POST /inbox/
Content-Type: mime/rfc-822

MIME ...
Subject: ccc
Message-ID: ccc-mid
...

s:
201 created
Location: http://host/inbox/ccc-mid

c:
GET /inbox/

s:
200 
ok

aaa: http://host/inbox/aaa-mid
bbb: http://host/inbox/aaa-mid
ccc: http://host/inbox/ccc-mid



but this example is juste quickly imagined to be an example, and must
not be considered as a proposal, nor as an complete and robust system.
there is surely problems in it :)
but it is concrete. Can't you give a concrete example of MoST model ?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3885
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-09 20:36:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

On Saturday 09 August 2003 05:08, Yannick Loiseau wrote:
> Le ven 08/08/2003  20:57, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> > Again and to be perfectly clear:
> >
> > THE FORMATS SHOULD BE *ALL* YOU NEED TO UNDERSTAND THE SYSTEM'S BEHAVIOR
> >
> > ~90% of your specification described how to use HTTP with your resources
> > ~10% was a description of the formats.
> >
> > So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you would
> > have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.
>
> Ok, so give an example..

The web-calculus provides exactly this functionality. Given an
understanding of the web-calculus, the only application
information that needs to be communicated is the structure of the
application web.

For example, the web-calculus specification uses an electronic
currency for its examples. This electronic currency application
interface is completely defined by the set of schemas that define
the structure of a currency exchange web. These schemas are
available at:

http://waterken.com/iou/

The productivity leverage comes from everyone working to a common,
simple and well-defined model. Before even starting an
application, everyone knows what the basic interactions will be.
The only difference between two applications is the shape of the
application graph. The shape of the application graph is precisely
defined by the schemas.

Tyler

-- 
The union of REST and capability-based security:
http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3886
Sender:Josh Sled <jsled-yahoogroup@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-10 21:17:36
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Handling big resources
Message:

On Mon, Apr 28, 2003 at 02:56:39PM +0200, Mailinglisten wrote:

I'm suprised nobody responded to this ... there are some serious application
perf. issue that can come up once one start using REST that need to be
accounted for.

| I've a REST interface for relational databases. A GET message to (table)
| resource produces the following list:
| 
| <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
| <resources xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
|     <resource
| xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/0/">0</resource>
|     <resource
| xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/1/">1</resource>
|     <resource
| xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/2/">2</resource>
|     <resource
| xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/3/">3</resource>
|     ...
|     <resource
| xlink:href="http://127.0.0.1:8080/sqlrest/CUSTOMER/600000/">600000</resource
| >
| </resource>
| 
| The list is to big to send it in one chunk. It would be better to breakt it
| in smaller pieces.

| Questions:
| 
| 1.) Can the server send the response with a 206 Partial Content SC, even the
| client hasn't requested a range?

It doesn't seem like the server should attempt to interpret the client
response this way, unless that's the contract the server has.  In any case,
it seems like 206 is inappropriate for this.

| 2.) That is the RESTian way for the server, to give the client a hint where
| or how he can request the next chunk?
|     a.) A reference in the XML Content like <resources
| xlink:href="http://...
|     b.) A Location Header field with the URL of the next Chunk
|     c.) A Content-Range header field in the form:
| 
|         Content-Range: resources start-end / total
| 
|     d.) Both? A link in the XML Content and information in the header?

Content-Range isn't right.  Location headers have a different purpose.
(a) seems more like the right thing....

We've done this by exposing the ranging by paramaterizing the URI, and
including details of the full response-space in the response itself.

GET /sqlrest/customer?count=0&offset=0
<resources size="60000" />

GET /sqlrest/customer?count=5&offset=0
<resources size="60000">
  <resource href="/sqlrest/customer/0">0</resource>
  <!-- ... -->
  <resource href="/sqlrest/customer/5">5</resource>
  <!-- See NOTE1 -->
</resources>

NOTE1:

On the theory that we're transfering hypertext media around, it seems
like something else could come back here... some description of how to
get the rest of the content.... maybe something like...

<resources href="/sqlrest/customer">
  <param name="count" val="5" />
  <param name="offset" val="5" />
</resources>

We've though about this a bit in our project, but we've just decided to
punt and make it an implicit part of the particular resource-space being
gotten ...


| 3.) Only the type "bytes" are mentioned in the HTTP specification. Can I use
| a own type like resources or are there any proposals for REST?

No ... HTTP is dealing with something else WRT content-range and byte-ranges,
not application-level content chunking.

| 4.) Are there a more REST like approach?

I think what I outlined above is, but I'd like to hear other options.


Another related issue we've run into is the reference vs. "expanded"
sub-resource.  Some container resources have many sub-elements, and the
application wants to get a particular sub-range.

GET /container
<container>
  <elt href="/container/1" />
  <elt href="/container/2" />
  <!-- ... -->
  <elt href="/container/127000" />
</container>

Since the application is only going to turn around and ask for expanded
versions for some window it's currently processing, we've taken to
expanding a sub-range:

GET /container?expand=true&count=2&offset=0
<container>
  <elt href="/container/1">
    <!-- elt data populated -->
  </elt>
  <elt href="/container/2">
    <!-- elt data populated -->
  </elt>
  <elt href="/container/3"/>
  <elt href="/container/4"/>
  <!-- ... -->
  <elt href="/container/127000" />
</container>


It turns out that xfering the rest of those elt-references is quite
prohibitive, especially over the WAN.  Especially since they're just
being ignored by the client, anyways.  I'd encourage you not to make
the same mistake.  Oh, and _always_ return something useful enough for
the caller ...

....jsled

-- 
http://www.asynchronous.org - `a=jsled; b=asynchronous.org; echo ${a}@${b}`





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3887
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-11 18:12:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

Ok.  I just read the HTTP spec a bit more carefully and I am going to 
change my position on this issue somewhat.  HTTP implies MoST even if ReST, 
perhaps, does not.  If you using HTTP and NOT using MoST architecture, you 
are violating the RFC2616, the HTTP specification!

"""
The PUT method requests that the enclosed entity be stored under the 
supplied Request-URI.
"""
[Hyptertext Transfer Protocol --- HTTP/1.1 (RFC2616)]

What does it mean to respond OK to a request that the "enclosed entity be 
stored"?  RFC2616 does not say that a "representation" of the enclosed 
entity is stored, but that the entity itself is stored.  I interpret this 
to mean that if I can PUT an entity with a particular content-type at a 
particular URI, I can GET back that entity with that same content-type at 
that URI.  (The alternative is to say that a server may operate 
destructively with respect to a PUT entity body which seems wrong)

"""
The GET method means retrieve whatever information (in the form of an 
entity) is identified by the Request-URI.
[...]
The Accept request-header field can be used to specify certain media types 
which are acceptable for the response.
[...]
If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client 
accepts all media types.
"""
[RFC2616]

So when a client sends a GET, it expects the information identified by the 
resource.  If "whatever information" means ALL information without data 
loss, the client can reasonably interpret the response to a GET to *BE* the 
server's representation.  (Obviously when the client sends an Accept 
header, it accepting non-fidelity to the server's actual representation, 
but that is really beside the point here.  GET without an Accept header 
implies fidelity).

"""
The POST method is used to request that the origin server accept the entity 
enclosed in the request as a new subordinate of the resource identified by 
the Request-URI in the Request-Line.
"""
[RFC2616]

Since the semantics of POST depend on the definition of "subordinate" 
resource and the definition of "subordinate" resource is dependent on the 
content-type of the server's representation of the resource, we can now say 
that the semantics of POST depends ENTIRELY on the content-type of the 
resource as determined by GET.

--On Friday, August 08, 2003 4:25 PM -0700 "Roy T. Fielding"
> IF the server
> allows a resource to be negotiable in terms of representations, then the
> resource (that abstract concept mapping) is independent of the bits.

To be more specific, IF the request is in response to a GET with an Accept 
header, the bits  of the returned entity may be arbitrarily far from the 
bits of the resource itself.  HOWEVER, if the GET comes *without* an Accept 
header, the server MUST send the resource itself.  In other words, NO 
hidden representation.

> The
> problem is the way you view a resource -- if you constrain the notion of
> a resource to being a stored representation, then you simply eliminate
> the freedom of the server to choose whether the resource is going to
> be negotiable in bit format.  There are good things and bad things
> about such a model, but it certainly isn't necessary.  The Web works
> fine without such a constraint.

MoST does not prohibit the server from handling Accept headers.  It just 
prohibits the server from sending random bits in response to a GET request 
*without* an Accept header.  If the server wants to handle Accept headers, 
GREAT, but that is really beside the point in this discussion.

>> I'm pretty sure that Yannick is doing nothing that contravenes any
>> spec.

I was wrong about this.  Reading the spec more carefully Yannick's app IS 
in violation of HTTP (details in other thread)

> HTTP needs to be flexible to support gateways and legacy
> systems for which the semantics you are demanding simply do not apply.

Unless you can give me a case where the MoST interpretation of HTTP cannot 
be used to support an application that you think it supports under your 
interpretation, this assertion is unfounded!

MoST architectural style means that you don't need hidden information to 
interact with an HTTP server.

If we take HTTP seriously by follow the requirements of MoST architectural 
style, we get more interoperability and transparency, higher productivity, 
and more happiness :- ).

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3888
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-11 18:07:25
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

--On Saturday, August 09, 2003 11:08 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@...> wrote:
>> So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you would
>> have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.
>
> Ok, so give an example.. I have to admit that i don't really understand.
> You have to define a format that is suitable for any kind of
> application. This look quite ambitious. You can use RDF to help the
> representation to be self descriptive, but you still have to define (ou
> refine) and RDFS. From an other pov, your proposal looks like wsdl (as
> Bill? said).

See my comments on taking HTTP seriously in the other thread.
Earlier, you defined an inbox index format.  I am saying that is enough to 
define your entire application from the client's perspective.

If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept 
header, the resource is an index and NOT a container.  That means the 
semantics of POST  should be with respect to that index and not a 
container.  In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST means 
add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container; messages 
must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.

If the server returns a container in response to a GET without an Accept 
header, the resource is a container and not an index.  That means the 
semantics of POST should be with respect to the container and not an index. 
In other words, if the resource is a container, then POST means add a 
message to the container and can at your option affect an index.  Messages 
are stored in the container  a la SMTP.  Note, nothing constrains the 
server from providing an index in response to a GET with a an "Accept: 
text/x-yannick-index", but that is really beside the point.

Note, nothing constrains how the server actually stores the index or the 
container.  All that is required is that clients can interact solely in 
terms of the representations it exposes.

>> HOW do you know that /inbox/ actually is a container containing MIME
>> messages?
>
> it's a one-line-doc matter...  :), or application/x-container, and no
> need for doc!

If the content-type returned from a GET without an Accept header is indeed 
an application/x-container
then how does the client obtain an index?  If it gets an index only when it 
sends the appropriate Accept header, then I have no issue with your app.

>>   The client does not need to know *anything*
>> about how the server thinks about inboxes internally.
>
> Why does it need it in the proposed example ?

It does if GET w/o an Accept header does not imply the required semantics 
w/r/t POST.

> the index is a *representation* of the container. e.g.

It depends what you mean by representation.
0 is a representation of all integers after a suitable transformation.
What is the content-type returned from a GET without an Accept header?
What information is that content-type intended to represent?

> c:
> GET /inbox/
>
> s:
> 200 ok
> aaa: http://host/inbox/aaa-mid
> bbb: http://host/inbox/aaa-mid

So /inbox/ is an index.  Appending an entry to this index is very different 
from appending a message to an inbox.

> c:
> POST /inbox/
> Content-Type: mime/rfc-822
>
> MIME ...
> Subject: ccc
> Message-ID: ccc-mid
> ...
>
> s:
> 201 created
> Location: http://host/inbox/ccc-mid

You CAN support this, but it is not HTTP because it is not meaningful to 
append a MIME message to an
index (because the index does not contain message data).

You needs to support this:
c:
POST /inbox/
Content-type: text/index-entry

ccc: http://host/inbox/ccc-mid

If this is not legal, you are not really supporting HTTP.

> but this example is juste quickly imagined to be an example, and must
> not be considered as a proposal, nor as an complete and robust system.
> there is surely problems in it :)
> but it is concrete. Can't you give a concrete example of MoST model ?

I hope I have been concrete with respect to your example....

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


>
>
>> -Alex-

>

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
