Post ID:3889
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-12 01:57:34
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept
> header, the resource is an index and NOT a container.  That means the
> semantics of POST  should be with respect to that index and not a
> container.  In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST means
> add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container; messages
> must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.
>
> If the server returns a container in response to a GET without an Accept
> header, the resource is a container and not an index.  That means the
> semantics of POST should be with respect to the container and not an
index.
> In other words, if the resource is a container, then POST means add a
> message to the container and can at your option affect an index.  Messages
> are stored in the container  a la SMTP.  Note, nothing constrains the
> server from providing an index in response to a GET with a an "Accept:
> text/x-yannick-index", but that is really beside the point.

If I understand correctly, the idea is that if a resource is labeled as a
"container" (where "container" has mutually agreed upon semantics), then a
client absolutely knows how and when each of the HTTP methods can be used on
that resource.  And what happens when you don't want to provide all
capabilities of a container?  For instances, what if the only function you
want to support is POST of a message and the only successful response is
202?  Once posted, there is no way to GET, PUT, DELETE, etc the message (via
that URI, anyhow).  It seems to me you would have to define the container
with restrictions or define a entirely new model ("drop box"?).  But then
what if the next time, you need something similar that provides only POST
and GET, except that also the expected response for the POST is either 201
or 302?

Let's take another look at RNA...

The interface is split into two URI types:  Identity and Inbox.  In either
case, the "client" (likely a remote server) may only POST an xml-based RNA
document.  In the case of the Identity URI, there is a simple rule that says
"if recipient likes the request entity, it will return a 200 with a similar
response entity, possibly adding or setting elements; otherwise, it will
reject the request appropriately."  In the case of the Inbox URI, there is a
simple rule that says "if recipient likes the request entity, it will return
a 202 (no response entity);  otherwise, it will reject the request
appropriately."  The Identity and Inbox URI have different criteria and
therefore do not necessarily return all of the same possible 4xx responses.
Now, as it happens to be that the Identity URI is highly visible, it also
defines the use of the GET method, which has absolutely no rules on how it
is implemented (beyond the semantics of a GET).  This is because people tend
to plug highly visible URIs into their web browsers and expect to get
something understandable back.  The Inbox URI, on the other hand, is
relatively hidden from the general user and therefore does not have the GET
method defined.

So, how can this be modeled in a way that would replace the need for
documentation?  What are the data models of the two URI types?  What allows
the client to know the valid range of RNA documents (in this case,
xml-based) that can be sent in the request entity, and in the case of the
Identity URI, returned in the response entity?  What if RNA were rewritten
to use ONX or YAML or some entirely proprietary format?  What allows the
clients to know what each of the possible 2xx, 3xx, and 4xx response codes
mean in context to the request such that it may correct its problem and try
again?

If you know how to model all of this in a clear, simple manner that doesn't
tie RNA's hands in any way, I'm all for it.  But what I feel you are
proposing is either too limiting or is too complicated.  Heck, I've got the
entire English language to write the spec with and I'm *still* not entirely
comfortable with the wording.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3890
Sender:"Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-12 04:28:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
Message:

>GET without an Accept header implies fidelity).
Don't forget user-agent.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3891
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-12 07:23:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Here, you're defining a generic behaviour for a container "super-type".
If this is all of Most, I'm ok with it.
If I well understood, MoST is nothing more a set of
rules/design-behaviour pattern/generic types/semantic ... call it how
ever you like, build on top of Rest, just as RDF or web calculous can be
considered too. If this is the case, there is no debate at all! These
are application level specificities, while Rest is
communication/interaction level. You can define a common way to express
rules and restrictions of your application, as you can define a generic
container "super-type", with the corresponding behaviours, but I thing
that is out of the scope of ReST...

Le lun 11/08/2003  20:07, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> --On Saturday, August 09, 2003 11:08 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
> >> So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you would
> >> have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.
> >
> > Ok, so give an example.. I have to admit that i don't really understand.
> > You have to define a format that is suitable for any kind of
> > application. This look quite ambitious. You can use RDF to help the
> > representation to be self descriptive, but you still have to define (ou
> > refine) and RDFS. From an other pov, your proposal looks like wsdl (as
> > Bill? said).
> 
> See my comments on taking HTTP seriously in the other thread.
> Earlier, you defined an inbox index format.  I am saying that is enough to 
> define your entire application from the client's perspective.
> 
> If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept 
> header, the resource is an index and NOT a container.  That means the 
> semantics of POST  should be with respect to that index and not a 
> container.  In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST means 
> add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container; messages 
> must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.
> 
> If the server returns a container in response to a GET without an Accept 
> header, the resource is a container and not an index.  That means the 
> semantics of POST should be with respect to the container and not an index. 
> In other words, if the resource is a container, then POST means add a 
> message to the container and can at your option affect an index.  Messages 
> are stored in the container  a la SMTP.  Note, nothing constrains the 
> server from providing an index in response to a GET with a an "Accept: 
> text/x-yannick-index", but that is really beside the point.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3892
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-12 20:24:12
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Alex Jacobson wrote:

> If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept
> header, the resource is an index and NOT a container. That means the
> semantics of POST should be with respect to that index and not a
> container. In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST
means
> add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container;
messages
> must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.

The wording in HTTP is "subordinate resource". Why can't a message
resource
be "subordinate" to an index resource? That's how directories work,
right?
If I GET a directory, I expect a hyperlinked list of its contents, not
all
the contents together in an archive.

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3893
Sender:"Ludwig, Justin" <jludwig@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-12 18:40:20
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Handling big resources
Message:

> We've done this by exposing the ranging by paramaterizing the URI, and
> including details of the full response-space in the response itself.

  Yes, that's how millions of web apps like Google etc. handle large lists.
By default (w/o the list-management query params) they just send back the
first ten or so items, then later send subsequent list chunks as the client
requests them.


> <resources href="/sqlrest/customer">
>   <param name="count" val="5" />
>   <param name="offset" val="5" />
> </resources>

  That's cool and more flexible for a sophisticated client, but for many
apps it's easier just to include a link to the previous and next chunks; for
example:

<resources rel="next" href="/sqlrest/customer?offset=5&count=5" />

And while urls that make sense and are guessable are really
developer-friendly and we need more of them, it's absolutely best web
practice to send a description for producing the next, prev, and other
related urls (if not the urls themselves) with every page, just as you do
for the urls that identify contained resources. It's self-descriptive, which
is an explicit rest interface constraint (see
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/rest_arch_style.htm#sec_5
_1_5), it enables clients to treat urls opaquely (see
http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/Axioms.html#opaque), and it furthers your
app's web of linked resources, harnessing the awesome power of the world
wide web.

  Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3894
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 02:28:48
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

--On Tuesday, August 12, 2003 1:24 PM -0700 Justin Sampson 
<justin.sampson@...> wrote:

> The wording in HTTP is "subordinate resource". Why can't a message 
resource
> be "subordinate" to an index resource?

Nothing about an index implies subordination of indexed resources.  You can 
PUT a message somewhere else and then updating the index.  You can add an 
entry to the index for a URL that does not currently resolve.  In contrast, 
the only way to add a message to a container is...to add a message to a 
container, making the message subordinate to the container.  Indexes don't 
imply subordination.  Containership does.

> That's how directories work, right?
> If I GET a directory, I expect a hyperlinked list of its contents, not all
> the contents together in an archive.

Since HTTP URLs are hierarchical, an enumeration of all subordinate URLs is 
sufficient to communicate "whatever information" the directory URI 
designates.

Notably, because indexes don't themselves imply subordination of indexed 
resources, you can't take an index to imply that you add a file to a 
directory by POSTing to it.  To get an entry to appear in the index, you 
must put a corresponding file in the directory.

So you can view my objection to POSTing to Yannicks message indexes as 
equivalent to objecting to POSTing to directory URLs.  The semantics just 
aren't there to do it.

-Alex-

PS GREAT question Justin!
___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax



> Alex Jacobson wrote:
>
>> If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept
>> header, the resource is an index and NOT a container. That means the
>> semantics of POST should be with respect to that index and not a
>> container. In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST
> means
>> add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container;
> messages
>> must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.
>
>
> Justin

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3895
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 00:17:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Seairth,

MoST is just about taking HTTP seriously.  If the resource does not allow a 
particular method, give an error.

Re RNA (<http://www.seairth.com/web/rna/>):

> The interface is split into two URI types:  Identity and Inbox.

Bad premise.  HTTP URIs designate RESOURCES that have *content-types*. 
URIs themselves do not have types.  This bad URL-type premise means you 
start by defining a special content-type for POST rather than a 
content-type for an inbox.  Having no inbox type means having no standard 
way to check your mail.  To me, this seems like a major failure in a 
"notification" protocol.  Your spec then becomes documentation of various 
interaction protocols that I find lengthy, arbitrary, and hard to follow 
(sorry).

Rather than a 15 page specification, how about one sentence:

 Map email addresses to HTTP by delivering to http://user@...

Given the constraints imposed by taking HTTP seriously, a little knowledge 
of existing content-types, and a little common sense, this one sentence is 
all you need to specify a system that does everything I believe RNA does. 
Simply tell users:

 Your inbox is located at http://user@...

Users can GET their inbox URLs and discover they have content-type: 
multipart/digest (RFC1521).  They can then build/install a simple 
HTTP<->POP proxy and to read their mail using their favorite POP clients. 
When they reply to messages, their mail delivery agents can attempt to POST 
to the delivery URL of the sender before attempting SMTP delivery.  (The 
delivery URL of the sender is defined by the one sentence spec).

Before they POST to this URI, they do a HEAD to discover the content-type 
they may POST.  When they discover the content-type is multipart/digest, 
they know they can POST message/rfc822.  When they attempt to POST a 
message/rfc822 but get a "413 Request Entity Too Large" (because the 
recipient requires that mail storage be the sender's responsibility), they 
PUT their message body to some URI they control and then re-POST using an 
RFC2017 URL external-body content-type.  The server responds 201 CREATED 
with a Location header.  If they later decide they want to cancel that 
message, they can try to DELETE the url provided in that Location header. 
If they get a 200, they know their DELETE is successful.  If they get a 
403, they know they are going to have to explain the message they sent in a 
fit of rage.

General Comments:
* The above system is defined ENTIRELY by the relevant content-types.  Any 
ambiguities are the result of ambiguities in the content-types and not 
ambiguities in how to use HTTP.  If you wanted to be more careful, you 
might define a multipart/external-body content-type that  allows only parts 
that are message/rfc822 with URL external-body content-type.  Note that 
having done so, you would still be COMPLETELY SILENT about HTTP methods as 
they would be determined entirely by your container type..

* There is no explicitly documented standard for associating a URL with a 
MIME-part.  You could specify one.  However, given the constraint of 
RFC2616 and digest format, I think the *obvious* standard is simply to give 
each part a Location: header.  I think this is so obvious that I am not 
sure it worth documenting.  But feel free.

* The above was so short because there are already MIME container types 
that do more-or-less what you want.  Some applications may require you do 
define new content-types and content-types for containers of those types 
but any discussion of using HTTP with those types would be tutorial rather 
than specification.

* I am not aware of a standard XML container type.  There used to be work 
on XML "groves" but I don't know where that went.  So implementing the 
above with XML types actually requires a lot more content-type 
documentation work.  Given the installed base of messaging applications 
that use MIME, I'm also not sure it is worth bothering.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





--On Monday, August 11, 2003 9:57 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs

>>
>> If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept
>> header, the resource is an index and NOT a container.  That means the
>> semantics of POST  should be with respect to that index and not a
>> container.  In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST means
>> add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container; messages
>> must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.
>>
>> If the server returns a container in response to a GET without an Accept
>> header, the resource is a container and not an index.  That means the
>> semantics of POST should be with respect to the container and not an
> index.
>> In other words, if the resource is a container, then POST means add a
>> message to the container and can at your option affect an index.
>> Messages are stored in the container  a la SMTP.  Note, nothing
>> constrains the server from providing an index in response to a GET with
>> a an "Accept: text/x-yannick-index", but that is really beside the point.

> want to support is POST of a message and the only successful response is
> 202?  Once posted, there is no way to GET, PUT, DELETE, etc the message
> (via that URI, anyhow).  It seems to me you would have to define the
> container with restrictions or define a entirely new model ("drop box"?).
> But then what if the next time, you need something similar that provides

> case, the "client" (likely a remote server) may only POST an xml-based RNA

> similar response entity, possibly adding or setting elements; otherwise,
> it will reject the request appropriately."  In the case of the Inbox URI,

> it will return a 202 (no response entity);  otherwise, it will reject the
> request appropriately."  The Identity and Inbox URI have different

> 4xx responses. Now, as it happens to be that the Identity URI is highly
> visible, it also defines the use of the GET method, which has absolutely
> no rules on how it is implemented (beyond the semantics of a GET).  This

> Identity URI, returned in the response entity?  What if RNA were rewritten

> mean in context to the request such that it may correct its problem and
> try again?

> If you know how to model all of this in a clear, simple manner that
> doesn't tie RNA's hands in any way, I'm all for it.  But what I feel you
> are proposing is either too limiting or is too complicated.  Heck, I've
> got the entire English language to write the spec with and I'm *still*
> not entirely comfortable with the wording.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3896
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 00:17:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

--On Tuesday, August 12, 2003 9:23 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@free.fr> wrote:
> Here, you're defining a generic behaviour for a container "super-type".

No I am saying that HTTP imposes strict requirements on how you interact 
with a container.  See the definition of POST in rfc2616.  See my last 
reply to Roy.

> If this is all of Most, I'm ok with it.
> If I well understood, MoST is nothing more a set of
> rules/design-behaviour pattern/generic types/semantic ... call it how
> ever you like, build on top of Rest, just as RDF or web calculous can be
> considered too. If this is the case, there is no debate at all!

MoST is REQUIRED by HTTP (RFC2616).  RDF and the web calculus are 
permitted.  ReST may be *incompatible* with HTTP (it is hard to tell).

> These are application level specificities, while Rest is
> communication/interaction level.

MoST addresses the same level as ReST.

> You can define a common way to express
> rules and restrictions of your application, as you can define a generic
> container "super-type", with the corresponding behaviours, but I thing
> that is out of the scope of ReST...

HTTP completely specifies the meaning of HTTP methods with respect to HTTP 
resources.  If you are defining different meanings for these methods you 
are violating HTTP.  MoST is just the observation that HTTP is good. 
Neither MoST nor HTTP says anything about the behavior of agents that 
interact with those resources.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

Post ID:3897
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 07:23:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Le mer 13/08/2003  02:17, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> --On Tuesday, August 12, 2003 9:23 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
> > Here, you're defining a generic behaviour for a container "super-type".
> 
> No I am saying that HTTP imposes strict requirements on how you interact 
> with a container.  See the definition of POST in rfc2616.  

"""
The actual function performed by the POST method is determined by the
server and is usually dependent on the Request-URI. The posted entity
is subordinate to that URI in the same way that a file is subordinate
to a directory containing it, a news article is subordinate to a
newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is subordinate to a
database.
"""

I don't see where this imply MoST... your proposed is based on Mime, not
HTTP, to imply how to interact with the resource...


> > These are application level specificities, while Rest is
> > communication/interaction level.
> 
> MoST addresses the same level as ReST.
> 
> > You can define a common way to express
> > rules and restrictions of your application, as you can define a generic
> > container "super-type", with the corresponding behaviours, but I thing
> > that is out of the scope of ReST...

> interact with those resources.

Post ID:3898
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 07:54:02
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Alex Jacobson wrote:

> > The wording in HTTP is "subordinate resource". Why can't a message
> > resource be "subordinate" to an index resource?
>
> Nothing about an index implies subordination of indexed resources. You
can
> PUT a message somewhere else and then updating the index. You can add
an
> entry to the index for a URL that does not currently resolve. In
contrast,
> the only way to add a message to a container is... to add a message to
a
> container, making the message subordinate to the container. Indexes
don't
> imply subordination. Containership does.

Okay, you're using "container" as distinct from, say, "collection" in
WebDAV.

> > That's how directories work, right?  If I GET a directory, I expect
a
> > hyperlinked list of its contents, not all the contents together in
an
> > archive.
>
> Since HTTP URLs are hierarchical, an enumeration of all subordinate
URLs
> is sufficient to communicate "whatever information" the directory URI
> designates.
>
> Notably, because indexes don't themselves imply subordination of
indexed
> resources, you can't take an index to imply that you add a file to a
> directory by POSTing to it. To get an entry to appear in the index,
you
> must put a corresponding file in the directory.
>
> So you can view my objection to POSTing to Yannicks message indexes as
> equivalent to objecting to POSTing to directory URLs. The semantics
just
> aren't there to do it.

HTTP still leaves POST pretty open. As Yannick just quoted, RFC 2616
says,
"The posted entity is subordinate to that URI in the same way that *a
file
is subordinate to a directory containing it*, a news article is
subordinate
to a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is subordinate to a
database" (emphasis mine). But you're right that I wouldn't think of
POSTing
a file to a directory.

Justin S.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3899
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 04:54:40
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>

> MoST is just about taking HTTP seriously.  If the resource does not allow
a
> particular method, give an error.

But if a client only knows a given resource is a "container", it won't know
that a given method is not allowed until the method is actually tried.  I
certainly wouldn't want to design a client with expectations that are not
necessarily true.

> Re RNA (<http://www.seairth.com/web/rna/>):
>
> > The interface is split into two URI types:  Identity and Inbox.
>
> Bad premise.  HTTP URIs designate RESOURCES that have *content-types*.
> URIs themselves do not have types.  This bad URL-type premise means you
> start by defining a special content-type for POST rather than a
> content-type for an inbox.  Having no inbox type means having no standard
> way to check your mail.  To me, this seems like a major failure in a
> "notification" protocol.  Your spec then becomes documentation of various
> interaction protocols that I find lengthy, arbitrary, and hard to follow
> (sorry).

Fair enough.  I know the spec needs some work.  From the comments you make
below, I feel you do not understand what RNA is (which I am willing to admit
may entirely have to do with the documentation).  A few thing I would like
to point out before continuing is that RNA is *not* a mail protocol and
"Inbox" does *not* mean a mail inbox.  Viewing RNA in this manner would
definitely cause the misunderstanding you seem to have.

Having said that, let's try another approach.  It may even be that this is
the sort of modeling you are talking about.  I'm making this up as I go, so
bear with me...

1. resources: Identity, Inbox
2. content-types: application/x.rna.agreement+xml,
application/x.rna.notification+xml
3. map(Identity): POST application/x.rna.agreement+xml =>
200(application/x.rna.agreement+xml), GET => (200(*/*), 302())
4. map(Inbox): POST application/x.rna.notification+xml => 202()


Here is how the above rules are read:

1. Two resources are involved: an Identity resource and an Inbox resource.
In order to write a client, the programmer will have to understand what
these resources are.  This understanding comes from documentation that
describes them.

2. Two content-types are involved: application/x.rna.agreement+xml and
application/x.rna.notification+xml [1].  As with the resources, the
programmer must understand the content-types to write the client.  Here,
however, it would at least be possible to plug in existing code (written by
another programmer).

3. An Identity resource allows two methods: POST and GET.  For POST, the
request entity's content-type must be application/x.rna.agreement+xml.  The
possible response [2] to a POST is 200, where the only returnable
content-type is also application/x.rna.agreement+xml.  For GET, the possible
responses can be 200, where the returnable content-type can be anything, and
302, where no response entity is given.

4. An Inbox resource allows one method: POST.  For POST, the request
entity's content-type must be application/x.rna.notification+xml.  The
possible response to a POST is 202, where no response entity is given.

Notes:
[1] Currently, the RNA spec only has one content-type:
application/x.rna+xml.  However, the above process has made me realize that
I really had two different content types that need to be defined.  On the
other hand, I suppose I could also just use application/xml with XML
Namespaces to differentiate the two document types internally.  That doesn't
really seem like a good approach, but I have to admit I am a bit gun shy
when it comes to XMLNS.
[2] 4xx and 5xx responses are alway implicitly supported, but can be
explicitly named above if special criteria need to be given (such as a
specific returnable content-type).


Now, as I said above, it is still up to the programmer to understand what
the resources and the content-types mean.  The above rules don't come
anywhere close to explaining what RNA actually is.  But I have to admit that
they do make it much easier to see how the pieces fit together, even if you
don't understand what the pieces are.  I think I will try to draft a rework
of the RNA documentation in this manner and see if it makes things easier to
understand and implement.  However, for the moment, I will give a quick
synopsis of each of those bits:

Identity Resource
This resource represents a user's (person, program, machine, etc.) identity.
Currently, it has only two functions:  negotiate RNA Agreement documents
(content-type of application/x.rna.agreement+xml), and to return something
(such as an html document) what queried. Upon successful negotiation of an
RNA Agreement document, the client has either been given access to an Inbox
Resource, or has been given validation of the current RNA Agreement.

Inbox Resource
This resource represents an endpoint that collects notifications.
Currently, it has only one function: accept RNA Notification documents
(content-type of application/x.rna.notification+xml).

application/x.rna.agreement+xml content-type
This content-type is an xml-based document used for negotiating access to
Inbox Resources.  This content-type has a set of rules governing what is
valid based on whether the document is being sent (as request entity) or
returned (as response entity).

application/x.rna.notification+xml content-type
This content-type is an xml-based document used to notify someone (or
something) about another resource.  This content-type has a limited set of
rules and format that must be conformed to.


Additional Note(s):  The RNA specification does not define any method for a
user to retrieve notifications sent to him.  It also does not define any
other configuration, validation, etc criteria.  RNA only defines the
"public" server interface.  It is expected that servers will act as clients
when using RNA between each other (as opposed to having a dedicated client
program).  I am currently working on a set of "private" server interfaces
that allows a user to view received notifications, define agreement
negotiation criteria, send notifications, etc.  This specification is being
kept separate from RNA on purpose.  This allows other to define their own
specifications for dealing with the back-end stuff as is appropriate for
their own uses of RNA.  For instance, one such set of interfaces may be used
to implement a mail-like usage of RNA.  Another such set of interfaces may
be used to implement a peer file-sharing network.  Yet another may be used
to implement an "instant messaging" function.


So, there we are... does this clear anything up about RNA?  Also, does any
of the above stuff look like what you want to do with MoST?  Well, until
tomorrow...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3900
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 13:36:23
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Hi all,

Alex's explanation of subordination and containment below
heightens for me the need for distinction between resource and
representation in the web lexicon.

Alex gives two examples.  In one, you POST an entry to an
index, which updates the index without necessarily changing the
resource which it indexes.  In the other, you POST a message
to a container, making the message subordinate to (and contained
within) the container.

If the index above indexes the container above, it is likely that
that latter operation affects both resources (the index and the
container), as evidenced by later GETs.

The problem here is an ambiguity between a representation of
the container and the index resource itself.  Let me clarify.  If there
was only one URI in the system and it identified the container
and you did a GET on it, it might be reasonable to call the served-
up representation an "index" or "directory" of the container.

Still assuming only that one URI, there is no defined operation
for POSTing to the index, because the index is a representation,
not a resource.  So although the resource is represented as an index,
you would still be POSTing to a container.

You can identify a resource which behaves as an index for the
designated container, and you could allow it to proxy for the
container, handling POSTS as if it were the container itself, if you
want to.  This would be legal HTTP, because HTTP also allows
resources to simply act as data processors, unconstrained by
notions of subordination, annotation and extension.

But I think I've drifted off the subject.  The main point is not to
confuse the container resource's representation (an index) with
some other resource (an index) which may not be implemented,
or which may be implemented with a semantics other than the
proxy one I mentioned above.

-Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, August 13, 2003 3:54 AM
Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging


> Alex Jacobson wrote:
>
> > > The wording in HTTP is "subordinate resource". Why can't a message
> > > resource be "subordinate" to an index resource?
> >
> > Nothing about an index implies subordination of indexed resources. You
> can
> > PUT a message somewhere else and then updating the index. You can add
> an
> > entry to the index for a URL that does not currently resolve. In
> contrast,
> > the only way to add a message to a container is... to add a message to
> a
> > container, making the message subordinate to the container. Indexes
> don't
> > imply subordination. Containership does.
>
> Okay, you're using "container" as distinct from, say, "collection" in
> WebDAV.
>
> > > That's how directories work, right?  If I GET a directory, I expect
> a
> > > hyperlinked list of its contents, not all the contents together in
> an
> > > archive.
> >
> > Since HTTP URLs are hierarchical, an enumeration of all subordinate
> URLs
> > is sufficient to communicate "whatever information" the directory URI
> > designates.
> >
> > Notably, because indexes don't themselves imply subordination of
> indexed
> > resources, you can't take an index to imply that you add a file to a
> > directory by POSTing to it. To get an entry to appear in the index,
> you
> > must put a corresponding file in the directory.
> >
> > So you can view my objection to POSTing to Yannicks message indexes as
> > equivalent to objecting to POSTing to directory URLs. The semantics
> just
> > aren't there to do it.
>
> HTTP still leaves POST pretty open. As Yannick just quoted, RFC 2616
> says,
> "The posted entity is subordinate to that URI in the same way that *a
> file
> is subordinate to a directory containing it*, a news article is
> subordinate
> to a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is subordinate to a
> database" (emphasis mine). But you're right that I wouldn't think of
> POSTing
> a file to a directory.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3901
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 15:48:56
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

>> MoST is just about taking HTTP seriously.  If the resource does not 
allow a
>> particular method, give an error.
>
> But if a client only knows a given resource is a "container", it won't
> know that a given method is not allowed until the method is actually
> tried. I certainly wouldn't want to design a client with expectations
> that are not necessarily true.

Nothing about ReST or MoST or HTTP prevents a server from requiring valid 
authentication tokens in GET request.  You can discover that authentication 
is required simply by receiving a 401.  More generally, why have all of 
these status codes if the client should simply know not to violate the 
constraints they describe from some out-of-band documentation.

What is at issue here is how much you can discover WITHOUT out-of-band 
documentation of the particular resource.  Per resource documentation means 
you no longer have a generic/visible/transparent API.

MoST says that HTTP provides enough constraints so that the only 
out-of-band documentation needed is the content-type definitions.

A useful rule:
If you would be better off defining a new HTTP method than using an 
existing one, you are not really using HTTP.  You would be better off using 
a new HTTP method if it is the only way to tell whether or not your 
resource has the functionality you are prescribing.  In other words, a 
resource that doesn't implement your method returns a 501 NOT IMPLEMENTED 
status.

> RNA is *not* a mail
> protocol and "Inbox" does *not* mean a mail inbox.  Viewing RNA in this
> manner would definitely cause the misunderstanding you seem to have.

OK, what is the purpose of RNA?

> Having said that, let's try another approach.  It may even be that this is
> the sort of modeling you are talking about.  I'm making this up as I go,
> so bear with me...
>
> 1. resources: Identity, Inbox
> 2. content-types: application/x.rna.agreement+xml,
> application/x.rna.notification+xml
> 3. map(Identity): POST application/x.rna.agreement+xml =>
> 200(application/x.rna.agreement+xml), GET => (200(*/*), 302())
> 4. map(Inbox): POST application/x.rna.notification+xml => 202()

Nope.  You still don't have a content-type for identity or inbox.

> 1. Two resources are involved: an Identity resource and an Inbox resource.
> In order to write a client, the programmer will have to understand what
> these resources are.  This understanding comes from documentation that
> describes them.

But since you don't provide content-type for the resources, the programmer 
has no way to understand what they are.

Instead you are providing documentation that describes how they respond to 
various HTTP method names.  The programmer still has no idea what they 
*are*.

What they *are* constrains how they interact via HTTP.  Defining a custom 
interface via HTTP is defining a custom interface and loses all the 
advantages of genericity/visibility/transparency etc.  It is NOT 
discoverable.
Given the arbitrariness of your interface, why not define a new HTTP method?

> 2. Two content-types are involved: application/x.rna.agreement+xml and
> application/x.rna.notification+xml [1].  As with the resources, the
> programmer must understand the content-types to write the client.  Here,
> however, it would at least be possible to plug in existing code (written
> by another programmer).

NOTHING motivates these content-types unless you specify the content-type 
of the resource itself.  They are completely arbitrary.  Why not just 
define a new HTTP method that requires these content-types?  Then, at 
least, you would know whether the resource supports it.

> 3. An Identity resource allows two methods: POST and GET.  For POST, the
> request entity's content-type must be application/x.rna.agreement+xml.
> The possible response [2] to a POST is 200, where the only returnable
> content-type is also application/x.rna.agreement+xml.  For GET, the
> possible responses can be 200, where the returnable content-type can be
> anything, and 302, where no response entity is given.

If the returned content-type is undefined, you are violating HTTP and 
describing NOTHING.

> 4. An Inbox resource allows one method: POST.  For POST, the request
> entity's content-type must be application/x.rna.notification+xml.  The
> possible response to a POST is 202, where no response entity is given.

202 implies ABSOLUTELY NOTHING about the behavior of the system.  You are 
describing entirely arbitrary interfaces.  Why not define a new method?

A resource that accepts POSTs of ANY content-type and returns random 
content in response to a GET implements RNA.  What is the point?
At least if you created a new method, the fact that RNA is supported would 
be visible.

> Notes:
> [1] Currently, the RNA spec only has one content-type:
> application/x.rna+xml.  However, the above process has made me realize
> that I really had two different content types that need to be defined.
> On the other hand, I suppose I could also just use application/xml with
> XML Namespaces to differentiate the two document types internally.  That
> doesn't really seem like a good approach, but I have to admit I am a bit
> gun shy when it comes to XMLNS.

It really helps HTTP to pass as specific a content-type as possible in the 
header.  Use the text/xml+format convention if you can.

> [2] 4xx and 5xx responses are alway implicitly supported, but can be
> explicitly named above if special criteria need to be given (such as a
> specific returnable content-type).

Your spec says that an RNA inbox accepts any POST of the content-type you 
specify.  Stuff that is not that content-type is not covered by your spec.
Again, your spec defines ABSOLUTELY NO visible behavior by an HTTP server.

> Identity Resource
> This resource represents a user's (person, program, machine, etc.)
> identity. Currently, it has only two functions:  negotiate RNA Agreement
> documents (content-type of application/x.rna.agreement+xml), and to
> return something (such as an html document) what queried. Upon successful
> negotiation of an RNA Agreement document, the client has either been
> given access to an Inbox Resource, or has been given validation of the
> current RNA Agreement.

If resources have "functions" you are implementing a custom interface.  Why 
not give these functions explicit method names?

> Inbox Resource
> This resource represents an endpoint that collects notifications.
> Currently, it has only one function: accept RNA Notification documents
> (content-type of application/x.rna.notification+xml).

See above re functions.

> Additional Note(s):  The RNA specification does not define any method for
> a user to retrieve notifications sent to him.  It also does not define any
> other configuration, validation, etc criteria.  RNA only defines the
> "public" server interface.

Fine.  Why not define custom method names for this interface so at least 
the client can know that the server actually claims to implement this 
interface?

> It is expected that servers will act as
> clients when using RNA between each other (as opposed to having a
> dedicated client program).  I am currently working on a set of "private"
> server interfaces that allows a user to view received notifications,
> define agreement negotiation criteria, send notifications, etc.  This
> specification is being kept separate from RNA on purpose.  This allows
> other to define their own specifications for dealing with the back-end
> stuff as is appropriate for their own uses of RNA.  For instance, one
> such set of interfaces may be used to implement a mail-like usage of RNA.
> Another such set of interfaces may be used to implement a peer
> file-sharing network.  Yet another may be used to implement an "instant
> messaging" function.

If you want to define customer interfaces, that is fine.  Its just not 
using HTTP.  Why not use IDL?

-Alex-
___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3902
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 16:08:10
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Yes, but that comes after:
"""
The POST method is used to request that the origin server accept the entity 
enclosed in the request as a new subordinate of the resource   identified 
by the Request-URI in the Request-Line.
"""

So the actual function performed by the POST method is determined by the 
RESOURCE identified by they URI (not the URI itself).  Subordination only 
has meaning based on the content-type of that resource.

The paragraph you quote also adds the constraint that the URI returned in 
the Location header in a 201 also must be subordinate in URI space to the 
POSTed URI.  Obviously the server has to figure out how best to implement 
this subordination.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

--On Wednesday, August 13, 2003 9:23 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@...> wrote:

> Le mer 13/08/2003  02:17, Alex Jacobson a crit :
>> --On Tuesday, August 12, 2003 9:23 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau
>> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
>> > Here, you're defining a generic behaviour for a container "super-type".
>>
>> No I am saying that HTTP imposes strict requirements on how you interact
>> with a container.  See the definition of POST in rfc2616.
>
> """
> The actual function performed by the POST method is determined by the
> server and is usually dependent on the Request-URI. The posted entity
> is subordinate to that URI in the same way that a file is subordinate
> to a directory containing it, a news article is subordinate to a
> newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is subordinate to a
> database.
> """
>
> I don't see where this imply MoST... your proposed is based on Mime, not
> HTTP, to imply how to interact with the resource...
>
>
>> > These are application level specificities, while Rest is
>> > communication/interaction level.
>>
>> MoST addresses the same level as ReST.
>>
>> > You can define a common way to express
>> > rules and restrictions of your application, as you can define a generic
>> > container "super-type", with the corresponding behaviours, but I thing
>> > that is out of the scope of ReST...
>>
>> HTTP completely specifies the meaning of HTTP methods with respect to
>> HTTP  resources.  If you are defining different meanings for these
>> methods you  are violating HTTP.  MoST is just the observation that HTTP
>> is good.  Neither MoST nor HTTP says anything about the behavior of
>> agents that  interact with those resources.
>>
>> -Alex-
>>
>> ___________________________________________________________________
>> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
>> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
>>
>> > Le lun 11/08/2003  20:07, Alex Jacobson a crit :
>> >> --On Saturday, August 09, 2003 11:08 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau
>> >> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
>> >> >> So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you
>> >> >> would have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.
>> >> >
>> >> > Ok, so give an example.. I have to admit that i don't really
>> >> > understand. You have to define a format that is suitable for any
>> >> > kind of application. This look quite ambitious. You can use RDF to
>> >> > help the representation to be self descriptive, but you still have
>> >> > to define (ou refine) and RDFS. From an other pov, your proposal
>> >> > looks like wsdl (as Bill? said).
>> >>
>> >> See my comments on taking HTTP seriously in the other thread.
>> >> Earlier, you defined an inbox index format.  I am saying that is
>> >> enough to  define your entire application from the client's
>> >> perspective.
>> >>
>> >> If the server returns an index in response to a GET without an Accept
>> >> header, the resource is an index and NOT a container.  That means the
>> >> semantics of POST  should be with respect to that index and not a
>> >> container.  In other words, if the resource IS an index, then POST
>> >> means add an entry to the index and NOT add a message to a container;
>> >> messages must be stored somewhere else a la DJ Bernstein.
>> >>
>> >> If the server returns a container in response to a GET without an
>> >> Accept header, the resource is a container and not an index.  That
>> >> means the semantics of POST should be with respect to the container
>> >> and not an index.  In other words, if the resource is a container,
>> >> then POST means add a  message to the container and can at your
>> >> option affect an index. Messages  are stored in the container  a la
>> >> SMTP.  Note, nothing constrains the  server from providing an index
>> >> in response to a GET with a an "Accept:  text/x-yannick-index", but
>> >> that is really beside the point.
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >

>> > rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

Post ID:3903
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 17:39:41
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
> > RNA is *not* a mail
> > protocol and "Inbox" does *not* mean a mail inbox.  Viewing RNA in this
> > manner would definitely cause the misunderstanding you seem to have.
>
> OK, what is the purpose of RNA?

Its nothing more than a way for one party to notify another party of a
resource.

> > Having said that, let's try another approach.  It may even be that this
is
> > the sort of modeling you are talking about.  I'm making this up as I go,
> > so bear with me...
> >
> > 1. resources: Identity, Inbox
> > 2. content-types: application/x.rna.agreement+xml,
> > application/x.rna.notification+xml
> > 3. map(Identity): POST application/x.rna.agreement+xml =>
> > 200(application/x.rna.agreement+xml), GET => (200(*/*), 302())
> > 4. map(Inbox): POST application/x.rna.notification+xml => 202()
>
> Nope.  You still don't have a content-type for identity or inbox.

What are you talking about?  Resources dont have content-types!  Only the
representations of them do.  For instance, suppose you have a resource that
is an image of me.  Either through conneg or through different URIs, a GET
may return a jpg, gif, png, svg, bmp, wmf, pdf, mix, pcx, or even ascii art.
Each of those representations have a content-type.  The resource itself is
not any one of those content-types and should not be expressed as such.  It
*may* be that the actual bits on the server are stored as svg (and converted
for all other content-type representations), but that doesn't mean that a
client should think of the resource as being an svg resource.  That is an
implementation detail that has nothing to do with the client-server
relationship. Likewise, neither the Identity or Inbox resources should have
a content-type.

> > 1. Two resources are involved: an Identity resource and an Inbox
resource.
> > In order to write a client, the programmer will have to understand what
> > these resources are.  This understanding comes from documentation that
> > describes them.
>
> But since you don't provide content-type for the resources, the programmer
> has no way to understand what they are.
>
> Instead you are providing documentation that describes how they respond to
> various HTTP method names.  The programmer still has no idea what they
> *are*.
>
> What they *are* constrains how they interact via HTTP.  Defining a custom
> interface via HTTP is defining a custom interface and loses all the
> advantages of genericity/visibility/transparency etc.  It is NOT
> discoverable.
> Given the arbitrariness of your interface, why not define a new HTTP
method?

All that needs knowing is what the resource does with the associated
content-type (3 and 4 above).  Beyond that, the client shouldn't care what
the resource is.

> > 2. Two content-types are involved: application/x.rna.agreement+xml and
> > application/x.rna.notification+xml [1].  As with the resources, the
> > programmer must understand the content-types to write the client.  Here,
> > however, it would at least be possible to plug in existing code (written
> > by another programmer).
>
> NOTHING motivates these content-types unless you specify the content-type
> of the resource itself.  They are completely arbitrary.  Why not just
> define a new HTTP method that requires these content-types?  Then, at
> least, you would know whether the resource supports it.

Huh?

> > 3. An Identity resource allows two methods: POST and GET.  For POST, the
> > request entity's content-type must be application/x.rna.agreement+xml.
> > The possible response [2] to a POST is 200, where the only returnable
> > content-type is also application/x.rna.agreement+xml.  For GET, the
> > possible responses can be 200, where the returnable content-type can be
> > anything, and 302, where no response entity is given.
>
> If the returned content-type is undefined, you are violating HTTP and
> describing NOTHING.

If you are talking about the bit concerning GET and the 200 response, I am
not saying it's undefined.  I am saying its the set of all possible
content-types.  But let's not get hung up on this detail.  It is only there
because most humans want to plug URIs into web browsers with the expectation
of getting something back.  Unlike URIs pointing to Inbox resource, URIs
pointing to Identity resources are highly visible.  Now, as we discuss this,
I do think this function is outside the scope of RNA, esp. given the
rewording in my prior post.  As I said, though, let's not get stuck on this
minor point.  It isn't central to RNA.

> > 4. An Inbox resource allows one method: POST.  For POST, the request
> > entity's content-type must be application/x.rna.notification+xml.  The
> > possible response to a POST is 202, where no response entity is given.
>
> 202 implies ABSOLUTELY NOTHING about the behavior of the system.  You are
> describing entirely arbitrary interfaces.  Why not define a new method?

Would you like 204 instead?  To me, 202 means "the request was valid and
there is nothing more to say".  If you know what
application/x.rna.notification+xml is and what its relationship to an Inbox
resource is, then I think it means all that it needs to mean.

> A resource that accepts POSTs of ANY content-type and returns random
> content in response to a GET implements RNA.  What is the point?
> At least if you created a new method, the fact that RNA is supported would
> be visible.

What?  Where did this come from?

> > Notes:
> > [2] 4xx and 5xx responses are alway implicitly supported, but can be
> > explicitly named above if special criteria need to be given (such as a
> > specific returnable content-type).
>
> Your spec says that an RNA inbox accepts any POST of the content-type you
> specify.  Stuff that is not that content-type is not covered by your spec.
> Again, your spec defines ABSOLUTELY NO visible behavior by an HTTP server.

Sorry, you've lost me here as well.  What do you mean by that last sentance?

> > Identity Resource
> > This resource represents a user's (person, program, machine, etc.)
> > identity. Currently, it has only two functions:  negotiate RNA Agreement
> > documents (content-type of application/x.rna.agreement+xml), and to
> > return something (such as an html document) what queried. Upon
successful
> > negotiation of an RNA Agreement document, the client has either been
> > given access to an Inbox Resource, or has been given validation of the
> > current RNA Agreement.
>
> If resources have "functions" you are implementing a custom interface.
Why
> not give these functions explicit method names?

Because POST is sufficient.  I don't see that creating a new method would be
any more helpful.

> > It is expected that servers will act as
> > clients when using RNA between each other (as opposed to having a
> > dedicated client program).  I am currently working on a set of "private"
> > server interfaces that allows a user to view received notifications,
> > define agreement negotiation criteria, send notifications, etc.  This
> > specification is being kept separate from RNA on purpose.  This allows
> > other to define their own specifications for dealing with the back-end
> > stuff as is appropriate for their own uses of RNA.  For instance, one
> > such set of interfaces may be used to implement a mail-like usage of
RNA.
> > Another such set of interfaces may be used to implement a peer
> > file-sharing network.  Yet another may be used to implement an "instant
> > messaging" function.
>
> If you want to define customer interfaces, that is fine.  Its just not
> using HTTP.  Why not use IDL?

I only mentioned this to make clear that this was not part of the RNA
specification. As with that bit above, let's not dwell on this, as it
doesn't directly have to do with the RNA specification and this
conversation.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3904
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 19:11:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

--On Wednesday, August 13, 2003 1:39 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:
>> OK, what is the purpose of RNA?
>
> Its nothing more than a way for one party to notify another party of a
> resource.

How is that functionally different from a mail system that requires RFC2017 
URL external body content-types? In other words a mail system in which the 
body of the message is access via URL rather than included in the message 
itself.

Since my one line spec does exactly that.  Why do I need all the RNA docs?

>> Nope.  You still don't have a content-type for identity or inbox.
>
> What are you talking about?  Resources dont have content-types!  Only the
> representations of them do.

That is the subject of the current debate.  My claim is that POST requires 
that resources MUST have content-types and that those resource 
content-types MUST be exposed whenever a client make a GET requests without 
an Accept header.

How the server stores the resource is irrelevant.  The server must BEHAVE 
as if the content-type is whatever it says in response to a raw GET.

Did you read my last reply to Roy?  Have you read the actual text of 
RFC2616?

> For instance, suppose you have a resource that is an image of me.

What does it mean for the resource to be an image of you?  You have a 
resource that is an image.  RFC2616 requires that the server behave as if 
the image is stored in whatever content-type it declares in response to a 
GET or HEAD request.

> Either through conneg or through different URIs,
> a GET may return a jpg, gif, png, svg, bmp, wmf, pdf, mix, pcx, or even
> ascii art. Each of those representations have a content-type.  The
> resource itself is not any one of those content-types and should not be
> expressed as such.  It *may* be that the actual bits on the server are
> stored as svg (and converted for all other content-type representations),
> but that doesn't mean that a client should think of the resource as being
> an svg resource.

You are confusing conneg with raw GET.  The client *should* think of the 
resource as being a text/xml+svg resource IF that is the content-type the 
server supplies in response to a GET without an Accept header.

> That is an implementation detail that has nothing to do
> with the client-server relationship. Likewise, neither the Identity or
> Inbox resources should have a content-type.

If they don't have a content-type, it is not really meaningfully to talk 
about POSTing to it because without a content-type you lack a notion of 
subordinate resources.

In what way is a notification subordnate to an Inbox or an Agreement 
subordinate to an Identity?  How can a client know that?

>> What they *are* constrains how they interact via HTTP.  Defining a custom
>> interface via HTTP is defining a custom interface and loses all the
>> advantages of genericity/visibility/transparency etc.  It is NOT
>> discoverable.
>> Given the arbitrariness of your interface, why not define a new HTTP
> method?
>
> All that needs knowing is what the resource does with the associated
> content-type (3 and 4 above).  Beyond that, the client shouldn't care what
> the resource is.

How does the client know the content-type it is supposed to POST?  If you 
are restricting POST to an entirely arbitrary content-type and the effect 
of that POST is entirely invisible to the client and the notion of 
"subordinate resource" has no meaning, in what sense are you implementing 
HTTP POST.  You are defining a new method and should choose another name? 
At very least, if you did, the client would know whether the server is 
actually implementing RNA or just accepting POSTs of *any* random 
content-type.  The client would know this based on the NOT IMPLEMENTED 
status code.  Your protocol provides the client NO WAY to know what the 
server is actually doing (whether the resource actually even intends to 
implement an RNA interface).

>> If the returned content-type is undefined, you are violating HTTP and
>> describing NOTHING.
>
> As I said, though, let's not
> get stuck on this minor point.  It isn't central to RNA.

The content-type of a resource is essential to HTTP.  Otherwise PUT, POST, 
and GET have no meaning.

>> 202 implies ABSOLUTELY NOTHING about the behavior of the system.  You are
>> describing entirely arbitrary interfaces.  Why not define a new method?
>
> Would you like 204 instead?  To me, 202 means "the request was valid and
> there is nothing more to say".  If you know what
> application/x.rna.notification+xml is and what its relationship to an
> Inbox resource is, then I think it means all that it needs to mean.

Unless Inbox has a content-type, I have NO way to know what its 
relationship is to ANYTHING.  All I know is that it accepts your 
content-type via a method you call POST (but that isn't the POST described 
by the HTTP spec).  Why not use another method name?  It would be less 
confusing.

>> > Notes:
>> > [2] 4xx and 5xx responses are always implicitly supported, but can be
>> > explicitly named above if special criteria need to be given (such as a
>> > specific returnable content-type).
>>
>> Your spec says that an RNA inbox accepts any POST of the content-type you
>> specify.  Stuff that is not that content-type is not covered by your
>> spec. Again, your spec defines ABSOLUTELY NO visible behavior by an HTTP
>> server.
>
> Sorry, you've lost me here as well.  What do you mean by that last
> sentence?

Are you defining the behavior of the URI with respect to all possible 
POSTed content-types or only with respect to the content-types you define? 
If the former, you can't talk about 4xx or 5xx codes.  If the later, you 
are moving even further away from HTTP and are really just defining a new 
HTTP method.

>> > Identity Resource
>> > This resource represents a user's (person, program, machine, etc.)
>> > identity. Currently, it has only two functions:  negotiate RNA
>> > Agreement documents (content-type of application/x.rna.agreement+xml),
>> > and to return something (such as an html document) what queried.

>> If resources have "functions" you are implementing a custom interface. 
Why
>> not give these functions explicit method names?
>
> Because POST is sufficient.  I don't see that creating a new method would
> be any more helpful.

You are *already* creating a new method, the only question is whether you 
can or should call it POST.  Since the HTTP spec reserves the POST method 
name, to comply with HTTP, you must choose another name.

-Alex-

S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
