Post ID:3905
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 20:54:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

> From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>

> > If you want to define customer interfaces, that is fine.  Its just not
> > using HTTP.  Why not use IDL?

Just to note that IDL is just a Interface Definition Language, while
HTTP is a protocol... IDL is similar to WSDL, used e.g. by corba or rpc
(which is probably what you mean)





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3906
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 20:58:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> --On Wednesday, August 13, 2003 1:39 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs
> <seairth@...> wrote:
> >> OK, what is the purpose of RNA?
> >
> > Its nothing more than a way for one party to notify another party of a
> > resource.
>
> How is that functionally different from a mail system that requires
RFC2017
> URL external body content-types? In other words a mail system in which the
> body of the message is access via URL rather than included in the message
> itself.
>
> Since my one line spec does exactly that.  Why do I need all the RNA docs?

Obviously, you don't.  Go on doing things the way you are.  If you want to
have a conversation of REST and MoST, that's fine.  But I'd appreciate it we
can do it without telling me that RNA is pointless.

> >> Nope.  You still don't have a content-type for identity or inbox.
> >
> > What are you talking about?  Resources dont have content-types!  Only
the
> > representations of them do.
>
> That is the subject of the current debate.  My claim is that POST requires
> that resources MUST have content-types and that those resource
> content-types MUST be exposed whenever a client make a GET requests
without
> an Accept header.

Well, this is where I disagree.

> How the server stores the resource is irrelevant.  The server must BEHAVE
> as if the content-type is whatever it says in response to a raw GET.

I do not see in the RFC where POST means anything about GET (or vice versa)
for the same resource.  Could you point it out for me?

> > For instance, suppose you have a resource that is an image of me.
>
> What does it mean for the resource to be an image of you?  You have a
> resource that is an image.  RFC2616 requires that the server behave as if
> the image is stored in whatever content-type it declares in response to a
> GET or HEAD request.

It does?  Where does it claim that?

> > Either through conneg or through different URIs,
> > a GET may return a jpg, gif, png, svg, bmp, wmf, pdf, mix, pcx, or even
> > ascii art. Each of those representations have a content-type.  The
> > resource itself is not any one of those content-types and should not be
> > expressed as such.  It *may* be that the actual bits on the server are
> > stored as svg (and converted for all other content-type
representations),
> > but that doesn't mean that a client should think of the resource as
being
> > an svg resource.
>
> You are confusing conneg with raw GET.  The client *should* think of the
> resource as being a text/xml+svg resource IF that is the content-type the
> server supplies in response to a GET without an Accept header.

If the client only knows about the text/xml+svg content-type, then that will
be its world-view of the resource regardless of what other representations
could be returned.  On the other hand, if the client knows both the
text/xml+svg and the image/gif content-types, and the resource can be
expressed as either, then I think it's foolish for the client to think that
the resource is just text/xml+svg.

> > That is an implementation detail that has nothing to do
> > with the client-server relationship. Likewise, neither the Identity or
> > Inbox resources should have a content-type.
>
> If they don't have a content-type, it is not really meaningfully to talk
> about POSTing to it because without a content-type you lack a notion of
> subordinate resources.
>
> In what way is a notification subordnate to an Inbox or an Agreement
> subordinate to an Identity?  How can a client know that?

What does this matter to the client?

> > Because POST is sufficient.  I don't see that creating a new method
would
> > be any more helpful.
>
> You are *already* creating a new method, the only question is whether you
> can or should call it POST.  Since the HTTP spec reserves the POST method
> name, to comply with HTTP, you must choose another name.

Hmm.. this seems to be the rub (or one of them, anyhow).  I think that RNA's
use of POST falls cleanly within the HTTP's intended use for POST.  You
don't.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3907
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-13 22:34:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

--On Wednesday, August 13, 2003 4:58 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:
>> Since my one line spec does exactly that.  Why do I need all the RNA
>> docs?
>
> Obviously, you don't.  Go on doing things the way you are.  If you want to
> have a conversation of REST and MoST, that's fine.  But I'd appreciate it
> we can do it without telling me that RNA is pointless.

Since this is a debate about the merits of ReST vs MoST, your ReSTful 
Notification Architecture is exhibit A.

My goal in this discussion is actually to convince you that RNA as it 
stands IS pointless.  More generally, my goal is to show all the people who 
are defining "ReSTful interfaces" that what they are doing is unnecessary. 
That they just need content-types.  All of you are smart people and my hope 
is that you will put your efforts into more valuable tasks.

If you are interested in a notification mechanism for HTTP, what I, 
personally, would really like to see is a WATCH http method.

Create a watch resource for watchedURI
C: WATCH watchedURI
C: Location: watcherURI
S: 201 CREATED
S: Location: watchURI

See what URI is doing the watching
C: GET watchURI
S: 200 OK
S:
S: watcherURI

Change it
C: PUT watchURI
C:
C: newWatcherURI
S: 200 OK

Stop watching
C: DELETE watchURI
S: 200 OK

This method creates a watchResource that replicates the current state of 
watchedURI to watcherURI.  Things that need refinement:
* what latency should the watcher expect?
* what happens if the watcherURI is unreachable?
* can the watchURI simply PUT the current state of the watchedURI rather 
than transmitting all the intermediate POSTs?
* can we use eTags to prevent loops?

The value of this HTTP method would be to decouple server functionality 
from resource management.  You could then have standalone webservers whose 
job is to maintain the integrity of resources.  Anyone else can implement 
functionality associated with a resource change independent of the actual 
web server managing the resource.


>> >> Nope.  You still don't have a content-type for identity or inbox.
>> >
>> > What are you talking about?  Resources dont have content-types!  Only
> the
>> > representations of them do.
>>
>> That is the subject of the current debate.  My claim is that POST
>> requires that resources MUST have content-types and that those resource
>> content-types MUST be exposed whenever a client make a GET requests
> without
>> an Accept header.
>
> Well, this is where I disagree.

I've given lots of reasons to believe that resources have content-types.
Care to provide a reason why you don't?

>> How the server stores the resource is irrelevant.  The server must BEHAVE
>> as if the content-type is whatever it says in response to a raw GET.
>
> I do not see in the RFC where POST means anything about GET (or vice
> versa) for the same resource.  Could you point it out for me?

I already did in my last reply to Roy.  Did you read it?
Here is the URL for your convenience:
<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/3887>

If a server accepts PUT, a subsequent GET of the resource MUST return the 
same data with the same content-type.  And again, RFC2616 says that POST 
means create a resource subordinate to resource designed by the POSTed URI. 
It make no sense to talk about subordinate resources if resource structure 
is hidden.  The way you expose resource structure in HTTP is via the 
content-type header.

Do you have an alternate interpretation of subordinate resource?

>> > For instance, suppose you have a resource that is an image of me.
>>
>> What does it mean for the resource to be an image of you?  You have a
>> resource that is an image.  RFC2616 requires that the server behave as if
>> the image is stored in whatever content-type it declares in response to a
>> GET or HEAD request.
>
> It does?  Where does it claim that?

Again, read my last reply to Roy.

>> You are confusing conneg with raw GET.  The client *should* think of the
>> resource as being a text/xml+svg resource IF that is the content-type the
>> server supplies in response to a GET without an Accept header.
>
> If the client only knows about the text/xml+svg content-type, then that
> will be its world-view of the resource regardless of what other
> representations could be returned.  On the other hand, if the client
> knows both the text/xml+svg and the image/gif content-types, and the
> resource can be expressed as either, then I think it's foolish for the
> client to think that the resource is just text/xml+svg.

Quoting myself from my last reply to Roy:
""""""
"""
The GET method means retrieve whatever information (in the form of an
entity) is identified by the Request-URI.
[...]
The Accept request-header field can be used to specify certain media types
which are acceptable for the response.
[...]
If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client
accepts all media types.
"""
[RFC2616]

So when a client sends a GET, it expects the information identified by the
resource. If "whatever information" means ALL information without data
loss, the client can reasonably interpret the response to a GET to *BE* the
server's representation. (Obviously when the client sends an Accept
header, it accepting non-fidelity to the server's actual representation,
but that is really beside the point here. GET without an Accept header
implies fidelity).
""""""

>> > That is an implementation detail that has nothing to do
>> > with the client-server relationship. Likewise, neither the Identity or
>> > Inbox resources should have a content-type.
>>
>> If they don't have a content-type, it is not really meaningfully to talk
>> about POSTing to it because without a content-type you lack a notion of
>> subordinate resources.
>>
>> In what way is a notification subordnate to an Inbox or an Agreement
>> subordinate to an Identity?  How can a client know that?
>
> What does this matter to the client?

Because otherwise the client isn't POSTing according to the definition in 
RFC2616.  It is just using another method that is also called POST (in 
violation of HTTP).

>> > Because POST is sufficient.  I don't see that creating a new method 
would
>> > be any more helpful.
>>
>> You are *already* creating a new method, the only question is whether you
>> can or should call it POST.  Since the HTTP spec reserves the POST method
>> name, to comply with HTTP, you must choose another name.
>
> Hmm.. this seems to be the rub (or one of them, anyhow).  I think that
> RNA's use of POST falls cleanly within the HTTP's intended use for POST.
> You don't.

Here, again, is the definition of POST:
"""
The POST method is used to request that the origin server accept the entity
enclosed in the request as a new subordinate of the resource identified by
the Request-URI in the Request-Line.
"""
[RFC2616]

In what sense does POSTing an RNA notification imply a request that it be 
accepted as a new subordinate of the inbox?
What does it mean for a notification to be a new subordinate of an inbox?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3908
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-14 08:41:53
Subject:[Fwd: Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging]
Message:

Le jeu 14/08/2003  00:34, Alex Jacobson a crit :

> So when a client sends a GET, it expects the information identified by the
> resource. If "whatever information" means ALL information without data
> loss, the client can reasonably interpret the response to a GET to *BE* the
> server's representation. (Obviously when the client sends an Accept
> header, it accepting non-fidelity to the server's actual representation,
> but that is really beside the point here. GET without an Accept header
> implies fidelity).
> """"""

So suppose that a messaging system can accept in a POST mime/rfc822,
xmtp,rss-rdf fragments, latex letter, etc. and stores messages in an
rbds. What is the "without data loss" server representation... the SQL
??
and if if parse all those formats to deal with message objects, having
methods and so on... what is the "without data loss" server
representation? the serialized object ?


> In what sense does POSTing an RNA notification imply a request that it be 
> accepted as a new subordinate of the inbox?
> What does it mean for a notification to be a new subordinate of an inbox?
> 

What does it mean for /you/ for a resource to be subordinate to an other
? it is not related to the uri, since they are opaque. It is not a
'index' question, since a file is subordinate to a directory (see rfc)
and when you get a directory (at least in Apache) you get an index and
not the content. Do you mean that Apache violate http ?
So what is subordination ? For me, it is just a kind of "relational
integrity" in rdbs (foreign keys, on.. cascade, trigers...) 
an message(mid,from,date,body) table is subordinate to a
box(title,id,desc) by sub(box.id,message.mid). You can select an index
(i.e. just all the ids of messages in the box) or an archive (all
messages) and to delete a box mean to delete all messages it contains.
But boxes and messages have there own namespaces (uri in the rest world)
This is how I understand subordination. (I don't mean that ressources
must be stored in an rdbs, it is just an analogy).





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3909
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-14 08:42:48
Subject:[Fwd: RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging]
Message:

Le mer 13/08/2003  04:28, Alex Jacobson a crit :

> Nothing about an index implies subordination of indexed resources.  You can 
> PUT a message somewhere else and then updating the index.  You can add an 
> entry to the index for a URL that does not currently resolve.  In contrast, 
> the only way to add a message to a container is...to add a message to a 
> container, making the message subordinate to the container.  Indexes don't 
> imply subordination.  Containership does.

What in a container representation, has you stated, imply that it is a
container is the content type. In your example, I know that I can POST a
mime/rfc822 because the inbox is message/delivery. But your doc is one
line because the documentation of these content-type has already been
done. Someone can't use your message system without reading all the mime
stuff... quite long!...
If I state somewhere that the index format used in a system IS a
container, then you can not say that nothing is imply any more, and it's
again juste one line (as long as "container" is supposed known, i.e. you
don't need to describe a container behaviour, which is not so
obvious...). That is what I mean by "super-types". a message/digest IS a
container, an RSS feed IS a container, a directory index IS a
container...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3910
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-14 15:41:32
Subject:Re: [Fwd: RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging]
Message:

> What in a container representation, has you stated, imply that it is a
> container is the content type. In your example, I know that I can POST a
> mime/rfc822 because the inbox is message/delivery. But your doc is one
> line because the documentation of these content-type has already been
> done. Someone can't use your message system without reading all the mime
> stuff... quite long!...

You need to define/select content-types *no matter what*.  My point is that 
you DON'T need to define the behavior of HTTP methods because RFC2616 
already does that.  If you are defining behavior for existing HTTP methods, 
you are probably violating the RFC.  And if you don't want to read the MIME 
RFCs, define a shorter content-type format:

===Syntax===
text/notification-container: part*
part: location? "\n" text/notification "\n"
location: URL
text/notification: (name-value-pair \s)*
name-value-pair: name ":" value "\n"
name: [^\s:]+
value: [^\n<>]*
identity: value "<" [A-z0-9]+ "@" DOMAIN-NAME ">"
==Semantics==
"Location" name identifies notified resource. requires URL value
"From" name identifies notifier, requires identity value

Hmm 12 more lines in ~5 min.  Still much less work than all of RNA.

Note: Your container syntax MUST be a container for MIME types or you can't 
POST to it.

> If I state somewhere that the index format used in a system IS a
> container, then you can not say that nothing is imply any more, and it's
> again juste one line (as long as "container" is supposed known, i.e. you
> don't need to describe a container behaviour, which is not so
> obvious...). That is what I mean by "super-types". a message/digest IS a
> container, an RSS feed IS a container, a directory index IS a
> container...

An index is, by definition, a container only of pointers and not of the 
indexed information itself.  You can *say* otherwise.  It just wouldn't be 
true.

"Back to back, they faced each other, drew their swords and shot each 
other."

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3911
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-14 21:42:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

Le jeu 14/08/2003  17:12, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> --On Thursday, August 14, 2003 9:03 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
> > So suppose that a messaging system can accept in a POST mime/rfc822,
> > xmtp,rss-rdf fragments, latex letter, etc. and stores messages in an
> > rbds. What is the "without data loss" server representation... the SQL
> > ??
> > and if if parse all those formats to deal with message objects, having
> > methods and so on... what is the "without data loss" server
> > representation? the serialized object ?
> 
> Starting from the perspective of what a resource can accept via POST is 
> incorrect.
> You must start from the perspective of what the resource *IS* then you know 
> what content-types can be made subordinate via a POST.
> 
> So my question to you is: what is this thing that you want to store your 
> various content-types?  Is there an existing content-type that describes 
> it?  If not, you need to define one so that, at least nominally.

The resource is a message, that can be represented by various
content-types, an thus the server can accept any of them, and return any
of them... 

> Once you do that, the client can do a HEAD of the URI and see that it has
> content-type: application/x-yannick-container
> 
> A google search on this content type reveals what resources types can be 
> subordinate to it.  Now you know what you can POST.
> 
> Again, how the server actually stores your container type is *irrelevant*. 
> Confusion caused by the vagueness of ReST.  All that matters is that it 
> acts as if the resource has the content-type claimed.
> 
> >> In what sense does POSTing an RNA notification imply a request that it
> >> be  accepted as a new subordinate of the inbox?
> >> What does it mean for a notification to be a new subordinate of an inbox?
> >>
> >
> > What does it mean for /you/ for a resource to be subordinate to an other
> > ? it is not related to the uri, since they are opaque. It is not a
> > 'index' question, since a file is subordinate to a directory (see rfc)
> > and when you get a directory (at least in Apache) you get an index and
> > not the content. Do you mean that Apache violate http ?
> 
> Justin asked this same question and I answered it.  Not all resources that 
> have subordinates are POSTable.  For example, since directories are not 
> POSTable, it is ok for the server to return an index of their subordinates. 
> The subordinates are identifiable as such because HTTP URIs are 
> hierarchical (not completely opaque).

http rfc2616 state that a file is subordinate to a directory ... in the
POST section!! How can you say that a directory is not postable ??

<quote page='53'>
9.5 POST

   The POST method is used to request that the origin server accept the
   entity enclosed in the request as a new subordinate of the resource
   identified by the Request-URI in the Request-Line. POST is designed
   to allow a uniform method to cover the following functions:

      - Annotation of existing resources;

      - Posting a message to a bulletin board, newsgroup, mailing list,
        or similar group of articles;

      - Providing a block of data, such as the result of submitting a
        form, to a data-handling process;

      - Extending a database through an append operation.

   The actual function performed by the POST method is determined by the
   server and is usually dependent on the Request-URI. The posted entity
   is subordinate to that URI in the same way that a file is subordinate
   to a directory containing it, a news article is subordinate to a
   newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is subordinate to a
   database.
</quote>

if my uri is http://host/messages?mid=132346132 , it's not
hierarchical... but the message is still subordinate to the box. (se
quote above), as long as a ref to that URI is present in the result of
the GET on the box uri (a external content in the header of a
mime/rfc822 in an message/digest if you want).





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3912
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-14 21:48:15
Subject:Re: [Fwd: RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging]
Message:

Le jeu 14/08/2003  17:41, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> > What in a container representation, has you stated, imply that it is a
> > container is the content type. In your example, I know that I can POST a
> > mime/rfc822 because the inbox is message/delivery. But your doc is one
> > line because the documentation of these content-type has already been
> > done. Someone can't use your message system without reading all the mime
> > stuff... quite long!...
> 
> You need to define/select content-types *no matter what*.  My point is that 
> you DON'T need to define the behavior of HTTP methods because RFC2616 
> already does that.  If you are defining behavior for existing HTTP methods, 
> you are probably violating the RFC.  And if you don't want to read the MIME 
> RFCs, define a shorter content-type format:

I don't define behaviours of HTTP methods, I define behavious of
resources

> ===Syntax===
> text/notification-container: part*
> part: location? "\n" text/notification "\n"
> location: URL
> text/notification: (name-value-pair \s)*
> name-value-pair: name ":" value "\n"
> name: [^\s:]+
> value: [^\n<>]*
> identity: value "<" [A-z0-9]+ "@" DOMAIN-NAME ">"
> ==Semantics==
> "Location" name identifies notified resource. requires URL value
> "From" name identifies notifier, requires identity value
> 
> Hmm 12 more lines in ~5 min.  Still much less work than all of RNA.
> 
> Note: Your container syntax MUST be a container for MIME types or you can't 
> POST to it.
> 
> > If I state somewhere that the index format used in a system IS a
> > container,

I mean a container representation
>  then you can not say that nothing is imply any more, and it's
> > again juste one line (as long as "container" is supposed known, i.e. you
> > don't need to describe a container behaviour, which is not so
> > obvious...). That is what I mean by "super-types". a message/digest IS a
> > container, an RSS feed IS a container, a directory index IS a
> > container...
> 
> An index is, by definition, a container only of pointers and not of the 
> indexed information itself.  You can *say* otherwise.  It just wouldn't be 
> true.
> 
> "Back to back, they faced each other, drew their swords and shot each 
> other."
> 
> -Alex-
> 
> ___________________________________________________________________
> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3913
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-15 13:33:26
Subject:The truth about POST?
Message:

There has been much discussion about how POST should or shouldn't be used.
What seems to be a major sticking point is the relationship of the request
entity to the resource.  For reference (RFC2616 9.5):

    The POST method is used to request that the origin
    server accept the entity enclosed in the request as a
    new subordinate of the resource identified by the
    Request-URI in the Request-Line."

Note that this does not say that the request entity is a "subordinate
resource".  It only says that it is "a new suboridnate of the resource".
Though some may disagree, that's a world of difference.  POST never once
claims that the request entity is a resource.  All it claims is that the
target resource can make a resource out of the request entity.  This is
evident by the variety of functions that POST can handle:

    - Annotation of existing resources;

    - Posting a message to a bulletin board, newsgroup,
      mailing list, or similar group of articles;

    - Providing a block of data, such as the result of
      submitting a form, to a data-handling process;

    - Extending a database through an append operation.

Make special note of the third example.

Now, the POST definition also says:

    The actual function performed by the POST method is
    determined by the server and is usually dependent on
    the Request-URI. The posted entity is subordinate to
    that URI in the same way that a file is subordinate to
    a directory containing it, a news article is subordinate
    to a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is
    subordinate to a database.

When trying to clarify what the definition means by "subordinate", it
focuses on easily visualizable concepts where "subordination" is already a
well-known concept.  This does *not* mean that this is an all-inclusive
clarification.  The point that I think they are trying to get across is that
the request entity is controlled by the resource, not the other way around.
A record cannot insert itself into a database, the database must insert a
record into itself.  The same can be said for file/directories and
articles/newsgroups.

The next part of the definition clearly points out that POST does not itself
treat the request entity as a resource.

    The action performed by the POST method might not
    result in a resource that can be identified by a URI. In
    this case, either 200 (OK) or 204 (No Content) is the
    appropriate response status, depending on whether or
    not the response includes an entity that describes
    the result.

 Again, it is up the the target resource to make that decision.  (Also, I
would argue that 202 (and possibly any other 2xx code)  is a valid response,
but that's a minor issue.)

And the last relevant part of the specification is:

    If a resource has been created on the origin server,
    the response SHOULD be 201 (Created) and contain
    an entity which describes the status of the request
    and refers to the new resource, and a Location header
    (see section 14.30).

Now, this part is a bit interesting.  Suppose I POST a request entity to a
resource such that the resource creates a new resource.  According to the
definition, the response entity is the "status" of the request, not a
representation of the new resource.  What this means to me is that even if
the POST operation ends with the creation a new resource, the POST itself is
still nothing more than what the third example above expresses.  In other
words, the response is still just the output of the target resource function
based on the input.


And that's it.  POST is not complicated.  It does not have all sorts of
additional semantics.  Resources that are POSTed to are not necessarily
directories, containers, indexes, etc.  They are just resources that accept
POST requests and give back a response.  That's it.  Boring, but quite
useful.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3914
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-19 16:25:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

Seairth,

POST requires that it is *meaningful* for the request-entity to be a 
subordinate of the target resource.  For example, it is meaningful to talk 
about POSTing a log-entry to a log-file because we understand that 
log-entry can be a subordinate of a logfile (even if the log-entry never 
gets its own URI).

In contrast, I'm still waiting for you to explain how an RNA notification 
is subordinate to an RNA inbox.  Is it subordinate "in the same way that a 
file is subordinate to a directory containing it, a news article is 
subordinate to a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is 
subordinate to a database?"  Unless you define what an inbox is, you can't 
really POST to it.

And, my more general point is, once you define what an inbox is, you don't 
need specifically to document POST as it is defined entirely by the 
semantics of RFC2616 and your definition of an inbox.

> Resources that are POSTed to are not necessarily
> directories, containers, indexes, etc.  They are just resources that
> accept POST requests and give back a response.  That's it.

There is no way to violate the semantics of POST under this interpretation; 
it has no meaning.  If POST means nothing in particular, why not use 
another verb name?  At very least, you could then use 501 NOT IMPLEMENTED 
to determine whether or not the resource has the behavior you expect from 
your method.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

--On Friday, August 15, 2003 9:33 AM -0400 Seairth Jacobs

> There has been much discussion about how POST should or shouldn't be used.
> What seems to be a major sticking point is the relationship of the request
> entity to the resource.  For reference (RFC2616 9.5):
>
>     The POST method is used to request that the origin
>     server accept the entity enclosed in the request as a
>     new subordinate of the resource identified by the
>     Request-URI in the Request-Line."
>

> resource".  It only says that it is "a new suboridnate of the resource".
> Though some may disagree, that's a world of difference.  POST never once
> claims that the request entity is a resource.  All it claims is that the

>     (see section 14.30).

> Now, this part is a bit interesting.  Suppose I POST a request entity to a
> resource such that the resource creates a new resource.  According to the
> definition, the response entity is the "status" of the request, not a
> representation of the new resource.  What this means to me is that even if
> the POST operation ends with the creation a new resource, the POST itself
> is still nothing more than what the third example above expresses.  In
> other words, the response is still just the output of the target resource
> function based on the input.
>
>
> And that's it.  POST is not complicated.  It does not have all sorts of
> additional semantics.  Resources that are POSTed to are not necessarily
> directories, containers, indexes, etc.  They are just resources that
> accept POST requests and give back a response.  That's it.  Boring, but
> quite useful.
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3915
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-19 23:12:06
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

Your observations seem based on your MoST architecural model.  I would like
to limit this discussion to REST.

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
>At very least, you could then use 501 NOT IMPLEMENTED
> to determine whether or not the resource has the behavior you expect from
> your method.

501 cannot be used on a resource-by-resource level.  The documentation says
the respsonse is appropriate "when the server does not recognize the request
method and is not capable of supporting it for any resource."  Note the "any
resource" part.  Instead, you should be using 405 ("method not allowed").

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3916
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-20 00:41:54
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

Alex,

It could be you're reading too much into the term 'subordinate'.  It
could be that all RFC2616 means to express is the difference between
PUT and POST.  It could be that 'subordinate' means, roughly,
'yielding control', so that the resource POSTed to remains in control
of the operation, as opposed to say, being replaced as a result of
the operation.

It could be that somewhere between POST having no meaning
and POST having a fully specified and complete and final meaning
lies the truth of POST.  According to 2616, that is.

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3917
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-20 01:52:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging
Message:

--On Thursday, August 14, 2003 11:42 PM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@...> wrote:
>> So my question to you is: what is this thing that you want to store your
>> various content-types?  Is there an existing content-type that describes
>> it?  If not, you need to define one so that, at least nominally.
>
> The resource is a message, that can be represented by various
> content-types, an thus the server can accept any of them, and return any
> of them...

The question is "to what sort of resource is your message a subordinate?"

> http rfc2616 state that a file is subordinate to a directory ... in the
> POST section!! How can you say that a directory is not postable ??

POST implies that there is an obvious meaning to a request for an entity to 
become a subordinate.  I am not sure how you POST to a directory because 
directory semantics usually require a file name to get stuff put in the 
directory.

If you are defining a directory-style resource that accepts POST and 
assigned random directory names, that's fine, but then, again, you need to 
communicate that in the content-type!

Why do you oppose requiring the user to ask for an index if the use wants 
an index?


> if my uri is http://host/messages?mid=132346132 , it's not
> hierarchical... but the message is still subordinate to the box. (se
> quote above), as long as a ref to that URI is present in the result of
> the GET on the box uri (a external content in the header of a
> mime/rfc822 in an message/digest if you want).

What is the URI of your box and when you do a raw GET, does the server 
return "whatever information" is referenced by the URI?  Does that 
information include the fact that it is meaningful for a message to be 
subordinate to your resource?
If I receive an index in response to a raw GET, how do I know whether I am 
supposed to POST notifications (a la RNA) or messages (as you seem to want)?
Does an index-type communicate that the resource is POSTable?  Directory 
indexes communicate only that the resource is a container.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3918
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-19 22:37:23
Subject:Re: [Fwd: RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging]
Message:

--On Thursday, August 14, 2003 11:48 PM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@...> wrote:
> I don't define behaviours of HTTP methods, I define behavious of
> resources

HTTP Resources don't have behaviors different from those defined by HTTP. 
If you are defining different behaviors, use different method names or 
protocols. If you are using methods defined in RFC2616, then (obviously) 
you don't need to define them yourself.

>> > If I state somewhere that the index format used in a system IS a
>> > container,
>
> I mean a container representation

"ABCDEF" is a "representation" of every-container possible because I 
declare it so.  That does not mean that it is valid HTTP to return "ABCDEF" 
in response to a raw get for a specific container.  HTTP requires that the 
server return "whatever information" is associated with the underlying 
resource.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3919
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-20 04:22:02
Subject:Re: [Fwd: RE: [rest-discuss] ReST vs MoST Messaging]
Message:

> "ABCDEF" is a "representation" of every-container possible because I
> declare it so.  That does not mean that it is valid HTTP to return
"ABCDEF"
> in response to a raw get for a specific container.  HTTP requires that the
> server return "whatever information" is associated with the underlying
> resource.

Alex, it could be you're reading too much meaning into "whatever".  I
read it to mean "whatever the implementation/authority deems fit", not
"every last bit of information possibly associated with the resource".
Isn't the latter just a bit extreme?

Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3920
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-20 17:57:42
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

I am not requiring all that much of the term subordinate.  It just has to 
have a clear meaning with respect to a POSTed request entity and a target 
resource.  Unless the client knows what it means for a request entity to be 
a subordinate of a target resource it can't make a request for the server 
to do make it so.  Either it is making a request for something else, or it 
is making a request for something random.  The only way for the client to 
know what it means for a request entity to be subordinate to a particular 
resource is for it to have a model of what the resource actually is and how 
another entity can be subordinate to that resource.

The question on the table is how the client discovers this model.

If the client discovers this model via out-of-band documentation, then 
there is really no reason to restrict the method name used to being POST. 
If we have to learn about a resource specific definition of "subordinate" 
for each resource, then we are better off proliferating method names and 
relying on 405 (thank you Seairth for the correction) to tell us what is 
going on.

Question for Seairth: Why do you insist on using POST?

If you do insist on using POST then implicitly you are saying that the 
client can acquire this model from within HTTP itself (without reference to 
custom resource APIs).  I think the only way HTTP provides for acquiring 
this model is by the client knowing the content-type of the target 
resource.

Alternative question for Seairth: If you do insist on using POST, how does 
the client know what it means?

Yet another version of this same question: Can you give an example of how a 
server could in theory return 200 and still violate the semantics of POST?

If you can't (if everything is permitted), then again why restricting 
yourself to this one method name.  Wouldn't it be better to proliferate 
method names corresponding to each service provided and use 405 to know 
what is actually available.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax


--On Tuesday, August 19, 2003 8:41 PM -0400 Walden Mathews 
<waldenm@...> wrote:

> Alex,
>
> It could be you're reading too much into the term 'subordinate'.  It
> could be that all RFC2616 means to express is the difference between
> PUT and POST.  It could be that 'subordinate' means, roughly,
> 'yielding control', so that the resource POSTed to remains in control
> of the operation, as opposed to say, being replaced as a result of
> the operation.
>
> It could be that somewhere between POST having no meaning
> and POST having a fully specified and complete and final meaning
> lies the truth of POST.  According to 2616, that is.
>
> Walden
>
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
> To: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>; "rest-discuss"
> <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, August 19, 2003 12:25 PM
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
>
>
>> Seairth,
>>
>> POST requires that it is *meaningful* for the request-entity to be a
>> subordinate of the target resource.  For example, it is meaningful to
>> talk about POSTing a log-entry to a log-file because we understand that
>> log-entry can be a subordinate of a logfile (even if the log-entry never
>> gets its own URI).
>>
>> In contrast, I'm still waiting for you to explain how an RNA notification
>> is subordinate to an RNA inbox.  Is it subordinate "in the same way that
>> a file is subordinate to a directory containing it, a news article is
>> subordinate to a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is
>> subordinate to a database?"  Unless you define what an inbox is, you
>> can't really POST to it.
>>
>> And, my more general point is, once you define what an inbox is, you
>> don't need specifically to document POST as it is defined entirely by the
>> semantics of RFC2616 and your definition of an inbox.
>>
>> > Resources that are POSTed to are not necessarily
>> > directories, containers, indexes, etc.  They are just resources that
>> > accept POST requests and give back a response.  That's it.
>>
>> There is no way to violate the semantics of POST under this
>> interpretation
> ;
>> it has no meaning.  If POST means nothing in particular, why not use
>> another verb name?  At very least, you could then use 501 NOT IMPLEMENTED
>> to determine whether or not the resource has the behavior you expect from
>> your method.
>>
>> -Alex-
>>
>> ___________________________________________________________________
>> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
>> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
>>
>> --On Friday, August 15, 2003 9:33 AM -0400 Seairth Jacobs
>> <seairth@...> wrote:
>>
>> > There has been much discussion about how POST should or shouldn't be
> used.
>> > What seems to be a major sticking point is the relationship of the
> request
>> > entity to the resource.  For reference (RFC2616 9.5):
>> >
>> >     The POST method is used to request that the origin
>> >     server accept the entity enclosed in the request as a
>> >     new subordinate of the resource identified by the
>> >     Request-URI in the Request-Line."
>> >
>> > Note that this does not say that the request entity is a "subordinate
>> > resource".  It only says that it is "a new suboridnate of the
>> > resource". Though some may disagree, that's a world of difference.
>> > POST never once claims that the request entity is a resource.  All it
>> > claims is that the target resource can make a resource out of the
>> > request entity.  This is evident by the variety of functions that POST
>> > can handle:
>> >
>> >     - Annotation of existing resources;
>> >
>> >     - Posting a message to a bulletin board, newsgroup,
>> >       mailing list, or similar group of articles;
>> >
>> >     - Providing a block of data, such as the result of
>> >       submitting a form, to a data-handling process;
>> >
>> >     - Extending a database through an append operation.
>> >
>> > Make special note of the third example.
>> >
>> > Now, the POST definition also says:
>> >
>> >     The actual function performed by the POST method is
>> >     determined by the server and is usually dependent on
>> >     the Request-URI. The posted entity is subordinate to
>> >     that URI in the same way that a file is subordinate to
>> >     a directory containing it, a news article is subordinate
>> >     to a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is
>> >     subordinate to a database.
>> >
>> > When trying to clarify what the definition means by "subordinate", it
>> > focuses on easily visualizable concepts where "subordination" is
>> > already
> a
>> > well-known concept.  This does *not* mean that this is an all-inclusive
>> > clarification.  The point that I think they are trying to get across is
>> > that the request entity is controlled by the resource, not the other
>> > way around. A record cannot insert itself into a database, the
>> > database must insert a record into itself.  The same can be said for
>> > file/directories and articles/newsgroups.
>> >
>> > The next part of the definition clearly points out that POST does not
>> > itself treat the request entity as a resource.
>> >
>> >     The action performed by the POST method might not
>> >     result in a resource that can be identified by a URI. In
>> >     this case, either 200 (OK) or 204 (No Content) is the
>> >     appropriate response status, depending on whether or
>> >     not the response includes an entity that describes
>> >     the result.
>> >
>> >  Again, it is up the the target resource to make that decision.  (Also,
> I
>> > would argue that 202 (and possibly any other 2xx code)  is a valid
>> > response, but that's a minor issue.)
>> >
>> > And the last relevant part of the specification is:
>> >
>> >     If a resource has been created on the origin server,
>> >     the response SHOULD be 201 (Created) and contain
>> >     an entity which describes the status of the request
>> >     and refers to the new resource, and a Location header
>> >     (see section 14.30).
>> >
>> > Now, this part is a bit interesting.  Suppose I POST a request entity
>> > to
> a
>> > resource such that the resource creates a new resource.  According to
> the
>> > definition, the response entity is the "status" of the request, not a
>> > representation of the new resource.  What this means to me is that even
> if
>> > the POST operation ends with the creation a new resource, the POST
> itself
>> > is still nothing more than what the third example above expresses.  In
>> > other words, the response is still just the output of the target
> resource
>> > function based on the input.
>> >
>> >
>> > And that's it.  POST is not complicated.  It does not have all sorts of
>> > additional semantics.  Resources that are POSTed to are not necessarily
>> > directories, containers, indexes, etc.  They are just resources that
>> > accept POST requests and give back a response.  That's it.  Boring, but
>> > quite useful.
>> >
>> > ---
>> > Seairth Jacobs
>> > seairth@...
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
>> > rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to
> http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>> >
>> >

>> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
>> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>>
>>
>>
>> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>>
>>

Post ID:3921
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-20 18:59:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>

<seairth@...>; "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, August 20, 2003 1:57 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?


> I am not requiring all that much of the term subordinate.  It just has to
> have a clear meaning with respect to a POSTed request entity and a target
> resource.

It's clearly different from PUT.  Where is it written that it must be
any clearer than that?  I think you're forcing that interpretation.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3922
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-20 19:34:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> I am not requiring all that much of the term subordinate.  It just has to
> have a clear meaning with respect to a POSTed request entity and a target
> resource.  Unless the client knows what it means for a request entity to
> be a subordinate of a target resource it can't make a request for the
server
> to do make it so.  Either it is making a request for something else, or it
> is making a request for something random.  The only way for the client to
> know what it means for a request entity to be subordinate to a particular
> resource is for it to have a model of what the resource actually is and
> how another entity can be subordinate to that resource.

Why does the client need to know anything more than what it POSTs and what
is returned?  If the request entity of a POST is acceptable by the server,
then the client knows that the request entity is subordinate in some fashion
to that resource.  If the server returns a representation of the resource
that client understands, then the client know what the server has told it
about that resource.  Beyond that, what does the client need to know?

In the case of RNA, there was nothing to return. The resource behind the
"InboxURI" is a black hole.  Stuff only goes in.  The resource has a
separate URI which allows all sorts of additional manipulation (if
authenticated) like GET and DELETE.  So why would the client that POSTs to
the InboxURI need to know anything about the resource?  The client knows
what a request entity with a content-type of
application/rna.notification+xml is.  It knows that, upon receiving a 2xx
response, the resource accepted the request entity.

 (NOTE: The "separate URI" mentioned above is not specifically defined by
RNA, only hinted at.  The implementation of that URI is up to the needs of
the specification using RNA as the "front end".  Maybe this has been the
problem.  Maybe the spec was not clear enough, specifically that it could
not be used as a stand-alone specification.  It needs an additional spec to
provide the "other half" of the application.  However, there isn't
necessarily a single "other" spec, which is why it was not included in RNA.)

> If you do insist on using POST then implicitly you are saying that the
> client can acquire this model from within HTTP itself (without reference
> to custom resource APIs).  I think the only way HTTP provides for
> acquiring this model is by the client knowing the content-type of the
> target resource.

I do not see why content-type would be enough.  For example, what would it
mean to a client that a resource (as perceived through its representation)
is an image/jpeg or application/xml?  How does that tell a client whether
you can GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE?  I suppose one could certainly define a
content-type with specific HTTP bindings, but that puts unreasonable
constraints on how the content-type may be used.  Maybe you are using
"content-type" in a way different than myself?  My meaning is limited to the
HTTP content-type header field.

> Alternative question for Seairth: If you do insist on using POST, how does
> the client know what it means?

What is "it"? The POST request?  The server?

> Yet another version of this same question: Can you give an example of how
> a server could in theory return 200 and still violate the semantics of
POST?

Is that question correct?  You seem to be asking me to give an example to
disprove myself... I think...

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3923
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-21 22:09:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

> Why does the client need to know anything more than what it POSTs and what
> is returned?

Because unless the server knows what the client intends in making a 
request, it cannot return 200 OK.  If the client has no idea what the 
result of a POST actually will be then the server can have no idea what the 
client's intention was in making the POST.  If the server has no idea what 
the client's intention was in making the POST it cannot make the claim that 
"The request has succeeded."(RFC2616 10.2.1)

> In the case of RNA [...] The client knows
> what a request entity with a content-type of
> application/rna.notification+xml is.  It knows that, upon receiving a 2xx
> response, the resource accepted the request entity.

And did what with it?  What did the client intend in POSTing the 
notification?

>> If you do insist on using POST then implicitly you are saying that the
>> client can acquire this model from within HTTP itself (without reference
>> to custom resource APIs).  I think the only way HTTP provides for
>> acquiring this model is by the client knowing the content-type of the
>> target resource.
>
> I do not see why content-type would be enough.  For example, what would it
> mean to a client that a resource (as perceived through its representation)
> is an image/jpeg or application/xml?

Assuming that the server returned the content-type in response to a raw-GET 
or raw-HEAD, the client knows that:
1. The server will act as if the resource is an instance of that 
content-type (even if its internal-representation/storage-model is 
different).  Therefore a change of content-type in response to another 
raw-GET or raw-HEAD implies a change of state not simply a change in the 
representation of that state.

2. The server will not return 413 Media Type Not Supported in response to a 
PUT of that content-type

3. If it is meaningful for another content-type to be a subordinate of the 
resource's content-type, the server will not return 413 in response to a 
POST of that content-type to that URI AND if the server returns 200, it 
will in fact make the POSTed entity of the resource in the manner implied 
by the content-type.  Since image/jpeg and application/xml do not provide a 
meaning for another entity to be subordinate, the server may return either 
413 or 405 in response to a POST to that resource.

> How does that tell a client whether
> you can GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE?

status codes and content-type.

But the real question is again how the server knows whether to return 200 
OK in response to such a request?  It can only return 200 OK if it knows 
what the client requested.  Since the intentions of a GET, PUT, and DELETE 
are obvious (though Yannick's original notification spec violated even 
DELETE), the only question left is how the server should interpret a POST 
request.  Unless there is a private out of band communication with the 
client, the only way it can constrain the meaning of POST enough to return 
200 is via the relation between the resource content-type and the POSTed 
content-type.  If the resource has no content-type, the server has no idea 
what the client means when it requests that the POSTed entity be made 
subordinate to that resource.

>> Alternative question for Seairth: If you do insist on using POST, how
>> does the client know what it means?
>
> What is "it"? The POST request?  The server?

I will rephrase the question: If the client makes a POST request, how does 
the server know what the client intended well enough to fulfill the request 
and claim that it succeeded by returning 200 OK?

>> Yet another version of this same question: Can you give an example of how
>> a server could in theory return 200 and still violate the semantics of
> POST?
>
> Is that question correct?  You seem to be asking me to give an example to
> disprove myself... I think...

If you can't give such an example, you need to explain why RFC2616 did not 
define POST simply as a catchall request that the server do some arbitrary 
server determined action with the request entity.  You need to explain all 
the verbiage about subordinate resources etc etc.

And, if you do believe POST is just such a catchall method, you actually 
need to explain why they bothered to define POST at all because then under 
your interpretation POST has no particular identifiable semantics and 
therefore "cannot be assumed to share the same semantics for separately 
extended clients and servers."(RFC2616 sect. 9)

In other words, if POST has no particular identifiable semantics, the only 
way for the server to claim accurately that a POST request succeed (200 
OK), is for it to have negotiated a private meaning of POST for that 
resource.  If you are defining a private API anyway, then there is no 
particular reason to use a
public method name and actually a good reason to use private method names 
so you can take advantage of 405 and 503 status codes and give more 
visibility to intermediaries about what is actually being done.

Can you give any good reason to use POST as the name of your RNA 
notification method?  Why not use RNA-NOTIFY?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax




--On Wednesday, August 20, 2003 3:34 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:

> From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
>>
>> I am not requiring all that much of the term subordinate.  It just has to
>> have a clear meaning with respect to a POSTed request entity and a target
>> resource.  Unless the client knows what it means for a request entity to
>> be a subordinate of a target resource it can't make a request for the
> server
>> to do make it so.  Either it is making a request for something else, or
>> it is making a request for something random.  The only way for the
>> client to know what it means for a request entity to be subordinate to a
>> particular resource is for it to have a model of what the resource
>> actually is and how another entity can be subordinate to that resource.

> is returned?  If the request entity of a POST is acceptable by the server,
> then the client knows that the request entity is subordinate in some

> RNA.)

>> client can acquire this model from within HTTP itself (without reference

>> target resource.

> mean to a client that a resource (as perceived through its representation)
> is an image/jpeg or application/xml?  How does that tell a client whether
> you can GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE?  I suppose one could certainly define a
> content-type with specific HTTP bindings, but that puts unreasonable
> constraints on how the content-type may be used.  Maybe you are using
> "content-type" in a way different than myself?  My meaning is limited to
> the HTTP content-type header field.
>
>> Alternative question for Seairth: If you do insist on using POST, how
>> does the client know what it means?
>
> What is "it"? The POST request?  The server?
>
>> Yet another version of this same question: Can you give an example of how
>> a server could in theory return 200 and still violate the semantics of
> POST?
>
> Is that question correct?  You seem to be asking me to give an example to
> disprove myself... I think...
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3924
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-21 22:17:29
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

>> I am not requiring all that much of the term subordinate.  It just has to
>> have a clear meaning with respect to a POSTed request entity and a target
>> resource.
>
> It's clearly different from PUT.  Where is it written that it must be
> any clearer than that?

It must be clear enough for the server to be able claim that the request 
succeeded (200 OK).  If the server doesn't know the meaning of the request, 
it can't return 200 OK.  And if the meaning of the request is subject to a 
private negotiation between the server operator and the client operator, 
then there is no particular reason to use a public method name.

How else can you interpret the beginning of section 9 of RFC2616:
"""
   The set of common methods for HTTP/1.1 is defined below. Although
   this set can be expanded, additional methods cannot be assumed to
   share the same semantics for separately extended clients and servers.
"""

If POST is a catchall, it is not a "common method" it is a private method 
with a public name and client and servers cannot assume that they share the 
same semantics when the method is used.

If POST has a specific meaning then it is a "common method" for all HTTP 
clients and servers.  If you have a different specific meaning for POST, 
please share.  But if you are saying that POST has no specific meaning at 
all, then I think you are talking about a protocol other than HTTP/1.1.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3925
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-22 00:18:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

Reiteration/clarification of my prior post:

The server needs to know what the client meant in making request  in order 
to claim that the request succeeded (200 OK).

Either the meaning of a POST is constrained by the request-entity and the 
requested URI or it is constrained by the request-entity and the 
content-type of the resource identified by that URI.

If you believe the former, then you believe the client cannot make a POST 
request without some out of band communication with the server and perhaps 
we should rename the POST method to DO_SOMETHING_WITH_THIS_REQUEST_ENTITY. 
If you believe the former then you should acknowledge that POST has no 
public definition at all (the intro to section 9 of rfc2616, 
notwithstanding) and that you really don't need a generic method name at 
all because the semantics are private between the client and server in any 
case (that you should really use a private method name).

However, if you insist on using POST as your method name, you MUST think 
that POST has a public meaning and therefore that clients can make a POST 
request without an out-of-band communication with a server operator.  I 
think the only way to constrain the meaning enough for the server to 
understand the client's intentions is via content-type.  If you can think 
of another constraint, please say so.

If you cannot provide another constraint, then you must conclude that 
content-type is the only way to constrain meaning, that the client must 
understand the content-type of the resource in order to POST to it, that 
therefore HTTP is about transferring the resource-model via content-type 
(the MoST thesis is correct), and that the server may NOT arbitrarily 
reinterpret the meaning of HTTP methods in a way that is visible to the 
client (the REST thesis is either vague or wrong).

QED

-Alex-

PS I am heading to Burning Man tomorrow and will be off-grid for the next 
10 days so don't be offended if I don't reply.  If you are attending 
Burning Man as well, I'd love to meet up.  I will be in  Camp 
Disorient/Ishkabibble at Esplanade and 10:00/Sacred.  I hope to see you 
there.


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3926
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-22 07:11:50
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

> 
> Assuming that the server returned the content-type in response to a raw-GET 
> or raw-HEAD, the client knows that:
> 1. The server will act as if the resource is an instance of that 
> content-type (even if its internal-representation/storage-model is 
> different).  Therefore a change of content-type in response to another 
> raw-GET or raw-HEAD implies a change of state not simply a change in the 
> representation of that state.

rfc2616 states that a post can be used to add comments to a document
(e.g.). So the "raw get" retrun an html document, which can accept ...
say xml+xlink anotea-like comments... it's not the same content-type...
how can you assume that? because in a wiki-like system, a post of html
to http://host/doc.html#section can mean that I want to add a paragraph
to this section... or any other example where you post to a "html"
document...

> 3. If it is meaningful for another content-type to be a subordinate of the 
> resource's content-type, the server will not return 413 in response to a 
> POST of that content-type to that URI AND if the server returns 200, it 
> will in fact make the POSTed entity of the resource in the manner implied 
> by the content-type.  Since image/jpeg and application/xml do not provide a 
> meaning for another entity to be subordinate, the server may return either 
> 413 or 405 in response to a POST to that resource.

For me, it is meaningful to post EXIF metadata to a image/jpeg. It's
juste an example of the fact that you (the client or the server) can't
presume of what can be meaningful in a post for the other side of the
application. If I make a system that *in a "row get"* return image/jpeg,
and allow a POST of metadat (exif of other similar system), And if I
don't give you additional doc, you'll never use this functionality,
simply assuming that you can't POST to a image/jpeg ?? Meatadata are
"subordinate" to the image, at least in my interpretation of what
"subordinate" means), so I can POST them to an image if the system
allows it...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3927
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-22 07:23:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
Message:

Le ven 22/08/2003  02:18, Alex Jacobson a crit :

> If you believe the former, then you believe the client cannot make a POST 
> request without some out of band communication with the server and perhaps 
> we should rename the POST method to DO_SOMETHING_WITH_THIS_REQUEST_ENTITY. 
> If you believe the former then you should acknowledge that POST has no 
> public definition at all (the intro to section 9 of rfc2616, 
> notwithstanding) and that you really don't need a generic method name at 
> all because the semantics are private between the client and server in any 
> case (that you should really use a private method name).

the first goal of POST was to deal with html forms, and thus with 
application/x-www-form-urlencoded. But you can't use this content-type
without doc ! the type does not suffice, you have to know the fields'
names, their types, and so on... 
content-type is not always sufficient to know what to do with a
resource.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3928
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-25 19:02:01
Subject:Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
Message:

http://www.seairth.com/web/suds/

Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS) is a small, easy, xml-based syntax for
discovering and negotiating resource URIs with specific interface
properties.  This is the first (very rough) draft, put together in a couple
hours.  Before continuing, I would like to get some feedback on it as it
stands right now.  If anyone is interested on working on it with me, let me
know.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3929
Sender:Berend de Boer <berend@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-25 19:51:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
Message:

>>>>> "Seairth" == Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> writes:

    Seairth> http://www.seairth.com/web/suds/ Simple URI Discovery
    Seairth> Syntax (SUDS) is a small, easy, xml-based syntax for

It always makes me extremely uneasy when I have to read documents with
copyrights...

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:
