-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3933
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-25 21:12:38
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
Message:

Berend de Boer wrote:

>     Justin> Every document has a copyright. Even this email. It's just
>     Justin> invisible.
> 
> There are documents with copylefts...

A copyleft is a copyright, too. But yes, there are public domain
documents, which have no copyright. Just pointing out that Seairth holds
an "all rights reserved" copyright on the page he posted, unless he
gives a copyright notice stating otherwise. We should be more uneasy
when a document does not have a copyright notice, methinks.

Justin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3934
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-26 00:17:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
Message:

Heh.  I warned that it was a rough draft.... :)

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> 1. Does a remote application want to discover URIs, or does it want
> to discover resources?

I agree that a remote application wants to discover resources.  However, in
order to work with those resources, it must do so through URIs and
representations.  The objective of SUDS to get ahold of the URI of a
resource, not the resource itself. I need to go reword all of that stuff.

> 2. What is a "resource URI", as opposed to a regular URI?

I didn't see "resource URI" in the document.  Oh wait, that was in the
e-mail.  In answer, there is no difference.  It probably would have been
better to read as "resource's URI".  After all, what you are after is the
URI, not the resource (that's what you use the aquired URI for).

> 3. In practice, what would SUDS actually be used for?  A focused
> scenario would help.  In mean, isn't the web really about the discovery
> of resources, one within the context of another?  And if that's the
> case, then where does this scheme fit in?

I don't know if that's what the web is all about, but it certainly is a part
of the equation.   However, the ability to do this effectively seems fairly
limited.  For instance, for any given resource, how can one know if it meets
the needs of your client?  How can a client know what a resource can and
cannot do (or what can be done to the resource)?  If there is a resource
that provides a specific representation through a given URI, how do you find
that URI?  It may be that the URI you currently have for the resource
returns HTML, and it may be that the html document contains <link> elements
to point to this same information.  However, this requires a client to be
capable of parsing html and <link> elements.  But it may be that the URI you
have returns another content-type.  It would then be necessary for the
client to understand that format to get the same information (assuming the
information was available).  SUDS, on the other hand, provides clients to
query this information at the resource level instead of the representation
level.

As for a scenario, let's see...  Suppose you have a blog entry at
http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.  Now, here are the things you could
do with SUDS for that URI:

1) Discover which content-types are available (which your client also
understands).

<suds>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="GET" content-type="text/xml"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="GET" content-type="application/pdf"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

returns

<suds>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.rss2">
        <returns http-method="GET" content-type="text/xml"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.atom">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri=""/>
</suds>

2) Discover where you can POST comments to.

<suds>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

returns

<suds>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.comments">
        <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
    </sud>
</suds>


Another scenario...  suppose robots.txt files and p3p were given a mime type
(or do they already have one?).  In this case, a query like the following
could be submitted to http://www.example.com/:

<suds>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

which would return

<suds>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/robots.txt">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/p3p.xml">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
    </sud>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/logo.jpg">
        <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

Yet another scenario...  suppose you have a URI
(http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss) to a "container" resource.  You
need to know what the client can and cannot do with/to the resource via the
given URI.  So, you POST the following:

<suds>
    <sud uri="">
        <accepts http-method="DELETE"/>
        <accepts http-method="GET"/>
        <accepts http-method="POST"/>
        <accepts http-method="PUT"/>
        <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
        <accepts conent-type="text/html"/>
        <accepts conent-type="text/xml"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

returns

<suds>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss">
        <accepts http-method="GET"/>
        <accepts http-method="POST" conent-type="text/xml"/>
        <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
        <returns content-type="text/xml"/>
        <returns content-type="application/pdf" content-encoding="gzip"/>
        <returns content-type="text/xhtml+xml"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

(hmm... maybe this should be about interfaces, not URIs... Resource
Interface Discovery Syntax (RIDS)?)


I have another example using an extended SUDS document, which is connected
to my RNA stuff, but I'm not ready to show that one yet...

So, how does any of this work for you?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3935
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-26 01:54:38
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
Message:

>
> (hmm... maybe this should be about interfaces, not URIs... Resource
> Interface Discovery Syntax (RIDS)?)
>
>
> I have another example using an extended SUDS document, which is connected
> to my RNA stuff, but I'm not ready to show that one yet...
>
> So, how does any of this work for you?
>

I think I'm still missing a big, important piece.  It looks like you have
some SUDS server that can basically answer questions about
syntax, but if I was looking for a resource in a serious way, I
would care more initially about the semantics, not the syntax, and
I don't see how you've addressed that (not meaning to sound as
if I think you should, mind you).

By analogy, it would be as if I went to The Home Depot in search
of a tool with seventeen moving parts and a power cord.

Also, I'm assuming this is a central registry kind of thing, as
opposed to a metadata service provided by SUDSY resources
generally.  Because instead of doing content negotiation on a
selected resource, it points you to a resource that fits the syntactic
requirement, right?

Walden





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3936
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-26 03:53:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
Message:

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> I think I'm still missing a big, important piece.  It looks like you have
> some SUDS server that can basically answer questions about
> syntax, but if I was looking for a resource in a serious way, I
> would care more initially about the semantics, not the syntax, and
> I don't see how you've addressed that (not meaning to sound as
> if I think you should, mind you).

It's true that I haven't directly addressed semantics.  However, there are
various levels of semantic discovery.  For instance, in the case of the blog
example, if I POST a SUDS document to the URI of the entry resource:

<suds>
    <sud uri="">
        <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

and I get back

<suds>
    <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.comments">
        <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
    </sud>
</suds>

what more needs to be known?  The semantics are wrapped up in the
content-type, http-method, and the relationship to the resource that
processed the SUDS request.  Now, I am not saying this is sufficient for all
needs.  I do believe, however, that it's a goog start.  Since the SUDS is
xml-based, it is also possible to extend the request to allow for additional
criteria.  Obviously, the SUDS more or less punts on this to avoid getting
bogged down in the endless possibilities...

> Also, I'm assuming this is a central registry kind of thing, as
> opposed to a metadata service provided by SUDSY resources
> generally.  Because instead of doing content negotiation on a
> selected resource, it points you to a resource that fits the syntactic
> requirement, right?

No, I was thinking about SUDSy resources, though I don't see why a central
registry couldn't be done.  The idea would be to enhance existing resources
to include this functionality.  So, instead of just having a blog entry
resource, you have a blog entry resource capable of processing SUDS
documents.

So, does this clear any of it up, or make things worse?  :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3937
Sender:"wiki1000" <wiki1000@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-27 17:55:49
Subject:XCAP protocol
Message:

Is there any comment here about the XCAP protocol at

http://xml.coverpages.org/ni2003-05-29-a.html ? 

A very RESTFUL (perhaps with some restrictions) to perform a VERY
general task: remote modification of an XML document.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3938
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-28 17:53:28
Subject:SID replaces SUDS
Message:

Okay, I have replaced SUDS with SID: Simple Interface Discovery.  Take a
look at http://www.seairth.com/web/sid/.  I have cleaned up the terminology
(I think), as well as attempted to clarify points and reworked some parts to
improve comprehension (again, I think).  Please take a look and let me know
what you think.

Seairth





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3939
Sender:"Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-28 18:33:19
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

How about "application resource space"?

Doesn't have the greatest acronym, though.

We do use the phrase "REST API" in our company, and it has kind
of bugged me. But in design discussions we talk about "mapping
concepts to the resource space", so that seems to be the idea to
emphasize.

Justin

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...m]
> Sent: Monday, July 28, 2003 6:20 AM
> To: rest-discuss
> Subject: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
>
> We all know that
>
>     API = Application Program(ming) Interface
>
> However, is this the correct terminology for RESTful interfaces
> (as implemented with HTTP)? Somehow, "API" doesn't seem right.
> I would think something like
>
>     HTTPAI = HTTP Application Interface
>
> or
>
>     ARI = Application Representation Interface
>
> or
>
>     ASI = Application State Interface
>
> or
>
>     RRI = Resource Representation Interface
>
> or
>
>     RHI = REST-HTTP Interface
>
> or something along those lines would be more appropriate... Is
> there such a term already? If not, any thoughts on what a good
> one would be?
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3940
Sender:Phil Eskelin <philip.eskelin@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-08-29 13:26:45
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

In my toolkit, which I currently call Rest++, I have RESTful Template
Library, or RTL, which coexists along side ATL, STL, and WTL frameworks.
RTL uses Xerces-C v2.3 and is what the rest of the samples and services I'm
currently programming for the toolkit are built on.

So if you're using Visual C++ and can use these frameworks in your
application, then you'll have a rich set of tools that cooperate nicely and
allow you to rapidly build applications in C++.

-----Original Message-----
From: "Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
Date: Thu, 28 Aug 2003 11:33:19 -0700
Subject: RE: OT: terminology?

How about "application resource space"?

Doesn't have the greatest acronym, though.

We do use the phrase "REST API" in our company, and it has kind
of bugged me. But in design discussions we talk about "mapping
concepts to the resource space", so that seems to be the idea to
emphasize.

Justin

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
> Sent: Monday, July 28, 2003 6:20 AM
> To: rest-discuss
> Subject: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
>
> We all know that
>
>     API = Application Program(ming) Interface
>
> However, is this the correct terminology for RESTful interfaces
> (as implemented with HTTP)? Somehow, "API" doesn't seem right.
> I would think something like
>
>     HTTPAI = HTTP Application Interface
>
> or

>     ARI = Application Representation Interface

> or

> elements.  But it may be that the URI you have returns another

> </suds>

>
> <suds>
>     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.comments">
>         <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
>     </sud>
> </suds>

> type (or do they already have one?).  In this case, a query like the
> following could be submitted to http://www.example.com/:
>

>     <sud uri="">
>         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>

> </suds>

>
> <suds>
>     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/robots.txt">
>         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>

>         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
>     </sud>
>     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/logo.jpg">
>         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
>     </sud>
> </suds>
>
> Yet another scenario...  suppose you have a URI
> (http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss) to a "container" resource.
> You need to know what the client can and cannot do with/to the resource
> via the given URI.  So, you POST the following:
>
> <suds>
>     <sud uri="">
>         <accepts http-method="DELETE"/>
>         <accepts http-method="GET"/>
>         <accepts http-method="POST"/>
>         <accepts http-method="PUT"/>
>         <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
>         <accepts conent-type="text/html"/>
>         <accepts conent-type="text/xml"/>
>     </sud>
> </suds>
>
> returns
>
> <suds>
>     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss">
>         <accepts http-method="GET"/>
>         <accepts http-method="POST" conent-type="text/xml"/>
>         <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
>         <returns content-type="text/xml"/>
>         <returns content-type="application/pdf" content-encoding="gzip"/>
>         <returns content-type="text/xhtml+xml"/>
>     </sud>
> </suds>
>
> (hmm... maybe this should be about interfaces, not URIs... Resource
> Interface Discovery Syntax (RIDS)?)
>
>
> I have another example using an extended SUDS document, which is connected
> to my RNA stuff, but I'm not ready to show that one yet...
>
> So, how does any of this work for you?
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
>

Why not simply talk about document types?  What exactly is a RESTful API 
aside from the verbs of HTTP?

--On Friday, August 29, 2003 2:26 PM +0100 Phil Eskelin 
<philip.eskelin@...> wrote:

> In my toolkit, which I currently call Rest++, I have RESTful Template
> Library, or RTL, which coexists along side ATL, STL, and WTL frameworks.
> RTL uses Xerces-C v2.3 and is what the rest of the samples and services
> I'm currently programming for the toolkit are built on.
>
> So if you're using Visual C++ and can use these frameworks in your
> application, then you'll have a rich set of tools that cooperate nicely
> and allow you to rapidly build applications in C++.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: "Justin Sampson" <justin.sampson@...>
> Date: Thu, 28 Aug 2003 11:33:19 -0700
> Subject: RE: OT: terminology?
>
> How about "application resource space"?
>
> Doesn't have the greatest acronym, though.
>
> We do use the phrase "REST API" in our company, and it has kind
> of bugged me. But in design discussions we talk about "mapping
> concepts to the resource space", so that seems to be the idea to
> emphasize.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3943
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-05 01:11:19
Subject:SID (was Re:Simple URI Discovery Syntax)
Message:

Welcome back to this world.  :)

In answer to your question: simplicity.  SID (which replaced SUDS) can be
learned in a matter of minutes.  No, it is not a perfect solution for all
situations (what is?).  But I think there is a great (or at least
increasing) need for better introspection, and I think that something like
WSDL is overkill for many.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...


----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>; "rest-discuss"
<rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, September 04, 2003 6:21 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)


> Seairth,
>
> Why not use IDL or WSDL?  Why use HTTP methods?
>
> -Alex-
>
>
> ___________________________________________________________________
> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
>
> --On Monday, August 25, 2003 8:17 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs
> <seairth@...> wrote:
>
> > Heh.  I warned that it was a rough draft.... :)
> >
> > From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
> >>
> >> 1. Does a remote application want to discover URIs, or does it want
> >> to discover resources?
> >
> > I agree that a remote application wants to discover resources.  However,
> > in order to work with those resources, it must do so through URIs and
> > representations.  The objective of SUDS to get ahold of the URI of a
> > resource, not the resource itself. I need to go reword all of that
stuff.
> >
> >> 2. What is a "resource URI", as opposed to a regular URI?
> >
> > I didn't see "resource URI" in the document.  Oh wait, that was in the
> > e-mail.  In answer, there is no difference.  It probably would have been
> > better to read as "resource's URI".  After all, what you are after is
the
> > URI, not the resource (that's what you use the aquired URI for).
> >
> >> 3. In practice, what would SUDS actually be used for?  A focused
> >> scenario would help.  In mean, isn't the web really about the discovery
> >> of resources, one within the context of another?  And if that's the
> >> case, then where does this scheme fit in?
> >
> > I don't know if that's what the web is all about, but it certainly is a
> > part of the equation.   However, the ability to do this effectively
seems
> > fairly limited.  For instance, for any given resource, how can one know
> > if it meets the needs of your client?  How can a client know what a
> > resource can and cannot do (or what can be done to the resource)?  If
> > there is a resource that provides a specific representation through a
> > given URI, how do you find that URI?  It may be that the URI you
> > currently have for the resource returns HTML, and it may be that the
html
> > document contains <link> elements to point to this same information.
> > However, this requires a client to be capable of parsing html and <link>
> > elements.  But it may be that the URI you have returns another
> > content-type.  It would then be necessary for the client to understand
> > that format to get the same information (assuming the information was
> > available).  SUDS, on the other hand, provides clients to query this
> > information at the resource level instead of the representation level.
> >
> > As for a scenario, let's see...  Suppose you have a blog entry at
> > http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.  Now, here are the things you
> > could do with SUDS for that URI:
> >
> > 1) Discover which content-types are available (which your client also
> > understands).
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" content-type="text/xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" content-type="application/pdf"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> > returns
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.rss2">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" content-type="text/xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.atom">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri=""/>
> > </suds>
> >
> > 2) Discover where you can POST comments to.
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> > returns
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.comments">
> >         <returns http-method="POST" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> >
> > Another scenario...  suppose robots.txt files and p3p were given a mime
> > type (or do they already have one?).  In this case, a query like the
> > following could be submitted to http://www.example.com/:
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> > which would return
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/robots.txt">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/p3p.xml">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/logo.jpg">
> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> > Yet another scenario...  suppose you have a URI
> > (http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss) to a "container" resource.
> > You need to know what the client can and cannot do with/to the resource
> > via the given URI.  So, you POST the following:
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="">
> >         <accepts http-method="DELETE"/>
> >         <accepts http-method="GET"/>
> >         <accepts http-method="POST"/>
> >         <accepts http-method="PUT"/>
> >         <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
> >         <accepts conent-type="text/html"/>
> >         <accepts conent-type="text/xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> > returns
> >
> > <suds>
> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss">
> >         <accepts http-method="GET"/>
> >         <accepts http-method="POST" conent-type="text/xml"/>
> >         <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
> >         <returns content-type="text/xml"/>
> >         <returns content-type="application/pdf"
content-encoding="gzip"/>
> >         <returns content-type="text/xhtml+xml"/>
> >     </sud>
> > </suds>
> >
> > (hmm... maybe this should be about interfaces, not URIs... Resource
> > Interface Discovery Syntax (RIDS)?)
> >
> >
> > I have another example using an extended SUDS document, which is
connected
> > to my RNA stuff, but I'm not ready to show that one yet...
> >
> > So, how does any of this work for you?
> >
> > ---
> > Seairth Jacobs
> > seairth@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3944
Sender:"Phil Eskelin" <philip.eskelin@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-05 13:20:20
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

I don't really think of it as an API - the only API that exists in my opinion is the HTTP API.  The framework is built upon this core API and provides you with reusable classes that allow, among other things, for connection between components and exchange of representations.  If you read Fielding's dissertation, it should be easy for you to imagine other classes that might exist in this framework as well.

-----Original Message-----
From: Alex Jacobson [mailto:alex@...]
Sent: Thursday, September 04, 2003 6:14 PM

Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?


Why not simply talk about document types?  What exactly is a RESTful API 
aside from the verbs of HTTP?

-Alex-

--On Friday, August 29, 2003 2:26 PM +0100 Phil Eskelin 
<philip.eskelin@...> wrote:

> In my toolkit, which I currently call Rest++, I have RESTful Template
> Library, or RTL, which coexists along side ATL, STL, and WTL frameworks.
> RTL uses Xerces-C v2.3 and is what the rest of the samples and services
> I'm currently programming for the toolkit are built on.
>
> So if you're using Visual C++ and can use these frameworks in your
> application, then you'll have a rich set of tools that cooperate nicely
> and allow you to rapidly build applications in C++.
>

> How about "application resource space"?
>
> Doesn't have the greatest acronym, though.
>
> We do use the phrase "REST API" in our company, and it has kind
> of bugged me. But in design discussions we talk about "mapping
> concepts to the resource space", so that seems to be the idea to
> emphasize.
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3945
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-05 21:13:03
Subject:RE: [rest-discuss] OT: terminology?
Message:

I read Fielding's dissertation.  If you read RFC2616, you can see why I ask 
this question.  A framework compliant with RFC2616, would simply be a set 
of types with operations for GET/PUT/POST/DELETE against instances.  An 
HTTP resource is simply something which exposes these methods.  Conneg is 
completely optional.  What are the classes in your framework?

-Alex-


--On Friday, September 05, 2003 2:20 PM +0100 Phil Eskelin

> provides you with reusable classes that allow, among other things, for
> connection between components and exchange of representations.  If you
> read Fielding's dissertation, it should be easy for you to imagine other

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3946
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-08 13:55:38
Subject:Is an interface part of a resource?
Message:

Is an interface part of a resource?  In other words, is the ability to make
requests to and get responses from a resource part of the resource itself?
Or is it totally separate, nothing more than "marshalling" of an autonomous
resource?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3947
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-09 00:07:49
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Is an interface part of a resource?
Message:

Seairth,

I don't think the question is clear the way you have worded
it.  In concrete terms, "when you GET a representation of a resource,
should that representation include a description of the operations
the resource supports?"  Isn't that closer to the real issue?

In general, aren't questions about the alleged composition of
a resource moot, because representations is all we can really
observe?

Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, September 08, 2003 9:55 AM
Subject: [rest-discuss] Is an interface part of a resource?


> Is an interface part of a resource?  In other words, is the ability to
make
> requests to and get responses from a resource part of the resource itself?
> Or is it totally separate, nothing more than "marshalling" of an
autonomous
> resource?
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3948
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-09 00:54:30
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Is an interface part of a resource?
Message:

From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> I don't think the question is clear the way you have worded
> it.  In concrete terms, "when you GET a representation of a resource,
> should that representation include a description of the operations
> the resource supports?"

That's not what I am asking.  Rephrased:

Is the *ability* to perform a GET against a resource part of that resource?
Is the response itself (not just the body) part of that resource?

or

Can a resource be accessible through HTTP and still not have any aspect of
HTTP be part of itself?

In concrete terms, suppose there is a text file (content-type: text/plain).
It exists, but is not accessible (limited to the discussion of HTTP).  It is
resource R.  Now, we make that text file available via HTTP at URI_A.  I can
issue a GET on URI and get back a representation of that text file.  Is it
still resource R or is it now resource R', where the ability to perform a
GET on it and to get back a representation (plus HTTP headers, etc) are also
part of the resource?

> Isn't that closer to the real issue?

Not exactly, though that conversation did spark my question.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3949
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-09 00:55:45
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] SID (was Re:Simple URI Discovery Syntax)
Message:

Ok, but if you are interesting in doing something WSDL-like, why are you 
interested in ReST?  My generic claim is that exposing an resource via HTTP 
is enough to identify its interface without resort to WSDL-like things.

Mark Baker says that is what ReST is about:
<http://www.markbaker.ca/2002/09/Blog/2002/11/19#2002-11-reinacker-uniform-
interface>
<http://www.thearchitect.co.uk/weblog/archives/2002/11/000023.html#comments>

Roy says something similar in his thesis:
"""
The semantics are thus not defined by the network interface (IIOP), but by 
the object's IDL spec. Whether this is a good thing or not depends on the 
application -- for distributed objects it is a necessity, for the Web it 
isn't.

Why is this important? Because it differentiates a system where network 
intermediaries can be effective agents from a system where they can be, at 
most, routers.

This kind of difference is also seen in the interpretation of a message as 
a unit or as a stream. HTTP allows the recipient or the sender to decide 
that on their own. CORBA IDL doesn't even allow streams (yet), but even 
when it does get extended to support streams, both sides of the 
communication will be tied to the same API, rather than being free to use 
whatever is most appropriate for their type of application.
[...]
What distinguishes HTTP from RPC isn't the syntax. It isn't even the 
different characteristics gained from using a stream as a parameter, though 
that helps to explain why existing RPC mechanisms were not usable for the 
Web. What makes HTTP significantly different from RPC is that the requests 
are directed to resources using a generic interface with standard semantics 
that can be interpreted by intermediaries almost as well as by the machines 
that originate services. The result is an application that allows for 
layers of transformation and indirection that are independent of the 
information origin, which is very useful for an Internet-scale, 
multi-organization, anarchically scalable information system. RPC 
mechanisms, in contrast, are defined in terms of language APIs, not 
network-based applications.
"""
<http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm>

How does this square with SID/SUDS?

-Alex-

--On Thursday, September 04, 2003 9:11 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:

> Welcome back to this world.  :)
>
> In answer to your question: simplicity.  SID (which replaced SUDS) can be
> learned in a matter of minutes.  No, it is not a perfect solution for all
> situations (what is?).  But I think there is a great (or at least
> increasing) need for better introspection, and I think that something like
> WSDL is overkill for many.
>
> ---
> Seairth Jacobs
> seairth@...
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Alex Jacobson" <alex@...>
> To: "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>; "rest-discuss"
> <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Thursday, September 04, 2003 6:21 PM
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Simple URI Discovery Syntax (SUDS)
>
>
>> Seairth,
>>
>> Why not use IDL or WSDL?  Why use HTTP methods?
>>
>> -Alex-
>>
>>
>> ___________________________________________________________________
>> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
>> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
>>
>> --On Monday, August 25, 2003 8:17 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs
>> <seairth@...> wrote:
>>
>> > Heh.  I warned that it was a rough draft.... :)
>> >
>> > From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>> >>
>> >> 1. Does a remote application want to discover URIs, or does it want
>> >> to discover resources?
>> >
>> > I agree that a remote application wants to discover resources.
>> > However, in order to work with those resources, it must do so through
>> > URIs and representations.  The objective of SUDS to get ahold of the
>> > URI of a resource, not the resource itself. I need to go reword all of
>> > that
> stuff.
>> >
>> >> 2. What is a "resource URI", as opposed to a regular URI?
>> >
>> > I didn't see "resource URI" in the document.  Oh wait, that was in the
>> > e-mail.  In answer, there is no difference.  It probably would have
>> > been better to read as "resource's URI".  After all, what you are
>> > after is
> the
>> > URI, not the resource (that's what you use the aquired URI for).
>> >
>> >> 3. In practice, what would SUDS actually be used for?  A focused
>> >> scenario would help.  In mean, isn't the web really about the
>> >> discovery of resources, one within the context of another?  And if
>> >> that's the case, then where does this scheme fit in?
>> >
>> > I don't know if that's what the web is all about, but it certainly is a
>> > part of the equation.   However, the ability to do this effectively
> seems
>> > fairly limited.  For instance, for any given resource, how can one know
>> > if it meets the needs of your client?  How can a client know what a
>> > resource can and cannot do (or what can be done to the resource)?  If
>> > there is a resource that provides a specific representation through a
>> > given URI, how do you find that URI?  It may be that the URI you
>> > currently have for the resource returns HTML, and it may be that the
> html
>> > document contains <link> elements to point to this same information.
>> > However, this requires a client to be capable of parsing html and
>> > <link> elements.  But it may be that the URI you have returns another
>> > content-type.  It would then be necessary for the client to understand
>> > that format to get the same information (assuming the information was
>> > available).  SUDS, on the other hand, provides clients to query this
>> > information at the resource level instead of the representation level.
>> >
>> > As for a scenario, let's see...  Suppose you have a blog entry at
>> > http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.  Now, here are the things you
>> > could do with SUDS for that URI:
>> >
>> > 1) Discover which content-types are available (which your client also
>> > understands).
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" content-type="text/xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" content-type="application/pdf"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > returns
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.rss2">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" content-type="text/xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.atom">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/atom+xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri=""/>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > 2) Discover where you can POST comments to.
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="POST"
>> >         conent-type="application/atom+xml"/> </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > returns
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/sudsIsTheFuture.comments">
>> >         <returns http-method="POST"
>> >         conent-type="application/atom+xml"/> </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> >
>> > Another scenario...  suppose robots.txt files and p3p were given a mime
>> > type (or do they already have one?).  In this case, a query like the
>> > following could be submitted to http://www.example.com/:
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > which would return
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/robots.txt">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="text/robots"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/policies/p3p.xml">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="application/p3p+xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/logo.jpg">
>> >         <returns http-method="GET" conent-type="image/jpeg"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > Yet another scenario...  suppose you have a URI
>> > (http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss) to a "container" resource.
>> > You need to know what the client can and cannot do with/to the resource
>> > via the given URI.  So, you POST the following:
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="">
>> >         <accepts http-method="DELETE"/>
>> >         <accepts http-method="GET"/>
>> >         <accepts http-method="POST"/>
>> >         <accepts http-method="PUT"/>
>> >         <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
>> >         <accepts conent-type="text/html"/>
>> >         <accepts conent-type="text/xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > returns
>> >
>> > <suds>
>> >     <sud uri="http://www.example.com/groups/rest-discuss">
>> >         <accepts http-method="GET"/>
>> >         <accepts http-method="POST" conent-type="text/xml"/>
>> >         <accepts content-encoding="gzip"/>
>> >         <returns content-type="text/xml"/>
>> >         <returns content-type="application/pdf"
> content-encoding="gzip"/>
>> >         <returns content-type="text/xhtml+xml"/>
>> >     </sud>
>> > </suds>
>> >
>> > (hmm... maybe this should be about interfaces, not URIs... Resource
>> > Interface Discovery Syntax (RIDS)?)
>> >
>> >
>> > I have another example using an extended SUDS document, which is
> connected
>> > to my RNA stuff, but I'm not ready to show that one yet...
>> >
>> > So, how does any of this work for you?
>> >
>> > ---
>> > Seairth Jacobs
>> > seairth@...
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
>> > rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to
> http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>> >
>> >
>>

>> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3950
Sender:Chuck Hinson <cmhinson@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-09 01:47:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Is an interface part of a resource?
Message:


Seairth Jacobs wrote:

>From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>  
>
>>I don't think the question is clear the way you have worded
>>it.  In concrete terms, "when you GET a representation of a resource,
>>should that representation include a description of the operations
>>the resource supports?"
>>    
>>
>
>That's not what I am asking.  Rephrased:
>
>Is the *ability* to perform a GET against a resource part of that resource?
>

Is that the same as 'Is the ability to respond to a GET request  part of 
the resource?'

>Is the response itself (not just the body) part of that resource?
>  
>

Are the words that are used to describe an idea part of the idea?

I'm not sure how to determine the answer to your question.  My instinct 
is to say that the HTTP stuff is not part of the resource, but at this 
point, I'm not sure how I would defend that statement (give me a while 
and I might come up with something).


>or
>
>Can a resource be accessible through HTTP and still not have any aspect of
>HTTP be part of itself?
>
>In concrete terms, suppose there is a text file (content-type: text/plain).
>It exists, but is not accessible (limited to the discussion of HTTP).  It is
>resource R.  Now, we make that text file available via HTTP at URI_A.  I can
>issue a GET on URI and get back a representation of that text file.  Is it
>still resource R or is it now resource R', where the ability to perform a
>GET on it and to get back a representation (plus HTTP headers, etc) are also
>part of the resource?
>  
>

A couple of points.

I seem to remember something somewhere talking about how resources may 
be composed of other resources (which is what I think your example 
describes).  I think in your example, you have identified two resources 
- one that is accessible via HTTP (R') and one that is not (R).  The one 
accessible via HTTP (R') is composed of another resource (R) that is not 
accessible via HTTP. (Either that or you have a resource that is 
accessible via two different mechanisms - your definition doesnt give 
enough detail for me to know which is the case.)

The second point is that a GET on R' by definition returns a 
representation of R', not R.  It may happen that the representations of 
the two resources are the same, but that doesnt change what you call the 
results of a GET on R'.  How a resource's representations are produced 
(e.g., retrieve from file or from database) is an implementation detail, 
and I wouldn't normally consider that detail to be relevant to the 
definition of the resource (although I'm sure there are resources where 
that detail is relevant).

--Chuck

Post ID:3951
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-10 04:52:03
Subject:RDF Forms
Message:

I'd appreciate comments on this, which is basically a way of
communicating what HTML forms does, with RDF, and with some RESTy
self-description voodoo (that may very well be overkill).

http://www.markbaker.ca/2003/05/RDF-Forms/

You might recognize parts of it from RestRDF, and my HTTP resource
state model.

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3952
Sender:<jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-10 18:40:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

Mark--
 
thanks for this, it's very interesting.
 
Some questions:
 
The container provides the ability to specify which media type
it accepts. If this is XML, then it makes sense to use
rf:acceptedNamespace to specify which semantics the conteiner
understands. But what if the input type is not XML but some other
form of semantically structured data? Propably the addition of
a more generic element such as rf:acceptedSemantics could help here?
 
 
Is the intention behind the rf-namespace to signal that the input is
requested or possible now (at the time of parsing) or is the intention
more
to publish the availablility of rf:Containers (e.g. publishing a list
of many rf:Containers to inform 'semantic web agents') in general?
 
 
Also, rf is a fragment-identifier-free namespace. Cool! ;-)
 
Jan

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3953
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-10 20:41:17
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

On Wed, Sep 10, 2003 at 08:20:02PM +0200, jalgermissen@... wrote:
> 
> Mark--
>  
> thanks for this, it's very interesting.

Good to hear, thanks.

> Some questions:
>  
> The container provides the ability to specify which media type
> it accepts. If this is XML, then it makes sense to use
> rf:acceptedNamespace to specify which semantics the conteiner
> understands. But what if the input type is not XML but some other
> form of semantically structured data? Propably the addition of
> a more generic element such as rf:acceptedSemantics could help here?

"acceptedNamespace" is just a hack to address the problem that
people are using application/xml incorrectly, as if the application
were dispatched on the namespace rather than the media type.  I should
probably say that in my description.

> Is the intention behind the rf-namespace to signal that the input is
> requested or possible now (at the time of parsing) or is the intention
> more
> to publish the availablility of rf:Containers (e.g. publishing a list
> of many rf:Containers to inform 'semantic web agents') in general?

The latter.  I think the former is best handled out of band to a
mechanism such as this.

> Also, rf is a fragment-identifier-free namespace. Cool! ;-)

Slash the hash!! 8-)

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca

Post ID:3954
Sender:Hugh Winkler <hughw@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-10 21:56:27
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

Mark Baker wrote:

> >> Also, rf is a fragment-identifier-free namespace. Cool! ;-)
>
> >Slash the hash!! 8-)

http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/Fragment.html#Fragment2

argues that rdf namespaces must end in fragment identifiers.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3955
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-10 21:23:43
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

Exactly what purpose does this spec serve that is not already served by 
HEAD, 405, 413,414, and 415?

HEAD gives you the content-type which implies both the allowed POSTable 
types and the allowed query strings.

If the server does not support all the content-types, entities, and query 
strings implied by the content-type of the resource identified by the 
target URI, it can return the above status codes.  If the content-type of 
the target resource does not sufficiently constrain the client, choose a 
more-specific content-type.

The semantic web needs is better documentation of content-types.  It does 
not need better documentation of the capabilities of particular URIs.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3956
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 02:32:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

On Wed, Sep 10, 2003 at 04:56:27PM -0500, Hugh Winkler wrote:
> Mark Baker wrote:
> 
> > >> Also, rf is a fragment-identifier-free namespace. Cool! ;-)
> >
> > >Slash the hash!! 8-)
> 
> http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/Fragment.html#Fragment2
> 
> argues that rdf namespaces must end in fragment identifiers.

Right.  Tim's wrong.  This is the rathole known as httpRange-14[1] in
W3C TAGland.  Tim believes that the range of http URIs is a "conceptual
work", whereas others, including Roy and myself, believe that the range
of http URIs (and indeed, any URI) is all resources.

 [1] http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/ilist#httpRange-14

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3957
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 06:52:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

Le mer 10/09/2003  23:23, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> Exactly what purpose does this spec serve that is not already served by 
> HEAD, 405, 413,414, and 415?

First, you need an uri on which to perform your HEAD. Therefore you need
at least an uri list.

> HEAD gives you the content-type which implies both the allowed POSTable 
> types and the allowed query strings.

Suppose that the default content-type is html, to be complient with
browsers (like IE) that ask for */* (even if the purpose of your service
is to be queried by a specific client dealing with xml).
Therefore, the submission method is an html form, and thus the
content-type is www-url-encoded. How do you then specify the names and
the types of the form's fields ?

> If the server does not support all the content-types, entities, and query 
> strings implied by the content-type of the resource identified by the 
> target URI, it can return the above status codes.  If the content-type of 
> the target resource does not sufficiently constrain the client, choose a 
> more-specific content-type.
> 
> The semantic web needs is better documentation of content-types.  It does 
> not need better documentation of the capabilities of particular URIs.
> 
> -Alex-

Post ID:3958

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms

> If the server does not support all the content-types, entities, and query 
> strings implied by the content-type of the resource identified by the 
> target URI, it can return the above status codes.  If the content-type of 
> the target resource does not sufficiently constrain the client, choose a 
> more-specific content-type.

Why do we have phonebooks?  I suppose one can just call all phone
numbers and ask for who they're looking for...

And why do we have garbage cans and mailboxes?  Why don't we just have
a steel box with a hole in it?  Then you could put your garbage and
your mail in one convenient place.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3959
Sender:<jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 13:38:01
Subject:RDF Forms (sample newsletter-order-container)
Message:

-- Mark--

here are some ideas about describing existing POST containers:

In general, there are millions of them on the Web in the form:

<form action="http://www.example.org/post-container" method="POST">
  <input type="text" name="foo" />
  <!-- more input/textarea/select elements here -->
</form>

Besides using application/x-www-form-urlencoded as the
accepted encoding, all the various input 'fields' have to be
communicated to the processing application. As a first shot
I suggest an rf:acceptsField property in the same style as
rf:indexedBy.

So, the above POST container can be described with

<rf:Container xmlns:rf="http://www.markbaker.ca/2003/rdfforms/"
              xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"
              rdf:about="http://www.example.org/post-container">
 
<rf:acceptedMediaType>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</rf:acceptedMediaType>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="http://www.example.com/foo"
rf:shortName="foo"/>
  <!-- others go here -->
</rf:Container>

To illustrate some of the issues that arise I tried to describe
the "newsletter-order-container" located at

       http://www.oasis-open.org/newsletters/action.php

(The form resides at
  http://www.oasis-open.org/newsletters/subscribe.phtml)
    

<rf:Container xmlns:rf="http://www.markbaker.ca/2003/rdfforms/"
              xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"
             
rdf:about="http://www.oasis-open.org/newsletters/action.php">
 
<rf:acceptedMediaType>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</rf:acceptedMediaType>

  <!-- These fields are the ones that can propably be 'standardized' for
       all newsletter-order-container: -->
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="http://www.newsletter.org/name"
rf:shortName="name"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="http://www.newsletter.org/email"
rf:shortName="email"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="http://www.newsletter.org/organisation"
rf:shortName="org"/>

  <!-- These fields are checkboxes that let the user choose what
       newsletters to order, meaning that we have to find a
       way to communicate to the application that these are
       multiple 1/0 'decisions'.  This is propbaly also common
       to all newsletter-order-container -->

  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="oasis"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="cover"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="dailynews"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="xmldev"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="samldev"/>
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="ebdev"/>

  <!-- Below we have to <select> elements with various
       options: -->

  <!-- original value/label pairs:

      Corporate Management/Corporate Management (CEO, COO, President,
VP, Director)
      Systems Management/CIO/CTO/IT/IS/Systems Management
      Net Management/Internet/Intranet/Web/E-Commerce Management
      engineering/Engineering Management
      consultant/Consultant
      other/Other
   -->
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="JFunction"/>

  <!-- original value/label pairs:

       vendor/Product Vendor
       user/User
       consultant/Consultant
       other/Other
   -->
  <rf:acceptsField rdf:resource="" rf:shortName="interest"/>
</rf:Container>

What needs to be resolved is how to communicate the possible
option values to the application and propably how to make use of
the additional information that the labels provide (e.g. when the
described container is renederd for a human user with a web browser.

Jan



Jan Algermissen                <algermissen@...>
Consultant & Programmer

http://www.topicmapping.com
http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3960
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 17:13:42
Subject:web-calculus presentation at HP Labs
Message:

Waterken Inc. recently presented the web-calculus to HP Labs in
Palo Alto, California. The talk explains how the web-calculus is
derived from existing REST theory, and highlights the advantages
of this design. The presentation generated much positive
discussion, especially amongst HP Lab's web services group.

HP Labs provided wonderful A/V support, including a video of the
presentation. The presentation video and the slides are available
for download from the Waterken Inc. site. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/HP2003/

The presentation is really the first work that explains the
functionality benefits that come from using the web-calculus. In
explaining these benefits, the presentation also serves as a good
primer on REST. I encourage everyone to download and view the
video.

Thanks to everyone at HP Labs who made the presentation possible.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3961
Sender:Ken MacLeod <ken@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 18:25:57
Subject:new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

HttpMethodsSupport[1] is copied from the Atom Wiki CarrotVsOrange
page[2], summarizing the support of PUT and DELETE methods in various
server and client toolkits.

While very promising for REST overall, the smattering of toolkits that
only support GET/POST may be cause for Pie/Echo/Atom to also support a
fallback technique.

  -- Ken

[1] http://internet.conveyor.com/RESTwiki/moin.cgi/HttpMethodsSupport
[2] http://intertwingly.net/wiki/pie/CarrotVsOrange





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3962
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 18:55:53
Subject:HTTP headers support
Message:

Is their an consensus to deal with http header in url query string when
it's impossible for the client to manage them (e.g. html forms).
It could be useful if everyone use the same parameters. I propose one of
the form HttpEquiv<Header>, inspired by the html meta tag 
(e.g. http://host/service/resource?HttpEquivAccept=text/xml )





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3963
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 17:49:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

<polemics>
Hmm, perhaps that is better than having to spider the entire internet to 
find out what the entry in the phonebook actually means....
</polemics>

But this is why I asked for a use case.

In practice, given a content-type for a resource, the number of e.g. 
POSTable content-types to that resource is, with a few notable exceptions 
fairly small.

And, if you are going to make the phonebook argument, why are you not 
enumerating all the content-types for which the resource can provide 
representations in response to a GET?

-Alex-

S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax




--On Thursday, September 11, 2003 9:13 AM -0400 Mark Baker 
<distobj@...> wrote:

>> If the server does not support all the content-types, entities, and
>> query  strings implied by the content-type of the resource identified by
>> the  target URI, it can return the above status codes.  If the
>> content-type of  the target resource does not sufficiently constrain the
>> client, choose a  more-specific content-type.

> numbers and ask for who they're looking for...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3964
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 18:18:00
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

--On Thursday, September 11, 2003 8:52 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@free.fr> wrote:

> Le mer 10/09/2003  23:23, Alex Jacobson a crit :
>> Exactly what purpose does this spec serve that is not already served by
>> HEAD, 405, 413,414, and 415?
>
> First, you need an uri on which to perform your HEAD. Therefore you need
> at least an uri list.

Yes, you obviously need a URI.  The question is whether it make sense to 
provide the information available from the URI along with the URI itself. 
Why not provide the URI along with the resource itself?

>> HEAD gives you the content-type which implies both the allowed POSTable
>> types and the allowed query strings.
>
> Suppose that the default content-type is html, to be complient with
> browsers (like IE) that ask for */* (even if the purpose of your service
> is to be queried by a specific client dealing with xml).
> Therefore, the submission method is an html form, and thus the
> content-type is www-url-encoded. How do you then specify the names and
> the types of the form's fields ?

A HEAD of /collection.xml returns content-type: application/shoe-orders+xml
Some research on this content-type tells you that it looks like this:
 <orders>
  <order custId="asdsad" addrId="abc123" cartId="abc123" ccNo=".....   />
  ...
 </orders>

The schema tells you which elements are required and which are optional.
Since the translation from form-encoded of these name value pairs to an 
update to this object is obvious, the content-type tells you everything you 
need to know about the form.

So now you create a form located at /form.html
it POSTs to /collection.xml

The server responds:
  201 Created
  Location: postedobjectlocation
  Content-type: text/plain

  Thank you for posting.

The end user is never directly exposed to the application/shoe-orders+xml 
type.

Note: It would be more elegant if there was a variant of multipart/mixed 
that had a types parameter which constrained the set of types allowed in 
the mix, but I am not aware of an RFC that looks like that so we are stuck 
with the above.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3965
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 20:28:46
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

Le jeu 11/09/2003  20:18, Alex Jacobson a crit :

[...]
> The schema tells you which elements are required and which are optional.
> Since the translation from form-encoded of these name value pairs to an 
> update to this object is obvious, the content-type tells you everything you 
> need to know about the form.
[...]
I disagree. your example is simple enough to make it obvious, but it is
not always the case. Moreover, this can't be automated. You have to look
for this schema. And finally, this suppose that your "default" (or
"main") type is application/shoe-order+xml, and I precised that is this
example case, default is text/html and the server can return many
formats, thanks to, e.g. , server-side xslt, so there is *no* "main"
type.

> 
> So now you create a form located at /form.html
> it POSTs to /collection.xml
> 
> The server responds:
>   201 Created
>   Location: postedobjectlocation
>   Content-type: text/plain
> 
>   Thank you for posting.
>

> type.

> that had a types parameter which constrained the set of types allowed in 
> the mix, but I am not aware of an RFC that looks like that so we are stuck 
> with the above.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3966
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-11 20:55:53
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

--On Thursday, September 11, 2003 10:28 PM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@...> wrote:
> your example is simple enough to make it obvious, but it is
> not always the case.

Ok.  Give me a non-obvious case that is not an example of poor engineering 
and that cannot be refactored to be simple enough to be obvious.

> Moreover, this can't be automated. You have to look
> for this schema.

You always need to understand the content-types (and schema) with which you 
are dealing.  RDF forms also requires you to understand schema.  The 
question is whether you need anything more (beyond the constraints of 
HTTP/1.1).  As far as understanding content-types (and schema), the effort 
on RDF forms would be better spent improving the infrastructure for 
resolving content-type names to their documentation.  Perhaps adding a url 
parameter to the content-type header designating the location of the 
documentation about the content-type would be the way to go.

> And finally, this suppose that your "default" (or
> "main") type is application/shoe-order+xml, and I precised that is this
> example case, default is text/html and the server can return many
> formats, thanks to, e.g. , server-side xslt, so there is *no* "main"
> type.

The default type of *what* is text/html?  The form?  The POSTable resource? 
The entity body returned from the POST?  The point of my elucidation 
(copied below) is that browser based form interaction never actually 
require a GET of a POSTable resource, so it can be whatever type you want. 
My general point is that that type should provide enough information for 
form-designers and other client-side developers to understand how to 
interact with the resource.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

>
>>
>> So now you create a form located at /form.html
>> it POSTs to /collection.xml
>>
>> The server responds:
>>   201 Created
>>   Location: postedobjectlocation
>>   Content-type: text/plain
>>
>>   Thank you for posting.
>>
>> The end user is never directly exposed to the
>> application/shoe-orders+xml  type.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3967
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-12 02:28:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

On Thu, Sep 11, 2003 at 02:25:57PM -0400, Ken MacLeod wrote:
> HttpMethodsSupport[1] is copied from the Atom Wiki CarrotVsOrange
> page[2], summarizing the support of PUT and DELETE methods in various
> server and client toolkits.
> 
> While very promising for REST overall, the smattering of toolkits that
> only support GET/POST may be cause for Pie/Echo/Atom to also support a
> fallback technique.

There's a middle ground here.  It's not perfectly RESTful, but is more
so than the everything-with-POST approach.  And what's making it
unRESTful is HTTP's lack of mandatory extensions (at least I think
that's the only thing).

A PUT would look like this;

POST /moby HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/not-echo+xml
Action: http://some-pie-uri.example.org/intent/put

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<entry>
 <title>Chapter 1</title>
 <author><name>Herman Melville</name></author>
 <created>1851-10-18T02:00:00Z</created>
 <content type='text/plain'>Call me Ishmael.</content>
 </entry>

and a "DELETE /moby" would look like this;

POST /moby HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/not-echo+xml
Action: http://some-pie-uri.example.org/intent/delete
[zero length body]

"Action" serves to identify the "extended intent" of the POST
submission.  It's the non-SOAP version of SOAPAction.

As mentioned, all that's missing for this to be fully RESTful, I
believe, is mandatory extensions.  So a more RESTful PUT-via-POST
example, using RFC 2774 which adds mandatory extensions to HTTP,
would be (though I'm *not* proposing this);

M-POST /moby HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/not-echo+xml
Man: "http://some-pie-uri.example.org/pie-ns/"; ns=1
1-Action: http://some-pie-uri.example.org/intent/put

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<entry>
 <title>Chapter 1</title>
 <author><name>Herman Melville</name></author>
 <created>1851-10-18T02:00:00Z</created>
 <content type='text/plain'>Call me Ishmael.</content>
 </entry>

I'd still like to be able to use PUT and DELETE though.  But doing
this in addition would seem to address the concerns of the folks who
are concerned about the lack of widespread support for PUT and
DELETE.

Mark.
--
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3968
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-12 02:44:22
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

BTW, I should also mention that I think that Tim's solution is
"good enough".  Tunneling is bad, but tunneling uniform semantics
("delete") makes it bearable.  As long as PUT and DELETE are also
supported, I'm happy.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3969
Sender:Yannick Loiseau <yloiseau@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-12 06:48:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

Le jeu 11/09/2003  22:55, Alex Jacobson a crit :
> --On Thursday, September 11, 2003 10:28 PM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
> > your example is simple enough to make it obvious, but it is
> > not always the case.
> 
> Ok.  Give me a non-obvious case that is not an example of poor engineering 
> and that cannot be refactored to be simple enough to be obvious.

as the use of html forms imply the use of an html browser as a GUI, and
not a custom client, the client can't deal with many http headers (e.g.
changing Accept on the fly, conditional GET, other methods than
post/get. This is browser poor engineering, not service. But to deal
with these problems, the simplest solution is to add params in the query
part that are not directly related to the content (data) of the
resource. (see my HttpEquiv... proposal). Thus, if your service use such
a trick, theses params are not implies by the "schema" of your type. In
addition, all your argumentation suppose that the type *has* a schema
and is validable... which in not alway true either. 

> > Moreover, this can't be automated. You have to look
> > for this schema.
> 
> You always need to understand the content-types (and schema) with which you 
> are dealing.  RDF forms also requires you to understand schema.  The 
> question is whether you need anything more (beyond the constraints of 
> HTTP/1.1).  As far as understanding content-types (and schema), the effort 
> on RDF forms would be better spent improving the infrastructure for 
> resolving content-type names to their documentation.  Perhaps adding a url 
> parameter to the content-type header designating the location of the 
> documentation about the content-type would be the way to go.

If such an url is included in the header, I agree for this argument. But
in the current situation, the name of the MIME type is not enough, and
it's all that you can obtain from the service. As you can't modify the
MIME standard, the solution would be a Meta-Content header, but this
discussion is an other problem, already debated here. Moreover, an
rf-like document allow to use a *unique* language to describe the form.
What is the language of your schema ? if it's the content is not xml ...
Such a unique format (joined with the discovery it implies, contrary tto
MIME that don't say where to find the format definition, when it even
exists) allow full automation e.g. on the fly form generation... 

> > And finally, this suppose that your "default" (or
> > "main") type is application/shoe-order+xml, and I precised that is this
> > example case, default is text/html and the server can return many
> > formats, thanks to, e.g. , server-side xslt, so there is *no* "main"
> > type.
> 
> The default type of *what* is text/html?  The form?  The POSTable resource? 

The postable resource, which is what is interesting here. Suppose you
have an url to an article. the default type of the get is html. you can
post comments to that article. Explain me how you deal with that...
The type return by the head is html. there is no schema for the post
content. You can't POST to an other uri, because you would loose the
meaning of the post. 

> The entity body returned from the POST?  The point of my elucidation 
> (copied below) is that browser based form interaction never actually 
> require a GET of a POSTable resource, so it can be whatever type you want. 
> My general point is that that type should provide enough information for 
> form-designers and other client-side developers to understand how to 
> interact with the resource.
> 
> -Alex-
> 
> 
> ___________________________________________________________________
> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
> 1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax
> 
> >
> >>
> >> So now you create a form located at /form.html
> >> it POSTs to /collection.xml
> >>
> >> The server responds:
> >>   201 Created
> >>   Location: postedobjectlocation
> >>   Content-type: text/plain
> >>
> >>   Thank you for posting.
> >>
> >> The end user is never directly exposed to the
> >> application/shoe-orders+xml  type.
> 
> 
>

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

Post ID:3970
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-12 11:14:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

Mark Baker wrote:

> I'd still like to be able to use PUT and DELETE though.  But doing
> this in addition would seem to address the concerns of the folks who
> are concerned about the lack of widespread support for PUT and
> DELETE.

Urrgghhh... Fwiw it's still a lot better that a recent and nasty 
hack I tried where DELETE and PUT were mapped onto URIs which is a 
complete mess.

I know you said to me once that it's not a fundamental problem that 
HTML forms don't support DELETE and PUT. But the workarounds such as 
yours leaves me deeply unconvinced - I think the HTML designers and 
the W3C set a very bad precedent and a lot of the goofy thinking 
around SOAP uber POST can be seen as coming from that precedent.

I'm working on a reliable delivery exchange over HTTP and I'm 
running into similar problems as CarrotVsOrange. My take on that 
debate is that RSS justifies using the full HTTP method set and 
working around is shortsighted - it's not just that current lack of 
widespread support for DELETE and PUT isn't a good technical 
argument, but for RSS it's a not a good expedient argument either, 
since RSS is not anywhere like as dependent on HTML forms or 
browsers as CGI type technology was.

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3971
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>

Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

Mark Baker wrote:

> BTW, I should also mention that I think that Tim's solution is
> "good enough".  Tunneling is bad, but tunneling uniform semantics
> ("delete") makes it bearable.  As long as PUT and DELETE are also
> supported, I'm happy.

I'm not. This only works if the syntax is uniform as well. Otherwise 
we're in codec hell. Uniform syntax + semantics could work.

Bill de hra

Post ID:3972

Mark Baker wrote:


> There's a middle ground here.  It's not perfectly RESTful, but is more
> so than the everything-with-POST approach.  And what's making it
> unRESTful is HTTP's lack of mandatory extensions (at least I think
> that's the only thing).

Mark,

True, but you only need extensions in this case to workaround the 
clients. The core problem is at the client, not HTTP, which has all 
the methods we need to get the job done already.

Nonetheless, thanks for this. I'm going to have a crack at 
implementing it for that reliable exchange application I mentioned 
elsewhere, so I can the map application onto HTML forms.

Bill de hra

Post ID:3973
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-12 15:09:20
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms (sample newsletter-order-container)
Message:

On Thu, Sep 11, 2003 at 03:38:01PM +0200, jalgermissen@... wrote:
> here are some ideas about describing existing POST containers:
> 
> In general, there are millions of them on the Web in the form:
> 
> <form action="http://www.example.org/post-container" method="POST">
>   <input type="text" name="foo" />
>   <!-- more input/textarea/select elements here -->
> </form>
> 
> Besides using application/x-www-form-urlencoded as the
> accepted encoding, all the various input 'fields' have to be
> communicated to the processing application. As a first shot
> I suggest an rf:acceptsField property in the same style as
> rf:indexedBy.

Right.  I mentioned this in the "Future Directions" section.  Though
on seeing it speced out so simply, I wonder why I didn't just do it.

Thanks, I'll add that.

> What needs to be resolved is how to communicate the possible
> option values to the application and propably how to make use of
> the additional information that the labels provide (e.g. when the
> described container is renederd for a human user with a web browser.

I think RDF Schema can help there.  You could, for example,
define a collection which includes your allowable values, then
declare the property to have a rdfs:domain of that collection.

We're doing that on a project I'm working on, anyhow.

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca
