-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3975
Sender:Alex Jacobson <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-12 18:45:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] RDF Forms
Message:

>> The default type of *what* is text/html?  The form?  The POSTable
>> resource?
>
> The postable resource, which is what is interesting here. Suppose you
> have an url to an article. the default type of the get is html. you can
> post comments to that article. Explain me how you deal with that...
> The type return by the head is html. there is no schema for the post
> content. You can't POST to an other uri, because you would loose the
> meaning of the post.

You obviously CAN post to another URI because if you couldn't then most 
forms on the web would, according to you, loose their meaning.   The other 
uri would designate the the collection of comments on the page at issue. 
The content-type of that collection might be e.g. application/comments+xml 
with obvious semantics with respect to form posted name/value pairs.

Posting to the HTML itself just isn't required.

-Alex-


___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3976
Sender:"bhaugen32" <bhaugen32@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-13 00:09:10
Subject:Re: new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

Bill de hra wrote:

> I'm working on a reliable delivery exchange over HTTP and I'm 
> running into similar problems as CarrotVsOrange. 

Is that something you can discuss in more detail?
For example, what do you mean by "reliable delivery exchange"?





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3977
Sender:=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Bill_de_h=D3ra?= <dehora@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-13 01:08:55
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

bhaugen32 wrote:
> Bill de hra wrote:
> 
> 
>>I'm working on a reliable delivery exchange over HTTP and I'm 
>>running into similar problems as CarrotVsOrange. 
> 
> 
> Is that something you can discuss in more detail?

It's a formalization of a problem I keep running into with WS and 
HTTP inter-administrative integrations. For my money, once you can 
reliably transfer documents using client-server HTTP, a considerable 
number of unneccesary WS specs can be canned.


> For example, what do you mean by "reliable delivery exchange"?

Once and only once delivery, on a pure client-server HTTP model, no 
extensions a la WebDAV/HTTPR, based on the five packet handshake 
protocol (parties exchange a token to begin with), state inspectable 
  by third parties.

But truthfully, in a commercial setting, I mean this - if it doesn't 
get from A to B, just once, my ass is on the line. The purpose of 
the protocol is to fulfil a business need at a low cost. Most of the 
customers I work with are concerned about being locked-in to magic 
black boxes, so opening the protocol is important in that respect.

Paul Prescod wrote up a great one pager on this a few years back on 
a model where the client and server exchange a URI token, and a lot 
of my understanding on what you can and can't do regarding reliable 
communications on the Internet came from Miles Sabin. I think you 
need a wee bit more than Paul outlined, but a hell of a lot less 
than any of the reliable-over-HTTP protocols I've seen.

It's not baked yet, the main issues are what resource the URI token 
names (I think it's the exchange and not the message) and the 
PUT/DELETE debacle (well, I think it's a debacle :)

Bill de hra





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3978
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-15 02:53:52
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Re: new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

Erm, yah, that's the idea.  Nice job. 8-)

P.S. I tried to get SOAP 1.2 to support body-less envelopes for exactly
the reason you really need them there.  The WG didn't like that idea.
But I'd just make the body empty in those case; no need to duplicate
what SOAPAction already makes clear.

On Fri, Sep 12, 2003 at 12:13:15PM -0400, sa3ruby wrote:
> Any thoughts on this:
> 
> http://www.intertwingly.net/wiki/pie/DifferentlyAbledClients





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3979
Sender:"djpowell.geo" <djpowell@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-15 08:55:08
Subject:Re: new wiki page: Http Methods Support
Message:

--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "sa3ruby" <rubys@i...> wrote:
> Any thoughts on this:
> 
> http://www.intertwingly.net/wiki/pie/DifferentlyAbledClients
> 
> ?
> 
> - Sam Ruby


I implemented something recently that used Apache CGI to do it's own 
hand-rolled Basic auth.  A trick that you can use to get Apache to 
supply a Authorization header to CGI scripts is to use these 
directives in a .htaccess file:

  RewriteEngine on 
  RewriteCond %{HTTP:authorization} (.*) 
  RewriteRule .* - [E=HTTP_AUTHORIZATION:%1] 

Is there any other reason that you need to use a different name?  
Remember that the "Authorization" header has special semantics in 
section 14.8 - shared caches may not cache the replies to requests 
that were sent with this header, unless arrangements are made to 
specifically make them cacheable.

-- 
Dave





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3980
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-17 18:50:32
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] web-calculus presentation at HP Labs
Message:

Tyler,

I just looked at your slides and have some questions:

You say a web service is a command interface for "pushing" commands.
I think it more accurate to say it is an interface for "pushing" state.
Moreover, the lambda calculus is theoretically incompatible with state
change, requiring Monads as a separate path to describe state change --
calculations and commands being considerably different (see e.g.
<http://www.research.avayalabs.com/user/wadler/papers/monadsdeclare/monadsdeclare.ps>).

Perhaps I am not understanding Web Calculus, but, based on this
presentation, it strikes me as inconsistent with ReST, MoST, and the lambda
calculus.  Perhaps you can clarify.

-Alex-

PS I am in the bay area for the next week.  I'd love to meet up for coffee
and talk about this stuff in person if you have the time.


On Thu, 11 Sep 2003, Tyler Close wrote:

> Waterken Inc. recently presented the web-calculus to HP Labs in
> Palo Alto, California. The talk explains how the web-calculus is
> derived from existing REST theory, and highlights the advantages
> of this design. The presentation generated much positive
> discussion, especially amongst HP Lab's web services group.
>
> HP Labs provided wonderful A/V support, including a video of the
> presentation. The presentation video and the slides are available
> for download from the Waterken Inc. site. See:
>
> http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/HP2003/
>
> The presentation is really the first work that explains the
> functionality benefits that come from using the web-calculus. In
> explaining these benefits, the presentation also serves as a good
> primer on REST. I encourage everyone to download and view the
> video.
>
> Thanks to everyone at HP Labs who made the presentation possible.
>
> Tyler
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>
>
>
> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3981
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-17 20:30:15
Subject:Re: [web-calculus] Re: [rest-discuss] web-calculus presentation at HP Labs
Message:

On Wednesday 17 September 2003 14:34, Alex Jacobson wrote:
> Tyler,
>
> I just looked at your slides and have some questions:

Great.

You should also view the video. I tried to make the slides as
informative as possible, but there's only so much you can do with
slides.

> You say a web service is a command interface for "pushing" commands.
> I think it more accurate to say it is an interface for "pushing" state.

Could you clarify, perhaps with an example?

> Moreover, the lambda calculus is theoretically incompatible with state
> change, requiring Monads as a separate path to describe state change --

Certainly Church's lambda-calculus did not have state change, but
many of the languages based on the lambda-calculus have
incorporated side-effects. When the presentation uses the term
lambda, it is using the term in much the same way as it is used in
Lisp.  Each node in the graph is a closure. The HTTP POST verb is
then understood to mean "apply".

Also note that the web-calculus is just an interface model, not a
computation model. The model used on the server to represent state
change is not relevant to the web-calculus. The web-calculus is
solely concerned with the interface the server exposes to the
client, just as REST is. Given this limitation, we are only
concerned with the interface aspects of the lambda-calculus,
namely applying arguments to an anonymous closure. In HTTP terms,
POSTing to a resource identified only by a URL.

As further explained in the presentation, the web-calculus then
extends the lambda-calculus model by incorporating graph
introspection, or GET in HTTP terms.

> Perhaps I am not understanding Web Calculus, but, based on this
> presentation, it strikes me as inconsistent with ReST, MoST, and the lambda
> calculus.  Perhaps you can clarify.

I suggest viewing the video. I am working on a paper based on the
video, but it is not ready yet. Of course, there is also the
web-calculus specification itself. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/

In the presentation, I show how the web-calculus is defined,
starting from REST's constraints. Definition of the web-calculus
proceeds by adding constraints. This process yields a model that
is compatible with REST, as the end product necessarily conforms
to REST's constraints.

The HP presentation is at:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/HP2003/

> -Alex-
>
> PS I am in the bay area for the next week.  I'd love to meet up for coffee
> and talk about this stuff in person if you have the time.

A face-to-face meeting would be great, but unfortunately I am not
in the Bay Area anymore. I was just down visiting friends when
Mark Miller and Alan Karp arranged for the presentation at HP
Labs. Mark introduces me at the start of the presentation video.
You may know Mark from his work on the E language
<http://www.erights.org/> and Xanadu, a precursor of the WWW.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3982
Sender:"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-26 00:44:49
Subject:is this okay?
Message:

I am reworking my little blog program such that it will now generate actual
static files that can be served directly by Apache.  For those of you aware
of Sam Ruby's Mombo, my program will work in a similar way.  Now, here's the
issue...

When a request is made for a file that does not yet physically exist,
mod_rewrite is used to redirect the request through a CGI script.  The
script then generates the file and stores it.  Now, what I need to do is
also return the contents of the file back to the user.  But!  I do not want
to deal with all of the headers that Apache would normally return were the
file already in place.  So here is my thought:  once the file has been
created, return a 301 (Moved Permanently) response back to the same exact
request URL.  The browser then re-GETs the file and Apache handles the
request without any CGI intervention the second time around.  (All other
requests get handled by Apache the first time around.)

All of you have probably noticed the potential for the good ol' "infinite
loop" problem, but interestingly, both IE and Mozilla allow such a
redirection back to the URL that just got the 301 response (and I am
guessing the other 30x responses do the same).  So, technically this seems
to work.  However, does anyone see anything "bad" about this approach?  It
seems to be very simple, clean, and effective, but I thought I would ask...
just in case...

---
Seairth (seairth@...)
Looking: http://www.seairth.com/blog/65





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3983
Sender:"algermissen1971" <jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-09-29 11:34:59
Subject:Addressing context?
Message:

Hi,

apologies if this is a bit off-topic, I am not sure how much my
question relates to
REST in general.

I am currently researching how Topic Maps and Web architecture relate
to each other.
One primary difference is addressing context: Topic Maps essentially
use two distinct
addressing contexts (to be chosen by the Topic Map author), using a
URI  as an
identifier for an abstract concept or as an identifier for 'a
document' (in the sense
of Web page).

I have understood that Web architecture is grounded in the existence
of a single,
unique addressing context (URI allways identifies resource) and
vaguely think that
I see some technical/conceptual advanteges of this, well, axiom.

The distinction can also bee seen this way: In TM-land the author of a
Topic Map
decides in what a given URI identifies, in Web-land the controling
authority
makes this decison.

My particular questions are:

- Is the idea that an authority controls the 'meaning of URI' a REST
principle or
  'just' a Web principle?

- What exactly are the technical advantages of using a unique
addressing context
  when building distributes systems based on REST? Has anybody
analized that
 in detail or can help me with some pointers?

Thanks.

Jan





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3984
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 02:32:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] Addressing context?
Message:

On Mon, Sep 29, 2003 at 07:34:59AM -0400, algermissen1971 wrote:
> I have understood that Web architecture is grounded in the existence
> of a single,
> unique addressing context (URI allways identifies resource) and
> vaguely think that
> I see some technical/conceptual advanteges of this, well, axiom.

I hope so! 8-)

> The distinction can also bee seen this way: In TM-land the author of a
> Topic Map
> decides in what a given URI identifies, in Web-land the controling
> authority
> makes this decison.
> 
> My particular questions are:
> 
> - Is the idea that an authority controls the 'meaning of URI' a REST
> principle or
>   'just' a Web principle?

I'd say the latter.  I don't recall REST talking at all about ownership,
though it's possible some degree of that is implicit in the "meaning
via use" aspect of REST.

> - What exactly are the technical advantages of using a unique
> addressing context
>   when building distributes systems based on REST? Has anybody
> analized that
>  in detail or can help me with some pointers?

Well, independent of REST, the benefit of global naming has been
discussed for many many years.  Not that I'm very familiar with the
history, but you might look up the work of Engelbart (Augment/NLS), or
Nelson (Xanadu).  Sorry I can't be more specific.  I'm sure somebody
here who's more familiar with hypertext would have a good pointer.

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca

In fact, it was rather difficult to grasp this part of Web architecture
because
we (1) really have in our bones that the *use* of a URI determines what
it
actually identifies.  IOW: the use provides addressing context.

(1) 'we': Topic Map community, but I think also a substantial portion
     of knowledge representation communities in general.

Sorry again, to raise these issues on this list. While I believe that
the 
use of names (e.g. URIs) in combination with context is the superior
choice for knowledge representation, I also understand that a
knowledge representation system can only be "on the Web" if it uses
a unique addressing context.

I am bringing this up here, because I am looking for the technical
arguments/benefits for a knowledge representation system to be
"on the Web" as much as possible and, well, I expect to get the
most qualified answers on this list.

One argument I know about is that unique addressing context enables 
intermediaries to 'add-in additional information'  because they need
not deal with any addressing ambiguity of the URIs they 'see'. (Hope
I recalled that correctly). 

Are there other arguments along these lines?



> 
> > The distinction can also bee seen this way: In TM-land the author of a
> > Topic Map
> > decides in what a given URI identifies, in Web-land the controling
> > authority
> > makes this decison.

> >

> > principle or
> >   'just' a Web principle?

> I'd say the latter.  I don't recall REST talking at all about ownership,
> though it's possible some degree of that is implicit in the "meaning
> via use" aspect of REST.

Mark, do you have any pointers regarding this "meaning via use"
aspect of REST?

And, uh, to me this sounds like the exact opposite to "meaning
via authoritative assignment"...?!?!?

> 
> > - What exactly are the technical advantages of using a unique
> > addressing context
> >   when building distributes systems based on REST? Has anybody
> > analized that
> >  in detail or can help me with some pointers?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3986
Sender:<jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 13:32:01
Subject:REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Hello--

I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:

REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
information
resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
concepts.
While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be an
architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a reason for
c). IMHO,
abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems but
are
subject to knowledge representation/information management (in other
words:
subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but not
part
of the architecture itself).

Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
include
c) ?

The second question I have is related to the question what the
semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:

"REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
 semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
 than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
 time the reference is created."

To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining the
semantics of resources.  What is the precise meaning of 'author' here?
Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the author that
somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?

Thanks,

Jan

[1]
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_2


-- 
Jan Algermissen                <algermissen@...>
Consultant & Programmer

http://www.topicmapping.com
http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3987
Sender:<jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 14:04:01
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

jalgermissen@... schrieb am 01.10.2003, 15:32:01:

> Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
> include abstract concepts?

Here is another way to express my question:

I don't believe that the notion of a resource's state makes any sense
wrt abstract concepts so why would REST allow me to TRANSFER
REPRESENTATIONS OF THE STATES of cars, dogs or even believes?

While POSTing to 'presidential democracy' IMHO *obviously* makes
no sense I also have serious problems with the idea of GETing a
representation of the state of 'presidential democracy'.

So, why does REST ("REpresentational State Transfer"!) include the
notion
of abstract concepts in the definition of resource?


Somewhat confused....

Jan


-- 
Jan Algermissen                <algermissen@...>
Consultant & Programmer

http://www.topicmapping.com
http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3988
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 14:12:03
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

On Wed, Oct 01, 2003 at 09:32:01AM -0400, jalgermissen@... wrote:
> I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:
> 
> REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
> information
> resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
> concepts.
> While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be an
> architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a reason for
> c). IMHO,
> abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems but
> are
> subject to knowledge representation/information management (in other
> words:
> subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but not
> part
> of the architecture itself).
> 
> Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
> include
> c) ?

Every thing (two words 8-) is a resource.  c) is automatically included
by this definition, and to remove it would be arbitrary, and would
lessen the power of the Web.

> The second question I have is related to the question what the
> semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
> 
> "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
>  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
>  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
>  time the reference is created."
> 
> To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining the
> semantics of resources.

No, it's just that the document returned via GET doesn't have to be
100% unambiguous about what the URI identifies (and I suggest that it
couldn't be if it wanted to, but that's another topic for another day
8-).

For example, a URI that returned a picture of a clock in my house could
be used to identify the following resources;

- the current time
- that particular clock
- the largest clock in my house
- a JPG image of a clock
- an object located 6.5' above the floor in my kitchen

From an observer's POV, the URI could identify any of those if I'm
only ever returning an image from my webcam pointed at that clock.

>  What is the precise meaning of 'author' here?
> Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the author that
> somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?

Any use of the URI can contribute to its meaning.  Using the clock
example, if a bunch of people used that URI to identify "the current
time", and then my clock breaks and I decide not to fix it (I'm using
it to identify "that particular clock"), then there is, in effect, an
expectation on me to change what it identifies to what most people
think it identifies.  It's up to me whether or not I want to do that,
of course.

A great example is the SOAP 1.1 URI at W3C; http://www.w3.org/TR/SOAP/ .
The URI should be able to be used as the identifier for "the latest
W3C version of SOAP", but so many people were using it to explicitly
refer to SOAP 1.1, rather than "SOAP in general", that the W3C made an
explicit decision not to redirect that URI to SOAP 1.2 once it went Rec.
FWIW, they did redirect for HTML; http://www.w3.org/TR/html

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3989
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 14:41:02
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Jan,

The two questions are closely related.  Suppose you know I've
been renovating my house for the last 4 years, and you're interested
in that project.

Suppose I (the author) assign a URI as an identifier of the concept
"Walden's house renovation", and give you that URI.

Suppose that you use a browser or whatever to deference that URI
periodically over a span of several years.  Suppose that each time
you do so, you retrieve a different "document" in response, each one
representing at the time of dereferencing the project under study.

Note that if each document so served required its own URI, then
there would be no identity at the level of my project, only identity
of documents representing it.  That would not serve your interest in
my project as well as having an identifier that targets the project
directly.

As the "author", I assign the URI, and then manage the implementation
such that the representations all support a "sameness" of subject.  Roy
uses the word "semantic" there.

Regards,

Walden

Post ID:3990
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 15:08:07
Subject:Re: Re: [rest-discuss] Addressing context?
Message:

> > > - Is the idea that an authority controls the 'meaning of URI' a REST
> > > principle or
> > >   'just' a Web principle?

If the question is whether URIs generically have
"meaning"  outside of the context in which they
are delivered, the answer is no.

The most general URI scheme is the "data:" URI
scheme (RFC2397) which allows delivery of raw data
via URI e.g.

    data:,I%20agree%20with%20you.

Since data: URIs have no authoity but do have
meaning (via context), I think we can trivially
assert that the meaning of at least some URIs
comes from use-context rather than any authority.

If the question is whether the meaning of URIs
with authorities e.g. HTTP URIs is controlled by
those authorities, the answer is still no.
If I send you an HTTP URI that returns the
sentence "I agree with you", only context
tells you who "I" is in the sentence, not the
authority.

Alternatively, what do you mean by "meaning of a
URI"?

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3991
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 15:27:07
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

An HTTP URI simply designates a location at which
data MAY be retrieved via the HTTP protocol.
NOTHING ELSE.

If I tell you "My address is 555 Maple Drive."
The meaning of "555 Maple Drive" is not that it is
my home.  "555 Maple Drive" simply designates a
location. Whether I in fact reside at that
location is irrelevant to its meaning.

HTTP URIs are locators.  They have no other
meaning in and of themselves.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com




On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:

> Jan,
>
> The two questions are closely related.  Suppose you know I've
> been renovating my house for the last 4 years, and you're interested
> in that project.
>
> Suppose I (the author) assign a URI as an identifier of the concept
> "Walden's house renovation", and give you that URI.
>
> Suppose that you use a browser or whatever to deference that URI
> periodically over a span of several years.  Suppose that each time
> you do so, you retrieve a different "document" in response, each one
> representing at the time of dereferencing the project under study.
>
> Note that if each document so served required its own URI, then
> there would be no identity at the level of my project, only identity
> of documents representing it.  That would not serve your interest in
> my project as well as having an identifier that targets the project
> directly.
>
> As the "author", I assign the URI, and then manage the implementation
> such that the representations all support a "sameness" of subject.  Roy
> uses the word "semantic" there.
>
> Regards,
>
> Walden
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: <jalgermissen@...>
> To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 9:32 AM
> Subject: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
>
>
> :
> : Hello--
> :
> : I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:
> :
> : REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
> : information
> : resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
> : concepts.
> : While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be an
> : architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a reason for
> : c). IMHO,
> : abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems but
> : are
> : subject to knowledge representation/information management (in other
> : words:
> : subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but not
> : part
> : of the architecture itself).
> :
> : Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
> : include
> : c) ?
> :
> : The second question I have is related to the question what the
> : semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
> :
> : "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
> :  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
> :  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
> :  time the reference is created."
> :
> : To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining the
> : semantics of resources.  What is the precise meaning of 'author' here?
> : Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the author that
> : somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?
> :
> : Thanks,
> :
> : Jan
> :
> : [1]
> : http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_2
> :
> :
> : --
> : Jan Algermissen                <algermissen@...>
> : Consultant & Programmer
> :
> : http://www.topicmapping.com
> : http://www.gooseworks.org
> :
> :
> : To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> : rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
> :
> :
> :
> : Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/
> :
> :

> rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3992
Sender:<jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 15:34:01
Subject:Re: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Mark Baker <distobj@...> schrieb am 01.10.2003, 16:12:03:
> On Wed, Oct 01, 2003 at 09:32:01AM -0400, jalgermissen@... wrote:
> > I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:
> > 
> > REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
> > information
> > resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
> > concepts.
> > While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be an
> > architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a reason for
> > c). IMHO,
> > abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems but
> > are
> > subject to knowledge representation/information management (in other
> > words:
> > subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but not
> > part
> > of the architecture itself).
> > 
> > Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
> > include
> > c) ?
> 
> Every thing (two words 8-) is a resource.  c) is automatically included
> by this definition, and to remove it would be arbitrary, and would
> lessen the power of the Web.

I understand, though that does not really satisfy me....but that is
another
topic for another day ;-)

> 
> > The second question I have is related to the question what the
> > semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
> > 
> > "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
> >  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
> >  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
> >  time the reference is created."
> > 
> > To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining the
> > semantics of resources.
> 
> No, it's just that the document returned via GET doesn't have to be
> 100% unambiguous about what the URI identifies (and I suggest that it
> couldn't be if it wanted to, but that's another topic for another day
> 8-).
> 
[...]
> Any use of the URI can contribute to its meaning.  Using the clock
> example, if a bunch of people used that URI to identify "the current
> time", and then my clock breaks and I decide not to fix it (I'm using
> it to identify "that particular clock"), then there is, in effect, an
> expectation on me to change what it identifies to what most people
> think it identifies.  It's up to me whether or not I want to do that,
> of course.

Ah, interesting. This focusses on the collaborative aspect of the Web
and kind of makes it possible for the Semantic Web to grow while
still being "on the Web". Did I get that right?

OTH: is that documented somewhere? Why is there an ongoing
debate within RDF/SW about what certain URIs denote and what not?
(e.g. fragment-identifier-URIs pointing to Web pages etc.)

IOW: Is it *your* explanation/position? REST's position?  Is the
RDF/SW community aware of this view at all?

Jan

P.S. Really helpfull, thanks Mark!



-- 
Jan Algermissen                <algermissen@...>
Consultant & Programmer

http://www.topicmapping.com
http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3993
Sender:<jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 16:12:01
Subject:Re: Re: Re: [rest-discuss] Addressing context?
Message:

"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...> schrieb am 01.10.2003, 17:08:07:
> > > > - Is the idea that an authority controls the 'meaning of URI' a REST
> > > > principle or
> > > >   'just' a Web principle?

Arggr - I meant to ask:

- Is the idea that an authority controls what the semantics of a
resource
  are a REST principle or  'just' a Web principle?

Sorry.

Jan

> If the question is whether URIs generically have
> "meaning"  outside of the context in which they
> are delivered, the answer is no.
> 
> The most general URI scheme is the "data:" URI
> scheme (RFC2397) which allows delivery of raw data
> via URI e.g.
> 
>     data:,I%20agree%20with%20you.
> 
> Since data: URIs have no authoity but do have
> meaning (via context), I think we can trivially
> assert that the meaning of at least some URIs
> comes from use-context rather than any authority.
> 
> If the question is whether the meaning of URIs
> with authorities e.g. HTTP URIs is controlled by
> those authorities, the answer is still no.
> If I send you an HTTP URI that returns the
> sentence "I agree with you", only context
> tells you who "I" is in the sentence, not the
> authority.
> 
> Alternatively, what do you mean by "meaning of a
> URI"?
> 
> -Alex-
> 
> ___________________________________________________________________
> S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
> 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
> 
> 
> On Wed, 1 Oct 2003 jalgermissen@... wrote:
> 
> >
> > Mark Baker  schrieb am 01.10.2003, 04:32:37:
> > > On Mon, Sep 29, 2003 at 07:34:59AM -0400, algermissen1971 wrote:
> > > > I have understood that Web architecture is grounded in the existence
> > > > of a single,
> > > > unique addressing context (URI allways identifies resource) and
> > > > vaguely think that
> > > > I see some technical/conceptual advanteges of this, well, axiom.
> > >
> > > I hope so! 8-)
> >
> > In fact, it was rather difficult to grasp this part of Web architecture
> > because
> > we (1) really have in our bones that the *use* of a URI determines what
> > it
> > actually identifies.  IOW: the use provides addressing context.
> >
> > (1) 'we': Topic Map community, but I think also a substantial portion
> >      of knowledge representation communities in general.
> >
> > Sorry again, to raise these issues on this list. While I believe that
> > the
> > use of names (e.g. URIs) in combination with context is the superior
> > choice for knowledge representation, I also understand that a
> > knowledge representation system can only be "on the Web" if it uses
> > a unique addressing context.
> >
> > I am bringing this up here, because I am looking for the technical
> > arguments/benefits for a knowledge representation system to be
> > "on the Web" as much as possible and, well, I expect to get the
> > most qualified answers on this list.
> >
> > One argument I know about is that unique addressing context enables
> > intermediaries to 'add-in additional information'  because they need
> > not deal with any addressing ambiguity of the URIs they 'see'. (Hope
> > I recalled that correctly).
> >
> > Are there other arguments along these lines?
> >
> >
> >
> > >
> > > > The distinction can also bee seen this way: In TM-land the author of a
> > > > Topic Map
> > > > decides in what a given URI identifies, in Web-land the controling
> > > > authority
> > > > makes this decison.
> > > >
> > > > My particular questions are:
> > > >
> > > > - Is the idea that an authority controls the 'meaning of URI' a REST
> > > > principle or
> > > >   'just' a Web principle?
> > >
> > > I'd say the latter.  I don't recall REST talking at all about ownership,
> > > though it's possible some degree of that is implicit in the "meaning
> > > via use" aspect of REST.
> >
> > Mark, do you have any pointers regarding this "meaning via use"
> > aspect of REST?
> >
> > And, uh, to me this sounds like the exact opposite to "meaning
> > via authoritative assignment"...?!?!?
> >
> > >
> > > > - What exactly are the technical advantages of using a unique
> > > > addressing context
> > > >   when building distributes systems based on REST? Has anybody
> > > > analized that
> > > >  in detail or can help me with some pointers?
> > >
> > > Well, independent of REST, the benefit of global naming has been
> > > discussed for many many years.  Not that I'm very familiar with the
> > > history, but you might look up the work of Engelbart (Augment/NLS), or
> > > Nelson (Xanadu).  Sorry I can't be more specific.  I'm sure somebody
> > > here who's more familiar with hypertext would have a good pointer.
> > >
> > > Mark.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Jan
> > > --
> > > Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca

Post ID:3994
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 16:34:59
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

alex,

that may be what the http spec says, but i don't believe
that's up-to-date with the thinking that's currently going
on in the web architecture area, in which uri are *identifiers*
primarily and may also be locators, names or whatever.

identity is a key principle here, not to be eclipsed by
something you may have found in the letters of the http
spec, the language of which is not always the most fortunate
from the architecture perspective.

since the nature of Jan's question was in the REST domain,
not in the HTTP domain, if we must split hairs, then I feel
an architecturally scoped answer is more appropriate than
a purely HTTP protocol scoped answer.  But we can let Jan
decide that.

Regards,
Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
Cc: <jalgermissen@...>; <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 11:27 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource


: An HTTP URI simply designates a location at which
: data MAY be retrieved via the HTTP protocol.
: NOTHING ELSE.
:
: If I tell you "My address is 555 Maple Drive."
: The meaning of "555 Maple Drive" is not that it is
: my home.  "555 Maple Drive" simply designates a
: location. Whether I in fact reside at that
: location is irrelevant to its meaning.
:
: HTTP URIs are locators.  They have no other
: meaning in and of themselves.
:
: -Alex-
:
: ___________________________________________________________________
: S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
: 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
:
:
:
:
: On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
:
: > Jan,
: >
: > The two questions are closely related.  Suppose you know I've
: > been renovating my house for the last 4 years, and you're interested
: > in that project.
: >
: > Suppose I (the author) assign a URI as an identifier of the concept
: > "Walden's house renovation", and give you that URI.
: >
: > Suppose that you use a browser or whatever to deference that URI
: > periodically over a span of several years.  Suppose that each time
: > you do so, you retrieve a different "document" in response, each one
: > representing at the time of dereferencing the project under study.
: >
: > Note that if each document so served required its own URI, then
: > there would be no identity at the level of my project, only identity
: > of documents representing it.  That would not serve your interest in
: > my project as well as having an identifier that targets the project
: > directly.
: >
: > As the "author", I assign the URI, and then manage the implementation
: > such that the representations all support a "sameness" of subject.  Roy
: > uses the word "semantic" there.
: >
: > Regards,
: >
: > Walden
: >

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3995
Sender:Mark Baker <distobj@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 17:08:17
Subject:Re: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

On Wed, Oct 01, 2003 at 11:34:01AM -0400, jalgermissen@... wrote:
> Ah, interesting. This focusses on the collaborative aspect of the Web
> and kind of makes it possible for the Semantic Web to grow while
> still being "on the Web". Did I get that right?

I think so.  I like the way you phrased that, as if this were a feature
rather than a bug.  Nice.

> OTH: is that documented somewhere?

Not AFAICT.

> Why is there an ongoing
> debate within RDF/SW about what certain URIs denote and what not?
> (e.g. fragment-identifier-URIs pointing to Web pages etc.)

I don't think there's any one answer to that, unfortunately.
Everybody sees things slightly differently.

> IOW: Is it *your* explanation/position? REST's position?  Is the
> RDF/SW community aware of this view at all?

It's mine, and I believe it to be in synch with Roy's, but I don't
think REST-the-architectural-style talks about it.  I figure it's an
emergent property of REST, or any style in which identifiers can be
late bound to representations (i.e. pretty much every large scale
system around).

Yes, the SW community is aware of this view.  The whole "public meaning"
discussion is about it, and many involved seem to also see things this
way, at least in part.

Mark.
-- 
Mark Baker.   Ottawa, Ontario, CANADA.        http://www.markbaker.ca





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3996
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 17:40:13
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

It depends on the scheme.

HTTP URIs identify locations at which data may be
retrieved/deposited.

MD5 URIs identify data that may be located at some HTTP URI
at some point in time.

DATA URIs identify the data contained therein, data that may be
located at particular HTTP URI at some point in time and
identified by an MD5 URI at all times.

ReST is about the value of using HTTP URIs as they were intended,
as resource location identifiers, rather than as channels for
communication with RPC servers.

If current thinking is that HTTP URIs designate anything
other than a location, more thinking is probably required.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com



On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:

> :
>
>





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3997
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 18:22:48
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Alex,

I think it would be incorrect, even for HTTP scheme, to assert
that the location is necessarily the resource.

REST says resources are anything with identity, and that URI
are identifiers for them.  Period.  HTTP and other specifications
may say what they will about locations, et cetera.

What is your statement below "ReST is about..." based on?  It
sounds to me like your own interpretation, which seems to favor
a dogmatic adherence to the letter of RFC 2616, rather than
an attempt to understand what's written in the REST thesis or
other ongoing efforts to define web architecture.

Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
Cc: <jalgermissen@...>; <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 1:40 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource


: It depends on the scheme.
:
: HTTP URIs identify locations at which data may be
: retrieved/deposited.
:
: MD5 URIs identify data that may be located at some HTTP URI
: at some point in time.
:
: DATA URIs identify the data contained therein, data that may be
: located at particular HTTP URI at some point in time and
: identified by an MD5 URI at all times.
:
: ReST is about the value of using HTTP URIs as they were intended,
: as resource location identifiers, rather than as channels for
: communication with RPC servers.
:
: If current thinking is that HTTP URIs designate anything
: other than a location, more thinking is probably required.
:
: -Alex-
:
: ___________________________________________________________________
: S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
: 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
:
:
:
: On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
:
: > alex,
: >
: > that may be what the http spec says, but i don't believe
: > that's up-to-date with the thinking that's currently going
: > on in the web architecture area, in which uri are *identifiers*
: > primarily and may also be locators, names or whatever.
: >
: > identity is a key principle here, not to be eclipsed by
: > something you may have found in the letters of the http
: > spec, the language of which is not always the most fortunate
: > from the architecture perspective.
: >
: > since the nature of Jan's question was in the REST domain,
: > not in the HTTP domain, if we must split hairs, then I feel
: > an architecturally scoped answer is more appropriate than
: > a purely HTTP protocol scoped answer.  But we can let Jan
: > decide that.
: >
: > Regards,
: > Walden
: >
: > ----- Original Message -----
: > From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
: > To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
: > Cc: <jalgermissen@...>; <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
: > Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 11:27 AM
: > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
: >
: >
: > : An HTTP URI simply designates a location at which
: > : data MAY be retrieved via the HTTP protocol.
: > : NOTHING ELSE.
: > :
: > : If I tell you "My address is 555 Maple Drive."
: > : The meaning of "555 Maple Drive" is not that it is
: > : my home.  "555 Maple Drive" simply designates a
: > : location. Whether I in fact reside at that
: > : location is irrelevant to its meaning.
: > :
: > : HTTP URIs are locators.  They have no other
: > : meaning in and of themselves.
: > :
: > : -Alex-
: > :
: > : ___________________________________________________________________
: > : S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
: > : 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
: > :
: > :
: > :
: > :
: > : On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
: > :
: > : > Jan,
: > : >
: > : > The two questions are closely related.  Suppose you know I've
: > : > been renovating my house for the last 4 years, and you're interested
: > : > in that project.
: > : >
: > : > Suppose I (the author) assign a URI as an identifier of the concept
: > : > "Walden's house renovation", and give you that URI.
: > : >
: > : > Suppose that you use a browser or whatever to deference that URI
: > : > periodically over a span of several years.  Suppose that each time
: > : > you do so, you retrieve a different "document" in response, each one
: > : > representing at the time of dereferencing the project under study.
: > : >
: > : > Note that if each document so served required its own URI, then
: > : > there would be no identity at the level of my project, only identity
: > : > of documents representing it.  That would not serve your interest in
: > : > my project as well as having an identifier that targets the project
: > : > directly.
: > : >
: > : > As the "author", I assign the URI, and then manage the
implementation
: > : > such that the representations all support a "sameness" of subject.
Roy
: > : > uses the word "semantic" there.
: > : >
: > : > Regards,
: > : >
: > : > Walden
: > : >
: > : > ----- Original Message -----
: > : > From: <jalgermissen@...>
: > : > To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
: > : > Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 9:32 AM
: > : > Subject: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
: > : >
: > : >
: > : > :
: > : > : Hello--
: > : > :
: > : > : I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:
: > : > :
: > : > : REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
: > : > : information
: > : > : resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
: > : > : concepts.
: > : > : While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be
an
: > : > : architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a
reason
: > for
: > : > : c). IMHO,
: > : > : abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems
but
: > : > : are
: > : > : subject to knowledge representation/information management (in
other
: > : > : words:
: > : > : subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but
not
: > : > : part
: > : > : of the architecture itself).
: > : > :
: > : > : Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource'
to
: > : > : include
: > : > : c) ?
: > : > :
: > : > : The second question I have is related to the question what the
: > : > : semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
: > : > :
: > : > : "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
: > : > :  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
: > : > :  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
: > : > :  time the reference is created."
: > : > :
: > : > : To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining
the
: > : > : semantics of resources.  What is the precise meaning of 'author'
here?
: > : > : Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the author
that
: > : > : somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?
: > : > :
: > : > : Thanks,
: > : > :
: > : > : Jan
: > : > :
: > : > : [1]
: > : > :
: >
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_2

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3998
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 19:28:20
Subject:Paper: Powerful Web Services Through Composition
Message:

I've written a new paper: "Powerful Web Services Through
Composition".  The paper's description is:

"This document shows how the web-calculus is derived from the
REST architectural model that underlies the World Wide Web (WWW).
The advantages of this approach to web services are highlighted."

The paper covers the material from my presentation at HP Labs a
few weeks ago. The paper and the talk explain why the web-calculus
is a good approach to web services.

I hope this paper will better communicate why I am working on the
web-calculus, and encourage others to as well.

I am thinking of submitting this paper to CACM, so I look forward
to any feedback.

Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3999
Sender:Tyler Close <tyler@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 19:29:29
Subject:Re: Paper: Powerful Web Services Through Composition
Message:

The URL is:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/REST/

Tyler

On Wednesday 01 October 2003 15:28, Tyler Close wrote:
> I've written a new paper: "Powerful Web Services Through
> Composition".  The paper's description is:
>
> "This document shows how the web-calculus is derived from the
> REST architectural model that underlies the World Wide Web (WWW).
> The advantages of this approach to web services are highlighted."
>
> The paper covers the material from my presentation at HP Labs a
> few weeks ago. The paper and the talk explain why the web-calculus
> is a good approach to web services.
>
> I hope this paper will better communicate why I am working on the
> web-calculus, and encourage others to as well.
>
> I am thinking of submitting this paper to CACM, so I look forward
> to any feedback.
>
> Tyler





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4000
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 20:30:08
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

> I think it would be incorrect, even for HTTP scheme, to assert
> that the location is necessarily the resource.

There is only one HTTP URI scheme, the HTTP
Uniform Resource Locator as defined in (rfc2616).

I would agree that server operators *should* avoid
changing what resources are found via particular
URLs but I think it is a mistake to say that they
are guaranteed to do so -- there are way too many
404s found via Google.  Would you sign a
contract that requires you to abide by the terms
of a document "identified" by a URL you don't
control?

Applied to HTTP, ReST stlye is about transferring
representations of the state of resources found
via HTTP URL's rather than e.g. transferring
representations of procedure calls to and
return-values from RPC servers.

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4001
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-01 21:46:31
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Alex,

I don't know where you are going with this, but it
doesn't sound like REST to me.  I think it's now pretty
far afield of Jan's question, and likely to be of no
value to continue.

Summary:

REST (re-) defines resources to include abstract
concepts because users of the system sometimes find
identity in abstraction.  In other words, they want it
to be that way.  They want the level of indirection and
late binding that allows representations to track a
single concept over time.  'Resource' is just the name
of a relationship that binds those representations into
single identity, the thing of interest.

Walden


----- Original Message ----- 
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
Cc: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 4:30 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource


: > I think it would be incorrect, even for HTTP scheme, to assert
: > that the location is necessarily the resource.
:
: There is only one HTTP URI scheme, the HTTP
: Uniform Resource Locator as defined in (rfc2616).
:
: I would agree that server operators *should* avoid
: changing what resources are found via particular
: URLs but I think it is a mistake to say that they
: are guaranteed to do so -- there are way too many
: 404s found via Google.  Would you sign a
: contract that requires you to abide by the terms
: of a document "identified" by a URL you don't
: control?
:
: Applied to HTTP, ReST stlye is about transferring
: representations of the state of resources found
: via HTTP URL's rather than e.g. transferring
: representations of procedure calls to and
: return-values from RPC servers.
:
: -Alex-

: > : > : If I tell you "My address is 555 Maple Drive."
: > : > : The meaning of "555 Maple Drive" is not that it is
: > : > : my home.  "555 Maple Drive" simply designates a
: > : > : location. Whether I in fact reside at that
: > : > : location is irrelevant to its meaning.
: > : > :
: > : > : HTTP URIs are locators.  They have no other
: > : > : meaning in and of themselves.
: > : > :
: > : > : -Alex-
: > : > :
: > : > :
___________________________________________________________________
: > : > : S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new
blog!!!
: > : > : 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
: > : > :
: > : > :
: > : > :
: > : > :
: > : > : On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
: > : > :
: > : > : > Jan,
: > : > : >
: > : > : > The two questions are closely related.  Suppose you know I've
: > : > : > been renovating my house for the last 4 years, and you're
interested
: > : > : > in that project.
: > : > : >
: > : > : > Suppose I (the author) assign a URI as an identifier of the
concept
: > : > : > "Walden's house renovation", and give you that URI.
: > : > : >
: > : > : > Suppose that you use a browser or whatever to deference that URI
: > : > : > periodically over a span of several years.  Suppose that each
time
: > : > : > you do so, you retrieve a different "document" in response, each
one
: > : > : > representing at the time of dereferencing the project under
study.
: > : > : >
: > : > : > Note that if each document so served required its own URI, then
: > : > : > there would be no identity at the level of my project, only
identity
: > : > : > of documents representing it.  That would not serve your
interest in
: > : > : > my project as well as having an identifier that targets the
project
: > : > : > directly.
: > : > : >
: > : > : > As the "author", I assign the URI, and then manage the
: > implementation
: > : > : > such that the representations all support a "sameness" of
subject.
: > Roy
: > : > : > uses the word "semantic" there.
: > : > : >
: > : > : > Regards,
: > : > : >
: > : > : > Walden
: > : > : >
: > : > : > ----- Original Message -----
: > : > : > From: <jalgermissen@...>
: > : > : > To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
: > : > : > Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 9:32 AM
: > : > : > Subject: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
: > : > : >
: > : > : >
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : Hello--
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of
resource:
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
: > : > : > : information
: > : > : > : resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b)
abstract
: > : > : > : concepts.
: > : > : > : While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST
to be
: > an
: > : > : > : architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a
: > reason
: > : > for
: > : > : > : c). IMHO,
: > : > : > : abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed
systems
: > but
: > : > : > : are
: > : > : > : subject to knowledge representation/information management (in
: > other
: > : > : > : words:
: > : > : > : subject to possible applications of the architectural style,
but
: > not
: > : > : > : part
: > : > : > : of the architecture itself).
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines
'resource'
: > to
: > : > : > : include
: > : > : > : c) ?
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : The second question I have is related to the question what the
: > : > : > : semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
: > : > : > :  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
: > : > : > :  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
: > : > : > :  time the reference is created."
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities
defining
: > the
: > : > : > : semantics of resources.  What is the precise meaning of
'author'
: > here?
: > : > : > : Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the
author
: > that
: > : > : > : somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : Thanks,
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : Jan
: > : > : > :
: > : > : > : [1]
: > : > : > :
: > : >
: >
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_2

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4002
Sender:"Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-02 00:04:37
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

> I don't believe that the notion of a resource's state makes any sense
> wrt abstract concepts so why would REST allow me to TRANSFER
> REPRESENTATIONS OF THE STATES of cars, dogs or even believes?

How do you think about abstract concepts like "3"?  Do you think of
it symbolically (the glyph) or numerically?  If you need to explain
to someone the algorithm for calculating the area of a circle, how
do you do that?  Those are all representations.

> While POSTing to 'presidential democracy' IMHO *obviously* makes
> no sense I also have serious problems with the idea of GETing a
> representation of the state of 'presidential democracy'.

Then don't provide one.  There is no requirement that all resources
have representations.

> So, why does REST ("REpresentational State Transfer"!) include the
> notion of abstract concepts in the definition of resource?

Because they are resources.

....Roy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4003
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-02 06:52:33
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Please bear with me....I get the impression that
there are a number of implicit ideas about REST that
I have been completely missing so far.

More questions....


I actually thought that REST is 'purely technical', an architecture
for distributed systems. (in that sense, for example, directly
comparable to Corba).

OTH, what Roy said in his last reply suggests that REST is also
considered with knowledge representation issues. Is that correct?


If so:
A fundamental concept in knowledge representation is to provide
surrogates for real-world subjects in order to provide 'electronic
handles' for making assertions about the real-world things. Is
this thinking within the realm of REST itself?

If so:
Are URIs intended to be these surrogates?


Might seem like an awkward way to approach this, but it will
help me understand.

Thanks.

Jan

--

Consultant & Programmer	                  http://www.gooseworks.org

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4005
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-02 12:18:44
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Walden Mathews wrote:
> 
> Jan,
> :
> : OTH, what Roy said in his last reply suggests that REST is also
> : considered with knowledge representation issues. Is that correct?
> :
> 
> I have trouble extracting a clear interpretation from "considered with
> knowledge representation issues".  Could you make that more explicit,
> maybe with reference to specific words Roy used?

What I mean is if REST goes beyond the technical aspects of distributed
systems?

Roy wrote:

"How do you think about abstract concepts like "3"?  Do you think of
it symbolically (the glyph) or numerically?  If you need to explain
to someone the algorithm for calculating the area of a circle, how
do you do that?  Those are all representations."

If REST is only about the technical aspects (e.g. how messages are
transferred, how interfaces are contrained) then what Roy writes is
IMHO outside the scope of REST. 

Put in another way: in what sense is what Roy writes relevant for
an architectural style for distributed systems?

To mw, what Roy says, are aspects of a possible application of REST
but not REST itself.

So, what am I missing?


Jan
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Walden

Jan Algermissen                           http://www.topicmapping.com
Consultant & Programmer	                  http://www.gooseworks.org





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4006
Sender:Walden Mathews <waldenm@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-02 14:15:04
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Jan,

I don't think it would ever be correct to say that "REST [or
any architectural style, for that matter] is only about the technical
aspects...".  The purpose of studying architectural styles is so
that we can reason about the properties of the system.

In this case, there are two properties driving the definition of
"resource" within the REST style:

(1) consistency of reference.  When you say "GET the algorithm
for computing the area of a circle" or "GET the current weather
in Norwalk", you want those requests to have consistent semantics
over time.  Even if the particular answers vary.

(2) scaleability.  One way to achieve that consistency is to let
identifiers identify representations, and rely on centralized link services
to
track state changes.  Every time the current weather in Norwalk
changed, a new document and a new identifier would have to be
minted, and all existing documents with a reference to Norwalk
weather would need their links updated, the overall cost of the operation
being commensurate with the total number of such links.  The other,
more scaleable, way to achieve that is to do what REST does:

"""
Traditional hypertext systems [61], which typically operate in a closed or
local environment, use unique node or document identifiers that change every
time the information changes, relying on link servers to maintain references
separately from the content [135]. Since centralized link servers are an
anathema to the immense scale and multi-organizational domain requirements
of the Web, REST relies instead on the author choosing a resource identifier
that best fits the nature of the concept being identified. Naturally, the
quality of an identifier is often proportional to the amount of money spent
to retain its validity, which leads to broken links as ephemeral (or poorly
supported) information moves or disappears over time.
"""

I don't think REST seeks to be a framework for knowledge
representation or semantics.  I think the requirements above led
to its definition being inevitably "conceptual".

REST "resource" is unlike any other architectural component
I am aware of in this sense.  A "filter" component in a pipe &
filter style makes promises about the consistency and relative
statelessness of the transform, but not any semantic consistency
of the output.

In modeling REST formally, you can remove "resource" from
the picture without harming the purely technical aspects of the
system.  What you then end up with is a many-to-many relation
from URI to representations.  Perhaps that's all the Web *really*
is, but it's hard to find any guidance in the building of useful
systems in that.  Put another way, it's hard to decide what value
such a system might be providing.

Interesting topic.

Walden

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4007
Sender:Jan Algermissen <jalgermissen@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-02 14:59:35
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
Message:

Walden Mathews wrote:

> 
> REST (re-) defines resources to include abstract
> concepts because users of the system sometimes find
> identity in abstraction.  In other words, they want it
> to be that way.  They want the level of indirection and
> late binding that allows representations to track a
> single concept over time.  

Hmm, I see some light I think.

Do you argue that resource is (re-) defined the way it is
on the basis of *observation*? 

To put this in other words: *Because* users are using URIs to
identify abstract concepts REST defines resource to include them?

Yet other words: The definition of resource is the result of
observation and not the result of, uhh, the process of 'engineering'
REST?  An *observation* not a *design decision*?

That would clarify a *lot*.


What I have allways thought is that keeping the unique addressing context
*forced* REST to include abstract concepts in the definition of resource
(*although* this is really awkward from the knowledge representation POV [1])


Jan

[1] Because it is the cause for the URI/meaning etc. trouble. 
    (To be clear: I am not trying to criticise REST, I am trying to
     understand its origin and implications)





> 'Resource' is just the name
> of a relationship that binds those representations into
> single identity, the thing of interest.
> 
> Walden
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
> Cc: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 4:30 PM
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
> 
> : > I think it would be incorrect, even for HTTP scheme, to assert
> : > that the location is necessarily the resource.
> :
> : There is only one HTTP URI scheme, the HTTP
> : Uniform Resource Locator as defined in (rfc2616).
> :
> : I would agree that server operators *should* avoid
> : changing what resources are found via particular
> : URLs but I think it is a mistake to say that they
> : are guaranteed to do so -- there are way too many
> : 404s found via Google.  Would you sign a
> : contract that requires you to abide by the terms
> : of a document "identified" by a URL you don't
> : control?
> :
> : Applied to HTTP, ReST stlye is about transferring
> : representations of the state of resources found
> : via HTTP URL's rather than e.g. transferring
> : representations of procedure calls to and
> : return-values from RPC servers.
> :
> : -Alex-
> :
> : ___________________________________________________________________
> : S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
> : 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> :
> : On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
> :
> : > Alex,
> : >
> : >
> : > REST says resources are anything with identity, and that URI
> : > are identifiers for them.  Period.  HTTP and other specifications
> : > may say what they will about locations, et cetera.
> : >
> : > What is your statement below "ReST is about..." based on?  It
> : > sounds to me like your own interpretation, which seems to favor
> : > a dogmatic adherence to the letter of RFC 2616, rather than
> : > an attempt to understand what's written in the REST thesis or
> : > other ongoing efforts to define web architecture.
> : >
> : > Walden
> : >
> : > ----- Original Message -----
> : > From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> : > To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
> : > Cc: <jalgermissen@...>; <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> : > Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 1:40 PM
> : > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
> : >
> : >
> : > : It depends on the scheme.
> : > :
> : > : HTTP URIs identify locations at which data may be
> : > : retrieved/deposited.
> : > :
> : > : MD5 URIs identify data that may be located at some HTTP URI
> : > : at some point in time.
> : > :
> : > : DATA URIs identify the data contained therein, data that may be
> : > : located at particular HTTP URI at some point in time and
> : > : identified by an MD5 URI at all times.
> : > :
> : > : ReST is about the value of using HTTP URIs as they were intended,
> : > : as resource location identifiers, rather than as channels for
> : > : communication with RPC servers.
> : > :
> : > : If current thinking is that HTTP URIs designate anything
> : > : other than a location, more thinking is probably required.
> : > :
> : > : -Alex-
> : > :
> : > : ___________________________________________________________________
> : > : S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
> : > : 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
> : > :
> : > :
> : > :
> : > : On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
> : > :
> : > : > alex,
> : > : >
> : > : > that may be what the http spec says, but i don't believe
> : > : > that's up-to-date with the thinking that's currently going
> : > : > on in the web architecture area, in which uri are *identifiers*
> : > : > primarily and may also be locators, names or whatever.
> : > : >
> : > : > identity is a key principle here, not to be eclipsed by
> : > : > something you may have found in the letters of the http
> : > : > spec, the language of which is not always the most fortunate
> : > : > from the architecture perspective.
> : > : >
> : > : > since the nature of Jan's question was in the REST domain,
> : > : > not in the HTTP domain, if we must split hairs, then I feel
> : > : > an architecturally scoped answer is more appropriate than
> : > : > a purely HTTP protocol scoped answer.  But we can let Jan
> : > : > decide that.
> : > : >
> : > : > Regards,
> : > : > Walden
> : > : >
> : > : > ----- Original Message -----
> : > : > From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> : > : > To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
> : > : > Cc: <jalgermissen@...>; <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> : > : > Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 11:27 AM
> : > : > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
> : > : >
> : > : >
> : > : > : An HTTP URI simply designates a location at which
> : > : > : data MAY be retrieved via the HTTP protocol.
> : > : > : NOTHING ELSE.
> : > : > :
> : > : > : If I tell you "My address is 555 Maple Drive."
> : > : > : The meaning of "555 Maple Drive" is not that it is
> : > : > : my home.  "555 Maple Drive" simply designates a
> : > : > : location. Whether I in fact reside at that
> : > : > : location is irrelevant to its meaning.
> : > : > :
> : > : > : HTTP URIs are locators.  They have no other
> : > : > : meaning in and of themselves.
> : > : > :
> : > : > : -Alex-
> : > : > :

> interest in
> : > : > : > my project as well as having an identifier that targets the
> project
> : > : > : > directly.
> : > : > : >

> : > implementation

> : > : > : > : Hello--
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of
> resource:
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
> : > : > : > : information
> : > : > : > : resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b)
> abstract
> : > : > : > : concepts.
> : > : > : > : While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST
> to be
> : > an
> : > : > : > : architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a
> : > reason
> : > : > for
> : > : > : > : c). IMHO,
> : > : > : > : abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed

> : > : > : > : are
> : > : > : > : subject to knowledge representation/information management (in
> : > other

> but
> : > not
> : > : > : > : part
> : > : > : > : of the architecture itself).
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines
> 'resource'
> : > to
> : > : > : > : include
> : > : > : > : c) ?
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : The second question I have is related to the question what the
> : > : > : > : semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
> : > : > : > :  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
> : > : > : > :  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
> : > : > : > :  time the reference is created."
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities
> defining
> : > the
> : > : > : > : semantics of resources.  What is the precise meaning of
> 'author'
> : > here?
> : > : > : > : Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the
> author
> : > that
> : > : > : > : somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?
> : > : > : > :
> : > : > : > : Thanks,
> : > : > : > :

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4008
Sender:"S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
Post Date/Time:2003-10-02 15:25:24
Subject:Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource (fwd)
Message:

Jan,

HTTP says that URLs are simply addresses for resources.

REST is an architectural style in which each URL maps to a the current
instances of the some concept e.g. the current issue of the newspaper or
the current state of Walden's house, or the October 1, 2003 issue of the
newspaper (this is the current instance of the 10/1/2003 newspaper).

Of course since the content varies, this begs the question of how you as
the user of such a resource know what concept is being instantiated and
represented at a particular URL.  And the answer is the communication
context in which the URL was delivered.

Roy's paper is relatively silent on this communication context other than
to say that it is supplied by the world wide web.

Personally, I prefer to collapse this division and view URLs in terms of a
set of commitments other parties make about the content available at a
resource and their abilities to uphold those commitments.  I prefer to
think of content located by a URLs as being the result of some party's PUT,
POST, or DELETE and avoid the trap into which many REST oriented developers
fall of exposing hidden representations

-Alex-

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com


--On Thursday, October 02, 2003 2:18 PM +0200 Jan Algermissen
<jalgermissen@...> wrote:

> Walden Mathews wrote:
>>
>> Jan,
>> :
>> : OTH, what Roy said in his last reply suggests that REST is also
>> : considered with knowledge representation issues. Is that correct?
>> :
>>
>> I have trouble extracting a clear interpretation from "considered with
>> knowledge representation issues".  Could you make that more explicit,
>> maybe with reference to specific words Roy used?
>
> What I mean is if REST goes beyond the technical aspects of distributed
> systems?
>
> Roy wrote:
>
> "How do you think about abstract concepts like "3"?  Do you think of
> it symbolically (the glyph) or numerically?  If you need to explain
> to someone the algorithm for calculating the area of a circle, how
> do you do that?  Those are all representations."
>
> If REST is only about the technical aspects (e.g. how messages are
> transferred, how interfaces are contrained) then what Roy writes is
> IMHO outside the scope of REST.
>
> Put in another way: in what sense is what Roy writes relevant for
> an architectural style for distributed systems?
>
> To mw, what Roy says, are aspects of a possible application of REST
> but not REST itself.
>
> So, what am I missing?
>
>
